BOOK
<EOS>
THE
FIRST
<EOS>
—
THE
PLOTTheir
searches
are
many
and
severe
.
<EOS>
They
come
either
in
the
night
or
early
in
the
morning
,
and
ever
seek
their
opportunity
,
when
the
Catholics
are
or
would
be
best
occupied
,
or
are
likely
to
be
worse
provided
or
look
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
They
willingliest
come
when
few
are
at
home
to
resist
them
,
that
they
may
rifle
coffers
,
and
do
what
they
list
.
<EOS>
They
lock
up
the
servants
,
and
the
mistress
of
the
house
,
and
the
whole
family
,
in
a
room
by
themselves
,
while
they
,
like
young
princes
,
go
rifling
the
house
at
their
will
.
<EOS>
Letter
to
Verstegan
,
ap
.
<EOS>
Stonyhurst
<EOS>
MSS.What
a
thing
is
it
for
a
Catholic
gentleman
to
have
his
house
suddenly
beset
on
all
sides
with
a
number
of
men
in
arms
,
both
horse
and
foot
!
<EOS>
and
not
only
his
house
and
gardens
,
and
such
enclosed
places
all
beset
,
but
all
highways
laid
,
for
some
miles
near
unto
him
,
that
none
shall
pass
,
but
they
shall
be
examined
!
<EOS>
Then
are
these
searchers
oft
-
times
so
rude
and
barbarous
,
that
,
if
the
doors
be
not
opened
in
the
instant
they
would
enter
,
they
break
open
the
doors
with
all
violence
,
as
if
they
were
to
sack
a
town
of
enemies
won
by
the
sword
.
<EOS>
Father
Gerard
's
MS.I.
—
AN
EXECUTION
IN
MANCHESTER
,
<EOS>
AT
<EOS>
THE
BEGINNING
OF
THE
SEVENTEENTH
<EOS>
CENTURYMore
than
two
hundred
and
thirty
-
five
years
ago
,
or
,
to
speak
with
greater
precision
,
in
1605
,
at
the
latter
end
of
June
<EOS>
,
it
was
rumoured
one
morning
in
Manchester
that
two
seminary
priests
,
condemned
at
the
late
assizes
under
the
severe
penal
enactments
then
in
force
against
the
Papists
,
were
about
to
suffer
death
on
that
day
.
<EOS>
Attracted
by
the
report
,
large
crowds
flocked
towards
the
place
of
execution
,
which
,
in
order
to
give
greater
solemnity
to
the
spectacle
,
had
been
fixed
at
the
southern
gate
of
the
old
Collegiate
Church
,
where
a
scaffold
was
erected
.
<EOS>
Near
it
was
a
large
blood
-
stained
block
,
the
use
of
which
will
be
readily
divined
,
and
adjoining
the
block
,
upon
a
heap
of
blazing
coals
,
smoked
a
caldron
filled
with
boiling
pitch
,
intended
to
receive
the
quarters
of
the
miserable
sufferers
.
<EOS>
The
place
was
guarded
by
a
small
band
of
soldiers
,
fully
accoutred
in
corslets
and
morions
,
and
armed
with
swords
,
half
-
pikes
,
and
calivers
.
<EOS>
Upon
the
steps
of
the
scaffold
stood
the
executioner,—a
square
-
built
,
ill
-
favoured
personage
,
busied
in
arranging
a
bundle
of
straw
upon
the
boards
.
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
a
buff
jerkin
,
and
had
a
long
-
bladed
,
two
-
edged
knife
thrust
into
his
girdle
.
<EOS>
Besides
these
persons
,
there
was
a
pursuivant,—an
officer
appointed
by
the
Privy
Council
to
make
search
throughout
the
provinces
for
recusants
,
Popish
priests
,
and
other
religious
offenders
.
<EOS>
He
was
occupied
at
this
moment
in
reading
over
a
list
of
suspected
persons
.
<EOS>
Neither
the
executioner
nor
his
companions
appeared
in
the
slightest
degree
impressed
by
the
butcherly
business
about
to
be
enacted
;
for
the
former
whistled
carelessly
as
he
pursued
his
task
,
while
the
latter
laughed
and
chatted
with
the
crowd
,
or
jestingly
pointed
their
matchlocks
at
the
jackdaws
wheeling
above
them
in
the
sunny
air
,
or
perching
upon
the
pinnacles
and
tower
of
the
neighbouring
fane
.
<EOS>
Not
so
the
majority
of
the
assemblage
.
<EOS>
Most
of
the
older
and
wealthier
families
in
Lancashire
still
continuing
to
adhere
to
the
ancient
faith
of
their
fathers
,
it
will
not
be
wondered
that
many
of
their
dependents
should
follow
their
example
.
<EOS>
And
,
even
of
those
who
were
adverse
to
the
creed
of
Rome
,
there
were
few
who
did
not
murmur
at
the
rigorous
system
of
persecution
adopted
towards
its
professors
.
<EOS>
At
nine
o'clock
,
the
hollow
rolling
of
a
muffled
drum
was
heard
at
a
distance
.
<EOS>
The
deep
bell
of
the
church
began
to
toll
,
and
presently
afterwards
the
mournful
procession
was
seen
advancing
from
the
market
-
place
.
<EOS>
It
consisted
of
a
troop
of
mounted
soldiers
,
equipped
in
all
respects
like
those
stationed
at
the
scaffold
,
with
their
captain
at
their
head
,
and
followed
by
two
of
their
number
with
hurdles
attached
to
their
steeds
,
on
which
were
tied
the
unfortunate
victims
.
<EOS>
Both
were
young
men
—
both
apparently
prepared
to
meet
their
fate
with
firmness
and
resignation
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
brought
from
Radcliffe
Hall
—
an
old
moated
and
fortified
mansion
belonging
to
a
wealthy
family
of
that
name
,
situated
where
the
close
,
called
Pool
Fold
,
now
stands
,
and
then
recently
converted
into
a
place
of
security
for
recusants
;
the
two
other
prisons
in
Manchester
—
namely
,
the
New
Fleet
on
Hunt
's
Bank
,
and
the
gaol
on
Salford
Bridge,—not
being
found
adequate
to
the
accommodation
of
the
numerous
religious
offenders
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
cavalcade
had
reached
the
place
of
execution
.
<EOS>
The
soldiers
drove
back
the
throng
with
their
pikes
,
and
cleared
a
space
in
front
of
the
scaffold
;
when
,
just
as
the
cords
that
bound
the
limbs
of
the
priests
were
unfastened
,
a
woman
in
a
tattered
woollen
robe
,
with
a
hood
partially
drawn
over
her
face,—the
features
of
which
,
so
far
as
they
could
be
discerned
,
were
sharp
and
attenuated,—a
rope
girded
round
her
waist
,
bare
feet
,
and
having
altogether
the
appearance
of
a
sister
of
Charity
,
sprang
forward
,
and
flung
herself
on
her
knees
beside
them
.
<EOS>
Clasping
the
hem
of
the
garment
of
the
nearest
priest
,
she
pressed
it
to
her
lips
,
and
gazed
earnestly
at
him
,
as
if
imploring
a
blessing
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
have
your
wish
,
daughter
,
"
said
the
priest
,
extending
his
arms
over
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Heaven
and
our
lady
bless
you!"The
<EOS>
woman
then
turned
towards
the
other
victim
,
who
was
audibly
reciting
the
Miserere
.
<EOS>
"Back
,
spawn
of
Antichrist
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
a
soldier
,
rudely
thrusting
her
aside
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
see
you
disturb
the
father
's
devotions
?
<EOS>
He
has
enough
to
do
to
take
care
of
his
own
soul
,
without
minding
yours
.
<EOS>
""Take
this
,
daughter
,
"
cried
the
priest
who
had
been
first
addressed
,
offering
her
a
small
volume
,
which
he
took
from
his
vest
,
"
and
fail
not
to
remember
in
your
prayers
the
sinful
soul
of
Robert
Woodroofe
,
a
brother
of
the
order
of
Jesus
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
woman
put
out
her
hand
to
take
the
book
;
but
before
it
could
be
delivered
to
her
,
it
was
seized
by
the
soldier
.
<EOS>
"Your
<EOS>
priests
have
seldom
anything
to
leave
behind
them
,
"
he
shouted
,
with
a
brutal
laugh
,
"
except
some
worthless
and
superstitious
relic
of
a
saint
or
martyr
.
<EOS>
What
's
this
?
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
a
breviary
—
a
mass
-
book
.
<EOS>
I
've
too
much
regard
for
your
spiritual
welfare
to
allow
you
to
receive
it
,
"
he
added
,
about
to
place
it
in
his
doublet
.
<EOS>
"Give
it
her
,
"
exclaimed
a
young
man
,
snatching
it
from
him
,
and
handing
it
to
the
woman
,
who
disappeared
as
soon
as
she
had
obtained
possession
of
it
.
<EOS>
The
soldier
eyed
the
new
-
comer
as
if
disposed
to
resent
the
interference
,
but
a
glance
at
his
apparel
,
which
,
though
plain
,
and
of
a
sober
hue
,
was
rather
above
the
middle
class
,
as
well
as
a
murmur
from
the
crowd
,
who
were
evidently
disposed
to
take
part
with
the
young
man
,
induced
him
to
stay
his
hand
.
<EOS>
He
,
therefore
,
contented
himself
with
crying
,
"
A
recusant
!
<EOS>
a
Papist!""I
am
neither
recusant
nor
Papist
,
knave
!
<EOS>
"
replied
the
other
,
sternly
;
"
and
I
counsel
you
to
mend
your
manners
,
and
show
more
humanity
,
or
you
shall
find
I
have
interest
enough
to
procure
your
dismissal
from
a
service
which
you
disgrace
.
<EOS>
"This
reply
elicited
a
shout
of
applause
from
the
mob
.
<EOS>
"Who
<EOS>
is
that
bold
speaker
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
pursuivant
from
one
of
his
attendants
.
<EOS>
"Humphrey
<EOS>
Chetham
of
Crumpsall
,
"
answered
the
man
:
"
son
to
one
of
the
wealthiest
merchants
of
the
town
,
and
a
zealous
upholder
of
the
true
faith
.
<EOS>
""He
has
a
strange
way
of
showing
his
zeal
,
"
rejoined
the
pursuivant
,
entering
the
answer
in
his
note
-
book
.
"
<EOS>
And
who
is
the
woman
he
befriended?""A
half
-
crazed
being
called
Elizabeth
Orton
,
"
replied
the
attendant
.
<EOS>
"
She
was
scourged
and
tortured
during
Queen
Elizabeth
's
reign
for
pretending
to
the
gift
of
prophecy
,
and
was
compelled
to
utter
her
recantation
within
yonder
church
.
<EOS>
Since
then
she
has
never
opened
her
lips
.
<EOS>
""Indeed
,
"
exclaimed
the
pursuivant
:
"
I
will
engage
to
make
her
speak
,
and
to
some
purpose
.
<EOS>
Where
does
she
live?""In
a
cave
on
the
banks
of
the
Irwell
,
near
Ordsall
Hall
,
"
replied
the
attendant
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
subsists
on
the
chance
contributions
of
the
charitable
;
but
she
solicits
nothing,—and
,
indeed
,
is
seldom
seen
.
<EOS>
""Her
<EOS>
cave
must
be
searched
,
"
observed
the
pursuivant
;
"
it
may
be
the
hiding
-
place
of
a
priest
.
<EOS>
Father
Campion
was
concealed
in
such
another
spot
at
Stonor
Park
,
near
Henley
-
on
-
Thames
,
where
he
composed
his
'
Decem
Rationes
;
'
and
,
for
a
long
time
,
eluded
the
vigilance
of
the
commissioners
.
<EOS>
We
shall
pass
it
in
our
way
to
Ordsall
Hall
to
-
night
,
shall
we
not?"The
attendant
nodded
in
the
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"If
we
surprise
Father
Oldcorne
,
"
continued
the
pursuivant
,
"
and
can
prove
that
Sir
William
Radcliffe
and
his
daughter
,
both
of
whom
are
denounced
in
my
list
,
are
harbourers
and
shelterers
of
recusants
,
we
shall
have
done
a
good
night
's
work
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
this
moment
,
an
officer
advanced
,
and
commanded
the
priests
to
ascend
the
scaffold
.
<EOS>
As
Father
Woodroofe
,
who
was
the
last
to
mount
,
reached
the
uppermost
step
,
he
turned
round
and
cried
in
a
loud
voice
,
"
<EOS>
Good
people
,
I
take
you
all
to
witness
that
I
die
in
the
true
Catholic
religion
,
and
that
I
rejoice
and
thank
God
with
all
my
soul
,
that
he
hath
made
me
worthy
to
testify
my
faith
therein
by
shedding
my
blood
in
this
manner
.
"
<EOS>
He
then
advanced
towards
the
executioner
,
who
was
busied
in
adjusting
the
cord
round
his
companion
's
throat
,
and
said
,
"
God
forgive
thee
—
do
thine
office
quickly
;
"
adding
in
a
lower
tone
,
"
Asperge
me
,
Domine
;
Domine
,
miserere
mei!"And
,
amid
the
deep
silence
that
ensued
,
the
executioner
performed
his
horrible
task
.
<EOS>
The
execution
over
,
the
crowd
began
to
separate
slowly
,
and
various
opinions
were
expressed
respecting
the
revolting
and
sanguinary
spectacle
just
witnessed
.
<EOS>
Many
,
who
condemned
—
and
the
majority
did
so
—
the
extreme
severity
of
the
laws
by
which
the
unfortunate
priests
had
just
suffered
,
uttered
their
sentiments
with
extreme
caution
;
but
there
were
some
whose
feelings
had
been
too
much
excited
for
prudence
,
and
who
inveighed
loudly
and
bitterly
against
the
spirit
of
religious
persecution
then
prevailing
;
while
a
few
others
of
an
entirely
opposite
persuasion
looked
upon
the
rigorous
proceedings
adopted
against
the
Papists
,
and
the
punishment
now
inflicted
upon
their
priesthood
,
as
a
just
retribution
for
their
own
severities
during
the
reign
of
Mary
.
<EOS>
In
general
,
the
common
people
entertained
a
strong
prejudice
against
the
Catholic
party,—for
,
as
it
has
been
shrewdly
observed
,
"
they
must
have
some
object
to
hate
;
heretofore
it
was
the
Welsh
,
the
Scots
,
or
the
Spaniards
,
but
now
in
these
latter
times
only
the
Papists
;
"
but
in
Manchester
,
near
which
,
as
has
been
already
stated
,
so
many
old
and
important
families
,
professing
that
religion
,
resided
<EOS>
,
the
case
was
widely
different
;
and
the
mass
of
the
inhabitants
were
favourably
inclined
towards
them
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
knowledge
of
this
feeling
that
induced
the
commissioners
,
appointed
to
superintend
the
execution
of
the
enactments
against
recusants
,
to
proceed
with
unusual
rigour
in
this
neighbourhood
.
<EOS>
The
state
of
the
Roman
Catholic
party
at
the
period
of
this
history
was
indeed
most
grievous
.
<EOS>
The
hopes
they
had
indulged
of
greater
toleration
on
the
accession
of
James
the
First
,
had
been
entirely
destroyed
.
<EOS>
The
persecutions
,
suspended
during
the
first
year
of
the
reign
of
the
new
monarch
,
were
now
renewed
with
greater
severity
than
ever
;
and
though
their
present
condition
was
deplorable
enough
,
it
was
feared
that
worse
remained
in
store
for
them
.
<EOS>
"
They
bethought
themselves
,
"
writes
Bishop
Goodman
,
"
that
now
their
case
was
far
worse
than
in
the
time
of
Queen
Elizabeth
;
for
they
did
live
in
some
hope
that
after
the
old
woman
's
life
,
they
might
have
some
mitigation
,
and
even
those
who
did
then
persecute
them
were
a
little
more
moderate
,
as
being
doubtful
what
times
might
succeed
,
and
fearing
their
own
case
.
<EOS>
But
,
now
that
they
saw
the
times
settled
,
having
no
hope
of
better
days
,
but
expecting
that
the
uttermost
rigour
of
the
law
should
be
executed
,
they
became
desperate
:
finding
that
by
the
laws
of
the
kingdom
their
own
lives
were
not
secured
,
and
for
the
carrying
over
of
a
priest
into
England
it
was
no
less
than
high
treason
.
<EOS>
A
gentlewoman
was
hanged
only
for
relieving
and
harbouring
a
priest
;
a
citizen
was
hanged
only
for
being
reconciled
to
the
Church
of
Rome
;
besides
,
the
penal
laws
were
such
,
and
so
executed
,
that
they
could
not
subsist
.
<EOS>
What
was
usually
sold
in
shops
and
usually
bought
,
this
the
pursuivant
would
take
away
from
them
as
being
Popish
and
superstitious
.
<EOS>
One
knight
did
affirm
that
in
one
term
he
gave
twenty
nobles
in
rewards
to
the
door
-
keeper
of
the
Attorney
-
General
;
another
did
affirm
,
that
his
third
part
which
remained
unto
him
of
his
estate
did
hardly
serve
for
his
expense
in
law
to
defend
him
from
other
oppressions
;
besides
their
children
to
be
taken
from
home
,
to
be
brought
up
in
another
religion
.
<EOS>
So
they
did
every
way
conclude
that
their
estate
was
desperate
;
they
could
die
but
once
,
and
their
religion
was
more
precious
unto
them
than
their
lives
.
<EOS>
They
did
further
consider
their
misery
;
how
they
were
debarred
in
any
course
of
life
to
help
themselves
.
<EOS>
They
could
not
practise
law,—they
could
not
be
<EOS>
citizens,—they
could
have
no
office
;
they
could
not
breed
up
their
sons
—
none
did
desire
to
match
with
them
;
they
had
neither
fit
marriages
for
their
daughters
,
nor
nunneries
to
put
them
into
;
for
those
few
which
are
beyond
seas
are
not
considerable
in
respect
of
the
number
of
recusants
,
and
none
can
be
admitted
into
them
without
great
sums
of
money
,
which
they
,
being
exhausted
,
could
not
supply
.
<EOS>
The
Spiritual
Court
did
not
cease
to
molest
them
,
to
excommunicate
them
,
then
to
imprison
them
;
and
thereby
they
were
utterly
disenabled
to
sue
for
their
own
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Such
is
a
faithful
picture
of
the
state
of
the
Catholic
party
at
the
commencement
of
the
reign
of
James
the
First
.
<EOS>
Pressed
down
by
these
intolerable
grievances
,
is
it
to
be
wondered
at
that
the
Papists
should
repine,—or
that
some
among
their
number
,
when
all
other
means
failed
,
should
seek
redress
by
darker
measures
?
<EOS>
By
a
statute
of
Elizabeth
,
all
who
refused
to
conform
to
the
established
religion
were
subjected
to
a
fine
of
twenty
pounds
a
lunar
month
;
and
this
heavy
penalty
,
remitted
,
or
rather
suspended
,
on
the
accession
of
the
new
sovereign
,
was
again
exacted
,
and
all
arrears
claimed
.
<EOS>
Added
to
this
,
James
,
whose
court
was
thronged
by
a
host
of
needy
Scottish
retainers
,
assigned
to
them
a
certain
number
of
wealthy
recusants
,
and
empowered
them
to
levy
the
fines
—
a
privilege
of
which
they
were
not
slow
to
avail
themselves
.
<EOS>
There
were
other
pains
and
penalties
provided
for
by
the
same
statute
,
which
were
rigorously
inflicted
.
<EOS>
To
withdraw
,
or
seek
to
withdraw
another
from
the
established
religion
was
accounted
high
treason
,
and
punished
accordingly
;
to
hear
mass
involved
a
penalty
of
one
hundred
marks
and
a
year
's
imprisonment
;
and
to
harbour
a
priest
,
under
the
denomination
of
a
tutor
,
rendered
the
latter
liable
to
a
year
's
imprisonment
,
and
his
employer
to
a
fine
of
ten
pounds
a
-
month
.
<EOS>
Impressed
with
the
belief
that
,
in
consequence
of
the
unremitting
persecutions
which
the
Catholics
underwent
in
Elizabeth
's
time
,
the
religion
would
be
wholly
extirpated
,
Doctor
Allen
,
a
Lancashire
divine
,
who
afterwards
received
a
cardinal
's
hat
,
founded
a
college
at
Douay
,
for
the
reception
and
education
of
those
intending
to
take
orders
.
<EOS>
From
this
university
a
number
of
missionary
priests
,
or
seminarists
,
as
they
were
termed
,
were
annually
sent
over
to
England
;
and
it
was
against
these
persons
,
who
submitted
to
every
hardship
and
privation
,
to
danger
,
and
death
itself
,
for
the
welfare
of
their
religion
,
and
in
the
hope
of
propagating
its
doctrines
,
that
the
utmost
rigour
of
the
penal
enactments
was
directed
.
<EOS>
Among
the
number
of
seminarists
despatched
from
Douay
,
and
capitally
convicted
under
the
statute
above
-
mentioned
,
were
the
two
priests
whose
execution
has
just
been
narrated
.
<EOS>
As
a
portion
of
the
crowd
passed
over
the
old
bridge
across
the
Irwell
connecting
Manchester
with
Salford
,
on
which
stood
an
ancient
chapel
erected
by
Thomas
de
Booth
,
in
the
reign
of
Edward
the
Third
,
and
recently
converted
into
a
prison
for
recusants
,
they
perceived
the
prophetess
,
Elizabeth
Orton
,
seated
upon
the
stone
steps
of
the
desecrated
structure
,
earnestly
perusing
the
missal
given
her
by
Father
Woodroofe
.
<EOS>
A
mob
speedily
collected
round
her
;
but
,
unconscious
seemingly
of
their
presence
,
the
poor
woman
turned
over
leaf
after
leaf
,
and
pursued
her
studies
.
<EOS>
Her
hood
was
thrown
back
,
and
discovered
her
bare
and
withered
neck
,
over
which
her
dishevelled
hair
streamed
in
long
sable
elf
-
locks
.
<EOS>
Irritated
by
her
indifference
,
several
of
the
by
-
standers
,
who
had
questioned
her
as
to
the
nature
of
her
studies
,
began
to
mock
and
jeer
her
,
and
endeavoured
,
by
plucking
her
robe
,
and
casting
little
pebbles
at
her
,
to
attract
her
attention
.
<EOS>
Roused
at
length
by
these
annoyances
,
she
arose
;
and
fixing
her
large
black
eyes
menacingly
upon
them
,
was
about
to
stalk
away
,
when
they
surrounded
and
detained
her
.
"Speak
<EOS>
to
us
,
Bess
,
"
cried
several
voices
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Prophesy
—
prophesy
.
<EOS>
""I
will
speak
to
you
,
"
replied
the
poor
woman
,
shaking
her
hand
at
them
,
"
I
will
prophesy
to
you
.
<EOS>
And
mark
me
,
though
ye
believe
not
,
my
words
shall
not
fall
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
""A
miracle
!
<EOS>
a
miracle
!
"
shouted
the
by
-
standers
.
"
<EOS>
Bess
Orton
,
who
has
been
silent
for
twenty
years
,
has
found
her
tongue
at
last
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
have
seen
a
vision
,
and
dreamed
a
dream
,
"
continued
the
prophetess
.
<EOS>
"
As
I
lay
in
my
cell
last
night
,
meditating
upon
the
forlorn
state
of
our
religion
,
and
of
its
professors
,
methought
nineteen
shadowy
figures
stood
before
me
—
ay
,
nineteen
—
for
I
counted
them
thrice
—
and
when
I
questioned
them
as
to
their
coming,—for
<EOS>
my
tongue
at
first
clove
to
the
roof
of
my
mouth
,
and
<EOS>
my
lips
refused
their
office,—one
of
them
answered
,
in
a
voice
which
yet
rings
in
my
ears
,
'
We
are
the
chosen
deliverers
of
our
fallen
and
persecuted
church
.
<EOS>
To
us
is
intrusted
the
rebuilding
of
her
temples,—to
our
hands
is
committed
the
destruction
of
our
enemies
.
<EOS>
The
work
will
be
done
in
darkness
and
in
secret,—with
toil
and
travail,—but
it
will
at
length
be
made
manifest
;
and
when
the
hour
is
arrived
,
our
vengeance
will
be
terrible
and
exterminating
.
'
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
they
vanished
from
my
sight
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
suddenly
starting
,
and
passing
her
hand
across
her
brow
,
as
if
to
clear
her
sight
,
"
it
was
no
dream
—
no
vision
.
<EOS>
I
see
one
of
them
now
.
<EOS>
""Where
?
<EOS>
where
?
"
cried
several
voices
.
<EOS>
The
prophetess
answered
by
extending
her
skinny
arm
towards
some
object
immediately
before
her
.
<EOS>
All
eyes
were
instantly
turned
in
the
same
direction
,
when
they
beheld
a
Spanish
soldier
—
for
such
his
garb
proclaimed
him
—
standing
at
a
few
paces
'
distance
from
them
.
<EOS>
He
was
wrapped
in
an
ample
cloak
,
with
a
broad
-
leaved
steeple
-
crowned
hat
,
decorated
with
a
single
green
feather
,
pulled
over
his
brows
,
and
wore
a
polished
-
steel
brigandine
,
trunk
hose
,
and
buff
boots
drawn
up
to
the
knees
.
<EOS>
His
arms
consisted
of
a
brace
of
petronels
thrust
into
his
belt
,
whence
a
long
rapier
depended
.
<EOS>
His
features
were
dark
as
bronze
,
and
well
-
formed
,
though
strongly
marked
,
and
had
an
expression
of
settled
sternness
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
grey
and
penetrating
,
and
shaded
by
thick
beetle
-
brows
;
and
his
physiognomy
was
completed
by
a
black
peaked
beard
.
<EOS>
His
person
was
tall
and
erect
,
and
his
deportment
soldier
-
like
and
commanding
.
<EOS>
Perceiving
<EOS>
he
had
become
an
object
of
notice
,
the
stranger
cast
a
compassionate
look
at
the
prophetess
,
who
still
remained
gazing
fixedly
at
him
,
and
throwing
her
a
few
pieces
of
money
,
strode
away
.
<EOS>
Watching
his
retreating
figure
till
it
disappeared
from
view
,
the
crazed
woman
tossed
her
arms
wildly
in
the
air
,
and
cried
,
in
a
voice
of
exultation
,
"
Did
I
not
speak
the
truth?—did
<EOS>
I
not
tell
you
I
had
seen
him
?
<EOS>
He
is
the
deliverer
of
our
church
,
and
is
come
to
avenge
the
righteous
blood
<EOS>
which
hath
been
this
day
shed
.
<EOS>
""Peace
,
woman
,
and
fly
while
there
is
yet
time
,
"
cried
the
young
man
who
had
been
designated
as
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
pursuivant
and
his
myrmidons
are
in
search
of
you
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
they
need
not
go
far
to
find
me
,
"
replied
the
prophetess
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
tell
them
what
I
told
these
people
,
that
the
day
of
bloody
retribution
is
at
hand,—that
the
avenger
is
arrived
.
<EOS>
I
have
seen
him
twice,—once
in
my
cave
,
and
once
again
here,—even
where
you
stand
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
you
do
not
keep
silence
and
fly
,
my
poor
creature
,
"
rejoined
Humphrey
Chetham
,
"
you
will
have
to
endure
what
you
suffered
years
ago,—stripes
,
and
perhaps
torture
.
<EOS>
Be
warned
by
me
—
ah
!
<EOS>
it
is
too
late
.
<EOS>
He
is
approaching
.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
him
come
,
"
replied
Elizabeth
Orton
,
"
I
am
ready
for
him
.
<EOS>
""Can
<EOS>
none
of
you
force
her
away
?
"
cried
Humphrey
Chetham
,
appealing
to
the
crowd
;
"
I
will
reward
you
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
stir
from
this
spot
,
"
rejoined
the
prophetess
,
obstinately
;
"
I
will
testify
to
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"The
kind
-
hearted
young
merchant
,
finding
any
further
attempt
to
preserve
her
fruitless
,
drew
aside
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
pursuivant
and
his
attendants
had
come

.
<EOS>
"
Seize
her
!
"
<EOS>
cried

former
,
"
and
let
her
be
placed
within
this
prison
till
I
have
reported
her
to

.
<EOS>
If
you
will
confess
to
me
,
woman
,
"
he

in

,
"
that
you
have
harboured

,
and
will
guide
us
to
his

,
you
shall
be
set

.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
know

no
priests
but

you
have
murdered
,
"
returned
the
prophetess
,
in

,
"
but
I
will
tell
you
something
that
you
wot
not
of
.
<EOS>
The
avenger
of
blood
is
at
hand
.
<EOS>
I
have
seen
him
.
<EOS>
All
here
have
seen
him
.
<EOS>
And
you
shall
see
him
—
but
not
now
—
not
now
.
<EOS>
""What
is
the
meaning
of
this
raving
?
<EOS>
"
demanded

pursuivant
.
<EOS>
"Pay
<EOS>
no

to
her
talk
<EOS>
,
"
interposed
Humphrey
Chetham
;
"
she
is
a
poor

being
,
who
knows
not
what
she
says
.
<EOS>
I
will
be
surety
for
her
inoffensive
conduct
.
<EOS>
""You
must
give
me
surety
for

,
sir
,
"
replied

pursuivant
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
learnt
that
you
were
last

Ordsall
Hall
,
the
seat

that
'
dangerous
<EOS>
temporiser,'—for
<EOS>
so
he
is

in
my

William
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
And
if
report
speaks

,
you
are
not

to
the

of
his
fair
daughter
,
Viviana
.
<EOS>
""What
is
this
to
thee
,
thou

?
<EOS>
"
cried
Humphrey
Chetham
,
reddening
,
partly

,
partly
,
it
might
be
,
from
another

.
<EOS>
"Much
,
as
you
shall
presently
find
,
good
Master
Wolf
-
in
-

-

,
"
retorted

;
"

you
prove
not
a
rank
Papist
at
heart
,
then
do
I
not
know
a
true
man
from

false
.
<EOS>
"This
<EOS>
angry
conference
was
cut
short
by
a

from
the
prophetess
.
<EOS>
Breaking
from
the

of
her
captors
,
who
were
about
to
force
her
into
the
prison
,
she
sprang
with
a
single
bound
upon
the
parapet
of
the
bridge
;
and
utterly
regardless
of
her
dangerous
position
,
turned
,
and
faced
the
soldiers
,
who
were
struck
mute
with
astonishment
.
"Tremble
!
<EOS>
"
she
cried
,
in
a
loud
voice,—"tremble
,
ye
evil
-
doers
!
<EOS>
Ye
who
have
despoiled
the
house
of
God,—have
broken
his
altars,—scattered
<EOS>
his
incense,—slain
his
priests
.
<EOS>
Tremble
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
The
avenger
is
arrived
.
<EOS>
The
bolt
is
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
It
shall
strike
king
,
lords
,
commons,—all
!
<EOS>
These
are
my
last
words,—take
them
to
heart
.
<EOS>
""Drag
her
off
!
<EOS>
"
roared
the
pursuivant
,
furiously
.
<EOS>
"Use
<EOS>
care
—
use
gentleness
,
if
ye
are
men
!
"
cried
Humphrey
Chetham
.
"Think
<EOS>
not
you
can
detain
me
!
"
cried
the
prophetess
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Avaunt
,
and
tremble!"So
saying
she
flung
herself
from
the
parapet
.
<EOS>
The
height
from
which
she
fell
was
about
fifty
feet
.
<EOS>
Dashed
into
the
air
like
jets
from
a
fountain
by
the
weight
and
force
of
the
descending
body
,
the
water
instantly
closed
over
her
.
<EOS>
But
she
rose
to
the
surface
of
the
stream
,
about
twenty
yards
below
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
"She
may
yet
be
saved
,
"
cried
Humphrey
Chetham
,
who
with
the
by
-
standers
had
hurried
to
the
side
of
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
"You
will
only
preserve
her
for
the
gallows
,
"
observed
the
pursuivant
.
<EOS>
"Your
malice
shall
not
prevent
my
making
the
attempt
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
.
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
assistance
is
at
hand
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
exclamation
was
occasioned
by
the
sudden
appearance
of
the
soldier
in
the
Spanish
dress
,
who
rushed
towards
the
left
bank
of
the
river
,
which
was
here
,
as
elsewhere
,
formed
of
red
sandstone
rock
,
and
following
the
course
of
the
current
,
awaited
the
next
appearance
of
the
drowning
woman
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
occur
till
she
had
been
carried
a
considerable
distance
down
the
stream
,
when
the
soldier
,
swiftly
divesting
himself
of
his
cloak
,
plunged
into
the
water
,
and
dragged
her
ashore
.
<EOS>
"Follow
<EOS>
me
,
"
cried
the
pursuivant
to
his
attendants
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
lose
my
prey
.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
before
he
gained
the
bank
of
the
river
,
the
soldier
and
his
charge
had
disappeared
,
nor
could
he
detect
any
traces
of
them
.
<EOS>
II
.
<EOS>
—
ORDSALL
CAVEAfter
rescuing
the
unfortunate
prophetess
from
a
watery
grave
in
the
manner
just
related
,
the
soldier
snatched
up
his
cloak
,
and
,
taking
his
dripping
burthen
in
his
arms
,
hurried
swiftly
along
the
bank
of
the
river
,
until
he
came
to
a
large
cleft
in
the
rock
,
into
which
he
crept
,
taking
the
prophetess
with
him
,
and
thus
eluded
observation
.
<EOS>
In
this
retreat
he
continued
upwards
of
two
hours
,
during
which
time
the
poor
creature
,
to
whom
he
paid
every
attention
that
circumstances
would
admit
,
had
so
far
recovered
as
to
be
able
to
speak
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
evident
that
the
shock
had
been
too
much
for
her
,
and
that
she
was
sinking
fast
.
<EOS>
She
was
so
faint
that
she
could
scarcely
move
;
but
she
expressed
a
strong
desire
to
reach
her
cell
before
she
breathed
her
last
.
<EOS>
Having
described
its
situation
as
accurately
as
she
could
to
the
soldier
—
who
before
he
ventured
forth
peeped
out
to
reconnoitre
—
he
again
raised
her
in
his
arms
,
and
by
her
direction
struck
into
a
narrow
lane
skirting
the
bank
of
the
river
.
<EOS>
Pursuing
this
road
for
about
half
a
mile
,
he
arrived
at
the
foot
of
a
small
knoll
,
covered
by
a
clump
of
magnificent
beech
-
trees
,
and
still
acting
under
the
guidance
of
the
dying
woman
,
whose
voice
grew
more
feeble
each
instant
,
he
mounted
it
,
and
from
its
summit
took
a
rapid
survey
of
the
surrounding
country
.
<EOS>
On
the
opposite
bank
of
the
river
stood
an
old
hall
,
while
further
on
,
at
some
distance
,
he
could
perceive
through
the
trees
the
gables
and
chimneys
of
another
ancient
mansion
.
<EOS>
"Raise
<EOS>
me
up
<EOS>
,
"
said
Elizabeth
Orton
,
as
he
lingered
on
this
spot
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
that
old
house
,
which
you
see
yonder
,
Hulme
Hall
,
I
was
born
.
<EOS>
I
would
willingly
take
one
look
at
it
before
I
die
.
"Illustration"And
<EOS>
the
other
hall
,
which
I
discern
through
the
trees
,
is
Ordsall
,
is
it
not
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
soldier
.
<EOS>
"It
is
,
"
replied
the
prophetess
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
let
us
make
what
haste
we
can
.
<EOS>
We
have
not
far
to
go
;
and
I
feel
I
shall
not
last
long
.
<EOS>
"Descending
<EOS>
the
eminence
,
and
again
entering
the
lane
,
which
here
made
a
turn
<EOS>
,
the
soldier
approached
a
grassy
space
,
walled
in
on
either
side
by
steep
sandstone
rocks
.
<EOS>
At
the
further
extremity
of
the
enclosure
,
after
a
moment
's
search
,
by
the
direction
of
his
companion
,
he
found
,
artfully
concealed
by
overhanging
brushwood
,
the
mouth
of
a
small
cave
.
<EOS>
He
crept
into
the
excavation
,
and
found
it
about
six
feet
high
,
and
of
considerable
depth
.
<EOS>
The
roof
was
ornamented
with
Runic
characters
and
other
grotesque
and
half
-
effaced
inscriptions
,
while
the
sides
were
embellished
with
Gothic
tracery
,
amid
which
the
letters
I.H.S.
,
carved
in
ancient
church
text
,
could
be
easily
distinguished
.
<EOS>
Tradition
assigned
the
cell
to
the
priests
of
Odin
,
but
it
was
evident
that
worshippers
at
other
and
holier
altars
had
more
recently
made
it
their
retreat
.
<EOS>
Its
present
occupant
had
furnished
it
with
a
straw
pallet
,
and
a
small
wooden
crucifix
fixed
in
a
recess
in
the
wall
.
<EOS>
Gently
depositing
her
upon
the
pallet
,
the
soldier
took
a
seat
beside
her
on
a
stone
slab
at
the
foot
of
the
bed
.
<EOS>
He
next
,
at
her
request
,
as
the
cave
was
rendered
almost
wholly
dark
by
the
overhanging
trees
,
struck
a
light
,
and
set
fire
to
a
candle
placed
within
a
lantern
.
<EOS>
After
a
few
moments
passed
in
prayer
,
the
recluse
begged
him
to
give
her
the
crucifix
that
she
might
clasp
it
to
her
breast
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
she
became
more
composed
,
and
prepared
to
meet
her
end
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
as
if
something
had
again
disturbed
her
,
she
opened
wide
her
glazing
eyes
,
and
starting
up
with
a
dying
effort
,
stretched
out
her
hands
.
<EOS>
"I
see
him
before
them
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
.
<EOS>
"
They
examine
him
—
they
adjudge
him
!
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
he
is
now
in
a
dungeon
!
<EOS>
See
,
the
torturers
advance
!
<EOS>
He
is
placed
on
the
rack
—
once
—
twice
—
<EOS>
thrice
<EOS>
—
they
turn
the
levers
!
<EOS>
His
joints
snap
in
their
sockets
—
his
sinews
crack
!
<EOS>
Mercy
!
<EOS>
he
confesses
!
<EOS>
He
is
led
to
execution
.
<EOS>
I
see
him
ascend
the
scaffold!""Whom
<EOS>
do
you
behold
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
soldier
,
listening
to
her
in
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"His
<EOS>
face
is
hidden
from
me
,
"
replied
the
prophetess
;
"
but
his
figure
is
not
unlike
your
own
.
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
I
hear
the
executioner
pronounce
his
name
.
<EOS>
How
are
you
called?""GUY
FAWKES
,
"
replied
the
soldier
.
<EOS>
"It
is
the
name
I
heard
,
"
rejoined
Elizabeth
Orton
.
<EOS>
And
,
sinking
backward
,
she
expired
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
gazed
at
her
for
some
time
,
till
he
felt
assured
that
the
last
spark
of
life
had
fled
.
<EOS>
He
then
turned
away
,
and
placing
his
hand
upon
his
chin
,
became
lost
in
deep
reflection
.
<EOS>
III
.
—
ORDSALL
HALLSoon
after
sunset
,
on
the
evening
of
the
events
previously
related
,
the
inmates
of
Ordsall
Hall
were
disturbed
and
alarmed
(
for
in
those
times
of
trouble
any
casual
disturbance
at
night
was
sufficient
to
occasion
alarm
to
a
Catholic
family
)
by
a
loud
clamour
for
admittance
from
some
one
stationed
at
the
farther
side
of
the
moat
,
then
,
as
now
,
surrounding
that
ancient
manorial
residence
.
<EOS>
The
drawbridge
being
raised
,
no
apprehension
was
entertained
of
an
attempt
at
forcible
entrance
on
the
part
of
the
intruder
,
who
,
so
far
as
he
could
be
discerned
in
the
deepening
twilight
,
rendered
yet
more
obscure
by
the
shade
of
the
trees
under
which
he
stood
,
appeared
to
be
a
solitary
horseman
.
<EOS>
Still
,
for
fear
of
a
surprise
,
it
was
judged
prudent
by
those
inside
the
hall
to
turn
a
deaf
ear
to
the
summons
;
nor
was
it
until
it
had
been
more
than
once
repeated
in
a
peremptory
tone
,
that
any
attention
was
paid
to
it
.
<EOS>
The
outer
gate
was
then
cautiously
opened
by
an
old
steward
,
and
a
couple
of
serving
-
men
,
armed
with
pikes
and
swords
,
who
demanded
the
stranger
's
business
,
and
were
answered
that
he
desired
to
speak
with
Sir
William
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
The
steward
rejoined
that
his
master
was
not
at
home
,
having
set
out
the
day
before
for
Chester
:
but
that
even
if
he
were
,
he
would
take
upon
himself
to
affirm
that
no
audience
would
be
given
,
on
any
pretence
whatever
,
to
a
stranger
at
such
an
unseasonable
hour
.
<EOS>
To
this
the
other
replied
,
in
a
haughty
and
commanding
voice
,
that
he
was
neither
a
stranger
to
Sir
William
Radcliffe
,
nor
ignorant
of
the
necessity
of
caution
,
though
in
this
instance
it
was
altogether
superfluous
;
and
as
,
notwithstanding
the
steward
's
assertion
to
the
contrary
,
he
was
fully
persuaded
his
master
was
at
home
,
he
insisted
upon
being
conducted
to
him
without
further
parley
,
as
his
business
would
not
brook
delay
.
<EOS>
In
vain
the
steward
declared
he
had
spoken
the
truth
.
<EOS>
The
stranger
evidently
disbelieved
him
;
but
,
as
he
could
obtain
no
more
satisfactory
answer
to
his
interrogations
,
he
suddenly
shifted
his
ground
,
and
inquired
whether
Sir
William
's
daughter
,
Mistress
Viviana
,
was
likewise
absent
from
home
.
<EOS>
"Before
<EOS>
I
reply
to
the
question
,
I
must
know
by
whom
and
wherefore
it
is
put
?
"
returned
the
steward
,
evasively
.
<EOS>
"Trouble
<EOS>
not
yourself
further
,
friend
,
but
deliver
this
letter
to
her
,
"
rejoined
the
horseman
,
flinging
a
packet
across
the
moat
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
addressed
to
her
father
,
but
there
is
no
reason
why
she
should
not
be
acquainted
with
its
contents
.
<EOS>
""Take
it
up
<EOS>
,
Olin
Birtwissel
,
"
cried
the
steward
,
eyeing
the
packet
which
had
fallen
at
his
feet
suspiciously
;
"
take
it
up
,
I
say
,
and
hold
it
to
the
light
,
that
I
may
consider
it
well
before
I
carry
it
to
our
young
mistress
.
<EOS>
I
have
heard
of
strange
treacheries
practised
by
such
means
,
and
care
not
to
meddle
with
it
.
<EOS>
""Neither
<EOS>
do
I
,
good
Master
Heydocke
,
"
replied
Birtwissel
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
touch
it
for
a
twelvemonth
's
wages
.
<EOS>
It
may
burst
,
and
spoil
my
good
looks
,
and
so
ruin
my
fortunes
with
the
damsels
.
<EOS>
But
here
is
Jeff
Gellibronde
,
who
,
having
no
beauty
to
lose
,
and
being
,
moreover
,
afraid
of
nothing
,
will
pick
it
up
for
you
.
<EOS>
""Speak
<EOS>
for
yourself
,
Olin
,
"
rejoined
Gellibronde
,
in
a
surly
tone
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
more
fancy
for
a
shattered
limb
,
or
a
scorched
face
,
than
my
neighbours
.
<EOS>
""Dolts
!
"
cried
the
stranger
,
who
had
listened
to
these
observations
with
angry
impatience
,
"
if
you
will
not
convey
my
packet
,
which
has
nothing
more
dangerous
about
it
than
an
ordinary
letter
,
to
your
mistress
,
at
least
acquaint
her
that
Mr.
Robert
Catesby
,
of
Ashby
St.
Legers
,
is
without
,
and
craves
an
instant
speech
with
her
.
<EOS>
""Mr
.
<EOS>
Catesby
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
steward
,
in
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"
If
it
be
indeed
your
worship
,
why
did
you
not
declare
yourself
at
once?""I
may
have
as
good
reason
for
caution
as
yourself
,
Master
Heydocke
,
"
returned
Catesby
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
"True
,
"
rejoined
the
steward
;
"
but
,
methinks
it
is
somewhat
strange
to
find
your
worship
here
,
when
I
am
aware
that
my
master
expected
to
meet
you
,
and
certain
other
honourable
gentlemen
that
you
wot
of
,
at
a
place
in
a
clean
opposite
direction
,
Holywell
,
in
Flintshire
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
cause
of
my
presence
,
since
you
desire
to
be
certified
of
the
matter
,
is
simply
this
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
urging
his
steed
towards
the
edge
of
the
moat
,
while
the
steward
advanced
to
meet
him
on
the
opposite
bank
,
so
that
a
few
yards
only
lay
between
them
;
"
I
came
round
by
Manchester
,
"
he
continued
,
in
a
lower
tone
,
"
to
see
if
any
assistance
could
be
rendered
to
the
unfortunate
fathers
Woodroofe
and
Forshawe
;
but
found
on
my
arrival
this
morning
that
I
was
too
late
,
as
they
had
just
been
executed
.
<EOS>
""Heaven
have
mercy
on
their
souls
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Heydocke
,
shuddering
,
and
crossing
himself
.
<EOS>
"
Yours
was
a
pious
mission
,
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
Would
it
had
been
availing!""I
would
so
,
too
,
with
all
my
soul
!
<EOS>
"
rejoined
the
other
,
fervently
;
"
but
fate
ordained
it
otherwise
.
<EOS>
While
I
was
in
the
town
,
I
accidentally
learnt
from
one
,
who
informed
me
he
had
just
parted
with
him
,
that
your
master
was
at
home
;
and
,
fearing
he
might
not
be
able
to
attend
the
meeting
at
Holywell
<EOS>
,
I
resolved
to
proceed
hither
at
nightfall
,
when
my
visit
was
not
likely
to
be
observed
;
having
motives
,
which
you
may
readily
conjecture
,
for
preserving
the
strictest
secrecy
on
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
The
letter
was
prepared
in
case
I
should
fail
in
meeting
with
him
.
<EOS>
And
now
that
I
have
satisfied
your
scruples
,
good
master
steward
,
if
Sir
William
be
really
within
,
I
pray
you
lead
me
to
him
forthwith
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
your
young
mistress
may
serve
my
turn
,
for
I
have
that
to
say
which
it
imports
one
or
other
of
them
to
know
.
<EOS>
""In
<EOS>
regard
to
my
master
,
"
replied
the
steward
,
"
he
departed
yesterday
for
Chester
,
on
his
way
to
join
the
pilgrimage
to
<EOS>
St.
Winifred
's
Well
,
as
I
have
already
assured
your
worship
.
<EOS>
And
whoever
informed
you
to
the
contrary
,
spoke
falsely
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
convey
your
letter
and
message
to
my
young
mistress
,
and
on
learning
her
pleasure
as
to
receiving
you
,
will
instantly
return
and
report
it
.
<EOS>
These
are
dangerous
times
,
your
worship
;
dangerous
times
.
<EOS>
A
good
Catholic
knows
not
whom
to
trust
,
there
are
so
many
spoilers
abroad
.
<EOS>
""How
,
sirrah
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
angrily
,
"
<EOS>
do
you
apply
that
observation
to
me?""Far
be
it
from
me
,
"
answered
Heydocke
,
respectfully
,
"
to
apply
any
observation
that
may
sound
offensive
to
your
worship
,
whom
I
know
to
be
a
most
worthy
gentleman
,
and
as
free
from
heresy
,
as
any
in
the
kingdom
.
<EOS>
I
was
merely
endeavouring
to
account
for
what
may
appear
my
over
-
caution
in
detaining
you
where
you
are
,
till
I
learn
my
lady
's
pleasure
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
rule
in
this
house
not
to
lower
the
drawbridge
without
orders
after
sunset
;
and
I
dare
not
,
for
my
place
,
disobey
it
.
<EOS>
Young
Mr.
Humphrey
Chetham
,
of
Crumpsall
,
was
detained
in
the
like
manner
no
later
than
last
night
;
and
he
is
a
visitor
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
significant
tone
,
"
who
is
not
altogether
unwelcome
to
my
mistress
—
ahem
!
<EOS>
But
duty
is
no
respecter
of
persons
;
and
in
my
master
's
absence
my
duty
is
to
protect
his
household
.
<EOS>
Your
worship
will
pardon
me
.
<EOS>
""I
will
pardon
anything
but
your
loquacity
and
tediousness
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
impatiently
.
"
<EOS>
About
your
errand
quickly
.
<EOS>
""I
am
gone
,
your
worship
,
"
returned
the
steward
,
disappearing
with
his
companions
.
<EOS>
Throwing
the
bridle
over
his
horse
's
neck
,
and
allowing
him
to
drink
his
fill
from
the
water
of
the
moat
,
and
afterwards
to
pluck
a
few
mouthfuls
of
the
long
grass
that
fringed
its
brink
,
Catesby
abandoned
himself
to
reflection
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
moments
,
as
the
steward
did
not
return
,
he
raised
his
eyes
,
and
fixed
them
upon
the
ancient
habitation
before
him,—ancient
,
indeed
,
it
was
not
at
this
time
,
having
been
in
a
great
measure
rebuilt
by
its
possessor
,
Sir
William
Radcliffe
,
during
the
latter
part
of
the
reign
of
Elizabeth
,
in
the
rich
and
picturesque
style
of
that
period
.
<EOS>
Little
could
be
distinguished
of
its
projecting
and
retiring
wings
,
its
walls
decorated
with
black
and
white
chequer
-
work
,
the
characteristic
of
the
class
of
architecture
to
which
it
belonged
,
or
of
its
magnificent
embayed
windows
filled
with
stained
glass
;
but
the
outline
of
its
heavy
roof
,
with
its
numerous
gables
,
and
groups
of
tall
and
elaborately
-
ornamented
chimneys
,
might
be
distinctly
traced
in
strong
relief
against
the
warm
and
still
-
glowing
western
sky
.
<EOS>
Though
much
gone
to
decay
,
grievously
neglected
,
and
divided
into
three
separate
dwelling
-
houses
,
Ordsall
Hall
still
retains
much
of
its
original
character
and
beauty
;
and
viewed
at
the
magic
hour
above
described
,
when
the
changes
produced
by
the
lapse
of
years
can
not
be
detected
,
it
presents
much
the
same
striking
appearance
that
it
offered
to
the
gaze
of
Catesby
.
<EOS>
Situated
on
the
north
bank
of
the
Irwell
,
which
supplies
the
moat
with
a
constant
stream
of
fresh
water
,
it
commands
on
the
south
-
west
a
beautiful
view
of
the
winding
course
of
the
river
,
here
almost
forming
an
island
,
of
Trafford
Park
and
its
hall
,
of
the
woody
uplands
beyond
it
,
and
of
the
distant
hills
of
Cheshire
.
<EOS>
The
mansion
itself
is
an
irregular
quadrangle
,
covering
a
considerable
tract
of
ground
.
<EOS>
The
gardens
,
once
exquisitely
laid
out
in
the
formal
taste
of
Elizabeth
's
days
,
are
also
enclosed
by
the
moat
,
surrounding
(
except
in
the
intervals
where
it
is
filled
up
)
a
space
of
some
acres
in
extent
.
<EOS>
At
the
period
of
this
history
,
it
was
approached
on
the
north
-
east
by
a
noble
avenue
of
sycamores
,
leading
to
within
a
short
distance
of
its
gates
.
<EOS>
As
Catesby
surveyed
this
stately
structure
,
and
pondered
upon
the
wealth
and
power
of
its
owner
,
his
meditations
thus
found
vent
in
words:—"If
I
could
but
link
Radcliffe
to
our
cause
,
or
win
the
hand
of
his
fair
daughter
,
and
so
bind
him
to
me
,
the
great
attempt
could
not
fail
.
<EOS>
She
has
refused
me
once
.
<EOS>
No
matter
.
<EOS>
I
will
persevere
till
she
yields
.
<EOS>
With
Father
Oldcorne
to
back
my
suit
,
I
am
assured
of
success
.
<EOS>
She
is
necessary
to
my
purpose
,
and
shall
be
mine
.
<EOS>
"Descended
<EOS>
from
an
ancient
Northamptonshire
family
,
and
numbering
among
his
ancestry
the
well
-
known
minister
of
the
same
name
who
flourished
in
the
reign
of
Richard
the
Third
,
Robert
Catesby,—at
this
time
about
forty,—had
in
his
youth
led
a
wild
and
dissolute
life
;
and
though
bred
in
the
faith
of
Rome
,
he
had
for
some
years
abandoned
its
worship
.
<EOS>
In
1580
,
when
the
Jesuits
,
Campion
and
Persons
,
visited
England
,
he
was
reconciled
to
the
church
he
had
quitted
,
and
thenceforth
became
as
zealous
a
supporter
and
promoter
of
its
doctrines
as
he
had
heretofore
been
their
bitter
opponent
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
actively
engaged
in
all
the
Popish
plots
of
the
period
,
and
was
even
supposed
to
be
connected
with
those
designs
of
a
darker
dye
which
were
set
on
foot
for
Elizabeth
's
destruction,—with
Somerville
's
conspiracy,—with
that
of
Arden
and
Throckmorton,—the
latter
of
whom
was
his
uncle
on
the
maternal
side,—with
<EOS>
the
plots
of
Bury
and
Savage,—of
Ballard,—and
of
Babington
.
<EOS>
After
the
execution
of
the
unfortunate
Queen
of
Scots
,
he
devoted
himself
to
what
was
termed
the
Spanish
faction
,
and
endeavoured
carry
out
the
schemes
of
a
party
,
who
,
distrusting
the
vague
promises
of
James
,
were
anxious
to
secure
the
succession
to
a
Catholic,—the
Infanta
of
Spain
,
or
the
Duke
of
Parma
.
<EOS>
On
the
insurrection
of
the
Earl
of
Essex
,
he
took
part
with
that
ill
-
fated
nobleman
;
and
,
though
he
escaped
condign
punishment
for
the
offence
,
he
was
imprisoned
and
heavily
fined
.
<EOS>
From
this
time
his
career
ran
in
darker
channels
.
"
<EOS>
Hunger
-
starved
for
innovation
,
"
as
he
is
finely
described
by
Camden,—imbued
with
the
fiercest
religious
fanaticism,—eloquent
,
wily
,
resolute,—able
alike
to
delude
the
powerful
and
intimidate
the
weak,—he
possessed
all
the
ingredients
of
a
conspirator
.
<EOS>
Associating
with
men
like
himself
,
of
desperate
character
and
broken
fortunes
,
he
was
ever
on
the
look
out
for
some
means
of
retrieving
his
own
condition
,
and
redressing
the
wrongs
of
his
church
.
<EOS>
Well
informed
of
the
actual
state
of
James
's
sentiments
,
when
,
on
that
monarch
's
accession
,
confident
hopes
were
entertained
by
the
Romanists
of
greater
toleration
for
their
religion
,
Catesby
was
the
first
to
point
out
their
mistake
,
and
to
foretel
the
season
of
terrible
persecution
that
was
at
hand
.
<EOS>
On
this
persecution
he
grounded
his
hopes
—
hopes
,
never
realized
,
for
the
sufferers
,
amid
all
the
grievances
they
endured
,
remained
constant
in
their
fidelity
to
the
throne
—
of
exciting
a
general
insurrection
among
the
Catholics
.
<EOS>
Disappointed
in
this
expectation,—disappointed
,
also
,
in
his
hopes
of
Spain
,
of
France
,
and
of
aid
from
Rome
,
he
fell
back
upon
himself
,
and
resolved
upon
the
execution
of
a
dark
and
dreadful
project
which
he
had
long
conceived
,
and
which
he
could
execute
almost
single
-
handed
,
without
aid
from
foreign
powers
,
and
without
the
co
-
operation
of
his
own
party
.
<EOS>
The
nature
of
this
project
,
which
,
if
it
succeeded
,
would
,
he
imagined
,
accomplish
all
or
more
than
his
wildest
dreams
of
ambition
or
fanaticism
had
ever
conceived
,
it
will
be
the
business
of
this
history
to
develope
.
<EOS>
Without
going
further
into
detail
at
present
,
it
may
be
mentioned
that
the
success
of
the
plot
depended
so
entirely
on
its
secrecy
,
and
so
well
aware
was
its
contriver
of
the
extraordinary
system
of
espionage
carried
on
by
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
and
the
Privy
Council
,
that
for
some
time
he
scarcely
dared
to
trust
it
out
of
his
keeping
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
after
much
deliberation
,
he
communicated
it
to
five
others
,
all
of
whom
were
bound
to
silence
by
an
oath
of
unusual
solemnity
;
and
as
it
was
necessary
to
the
complete
success
of
the
conspiracy
that
its
outbreak
should
be
instantaneously
followed
by
a
rise
on
the
part
of
the
Catholics
,
he
darkly
hinted
that
a
plan
was
on
foot
for
their
deliverance
from
the
yoke
of
their
oppressors
,
and
counselled
them
to
hold
themselves
in
readiness
to
fly
to
arms
at
a
moment
's
notice
.
<EOS>
But
here
again
he
failed
.
<EOS>
Few
were
disposed
to
listen
to
him
;
and
of
those
who
did
,
the
majority
returned
for
answer
,
"
that
their
part
was
endurance
,
and
that
the
only
arms
which
Christians
could
use
against
lawful
powers
in
their
severity
were
prayers
and
tears
.
<EOS>
"Among
<EOS>
the
Popish
party
of
that
period
,
as
in
our
own
time
,
were
ranked
many
of
the
oldest
and
most
illustrious
families
in
the
kingdom,—families
not
less
remarkable
for
their
zeal
for
their
religion
than
,
as
has
before
been
observed
,
for
their
loyalty;—a
loyalty
afterwards
approved
in
the
disastrous
reign
of
James
the
Second
by
their
firm
adherence
to
what
they
considered
the
indefeasible
right
of
inheritance
.
<EOS>
Plots
,
indeed
,
were
constantly
hatched
throughout
the
reigns
of
Elizabeth
and
James
,
by
persons
professing
the
religion
of
Rome
;
but
in
these
the
mass
of
the
Catholics
had
no
share
.
<EOS>
And
even
in
the
seasons
of
the
bitterest
persecution
,
when
every
fresh
act
of
treason
,
perpetrated
by
some
lawless
and
disaffected
individual
,
was
visited
with
additional
rigour
on
their
heads,—when
the
scaffold
reeked
with
their
blood
,
and
the
stake
smoked
with
their
ashes,—when
their
quarters
were
blackening
on
the
gates
and
market
-
crosses
of
every
city
in
the
realm,—when
their
hearths
were
invaded
,
their
religion
proscribed
,
and
the
very
name
of
Papist
had
become
a
by
-
word,—even
<EOS>
in
those
terrible
seasons
,
as
in
the
season
under
consideration
,
they
remained
constant
in
their
fidelity
to
the
crown
.
<EOS>
From
the
troubled
elements
at
work
,
some
fierce
and
turbulent
spirits
were
sure
to
arise,—some
gloomy
fanatics
who
,
having
brooded
over
their
wrongs
,
real
or
imaginary
,
till
they
had
lost
all
scruples
of
conscience
,
hesitated
at
no
means
of
procuring
redress
.
<EOS>
But
it
would
be
unjust
to
hold
up
such
persons
as
representatives
of
the
whole
body
of
Catholics
.
<EOS>
Among
the
conspirators
themselves
there
were
redeeming
shades
.
<EOS>
All
were
not
actuated
by
the
same
atrocious
motives
.
<EOS>
Mixed
feelings
induced
Catesby
to
adopt
the
measure
.
<EOS>
Not
so
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
had
already
been
leagued
with
the
design
.
<EOS>
One
idea
alone
ruled
him
.
<EOS>
A
soldier
of
fortune
,
but
a
stern
religious
enthusiast
,
he
supposed
himself
chosen
by
Heaven
for
the
redemption
of
his
Church
,
and
cared
not
what
happened
to
himself
,
provided
he
accomplished
his
(
as
he
conceived
)
holy
design
.
<EOS>
In
considering
the
causes
which
produced
the
conspiracy
about
to
be
related
,
and
in
separating
the
disaffected
party
of
the
Papists
from
the
temperate
,
due
weight
must
be
given
to
the
influence
of
the
priesthood
.
<EOS>
Of
the
Romish
clergy
there
were
two
classes
—
the
secular
priests
,
and
the
Jesuits
and
missionaries
.
<EOS>
While
the
former
,
like
the
more
moderate
of
the
laity
,
would
have
been
well
-
contented
with
toleration
for
their
religion
,
the
latter
breathed
nothing
but
revenge
,
and
desired
the
utter
subversion
of
the
existing
government,—temporal
as
well
as
ecclesiastical
.
<EOS>
Men
,
for
the
most
part
,
of
high
intellectual
powers
,
of
untiring
energy
,
and
unconquerable
fortitude
,
they
were
enabled
by
their
zeal
and
ability
to
make
many
proselytes
.
<EOS>
By
their
means
,
secret
correspondence
was
carried
on
with
the
different
courts
of
Europe
;
and
they
were
not
without
hope
that
,
taking
advantage
of
some
favourable
crisis
,
they
should
yet
restore
their
church
to
its
former
supremacy
.
<EOS>
To
these
persons,—who
held
as
a
maxim
,
"
Qui
religionem
Catholicam
deserit
regnandi
jus
omne
amisit,"—Catesby
<EOS>
and
his
associates
proved
ready
and
devoted
agents
.
<EOS>
Through
their
instrumentality
,
they
hoped
to
accomplish
the
great
work
of
their
restoration
.
<EOS>
To
Father
Garnet
,
the
provincial
of
the
English
Jesuits
,
of
whom
it
will
be
necessary
to
speak
more
fully
hereafter
,
the
plot
had
been
revealed
by
Catesby
under
the
seal
of
confession
;
and
,
though
it
subsequently
became
a
question
whether
he
was
justified
in
withholding
a
secret
of
such
importance
to
the
state
,
it
is
sufficient
for
the
present
purpose
to
say
that
he
did
withhold
it
.
<EOS>
For
the
treasonable
practices
of
the
Jesuits
and
their
faction
some
palliation
may
perhaps
be
found
in
the
unrelenting
persecution
to
which
they
were
subjected
;
but
if
any
excuse
can
be
admitted
for
them
,
what
opinion
must
be
formed
of
the
conduct
of
their
temperate
brethren
?
<EOS>
Surely
,
while
the
one
is
condemned
,
admiration
may
be
mingled
with
the
sympathy
which
must
be
felt
for
the
unmerited
sufferings
of
the
other!From
the
foregoing
statement
,
it
will
be
readily
inferred
that
Sir
William
Radcliffe
,
a
devout
Catholic
,
and
a
man
of
large
possessions
,
though
somewhat
reduced
by
the
heavy
fines
imposed
upon
him
as
a
recusant
,
must
have
appeared
an
object
of
importance
to
the
conspirators
;
nor
will
it
be
wondered
at
,
that
every
means
were
used
to
gain
him
to
their
cause
.
<EOS>
Acting
,
however
,
upon
the
principles
that
swayed
the
well
-
disposed
of
his
party
,
the
knight
resisted
all
these
overtures
,
and
refused
to
take
any
share
in
proceedings
from
which
his
conscience
and
loyalty
alike
revolted
.
<EOS>
Baffled
,
but
not
defeated
,
Catesby
returned
to
the
charge
on
a
new
point
of
assault
.
<EOS>
Himself
a
widower
(
or
supposed
to
be
so
)
,
he
solicited
the
hand
of
the
lovely
Viviana
Radcliffe
,
Sir
William
's
only
child
,
and
the
sole
heiress
of
his
possessions
.
<EOS>
But
his
suit
in
this
quarter
was
,
also
,
unsuccessful
.
<EOS>
The
knight
rejected
the
proposal
,
alleging
that
his
daughter
had
no
inclination
to
any
alliance
,
inasmuch
as
she
entertained
serious
thoughts
of
avowing
herself
to
heaven
.
<EOS>
Thus
foiled
,
Catesby
ostensibly
relinquished
his
design
.
<EOS>
Shortly
before
the
commencement
of
this
history
,
a
pilgrimage
to
<EOS>
Saint
Winifred
's
Well
,
in
Flintshire
,
was
undertaken
by
Father
Garnet
,
the
provincial
of
the
Jesuits
before
mentioned
,
in
company
with
several
distinguished
Catholic
personages
of
both
sexes
,
and
to
this
ceremonial
Sir
William
and
his
daughter
were
urgently
bidden
.
<EOS>
The
invitation
was
declined
on
the
part
of
Viviana
,
but
accepted
by
the
knight
,
who
,
though
unwilling
to
leave
home
at
a
period
of
so
much
danger
,
or
to
commit
his
daughter
to
any
care
but
his
own
,
even
for
so
short
a
space
,
felt
it
to
be
his
duty
to
give
countenance
by
his
presence
to
the
ceremonial
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
departed
for
Chester
on
the
previous
day
,
as
stated
by
the
steward
.
<EOS>
And
,
though
Catesby
professed
ignorance
on
the
subject
,
and
even
affirmed
he
had
heard
to
the
contrary
,
it
may
be
doubted
whether
he
was
not
secretly
informed
of
the
circumstance
,
and
whether
his
arrival
,
at
this
particular
conjuncture
,
was
not
preconcerted
.
<EOS>
Thus
much
in
explanation
of
what
is
to
follow
.
<EOS>
The
course
of
Catesby
's
reflections
was
cut
short
by
the
return
of
the
steward
,
who
,
informing
him
that
he
had
his
mistress
's
commands
to
admit
him
,
immediately
lowered
the
drawbridge
for
that
purpose
.
<EOS>
Dismounting
,
and
committing
his
steed
to
one
of
the
serving
-
men
,
who
advanced
to
take
it
,
Catesby
followed
his
conductor
through
a
stone
gateway
,
and
crossing
the
garden
,
was
ushered
into
a
spacious
and
lofty
hall
,
furnished
with
a
long
massy
oak
table
,
at
the
upper
end
of
which
was
a
raised
dais
.
<EOS>
At
one
side
of
the
chamber
yawned
a
huge
arched
fire
-
place
,
garnished
with
enormous
andirons
,
on
which
smouldered
a
fire
composed
of
mixed
turf
and
wood
.
<EOS>
Above
the
chimney
-
piece
hung
a
suit
of
chain
-
armour
,
with
the
battle
-
axe
,
helmet
,
and
gauntlets
of
Sir
John
Radcliffe
,
the
first
possessor
of
Ordsall
,
who
flourished
in
the
reign
of
Edward
the
First
:
on
the
right
,
masking
the
entrance
,
stood
a
magnificent
screen
of
carved
oak
.
<EOS>
Traversing
this
hall
,
Heydocke
led
the
way
to
another
large
apartment
;
and
placing
lights
on
a
Gothic
-
shaped
table
,
offered
a
seat
to
the
new
-
comer
,
and
departed
.
<EOS>
The
room
in
which
Catesby
was
left
was
termed
the
star-
chamber
—
a
name
retained
to
this
day
—
from
the
circumstance
of
its
ceiling
being
moulded
and
painted
to
resemble
the
heavenly
vault
when
studded
with
the
luminaries
of
night
.
<EOS>
It
was
terminated
by
a
deeply
-
embayed
window
filled
with
stained
glass
of
the
most
gorgeous
colours
.
<EOS>
The
walls
,
in
some
places
,
were
hung
with
arras
,
in
others
,
wainscoted
with
dark
lustrous
oak
,
embellished
with
scrolls
,
ciphers
,
and
fanciful
designs
.
<EOS>
The
mantel
-
piece
was
of
the
same
solid
material
,
curiously
carved
,
and
of
extraordinary
size
.
<EOS>
It
was
adorned
with
the
armorial
bearings
of
the
family
—
two
bends
engrailed
,
and
in
chief
a
label
of
three,—and
other
devices
and
inscriptions
.
<EOS>
The
hearth
was
considerably
raised
above
the
level
of
the
floor
,
and
there
was
a
peculiarity
in
the
construction
of
the
massive
wooden
pillars
flanking
it
,
that
attracted
the
attention
of
Catesby
,
who
rose
with
the
intention
of
examining
them
more
narrowly
,
when
he
was
interrupted
by
the
entrance
of
the
lady
of
the
mansion
.
<EOS>
Advancing
at
a
slow
and
dignified
pace
,
Viviana
Radcliffe
courteously
but
gravely
saluted
her
guest
;
and
,
without
offering
him
her
hand
,
motioned
him
to
a
chair
,
while
she
seated
herself
at
a
little
distance
.
<EOS>
Catesby
had
seen
her
twice
before
;
and
whether
the
circumstances
under
which
they
now
met
might
have
caused
some
change
in
her
demeanour
he
could
not
tell
,
but
he
thought
her
singularly
altered
.
<EOS>
A
year
ago
,
she
had
been
a
lively
,
laughing
girl
of
seventeen
,
with
a
bright
brown
skin
,
dark
flowing
tresses
,
and
eyes
as
black
and
radiant
as
those
of
a
gipsy
.
<EOS>
She
was
now
a
grave
,
collected
woman
,
infinitely
more
beautiful
,
but
wholly
changed
in
character
.
<EOS>
Her
complexion
had
become
a
clear
,
transparent
white
,
and
set
off
to
great
advantage
her
large
,
luminous
eyes
,
and
jetty
brows
.
<EOS>
Her
figure
was
tall
and
majestic
;
her
features
regular
,
delicately
formed
,
and
of
the
rarest
and
proudest
class
of
beauty
.
<EOS>
She
was
attired
in
a
dress
of
black
wrought
velvet
,
entirely
without
ornament
except
the
rosary
at
her
girdle
,
with
a
small
ebony
crucifix
attached
to
it
.
<EOS>
She
wore
a
close
-
fitting
cap
,
likewise
of
black
velvet
,
edged
with
pearls
,
beneath
which
her
raven
tresses
were
gathered
in
such
a
manner
as
to
display
most
becomingly
the
smooth
and
snowy
expanse
of
her
forehead
.
<EOS>
The
gravity
of
her
manner
,
not
less
than
her
charms
of
person
,
seem
to
have
struck
Catesby
mute
.
<EOS>
He
gazed
on
her
in
silent
admiration
for
a
brief
space
,
utterly
forgetful
of
the
object
of
his
visit
,
and
the
part
he
intended
to
play
.
<EOS>
During
this
pause
,
she
maintained
the
most
perfect
composure
,
and
fixing
her
dark
eyes
full
upon
him
,
appeared
to
await
the
moment
when
he
might
choose
to
open
the
conversation
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
his
age
,
and
the
dissolute
and
distracted
life
he
had
led
,
Catesby
was
still
good
-
looking
enough
to
have
produced
a
favourable
impression
upon
any
woman
easily
captivated
by
manly
beauty
.
<EOS>
The
very
expression
of
his
marked
and
peculiar
physiognomy,—in
some
degree
an
index
to
his
character,—was
sufficient
to
rivet
attention
;
and
the
mysterious
interest
generally
inspired
by
his
presence
was
not
diminished
on
further
acquaintance
with
him
.
<EOS>
Though
somewhat
stern
in
their
expression
,
his
features
were
strikingly
handsome
,
cast
in
an
oval
mould
,
and
clothed
with
the
pointed
beard
and
trimmed
mustaches
invariably
met
with
in
the
portraits
of
Vandyck
.
<EOS>
His
frame
was
strongly
built
,
but
well
proportioned
,
and
seemed
capable
of
enduring
the
greatest
fatigue
.
<EOS>
His
dress
was
that
of
an
ordinary
gentleman
of
the
period
,
and
consisted
of
a
doublet
of
quilted
silk
,
of
sober
colour
and
stout
texture
;
large
trunk
-
hose
swelling
out
at
the
hips
;
and
buff
boots
,
armed
with
spurs
with
immense
rowels
.
<EOS>
He
wore
a
high
and
stiffly
-
starched
ruff
round
his
throat
;
and
his
apparel
was
completed
by
a
short
cloak
of
brown
cloth
,
lined
with
silk
of
a
similar
colour
.
<EOS>
His
arms
were
rapier
and
poniard
,
and
his
high
-
crowned
plumed
hat
,
of
the
peculiar
form
then
in
vogue
,
and
looped
on
the
"
leer
-
side
"
with
a
diamond
clasp
,
was
thrown
upon
the
table
.
<EOS>
Some
little
time
having
elapsed
,
during
which
he
made
no
effort
to
address
her
,
Viviana
broke
silence
.
<EOS>
"I
understood
you
desired
to
speak
with
me
on
a
matter
of
urgency
,
Mr.
Catesby
,
"
she
remarked
.
<EOS>
"I
did
so
,
"
he
replied
,
as
if
aroused
from
a
reverie
;
"
and
I
can
only
excuse
my
absence
of
mind
and
ill
manners
,
on
the
plea
that
the
contemplation
of
your
charms
has
driven
all
other
matter
out
of
my
head
.
<EOS>
""Mr
.
<EOS>
Catesby
,
"
returned
Viviana
,
rising
,
"
if
the
purpose
of
your
visit
be
merely
to
pay
unmerited
compliments
,
I
must
at
once
put
an
end
to
it
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
have
only
obeyed
the
impulse
of
my
heart
,
"
resumed
the
other
,
passionately
,
"
and
uttered
what
involuntarily
rose
to
my
lips
.
<EOS>
But
,
"
he
added
,
checking
himself
,
"
I
will
not
offend
you
with
my
admiration
.
<EOS>
If
you
have
read
my
letter
to
your
father
,
you
will
not
require
to
be
informed
of
the
object
of
my
visit
.
<EOS>
""I
have
not
read
it
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
returning
him
the
packet
with
the
seal
unbroken
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
give
no
opinion
on
any
matter
of
difficulty
.
<EOS>
And
I
have
no
desire
to
know
any
secret
with
which
my
father
might
not
desire
me
to
be
acquainted
.
<EOS>
""Are
<EOS>
we
overheard
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Catesby
,
glancing
suspiciously
at
the
fire
-
place
.
<EOS>
"By
<EOS>
no
one
whom
you
would
care
to
overhear
us
,
"
returned
the
maiden
.
<EOS>
"Then
<EOS>
it
is
as
I
supposed
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
Father
Oldcorne
is
concealed
behind
that
mantel
-
piece?"Viviana
smiled
an
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"Let
<EOS>
him
come
forth
<EOS>
,
I
pray
you
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
What
I
have
to
say
concerns
him
as
much
as
yourself
or
your
father
;
and
I
would
gladly
have
his
voice
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
shall
have
it
,
my
son
<EOS>
,
"
replied
a
reverend
personage
,
clad
in
a
priestly
garb
,
stepping
from
out
one
side
of
the
mantel
-
piece
,
which
flew
suddenly
open
,
disclosing
a
recess
curiously
contrived
in
the
thickness
of
the
wall
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
it
,
"
said
Father
Oldcorne
,
for
he
it
was
,
approaching
and
extending
his
arms
over
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Accept
my
blessing
and
my
welcome
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
<EOS>
received
the
benediction
with
bowed
head
and
bended
knee
.
"And
<EOS>
now
,
"
continued
the
priest
,
"
what
has
the
bravest
soldier
of
our
church
to
declare
to
its
lowliest
<EOS>
servant?"Catesby
then
briefly
explained
,
as
he
had
before
done
to
the
steward
,
why
he
had
taken
Manchester
in
his
route
to
North
Wales
;
and
,
after
lamenting
his
inability
to
render
any
assistance
to
the
unfortunate
priests
,
he
went
on
to
state
that
he
had
accidentally
learnt
,
from
a
few
words
<EOS>
let
fall
by
the
pursuivant
to
his
attendant
,
that
a
warrant
had
been
sent
by
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
for
Sir
William
Radcliffe
's
arrest
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
father
's
arrest
!
"
exclaimed
Viviana
,
trembling
violently
.
<EOS>
"
What
—
what
is
laid
to
his
charge?""Felony
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
sternly—"felony
,
without
benefit
of
clergy
—
for
so
it
is
accounted
by
the
present
execrable
laws
of
our
land,—in
harbouring
a
Jesuit
priest
.
<EOS>
If
he
is
convicted
of
the
offence
,
his
punishment
will
be
death
—
death
on
the
gibbet
,
accompanied
by
indignities
worse
than
those
shown
to
a
common
felon
.
<EOS>
""Holy
<EOS>
Virgin
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Father
Oldcorne
,
lifting
up
his
hands
,
and
raising

eyes
to

.
<EOS>
"From
what
I
gathered
,
the
officers
will
visit
this
house
to
-
night
,
"
continued
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"Our
<EOS>
Lady
be
praised
,
they
will
not
find
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
who
had
been
thrown
into
an
agony

.
<EOS>
"
What
is
to

in
this

,

father
?
"
she

,
turning
to
the
priest
,
with
a

.
<EOS>
"Heaven
<EOS>
only
knows
,
dear
daughter
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
appeal
for
counsel
to
one
who
is
more
able
to

than
I
am,—Mr
.
<EOS>
Catesby
.
<EOS>
Well

of
the

of
our

,
and
having
often
eluded
their
snares
himself
,
he
may
enable
you
to
escape

.
<EOS>
My
own
course
is
clear
.
<EOS>
I
shall
quit
this
roof
at
once
,
deeply
and
bitterly
regretting
that
by
entering
it
,
I
have
placed

so

,
and
from

have

so

,
in

.
<EOS>
""Oh
,
no
,
father
!
"
exclaimed
Viviana
,
"
you
shall
not
go
.
<EOS>
""Daughter
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
,
solemnly
,
"
I
have
long
borne
the
cross
of
Christ,—have
long

the
stripes
,
inflicted
upon

by
the

of
our
faith
,
in
patience
;
and
my
last

and

testify
to
the
truth
of
our

.
<EOS>
But
,
though
I
could
endure
aught
on

,
I
can
not

to
bring
misery
and

upon
others
.
<EOS>
Hinder
me
not
,
dear
daughter
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
at
once
.
<EOS>
""Hold
,
father
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
The
step
you
would
take
may
bring
about
what
you
are
most

to
avoid
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
discovered
and
apprehended
in
this

,

to

,
and

will

.
<EOS>
Tarry
where
you
are
.
<EOS>
Let

make

search
.
<EOS>
I
will
engage
to
baffle

.
<EOS>
""He
speaks
the
truth
,
dear

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

—

.
<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
""Whatever

"

,

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
""My

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
""The

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

.
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"So

<EOS>
"Forgive

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
""Rise
,

,
"

,

.

"

,

.

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
""You
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

"

"

<EOS>
In

.

""In

!
"

.

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
""Ay
,

,

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
Redemption
draweth
nigh
;
the
year
of

approacheth
to

;
and

.
<EOS>
England
shall
again

called

,

.
<EOS>
Those

.
<EOS>
Righteousness
shall
prosper
,
and

be

.
<EOS>
False
error

,

?
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Proud

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Repent
,
ye

,
with
speed
,
and
prevent

dreadful
wrath
of
the
Powerable
.
<EOS>
He
will
come
as
flame
that
burneth
out
beyond

.
<EOS>
His
fury
shall
fly
forth
as

,
and
pitch
upon
their
tops
that
malign

.
<EOS>
They
shall
perish
in
his
fury
,
and

.
<EOS>
""Amen
!
"
<EOS>

,

,
"

<EOS>
""Neglect

"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Gentem
auferte

Credentium

,
Ut

Persolvamus

.
"After

.
<EOS>
His
steed

;
and

,

,
which

,

.
<EOS>
IV
.
—
<EOS>
THE
SEARCHImmediately
after
Catesby
's
departure
,
Heydocke
was
summoned
to
his
mistress
's
presence
.
<EOS>
He
found
her
with
the
priest
,
and
was
informed
that
in
all
probability
the
house
would
be
visited
that
night
by
the
messengers
of
the
Privy
Council
.
<EOS>
The
old
steward
received
the
intelligence
as
he
might
have
done
his
death
-
warrant
,
and
looked
so
bewildered
and
affrighted
,
that
Viviana
half
repented
having
acquainted
him
with
it
.
"Compose
<EOS>
yourself
,
Master
Heydocke
,
"
she
said
,
trying
to
reason
him
out
of
his
fears
;
"
the
search
may
not
take
place
.
<EOS>
And
if
it
does
,
there
is
nothing
to
be
alarmed
at
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
afraid
,
you
perceive
.
<EOS>
""Nothing
to
be
alarmed
at
,
my
dear
young
lady
!
"
gasped
the
steward
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
never
witnessed
a
midnight
search
for
a
priest
by
these
ruffianly
catchpoles
,
as
I
have
,
or
you
would
not
say
so
.
<EOS>
Father
Oldcorne
will
comprehend
my
uneasiness
,
and
excuse
it
.
<EOS>
The
miscreants
break
into
the
house
like
robbers
,
and
treat
its
inmates
worse
than
robbers
would
treat
them
.
<EOS>
They
have
no
regard
for
decency,—no
consideration
for
sex,—no
respect
for
persons
.
<EOS>
Not
a
chamber
is
sacred
from
them
.
<EOS>
If
a
door
is
bolted
,
they
burst
it
open
;
a
cabinet
locked
,
they
tarry
not
for
the
key
.
<EOS>
They
pull
down
the
hangings
,
thrust
their
rapier
-
points
into
the
crevices
of
the
wainscot
,
discharge
their
fire
-
arms
against
the
wall
,
and
sometimes
threaten
to
pull
down
the
house
itself
,
if
the
object
of
their
quest
be
not
delivered
to
them
.
<EOS>
Their
oaths
,
abominations
,
and
menaces
are
horrible
;
and
their
treatment
of
females
,
even
of
your
degree
,
honoured
mistress
,
too
barbarous
to
relate
.
<EOS>
Poor
Lady
Nevil
died
of
the
fright
she
got
by
such
a
visit
at
dead
of
night
to
her
residence
in
Holborn
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Vavasour
,
of
York
,
lost
her
senses
;
and
many
others
whom
I
could
mention
have
been
equal
sufferers
.
<EOS>
Nothing
to
be
alarmed
at
!
<EOS>
Heaven
grant
,
my
dear
,
dear
young
lady
,
that
you
may
never
be
fatally
convinced
to
the
contrary!""Suppose
my
apprehensions
are
as
great
as
your
own
,
Master
Heydocke
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
who
,
though
somewhat
infected
by
his
terrors
,
still
maintained
her
firmness
;
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
see
how
the
danger
is
to
be
averted
by
idle
lamentations
and
misgivings
.
<EOS>
We
must
meet
it
boldly
;
and
trust
to
Him
who
is
our
only
safeguard
in
the
hour
of
peril
,
for
protection
.
<EOS>
Do
not
alarm
the
household
,
but
let
all
retire
to
rest
as
usual
.
<EOS>
""Right
,
daughter
,
"
observed
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Preparations
for
resistance
would
only
excite
suspicion
.
<EOS>
""Can
<EOS>
you
depend
on
the
servants
,
in
case
they
are
examined
?
"
asked
Viviana
of
the
steward
,
who
by
this
time
had
partially
recovered
his
composure
.
<EOS>
"I
think
so
,
"
returned
Heydocke
;
"
but
the
threats
of
the
officers
are
so
dreadful
,
and
their
conduct
so
violent
and
outrageous
,
that
I
can
scarcely
answer
for
myself
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
advise
your
reverence
to
remain
in
that
hiding
-
place
,
"
he
added
,
pointing
to
the
chimney
-
piece
;
"
they
are
sure
to
discover
it
.
<EOS>
""If
not
here
<EOS>
,
where
shall
I
conceal
myself
?
"
rejoined
Oldcorne
,
uneasily
.
<EOS>
"There
<EOS>
are
many
nooks
in
which
your
reverence
might
hide
,
"
replied
the
steward
;
"
but
the
knaves
are
so
crafty
,
and
so
well
experienced
in
their
vocation
,
that
I
dare
not
recommend
any
of
them
as
secure
.
<EOS>
I
would
advise
you
to
remain
on
the
watch
,
and
,
in
case
of
alarm
,
I
will
conduct
you
to
the
oratory
in
the
north
gallery
,
adjoining
Mistress
Viviana
's
sleeping
-
chamber
,
where
there
is
a
panel
in
the
wall
,
known
only
to
myself
and
my
master
,
opening
upon
a
secret
passage
running
many
hundred
yards
underground
,
and
communicating
with
a
small
outbuilding
on
the
other
side
of
the
moat
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
contrivance
in
this
passage
,
which
I
will
explain
to
your
reverence
if
need
be
,
which
will
cut
off
any
possibility
of
pursuit
in
that
quarter
.
<EOS>
""Be
it
<EOS>
so
,
"
replied
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"
I
place
myself
in
your
hands
,
good
Master
Heydocke
,
well
assured
of
your
fidelity
.
<EOS>
I
shall
remain
throughout
the
night
in
this
chamber
,
occupied
in
my
devotions
.
<EOS>
""You
will
suffer
me
to
pray
with
you
,
father
,
I
trust
?
"
said
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
you
desire
it
,
assuredly
,
dear
daughter
,
"
rejoined
Oldcorne
;
"
but
I
am
unwilling
you
should
sacrifice
your
rest
.
<EOS>
""It
will
be
no
sacrifice
,
father
,
for
I
should
not
slumber
,
even
if
I
sought
my
couch
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"
Go
,
good
Heydocke
.
<EOS>
Keep
vigilant
watch
:
and
,
if
you
hear
the
slightest
noise
without
,
fail
not
to
give
us
warning
.
<EOS>
"The
steward
bowed
,
and
departed
.
<EOS>
Some
hours
elapsed
,
during
which
nothing
occurred
to
alarm
Viviana
and
her
companion
,
who
consumed
the
time
in
prayer
and
devout
conversation
;
when
,
just
at
the
stroke
of
two,—as
the
former
was
kneeling
before
her
spiritual
adviser
,
and
receiving
absolution
for
the
slight
offences
of
which
a
being
so
pure
-
minded
could
be
supposed
<EOS>
capable,—a
noise
like
the
falling
of
a
bar
of
iron
was
heard
beneath
the
window
.
<EOS>
The
priest
turned
pale
,
and
cast
a
look
of
uneasiness
at
the
maiden
,
who
said
nothing
,
but
snatching
up
the
light
,
and
motioning
him
to
remain
quiet
,
hurried
out
of
the
room
in
search
of
the
steward
.
<EOS>
He
was
nowhere
to
be
found
.
<EOS>
In
vain
,
she
examined
all
the
lower
rooms,—in
vain
,
called
to
him
by
name
.
<EOS>
No
answer
was
returned
.
<EOS>
Greatly
terrified
,
she
was
preparing
to
retrace
her
steps
,
when
she
heard
the
sound
of
muttered
voices
in
the
hall
.
<EOS>
Extinguishing
her
light
,
she
advanced
to
the
door
,
which
was
left
ajar
,
and
,
taking
care
not
to
expose
herself
to
observation
,
beheld
several
armed
figures
,
some
of
whom
bore
dark
lanterns
,
while
others
surrounded
and
menaced
with
their
drawn
swords
the
unfortunate
steward
.
<EOS>
From
their
discourse
she
ascertained
that
,
having
thrown
a
plank
across
the
moat
,
and
concealed
themselves
within
the
garden
until
they
had
reconnoitred
the
premises
,
they
had
contrived
to
gain
admittance
unperceived
through
the
window
of
a
small
back
room
,
in
which
they
had
surprised
Heydocke
,
who
had
fallen
asleep
on
his
post
,
and
captured
him
.
<EOS>
One
amongst
their
number
,
who
appeared
to
act
as
leader
,
and
whom
,
from
his
garb
,
and
the
white
wand
he
carried
,
Viviana
knew
must
be
a
pursuivant
,
now
proceeded
to
interrogate
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
To
every
question
proposed
to
him
the
steward
shook
his
head
;
and
,
in
spite
of
the
threats
of
the
examinant
,
and
the
blows
of
his
followers
,
he
persisted
in
maintaining
silence
.
<EOS>
"If
we
can
not
make
this
contumacious
rascal
speak
,
we
will
find
others
more
tractable
,
"
observed
the
pursuivant
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
leave
any
corner
of
the
house
unvisited
;
nor
a
soul
within
it
unquestioned
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
here
they
come!"As
he
spoke
,
several
of
the
serving
-
men
,
with
some
of
the
female
domestics
,
who
had
been
alarmed
by
the
noise
,
rushed
into
the
hall
,
and
on
seeing
it
filled
with
armed
men
,
were
about
to
retreat
,
when
they
were
instantly
seized
and
detained
.
<EOS>
A
scene
of
great
confusion
now
ensued
.
<EOS>
The
women
screamed
and
cried
for
mercy
,
while
the
men
struggled
and
fought
with
their
captors
.
<EOS>
Commanding
silence
at
length
,
the
pursuivant
proclaimed
in
the
King
's
name
that
whoever
would
guide
him
to
the
hiding
-
place
of
Father
Oldcorne
,
a
Jesuit
priest
,
whom
it
was
known
,
and
could
be
proved
,
was
harboured
within
the
mansion
,
should
receive
a
free
pardon
and
reward
;
while
those
who
screened
him
,
or
connived
at
his
concealment
,
were
liable
to
fine
,
imprisonment
,
and
even
more
severe
punishment
.
<EOS>
Each
servant
was
then
questioned
separately
.
<EOS>
But
,
though
all
were
more
or
less
rudely
dealt
with
,
no
information
could
be
elicited
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Viviana
was
a
prey
to
the
most
intolerable
anxiety
.
<EOS>
Unable
to
reach
Father
Oldcorne
without
crossing
the
hall
,
which
she
did
not
dare
to
attempt
,
she
gave
him
up
for
lost
;
her
sole
hope
being
that
,
on
hearing
the
cries
of
the
domestics
,
he
would
provide
for
his
own
safety
.
<EOS>
Her
anxiety
was
still
farther
increased
when
the
pursuivant
,
having
exhausted
his
patience
by
fruitless
interrogatories
,
and
satisfied
his
malice
by
frightening
two
of
the
females
into
fits
,
departed
with
a
portion
of
his
band
to
search
the
house
,
leaving
the
rest
as
a
guard
over
the
prisoners
.
<EOS>
Viviana
then
felt
that
,
if
she
would
save
Father
Oldcorne
,
the
attempt
must
be
made
without
a
moment
's
delay
,
and
at
any
hazard
.
<EOS>
Watching
her
opportunity
,
when
the
troopers
were
occupied,—some
in
helping
themselves
to
such
viands
and
liquors
as
they
could
lay
hands
upon,—some
in
searching
the
persons
of
the
prisoners
for
amulets
and
relics,—while
others
,
more
humane
,
were
trying
to
revive
the
swooning
women
,
she
contrived
to
steal
unperceived
across
the
lower
end
of
the
hall
.
<EOS>
Having
gained
the
passage
,
she
found
to
her
horror
that
the
pursuivant
and
his
band
were
already
within
the
star
-
chamber
.
<EOS>
They
were
sounding
the
walls
with
hammers
and
mallets
,
and
from
their
exclamations
,
she
learnt
that
they
had
discovered
the
retreat
behind
the
fire
-
place
,
and
were
about
to
break
it
open
.
<EOS>
"We
<EOS>
have
him
,
"
roared
the
pursuivant
,
in
a
voice
of
triumph
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
old
owl
's
roost
is
here!"Viviana
,
who
stood
at
the
door
,
drew
in
her
breath
,
expecting
that
the
next
moment
would
inform
her
that
the
priest
was
made
captive
.
<EOS>
Instead
of
this
,
she
was
delighted
to
find
,
from
the
oaths
of
rage
and
disappointment
uttered
by
the
troopers
,
that
he
had
eluded
them
.
<EOS>
"He
must
be
in
the
house
,
at
all
events
,
"
growled
the
pursuivant
;
"
nor
is
it
long
since
he
quitted
his
hiding
-
place
,
as
this
cushion
proves
.
<EOS>
We
will
not
go
away
without
him
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
let
us
proceed
to
the
upper
chambers
.
<EOS>
"Hearing
<EOS>
their
footsteps
approach
,
Viviana
darted
off
,
and
quickly
ascending
the
principal
staircase
,
entered
a
long
corridor
.
<EOS>
Uncertain
what
to
do
,
she
was
about
to
proceed
to
her
own
chamber
,
and
bar
the
door
,
when
she
felt
her
arm
grasped
by
a
man
.
<EOS>
With
difficulty
repressing
a
shriek
,
she
strove
to
disengage
herself
,
when
a
whisper
told
her
it
was
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"Heaven
be
praised
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
<EOS>
"
you
are
safe
.
<EOS>
How
—
how
did
you
escape?""I
flew
upstairs
on
hearing
the
voices
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"
But
what
has
happened
to
the
steward?""He
is
a
prisoner
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
then
is
lost
,
unless
you
are
acquainted
with
the
secret
panel
he
spoke
of
in
the
oratory
,
"
rejoined
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"Alas
!
<EOS>
father
,
I
am
wholly
ignorant
of
it
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"
But
,
come
with
me
into
my
chamber
;
they
will
not
dare
to
invade
it
.
<EOS>
""I
know
not
that
,
"
returned
the
priest
,
despairingly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
These
sacrilegious
villains
would
not
respect
the
sanctity
of
the
altar
itself
.
<EOS>
""They
come
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
as
lights
were
seen
at
the
foot
of
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
"
Take
my
hand
—
this
way
,
father
.
<EOS>
"They
had
scarcely
gained
the
room
,
and
fastened
the
door
,
when
the
pursuivant
and
his
attendants
appeared
in
the
corridor
.
<EOS>
The
officer
,
it
would
seem
,
had
been
well
instructed
where
to
search
,
or
was
sufficiently
practised
in
his
duty
,
for
he
proceeded
at
once
to
several
hiding
-
places
in
the
different
chambers
which
he
visited
.
<EOS>
In
one
room
he
detected
a
secret
staircase
in
the
wall
,
which
he
mounted
,
and
discovered
a
small
chapel
built
in
the
roof
.
<EOS>
Stripping
it
of
its
altar
,
its
statue
of
the
Virgin
,
its
crucifix
,
pix
,
chalice
,
and
other
consecrated
vessels
,
he
descended
,
and
continued
his
search
.
<EOS>
Viviana
's
chamber
was
now
the
only
one
unvisited
.
<EOS>
Trying
the
door
,
and
finding
it
locked
,
he
tapped
against
it
with
his
wand
.
"Who
<EOS>
knocks
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
maiden
.
<EOS>
"A
state
-
messenger
,
"
was
the
reply
.
<EOS>
"
I
demand
entrance
in
the
King
's
name
.
<EOS>
""You
can
not
have
it
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
sleeping
-
chamber
.
<EOS>
""My
duty
allows
me
no
alternative
,
"
rejoined
the
pursuivant
,
harshly
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
not
admit
me
quietly
,
I
must
use
force
.
<EOS>
""Do
<EOS>
you
know
to
whom
you
offer
this
rudeness
?
"
returned
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
the
daughter
of
Sir
William
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
know
it
,
"
replied
the
pursuivant
;
"
but
I
am
not
exceeding
my
authority
.
<EOS>
I
hold
a
warrant
for
your
father
's
arrest
.
<EOS>
And
,
if
he
had
not
been
from
home
,
I
should
have
carried
him
to
prison
along
with
the
Jesuit
priest
<EOS>
whom
,
I
suspect
,
is
concealed
within
your
chamber
.
<EOS>
Open
the
door
,
I
command
you
;
and
do
not
hinder
me
in
the
execution
of
my
duty
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
no
answer
was
returned
to
the
application
,
the
pursuivant
commanded
his
men
to
burst
open
the
door
;
and
the
order
was
promptly
obeyed
.
<EOS>
The
chamber
was
empty
.
<EOS>
On
searching
it
,
however
,
the
pursuivant
found
a
door
concealed
by
the
hangings
of
the
bed
.
<EOS>
It
was
bolted
on
the
other
side
,
but
speedily
yielded
to
his
efforts
.
<EOS>
Passing
through
it
,
he
entered
upon
a
narrow
gallery
,
at
the
extremity
of
which
his
progress
was
stopped
by
another
door
,
likewise
fastened
on
the
further
side
.
<EOS>
On
bursting
it
open
,
he
entered
a
small
oratory
,
wainscoted
with
oak
,
and
lighted
by
an
oriel
window
filled
with
stained
glass
,
through
which
the
newly
-
risen
moon
was
pouring
its
full
radiance
,
and
discovered
the
object
of
his
search
.
<EOS>
"Father
<EOS>
Oldcorne
,
I
arrest
you
as
a
Jesuit
and
a
traitor
,
"
shouted
the
pursuivant
,
in
a
voice
of
exultation
.
<EOS>
"
Seize
him
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
calling
to
his
men
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
shall
not
take
him
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
clinging
despairingly
to
the
priest
,
who
offered
no
resistance
,
but
clasped
a
crucifix
to
his
breast
.
<EOS>
"Leave
<EOS>
go
your
hold
,
young

,
"
rejoined
the
pursuivant
,
grasping
Oldcorne
by
the
collar
of
his

,
and
dragging
him
along
;
"
and
rest
thankful
that
I
make
you
not
,
also
,
my
prisoner
.
<EOS>
""Take
me
;
but
spare
him!—in
mercy

!
<EOS>
"
shrieked
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
solicit
mercy
from
one
who
knows
it
not
,
daughter
,
"
observed
the
priest
.
"
<EOS>
Lead
on
,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
am
ready
to
attend
you
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
destination
is
the
New
Fleet
,
father
,
"
retorted
the
pursuivant
,
in

tone

;
"
unless

prefer
the
cell
in
Radcliffe
Hall
lately

by

,
Father
Woodroofe
.
<EOS>
""Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
<EOS>
"

Viviana
.
<EOS>
"You
may
spare
your
voice
,
fair

,
"
sneered

.
"
<EOS>
No
help
is
at
hand
.
<EOS>
Your
servants
are
all
prisoners
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
words
were
scarcely
uttered
,
when
a
sliding
panel
in
the
wall
flew
open
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
,
followed
by
Humphrey
Chetham
,
and
another

,
sprang
through
the

,
and
presented
a

at
the
head

the
