.
<EOS>
V.
—
<EOS>
CHAT
MOSSThe
pursuivant
was
taken
so
completely
unawares
by
the
sudden
appearance
of
Guy
Fawkes
and
his
companions
,
that
he
made
no
attempt
at
resistance
.
<EOS>
Nor
were
his
attendants
less
confounded
.
<EOS>
Before
they
recovered
from
their
surprise
,
Humphrey
Chetham
seized
Viviana
in
his
arms
,
and
darting
through
the
panel
,
called
to
the
priest
to
follow
him
.
<EOS>
Father
Oldcorne
was
about
to
comply
,
when
one
of
the
soldiers
,
grasping
the
surcingle
at
his
waist
,
dragged
him
forcibly
backwards
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
however
,
he
was
set
free
by
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
,
felling
the
man
to
the
ground
,
and
interposing
himself
between
the
priest
and
the
other
soldier
,
enabled
the
former
to
make
good
his
retreat
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
planted
himself
in
front
of
the
panel
,
and
with
a
petronel
in
each
hand
,
menaced
his
opponents
.
<EOS>
"Fly
<EOS>
for
your
lives
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
shouted
in
a
loud
voice
to
the
others
.
"
<EOS>
Not
a
moment
is
to
be
lost
.
<EOS>
I
have
taken
greater
odds
,
and
in
a
worse
cause
,
and
have
not
been
worsted
.
<EOS>
Heed
me
not
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
I
will
defend
the
passage
till
you
are
beyond
reach

.
<EOS>
Fly!—fly!""After
them
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
the
pursuivant
,
stamping
with
rage
and
vexation
;
"
after
them
instantly
!
<EOS>
Hew
down
that
bold
traitor
.
<EOS>
Show
him
no
quarter
.
<EOS>
His
life
is
forfeit
to
the
king
.
<EOS>
Slay
him
as
you
would
a
dog!"But
the
men
,
having
no

arms
,
were
so
much

by
the

Guy

,

,
that

's

.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
you
hear

,

?
"
roared

.
"
<EOS>
Cut
him
down
without

.
<EOS>
""They
dare
not
move

,
"
rejoined
Guy
Fawkes
,
in
a

.
<EOS>
Illustration"Recreants
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
pursuivant
,
foaming
with
rage
,
"
is
my
prey
to
be
snatched
from
me
at
the
very
moment
I
have
secured

,
through

?
<EOS>
Obey

,

,

,

to
my
Lord
Derby

in

's

<EOS>
you

.
<EOS>
What!—are
<EOS>
you
afraid

one
man?""Our
pikes
<EOS>
are
no
match

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"They

,
"

Guy
Fawkes
;
"
and

will
do
well
not

.
<EOS>
As

,

,
"

,

,
"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"Ha
!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
You

in

.
<EOS>
""I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
""I

"

.
<EOS>
"
But

.
<EOS>
""I

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

!
"

,

"

.
<EOS>
""Be

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
""I

,
"

;
"
our

.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
it

,
"

Fawkes
,

,

.
<EOS>
"Confusion
!
"

pursuivant
;
"
but
he
shall
not

.
<EOS>
Break
open
the
panel
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
order
was
promptly

.
<EOS>
The
men
battered
the
stout
oak
board
,
which
was
of
great
thickness
,
with
their
pikes
,
but
it
resisted
every
effort
,
nor
was

until
the
arrival
of
a
fresh
band
of

with

,

,

,

to

,
that
it
could
be
forced
open
.
<EOS>
This
accomplished
,
the
pursuivant
,
commanding
his
attendants
to
follow
him
,
dashed
through
the
aperture
.
<EOS>
As
they
proceeded
singly
along
the
narrow
passage
,
the
roof
became
so
low
that
they
were
compelled
to
adopt
a
stooping
posture
.
<EOS>
In
this
manner
they
hurried
on
until
their
further
progress
was
stopped
by
a
massive
stone
door
,
which
appeared
to
descend
from
above
by
some
hidden
contrivance
,
no
trace
of
bolt
or
other
fastening
being
discernible
.
<EOS>
The
flag
fitted
closely
in
channels
in
the
walls
,
and
had
all
the
appearance
of
solid
masonry
.
<EOS>
After
examining
this
obstacle
for
a
moment
,
the
pursuivant
was
convinced
that
any
attempt
to
move
it
would
be
impracticable
,
and
muttering
a
deep
execration
,
he
gave
the
word
to
return
.
<EOS>
"From
the
course
it
appears
to
take
,
"
he
observed
,
"
this
passage
must
communicate
with
the
garden,—perhaps
with
the
further
side
of
the
moat
.
<EOS>
We
may
yet
secure
them
,
if
we
use
despatch
.
<EOS>
"To
return
to
the
fugitives
.
<EOS>
On
arriving
at
the
point
where
the
stone
door
was
situated
,
which
he
discovered
by
the
channels
in
the
wall
above
-
mentioned
,
Guy
Fawkes
searched
for
an
iron
ring
,
and
,
having
found
it
,
drew
it
towards
him
,
and
the
ponderous
flag
slowly
dropped
into
its
place
.
<EOS>
He
then
groped
his
way
cautiously
along
in
the
dark
,
until
his
foot
encountered
the
top
of
a
ladder
,
down
which
he
crept
,
and
landed
on
the
floor
of
a
damp
deep
vault
.
<EOS>
Having
taken
the
precaution
to
remove
the
ladder
,
he
hastened
onwards
for
about
fifty
yards
,
when
he
came
to
a
steep
flight
of
stone
steps
,
distinguishable
by
a
feeble
glimmer
of
light
from
above
,
and
mounting
them
,
emerged
through
an
open
trap
-
door
into
a
small
building
situated
at
the
western
side
of
the
moat
,
where
,
to
his
surprise
and

,
he
found
the
other

.
<EOS>
"How
<EOS>
comes
it
you
are
here
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
in

tone
.
<EOS>
"
I
kept
the
wolves
at
bay
thus
long
,
to
enable
you
to
make
good

retreat
.
<EOS>
""Miss
<EOS>
Radcliffe
is
too
weak
to
move
,
"
replied
Humphrey
Chetham
;
"
and
I
could
not

Father
Oldcorne
to

.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
care
not
what
becomes

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
The

race
is
run

.
<EOS>
But
I
cannot
—
will
not

.
<EOS>
""Think
<EOS>
not
of
me
,
father
,

,
"

,
who
had

.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
better
soon
.
<EOS>
Master

,
I

,
will

,

I

to

.
<EOS>
""Command

please

Miss
Radcliffe
,
"

Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
but
to
express
a
wish
to
insure
its
fulfilment
on
my
part
.
<EOS>
""Oh
!
<EOS>
that
you
had
suffered
Mr.
Catesby
to
tarry
with
us
till
the
morning
,
as
he
himself

,
dear
daughter
,
"

,

.
"Has
<EOS>
Catesby
been
here
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Guy
Fawkes
,

look

.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
has
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"
He
came
to
warn

that

hall

this
night

by
the
officers
of

;
and

.
<EOS>
""Where

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"On
<EOS>
the
way

Chester
<EOS>
,

,
at

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"This

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
Catesby
here
,
and
I
not

had
a
secret

for

,
my

,
"

Oldcorne
,
significantly
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
I

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"Viviana
<EOS>
Radcliffe
,
"
murmured
Humphrey
Chetham
,
in
low
and
tender
accents
,
"
something
tells
me
that
this
moment
will
decide
my
future
fate
.
<EOS>
Emboldened
by
the
mysterious
manner
in
which
we
have
been
brought
together
,
and
you
,
as
it
were
,
have
been
thrown
upon
my
protection
,
I
venture
to
declare
the
passion
I
have
long
indulged
for
you;—a
passion
which
,
though
deep
and
fervent
as
ever
agitated
human
bosom
,
has
hitherto
,
from
the
difference
of
our
rank
,
and
yet
more
from
the
difference
of
our
religious
opinions
,
been
without
hope
.
<EOS>
What
has
just
occurred,—added
to
the
peril
in
which
your
worthy
father
stands
,
and
the
difficulties
in
which
you
yourself
will
necessarily
be
involved,—makes
<EOS>
me
cast
aside
all
misgiving
,
and
perhaps
with
too
much
presumption
,
but
with
a
confident
belief
that
the
sincerity
of
my
love
renders
me
not
wholly
undeserving
of
your
regard
,
earnestly
solicit
you
to
give
me
a
husband
's
right
to
watch
over
and
defend
you
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
was
silent
.
<EOS>
But
even
by
the
imperfect
light
the
young
merchant
could
discern
that
her
cheek
was
covered
with
blushes
.
<EOS>
"Your
answer
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
taking
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"You
must
take
it
from
my
lips
,
Master
Chetham
,
"
interposed
the
priest
;
"
Viviana
Radcliffe
never
can
be
yours
.
<EOS>
""Be
pleased
to
let
her
speak
for
herself
,
reverend
sir
,
"
rejoined
the
young
merchant
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"I
represent
her
father
,
and
have
acquainted
you
with
his
determination
,
"
rejoined
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"
Appeal
to
her
,
and
she
will
confirm
my
words
.
<EOS>
""Viviana
,
is
this
true
?
"
asked
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
Does
your
father
object
to
your
union
with
me?"Viviana
answered
by
a
deep
sigh
,
and
gently
withdrew
her
hand
from
the
young
merchant
's
grasp
.
<EOS>
"Then
there
is
no
hope
for
me
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"Alas
!
<EOS>
no
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
nor
for
me
—
of
earthly
affection
.
<EOS>
I
am
already
dead
to
the
world
.
<EOS>
""How
<EOS>
so
?
"
he
asked
.
<EOS>
"I
am
about
to
vow
myself
to
Heaven
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
!
"
exclaimed
the
young
man
,
throwing
himself
at
her
feet
,
"
reflect!—oh
!
<EOS>
reflect
,
before
you
take
this
fatal
—
this
irrevocable
step
.
<EOS>
""Rise
,
sir
,
"
interposed
the
priest
,
sternly
;
"
you
plead
in
vain
.
<EOS>
Sir
William
Radcliffe
will
never
we
d
his
daughter
to
a
heretic
.
<EOS>
In
his
name
I
command
you
to
desist
from
further

.
<EOS>
""I
obey
,
"
replied
Chetham
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"We
<EOS>
lose
time
here
,
"
observed
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
had
been
lost
for
a

.
<EOS>
"
I
will
undertake
to
provide
for
your

,
father
.
<EOS>
But
,
what
must
be
done
with
Viviana
?
<EOS>
She
can
not
be
left
here
.
<EOS>
And
her
return
to
the
hall
would
be
attended
with
danger
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
return
till
the
miscreants
have
quitted

,
"
said
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"Their
<EOS>
departure
is
uncertain
,
"

Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
When
they
are
baulked
of
their
prey
they
sometimes
haunt
a

for
weeks
.
<EOS>
""What
will
become
of
me
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,

.
<EOS>
"It
were
vain
,
I
fear
,
to

to

father
at
Clayton

,

,
"

Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"Your

is
most
kind
,

,
"
replied
Oldcorne
,
"
and
is
duly

.
<EOS>
But
Viviana
will
see
the
propriety
—
on
every

—
of

.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
do
<EOS>
;
I
do
,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"Will
<EOS>
you

yourself
to

protection
?
"
observed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Willingly
,
"
replied
the
priest
,

for

.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
find

,
"
he

,

to

,
"
where
your
father
can

,
and
where
we

this

has
blown

.
<EOS>
""I
know
many
such
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
"
both
in
this
county
and
in
Yorkshire
,
and
will
guide
you

one
.
<EOS>
""My
<EOS>
horses
are
at

,
"
said
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
tied
beneath
the
trees
in
the
avenue
.
<EOS>
My
servant
shall
bring
them
to
the
door
,
"
and
,

to

,
he

to
that

.
<EOS>
"
I
was
riding
hither
an
hour
before

,
"
he

,

Viviana
,
"
to

you

,

pursuivant
mention
his

to
Ordsall

,
to
one

,
when
,
as
I

the

,
this
person
,
"
pointing
to
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
crossed
my
path
,
and
,
seizing
the
bridle
of
my
steed
,
demanded
whether
I
was
a
friend
to
Sir
William
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
I
answered
in
the
affirmative
,
and
desired
to
know
the
motive
of
his
inquiry
.
<EOS>
He
then
told
me
that
the
house
was
invested
by
a
numerous
band
of
armed
men
,
who
had
crossed
the
moat
by
means
of
a
plank
,
and
were
at
that
moment
concealed
within
the
garden
.
<EOS>
This
intelligence
,
besides
filling
me
with
alarm
,
disconcerted
all
my
plans
,
as
I
hoped
to
have
been
beforehand
with
them
—
their
inquisitorial
searches
being
generally
made
at
a
late
hour
,
when
all
the
inmates
of
a
house
intended
to
be
surprised
are
certain
to
have
retired
to
rest
.
<EOS>
While
I
was
bitterly
reproaching
myself
for
my
dilatoriness
,
and
considering
what
course
it
would
be
best
to
pursue
,
my
servant
,
Martin
Heydocke
,
son
to
your
father
's
old

,
who
had
ridden
up
at
the
stranger
's

,
informed

that
he
was
acquainted
with
a
secret
passage
communicating
beneath
the
moat
with
the
hall
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
I
dismounted
;
and
fastening
my
horse
to
a
tree
,
ordered
him
to
lead
me
to
it
without
an
instant
's
delay
.
<EOS>
The
stranger
,
who
gave
his
name
as
Guy
Fawkes
,
and
professed
himself
a
stanch

,
and
a

of
Father
Oldcorne
,
begged
permission
to
join
us
,
in
a

so
earnest
,
that
I
at
once
acceded
to
his
request
.
<EOS>
We
then
proceeded
to
this
building
,
and
after
some
search
discovered
the
trap
-
door
.
<EOS>
Much
time
was
lost
,
owing
to
our
being
unprovided
with
lights
,
in
the
subterranean
passage
;
and
it
was

before

could
find
the
ring
connected
with
the
stone

,
the

of
which
Martin
explained
to

.
<EOS>
This
delay
we
feared
would
render
our
scheme
abortive
,
when
,
just
as
we
reached
the
panel
,
we

your

.
<EOS>
The
spring
was
touched
,
and
—
you
know
the
rest
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
shall
never
forget
it
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
in
a

.
<EOS>
At

,
the

of

was
heard
at
the

;
and

next

the

Heydocke
,
who
,

,

,

,
"
They

<EOS>
are
coming!""The
pursuivant
?
<EOS>
"

Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Not
<EOS>
him

,
but

gang
,
"

Martin
.
<EOS>
"
Some

,
while
others

crossing

.
<EOS>
Several
are
on

,
and
I
think
I
discern
the
pursuivant
amongst
the
number
.
<EOS>
They
have
seen
me
,
and
are
hurrying
in
this
direction
.
<EOS>
"As
he
spoke
,
a

.
<EOS>
"We
are
lost
!
"

.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
not

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Heaven

.
<EOS>
The
Lord
will

out

.
<EOS>
""To
horse
,

,

,
"

Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
The
shouts
grow

.
<EOS>
Your
enemies
are
fast

.
<EOS>
""Viviana
,
"

Fawkes
,
"
are

to

will

anything
rather

to
those

,
"

.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
then
raised
her
in

,
and
sprang

his
lovely

upon
the
nearest

.
<EOS>
His

was
quickly

by
Humphrey
Chetham
,
who
,

on
the
other
horse
,
assisted
the
priest
to

.
<EOS>
While
this
took
place
,
Martin
Heydocke
darted
into
the
shed
,
and
instantly
bolted
the
door
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
beautiful
moonlight
night
,
almost
as
bright
as
day
,
and
the
movements
of
each
party
were
fully
revealed
to
the
other
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
perceived
at
a
glance
that
they
were
surrounded
;
and
,
though
he
had
no
fears
for
himself
,
he
was
full
of
apprehension
for
the
safety
of
his
companion
.
<EOS>
While
he
was
debating
with
himself
as
to
the
course
it
would
be
best
to
pursue
,
Humphrey
Chetham
shouted
to
him
to
turn
to
the
left
,
and
started
off
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
Grasping
his
fair
charge
,
whom
he
had
placed
before
him
on
the
saddle
,
firmly
with
his
left
arm
,
and
wrapping
her
in
his
ample

,
Guy
Fawkes
drew
his
sword
,
and
striking

into
his
steed
,
followed
in
the
same
track
.
<EOS>
The
little
fabric
which
had
afforded
them
temporary
shelter
,
it
has
already
been
mentioned
,
was
situated
on
the
west
of
the
hall
,
at
a
short
distance
from
the
moat
,
and
was
screened
from
observation
by
a
small
shrubbery
.
<EOS>
No
sooner
did
the
fugitives
emerge
from
this
cover
,
than
loud
outcries
were
raised
by
their
antagonists
,
and
every
effort
was
made
to
intercept
them
.
<EOS>
On
the
right
,
galloping
towards
them
on
a
light
but
swift
courser
,
taken
from
Sir
William
Radcliffe
's
stables
,
came
the
pursuivant
,
attended
by
half
-
a
-
dozen
troopers
,
who
had
accommodated
themselves
with
horses
in
the
same
manner
as
their
leader
.
<EOS>
Between
them
and
the
road
leading
to
Manchester
,
were
stationed
several
armed
men
on
foot
.
<EOS>
At
the
rear
,
voices
proclaimed
that
others
were
in
full
pursuit
;
while
in
front
,
a
fourth
detachment
menaced
them
with
their
pikes
.
<EOS>
Thus
beset
on
all
sides
,
it
seemed
scarcely
possible
to
escape
.
<EOS>
Nothing
daunted
,
however
,
by
the
threats
and
vociferations
with
which
they
were
received
,
the
two
horsemen
boldly
charged
this
party
.
<EOS>
The
encounter
was
instantaneous
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
warded
off
a
blow
,
which
,
if
it
had
taken
effect
,
must
have
robbed
Viviana
of
life
,
and
struck
down
the
fellow
who
aimed
it
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
,
his
career
was
checked
by
another
assailant
,
who
,
catching
his
bridle
with
the
hook
of
his
pike
,
commanded
him
to
surrender
.
<EOS>
Fawkes
replied
by
cleaving
the
man
's
staff
asunder
,
and
,
having
thus
disembarrassed
himself
,
was
about
to
pursue
his
course
,
when
he
perceived
that
Humphrey
Chetham
was
in
imminent
danger
from
a
couple
of
soldiers
who
had
stopped
him
,
and
were
trying
to
unhorse
his
companion
.
<EOS>
Riding
up
to
them
,
Guy
Fawkes
,
by
a
vigorous
and
well
-
directed
attack
,
speedily
drove
them
off
;
and
the
fugitives
,
being
now
unimpeded
,
were
enabled
to
continue
their
career
.
<EOS>
The
foregoing
occurrences
were
witnessed
by
the
pursuivant
with
the
utmost
rage
and
vexation
.
<EOS>
Pouring
forth
a
torrent
of
threats
and
imprecations
,
he
swore
he
would
never
rest
till
he
had
secured
them
,
and
urging
his
courser
to
its
utmost
speed
,
commanded
his
men
to
give
chase
.
<EOS>
Skirting
a
sluice
,
communicating
between
the
Irwell
and
the
moat
,
Humphrey
Chetham
,
who
,
as
better
acquainted
with
the
country
than
his
companions
,
took
the
lead
,
proceeded
along
its
edge
for
about
a
hundred
yards
,
when
he
suddenly
struck
across
a
narrow
bridge
covered
with
sod
,
and
entered
the
open
fields
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
Viviana
had
remained
silent
.
<EOS>
Though
fully
aware
of
the
risk
she
had
run
,
she
gave
no
sign
of
alarm
—
not
even
when
the
blow
was
aimed
against
her
life
;
and
it
was
only
on
conceiving
the
danger
in
some
degree
past
,
that
she
ventured
to
express
her
gratitude
.
<EOS>
"You
have
displayed
so
much
courage
,
"
said
Guy
Fawkes
,
in
answer
to
her
speech
,
"
that
it
would
be
unpardonable
to
deceive
you
.
<EOS>
Our
foes
are
too
near
us
,
and
too
well
mounted
,
to
make
it
by
any
means
certain
we
shall
escape
them,—unless
by
stratagem
.
<EOS>
""They
are
within
a
hundred
yards
of
us
,
"
cried
Humphrey
Chetham
,
glancing
fearfully
backwards
.
<EOS>
"
They
have
possessed
themselves
of
your
father
's
fleetest
horses
;
and
,
if
I
mistake
not
,
the
rascally
pursuivant
has
secured
your
favourite
barb
.
<EOS>
""My
<EOS>
gentle
Zayda
!
"

Viviana
.
"
<EOS>
Then
indeed
we
are
lost
.
<EOS>
She
has
not
her
match
for
speed
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
she
bring
her

,

,
"

Fawkes
,
significantly
.
<EOS>
The
same

,
almost

,
occurred
to

.
<EOS>
Having
witnessed

by
Guy

in

,

single

and
finding
that
the
high

by

,

.
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>
They

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chat

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Surveyed

Dunham
,

,
envying

her

to

<EOS>
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Conjecture
fixes

,

;

—

—
being

,
had
choked

,
and
so

to

.
<EOS>
Drayton
,
however
,
in
the
following

from

,

Chat
Moss
at
my
fall
<EOS>
Lies
fall
of

and

,
<EOS>
her
unctuous

;
And
blocks
as

,
<EOS>
with

found
,
There
at
the
General
Flood
supposed

.
<EOS>
But

former

appears
the
more

.
<EOS>
A

,

,

,

,
"

,

by

,
whereby

,

.
<EOS>
Instead
thereof
is
now
a
valley

a

;
and
many

were

thrown

,

,

,

,
(

,
)

.
<EOS>
If

,
no

so

found

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
For

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,
for

,

earth
that
surrounds
them
,
whence
the
common
people
suppose
them
firs
,
though
Cæsar
denies
that
there
were
such
trees
in
Britain
.
<EOS>
"But
,
though
vast
masses
of
the
bog
had
been
carried
off
by
the
Irwell
and
the
Mersey
,
as
related
by
Camden
,
the
general
appearance
of
the
waste,—with
<EOS>
the
exception
of
the
valley
and
the
small
stream,—was
much
the
same
as
it
continued
to
our
own
time
.
<EOS>
Its
surface
was
more
broken
and
irregular
,
and
black
gaping
chasms
and
pits
filled
with
water
and
slime
as
dark
-
coloured
as
the
turf
whence
it
flowed
,
pointed
out
the
spots
where
the
swollen
and
heaving
swamp
had
burst
its
bondage
.
<EOS>
Narrow
paths
,
known
only
to
the
poor
turf
-
cutters
and
other
labourers
who
dwelt
upon
its
borders
,
and
gathered
fuel
with
poles
and
spits
in
the
manner
above
described
,
intersected
it
at
various
points
.
<EOS>
But
as
they
led
in
many
cases
to
dangerous
and
deep
gulfs
,
to
dismal
quagmires
and
fathomless
pits
;
and
,
moreover
,
as
the
slightest
departure
from
the
proper
track
would
have
whelmed
the
traveller
in
an
oozy
bed
,
from
which
,
as
from
a
quicksand
,
he
would
have
vainly
striven
to
extricate
himself,—it
was
never
crossed
without
a
guide
,
except
by
those
familiar
with
its
perilous
courses
.
<EOS>
One
painful
circumstance
connected
with
the
history
of
Chat
Moss
remains
to
be
recorded
—
namely
,
that
the
attempt
made
to
cultivate
it
by
the
great
historian
Roscoe,—an
attempt
since
carried
out
,
as
has
already
been
shown
,
with
complete
success,—ended
in
a
result
ruinous
to
the
fortunes
of
that
highly
-
gifted
person
,
who
,
up
to
the
period
of
this
luckless
undertaking
,
was
as
prosperous
as
he
was
meritorious
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
fugitives
had
approached
the
confines
of
the
marsh
.
<EOS>
An
accident
,
however
,
had
just
occurred
,
which
nearly
proved
fatal
to
Viviana
,
and
,
owing
to
the
delay
it
occasioned
,
brought
their
pursuers
into
dangerous
proximity
with
them
.
<EOS>
In
fording
the
Irwell
,
which
,
from
its
devious
course
,
they
were
again
compelled
to
cross
,
about
a
quarter
of
a
mile
below
Barton
,
her
horse
missed
its
footing
,
and
precipitated
her
into
the
rapid
current
.
<EOS>
In
another
instant
she
would
have
been
borne
away
,
if
Guy
Fawkes
had
not
flung
himself
into
the
water
,
and
seized
her
before
she
sank
.
<EOS>
Her
affrighted
steed
,
having
got
out
of
its
depth
,
began
to
swim
off
,
and
it
required
the
utmost
exertion
on
the
part
of
Humphrey
Chetham
,
embarrassed
as
he
was
by
the
priest
,
to
secure
it
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
all
was
set
to
rights
,
and
Viviana
was
once
more
placed
on
the
saddle
,
without
having
sustained
further
inconvenience
than
was
occasioned
by
her
dripping
apparel
.
<EOS>
But
those
few
minutes
,
as
has
been
just
stated
,
sufficed
to
bring
the
pursuivant
and
his
men
close
upon
them
;
and
as
they
scrambled
up
the
opposite
bank
,
the
plunging
and
shouting
behind
them
told
that
the
latter
had
entered
the
stream
.
<EOS>
"Yonder
<EOS>
is
Baysnape
,
"
exclaimed
Humphrey
Chetham
,
calling
Viviana
's
attention
to
a
ridge
of
high
ground
on
the
borders
of
the
waste
.
<EOS>
"
Below
it
lies
the
path
by
which
I
propose
to
enter
the
moss
.
<EOS>
We
shall
speedily
be
out
of
the
reach
of
our
enemies
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
marsh
at
least
will
hide
us
,
"
answered
Viviana
,
with
a
shudder
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
terrible
alternative
.
<EOS>
""Fear
<EOS>
nothing
,
dear
daughter
,
"
observed
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
saints
,
who
have
thus
marvellously
protected
us
,
will
continue
to
watch
over
us
to
the
end
,
and
will
make
the
path
over
yon
perilous
waste
as
safe
as
the
ground
on
which
we
tread
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
like
not
the
appearance
of
the
sky
,
"
observed
Guy
Fawkes
,
looking
uneasily
upwards
.
<EOS>
"
Before
we
reach
the
spot
you
have
pointed
out
,
the
moon
will
be
obscured
.
<EOS>
Will
it
be
safe
to
traverse
the
moss
in
the
dark?""It
<EOS>
is
our
only
chance
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
,
speaking
in
a
low
tone
,
that
his
answer
might
not
reach
Viviana
's
ears
;
"
and
after
all
,
the
darkness
may
be
serviceable
.
<EOS>
Our
pursuers
are
so
near
,
that
if
it
were
less
gloomy
,
they
might
hit
upon
the
right
track
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
a
risk
to
us
to
proceed
,
but
certain
destruction
to
those
who
follow
.
<EOS>
And
now
let
us
make
what
haste
we
can
.
<EOS>
Every
moment
is
precious
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
dreary
and
fast
darkening
waste
had
now
opened
upon
them
in
all
its
horrors
.
<EOS>
Far
as
the
gaze
could
reach
appeared
an
immense
expanse
,
flat
almost
as
the
surface
of
the
ocean
,
and
unmarked
,
so
far
as
could
be
discerned
in
that
doubtful
light
,
by
any
trace
of
human
footstep
or
habitation
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
stern
and
sombre
prospect
,
and
calculated
to
inspire
terror
in
the
stoutest
bosom
.
<EOS>
What
effect
it
produced
on
Viviana
may
be
easily
conjectured
.
<EOS>
But
her
nature
was
brave
and
enduring
,
and
,
though
she
trembled
so
violently
as
scarcely
to
be
able
to
keep
her
seat
,
she
gave
no
utterance
to
her
fears
.
<EOS>
They
were
now
skirting
that
part
of
the
morass
since
denominated
,
from
the
unfortunate
speculation
previously
alluded
to
,
"
Roscoe
's
Improvements
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
tract
was
the
worst
and
most
dangerous
portion
of
the
whole
moss
.
<EOS>
Soft
,
slabby
,
and
unsubstantial
,
its
treacherous
beds
scarcely
offered
secure
footing
to
the
heron
that
alighted
on
them
.
<EOS>
The
ground
shook
beneath
the
fugitives
as
they
hurried
past
the
edge
of
the
groaning
and
quivering
marsh
.
<EOS>
The
plover
,
scared
from
its
nest
,
uttered
its
peculiar
and
plaintive
cry
;
the
bittern
shrieked
;
other
night
-
fowl
poured
forth
their
doleful
notes
;
and
the
bull
-
frog
added
its
deep
croak
to
the
ominous
concert
.
<EOS>
Behind
them
came
the
thundering
tramp
and
loud
shouts
of
their
pursuers
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
had
judged
correctly
.
<EOS>
Before
they
reached
Baysnape
the
moon
had
withdrawn
behind
a
rack
of
clouds
,
and
it
had
become
profoundly
dark
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
this
point
,
Humphrey
Chetham
called
to
them
to
turn
off
to
the
right
.
<EOS>
"Follow
<EOS>
singly
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
do
not
swerve
a
hair
's
breadth
from
the
path
.
<EOS>
The
slightest
deviation
will
be
fatal
.
<EOS>
Do
you
,
sir
,
"
he
added
to
the
priest
,
"
mount
behind
Guy
Fawkes
,
and
let
Viviana
come
next
after
me
.
<EOS>
If
I
should
miss
my
way
,
do
not
stir
for
your
life
.
<EOS>
"The
transfer
effected
,
the
fugitives
turned
off
to
the
right
,
and
proceeded
at
a
cautious
pace
along
a
narrow
and
shaking
path
.
<EOS>
The
ground
trembled
so
much
beneath
them
,
and
their
horses
'
feet
sank
so
deeply
in
the
plashy
bog
,
that
Viviana
demanded
,
in
a
tone
of
some
uneasiness
,
if
he
was
sure
he
had
taken
the
right
<EOS>
course?"If
I
had
not
,
"
replied
Humphrey
Chetham
,
"
we
should
ere
this
have
found
our
way
to
the
bottom
of
the
morass
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
a
floundering
plunge
,
accompanied
by
a
horrible
and
quickly
-
stifled
cry
,
told
that
one
of
their
pursuers
had
perished
in
endeavouring
to
follow
them
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
poor
wretch
is
gone
to
his
account
,
"
observed
Viviana
,
in
a
tone
of
commiseration
.
"
<EOS>
Have
a
care!—have
a
care
,
lest
you
share
the
same
fate
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
I
can
save
you
<EOS>
,
I
care
not
what
becomes
of
me
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
.
<EOS>
"
Since
I
can
never
hope
to
possess
you
,
life
has
become
valueless
in
my
eyes
.
<EOS>
""Quicken
<EOS>
your
pace
,
"
shouted
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
brought
up
the
rear
.
<EOS>
"
Our
pursuers
have
discovered
the
track
,
and
are
making
towards
us
.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
them
do
so
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
.
<EOS>
"
They
can
do
us
no
farther
injury
.
<EOS>
""That
is
false
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
voice
of
a
soldier
from
behind
.
<EOS>
And
,
as
the
words
were
uttered
,
a
shot
was
fired
,
which
,
though
aimed
against
Chetham
,
took
effect
upon
his
steed
.
<EOS>
The
animal
staggered
,
and
his
rider
had
only
time
to
slide
from
his
back
when
he
reeled
off
the
path
,
and
was
ingulfed
in
the
marsh
.
<EOS>
Hearing
the
plunge
of
the
steed
,
the
man
fancied
he
had
hit
his
mark
,
and
hallooed
in
an
exulting
voice
to
his
companions
.
<EOS>
But
his
triumph
was
of
short
duration
.
<EOS>
A
ball
from
the
petronel
of
Guy
Fawkes
pierced
his
brain
,
and
dropping
from
his
saddle
,
he
sank
,
together
with
his
horse
,
which
he
dragged
along
with
him
into
the
quagmire
.
<EOS>
"Waste
<EOS>
no
more
shot
,
"
cried
Humphrey
Chetham
;
"
the
swamp
will
fight
our
battles
for
us
.
<EOS>
Though
I
grieve
for
the
loss
of
my
horse
,
I
may
be
better
able
to
guide
you
on
foot
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
seized
Viviana
's
bridle
,
and
drew
her
steed
along
at
a
quick
pace
,
but
with
the
greatest
caution
.
<EOS>
As
they
proceeded
,
a
light
like
that
of
a
lantern
was
seen
to
rise
from
the
earth
,
and
approach
them
.
<EOS>
"Heaven
be
praised
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Viviana
:
"
some
one
has
heard
us
,
and
is
hastening
to
our
assistance
.
<EOS>
""Not
<EOS>
so
,
"
replied
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
The
light
you
behold
is
an
ignis
fatuus
.
<EOS>
Were
you
to
trust
yourself
to
its
delusive
gleam
,
it
would
lead
you
to
the
most
dangerous
parts
of
the
moss
.
<EOS>
"And
,
as
if
to
exhibit
its
real
character
,
the
little
flame
,
which
hitherto
had
burnt
as
brightly
and
steadily
as
a
wax
-
candle
,
suddenly
appeared
to
dilate
,
and
assuming
a
purple
tinge
,
emitted
a
shower
of
sparks
,
and
then
flitted
rapidly
over
the
plain
.
<EOS>
"Woe
<EOS>
to
him
that
follows
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"It
has
a
strange
unearthly
look
,
"
observed
Viviana
,
crossing
herself
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
much
difficulty
in
persuading
myself
<EOS>
it
is
not
the
work
of
some
malignant
sprite
.
<EOS>
""It
is
only
an
exhalation
of
the
marsh
,
"
replied
Chetham
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
see
!
<EOS>
others
are
at
hand
.
<EOS>
"Their
<EOS>
approach
,
indeed
,
seemed
to
have
disturbed
all
the
weird
children
of
the
waste
.
<EOS>
Lights
were
seen
trooping
towards
them
in
every
direction
;
sometimes
stopping
,
sometimes
rising
in
the
air
,
now
contracting
,
now
expanding
,
and
when
within
a
few
yards
of
the
travellers
,
retreating
with
inconceivable
swiftness
.
<EOS>
"It
is
a
marvellous
and
incomprehensible
spectacle
,
"
remarked
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
common
folk
hereabouts
affirm
that
these
Jack
-
o'-lanterns
,
as
they
term
them
,
always
appear
in
greater
numbers
when
some
direful
catastrophe
is
about
to
take
place
,
"
rejoined
the
young
merchant
.
<EOS>
"Heaven
<EOS>
avert
it
from
us
,
"
ejaculated
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"It
is
an
idle
superstition
,
"
returned
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
But
we
must
now
keep
silence
,
"
he
continued
,
lowering
his
voice
,
and
stopping
near
the
charred
stump
of
a
tree
,
left
,
it
would
seem
,
as
a
mark
.
<EOS>
"
The
road
turns
here
;
and
,
unless
our
pursuers
know
it
,
we
shall
now
quit
them
for
ever
.
<EOS>
We
must
not
let
a
sound
betray
the
course
we
are
about
to
take
.
<EOS>
"Having
turned
this
dangerous
corner
in
safety
,
and
conducted
his
companions
as
noiselessly
as
possible
for
a
few
yards
along
the
cross
path
,
which
being
much
narrower
was
consequently
more
perilous
than
the
first
,
Humphrey
Chetham
stood
still
,
and
,
imposing
silence
upon
the
others
,
listened
to
the
approach
of
their
pursuers
.
<EOS>
His
prediction
was
speedily
and
terribly
verified
.
<EOS>
Hearing
the
movement
in
advance
,
but
unable
to
discover
the
course
taken
by
the
fugitives
,
the
unfortunate
soldiers
,
fearful
of
losing
their
prey
,
quickened
their
pace
,
in
the
expectation
of
instantly
overtaking
them
.
<EOS>
They
were
fatally
undeceived
.
<EOS>
Four
only
of
their
number
,
besides
their
leader
,
remained,—two
<EOS>
having
perished
in
the
manner
heretofore
described
.
<EOS>
The
first
of
these
,
disregarding
the
caution
of
his
comrade
,
laughingly
urged
his
horse
into
a
gallop
,
and
,
on
passing
the
mark
,
sunk
as
if
by
magic
,
and
before
he
could
utter
a
single
warning
cry
,
into
the
depths
of
the
morass
.
<EOS>
His
disappearance
was
so
instantaneous
,
that
the
next
in
order
,
though
he
heard
the
sullen
plunge
,
was
unable
to
draw
in
the
rein
,
and
was
likewise
ingulfed
.
<EOS>
A
third
followed
;
and
a
fourth
,
in
his
efforts
to
avoid
their
fate
,
backed
his
steed
over
the
slippery
edge
of
the
path
.
<EOS>
Only
one
now
remained
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
pursuivant
,
who
,
with
the
prudence
that
characterized
all
his
proceedings
,
had
followed
in
the
rear
.
<EOS>
He
was
so
dreadfully
frightened
,
<EOS>
that
,
adding
his
shrieks
to
those
of
his
attendants
,
he
shouted
to
the
fugitives
,
imploring
assistance
in
the
most
piteous
terms
,
and
promising
never
again
to
molest
them
,
if
they
would
guide
him
to
a
place
of
safety
.
<EOS>
But
his
cries
were
wholly
unheeded
;
and
he
perhaps
endured
in
those
few
minutes
of
agony
as
much
suffering
as
he
had
inflicted
on
the
numerous
victims
of
his
barbarity
.
<EOS>
It
was
indeed
an
appalling
moment
.
<EOS>
Three
of
the
wretched
men
had
not
yet
sunk
,
but
were
floundering
about
in
the
swamp
,
and
shrieking
for
help
.
<EOS>
The
horses
,
as
much
terrified
as
their
riders
,
added
their
piercing
cries
to
the
half
-
suffocated
yells
.
<EOS>
And
,
as
if
to
make
the
scene
more
ghastly
,
myriads
of
dancing
lights
flitted
towards
them
,
and
throwing
an
unearthly
glimmer
over
this
part
of
the
morass
,
fully
revealed
their
struggling
figures
.
<EOS>
Moved
by
compassion
for
the
poor
wretches
,
Viviana
implored
Humphrey
Chetham
to
assist
them
,
and
,
finding
him
immovable
,
she
appealed
to
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"They
are
beyond
all
human
aid
,
"
the
latter
replied
.
<EOS>
"Heaven
have
mercy
on
their
souls
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
the
priest
"
Pray
for
them
,
dear
daughter
.
<EOS>
Pray
heartily
,
as
I
am
about
to
do
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
recited
in
an
audible
voice
the
Romish
formula
of
supplication
for
those
in
extremis
.
<EOS>
Averting
her
gaze
from
the
spectacle
,
Viviana
joined
fervently
in
the
prayer
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
two
of
the
strugglers
had
disappeared
.
<EOS>
The
third
,
having
freed
himself
from
his
horse
,
contrived
for
some
moments
,
during
which
he
uttered
the
most
frightful
cries
,
to
keep
his
head
above
the
swamp
.
<EOS>
His
efforts
were
tremendous
,
but
unavailing
,
and
served
only
to
accelerate
his
fate
.
<EOS>
Making
a
last
desperate
plunge
towards
the
bank
where
the
fugitives
were
standing
,
he
sank
above
the
chin
.
<EOS>
The
expression
of
his
face
,
shown
by
the
ghastly
glimmer
of
the
fen
-
fires
,
as
he
was
gradually
swallowed
up
,
was
horrible
.
<EOS>
"Requiem
<EOS>
æternam
dona
eis
,
Domine
,
"
exclaimed
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
is
over
,
"
cried
Humphrey
Chetham
,
taking
the
bridle
of
Viviana
's
steed
,
and
leading
her
onwards
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
free
from
our
pursuers
.
<EOS>
""There
is
one
left
<EOS>
,
"
she
rejoined
,
casting
a
look
backwards
.
<EOS>
"It
is
the
pursuivant
,
"
returned
Guy
Fawkes
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
within
shot
,
"
he
added
,
drawing
his
petronel
.
<EOS>
"Oh
,
<EOS>
no
—
no!—in
pity
spare
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
Too
many
lives
have
been
sacrificed
already
.
<EOS>
""He
is
the
cause
of
all
the
mischief
,
"
answered
Guy
Fawkes
,
unwillingly
replacing
the
petronel
in
his
belt
,
"
and
may
live
to
injure
you
and
your
father
.
<EOS>
""I
will
hope
not
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
;
"
but
,
spare
him!—oh
,
<EOS>
spare
<EOS>
him!""Be
it
as
you
please
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
marsh
,
I
trust
,
will
not
be
so
merciful
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
they
slowly
resumed
their
progress
.
<EOS>
On
hearing
their
departure
,
the
pursuivant
renewed
his
cries
in
a
more
piteous
tone
than
ever
;
but
,
in
spite
of
the
entreaties
of
Viviana
,
nothing
could
induce
her
companions
to
lend
him
assistance
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
they
proceeded
in
silence
,
and
without
accident
.
<EOS>
As
they
advanced
,
the
difficulties
of
the
path
increased
,
and
it
was
fortunate
that
the
moon
,
emerging
from
the
clouds
in
which
,
up
to
this
moment
,
she
had
been
shrouded
,
enabled
them
to
steer
their
course
in
safety
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
after
a
tedious
and
toilsome
march
for
nearly
half
a
mile
,
the
footing
became
more
secure
,
the
road
widened
,
and
they
were
able
to
quicken
their
pace
.
<EOS>
Another
half
mile
landed
them
upon
the
western
bank
of
the
morass
.
<EOS>
Viviana
's
first
impulse
was
to
give
thanks
to
Heaven
for
their
deliverance
,
nor
did
she
omit
in
her
prayer
a
supplication
for
the
unfortunate
beings
who
had
perished
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
the
point
now
known
as
Rawson
Nook
,
they
entered
a
lane
,
and
proceeded
towards
Astley
Green
,
where
perceiving
a
cluster
of
thatched
cottages
among
the
trees
,
they
knocked
at
the
door
of
the
first
,
and
speedily
obtained
admittance
from
its
inmates
,
a
turf
-
cutter
and
his
wife
.
<EOS>
The
man
conveyed
their
steeds
to
a
neighbouring
barn
,
while
the
good
dame
offered
Viviana
such
accommodation
and
refreshment
as
her
humble
dwelling
afforded
.
<EOS>
Here
they
tarried
till
the
following
evening
,
as
much
to
recruit
Miss
Radcliffe
's
strength
,
as
for
security
.
<EOS>
At
the
young
merchant
's
request
,
the
turf
-
cutter
went
in
the
course
of
the
day
to
see
what
had
become
of
the
pursuivant
.
<EOS>
He
was
nowhere
to
be
found
.
<EOS>
But
he
accidentally
learned
from
another
hind
,
who
followed
the
same
occupation
as
himself
,
that
a
person
answering
to
the
officer
's
description
had
been
seen
to
emerge
from
the
moss
near
Baysnape
at
daybreak
,
and
take
the
road
towards
Manchester
.
<EOS>
Of
the
unfortunate
soldiers
nothing
but
a
steel
cap
and
a
pike
,
which
the
man
brought
away
with
him
,
could
be
discovered
.
<EOS>
After
much
debate
,
it
was
decided
that
their
safest
plan
would
be
to
proceed
to
Manchester
,
where
Humphrey
Chetham
undertook
to
procure
them
safe
lodgings
at
the
Seven
Stars,—an
excellent
hostel
,
kept
by
a
worthy
widow
,
who
,
he
affirmed
,
would
do
anything
to
serve
him
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
they
set
out
at
nightfall,—Viviana
taking
her
place
before
Guy
Fawkes
,
and
relinquishing
Zayda
to
the
young
merchant
and
the
priest
.
<EOS>
Shaping
their
course
through
Worsley
,
by
Monton
Green
and
Pendleton
,
they
arrived
in
about
an
hour
within
sight
of
the
town
,
which
then,—not
<EOS>
a
tithe
of
its
present
size
,
and
unpolluted
by
the
smoky
atmosphere
in
which
it
is
now
constantly
enveloped,—was
not
without
some
pretensions
to
a
picturesque
appearance
.
<EOS>
Crossing
Salford
Bridge
,
they
mounted
Smithy
-
Bank
,
as
it
was
then
termed
,
and
proceeding
along
Cateaton
-
street
and
Hanging
Ditch
,
struck
into
Whithing
(
now
Withy
)
Grove
,
at
the
right
of
which
,
just
where
a
few
houses
were
beginning
to
straggle
up
Shude
Hill
,
stood
,
and
still
stands
,
<EOS>
the
comfortable
hostel
of
the
Seven
Stars
.
<EOS>
Here
they
stopped
,
and
were
warmly
welcomed
by
its
buxom
mistress
,
Dame
Sutcliffe
.
<EOS>
Muffled
in
Guy
Fawkes
's
cloak
,
the
priest
gained
the
chamber
to
which
he
was
ushered
unobserved
.
<EOS>
And
Dame
Sutcliffe
,
though
her
Protestant
notions
were
a
little
scandalized
at
her
dwelling
being
made
the
sanctuary
of
a
Popish
priest
,
promised
,
at
the
instance
of
Master
Chetham
,
whom
she
knew
to
be
no
favourer
of
idolatry
in
a
general
way
,
to
be
answerable
for
his
safety
.
<EOS>
VI
.
—
<EOS>
THE
DISINTERMENTHaving
seen
every
attention
shown
to
Viviana
by
the
hostess,—who
,
as
soon
as
she
discovered
that
she
had
the
daughter
of
Sir
William
Radcliffe
of
Ordsall
,
under
her
roof
,
bestirred
herself
in
right
earnest
for
her
accommodation,—Humphrey
Chetham
,
notwithstanding
the
lateness
of
the
hour,—it
<EOS>
was
past
<EOS>
midnight,—expressed
his
determination
to
walk
to
his
residence
at
Crumpsall
,
to
put
an
end
to
any
apprehension
which
might
be
entertained
by
the
household
at
his
prolonged
absence
.
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
he
set
forth
;
and
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
seemed
to
be
meditating
some
project
which
he
was
unwilling
to
disclose
to
the
others
,
quitted
the
hostel
with
him
,
bidding
the
chamberlain
sit
up
for
him
,
as
he
should
speedily
return
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
gone
far
when
he
inquired
the
nearest
way
to
the
Collegiate
Church
,
and
was
answered
that
they
were
then
proceeding
towards
it
,
and
in
a
few
moments
should
arrive
at
its
walls
.
<EOS>
He
next
asked
the
young
merchant
whether
he
could
inform
him
which
part
of
the
churchyard
was
allotted
to
criminals
.
<EOS>
Humphrey
Chetham
,
somewhat
surprised
by
the
question
,
replied
,
"
At
the
north
-
west
,
near
the
charnel
,
"
adding
,
"
I
shall
pass
within
a
short
distance
of
the
spot
,
and
will
point
it
out
to
you
.
"Entering
<EOS>
Fennel
Street
,
at
the
end
of
which
stood
an
ancient
cross
,
they
soon
came
in
sight
of
the
church
.
<EOS>
The
moon
was
shining
brightly
,
and
silvered
the
massive
square
tower
of
the
fane
,
the
battlements
,
pinnacles
,
buttresses
,
and
noble
eastern
window
,
with
its
gorgeous
tracery
.
<EOS>
While
Guy
Fawkes
paused
for
a
moment
to
contemplate
this
reverend
and
beautiful
structure
,
two
venerable
personages
,
having
long
snowy
beards
,
and
wrapped
in
flowing
mantles
edged
with
sable
fur
,
passed
the
end
of
the
street
.
<EOS>
One
of
them
carried
a
lantern
,
though
it
was
wholly
needless
,
as
it
was
bright
as
day
;
and
as
they
glided
stealthily
along
,
there
was
something
so
mysterious
in
their
manner
,
that
it
greatly
excited
the
curiosity
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
inquired
from
his
companion
if
he
knew
who
they
were
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
foremost
is
the
warden
of
Manchester
,
the
famous
Doctor
Dee
,
"
replied
Humphrey
Chetham
,
"
divine
,
mathematician
,
astrologer,—and
<EOS>
if
report
speaks
truly
,
conjuror
.
<EOS>
""Is
<EOS>
that
Doctor
Dee
?
"
cried
Guy
Fawkes
,
in
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"It
is
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
:
"
and
the
other
in
the
Polish
cap
is
the
no
-
less
celebrated
Edward
Kelley
,
the
doctor
's
assistant
,
or
,
as
he
is
ordinarily
termed
,
<EOS>
his
seer
.
<EOS>
""They
have
entered
the
churchyard
,
"
remarked
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
follow
them
.
<EOS>
""I
would
not
advise
you
to
do
so
,
"
rejoined
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
Strange
tales
are
told
of
them
.
<EOS>
You
may
witness
that
it
is
not
safe
to
look
upon
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
caution
,
however
,
was
unheeded
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
had
already
disappeared
,
and
the
young
merchant
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
,
proceeded
on
his
way
towards
Hunt
's
Bank
.
<EOS>
On
gaining
the
churchyard
,
Guy
Fawkes
perceived
the
warden
and
his
companion
creeping
stealthily
beneath
the
shadow
of
a
wall
in
the
direction
of
a
low
fabric
,
which
appeared
to
be
a
bone
-
house
,
or
charnel
,
situated
at
the
north
-
western
extremity
of
the
church
.
<EOS>
Before
this
building
grew
a
black
and
stunted
yew
-
tree
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
it
,
they
paused
,
and
looked
round
to
see
whether
they
were
observed
.
<EOS>
They
did
not
,
however
,
notice
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
had
concealed
himself
behind
a
buttress
.
<EOS>
Kelley
then
unlocked
the
door
of
the
charnel
,
and
brought
out
a
pickaxe
and
mattock
.
<EOS>
Having
divested
himself
of
his
cloak
,
he
proceeded
to
shovel
out
the
mould
from
a
new
-
made
grave
at
a
little
distance
from
the
building
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Dee
stood
by
,
and
held
the
lantern
for
his
assistant
.
<EOS>
Determined
to
watch
their
proceedings
,
Guy
Fawkes
crept
towards
the
yew
-
tree
,
behind
which
he
ensconced
himself
.
<EOS>
Kelley
,
meanwhile
,
continued
to
ply
his
spade
with
a
vigour
that
seemed
almost
incomprehensible
in
one
so
far
stricken
in
years
,
and
of
such
infirm
appearance
.
<EOS>
At
length
he
paused
,
and
kneeling
within
the
shallow
grave
,
endeavoured
to
drag
something
from
it
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Dee
knelt
to
assist
him
.
<EOS>
After
some
exertion
,
they
drew
forth
the
corpse
of
a
female
,
which
had
been
interred
without
coffin
,
and
apparently
in
the
habiliments
worn
during
life
.
<EOS>
A
horrible
suspicion
crossed
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Resolving
to
satisfy
his
doubts
at
once
,
he
rushed
forward
,
and
beheld
in
the
ghastly
lineaments
of
the
dead
the
features
of
the
unfortunate
prophetess
,
Elizabeth
Orton
.
<EOS>
VII
.
<EOS>
—
DOCTOR
DEE"How
<EOS>
now
,
ye
impious
violators
of
the
tomb
!
<EOS>
ye
worse
than
famine
-
stricken
wolves
,
that
rake
up
the
dead
in
churchyards
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Guy
Fawkes
,
in
a
voice
of
thunder
,
to
Doctor
Dee
and
his
companion
;
who
,
startled
by
his
sudden
appearance
,
dropped
the
body
,
and
retreated
to
a
short
distance
.
<EOS>
"
What
devilish
rites
are
ye
about
to
enact
,
that
ye
thus
profane
the
sanctity
of
the
grave?"Illustration"And
who
art
thou
that
darest
thus
to
interrupt
us
?
"
demanded
Dee
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"It
<EOS>
matters
not
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
striding
towards
them
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Suffice
it
<EOS>
you
are
both
known
to
me
.
<EOS>
You
,
John
Dee
,
warden
of
Manchester
,
who
deserve
to
be
burnt
at
the
stake
for
your
damnable
practices
,
rather
than
hold
the
sacred
office
you
fill
;
and
you
,
Edward
Kelley
,
his
associate
,
who
boast
of
familiar
intercourse
with
demons
,
and
,
unless
fame
belies
you
,
have
purchased
the
intimacy
at
the
price
of
your
soul
's
salvation
.
<EOS>
I
know
you
both
.
<EOS>
I
know
,
also
,
whose
body
you
have
disinterred
—
it
is
that
of
the
ill
-
fated
prophetess
,
Elizabeth
Orton
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
do
not
instantly
restore
it
to
the
grave
whence
you
have
snatched
it
,
I
will
denounce
you
to
the
authorities
of
the
town
.
<EOS>
""Knowing
<EOS>
thus
much
,
you
should
know
still
more
,
"
retorted
Doctor
Dee
,
"
namely
,
that
I
am
not
to
be
lightly
provoked
.
<EOS>
You
have
no
power
to
quit
the
churchyard
—
nay
,
not
so
much
as
to
move
a
limb
without
my
permission
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
he
drew
from
beneath
his
cloak
a
small
phial
,
the
contents
of
which
he
sprinkled
over
the
intruder
.
<EOS>
Its
effect
was
wonderful
and
instantaneous
.
<EOS>
The
limbs
of
Guy
Fawkes
stiffened
where
he
stood
.
<EOS>
His
hand
remained
immovably
fixed
upon
the
pommel
of
his
sword
,
and
he
seemed
transformed
into
a
marble
statue
.
<EOS>
"You
will
henceforth
acknowledge
and
respect
my
power
,
"
he
continued
.
<EOS>
"
Were
it
my
pleasure
,
I
could
bury
you
twenty
fathoms
deep
in
the
earth
beneath
our
feet
;
or
,
by
invoking
certain
spirits
,
convey
you
to
the
summit
of
yon
lofty
tower
,
"
pointing
to
the
church
,
"
and
hurl
you
from
it
headlong
.
<EOS>
But
I
content
myself
with
depriving
you
of
motion
,
and
leave
you
in
possession
of
sight
and
speech
,
that
you
may
endure
the
torture
of
witnessing
what
you
can
not
prevent
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
was
about
to
return
to
the
corpse
with
Kelley
,
when
Guy
Fawkes
exclaimed
,
in
a
hollow
voice,"Set
me
free
,
and
I
will
instantly
depart
.
<EOS>
""Will
<EOS>
you
swear
never
to
divulge
what
you
have
seen
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Dee
,
pausing
.
<EOS>
"Solemnly
,
"
he
replied
.
<EOS>
"I
will
trust
you
,
then
,
"
rejoined
the
Doctor;—"the
rather
that
your
presence
interferes
with
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
"Taking
<EOS>
a
handful
of
loose
earth
from
an
adjoining
grave
,
and
muttering
a
few
words
,
that
sounded
like
a
charm
<EOS>
,
he
scattered
it
over
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
The
spell
was
instantly
broken
.
<EOS>
A
leaden
weight
seemed
to
be
removed
from
his
limbs
.
<EOS>
His
joints
regained
their
suppleness
,
and
with
a
convulsive
start
,
like
that
by
which
a
dreamer
casts
off
a
nightmare
,
he
was
liberated
from
his
preternatural
thraldom
.
"And
<EOS>
now
,
begone
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Doctor
Dee
,
authoritatively
.
<EOS>
"Suffer
<EOS>
me
to
tarry
with
you
a
few
moments
,
"
said
Guy
Fawkes
,
in
a
deferential
tone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Heretofore
,
I
will
freely
admit
,
I
regarded
you
as
an
impostor
;
but
now
I
am
convinced
you
are
deeply
skilled
in
the
occult
sciences
,
and
would
fain
consult
you
on
the
future
.
<EOS>
""I
have
already
said
that
your
presence
troubles
me
,
"
replied
Doctor
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
if
you
will
call
upon
me
at
the
College
to
-
morrow
,
it
may
be
I
will
give
you
further
proofs
of
my
skill
.
<EOS>
""Why
not
now
,
reverend
sir
?
"
urged
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
The
question
I
would
ask
is
better
suited
to
this
dismal
spot
and
witching
hour
,
than
to
daylight
and
the
walls
of
your
study
.
""Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Dee
.
"
<EOS>
Your
name?""Guy
Fawkes
,
"
replied
the
other
.
<EOS>
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
!
<EOS>
"
echoed
the
Doctor
,
starting
.
"
<EOS>
Nay
,
then
,
I
guess
the
nature
of
the
question
you
would
ask
.
<EOS>
""Am
<EOS>
I
then
known
to
you
,
reverend
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Fawkes
,
uneasily
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
well
as
to
yourself
—
nay
,
better
,
"
answered
the
Doctor
.
<EOS>
"
Bring
the
lantern
hither
,
Kelley
,
"
he

,

.
"
<EOS>
Look
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
elevating

light
so
as

throw
it
upon
the
countenance
of
Fawkes
:
"
it
is
the
very

bronzed
and
strongly
-

iron

,
and
foreign

of
the
figure
we

in

.
<EOS>
""It
is
,
"
replied
Kelley
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
have
singled
him
out
amid
a
thousand
.
<EOS>
He
looked
thus
as
we
tracked
his
perilous

,
with

,
the
priest
,
Chetham
,
and

,

Chat
Moss
.
<EOS>
""How
<EOS>
have
you
learned
this
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Guy
Fawkes
,
in

.
<EOS>
"By
<EOS>
the
art
that
reveals

,
"
answered
Kelley
.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
proof
that
your
thoughts
are
known
to
me
<EOS>
,
"
observed
Dee
,
"
I
will
tell
you
the
inquiry
you
would
make
before
it
is
uttered
.
<EOS>
You
would
learn
whether
the
enterprise
on
which
you
are
engaged
will
succeed
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
would
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Yet
<EOS>
more
,
"
continued
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
aware
of
the
nature
of
the
plot
,
and
could
name
to
you
all
connected
with
it
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
power
is
,
indeed
,
wonderful
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
in
an
altered
tone
.
"
<EOS>
But
will
you
give
me
the
information
<EOS>
I
require?""Hum
!
"
muttered
Dee
.
<EOS>
"I
am
too
poor
to
purchase
it
,
"
proceeded
Fawkes
,
"
unless
a
relic
I
have
brought
from
Spain
has
any
value
in
your

.
<EOS>
"Illustration"Tush
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Dee
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
suppose
I
am
a
common
juggler
,
and
practise
my
art
for
gain?""By
no

,
reverend

,
"
said
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
would
not
willingly
put
you
to

without

.
<EOS>
""Well
,
then
,
"
replied
Dee
,
"
I
will
not
refuse
your
request
.
<EOS>
And
yet
I
would
caution
you
to
beware
how
you
pry
into
the
future
.
<EOS>
You
may
repent
your
rashness
when
it
is
too
late
.
<EOS>
""I
have
no
fear
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
know
the
worst
.
<EOS>
""Enough
,
"
answered
Dee
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
listen
to
me
.
<EOS>
That
carcass
having
been
placed
in
the
ground
without
the
holy
rites
of
burial
being
duly
performed
,
I
have
power
over
it
.
<EOS>
And
,
as
the
witch
of
Endor
called
up
Samuel
,
as
is
recorded
in
Holy
Writ,—as
Erichtho
raised
up
a
corpse
to
reveal
to
Sextus
Pompeius
<EOS>
the
event
of
the
Pharsalian
war,—as
Elisha
breathed
life
into
the
nostrils
of
the
Shunamite
's
son,—as
Alcestis
was
invoked
by
Hercules,—and
as
the
dead
maid
was
brought
back
to
life
by
Apollonius
Thyaneus,—so
I
,
by
certain
powerful

,
will
allure
the

of
the
prophetess
,
for
a
short
space
,
to
its
former
tenement
,
and
compel
it
to
answer
my
questions
.
<EOS>
Dare
you
be
present
at
this
ceremony?""I
dare
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Follow
<EOS>
me
,
then
,
"
said
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
need
all
your
courage
.
<EOS>
"Muttering
<EOS>
a
hasty
prayer
,
and
secretly
crossing
himself
<EOS>
,
Guy
Fawkes
strode
after
him
towards
the
grave
.
<EOS>
By
the
Doctor
's
directions
,
he
,
with
some
reluctance
,
assisted
Kelley
to
raise
the
corpse
,
and
convey
it
to
the
charnel
.
<EOS>
Dee
followed
,
bearing
the
lantern
,
and
,
on
entering
the
building
,
closed
and
fastened
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
chamber
in
which
Guy
Fawkes
found
himself
was
in
perfect
keeping
with
the
horrible
ceremonial
about
to
be
performed
.
<EOS>
In
one
corner
lay
a
mouldering
heap
of
skulls
,
bones
,
and
other
fragments
of
mortality
;
in
the
other
a
pile
of
broken
coffins
,
emptied
of
their
tenants
,
and
reared
on
end
.
<EOS>
But
what
chiefly
attracted
his
attention
,
was
a
ghastly
collection
of
human
limbs
,
blackened
with
pitch
,
girded
round
with
iron
hoops
,
and
hung
,
like
meat
in
a
shambles
,
against
the
wall
.
<EOS>
There
were
two
heads
,
and
,
though
the
features
were
scarcely
distinguishable
,
owing
to
the
liquid
in
which
they
had
been
immersed
,
they
still
retained
a
terrific
expression
of
agony
.
<EOS>
Seeing
his
attention
directed
to
these
revolting
objects
,
Kelley
informed
him
they
were
the
quarters
of
the
two
priests
who
had
recently
been
put
to
death
,
which
had
been
left
there
previously
to
being
placed
on
the
church
-
gates
.
<EOS>
The
implements
,
and
some
part
of
the
attire
used
by
the
executioner
in
his
butcherly
office
,
were
scattered
about
,
and
mixed
with
the
tools
of
the
sexton
;
while
in
the
centre
of
the
room
stood
a
large
wooden
frame
supported
by
trestles
.
<EOS>
On
this
frame
,
stained
with
blood
and
smeared
with
pitch
,
showing
the
purpose
to
which
it
had
been
recently
put
,
the
body
was
placed
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
Doctor
Dee
set
down
the
lantern
beside
it
;
and
,
as
the
light
fell
upon
its
livid
features
,
sullied
with
earth
,
and
exhibiting
traces
of
decay
<EOS>
,
Guy
Fawkes
was
so
appalled
by
the
sight
that
he
half
repented
of
what
he
had
undertaken
.
<EOS>
Noticing
his
irresolution
,
Doctor
Dee
said
,
"
You
may
yet
retire
if
you
think
proper
.
<EOS>
""No
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
rousing
himself
;
"
I
will
go
through
with
it
.
<EOS>
""It
is
well
,
"
replied
Dee
.
<EOS>
And
he
extinguished
the
light
.
<EOS>
An
awful
silence
now
ensued
,
broken
only
by
a
low
murmur
from
Doctor
Dee
,
who
appeared
to
be
reciting
an
incantation
.
<EOS>
As
he
proceeded
,
his
tones
became
louder
,
and
his
accents
those
of
command
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
he
paused
,
and
seemed
to
await
a
response
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
none
was
made
,
greatly
to
the
disappointment
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
whose
curiosity
,
notwithstanding
his
fears
,
was
raised
to
the
highest
pitch
<EOS>
,
he
cried
,
"
Blood
is
wanting
to
complete
the
charm
.
<EOS>
""If
that
is
all
<EOS>
,
I
will
speedily
supply
the
deficiency
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
;
and
,
drawing
his
rapier
<EOS>
,
he
bared
his
left
arm
,
and
pricked
it
deeply
with
the
point
of
the
weapon
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
bleed
now
,
"
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"Sprinkle
<EOS>
the
corpse
with
the
ruddy
current
,
"
rejoined
Doctor
Dee
.
<EOS>
"Your
<EOS>
commands
are
obeyed
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
placed
my
hand
on
its
breast
,
and
the
blood
is
flowing
upon
it
.
<EOS>
"Upon
<EOS>
this
the
Doctor
began
to
mutter
an
incantation
in
a
louder
and
more
authoritative
tone
than
before
.
<EOS>
Presently
,
Kelley
added
his
voice
,
and
they
both
joined
in
a
sort
of
chorus
,
but
in
a
jargon
wholly
unintelligible
to
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
All
at
once
a
blue
flame
appeared
above
their
heads
,
and
,
slowly
descending
,
settled
upon
the
brow
of
the
corpse
,
lighting
up
the
sunken
cavities
of
the
eyes
,
and
the
discoloured
and
distorted
features
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
charm
works
,
"
shouted
Doctor
Dee
.
<EOS>
"She
<EOS>
moves
!
<EOS>
she
moves
!
"
exclaimed
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
alive!""Take
off
your
hand
,
"
cried
the
Doctor
,
"
or
mischief
may
ensue
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
again
continued
his
incantation
.
<EOS>
"Down
on
your
knees
!
<EOS>
"
he
exclaimed
,
at
length
,
in
a
terrible
voice
.
"
<EOS>
The
spirit
is
at
hand
.
<EOS>
"There
<EOS>
was
a
rushing
sound
,
and
a
stream
of
dazzling
lightning
shot
down
upon
the
corpse
,
which
emitted
a
hollow
groan
.
<EOS>
In
obedience
to
the
Doctor
's
commands
,
Guy
Fawkes
had
prostrated
himself
on
the
ground
:
but
he
kept
his
gaze
steadily
fixed
on
the
body
,
which
,
to
his
infinite
astonishment
,
slowly
arose
,
until
it
stood
erect
upon
the
frame
.
<EOS>
There
it
remained
perfectly
motionless
,
with
the
arms
close
to
the
sides
,
and
the
habiliments
torn
and
dishevelled
.
<EOS>
The
blue
light
still
retained
its
position
upon
the
brow
,
and
communicated
a
horrible
glimmer
to
the
features
.
<EOS>
The
spectacle
was
so
dreadful
that
Guy
Fawkes
would
fain
have
averted
his
eyes
,
but
he
was
unable
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Dee
and
his
companion
,
meanwhile
,
continued
their
invocations
,
until
,
as
it
seemed
to
Fawkes
,
the
lips
of
the
corpse
moved
,
and
an
awful
voice
exclaimed
,
"
Why
have
you
called
me?""Daughter
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Doctor
Dee
,
rising
,
"
in
life
thou
wert
endowed
with
the
gift
of
prophecy
.
<EOS>
In
the
grave
,
that
which
is
to
come
must
be
revealed
to
thee
.
<EOS>
We
would
question
thee
.
<EOS>
""Speak
<EOS>
,
and
I
will
answer
,
"
replied
the
corpse
.
<EOS>
"Interrogate
<EOS>
her
,
my
son
,
"
said
Dee
,
addressing
Fawkes
,
"
and
be
brief
,
for
the
time
is
short
.
<EOS>
So
long
only
as
that
flame
burns
have
I
power
over
her
.
<EOS>
""Spirit
of
Elizabeth
Orton
<EOS>
,
"
cried
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
if
indeed
thou
standest
before
me
,
and
some
demon
hath
not
entered
thy
frame
to
delude
me,—by
<EOS>
all
that
is
holy
,
and
by
every
blessed
saint
,
I
adjure
thee
to
tell
me
whether
the
scheme
on
which
I
am
now
engaged
for
the
advantage
of
the
Catholic
Church
will
prosper?""Thou
art
mistaken
,
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
returned
the
corpse
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Thy
scheme
is
not
for
the
advantage
of
the
Catholic
Church
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
pause
to
inquire
wherefore
,
"
continued
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
grant
that
the
means
are
violent
and
wrongful
,
will
the
end
be
<EOS>
successful?""The
end
will
be
death
,
"
replied
the
corpse
.
<EOS>
"To
<EOS>
the
tyrant
—
to
the
oppressors
?
"
demanded
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"To
<EOS>
the
conspirators
,
"
was
the
answer
.
<EOS>
"Ha
!
"
ejaculated
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Proceed
,
if
you
have
aught
more
to
ask
,
"
cried
Dr.
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
The
flame
is
expiring
.
<EOS>
""Shall
<EOS>
we
restore
the
fallen
religion
?
"
demanded
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
But
before
the
words
could
be
pronounced
the
light
vanished
,
and
a
heavy
sound
was
heard
,
as
of
the
body
falling
on
the
frame
.
<EOS>
"It
is
over
,
"
said
Doctor
Dee
.
<EOS>
"Can
<EOS>
you
not
summon
her
again
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Fawkes
,
in
a
tone
of
deep
disappointment
.
<EOS>
"
I
had
other
questions
to
ask
.
<EOS>
""Impossible
,
"
replied
the
Doctor
.
<EOS>
"
The
spirit
is
fled
,
and
will
not
be
recalled
.
<EOS>
We
must
now
commit
the
body
to
the
earth
.
<EOS>
And
this
time
it
shall
be
more
decently
interred
.
<EOS>
""My
<EOS>
curiosity
is
excited,—not
satisfied
,
"
said
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Would
it
were
to
occur
again!""It
is
ever
thus
,
"
replied
Doctor
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
We
seek
to
know
that
which
is
interdicted,—and
quench
our
thirst
at
a
fountain
that
only
inflames
our
curiosity
the
more
.
<EOS>
Be
warned
,
my
son
.
<EOS>
You
are
embarked
on
a
perilous
enterprise
,
and
if
you
pursue
it
,
it
will
lead
you
to
certain
destruction
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
retreat
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
"
and
would
not
,
if
I
could
.
<EOS>
I
am
bound
by
an
oath
too
terrible
to
be
broken
.
<EOS>
""I
will
absolve
you
of
your
oath
,
my
son
,
"
said
Dr.
Dee
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
can
not
,
reverend
sir
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
By
no
sophistry
could
I
clear
my
conscience
of
the
ties
imposed
upon
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
sworn
never
to
desist
from
the
execution
of
this
scheme
,
unless
those
engaged
in
it
shall
give
me
leave
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
so
resolved
am
I
,
that
if
I
stood
alone
I
would
go
on
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
a
deep
groan
issued
from
the
corpse
.
<EOS>
"You
are
again
warned
,
my
son
,
"
said
Dee
.
<EOS>
"Come
forth
,
"
said
Guy
Fawkes
,
rushing
towards
the
door
,
and
throwing
it
open
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
place
stifles
me
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
night
has
already
been
described
as
bright
and
beautiful
.
<EOS>
Before
him
stood
the
Collegiate
Church
bathed
in
moonlight
.
<EOS>
He
gazed
abstractedly
at
this
venerable
structure
for
a
few
moments
,
and
then
returned
to
the
charnel
,
where
he
found
Doctor
Dee
and
Kelley
employed
in
placing
the
body
of
the
prophetess
in
a
coffin
,
which
they
had
taken
from
a
pile
in
the
corner
.
<EOS>
He
immediately
proffered
his
assistance
,
and
in
a
short
space
the
task
was
completed
.
<EOS>
The
coffin
was
then
borne
towards
the
grave
,
at
the
edge
of
which
it
was
laid
while
the
burial
-
service
was
recited
by
Doctor
Dee
.
<EOS>
This
ended
,
it
was
lowered
into
its
shallow
resting
-
place
,
and
speedily
covered
with
earth
.
<EOS>
When
all
was
ready
for
their
departure
,
the
Doctor
turned
to
Fawkes
,
and
,
bidding
him
farewell
,
observed,"If
<EOS>
you
are
wise
,
my
son
,
you
will
profit
by
the
awful
warning
you
have
this
night
received
.
<EOS>
""Before
we
part
,
reverend
sir
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
"
I
would
ask
if
you
know
of
other
means
whereby
an
insight
may
be
obtained
into
the
future?""Many
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
magic
glass
,
in
which
,
with
due
preparation
,
you
may
behold
exact
representations
of
coming
events
.
<EOS>
I
am
now
returning
to
the
College
,
and
if
you
will
accompany
me
,
I
will
show
it
to
you
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
offer
was
eagerly
accepted
,
and
the
party
quitted
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
VIII
.
<EOS>
—
THE
MAGIC
<EOS>
GLASSThe
old
College
of
Manchester
occupied
,
as
is
well
known
,
the
site
of
the
existing
structure
,
called
after
the
benevolent
individual
by
whom
that
admirable
charity
was
founded
,
and
whom
we
have
ventured
to
introduce
in
this
history,—the
Chetham
Hospital
.
<EOS>
Much
,
indeed
,
of
the
ancient
building
remains
;
for
though
it
was
considerably
repaired
and
enlarged
,
being
"
very
ruinous
and
in
great
decay
,
"
at
the
time
of
its
purchase
in
1654
,
by
the
feoffees
under
Humphrey
Chetham
's
will
,
from
the
sequestrators
of
the
Earl
of
Derby
's
estates
,
still
the
general
character
of
the
fabric
has
been
preserved
,
and
several
of
its
chambers
retained
.
<EOS>
Originally
built
on
the
foundation
of
a
manor
-
house
denominated
<EOS>
The
Baron
's
Hall,—the
abode
of
the
Grelleys
and
the
De
la
Warrs
,
lords
of
Manchester,—the
College
continued
to
be
used
as
the
residence
of
the
warden
and
fellows
of
the
Collegiate
Church
until
the
reign
of
Edward
the
First
,
when
that
body
was
dissolved
.
<EOS>
On
the
accession
,
however
,
of
Mary
,
the
College
was
re
-
established
;
but
the
residence
of
the
ecclesiastical
body
being
removed
to
a
house
in
Deansgate
,
the
building
was
allowed
to
become
extremely
dilapidated
,
and
was
used
partly
as
a
prison
for
recusants
and
other
offenders
,
and
partly
as
a
magazine
for
powder
.
<EOS>
In
this
state
Dr.
Dee
found
it
when
he
succeeded
to
the
wardenship
in
1595
,
and
preferring
it
,
notwithstanding
its
ruinous
condition
,
to
the
house
appointed
for
him
elsewhere
,
took
up
his
abode
within
it
.
<EOS>
Situated
on
a
high
rock
,
overhanging
the
river
Irk
—
at
that
time
a
clear
stream
,
remarkable
for
the
excellence
of
its
fish,—and
constructed
entirely
of
stone
,
the
old
College
had
then
,
and
still
has
to
a
certain
extent
,
a
venerable
and
monastic
appearance
.
<EOS>
During
Dee
's
occupation
of
it
,
it
became
a
sort
of
weird
abode
in
the
eyes
of
the
vulgar
,
and
many
a
timorous
look
was
cast
at
it
by
those
who
walked
at
eventide
on
the
opposite
bank
of
the
Irk
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
the
curiosity
of
the
watchers
was
rewarded
by
beholding
a
few
sparks
issue
from
the
chimney
,
and
now
and
then
,
the
red
reflection
of
a
fire
might
be
discerned
through
the
window
.
<EOS>
But
generally
nothing
could
be
perceived
,
and
the
building
seemed
as
dark
and
mysterious
as
its
occupant
.
<EOS>
One
night
,
however
,
a
loud
explosion
took
place,—so
loud
,
indeed
,
that
it
shook
the
whole
pile
to
its
foundation
,
dislodged
one
or
two
of
the
chimneys
,
and
overthrew
an
old
wall
,
the
stones
of
which
rolled
into
the
river
beneath
.
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
the
concussion
,
the
inhabitants
of
Hunt
's
Bank
rushed
forth
,
and
saw
,
to
their
great
alarm
,
that
the
wing
of
the
college
occupied
by
Doctor
Dee
was
in
flames
.
<EOS>
Though
many
of
them
attributed
the
circumstance
to
supernatural
agency
,
and
were
fully
persuaded
that
the
enemy
of
mankind
was
at
that
instant
bearing
off
the
conjuror
and
his
assistant
,
and
refused
to
interfere
to
stop
the
conflagration
,
others
,
more
humane
and
less
superstitious
,
hastened
to
lend
their
aid
to
extinguish
the
flames
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
College
,
they
could
scarcely
credit
their
senses
on
finding
that
there
was
no
appearance
of
fire
;
and
they
were
met
by
the
Doctor
and
his
companion
at
the
gates
,
who
informed
them
that
their
presence
was
unnecessary
,
as
all
danger
was
over
.
<EOS>
From
that
night
Doctor
Dee
's
reputation
as
a
wizard
was
firmly
established
.
<EOS>
At
the
period
of
this
history
,
Doctor
Dee
was
fast
verging
on
eighty
,
having
passed
a
long
life
in
severe
and
abstruse
study
.
<EOS>
He
had
travelled
much
,
had
visited
most
of
the
foreign
courts
,
where
he
was
generally
well
received
,
and
was
profoundly
versed
in
mathematics
,
astronomy
,
the
then
popular
science
of
judicial
astrology
,
and
other
occult
learning
.
<EOS>
So
accurate
were
his
calculations
esteemed
,
that
he
was
universally
consulted
as
an
oracle
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
,
he
resided
in
Germany
,
where
he
was
invited
by
the
Emperor
Charles
the
Fifth
,
and
retained
by
his
brother
and
successor
,
Ferdinando
.
<EOS>
He
next
went
to
Louvain
,
where
his
reputation
had
preceded
him
;
and
from
thence
to
Paris
,
where
he
lectured
at
the
schools
on
geometry
,
and
was
offered
a
professorship
of
the
university
,
but
declined
it
.
<EOS>
On
his
return
to
England
in
1551
,
he
was
appointed
one
of
the
instructors
of
the
youthful
monarch
,
Edward
the
Sixth
,
who
presented
him
with
an
annual
pension
of
a
hundred
marks
.
<EOS>
This
he
was
permitted
to
commute
for
the
rectory
of
Upton
-
upon
-
Severn
,
which
he
retained
until
the
accession
of
Mary
,
when
being
charged
with
devising
her
Majesty
's
destruction
by
<EOS>
enchantments,—certain
waxen
images
of
the
Queen
having
been
found
within
his
abode,—he
was
thrown
into
prison
,
rigorously
treated
,
and
kept
in
durance
for
a
long
period
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
from
want
of
sufficient
proof
against
him
,
he
was
liberated
.
<EOS>
Dee
shared
the
common
fate
of
all
astrologers
:
he
was
alternately
honoured
and
disgraced
.
<EOS>
His
next
patron
was
Lord
Robert
Dudley
(
afterwards
the
celebrated
Earl
of
Leicester
)
,
who
,
it
is
well
-
known
,
was
a
firm
believer
in
the
superstitious
arts
to
which
Dee
was
addicted
,
and
by
whom
he
was
employed
,
on
the
accession
of
Elizabeth
,
to
erect
a
scheme
to
ascertain
the
best
day
for
her
coronation
.
<EOS>
His
prediction
was
so
fortunate
that
it
procured
him
the
favour
of
the
Queen
,
from
whom
he
received
many
marks
of
regard
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
not
needful
to
follow
him
through
his
various
wanderings
,
it
may
be
sufficient
to
mention
,
that
in
1564
he
proceeded
to
Germany
on
a
visit
to
the
Emperor
Maximilian
,
to
whom
he
dedicated
his
"
Monas
Hieroglyphica
;
"
that
in
1571
he
fell
grievously
sick
in
Lorrain
,
whither
two
physicians
were
despatched
to
his
aid
by
Elizabeth
;
and
that
on
his
recovery
he
returned
to
his
own
country
,
and
retired
to
Mortlake
,
where
he
gathered
together
a
vast
library
,
comprising
the
rarest
and
most
curious
works
on
all
sciences
,
together
with
a
large
collection
of
manuscripts
.
<EOS>
While
thus
living
in
retirement
,
he
was
sought
out
by
Edward
Kelley
,
a
native
of
Worcestershire
,
who
represented
himself
as
in
possession
of
an
old
book
of
magic
,
containing
forms
of
invocation
,
by
which
spirits
might
be
summoned
and
controlled
,
as
well
as
a
ball
of
ivory
,
found
in
the
tomb
of
a
bishop
who
had
made
great
progress
in
hermetic
philosophy
,
which
was
filled
with
the
powder
of
projection
.
<EOS>
These
treasures
Kelley
offered
to
place
in
the
hands
of
the
Doctor
on
certain
conditions
,
which
were
immediately
acquiesced
in
,
and
thenceforth
Kelley
became
a
constant
inmate
in
his
house
,
and
an
assistant
in
all
his
practices
.
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
,
they
were
joined
by
a
Polish
nobleman
,
Albert
de
Laski
,
Palatine
of
Suabia
,
whom
they
accompanied
to
Prague
,
at
the
instance
of
the
Emperor
Rodolph
the
Second
,
who
desired
to
be
initiated
into
their
mysteries
.
<EOS>
Their
reception
at
this
court
was
not
such
as
to
induce
a
long
sojourn
at
it
;
and
Dee
having
been
warned
by
his
familiar
spirits
to
sell
his
effects
and
depart
,
complied
with
the
intimation
,
and
removed
to
Poland
.
<EOS>
The
same
fate
attended
him
here
.
<EOS>
The
nuncio
of
the
Pope
denounced
him
as
a
sorcerer
,
and
demanded
that
he
should
be
delivered
up
to
the
Inquisition
.
<EOS>
This
was
refused
by
the
monarch
;
but
Dee
and
his
companion
were
banished
from
his
dominions
,
and
compelled
to
fly
to
Bohemia
,
where
they
took
refuge
in
the
castle
of
Trebona
,
belonging
to
Count
Rosenberg
.
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
,
Dee
and
Kelley
separated
,
the
magical
instruments
being
delivered
to
the
former
,
who
bent
his
course
homewards
;
and
on
his
arrival
in
London
was
warmly
welcomed
by
the
Queen
.
<EOS>
During
his
absence
,
his
house
at
Mortlake
had
been
broken
open
by
the
populace
,
under
the
pretence
of
its
being
the
abode
of
a
wizard
,
and
rifled
of
its
valuable
library
and
manuscripts,—a
loss
severely
felt
by
its
owner
.
<EOS>
Some
years
were
now
passed
by
Dee
in
great
destitution
,
during
which
he
prosecuted
his
studies
with
the
same
ardour
as
before
,
until
at
length
in
1595
,
when
he
was
turned
seventy
,
fortune
again
smiled
upon
him
,
and
he
was
appointed
to
the
wardenship
of
the
College
at
Manchester
,
whither
he
repaired
,
and
was
installed
in
great
pomp
.
<EOS>
But
his
residence
in
this
place
was
not
destined
to
be
a
tranquil
one
.
<EOS>
His
reputation
as
a
dealer
in
the
black
art
had
preceded
him
,
and
rendered
him
obnoxious
to
the
clergy
,
with
whom
he
had
constant
disputes
,
and
a
feud
subsisted
between
him
and
the
fellows
of
his
church
.
<EOS>
It
has
already
been
mentioned
that
he
refused
to
occupy
the
house
allotted
him
,
but
preferred
taking
up
his
quarters
in
the
old
dilapidated
College
.
<EOS>
Various
reasons
were
assigned
by
his
enemies
for
this
singular
choice
of
abode
.
<EOS>
They
affirmed
—
and
with
some
reason
—
that
he
selected
it
because
he
desired
to
elude
observation,—and
that
his
mode
of
life
,
sufficiently
improper
in
a
layman
,
was
altogether
indecorous
in
an
ecclesiastic
.
<EOS>
By
the
common
people
he
was
universally
regarded
as
a
conjuror
—
and
many
at
first
came
to
consult
him
;
but
he
peremptorily
dismissed
all
such
applicants
;
and
,
when
seven
females
,
supposed
to
be
possessed
,
were
brought
to
him
that
he
might
exercise
his
power
over
the
evil
spirits
,
he
refused
to
interfere
.
<EOS>
He
also
publicly
examined
and
rebuked
a
juggler
,
named
Hartley
,
who
pretended
to
magical
knowledge
.
<EOS>
But
these
things
did
not
blind
his
enemies
,
who
continued
to
harass
him
to
such
a
degree
,
that
he
addressed
a
petition
to
James
the
First
,
entreating
to
be
brought
to
trial
,
when
the
accusations
preferred
against
him
might
be
fully
investigated
,
and
his
character
cleared
.
<EOS>
The
application
,
and
another
to
the
like
effect
addressed
to
parliament
,
were
disregarded
.
<EOS>
Dee
had
not
been
long
established
in
Manchester
when
he
was
secretly
joined
by
Kelley
,
and
they
recommenced
their
search
after
the
grand
secret,—passing
the
nights
in
making
various
alchymical
experiments
,
or
in
fancied
conferences
with
invisible
beings
.
<EOS>
Among
other
magical
articles
possessed
by
Doctor
Dee
was
a
large
globe
of
crystal
,
which
he
termed
the
Holy
Stone
,
because
he
believed
it
had
been
brought
him
by
"
angelical
ministry
;
"
and
"
in
which
,
"
according
to
Meric
Casaubon
,
"
and
out
of
which
,
by
persons
qualified
for
it
,
and
admitted
to
the
sight
of
it
,
all
shapes
and
figures
mentioned
in
every
action
were
seen
,
and
voices
heard
.
<EOS>
"
The
same
writer
informs
us
<EOS>
it
was
"
round
-
shaped
,
of
a
pretty
bigness
,
and
most
like
unto
crystal
.
<EOS>
"
Dee
himself
declared
to
the
Emperor
Rodolph
,
"
that
the
spirits
had
brought
him
a
stone
of
that
value
that
no
earthly
kingdom
was
of
such
worthiness
as
to
be
compared
to
the
virtue
and
dignity
thereof
.
"
<EOS>
He
was
in
the
habit
of
daily
consulting
this
marvellous
stone
,
and
recording
the
visions
he
saw
therein
,
and
the
conferences
he
held
through
it
with
the
invisible
world
.
<EOS>
Followed
by
Guy
Fawkes
and
Kelley
,
the
Doctor
took
his
way
down
Long
Mill
Gate
,
and
stopping
at
an
arched
gateway
on
the
left
,
near
which
,
on
the
site
of
the
modern
structure
,
stood
the
public
school
,
founded
a
century
before
by
Hugh
Oldham
,
Bishop
of
Exeter,—he
unlocked
a
small
wicket
,
and
entered
a
spacious
court
,
surrounded
on
one
side
by
high
stone
walls
,
and
on
the
other
by
a
wing
of
the
College
.
<EOS>
Conducting
his
guest
to
the
principal
entrance
of
the
building
,
which
lay
at
the
farther
end
of
the
court
,
Doctor
Dee
ushered
him
into
a
large
chamber
,
panelled
with
oak
,
and
having
a
curiously
-
moulded
ceiling
,
ornamented
with
grotesque
sculpture
.
<EOS>
This
room
,
still
in
existence
,
and
now
occupied
by
the
master
of
the
school
,
formed
Doctor
Dee
's
library
.
<EOS>
Offering
Fawkes
a
chair
,
the
Doctor
informed
him
that
when
all
was
ready
,
Kelley
should
summon
him
,
and
,
accompanied
by
his
assistant
,
he
withdrew
.
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
elapsed
before
Kelley
returned
.
<EOS>
Motioning
Guy
Fawkes
to
follow
him
<EOS>
,
he
led
the
way
through
several
intricate
passages
to
a
chamber
which
was
evidently
the
magician
's
sacred
retreat
.
<EOS>
In
a
recess
on
one
side
stood
a
table
,
covered
with
cabalistic
characters
and
figures
,
referring
to
the
celestial
influences
.
<EOS>
On
it
was
placed
the
holy
stone
,
diffusing
such
a
glistening
radiance
as
is
emitted
by
the
pebble
called
cat's
-
eye
.
<EOS>
On
the
floor
a
wide
circle
was
described
,
in
the
rings
of
which
magical
characters
,
resembling
those
on
the
table
,
were
traced
.
<EOS>
In
front
stood
a
brasier
,
filled
with
flaming
coals
;
and
before
it
hung
a
heavy
black
curtain
,
appearing
to
shroud
some
mystery
from
view
.
<EOS>
Desiring
Fawkes
to
place
himself
in
the
centre
of
the
circle
,
Doctor
Dee
took
several
ingredients
from
a
basket
handed
him
by
Kelley
,
and
cast
them
into
the
brasier
.
<EOS>
As
each
herb
or
gum
was
ignited
,
the
flame
changed
its
colour
;
now
becoming
crimson
,
now
green
,
now
blue
,
while
fragrant
or
noxious
odours
loaded
the
atmosphere
.
<EOS>
These
suffumigations
ended
,
Dee
seated
himself
on
a
chair
near
the
table
,
whither
<EOS>
he
was
followed
by
Kelley
,
and
commanding
Fawkes
not
to
move
a
footstep
,
as
he
valued
his
safety
,
he
waved
his
wand
,
and
began
in
a
solemn
tone
to
utter
an
invocation
.
<EOS>
As
he
continued
,
a
hollow
noise
was
heard
overhead
,
which
gradually
increased
in
loudness
,
until
it
appeared
as
if
the
walls
were
tumbling
about
their
ears
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
spirits
are
at
hand
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
look
behind
you
,
or
they
will
tear
you
in
pieces
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
a
horrible
din
was
heard
,
as
of
mingled
howling
,
shrieking
,
and
laughter
.
<EOS>
It
was
succeeded
by
a
low
faint
strain
of
music
,
which
gradually
died
away
,
and
then
all
was
silent
.
<EOS>
"All
is
prepared
,
"
cried
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
what
would
you
<EOS>
behold?""The
progress
of
the
great
enterprise
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Dee
waved
his
wand
.
<EOS>
The
curtains
slowly
unfolded
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
perceived
as
in
a
glass
a
group
of
dark
figures
;
amongst
which
he
noticed
one
in
all
respects
resembling
himself
.
<EOS>
A
priest
was
apparently
proposing
an
oath
,
which
the
others
were
uttering
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
you
recognise
them
?
"
said
Doctor
Dee
.
<EOS>
"Perfectly
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Look
<EOS>
again
,
"
said
Dee
.
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
the
figures
melted
away
,
and
a
new
scene
was
presented
on
the
glass
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
gloomy
vault
,
filled
with
barrels
,
partly
covered
with
fagots
and
billets
of
wood
.
<EOS>
"Have
<EOS>
you
seen
enough
?
"
demanded
Dee
.
<EOS>
"No
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
firmly
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
what
is
past
.
<EOS>
I
would
behold
that
which
is
to
come
.
<EOS>
""Look
<EOS>
again
,
then
,
"
rejoined
the
Doctor
,
waving
his
wand
.
<EOS>
For
an
instant
the
glass
was
darkened
,
and
nothing
could
be
discerned
except
the
lurid
flame
and
thick
smoke
arising
from
the
brasier
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
an
icy
chill
shot
through
the
frame
of
Guy
Fawkes
as
he
beheld
a
throng
of
skeletons
arranged
before
him
.
<EOS>
The
bony
fingers
of
the
foremost
of
the
grisly
assemblage
were
pointed
towards
an
indistinct
object
at
its
feet
.
<EOS>
As
this
object
gradually
became
more
defined
,
Guy
Fawkes
perceived
that
it
was
a
figure
resembling
himself
,
stretched
upon
the
wheel
,
and
writhing
in
the
agonies
of
torture
.
<EOS>
He
uttered
an
exclamation
of
terror
,
and
the
curtains
were
instantly
closed
.
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
afterwards
,
Guy
Fawkes
quitted
the
College
,
and
returned
to
the
Seven
Stars
.
<EOS>
IX
.
—
<EOS>
THE
PRISON
ON
SALFORD
BRIDGEOn
<EOS>
the
following
morning
,
Guy
Fawkes
had
a
long
and
private
conference
with
Father
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
The
priest
appeared
greatly
troubled
by
the
communication
made
to
him
,
but
he
said
nothing
,
and
was
for
some
time
lost
in
reflection
,
and
evidently
weighing
within
himself
what
course
it
would
be
best
to
pursue
.
<EOS>
His
uneasiness
was
not
without
effect
on
Viviana
Radcliffe
,
and
she
ventured
at
last
to
inquire
whether
he
apprehended
any
new
danger
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
scarcely
know
what
I
apprehend
,
dear
daughter
,
"
he
answered
.
<EOS>
"
But
circumstances
have
occurred
which
render
it
impossible
<EOS>
we
can
remain
longer
in
our
present
asylum
with
safety
.
<EOS>
We
must
quit
it
at
nightfall
.
<EOS>
""Is
our
retreat
then
discovered
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Viviana
,
in
alarm
.
"Not
<EOS>
as
yet
,
I
trust
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
;
"
but
I
have
just
ascertained
from
a
messenger
that
the
pursuivant
,
who
,
we
thought
,
had
departed
for
Chester
,
is
still
lingering
within
the
town
.
<EOS>
He
has
offered
a
large
reward
for
my
apprehension
,
and
having
traced
us
to
Manchester
,
declares
he
will
leave
no
house
unsearched
till
he
finds
us
.
<EOS>
He
has
got
together
a
fresh
band
of
soldiers
,
and
is
now
visiting
every
place
he
thinks
likely
to
afford
us
shelter
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
this
is
the
case
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
,
"
why
remain
here
a
single
moment
?
<EOS>
Let
us
fly
at
once
.
<EOS>
""That
would
avail
nothing,—or
rather
,
it
would
expose
us
to
fresh
risk
,
dear
daughter
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"
Every
approach
to
the
town
is
guarded
,
and
soldiers
are
posted
at
the
corners
of
the
streets
,
who
stop
and
examine
each
suspected
person
.
<EOS>
""Heaven
<EOS>
protect
us
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
this
is
not
all
,
"
continued
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"
By
some
inexplicable
and
mysterious
means
,
the
designs
of
certain
of
the
most
assured
friends
of
the
catholic
cause
have
come
to
the
knowledge
of
our
enemies
,
and
the
lives
and
safeties
of
many
worthy
men
will
be
endangered
:
amongst
others
,
that
of
your
father
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
terrify
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
rack
shall
force
nothing
from
me
,
father
,
"
said
Fawkes
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"Nor
<EOS>
from
me
,
my
son
,
"
rejoined
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
that
within
me
which
will
enable
me
to
sustain
the
bitterest
agonies
that
the
persecutors
of
our
Church
can
inflict
.
<EOS>
""Nor
<EOS>
shall
it
force
aught
from
me
,
"
added
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
,
though
you
have
trusted
me
with
nothing
that
can
implicate
others
,
I
plainly
perceive
some
plot
is
in
agitation
for
the
restoration
of
our
religion
,
and
I
more
than
suspect
Mr.
Catesby
is
its
chief
contriver
.
<EOS>
""Daughter
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Oldcorne
,
uneasily
.
<EOS>
"Fear
<EOS>
nothing
,
father
,
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
As
I
have
said
,
the
rack
shall
not
force
me
to
betray
you
.
<EOS>
Neither
should
it
keep
me
silent
when
I
feel
that
my
counsel
—
such
as
it
is
—
may
avail
you
.
<EOS>
The
course
you
are
pursuing
is
a
dangerous
and
fatal
one
;
dangerous
to
yourselves
,
and
fatal
to
the
cause
you
would
serve
.
<EOS>
Do
not
deceive
yourselves
.
<EOS>
You
are
struggling
hopelessly
and
unrighteously
,
and
Heaven
will
never
assist
an
undertaking
which
has
its
aim
in
the
terrible
waste
of
life
you
meditate
.
<EOS>
"Father
<EOS>
Oldcorne
made
no
reply
,
but
walked
apart
with
Guy
Fawkes
;
and
Viviana
abandoned
herself
to
sorrowful
reflection
.
<EOS>
Shortly
after
this
,
the
door
was
suddenly
thrown
open
,
and
Humphrey
Chetham
rushed
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
His
looks
were
full
of
apprehension
,
and
Viviana
was
at
no
loss
to
perceive
that
some
calamity
was
at
hand
.
<EOS>
"What
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
she
cried
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
pursuivant
and
his
men
are
below
,
"
he
replied
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
interrogating
the
hostess
,
and
are
about
to
search
the
house
.
<EOS>
I
managed
to
pass
them
unperceived
.
<EOS>
""We
will
resist
them
to
the
last
,
"
said
Guy
Fawkes
,
drawing
a
petronel
.
<EOS>
"Resistance
will
be
in
vain
,
"
rejoined
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
They
more
than
treble
our
number
.
<EOS>
""Is
there
<EOS>
no
means
of
escape
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"None
<EOS>
whatever
,
"
replied
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
I
hear
them
on
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
The
terrified
hostess
has
not
dared
to
deny
you
,
and
is
conducting
them
hither
.
<EOS>
""Stand
<EOS>
back
!
"
cried
Guy
Fawkes
,
striding
towards
the
door
,
"
and
let
me
alone
confront
them
.
<EOS>
That
accursed
pursuivant
has
escaped
me
once
.
<EOS>
But
he
shall
not
do
so
a
second
time
.
<EOS>
""My
son
,
"
said
Oldcorne
,
advancing
towards
him
;
"
preserve
yourself
,
if
possible
.
<EOS>
Your
life
is
of
consequence
to
the
great
cause
.
<EOS>
Think
not
of
us
—
think
not
of
revenging
yourself
upon
this
caitiff
.
<EOS>
But
think
of
the
high
destiny
for
which
you
are
reserved
.
<EOS>
That
window
offers
a
means
of
retreat
.
<EOS>
Avail
yourself
of
it
.
<EOS>
Fly!—Fly!""Ay
,
fly
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Viviana
.
"
<EOS>
And
you
,
Humphrey
Chetham,—your
presence
here
can
do
no
good
.
<EOS>
Quick!—they
come!""Nothing
should
induce
me
to
quit
you
at
such
a
moment
,
Viviana
,
"
replied
Chetham
,
"
but
the
conviction
that
I
may
be
able
to
liberate
you
,
should
these
miscreants
convey
you
to
prison
.
<EOS>
""Fly!—fly
,
my
son
,
"
cried
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
"Thus
urged
,
Guy
Fawkes
reluctantly
yielded
to
Oldcorne
's
entreaties
and
sprang
through
the
window
.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
by
Chetham
.
<EOS>
Viviana
darted
to
the
casement
,
and
saw
that
they
had
alighted
in
safety
on
the
ground
,
and
were
flying
swiftly
up
Shude
Hill
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
pursuivant
had
reached
the
door
,
which
Chetham
had
taken
the
precaution
to
fasten
,
and
was
trying
to
burst
it
open
.
<EOS>
The
bolts
offered
but
a
feeble
resistance
to
his
fury
,
and
the
next
moment
he
dashed
into
the
room
,
at
the
head
of
a
band
of
soldiers
.
<EOS>
"Seize
them
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
glancing
round
the
room
with
a
look
of
disappointment
,
"
where
are
the
others
?
<EOS>
Where
is
the
soldier
in
the
Spanish
garb
?
<EOS>
Where
is
Humphrey
Chetham
?
<EOS>
Confess
at
once
,
dog
!
"
<EOS>
he
continued
,
seizing
the
priest
by
the
throat
,
"
or
I
will
pluck
the
secret
