from
your
breast
.
<EOS>
""Do
not
harm
him
,
"
interposed
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
answer
the
question
.
<EOS>
They
are
fled
.
<EOS>
""Fled
!
"
echoed
the
pursuivant
in
consternation
.
"
<EOS>
How?""Through
that
window
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"After
them
!
"
cried
the
pursuivant
to
some
of
his
attendants
.
<EOS>
"
Take
the
soldier
,
dead
or
alive
!
<EOS>
And
now
,
"
he
continued
,
as
his
orders
were
obeyed
,
"
you
,
Father
Oldcorne
,
Jesuit
and
traitor
;
and
you
,
Viviana
Radcliffe
,
his
shelterer
and
abettor
,
I
shall
convey
you
both
to
the
prison
on
Salford
Bridge
.
<EOS>
Seize
them
,
and
bring
them
along
.
<EOS>
""Touch
<EOS>
me
not
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
,
pushing
the
men
aside
,
who
rudely
advanced
to
obey
their
leader
's
command
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
warrant
for
this
brutality
.
<EOS>
I
am
ready
to
attend
you
.
<EOS>
Take
my
arm
,
father
.
"Abashed
<EOS>
at
this
reproof
,
the
pursuivant
stalked
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
Surrounded
by
the
soldiers
,
Viviana
and
the
priest
followed
.
<EOS>
The
sad
procession
was
attended
by
crowds
to
the
very
door
of
the
prison
,
where
,
by
the
pursuivant
's
commands
,
they
were
locked
in
separate
cells
.
<EOS>
The
cell
in
which
Viviana
was
confined
was
a
small
chamber
at
the
back
of
the
prison
,
and
on
the
upper
story
.
<EOS>
It
had
a
small
grated
window
overlooking
the
river
.
<EOS>
It
has
already
been
mentioned
that
this
prison
was
originally
a
chapel
built
in
the
reign
of
Edward
the
Third
,
and
had
only
recently
been
converted
into
a
place
of
security
for
recusants
.
<EOS>
The
chamber
allotted
to
Viviana
was
contrived
in
the
roof
,
and
was
so
low
that
she
could
scarcely
stand
upright
in
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
furnished
with
a
chair
,
a
small
table
,
and
a
straw
pallet
.
<EOS>
The
hours
passed
wearily
with
Viviana
as
they
were
marked
by
the
deep
-
toned
clock
of
the
Collegiate
Church
,
the
tall
tower
of
which
fronted
her
window
.
<EOS>
Oppressed
by
the
most
melancholy
reflections
,
she
was
for
some
time
a
prey
almost
to
despair
.
<EOS>
On
whatever
side
she
looked
,
the
prospect
was
equally
cheerless
,
and
her
sole
desire
was
that
she
might
find
a
refuge
from
her
cares
in
the
seclusion
of
a
convent
.
<EOS>
For
this
she
prayed,—and
<EOS>
she
prayed
also
that
Heaven
would
soften
the
hearts
of
her
oppressors
,
and
enable
those
who
suffered
to
endure
their
yoke
with
patience
.
<EOS>
In
the
evening
provisions
were
brought
her
,
and
placed
upon
the
table
,
together
with
a
lamp
,
by
a
surly
looking
gaoler
.
<EOS>
But
Viviana
had
no
inclination
to
eat
,
and
left
them
untouched
.
<EOS>
Neither
could
she
prevail
upon
herself
to
lie
down
on
the
wretched
pallet
,
and
she
therefore
determined
to
pass
the
night
in
the
chair
.
<EOS>
After
some
hours
of
watchfulness
,
her
eyelids
closed
,
and
she
continued
to
slumber
until
she
was
aroused
by
a
slight
noise
at
the
window
.
<EOS>
Starting
at
the
sound
,
she
flew
towards
it
,
and
perceived
in
the
gloom
the
face
of
a
man
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
uttered
a
loud
cry
,
when
the
circumstances
of
her
situation
rushed
to
her
mind
,
and
the
possibility
that
it
might
be
a
friend
checked
her
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
satisfied
her
that
she
had
acted
rightly
.
<EOS>
A
voice
,
which
she
recognised
as
that
of
Humphrey
Chetham
,
called
to
her
by
name
in
a
low
tone
,
bidding
her
fear
nothing
,
as
he
was
come
to
set
her
free
.
"How
<EOS>
have
you
managed
to
reach
this
window
?
"
asked
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"By
<EOS>
a
rope
ladder
<EOS>
,
"
he
answered
.
<EOS>
"
I
contrived
in
the
darkness
to
clamber
upon
the
roof
of
the
prison
from
the
parapets
of
the
bridge
,
and
,
after
securing
the
ladder
to
a
projection
,
dropped
the
other
end
into
a
boat
,
rowed
by
Guy
Fawkes
,
and
concealed
beneath
the
arches
of
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
If
I
can
remove
this
bar
so
as
to
allow
you
to
pass
through
the
window
,
dare
you
descend
the
ladder?""No
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
shuddering
.
<EOS>
"
My
brain
reels
at
the
mere
idea
.
<EOS>
""Think
<EOS>
of
the
fate
you
will
escape
,
"
urged
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
what
will
become
of
Father
Oldcorne
?
"
asked
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he?""In
the
cell
immediately
beneath
you
,
"
replied
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"Can
<EOS>
you
not
liberate
him
?
<EOS>
"
she
continued
.
<EOS>
"Assuredly
,
if
he
will
risk
the
descent
,
"
answered
Chetham
,
reluctantly
.
<EOS>
"Free
him
first
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
,
"
and
<EOS>
at
all
hazards
<EOS>
I
will
accompany
you
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
young
merchant
made
no
reply
,
but
disappeared
from
the
window
.
<EOS>
Viviana
strained
her
gaze
downwards
;
but
it
was
too
dark
to
allow
her
to
see
anything
.
<EOS>
She
,
however
,
heard
a
noise
like
that
occasioned
by
a
file
;
and
shortly
afterwards
a
few
muttered
words
informed
her
that
the
priest
was
passing
through
the
window
.
<EOS>
The
cords
of
the
ladder
shook
against
the
bars
of
her
<EOS>
window,—and
<EOS>
she
held
her
breath
for
fear
.
<EOS>
From
this
state
of
suspense
she
was
relieved
in
a
few
minutes
by
Humphrey
Chetham
,
who
informed
her
that
Oldcorne
had
descended
in
safety
,
and
was
in
the
boat
with
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"I
will
fulfil
my
promise
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
trembling
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
fear
my
strength
will
fail
me
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
had
better
find
death
below
than
tarry
here
,
"
replied
Humphrey
Chetham
,
who
as
he
spoke
was
rapidly
filing
through
the
iron
bar
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
this
impediment
will
be
removed
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
young
merchant
worked
hard
,
and
in
a
short
time
the
stout
bar
yielded
to
his
efforts
.
<EOS>
"Now
,
then
,
"
he
cried
,
springing
into
the
room
,
"
you
are
free
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
dare
not
make
the
attempt
,
"
said
Viviana
;
"
my
strength
utterly
fails
me
.
<EOS>
""Nay
<EOS>
,
then
,
"
he
replied
;
"
I
will
take
the
risk
upon
myself
.
<EOS>
You
must
not
remain
here
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
caught
her
in
his
arms
,
and
bore
her
through
the
window
.
<EOS>
With
some
difficulty
,
and
no
little
risk
,
he
succeeded
in
gaining
a
footing
on
the
ladder
.
<EOS>
This
accomplished
,
he
began
slowly
to
descend
.
<EOS>
When
half
way
down
,
he
found
he
had
overrated
his
strength
,
and
he
feared
he
should
be
compelled
to
quit
his
hold
;
but
,
nerved
by
his
passion
,
he
held
on
,
and
making
a
desperate
effort
,
completed
the
descent
in
safety
.
<EOS>
X.
—
<EOS>
THE
FATE
OF
THE
PURSUIVANTAssisted
by
the
stream
,
and
plying
his
oars
with
great
rapidity
<EOS>
,
Guy
Fawkes
soon
left
the
town
far
behind
him
;
nor
did
he
relax
his
exertions
until
checked
by
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
He
then
ceased
rowing
,
and
directed
the
boats
towards
the
left
bank
of
the
river
.
<EOS>
"Here
<EOS>
we
propose
to
land
,
"
observed
the
young
merchant
to
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
not
more
than
a
hundred
yards
from
Ordsall
Cave
,
where
you
can
take
refuge
for
a
short
time
,
while
I
proceed
to
the
Hall
,
and
ascertain
whether
you
can
return
to
it
with
safety
.
<EOS>
""I
place
myself
entirely
in
your
hands
,
"
she
replied
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
fear
such
a
course
will
be
to
rush
into
the
very
face
of
danger
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
that
I
could
join
my
father
at
Holywell
!
<EOS>
With
him
I
should
feel
secure
.
<EOS>
""Means
may
be
found
to
effect
your
wishes
,
"
returned
Humphrey
Chetham
;
"
but
,
after
the
suffering
you
have
recently
endured
,
it
will
scarcely
be
prudent
to
undertake
so
long
a
journey
without
a
few
hours
'
repose
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow,—or
the
next
day,—you
may
set
out
.
<EOS>
""I
am
fully
equal
to
it
now
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
,
eagerly
;
"
and
any
fatigue
I
may
undergo
will
not
equal
my
present
anxiety
.
<EOS>
You
have
already
done
so
much
for
me
,
that
I
venture
to
presume
still
further
upon
your
kindness
.
<EOS>
Provide
some
means
of
conveyance
for
me
and
for
Father
Oldcorne
to
Chester
,
and
I
shall
for
ever
be
beholden
to
you
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
will
not
only
do
what
you
desire
,
Viviana
<EOS>
,
if
it
be
possible
,
"
answered
Chetham
;
"
but
,
if
you
will
allow
me
,
I
will
serve
as
your
escort
.
<EOS>
""And
I
,
also
,
"
added
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
I
fear
is
,
that
your
strength
may
fail
you
,
"
continued
the
young
merchant
,
in
a
tone
of
uneasiness
.
<EOS>
"Fear
<EOS>
nothing
then
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
made
of
firmer
material
than
you
imagine
.
<EOS>
Think
only
of
what
you
can
do
,
and
doubt
not
my
ability
to
do
it
,
also
.
<EOS>
""I
ever
deemed
you
of
a
courageous
nature
,
daughter
,
"
observed
Oldcorne
;
"
but
your
resolution
surpasses
my
belief
.
<EOS>
"By
<EOS>
this
time
the
boat
had
approached
the
shore
.
<EOS>
Leaping
upon
the
rocky
bank
,
the
young
merchant
assisted
Viviana
to
land
,
and
then
performed
the
same
service
for
the
priest
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
was
the
last
to
disembark
;
and
,
having
pulled
the
skiff
aground
,
he
followed
the
others
,
who
waited
for
him
at
a
short
distance
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
profoundly
dark
,
and
the
path
they
had
taken
,
being
shaded
by
large
trees
,
was
scarcely
discernible
.
<EOS>
Carefully
guiding
Viviana
,
who
leaned
on
him
for
support
,
the
young
merchant
proceeded
at
a
slow
pace
,
and
with
the
utmost
caution
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
they
were
surprised
and
alarmed
by
a
vivid
blaze
of
light
bursting
through
the
trees
on
the
left
.
<EOS>
"Some
building
must
be
on
fire
!
"
exclaimed
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"It
<EOS>
is
Ordsall
Hall,—it
is
your
father
's
residence
,
"
cried
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"It
is
the
work
of
that
accursed
pursuivant
,
I
will
be
sworn
,
"
said
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
it
be
so
,
<EOS>
may
Heaven
's
fire
consume
him
!
"
rejoined
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"Alas
!
<EOS>
alas
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
bursting
into
tears
,
"
I
thought
myself
equal
to
every
calamity
;
but
this
new
stroke
of
fate
is
more
than
I
can
bear
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
she
spoke
,
the
conflagration
evidently
increased
.
<EOS>
The
sky
was
illumined
by
the
red
reflection
of
the
flames
;
and
as
the
party
hurried
forward
to
a
rising
ground
,
whence
a
better
view
could
be
obtained
of
the
spectacle
,
they
saw
the
dark
walls
of
the
ancient
mansion
apparently
wrapped
in
the
devouring
element
.
<EOS>
"Let
<EOS>
us
hasten
thither
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
distractedly
.
<EOS>
"I
and
Guy
Fawkes
will
fly
there
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
,
"
and
render
all
the
assistance
in
our
power
.
<EOS>
But
,
first
,
let
me
convey
you
to
the
cave
.
<EOS>
"More
<EOS>
dead
than
alive
,
Viviana
suffered
herself
to
be
borne
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
Making
his
way
over
every
impediment
,
Chetham
soon
reached
the
excavation
;
and
depositing
his
lovely
burthen
upon
the
stone
couch
,
and
leaving
her
in
charge
of
the
priest
,
he
hurried
with
Guy
Fawkes
towards
the
Hall
.
<EOS>
On
arriving
at
the
termination
of
the
avenue
,
they
found
,
to
their
great
relief
,
that
it
was
not
the
main
structure
,
but
an
outbuilding
which
was
in
flames
,
and
from
its
situation
the
young
merchant
conceived
it
to
be
the
stables
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
they
made
this
discovery
,
they
slackened
their
pace
,
being
apprehensive
,
from
the
shouts
and
other
sounds
that
reached
them
,
that
some
hostile
party
might
be
among
the
assemblage
.
<EOS>
Crossing
the
drawbridge
—
which
was
fortunately
<EOS>
lowered,—they
were
about
to
shape
their
course
towards
the
stables
,
which
lay
at
the
further
side
of
the
Hall
,
when
they
perceived
the
old
steward
,
Heydocke
,
standing
at
the
doorway
and
wringing
his
hands
in
distraction
.
<EOS>
Humphrey
Chetham
immediately
called
to
him
.
<EOS>
"I
should
know
that
voice
!
"
cried
the
old
man
,
stepping
forward
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Chetham
,
is
it
you
?
<EOS>
You
are
arrived
at
a
sad
time
,
sir
—
a
sad
time
—
to
see
the
old
house
,
where
I
have
dwelt
,
man
and
boy
,
sixty
years
and
more
,
in
flames
.
<EOS>
But
one
calamity
has
trodden
upon
the
heels
of
another
.
<EOS>
Ever
since
Sir
William
departed
for
Holywell
nothing
has
gone
right
—
<EOS>
nothing
<EOS>
whatever
.
<EOS>
First
,
the
house
was
searched
by
the
pursuivant
and
his
gang
;
then
,
my
young
mistress
disappeared
;
then
it
was
rifled
by
these
plunderers
;
and
now
,
to
crown
all
,
it
is
on
fire
,
and
will
speedily
be
burnt
to
the
ground
.
""Say
<EOS>
not
so
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
.
<EOS>
"
The
flames
have
not
yet
reached
the
Hall
;
and
,
if
exertion
is
used
,
they
may
be
extinguished
without
further
mischief
.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
those
who
have
kindled
them
extinguish
them
,
"
replied
Heydocke
,
sullenly
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
raise
hand
more
.
<EOS>
""Who
<EOS>
are
the
incendiaries
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
pursuivant
and
his
myrmidons
,
"
replied
Heydocke
.
<EOS>
"
They
came
here
to
-
night
;
and
after
ransacking
the
house
under
pretence
of
procuring
further
evidence
against
my
master
,
and
carrying
off
everything
valuable
they
could
collect
—
plate
,
jewels
,
ornaments
,
money
,
and
even
wearing-
<EOS>
apparel,—they
ended
by
locking
up
all
the
servants,—except
myself
,
who
managed
to
elude
their
vigilance,—in
the
cellar
,
and
setting
fire
to
the
stables
.
<EOS>
""Wretches
!
"
exclaimed
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"Wretches
,
indeed
!
"
repeated
the
steward
.
<EOS>
"
But
this
is
not
all
the
villany
they
contemplate
.
<EOS>
I
had
concealed
myself
in
the
store
-
room
,
under
a
heap
of
lumber
,
and
in
searching
for
me
they
chanced
upon
a
barrel
of
gunpowder—""Well
!
"
<EOS>
interrupted
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Well
,
<EOS>
sir
,
"
pursued
Heydocke
,
"
<EOS>
I
heard
the
pursuivant
remark
to
one
of
his
comrades
,
'
This
is
a
lucky
discovery
.
<EOS>
If
we
ca
n't
find
the
steward
,
we
'll
blow
him
and
the
old
house
to
the
devil
.
'
<EOS>
Just
then
,
some
one
came
to
tell
him
I
was
hidden
in
the
stables
,
and
the
whole
troop
adjourned
thither
.
<EOS>
But
being
baulked
of
their
prey
,
I
suppose
,
they
wreaked
their
vengeance
in
the
way
you
perceive
.
<EOS>
""No
<EOS>
doubt
,
"
rejoined
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
But
they
shall
bitterly
rue
it
.
<EOS>
I
will
myself
represent
the
affair
to
the
Commissioners
.
<EOS>
""It
will
be
useless
,
"
groaned
Heydocke
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
law
to
protect
the
property
of
a
Catholic
.
<EOS>
""Where
<EOS>
is
the
barrel
of
gunpowder
you
spoke
of
?
"
asked
Guy
Fawkes
,
as
if
struck
by
a
sudden
idea
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
villains
took
it
with
them
when
they
quitted
the
store
-
room
,
"
replied
the
steward
.
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
they
have
got
it
in
the
yard
.
<EOS>
""They
have
lighted
a
fire
which
shall
be
quenched
with
their
blood
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
fiercely
.
"
<EOS>
Follow
me
.
<EOS>
I
may
need
you
both
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
darted
off
,
and
turning
the
corner
,
came
in
front
of
the
blazing
pile
.
<EOS>
Occupying
one
side
of
a
large
quadrangular
court
,
the
stables
were
wholly
disconnected
with
the
Hall
,
and
though
the
fire
burnt
furiously
,
yet
as
the
wind
carried
the
flames
and
sparks
in
a
contrary
direction
,
it
was
possible
the
latter
building
might
escape
if
due
precaution
were
taken
.
<EOS>
So
far
,
however
,
from
this
being
the
case
,
it
seemed
the
object
of
the
bystanders
to
assist
the
progress
of
the
conflagration
.
<EOS>
Several
horses
,
saddled
and
bridled
,
had
been
removed
from
the
stable
,
and
placed
within
an
open
cowhouse
.
<EOS>
To
these
Guy
Fawkes
called
Chetham
's
attention
,
and
desired
him
and
the
old
steward
to
secure
some
of
them
.
<EOS>
Hastily
giving
directions
to
Heydocke
,
the
young
merchant
obeyed,—sprang
on
the
back
of
the
nearest
courser
,
and
seizing
the
bridles
of
two
others
,
rode
off
with
them
.
<EOS>
His
example
was
followed
by
Heydocke
,
and
one
steed
only
was
left
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
confusion
and
clamour
prevailing
around
,
that
the
above
proceeding
passed
unnoticed
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
,
meanwhile
,
ensconcing
himself
behind
the
court
-
gate
,
looked
about
for
the
barrel
of
gunpowder
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
he
could
discover
no
trace
of
it
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
beneath
a
shed
,
not
far
from
him
,
he
perceived
a
soldier
seated
upon
a
small
cask
,
which
he
had
no
doubt
<EOS>
was
the
object
he
was
in
search
of
.
<EOS>
So
intent
was
the
man
upon
the
spectacle
before
him
,
that
he
was
wholly
unaware
of
the
approach
of
an
enemy
;
and
creeping
noiselessly
up
to
him
,
Guy
Fawkes
felled
him
to
the
ground
with
a
blow
from
the
heavy
butt
-
end
of
his
petronel
.
<EOS>
The
action
was
not
perceived
by
the
others
;
and
carrying
the
cask
out
of
the
yard
,
Fawkes
burst
in
the
lid
,
and
ascertained
that
the
contents
were
what
they
had
been
represented
.
<EOS>
He
then
glanced
around
,
to
see
how
he
could
best
execute
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
On
the
top
of
the
wall
adjoining
the
stables
he
beheld
the
pursuivant
,
with
three
or
four
soldiers
,
giving
directions
and
issuing
orders
.
<EOS>
Another
and
lower
wall
,
forming
the
opposite
side
of
the
quadrangle
,
and
built
on
the
edge
of
the
moat
,
approached
the
scene
of
the
fire
,
and
on
this
,
Guy
Fawkes
,
with
the
barrel
of
gunpowder
on
his
shoulder
,
mounted
.
<EOS>
Concealing
himself
behind
a
tree
which
overshadowed
it
,
he
watched
a
favourable
moment
for
his
enterprise
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
to
wait
long
.
<EOS>
Prompted
by
some
undefinable
feeling
,
which
caused
him
to
rush
upon
his
destruction
,
the
pursuivant
ventured
upon
the
roof
of
the
stables
,
and
was
followed
by
his
companions
.
<EOS>
No
sooner
did
this
occur
,
than
Guy
Fawkes
dashed
forward
,
and
hurled
the
barrel
with
all
his
force
into
the
midst
of
the
flames
,
throwing
himself
at
the
same
moment
into
the
moat
.
<EOS>
The
explosion
was
instantaneous
and
tremendous;—so
loud
as
to
be
audible
even
under
the
water
.
<EOS>
Its
effects
were
terrible
.
<EOS>
The
bodies
of
the
pursuivant
and
his
companions
were
blown
into
the
air
,
and
carried
to
the
further
side
of
the
moat
.
<EOS>
Of
those
standing
before
the
building
,
several
were
destroyed
,
and
all
more
or
less
injured
.
<EOS>
The
walls
were
thrown
down
by
the
concussion
,
and
the
roof
and
its
fiery
fragments
projected
into
the
moat
.
<EOS>
An
effectual
stop
was
put
to
the
conflagration
;
and
,
when
Guy
Fawkes
rose
to
the
boiling
and
agitated
surface
of
the
water
,
the
flames
were
entirely
extinguished
.
<EOS>
Hearing
groans
on
the
opposite
bank
of
the
moat
,
he
forced
his
way
through
the
blazing
beams
,
which
were
hissing
near
him
;
and
snatching
up
a
still
burning
fragment
,
hastened
in
the
direction
of
the
sound
.
<EOS>
In
the
blackened
and
mutilated
object
that
met
his
gaze
,
he
recognised
the
pursuivant
.
<EOS>
The
dying
wretch
also
recognised
him
,
and
attempted
to
speak
;
but
in
vain
—
his
tongue
refused
its
office
,
and
with
a
horrible
attempt
at
articulation
,
he
expired
.
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
the
explosion
,
the
domestics,—who
it
has
already
been
mentioned
were
confined
in
the
cellar;—were
rendered
so
desperate
by
their
fears
,
that
they
contrived
to
break
out
of
their
prison
,
and
now
hastened
to
the
stables
to
ascertain
the
cause
of
the
report
.
<EOS>
Leaving
them
to
assist
the
sufferers
,
whose
dreadful
groans
awakened
some
feelings
of
compunction
in
his
iron
breast
,
Guy
Fawkes
caught
the
steed,—which
had
broken
its
bridle
and
rushed
off
,
and
now
stood
shivering
,
shaking
,
and
drenched
in
moisture
near
the
drawbridge,—and
,
mounting
it
,
galloped
towards
the
cave
.
<EOS>
At
its
entrance
,
he
was
met
by
Humphrey
Chetham
and
Oldcorne
,
who
eagerly
inquired
what
had
happened
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
briefly
explained
.
<EOS>
"It
is
the
hand
of
Heaven
manifested
by
your
arm
,
my
son
,
"
observed
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"
Would
that
it
had
stricken
the
tyrant
and
apostate
prince
by
whom
our
church
is
persecuted
!
<EOS>
But
his
turn
will
speedily
arrive
.
<EOS>
""Peace
,
father
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Guy
Fawkes
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
do
not
lament
the
fate
of
the
pursuivant
,
"
observed
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
But
this
is
a
frightful
waste
of
human
life
—
and
in
such
a
cause!""It
is
the
cause
of
Heaven
,
young
sir
,
"
rejoined
the
priest
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"I
do
not
think
so
,
"
returned
Chetham
;
"
and
,
but
for
my
devotion
to
Viviana
,
I
would
have
no
further
share
in
it
.
<EOS>
""You
are
at
liberty
to
leave
us
,
if
you
think
proper
,
"
retorted
the
priest
,
coldly
.
<EOS>
"Nay
,
say
not
so
,
father
,
"
interposed
Viviana
,
who
had
been
an
unobserved
listener
to
the
foregoing
discourse
.
<EOS>
"
You
owe
your
life
—
your
liberty
,
to
Mr.
Chetham
.
<EOS>
""True
,
daughter
<EOS>
,
"
replied
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
too
hasty
,
and
entreat
his
forgiveness
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
have
it
,
reverend
sir
,
"
rejoined
the
young
merchant
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
Master
Heydocke
,
"
he
added
,
turning
to
the
steward
,
"
you
may
return
to
the
Hall
with
safety
.
<EOS>
No
one
will
molest
you
more
,
and
your
presence
may
be
needed
.
<EOS>
""But
<EOS>
my
young
mistress
—
"
said
Heydocke
.
<EOS>
"I
am
setting
out
for
Holywell
to
join
my
father
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
receive
our
instructions
from
that
place
.
<EOS>
""It
is
well
,
"
returned
the
old
man
,
bowing
respectfully
.
<EOS>
"
Heaven
shield
us
from
further
misfortune!"Humphrey
Chetham
having
assisted
Viviana
into
the
saddle
,
and
the
rest
of
the
party
having
mounted
,
they
took
the
road
to
Chester
,
while
Heydocke
returned
to
the
Hall
.
<EOS>
XI
.
—
THE
PILGRIMAGE
TO
ST
.
<EOS>
WINIFRED
'S
WELLEarly
on
the
following
morning
,
the
party
,
who
had
ridden
hard
,
and
had
paused
only
for
a
short
time
at
Knutsford
to
rest
their
steeds
,
approached
the
ancient
and
picturesque
city
of
Chester
.
<EOS>
Skirting
its
high
,
and
then
partly
fortified
walls
,
above
which
appeared
the
massive
tower
of
the
venerable
cathedral
,
they
passed
through
the
east
-
gate
,
and
proceeding
along
the
street
deriving
its
name
from
that
entrance
,
were
about
to
halt
before
the
door
of
a
large
hostel
,
called
the
Saint
Werburgh
's
Abbey
,
when
,
to
their
great
surprise
,
they
perceived
Catesby
riding
towards
them
.
<EOS>
"I
thought
I
could
not
be
mistaken
,
"
cried
the
latter
,
as
he
drew
near
and
saluted
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
about
to
set
out
for
Manchester
with
a
despatch
to
you
from
your
father
,
Miss
Radcliffe
,
when
this
most
unexpected
and
fortunate
encounter
spares
me
the
journey
.
<EOS>
But
may
I
ask
why
I
see
you
here
,
and
thus
attended
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
glancing
uneasily
at
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
A
few
words
from
Father
Oldcorne
explained
all
.
<EOS>
Catesby
affected
to
bend
his
brow
,
and
appear
concerned
at
the
relation
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
scarcely
repress
his
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
"Sir
<EOS>
William
Radcliffe
must
join
us
now
,
"
he
whispered
to
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
must
—
he
shall
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
,
in
the
same
tone
.
<EOS>
"Your
<EOS>
father
wishes
you
to
join
him
at
Holt
,
Miss
Radcliffe
,
"
remarked
Catesby
,
turning
to
her
,
"
whence
the
pilgrimage
starts
to
-
morrow
for
<EOS>
Saint
Winifred
's
Well
.
<EOS>
There
are
already
nearly
thirty
devout
persons
assembled
.
<EOS>
""Indeed
!
"
replied
Viviana
.
"
<EOS>
May
I
inquire
their
names
.
<EOS>
""Sir
Everard
and
Lady
Digby
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
"
the
Lady
Anne
Vaux
and
her
sister
,
Mrs.
Brooksby
;
Mr.
Ambrose
Rookwood
and
his
wife
,
the
two
Winters
,
Tresham
,
Wright
,
Fathers
Garnet
and
Fisher
,
and
many
others
,
in
all
probability
unknown
to
you
.
<EOS>
The
procession
started
ten
days
ago
from
Gothurst
,
in
Buckinghamshire
,
Sir
Everard
Digby
's
residence
,
and
proceeded
from
thence
by
slow
stages
to
Norbrook
and
Haddington
,
at
each
of
which
houses
it
halted
for
some
days
.
<EOS>
Yesterday
,
it
reached
Holt
,
and
starts
,
as
I
have
just
told
you
,
to
-
morrow
for
Holywell
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
so
disposed
,
you
will
be
able
to
attend
it
.
<EOS>
""I
will
gladly
do
so
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
"
<EOS>
And
since
I
find
it
is
not
necessary
to
hurry
forward
,
I
will
rest
myself
for
a
short
time
here
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
she
dismounted
,
and
the
whole
party
entered
the
hostel
.
<EOS>
Viviana
withdrew
to
seek
a
short
repose
,
and
glance
over
her
father
's
letter
,
while
Catesby
,
Guy
Fawkes
,
and
Oldcorne
,
were
engaged
in
deep
consultation
.
<EOS>
Humphrey
Chetham
,
perceiving
that
his
attendance
was
no
further
required
,
and
that
he
was
an
object
of
suspicion
and
dislike
to
Catesby,—for
whom
he
also
entertained
a
similar
aversion,—prepared
to
return
.
<EOS>
And
when
Viviana
made
her
appearance
,
he
advanced
to
bid
her
farewell
.
<EOS>
"I
can
be
of
no
further
service
to
you
,
Viviana
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
mournful
tone
;
"
and
as
my
presence
might
be
as
unwelcome
to
your
father
,
as
it
seems
to
be
to
others
of
your
friends
,
I
will
now
take
my
leave
.
<EOS>
""Farewell
,
Mr.
Chetham
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
attempt
to
oppose
your
departure
;
for
,
much
as
I
grieve
to
lose
you
—
and
that
I
do
<EOS>
so
these
tears
will
testify,—I
feel
that
it
is
for
the
best
.
<EOS>
I
owe
you
much
—
more
—
far
more
than
I
can
ever
repay
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
unworthy
in
me
,
and
unfair
to
you
,
to
say
that
I
do
not
,
and
shall
not
ever
feel
the
deepest
interest
in
you
;
that
,
next
to
my
father
,
there
is
no
one
whom
I
regard
—
nay
,
whom
I
love
so
much
.
<EOS>
""Love
!
<EOS>
Viviana
?
<EOS>
"
echoed
the
young
merchant
,
trembling
.
<EOS>
"Love
<EOS>
,
Mr.
Chetham
,
"
she
continued
,
turning
very
pale
;
"
since
you
compel
me
to
repeat
the
word
.
<EOS>
I
avow
it
boldly
,
because
—
"
and
her
voice
faltered,—"I
would
not
have
you
suppose
me
ungrateful
,
and
because
I
never
can
be
yours
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
attempt
to
dissuade
you
from
the
fatal
determination
you
have
formed
of
burying
your
charms
in
a
cloister
,
"
rejoined
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
oh
!
<EOS>
if
you
do
love
me
,
why
condemn
yourself
<EOS>
—
why
condemn
me
to
hopeless
misery?""I
will
tell
you
why
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
"
<EOS>
Because
you
are
not
of
my
faith
;
and
because
I
never
will
we
d
a
heretic
.
<EOS>
""I
am
answered
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
,
sadly
.
<EOS>
"Mr
.
<EOS>
Chetham
,
"
interposed
Oldcorne
,
who
had
approached
them
unperceived
;
"
it
is
in
your
power
to
change
Viviana
's
determination
.
""How
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
young
merchant
,
starting
.
<EOS>
"By
being
reconciled
to
the
Church
of
Rome
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
it
will
remain
unaltered
,
"
replied
Chetham
,
firmly
.
<EOS>
"And
,
if
Mr.
Chetham
would
consent
to
this
proposal
,
I
would
not
,
"
said
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Farewell
,
"
she
added
,
extending
her
hand
to
him
,
which
he
pressed
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
let
us
prolong
an
interview
so
painful
to
us
both
.
<EOS>
The
best
wish
I
can
desire
for
you
is
,
that
we
may
never
meet
again
.
<EOS>
"Without
<EOS>
another
word
,
and
without
hazarding
a
look
at
the
object
of
his
affections
,
Chetham
rushed
out
of
the
room
,
and
mounting
his
horse
,
rode
off
in
the
direction
of
Manchester
.
<EOS>
"Daughter
,
"
observed
Oldcorne
,
as
soon
as
he
was
gone
,
"
I
can
not
too
highly
approve
of
your
conduct
,
or
too
warmly
applaud
the
mastery
you
display
over
your
feelings
.
<EOS>
But
—
—
"
and
he
hesitated
.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
what
,
father
?
"
cried
Viviana
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
think
I
have
done
wrong
in
dismissing
him?""By
no
means
,
dear
daughter
,
"
replied
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
acted
most
discreetly
.
<EOS>
But
you
will
forgive
me
if
I
urge
you
—
nay
,
implore
you
not
to
take
the
veil
;
but
rather
to
bestow
your
hand
upon
some
Catholic
gentleman——""Such
as
Mr.
Catesby
,
"
interrupted
Viviana
,
glancing
in
the
direction
of
the
individual
she
mentioned
,
who
was
watching
them
narrowly
from
the
further
end
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
"Ay
,
Mr.
Catesby
,
"
repeated
Oldcorne
,
affecting
not
to
notice
the
scornful
emphasis
laid
on
the
name
.
<EOS>
"
None
more
fitting
could
be
found
,
nor
more
worthy
of
you
.
<EOS>
Our
Church
has
not
a
more
zealous
servant
and
upholder
;
and
he
will
be
at
once
a
father
and
a
husband
to
you
.
<EOS>
Such
a
union
would
be
highly
profitable
to
our
religion
.
<EOS>
And
,
though
it
is
well
for
those
whose
hearts
are
burthened
with
affliction
,
and
who
are
unable
to
render
any
active
service
to
their
faith
,
to
retire
from
the
world
,
it
behoves
every
sister
of
the
Romish
Church
to
support
it
at
a
juncture
like
the
present
,
at
any
sacrifice
of
personal
feeling
.
<EOS>
""Urge
me
no
more
<EOS>
,
father
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
firmly
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
make
every
sacrifice
for
my
religion
,
consistent
with
principle
and
feeling
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
make
this
;
neither
am
<EOS>
I
required
to
make
it
.
<EOS>
And
I
beg
you
will
entreat
Mr.
Catesby
to
desist
from
further
importunity
.
"Oldcorne
<EOS>
bowed
and
retired
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
another
syllable
exchanged
between
them
prior
to
their
departure
.
<EOS>
Crossing
the
old
bridge
over
the
Dee
,
then
defended
at
each
extremity
by
a
gate
and
tower
,
the
party
took
the
road
to
Holt
,
where
they
arrived
in
about
an
hour
.
<EOS>
The
recent
conversation
had
thrown
a
restraint
over
them
,
which
was
not
removed
during
the
journey
.
<EOS>
Habitually
taciturn
,
as
has
already
been
remarked
,
Guy
Fawkes
seemed
gloomier
and
more
thoughtful
than
ever
;
and
though
he
rode
by
the
side
of
Viviana
,
he
did
not
volunteer
a
remark
,
and
scarcely
appeared
conscious
of
her
presence
.
<EOS>
Catesby
and
Oldcorne
kept
aloof
,
and
it
was
not
until
they
came
in
sight
of
the
little
town
which
formed
their
destination
that
the
former
galloped
forward
,
and
striking
into
the
path
on
the
right
,
begged
Viviana
to
follow
him
.
<EOS>
A
turn
in
the
road
shortly
afterwards
showed
them
a
large
mansion
screened
by
a
grove
of
beech
-
trees
.
<EOS>
"That
is
the
house
to
which
we
are
going
,
"
observed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
spoke
,
they
approached
a
lodge
,
the
gates
of
which
being
opened
by
an
attendant
,
admitted
them
to
the
avenue
.
<EOS>
Viviana
's
heart
throbbed
with
delight
at
the
anticipated
meeting
with
her
father
;
but
she
could
not
repress
a
feeling
of
anxiety
at
the
distressing
intelligence
she
had
to
impart
to
him
.
<EOS>
As
she
drew
near
the
house
she
perceived
him
walking
beneath
the
shade
of
the
trees
with
two
other
persons
;
and
quickening
her
pace
,
sprang
from
her
steed
,
and
almost
before
he
was
aware
of
it
was
in
his
arms
.
<EOS>
"Why
<EOS>
do
I
see
you
here
so
unexpectedly
,
my
dear
child
?
"
cried
Sir
William
Radcliffe
,
as
soon
as
he
had
recovered
from
the
surprise
which
her
sudden
appearance
occasioned
him
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Catesby
only
left
this
morning
,
charged
with
a
letter
entreating
you
to
set
out
without
delay,—and
<EOS>
now
I
behold
you
.
<EOS>
What
has
happened?"Viviana
then
recounted
the
occurrences
of
the
last
few
days
.
<EOS>
"It
is
as
I
feared
,
"
replied
Sir
William
,
in
a
desponding
tone
.
<EOS>
"
Our
oppressors
will
never
cease
till
they
drive
us
to
desperation!""They
will
not
!
"
rejoined
a
voice
behind
him
.
"
<EOS>
Well
may
we
exclaim
with
the
prophet—'How
long
,
O
Lord
,
shall
I
cry
,
and
thou
wilt
not
hear
?
<EOS>
Shall
I
cry
out
to
thee
suffering
violence
,
and
thou
wilt
not
save
?
<EOS>
Why
hast
thou
showed
me
iniquity
and
grievance
,
to
see
rapine
and
injustice
before
me
?
<EOS>
Why
lookest
thou
upon
them
that
do
unjust
things
,
and
holdest
thy
peace
when
the
wicked
devoureth
the
man
that
is
more
just
than
himself?'"Viviana
looked
in
the
direction
of
the
speaker
and
beheld
a
man
in
a
priestly
garb
,
whose
countenance
struck
her
forcibly
.
<EOS>
He
was
rather
under
the
middle
height
,
of
a
slight
spare
figure
,
and
in
age
might
be
about
fifty
.
<EOS>
His
features
,
which
in
his
youth
must
have
been
pleasing
,
if
not
handsome
,
and
which
were
still
regular
,
were
pale
and
emaciated
;
but
his
eye
was
dark
,
and
of
unusual
brilliancy
.
<EOS>
A
single
glance
at
this
person
satisfied
her
it
was
Father
Garnet
,
the
provincial
of
the
English
Jesuits
;
nor
was
she
mistaken
in
her
supposition
.
<EOS>
Of
this
remarkable
person
,
so
intimately
connected
with
the
main
events
of
the
history
about
to
be
related
,
it
may
be
proper
to
offer
some
preliminary
account
.
<EOS>
Born
at
Nottingham
in
1554
,
in
the
reign
of
Queen
Mary
,
and
of
obscure
parentage
,
Henry
Garnet
was
originally
destined
to
the
Protestant
Church
,
and
educated
,
with
a
view
to
taking
orders
,
at
Winchester
school
,
whence
<EOS>
it
was
intended
he
should
be
removed
in
due
course
to
Oxford
.
<EOS>
But
this
design
was
never
carried
into
effect
.
<EOS>
Influenced
by
motives
,
into
which
it
is
now
scarcely
worth
while
inquiring
,
and
which
have
been
contested
by
writers
on
both
sides
of
the
question
,
Garnet
proceeded
from
Winchester
to
London
,
where
he
engaged
himself
as
corrector
of
the
press
to
a
printer
of
law
-
books
,
named
Tottel
,
in
which
capacity
he
became
acquainted
with
Sir
Edward
Coke
and
Chief
Justice
Popham,—one
of
whom
was
afterwards
to
be
the
leading
counsel
against
him
,
and
the
other
his
judge
.
<EOS>
After
continuing
in
this
employment
for
two
years
,
during
which
he
had
meditated
a
change
in
his
religion
,
he
went
abroad
,
and
travelling
first
to
Madrid
,
and
then
to
Rome
,
saw
enough
of
the
Catholic
priesthood
to
confirm
his
resolution
,
and
in
1575
he
assumed
the
habit
of
a
Jesuit
.
<EOS>
Pursuing
his
studies
with
the
utmost
zeal
and
ardour
at
the
Jesuits
'
College
,
under
the
celebrated
Bellarmine
,
and
the
no
less
celebrated
Clavius
,
he
made
such
progress
,
that
upon
the
indisposition
of
the
latter
,
he
was
able
to
fill
the
mathematical
chair
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
he
less
skilled
in
philosophy
,
metaphysics
,
and
divinity
;
and
his
knowledge
of
Hebrew
was
so
profound
that
he
taught
it
publicly
in
the
Roman
schools
.
<EOS>
To
an
enthusiastic
zeal
in
the
cause
of
the
religion
he
had
espoused
,
Garnet
added
great
powers
of
persuasion
and
eloquence,—a
combination
of
qualities
well
fitting
him
for
the
office
of
a
missionary
priest
;
and
undismayed
by
the
dangers
he
would
have
to
encounter
,
and
eager
to
propagate
his
doctrines
,
he
solicited
to
be
sent
on
this
errand
to
his
own
country
.
<EOS>
At
the
instance
of
Father
Persons
,
he
received
an
appointment
to
the
mission
in
1586
,
and
he
secretly
landed
in
England
in
the
same
year
.
<EOS>
Braving
every
danger
,
and
shrinking
from
no
labour
,
he
sought
on
all
hands
to
make
proselytes
to
the
ancient
faith
,
and
to
sustain
the
wavering
courage
of
its
professors
.
<EOS>
Two
years
afterwards
,
on
the
imprisonment
of
the
Superior
of
the
Jesuits
,
being
raised
to
that
important
post
,
he
was
enabled
to
extend
his
sphere
of
action
;
and
redoubling
his
exertions
in
consequence
,
he
so
well
discharged
his
duties
,
that
it
was
mainly
owing
to
him
that
the
Catholic
party
was
kept
together
during
the
fierce
persecutions
of
the
latter
end
of
Elizabeth
's
reign
.
<EOS>
Compelled
to
personate
various
characters
,
as
he
travelled
from
place
to
place
,
Garnet
had
acquired
a
remarkable
facility
for
disguise
;
and
such
was
his
address
and
courage
,
that
he
not
unfrequently
imposed
upon
the
very
officers
sent
in
pursuit
of
him
.
<EOS>
Up
to
the
period
of
Elizabeth
's
demise
,
he
had
escaped
arrest
;
and
,
though
involved
in
the
treasonable
intrigue
with
the
king
of
Spain
,
and
other
conspiracies
,
he
procured
a
general
pardon
under
the
great
seal
.
<EOS>
His
office
and
profession
naturally
brought
him
into
contact
with
the
chief
Catholic
families
throughout
the
kingdom
;
and
he
maintained
an
active
correspondence
with
many
of
them
,
by
means
of
his
various
agents
and
emissaries
.
<EOS>
The
great
object
of
his
life
being
the
restoration
of
the
fallen
religion
,
to
accomplish
this
,
as
he
conceived
,
great
and
desirable
end
,
he
was
prepared
to
adopt
any
means
,
however
violent
or
obnoxious
.
<EOS>
When
,
under
the
seal
of
confession
,
Catesby
revealed
to
him
his
dark
designs
,
so
far
from
discouraging
him
,
all
he
counselled
was
caution
.
<EOS>
Having
tested
the
disposition
of
the
wealthier
Romanists
to
rise
against
their
oppressors
,
and
finding
a
general
insurrection
,
as
has
before
been
stated
,
impracticable
,
he
gave
every
encouragement
and
assistance
to
the
conspiracy
forming
among
the
more
desperate
and
discontented
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
At
his
instigation
,
the
present
pilgrimage
to
Saint
Winifred
's
Well
was
undertaken
,
in
the
hope
that
,
when
so
large
a
body
of
the
Catholics
were
collected
together
,
some
additional
aid
to
the
project
might
be
obtained
.
<EOS>
One
of
the
most
mysterious
and
inexplicable
portions
of
Garnet
's
history
is
that
relating
to
Anne
Vaux
.
<EOS>
This
lady
,
the
daughter
of
Lord
Vaux
of
Harrowden
,
a
rigid
Catholic
nobleman
,
and
one
of
Garnet
's
earliest
patrons
and
friends
,
on
the
death
of
her
father
,
in
1595
,
attached
herself
to
his
fortunes,—accompanied
him
in
all
his
missions,—shared
all
his
privations
and
dangers,—and
,
regardless
of
calumny
or
reproach
,
devoted
herself
entirely
to
his
service
.
<EOS>
What
is
not
less
singular
,
her
sister
,
who
had
married
a
Catholic
gentleman
named
Brooksby
,
became
his
equally
zealous
attendant
.
<EOS>
Their
enthusiasm
produced
a
similar
effect
on
Mr.
Brooksby
;
and
wherever
Garnet
went
,
all
three
accompanied
him
.
<EOS>
By
his
side
,
on
the
present
occasion
,
stood
Sir
Everard
Digby
.
<EOS>
Accounted
one
of
the
handsomest
,
most
accomplished
,
and
best
-
informed
men
of
his
time
,
Sir
Everard
,
at
the
period
of
this
history
only
twenty
-
four
,
had
married
,
when
scarcely
sixteen
,
Maria
,
heiress
of
the
ancient
and
honourable
family
of
Mulshoe
,
with
whom
he
obtained
a
large
fortune
,
and
the
magnificent
estate
of
Gothurst
,
or
Gaythurst
,
in
Buckinghamshire
.
<EOS>
Knighted
by
James
the
First
at
Belvoir
Castle
,
on
his
way
from
Scotland
to
London
,
Digby
,
who
had
once
formed
one
of
the
most
brilliant
ornaments
of
the
court
,
had
of
late
in
a
great
degree
retired
from
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
,
"
writes
Father
Greenway
,
"
that
he
had
dwelt
much
in
the
Queen
's
court
,
and
was
in
the
way
of
obtaining
honours
and
distinction
by
his
graceful
manners
and
rare
parts
,
he
chose
rather
to
bear
the
cross
with
the
persecuted
Catholics
,
et
vivere
abjectus
in
domo
Domini
,
than
to
sail
through
the
pleasures
of
a
palace
and
the
prosperities
of
the
world
,
to
the
shipwreck
of
his
conscience
and
the
destruction
of
his
soul
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Having
only
when
he
completed
his
minority
professed
the
Catholic
religion
,
he
became
deeply
concerned
at
its
fallen
state
,
and
his
whole
thoughts
were
bent
upon
its
restoration
.
<EOS>
This
change
in
feeling
was
occasioned
chiefly
,
if
not
altogether
,
by
Garnet
,
by
whom
his
conversion
had
been
accomplished
.
<EOS>
Sir
Everard
Digby
was
richly
attired
in
a
black
velvet
doublet
,
with
sleeves
slashed
with
white
satin
,
and
wore
a
short
mantle
of
the
same
material
,
similarly
lined
.
<EOS>
He
had
the
enormous
trunk
hose
,
heretofore
mentioned
as
the
distinguishing
peculiarity
of
the
costume
of
the
period
,
and
wore
black
velvet
shoes
,
ornamented
with
white
roses
.
<EOS>
An
ample
ruff
encircled
his
throat
.
<EOS>
His
hat
was
steeple
-
crowned
,
and
somewhat
broader
in
the
leaf
than
was
ordinarily
worn
,
and
shaded
with
a
plume
of
black
feathers
.
<EOS>
His
hair
was
raven
black
,
and
he
wore
a
pointed
beard
,
and
moustaches
.
<EOS>
His
figure
was
tall
and
stately
,
and
his
features
grave
and
finely
formed
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
group
had
been
joined
by
the
others
,
and
a
friendly
greeting
took
place
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
was
presented
by
Catesby
to
Sir
William
Radcliffe
and
Sir
Everard
Digby
.
<EOS>
To
Garnet
he
required
no
introduction
,
and
Father
Oldcorne
was
known
to
all
.
<EOS>
After
a
little
further
conversation
,
the
party
adjourned
to
the
house
,
which
belonged
to
a
Welsh
Catholic
gentleman
,
named
Griffiths
,
who
,
though
absent
at
the
time
,
had
surrendered
it
to
the
use
of
Sir
Everard
Digby
and
his
friends
.
<EOS>
On
their
entrance
,
Viviana
was
introduced
by
her
father
to
Lady
Digby
,
who
presided
as
hostess
,
and
welcomed
her
with
great
cordiality
.
<EOS>
She
was
then
conducted
to
her
own
room
,
where
she
was
speedily
joined
by
Sir
William
;
and
they
remained
closeted
together
till
summoned
to
the
principal
meal
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
At
the
table
,
which
was
most
hospitably
served
,
Viviana
found
,
in
addition
to
her
former
companions
,
a
large
assemblage
,
to
most
of
whom
<EOS>
she
was
a
stranger
,
consisting
of
Anne
Vaux
,
Mr.
Brooksby
and
his
wife
,
Ambrose
Rookwood
,
two
brothers
named
Winter
,
two
Wrights
,
Francis
Tresham,—persons
of
whom
it
will
be
necessary
to
make
particular
mention
hereafter,—and
<EOS>
several
others
,
in
all
amounting
to
thirty
.
<EOS>
The
meal
over
,
the
company
dispersed
,
and
Viviana
and
her
father
,
passing
through
an
open
window
,
wandered
forth
upon
a
beautiful
and
spreading
lawn
,
and
thence
under
the
shade
of
the
beech
-
trees
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
been
long
here
,
anxiously
conferring
on
recent
events
,
when
they
perceived
Garnet
and
Catesby
approaching
.
"Father
,
dear
father
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
hastily
,
"
<EOS>
I
was
about
to
warn
you
;
but
I
have
not
time
to
do
so
now
.
<EOS>
Some
dark
and
dangerous
plot
is
in
agitation
to
restore
our
religion
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Catesby
is
anxious
to
league
you
with
it
.
<EOS>
Do
not
—
do
not
yield
to
his
solicitations!""Fear
nothing
on
that
score
,
Viviana
,
"
replied
Sir
William
,
"
I
have
already
perplexities
enow
,
without
adding
to
them
.
<EOS>
""I
will
leave
you
,
then
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
And
,
as
soon
as
the
others
came
up
,
she
made
some
excuse
for
withdrawing
,
and
returned
to
the
house
.
<EOS>
The
window
of
her
chamber
commanded
the
avenue
,
and
from
it
she
watched
the
group
.
<EOS>
They
remained
for
a
long
time
pacing
up
and
down
,
in
earnest
conversation
.
<EOS>
By
and
by
,
they
were
joined
by
Oldcorne
and
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Then
came
a
third
party
,
consisting
of
the
Winters
and
Wrights
;
and
,
lastly
,
Sir
Everard
Digby
and
Tresham
swelled
the
list
.
<EOS>
The
assemblage
was
then
harangued
by
Catesby
,
and
the
most
profound
attention
paid
to
his
address
.
<EOS>
Viviana
kept
her
eye
fixed
upon
her
father
's
countenance
,
and
from
its
changing
expression
inferred
what
effect
the
speech
produced
upon
him
.
<EOS>
At
its
conclusion
,
the
assemblage
separated
in
little
groups
;
and
she
perceived
,
with
great
uneasiness
,
that
Father
Garnet
passed
his
arm
through
that
of
her
father
,
and
led
him
away
.
<EOS>
Some
time
elapsed
,
and
neither
of
them
re
-
appeared
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
warning
was
in
vain
;
he
has
joined
them
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
.
<EOS>
"No
,
Viviana
!
"
cried
her
father
's
voice
behind
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
joined
them
.
<EOS>
Nor
shall
I
do
so
.
<EOS>
""Heaven
be
praised
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
flinging
her
arms
around
his
neck
.
<EOS>
Neither
of
them
were
aware
that
they
were
overheard
by
Garnet
,
who
had
noiselessly
followed
Sir
William
into
the
room
,
and
muttered
to
himself
,
"
<EOS>
For
all
this
,
he
shall
join
the
plot
,
and
she
shall
we
d
Catesby
.
"He
<EOS>
then
coughed
slightly
,
to
announce
his
presence
;
and
,
apologizing
to
Viviana
for
the
intrusion
,
told
her
he
came
to
confess
her
previously
to
the
celebration
of
mass
,
which
would
take
place
that
evening
,
in
a
small
chapel
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
Wholly
obedient
to
the
command
of
her
spiritual
advisers
,
Viviana
instantly
signified
her
assent
;
and
,
her
father
having
withdrawn
,
she
laid
open
the
inmost
secrets
of
her
heart
to
the
Jesuit
.
<EOS>
Severely
reprobating
her
love
for
a
heretic
,
before
he
would
give
her
absolution
,
Garnet
enjoined
her
,
as
a
penance
,
to
walk
barefoot
to
the
holy
well
on
the
morrow
,
and
to
make
a
costly
offering
at
the
shrine
of
the
saint
.
<EOS>
Compliance
being
promised
to
his
injunction
,
he
pronounced
the
absolution
,
and
departed
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
,
mass
was
celebrated
by
Garnet
,
and
the
sacrament
administered
to
the
assemblage
.
<EOS>
An
hour
before
daybreak
,
the
party
again
assembled
in
the
chapel
,
where
matins
were
performed
;
after
which
,
the
female
devotees
,
who
were
clothed
in
snow
-
white
woollen
robes
,
with
wide
sleeves
and
hoods
,
and
having
large
black
crosses
woven
in
front
,
retired
for
a
short
time
,
and
re
-
appeared
,
with
their
feet
bared
,
and
hair
unbound
.
<EOS>
Each
had
a
large
rosary
attached
to
the
cord
that
bound
her
waist
.
<EOS>
Catesby
thought
Viviana
had
never
appeared
so
lovely
as
in
this
costume
;
and
as
he
gazed
at
her
white
and
delicately
formed
feet
,
her
small
rounded
ankles
,
her
dark
and
abundant
tresses
falling
in
showers
almost
to
the
ground
,
he
became
more
deeply
enamoured
than
before
.
<EOS>
His
passionate
gaze
was
,
however
,
unnoticed
,
as
the
object
of
it
kept
her
eyes
steadily
fixed
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Lady
Digby
,
who
was
a
most
beautiful
woman
,
scarcely
appeared
to
less
advantage
;
and
,
as
she
walked
side
by
side
with
Viviana
in
the
procession
,
the
pair
attracted
universal
admiration
from
all
who
beheld
them
.
<EOS>
Everything
being
at
last
in
readiness
,
and
the
order
of
march
fully
arranged
,
two
youthful
choristers
,
in
surplices
,
chanting
a
hymn
to
Saint
Winifred
,
set
forth
.
<EOS>
They
were
followed
by
two
men
bearing
silken
banners
,
on
one
of
which
was
displayed
the
martyrdom
of
the
saint
whose
shrine
they
were
about
to
visit
,
and
on
the
other
a
lamb
carrying
a
cross
;
next
came
Fathers
Oldcorne
and
Fisher
,
each
sustaining
a
large
silver
crucifix
;
next
,
Garnet
alone
,
in
the
full
habit
of
his
order
;
next
,
the
females
,
in
the
attire
before
described
,
and
walking
two
and
two
;
next
,
Sir
Everard
Digby
and
Sir
William
Radcliffe
;
and
lastly
,
the
rest
of
the
pilgrims
,
to
the
number
of
fourteen
.
<EOS>
These
were
all
on
foot
.
<EOS>
But
at
the
distance
of
fifty
paces
behind
them
rode
Guy
Fawkes
and
Catesby
,
at
the
head
of
twenty
well
-
armed
and
well
-
mounted
attendants
,
intended
to
serve
as
a
guard
in
case
of
need
.
<EOS>
In
such
order
,
this
singular
procession
moved
forward
at
a
slow
pace
,
taking
its
course
along
a
secluded
road
leading
to
the
ridge
of
hills
extending
from
the
neighbourhood
of
Wrexham
to
Mold
,
and
from
thence
,
in
an
almost
unbroken
chain
,
to
Holywell
.
<EOS>
Along
these
heights
,
whence
magnificent
views
were
obtained
of
the
broad
estuary
of
the
Dee
and
the
more
distant
ocean
,
the
train
proceeded
without
interruption
;
and
though
the
road
selected
was
one
seldom
traversed
,
and
through
a
country
thinly
peopled
,
still
,
the
rumour
of
the
pilgrimage
having
gone
abroad
,
hundreds
were
stationed
at
different
points
to
behold
it
.
<EOS>
Some
expressions
of
disapprobation
were
occasionally
manifested
by
the
spectators
;
but
the
presence
of
the
large
armed
force
effectually
prevented
any
interference
.
<EOS>
Whenever
such
a
course
could
be
pursued
,
the
procession
took
its
way
over
the
sward
.
<EOS>
Still
the
sufferings
of
the
females
were
severe
in
the
extreme
;
and
before
Viviana
had
proceeded
a
mile
,
her
white
,
tender
feet
were
cut
and
bruised
by
the
sharp
flints
over
which
she
walked
;
every
step
she
took
leaving
a
bloody
print
behind
it
.
<EOS>
Lady
Digby
was
in
little
better
condition
.
<EOS>
But
such
was
the
zeal
by
which
they
,
in
common
with
all
the
other
devotees
following
them
,
were
animated
,
that
not
a
single
murmur
was
uttered
.
<EOS>
Proceeding
in
this
way
,
they
reached
at
mid
-
day
a
small
stone
chapel
on
the
summit
of
the
hill
overlooking
Plas
-
Newydd
,
where
they
halted
,
and
devotions
being
performed
,
the
females
bathed
their
lacerated
limbs
in
a
neighbouring
brook
,
after
which
they
were
rubbed
with
a
cooling
and
odorous
ointment
.
<EOS>
Thus
refreshed
,
they
again
set
forward
,
and
halting
a
second
time
at
Plas
-
Isaf
,
where
similar
religious
ceremonies
were
observed
,
they
rested
for
the
day
at
a
lodging
prepared
for
their
reception
in
the
vicinity
of
Mold
.
<EOS>
The
night
being
passed
in
prayer
,
early
in
the
morning
they
commenced
their
march
in
the
same
order
as
before
.
<EOS>
When
Viviana
first
set
her
feet
to
the
ground
,
she
felt
as
if
she
were
treading
on
hot
iron
,
and
the
pain
was
so
excruciating
,
that
she
could
not
repress
a
cry
.
<EOS>
"Heed
<EOS>
not
your
sufferings
,
dear
daughter
,
"
observed
Garnet
,
compassionately
;
"
the
waters
of
the
holy
fountain
will
heal
the
wounds
both
of
soul
and
body
.
<EOS>
"Overcoming
<EOS>
her
agony
by
a
powerful
effort
<EOS>
,
she
contrived
to
limp
forward
;
and
the
whole
party
was
soon
after
in
motion
.
<EOS>
Halting
;
for
two
hours
at
Pentre
-
Terfyn
,
and
again
at
Skeviog
,
the
train
,
towards
evening
,
reached
the
summit
of
the
hill
overlooking
Holywell
,
at
the
foot
of
which
could
be
seen
the
ruins
of
Basingwerk
Abbey
,
and
the
roof
of
the
ancient
chapel
erected
over
the
sacred
spring
.
<EOS>
At
this
sight
,
those
who
were
foremost
in
the
procession
fell
on
their
knees
;
and
the
horsemen
dismounting
,
imitated
their
example
.
<EOS>
An
earnest
supplication
to
Saint
Winifred
was
then
poured
forth
by
Father
Garnet
,
in
which
all
the
others
joined
,
and
a
hymn
in
her
honour
chanted
by
the
choristers
.
<EOS>
Their
devotions
ended
,
the
whole
train
arose
,
and
walked
slowly
down
the
steep
descent
.
<EOS>
As
they
entered
the
little
town
,
which
owes
its
name
and
celebrity
to
the
miraculous
spring
rising
within
it
,
they
were
met
by
a
large
concourse
of
people
,
who
had
flocked
from
Flint
,
and
the
other
neighbouring
places
to
witness
the
ceremonial
.
<EOS>
Most
of
the
inhabitants
of
Holywell
,
holding
their
saintly
patroness
in
the
deepest
veneration
,
viewed
this
pilgrimage
to
her
shrine
as
a
proper
tribute
of
respect
,
while
those
of
the
opposite
faith
were
greatly
impressed
by
it
.
<EOS>
As
the
procession
advanced
,
the
crowd
divided
into
two
lines
to
allow
it
passage
,
and
many
fell
on
their
knees
imploring
a
blessing
from
Garnet
,
which
he
in
no
instance
refused
.
<EOS>
When
within
a
hundred
yards
of
the
sacred
well
,
they
were
met
by
a
priest
,
followed
by
another
small
train
of
pilgrims
.
<EOS>
A
Latin
oration
having
been
pronounced
by
this
priest
,
and
replied
to
in
the
same
language
by
Garnet
,
the
train
was
once
more
put
in
motion
,
and
presently
reached
the
ancient
fabric
built
over
the
sacred
fountain
.
<EOS>
The
legend
of
Saint
Winifred
is
so
well
known
,
that
it
is
scarcely
necessary
to
repeat
it
.
<EOS>
For
the
benefit
of
the
uninformed
,
however
,
it
may
be
stated
that
she
flourished
about
the
middle
of
the
seventh
century
,
and
was
the
daughter
of
Thewith
,
one
of
the
chief
lords
of
Wales
.
<EOS>
Devoutly
educated
by
a
monk
named
Beuno
,
who
afterwards
received
canonization
,
she
took
the
veil
,
and
retired
to
a
small
monastery
(
the
ruins
of
which
still
exist
)
,
built
by
her
father
near
the
scene
of
her
subsequent
martyrdom
.
<EOS>
Persecuted
by
the
addresses
of
Caradoc
,
son
of
Alan
,
Prince
of
Wales
,
she
fled
from
him
to
avoid
his
violence
.
<EOS>
He
followed
,
and
inflamed
by
fury
at
her
resistance
,
struck
off
her
head
.
<EOS>
For
this
atrocity
,
the
earth
instantly
opened
and
swallowed
him
alive
,
while
from
the
spot
where
the
head
had
fallen
gushed
forth
a
fountain
of
unequalled
force
and
purity
,
producing
more
than
a
hundred
tons
a
minute
.
<EOS>
The
bottom
of
this
miraculous
well
is
strewn
with
pebbles
streaked
with
red
veins
,
in
memory
of
the
virgin
saint
from
whose
blood
it
sprung
.
<EOS>
On
its
margin
grows
an
odorous
moss
,
while
its
gelid
and
translucent
waters
are
esteemed
a
remedy
for
many
disorders
.
<EOS>
Winifred
's
career
did
not
terminate
with
her
decapitation
.
<EOS>
Resuscitated
by
the
prayers
of
Saint
Beuno
,
she
lived
many
years
a
life
of
the
utmost
sanctity
,
bearing
,
as
a
mark
of
the
miracle
performed
in
her
behalf
,
a
narrow
crimson
circle
round
her
throat
.
<EOS>
Passing
the
chapel
adjoining
the
well
,
built
in
the
reign
of
Henry
the
Seventh
by
his
mother
,
the
pious
Countess
of
Richmond
,
the
pilgrims
came
to
the
swift
clear
stream
rushing
from
the
well
.
<EOS>
Instead
of
ascending
the
steps
leading
to
the
edifice
built
over
the
spring
,
they
plunged
into
the
stream
,
and
crossing
it
entered
the
structure
by
a
doorway
on
the
further
side
.
<EOS>
Erected
by
the
Countess
of
Richmond
at
the
same
period
as
the
chapel
,
this
structure
,
quadrangular
in
form
,
and
of
great
beauty
,
consists
of
light
clustered
pillars
and
mouldings
,
supporting
the
most
gorgeous
tracery
and
groining
,
the
whole
being
ornamented
with
sculptured
bosses
,
pendent
capitals
,
fretwork
,
niches
,
and
tabernacles
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
is
a
large
stone
basin
,
to
receive
the
water
of
the
fountain
,
around
which
the
procession
now
grouped
,
and
as
soon
as
all
were
assembled
,
at
the
command
of
Father
Garnet
they
fell
on
their
knees
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
solemn
and
striking
sight
to
see
this
large
group
prostrated
around
that
beautiful
fountain
,
and
covered
by
that
ancient
structure,—a
touching
thing
to
hear
the
voice
of
prayer
mingling
with
the
sound
of
the
rushing
water
.
<EOS>
After
this
,
they
all
arose
.
<EOS>
A
hymn
was
then
chanted
,
and
votive
offerings
made
at
the
shrine
of
the
saint
.
<EOS>
The
male
portion
of
the
assemblage
then
followed
Garnet
to
the
chapel
,
where
further
religious
rites
were
performed
,
while
the
female
devotees
,
remaining
near
the
fountain
,
resigned
themselves
to
the
care
of
several
attendants
of
their
own
sex
,
who
,
having
bathed
their
feet
in
the
water
,
applied
some
of
the
fragrant
moss
above
described
to
the
wounds
;
and
,
such
was
the
faith
of
the
patients
,
or
the
virtue
of
the
application
,
that
in
a
short
time
they
all
felt
perfectly
restored
,
and
able
to
join
their
companions
in
the
chapel
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
the
evening
was
spent
,
and
it
was
not
until
late
that
they
finished
their
devotions
,
and
departed
to
the
lodgings
provided
for
them
in
the
town
.
<EOS>
Impressed
with
a
strange
superstitious
feeling
,
which
he
could
scarcely
acknowledge
to
himself
,
Guy
Fawkes
determined
to
pass
the
night
near
the
well
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
without
communicating
his
intention
to
his
companions
,
he
threw
a
small
knapsack
over
his
shoulder
,
containing
a
change
of
linen
,
and
a
few
articles
of
attire
,
and
proceeded
thither
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
brilliant
moonlight
night
,
and
,
as
the
radiance
,
streaming
through
the
thin
clustered
columns
of
the
structure
,
lighted
up
its
fairy
architecture
,
and
fell
upon
the
clear
cold
waves
of
the
fountain
,
revealing
the
blood
-
streaked
pebbles
beneath
,
the
effect
was
inexpressibly
beautiful
.
<EOS>
So
charmed
was
Guy
Fawkes
by
the
sight
,
that
he
remained
for
some
time
standing
near
the
edge
of
the
basin
,
as
if
fascinated
by
the
marvellous
spring
that
boiled
up
and
sparkled
at
his
feet
.
<EOS>
Resolved
to
try
the
efficacy
of
the
bath
,
he
threw
off
his
clothes
and
plunged
into
it
.
<EOS>
The
water
was
cold
as
ice
;
but
on
emerging
from
it
he
felt
wonderfully
refreshed
.
<EOS>
Having
dressed
himself
,
he
wrapped
his
cloak
around
him
,
and
,
throwing
himself
on
the
stone
floor
,
placed
the
knapsack
under
his
head
,
and
grasping
a
petronel
in
his
right
hand
,
to
be
ready
in
case
of
a
surprise
,
disposed
himself
to
slumber
.
<EOS>
IllustrationAccustomed
to
a
soldier
's
couch
,
he
soon
fell
asleep
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
long
closed
his
eyes
when
he
dreamed
that
from
out
of
the
well
a
female
figure
,
slight
and
unsubstantial
as
the
element
from
which
it
sprang
,
arose
.
<EOS>
It
was
robed
in
what
resembled
a
nun
's
garb
;
but
so
thin
and
vapoury
,
that
the
very
moonlight
shone
through
it
.
<EOS>
From
the
garments
of
the
figure
,
as
well
as
from
the
crimson
circle
round
its
throat
,
he
knew
that
it
must
be
the
patroness
of
the
place
,
the
sainted
Winifred
,
that
he
beheld
.
<EOS>
He
felt
no
horror
,
but
the
deepest
awe
.
<EOS>
The
arm
of
the
figure
was
raised,—its
benignant
regards
fixed
upon
him,—and
,
as
soon
as
it
gained
the
level
of
the
basin
,
it
glided
towards
him
.
<EOS>
XII
.
<EOS>
—
THE
VISIONBefore
daybreak
on
the
following
morning
,
Garnet
,
who
had
been
engaged
in
earnest
conference
with
Catesby
during
the
whole
of
the
night
,
<EOS>
repaired
to
the
sacred
spring
for
the
purpose
of
bathing
within
it
,
and
performing
his
solitary
devotions
at
the
shrine
of
the
saint
.
<EOS>
On
ascending
the
steps
of
the
structure
,
he
perceived
Guy
Fawkes
kneeling
beside
the
fountain
,
apparently
occupied
in
prayer
;
and
,
being
unwilling
to
disturb
him
,
he
paused
.
<EOS>
Finding
,
however
,
after
the
lapse
of
a
few
minutes
,
that
he
did
not
move
,
he
advanced
towards
him
,
and
was
about
to
lay
his
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
when
he
was
arrested
by
the
very
extraordinary
expression
of
his
countenance
.
<EOS>
His
lips
were
partly
open
,
but
perfectly
motionless
,
and
his
eyes
,
almost
starting
from
their
sockets
,
were
fixed
upon
the
boiling
waters
of
the
spring
.
<EOS>
His
hands
were
clasped
,
and
his
look
altogether
was
that
of
one
whose
faculties
were
benumbed
by
awe
or
terror
.
<EOS>
Aware
of
the
fanatical
and
enthusiastical
character
of
Fawkes
,
Garnet
had
little
doubt
that
,
by
keeping
long
vigil
at
the
fountain
,
he
had
worked
himself
into
such
a
state
of
over
-
excitement
as
to
imagine
he
beheld
some
preternatural
appearance
;
and
it
was
with
some
curiosity
that
he
awaited
the
result
.
<EOS>
Glancing
in
the
same
direction
,
his
eye
rested
upon
the
bottom
of
the
well
,
but
he
could
discern
nothing
except
the
glittering
and
blood
-
streaked
pebbles
,
and
the
reflection
of
the
early
sunbeams
that
quivered
on
its
steaming
surface
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
a
convulsion
passed
over
the
frame
of
the
kneeler
,
and
heaving
a
deep
sigh
he
arose
.
<EOS>
Turning
to
quit
the
spring
,
he
confronted
Garnet
,
and
demanded
,
in
<EOS>
a
low
voice—"Have
<EOS>
you
likewise
seen
the
vision
,
father?"Garnet
made
no
reply
,
but
regarded
him
steadfastly
.
<EOS>
"Has
<EOS>
the
blessed
Winifred
appeared
to
you
,
I
say
?
"
continued
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"No
,
"
answered
Garnet
;
"
I
am
but
just
come
hither
.
<EOS>
It
is
for
you
,
my
son,—the
favoured
of
Heaven,—for
whom
such
glorious
visions
are
reserved
.
<EOS>
I
have
seen
nothing
.
<EOS>
How
did
the
saint
manifest
herself
to
you?""In
her
earthly
form
,
"
replied
Fawkes
;
"
or
rather
,
I
should
say
,
in
the
semblance
of
the
form
she
bore
on
earth
.
<EOS>
Listen
to
me
,
father
.
<EOS>
I
came
hither
last
night
to
make
my
couch
beside
the
fountain
.
<EOS>
After
plunging
into
it
,
I
felt
marvellously
refreshed
,
and
disposed
myself
to
rest
on
that
stone
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
had
my
eyes
closed
when
the
saintly
virgin
appeared
to
me
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
father
,
it
was
a
vision
of
seraphic
beauty
,
such
as
the
eye
of
man
hath
seldom
<EOS>
seen!""And
such
only
as
it
is
permitted
the
elect
of
Heaven
to
see
,
"
observed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"Alas
!
<EOS>
father
,
"
rejoined
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
I
can
lay
little
claim
to
such
an
epithet
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
I
begin
to
fear
that
I
have
incurred
the
displeasure
of
Heaven
.
<EOS>
""Think
<EOS>
not
so
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
uneasily
.
"
<EOS>
Relate
your
vision
,
and
I
will
interpret
it
to
you
.
<EOS>
""Thus
<EOS>
then
it
was
,
father
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
The
figure
of
the
saint
arose
from
out
the
well
,
and
gliding
towards
me
laid
its
finger
upon
my
brow
.
<EOS>
My
eyes
opened
,
but
I
was
as
one
oppressed
with
a
nightmare
,
unable
to
move
.
<EOS>
I
then
thought
I
heard
my
name
pronounced
by
a
voice
so
wondrously
sweet
that
my
senses
were
quite
ravished
.
<EOS>
Fain
would
I
have
prostrated
myself
,
but
my
limbs
refused
their
office
.
<EOS>
Neither
could
I
speak
,
for
my
tongue
was
also
enchained
.
<EOS>
""Proceed
,
my
son
,
"
observed
Garnet
;
"
I
am
curious
to
know
what
ensued
.
<EOS>
""Father
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
if
the
form
I
beheld
was
that
of
Saint
Winifred,—and
that
it
was
so
,
<EOS>
I
can
not
doubt,—the
enterprise
on
which
we
are
engaged
will
fail
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
approved
by
Heaven
.
<EOS>
The
vision
warned
me
to
desist
.
<EOS>
""You
can
not
desist
,
my
son
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
,
sternly
.
"
<EOS>
Your
oath
binds
you
to
the
project
.
<EOS>
""True
,
"
replied
Fawkes
;
"
and
I
have
no
thought
of
abandoning
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
well
assured
it
will
not
be
successful
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
thinking
so
,
my
son
,
will
be
the
most
certain
means
of
realizing
your
apprehensions
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
gravely
.
"
<EOS>
But
let
me
hear
the
exact
words
of
the
spirit
.
<EOS>
You
may
have
misunderstood
them
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
repeat
them
precisely
,
father
,
"
replied
Fawkes
;
"
but
I
could
not
misapprehend
their
import
,
which
was
the
deepest
commiseration
for
our
forlorn
and
fallen
church
,
but
a
positive
interdiction
against
any
attempt
to
restore
it
by
bloodshed
.
'
<EOS>
Suffer
on
,
'
said
the
spirit
;
'
bear
the
yoke
patiently
,
and
in
due
season
God
will
avenge
your
wrongs
,
and
free
you
from
oppression
.
<EOS>
You
are
thus
afflicted
that
your
faith
may
be
purified
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
resort
to
violence
,
you
will
breed
confusion
,
and
injure
,
not
serve
,
the
holy
cause
on
which
you
are
embarked
.
'
<EOS>
Such
,
father
,
was
the
language
of
the
saint
.
<EOS>
It
was
uttered
in
a
tone
so
tender
and
sympathizing
,
that
every
word
found
an
echo
in
my
heart
,
and
I
repented
having
pledged
myself
to
the
undertaking
.
<EOS>
But
,
when
I
tell
you
that
she
added
that
all
concerned
in
the
conspiracy
should
perish
,
perhaps
you
may
be
deterred
from
proceeding
further
.
<EOS>
""Never
!
"
returned
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
will
I
suffer
any
one
engaged
in
it
to
retreat
.
<EOS>
What
matter
if
a
few
perish
,
if
the
many
survive
?
<EOS>
Our
blood
will
not
be
shed
in
vain
,
if
the
true
religion
of
God
is
restored
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
as
strongly
as
the
blessed
Winifred
herself
resisted
the
impious
ravisher
,
Caradoc
,
will
I
resist
all
inducements
to
turn
aside
from
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
the
enterprise
will
fail
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
we
shall
perish
.
<EOS>
But
if
we
die
thus
,
we
shall
die
as
martyrs
,
and
our
deaths
will
be
highly
profitable
to
the
Catholic
religion
.
<EOS>
""I
doubt
it
,
"
observed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
son
,
"
said
Garnet
,
solemnly
,
"
I
have
ever
looked
upon
you
as
one
destined
to
be
the
chief
agent
in
the
great
work
of
redemption
.
<EOS>
I
have
thought
that
,
like
Judith
,
you
were
chosen
to
destroy
the
Holofernes
who
oppresses
us
.
<EOS>
Having
noted
in
you
a
religious
fervour
,
and
resolution
admirably
fitting
you
for
the
task
,
I
thought
,
and
still
think
you
expressly
chosen
by
Heaven
for
it
.
<EOS>
But
,
if
you
have
any
misgiving
,
I
beseech
you
to
withdraw
from
it
.
<EOS>
I
will
absolve
you
from
your
oath
;
and
,
enjoining
you
only
to
strictest
secrecy
,
will
pray
you
to
depart
at
once
,
lest
your
irresolution
should
be
communicated
to
the
others
.
<EOS>
""Fear
nothing
from
me
,
father
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
irresolution
,
no
wavering
,
nor
shall
any
engaged
with
us
be
shaken
by
my
apprehension
.
<EOS>
You
have
asked
me
what
I
saw
and
heard
,
and
I
have
told
you
truly
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
speak
of
it
no
more
.
<EOS>
""It
will
be
well
to
observe
silence
,
my
son
,
"
answered
Garnet
;
"
for
though
you
,
like
myself
,
are
unnerved
,
its
effect
on
others
might
be
injurious
.
<EOS>
But
you
have
not
yet
brought
your
relation
to
an
end
.
<EOS>
How
did
the
figure
disappear?""As
<EOS>
it
arose
,
father
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Uttering
in
a
sweet
but
solemn
voice
,
which
yet
rings
in
my
cars
,
the
words
,
'
Be
warned
!
'
<EOS>
it
glided
back
to
the
fountain
,
whose
waves
as
it
approached
grew
still
,
and
gradually
melted
from
my
view
.
<EOS>
""But
<EOS>
when
I
came
hither
,
you
appeared
to
be
gazing
at
the
spring
,
"
said
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
then
behold?""My
<EOS>
first
impulse
on
awakening
about
an
hour
ago
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
"
was
to
prostrate
myself
before
the
fountain
,
and
to
entreat
the
intercession
of
the
saint
,
who
had
thus
marvellously
revealed
herself
to
me
.
<EOS>
As
I
prayed
,
methought
its
clear
lucid
waters
became
turbid
,
and
turned
to
the
colour
of
blood
.
<EOS>
""It
is
a
type
of
the
blood
of
slaughtered
brethren
of
our
faith
,
which
has
been
shed
by
our
oppressors
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"Rather
<EOS>
of
our
own
,
which
shall
be
poured
forth
in
this
cause
,
"
retorted
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
matter
.
<EOS>
I
am
prepared
to
lose
the
last
drop
of
mine
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
I
,
"
said
Garnet
;
"
and
<EOS>
,
I
doubt
not
,
like
those
holy
men
who
have
suffered
for
their
faith
,
that
we
shall
both
win
a
crown
of
martyrdom
.
<EOS>
""Amen
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
And
you
think
the
sacrifice
we
are
about
to
offer
will
prove
acceptable
to
God?""I
am
convinced
of
it
,
my
son
,
"
answered
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
take
the
sainted
virgin
,
from
whose
blood
this
marvellous
spring
was
produced
,
to
witness
that
I
devote
myself
unhesitatingly
to
the
project
,
and
that
I
firmly
believe
it
will
profit
our
church
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
a
singular
circumstance
occurred
,
which
did
not
fail
to
produce
an
impression
on
both
parties,—especially
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
A
violent
gust
of
wind
,
apparently
suddenly
aroused
,
whistled
through
the
slender
columns
of
the
structure
,
and
catching
the
surface
of
the
water
<EOS>
dashed
it
in
tiny
waves
against
their
feet
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
saint
is
offended
,
"
observed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"It
would
almost
seem
so
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
after
a
pause
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
proceed
to
the
chapel
,
and
pray
at
her
shrine
.
<EOS>
We
will
confer
on
this
matter
hereafter
.
<EOS>
Meantime
,
swear
to
me
that
you
will
observe
profound
secrecy
respecting
this
vision
.
<EOS>
""I
swear
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
another
and
more
violent
gust
agitated
the
fountain
.
<EOS>
"We
will
tarry
here
no
longer
,
"
said
Garnet
,
"
I
am
not
proof
against
these
portents
of
ill
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
led
the
way
to
the
chapel
.
<EOS>
Here
they
were
presently
joined
by
several
of
the
female
devotees
,
including
Viviana
,
Anne
Vaux
,
and
Lady
Digby
.
<EOS>
Matins
were
then
said
,
after
which
various
offerings
were
made
at
the
shrine
of
the
saint
.
<EOS>
Lady
Digby
presented
a
small
tablet
set
in
gold
,
representing
on
one
side
the
martyrdom
of
Saint
Winifred
,
and
on
the
other
the
Salutation
of
our
Lady
.
<EOS>
Anne
Vaux
gave
a
small
enamelled
cross
of
gold
;
Viviana
a
girdle
of
the
same
metal
,
with
a
pendant
sustaining
a
small
Saint
John
's
head
surrounded
with
pearls
.
<EOS>
"Mine
will
be
a
poor
soldier
's
offering
,
"
said
Guy
Fawkes
,
approaching
the
shrine
,
which
was
hung
around
with
the
crutches
,
staves
,
and
bandages
of
those
cured
by
the
healing
waters
of
the
miraculous
spring
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
small
silver
scallop
-
shell
,
given
me
by
a
pilgrim
,
who
died
in
my
arms
near
the
chapel
of
Saint
James
of
Compostella
,
in
Spain
,
is
the
sole
valuable
I
possess
.
<EOS>
""It
will
be
as
acceptable
as
a
more
costly
gift
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
placing
it
on
the
shrine
.
<EOS>
Of
all
the
offerings
then
made
,
that
silver
scallop
-
shell
is
the
only
one
preserved
.
<EOS>
XIII
.
<EOS>
—
<EOS>
THE
CONSPIRATORSOn
Viviana
's
return
from
her
devotions
<EOS>
,
she
found
her
father
in
the
greatest
perturbation
and
alarm
.
<EOS>
The
old
steward
,
Heydocke
,
who
had
ridden
express
from
Ordsall
Hall
,
had
just
arrived
,
bringing
word
that
the
miserable
fate
of
the
pursuivant
and
his
crew
had
aroused
the
whole
country
;
that
officers
,
attended
by
a
strong
force
,
and
breathing
vengeance
,
were
in
pursuit
of
Sir
William
Radcliffe
and
his
daughter
;
that
large
sums
were
offered
for
the
capture
of
Guy
Fawkes
and
Father
Oldcorne
;
that
most
of
the
servants
were
imprisoned
;
that
he
himself
had
escaped
with
great
difficulty
;
and
that
,
to
sum
up
this
long
catalogue
of
calamities
,
Master
Humphrey
Chetham
was
arrested
,
and
placed
in
the
New
Fleet
.
<EOS>
"
In
short
,
my
dear
young
mistress
,
"
concluded
the
old
man
,
"
as
I
have
just
observed
to
Sir
William
,
all
is
over
with
us
,
and
there
is
nothing
left
but
the
grave
.
<EOS>
""What
course
have
you
resolved
upon
,
dear
father
,
"
inquired
Viviana
,
turning
anxiously
to
him
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
shall
surrender
myself
,
"
he
answered
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
guilty
of
no
crime
,
and
can
easily
clear
myself
from
all
imputation
.
<EOS>
""You
are
mistaken
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
hope
for
justice
from
those
who
know
it
not
.
<EOS>
But
,
while
the
means
of
escape
are
allowed
you
,
avail
yourself
of
them
.
<EOS>
""No
,
Viviana
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Sir
William
Radcliffe
,
firmly
;
"
my
part
is
taken
.
<EOS>
I
shall
abide
the
arrival
of
the
officers
.
<EOS>
For
you
,
I
shall
intrust
you
to
the
care
of
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
""You
can
not
mean
this
,
dear
father
,
"
she
cried
,
with
a
look
of
distress
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
if
you
do
,
I
will
never
consent
to
such
an
arrangement
.
<EOS>
""Mr
.
<EOS>
Catesby
is
strongly
attached
to
you
,
child
,
"
replied
Sir
William
,
"
and
will
watch
over
your
safety
as
carefully
as
I
could
do
myself
.
<EOS>
""He
may
be
attached
to
me
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
,
"
<EOS>
though
I
doubt
the
disinterestedness
of
his
love
.
<EOS>
But
nothing
can
remove
my
repugnance
to
him
.
<EOS>
Forgive
me
,
therefore
,
if
,
in
this
one
instance
,
I
decline
to
obey
your
commands
.
<EOS>
I
dare
not
trust
myself
with
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
""How
<EOS>
am
I
to
understand
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sir
William
.
<EOS>
"Do
not
ask
me
to
explain
,
dear
father
,
"
she
answered
,
"
but
imagine
I
must
have
good
reason
for
what
I
say
.
<EOS>
Since
you
are
resolved
upon
surrendering
yourself
,
I
will
go
into
captivity
with
you
.
<EOS>
The
alternative
is
less
dreadful
than
that
you
have
proposed
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
distract
me
,
child
,
"
cried
the
knight
,
rising
and
pacing
the
chamber
in
great
agitation
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
bear
the
thought
of
your
imprisonment
.
<EOS>
Yet
if
I
fly
,
I
appear
to
confess
myself
guilty
.
<EOS>
""If
your
worship
will
intrust
Mistress
Viviana
with
me
,
"
interposed
the
old
steward
,
"
I
will
convey
her
whithersoever
<EOS>
you
direct,—will
watch
over
her
day
and
night,—and
,
if
need
be
,
die
in
her
defence
.
<EOS>
""Thou
wert
ever
a
faithful
servant
,
good
Heydocke
,
"
rejoined
Sir
William
,
extending
his
hand
kindly
to
him
,
"
and
art
as
true
in
adversity
as
in
prosperity
.
<EOS>
""Shame
<EOS>
to
me
if
I
were
not
,
"
replied
Heydocke
,
pressing
the
knight
's
fingers
to
his
lips
and
bathing
them
in
his
tears
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shame
to
me
if
I
hesitated
to
lay
down
my
life
for
a
master
to
whom
I
owe
so
much
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
it
is
your
pleasure
,
dear
father
,
"
observed
Viviana
,
"
I
will
accompany
Master
Heydocke
;
but
I
would
far
rather
be
permitted
to
remain
with
you
.
<EOS>
""It
would
avail
nothing
,
"
replied
Sir
William
,
"
we
should
be
separated
by
the
officers
.
<EOS>
Retire
to
your
chamber
,
and
prepare
for
instant
departure
;
and
,
in
the
mean
while
,
I
will
consider
what
is
best
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
worship
's
decision
must
be
speedy
,
"
observed
Heydocke
;
"
I
had
only
a
few
hours
'
start
of
the
officers
.
<EOS>
They
will
be
here
ere
long
.
<EOS>
""Take
this
purse
,
"
replied
Sir
William
,
"
and
hire
three
of
the
fleetest
horses
you
can
procure
,
and
station
yourself
at
the
outskirts
of
the
town
,
on
the
road
to
Saint
Asaph
.
<EOS>
You
understand
.
<EOS>
""Perfectly
,
"
replied
Heydocke
.
<EOS>
And
he
departed
to
execute
his
master
's
commands
,
while
Viviana
withdrew
to
her
own
chamber
.
<EOS>
Left
alone
,
the
knight
was

as
to
where

should
shape

,
when
he

Catesby

.
<EOS>
"We
<EOS>
have
just

,
Sir
William
,
"
said

former
,
"
and
have
learnt
the
alarming

he
has
brought
.
<EOS>
""What
is
your
counsel
in
this
emergency
,
father
?
"
said
Radcliffe
,
appealing
to
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"Flight,—instant
flight
,
my
son
,
"
was
the
answer
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
counsel
is
resistance
,
"
said
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
here
assembled
in
large
numbers
,
and
are
well
armed
.
<EOS>
Let

await
the

officers
,
and

.
<EOS>
""They

,

,
"
replied

;
"
and

many

,

,

to

at

.
<EOS>
""True
,
"

Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
say
you
then
,
"
he

,
addressing
Radcliffe
,
"
to
our
immediate
return
to
Holt
,
where
means
may
be
found
to
screen
you
till
this
storm
is
blown
over?"Sir
<EOS>
William
having
assented
to
the
proposal
,
Catesby
instantly
departed
to
acquaint
the
others
,
and
,
as

,

quitted
Holywell
,
and
,

at

,
took
the
direction
of
Mold
,
where
they
arrived
,
having
ridden
at
a
swift
pace
,
in
about
half
an
hour
.
<EOS>
From
thence
they
proceeded
,
without
accident
or

,
to
the
mansion
they
had
recently
occupied
near
Holt
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
it
,
all
the
domestics
were
armed
,
and
certain
of
their
number
stationed
at
the
different
approaches
to

house
to
give

in
case
of
the
enemy
's

.
<EOS>
But
as
nothing
occurred
during
the
night
,
the
fears
of
Sir
William
and
his
friends
began
in
some
degree
to
subside
.
<EOS>
About
noon
,
on
the
following
day
,
as
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
ever
since
the
vision
at
<EOS>
Saint
Winifred
's
Well
had
shunned
all
companionship
,
walked
forth
beneath
the
avenue
alone
<EOS>
,
he
heard
a
light
step
behind
him
,
and
,
turning
,
beheld
Viviana
.
<EOS>
Gravely
bowing
,
he
was
about
to
pursue
his
course
,
when
quickening
her
pace
she
was
instantly
by
his
side
.
<EOS>
"I
have
a
favour
to
solicit
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"There
is
none
I
would
refuse
you
,
"
answered
Fawkes
,
halting
;
"
but
,
though
I
have
the
will
,
I
may
not

the
power
to
grant
your
request
.
<EOS>
""Hear
<EOS>
me
,
then
,
"
she

,
hurriedly
.
<EOS>
"
Of
all
my
father
's
friends
—
of
all
who
are
here
assembled
,
you
are
the
only
one
I
dare

from

I
can
hope
for

.
<EOS>
""I
am
at
once
flattered
and

by
your
words
,
Viviana
<EOS>
,
"
he
rejoined
;
"
nor
can
I

whither
they

.
<EOS>
But
speak
freely
.
<EOS>
If
I
can
not
render
you
aid
,
I
can
at

counsel
.
<EOS>
""I
must
premise
,
then
,
"
said
Viviana
,
"
that
I
am
aware
from
certain
obscure
hints
<EOS>
let
fall
by
Father
Oldcorne
,
that
you
,
Mr.
Catesby
,
and
others
are
engaged
in
a
dark

.
<EOS>
""Viviana
<EOS>
Radcliffe
,
"
returned
Guy
Fawkes
,
sternly
,
"
you
have
once
before
avowed
your
knowledge
of
this
plot
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
attempt
disguise
with
you
.
<EOS>
A
project
is
in
agitation
for
the
deliverance
of
our
fallen

;
and
,
since
you
have
become

with
its
existence
—
no

—
you
must
be
bound
by
an
oath
of
secrecy
,
or
,
"
and
his

,
and
his

sterner
,
"
I
will
not
answer
for
your
life
.
<EOS>
""I
will
willingly
take
the
oath
,
on
certain
conditions
,
"
said
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"You
must
take

,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Hear
me
out
,
"
said
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
Knowing
that
Mr.
Catesby
and
Father
Garnet
are

induce
my
father
to
join
this
conspiracy
,
I
came

.
<EOS>
""Were
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

,
"

Fawkes
,
"
I

the

.
<EOS>
Sir
William
Radcliffe
would

justly
indignant
at

on

.
<EOS>
""Heed
not

,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
You
,
I
fear
,
are
linked
to
this
fearful
project
beyond
the
possibility
of
being
set
free
.
<EOS>
But
he
is
not
.
<EOS>
Save
him
!
<EOS>
save
him!""I
will
take
no
part
in
urging
him
to

,
"

Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
But
I

.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>

,
"
she

;
"

to

,
I

.
<EOS>
""Viviana
,
"

,

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
""I
care
not
<EOS>
,
"
she

;
"
I
would

twenty

,
if

,
to

.
<EOS>
""You
are

,
"

,

;
"

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
""Everything

,
"

.
<EOS>
"Well

,
"

,

;
"
the

.
""Thanks
!
<EOS>
thanks
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated

;
and
,

,

-

.
<EOS>
While

,

,

.
<EOS>
Their

;

,

.
<EOS>
"This

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"You

,

,
of

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"It

,

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
Miss
Radcliffe
was

,

offered

.
<EOS>
""That

,
"

.
<EOS>
"Let
<EOS>
the

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
More

.
<EOS>
We

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
""I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

Will

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
None

.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,

towards

,
and

,

house,—a

overrun

,
and

in

.
<EOS>
Here
they
found
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
Ambrose

,
Francis
Tresham
,
Thomas
and
Robert
Winter
,
John
and
Christopher
Wright
,

.
<EOS>
The
door
being
closed
and
bolted
,
Garnet
,
placing
himself
in
the
midst
of
the
assemblage
,
said
,
"
Before
we
proceed
further
,
I
will
again
administer
the
oath
to
all
present
.
"
<EOS>
Drawing
from
his
vest
a
primer
,
and

Sir
Everard
Digby
,
he
desired
him
to

,
and
continued
thus
in
a

,
"
You
shall
swear
by
the
Blessed
Trinity
,
and
by
the

you
propose
to
receive
,
never
to
disclose
directly
nor

,
by
word

,
the

that

proposed

to
keep
secret
,
nor
desist
from

thereof
,
until
the
rest
shall
give
you
leave
.
<EOS>
""I
swear
,
"
replied
Digby
,
kissing
the
primer
.
<EOS>
The
oath
was
then
taken
in
like

by
the
others
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
Catesby
was
about
to
address
the

,
when
Tresham
,
glancing
uneasily
at
the
door
,
remarked
,
"
Are
you
assured
we
have
no
eavesdroppers?""I
will
keep
watch
without
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
"
if
you
have
any
fears
.
<EOS>
""It
were
better
,
"
replied
Robert
Winter
.
<EOS>
"
We
can
not
be
too
cautious
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
go
forth
,
you
will
not
be
able
to
take

in
the
