.
<EOS>
""My
part
is
to
act
,
not
talk
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
marching
towards
the
door
.
<EOS>
And
shutting
it
after
him
,
he
took
up
his
position
outside
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
Catesby
commenced
a
long
and
inflammatory
harangue
,
in
which
he
expatiated
with
great
eloquence
and
fervour
on
the
wrongs
of
the
Catholic
party
,
and
the
deplorable
condition
of
their
church
.
<EOS>
"
It
were
easy
to
slay
the
tyrant
by
whom
we
are
oppressed
,
"
he
said
,
in
conclusion
;
"
but
his
destruction
would
be
small
gain
to
us
.
<EOS>
We
must
strike
deeper
,
to
hew
down
the
baneful
stock
of
heresy
.
<EOS>
All
our
adversaries
must
perish
with
him
,
and
in
such
a
manner
as
shall
best
attest
the
vengeance
of
Heaven
.
<EOS>
Placed
beneath
the
Parliament
-
house
,
a
mine
of
powder
shall
hurl
its
heretical
occupants
into
the
air,—nor
shall
any
one
survive
the
terrible
explosion
.
<EOS>
Are
we
all
agreed
to
this
plan?"All
<EOS>
the
conspirators
expressed
their
assent
,
except
Sir
Everard
Digby
.
<EOS>
"Before
<EOS>
I
give
my
concurrence
to
the
measure
,
"
observed
the
latter
,
"
I
would
fain
be
resolved
by
Father
Garnet
whether
it
is
lawful
to
destroy
some
few
of
our
own
faith
with
so
many
heretics
.
<EOS>
""Unquestionably
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
"
<EOS>
As
in
besieging
a
city
we
have
a
right
to
kill
all
within
it
,
whether
friends
or
enemies
,
so
in
this
case
we
are
justified
in
destroying
the
innocent
with
the
guilty
,
because
their
destruction
will
be
advantageous
to
the
Catholic
cause
.
<EOS>
""I
am
satisfied
,
"
replied
Digby
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
to
the
tyrant
and
apostate
James
,
"
continued
Garnet
,
"
he
is
excommunicated
,
and
his
subjects
released
from
their
allegiance
.
<EOS>
I
have
two
breves
sent
over
by
his
holiness
Pope
Clement
VIII
.
<EOS>
three
years
ago
,
one
directed
to
the
clergy
,
and
the
other
to
the
nobility
of
this
realm
,
wherein
,
alluding
to
Queen
Elizabeth
<EOS>
,
it
is
expressly
declared
that
,
'
so
soon
as
that
miserable
woman
should
depart
out
of
this
life
,
none
shall
be
permitted
to
ascend
the
throne
,
how
near
soever
in
proximity
of
blood
,
unless
they
are
such
as
will
not
only
tolerate
the
Catholic
faith
,
but
in
every
way
support
it
.
'
<EOS>
By
this
brief
,
James
is
expressly
excluded
.
<EOS>
He
has
betrayed
,
not
supported
the
church
of
Rome
.
<EOS>
Having
broken
his
word
with
us
,
and
oppressed
our
brethren
more
rigorously
even
than
his
predecessor
,
the
remorseless
Elizabeth
,
he
is
unworthy
longer
to
reign
,
and
must
be
removed
.
<EOS>
""He
must
,
"
reiterated
the
conspirators
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
Parliament
-
house
being
the
place
where
all
the
mischief
done
<EOS>
us
has
been
contrived
by
our
adversaries
,
it
is
fitting
that
it
should
be
the
place
of
their
chastisement
,
"
remarked
Catesby
.
"Doubtless
,
"
rejoined
Ambrose
Rookwood
.
<EOS>
"Yet
<EOS>
if
the
blow
we
meditate
should
miscarry
,
"
observed
Thomas
Winter
,
"
<EOS>
the
injury
to
the
Catholic
religion
will
be
so
great
,
that
not
only
our
enemies
,
but
our
very
friends
will
condemn
us
.
<EOS>
""There
is
no
chance
of
miscarriage
,
if
we
are
true
to
each
other
,
"
returned
Catesby
,
confidently
.
"
<EOS>
And
if
I
suspected
any
one
of
treachery
,
I
would
plunge
my
sword
into
his
bosom
,
were
he
my
brother
.
<EOS>
""You
would
do
wrong
to
act
thus
on
mere
suspicion
,
"
remarked
Tresham
,
who
stood
near
him
.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
a
case
like
this
<EOS>
,
he
who
gives
the
slightest
ground
for
doubt
would
merit
death
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
sternly
;
"
and
I
would
slay
him
.
<EOS>
""Hum
!
"
exclaimed
Tresham
,
uneasily
.
<EOS>
"Mr
.
<EOS>
Catesby
will
now
perhaps
inform
us
what
has
been
done
to
carry
the
project
into
effect
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sir
Everard
Digby
.
<EOS>
"A
small
habitation
has
been
taken
by
one
of
our
confederates
,
Mr.
Thomas
Percy
,
immediately
adjoining
the
Parliament
-
house
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
"
from
the
cellar
of
which
it
is
proposed
to
dig
a
mine
through
the
wall
of
the
devoted
building
,
and
to
deposit
within
it
a
sufficient
quantity
of
gunpowder
and
other
combustibles
to
accomplish
our
purpose
.
<EOS>
This
mine
must
be
digged
by
ourselves
,
as
we
can
employ
no
assistants
,
and
will
be
a
laborious
and
dangerous
task
.
<EOS>
But
I
for
one
will
cheerfully
undertake
it
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
I
,
"
said
the
elder
Wright
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
I
,
"
cried
several
others
.
<EOS>
"Supposing
<EOS>
the
mine
digged
,
and
the
powder
deposited
,
"
observed
Ambrose
Rookwood
,
"
whose
hand
will
fire
the
train?""Mine
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Guy
Fawkes
,
throwing
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
had
spoken
,
he
retired
and
closed
it
after

.
<EOS>
"He
will
keep
his
word
,
"
remarked
Garnet
.
"
<EOS>
He
is
of
a
nature
so
resolute
that
he
would
destroy
himself
with
the
victims
rather
than
fail
.
<EOS>
Catiline
was
not
a
bolder
conspirator
than
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
""Well
,
gentlemen
<EOS>
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
"
we
are
now
at
the
latter
end
of
July
.
<EOS>
All
must
be
ready
against
the
meeting
of
Parliament
in
November
.
<EOS>
""There
is
some
likelihood
,
I

,
that
the

of
the
house
will
be

,
"

.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
much
the
better
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
"
it

give
us
more

.
<EOS>
""So
<EOS>
much
the
worse
<EOS>
,
I
think
,
"
cried
Ambrose
Rookwood
.
<EOS>
"
Delays
are
ever
dangerous
,
and
doubly

in
a
case
like
ours
.
<EOS>
""I
am
far
from
desiring

,
"
observed

Everard
Digby
,
"
but
I

,

,

made
to

King
in

.
<EOS>
""It
is
useless
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
So
far
from
toleration
,
he
meditates
severer

against
us
;
and
,
I
am
well

,
if
Parliament
is
allowed
to

,
such

will
be
passed
as

all

within

.
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
<EOS>
We
have
no
hope
from
James
,
nor
his
ministers
.
<EOS>
""Nor
<EOS>
yet

France
or

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
In

with

Constable
Velasco

,

received

good
-
will
of
Philip
towards

,
but
no

in
our

.
<EOS>
The
Archduke
Albert
is
well
disposed
,
but
he
can
render
no

.
<EOS>
We
must
depend
upon

.
<EOS>
""Ay
,
marry
,
<EOS>
must

,
"

Catesby
,
"
and
fortunate
<EOS>
is

unaided
.
<EOS>
We
only
require

to
follow

the

.
<EOS>
""My
<EOS>
whole

,
"
replied
Sir
Everard
Digby
.
<EOS>
"Part
of
mine
has
already

given
,
"
said
Tresham
,
"
and
the
rest
shall
follow
.
<EOS>
""Would
<EOS>
I
had
aught
to
peril
in
the
matter
except

,
"
said
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
throw
everything

.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
do
enough

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To

.
<EOS>
""I
live
for
nothing
else
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
"
and
if
I
see
it
successful
,
I
shall
have
lived
long
enough
.
<EOS>
""Cannot
<EOS>
Sir
William
Radcliffe
be
induced
to
join

?
"

Rookwood
.
"
<EOS>
He
would
be
an
important

,
and

would

.
<EOS>
""I
have
sounded

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But
he
appears
reluctant
.
<EOS>
""Be

,
"
urged
Christopher
Wright
.
<EOS>
"
The
jeopardy
in
which
he
now
stands
may
make

change
his
mind
.
<EOS>
""I
am
loth
to
interrupt
the
discussion
,
"
returned
Garnet
,
"
but
I
think
we
have
tarried
here
long
enough
.
<EOS>
We
will
meet
again
at
midnight
,
when
I
hope
to
introduce
Sir
William
Radcliffe
to
you
as

.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
party
then
separated
,
and
Garnet
went
in
search
of
the
knight
.
<EOS>
Ascertaining
that
he
was
in
his
own
chamber
,
he
proceeded
thither
,
and
found
him
alone
.
<EOS>
Entering
at
once
upon
the
subject
in
hand
,
Garnet
pleaded
his
cause
with
so
much

that

at
last
wrung
a
reluctant

from

listener
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
able
to
conceal
his

,
he
then
proposed

William
to

him
to

private

in

house
,
where
,
having
taken

oath
,
and
received

sacrament
upon
it
,
he
should
forthwith
be
introduced
to
the
conspirators
,
and
the
whole

of
the
plot
revealed
to

.
<EOS>
To
this
the
knight
,
with
some

,
agreed
.
<EOS>
As
they
traversed
a
gallery
leading
to
the
chapel
,
they
met
Viviana
.
<EOS>
For
the
first
time
in
his
life
Radcliffe
's
gaze
sank
before
his
daughter
,
and
he
would
have
passed

without

had

not
stopped

.
"Father
!
<EOS>
dear
father
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she

,
"
I
know
whither
you
are
going
—
and
for
what

.
<EOS>
Do
not
—
do
not

.
<EOS>
"IllustrationSir
<EOS>
William
Radcliffe
made
no

,
but

gently
to

aside
.
<EOS>
She
would

,

,

,
but
prostrating

before

,
clasped

,
and
besought

not
to

.
<EOS>
Making
a
significant

to
Sir
William
,
Garnet
walked
forward
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
,
"
cried
the
knight
,

,
"
my
resolution
is
taken
.
<EOS>
I
command
you
to

chamber
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>

,
he
broke
from
her
,
and
followed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
Clasping
her

to

,
Viviana
gazed

,

.
<EOS>
On

,
Sir
William
,
who
had

much

by

,

some

in

.
<EOS>
Garnet
employed
the
time
in
renewing
his
arguments
,
and
with
so
much
address
that
he
succeeded
in
quieting
the
scruples
of

which
had
been

in

knight
's

by

daughter
's

.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
now
,
my
son
,
"
he
said
,
"
since
you
have
determined
to
enrol

name
in
the
list
of
those
sworn
to
deliver
their
church
from
oppression
,
take
this
primer
in
your
hand
,
and
kneel
down
before
the
altar
,
while
I
administer
the
oath
which
is
to
unite
you
to
us
.
"Garnet
<EOS>
then
advanced
towards
the
altar
,
and
Sir
William
was
about
to
prostrate
himself
upon
a
cushion
beside
it
,
when
the
door
was
suddenly
thrown
open
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
strode
into

.
<EOS>
"Hold
<EOS>
!
"
he
exclaimed
,
grasping
Radcliffe
's
right

,
and
fixing
his
dark

upon

;
"
you
shall
not
take
that
oath
.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
mean
you
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Garnet
,
who
,
as
well
as
the
knight
,
was

with
astonishment
at
this
intrusion
.
"
<EOS>
Sir
William
Radcliffe
is
about
to
join
us
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
know
it
,
"
replied
Fawkes
;
"
but
it
may
not
be
.
<EOS>
He
has
no
heart
in
the
business
,
and
will
lend
it
no
efficient
assistance
.
<EOS>
We
are
better
without
him
,
than
with
him
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
he
took
the
primer
from
the
knight
's
hand
,
and
laid
it
upon
the
altar
.
<EOS>
"This
<EOS>
conduct
is
inexplicable
,
"
cried
Garnet
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
answer
for
it
to
others
,
as
well
as
to
me
.
<EOS>
""I
will
answer
for
it
to
all
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Let
Sir
William
Radcliffe
declare
before

,
and

Heaven
,
that
he
approves
the
measure
,
and
I
am
content

should
take

oath
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
belie
my
conscience
by
saying
so
,
"
replied
the
knight
,
who
appeared
agitated
by

.
<EOS>
"Yet
<EOS>
you
have
promised
to
join
us
,
"
cried
Garnet
,
reproachfully
.
<EOS>
"Better
break
that
promise
than
a
solemn
oath
,
"
rejoined
Guy
Fawkes
,
sternly
.
"
<EOS>
Sir
William
Radcliffe
,
there
are
reasons
why
you
should
not
join
this
conspiracy
.
<EOS>
Examine
your
inmost
heart
,
and
it
will
tell
you
what
they
are
.
<EOS>
""I
understand
you
,
"
replied
the
knight
.
<EOS>
"Get
<EOS>
hence
,
"
cried
Garnet
,
unable
to
control
his
indignation
,
"
or
I
will
pronounce
our
Church
's
most

against
you
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
shall
not
shrink
from

,
father
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
humbly
,
but
firmly
,
"
seeing
I
am
acting
rightly
.
<EOS>
""Undeceive
<EOS>
yourself
,
then
,
at
once
,
"
returned
Garnet
,
"
and
learn
that
you
are
thwarting
our
great
and
holy

.
<EOS>
""On
<EOS>
the
contrary
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
"
I
am
promoting
it
,
by
preventing
one
from
joining
it
who
will
endanger
its
success
.
<EOS>
""You
are
a
traitor
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Garnet
,
furiously
.
<EOS>
"A
traitor
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Guy
Fawkes
,
his
eye
blazing
with
fierce
lustre
,
though
his
voice
and
demeanour
were
unaltered,—"I
,
who
have
been
warned
thrice,—twice
by
the
dead,—and
lastly
by
a
vision
from
heaven
,
yet
still
remain
firm
to
my
purpose,—I
,
who
have
voluntarily
embraced
the
most
dangerous
and
difficult
part
of
the
enterprise,—I
,
who
would
suffer
the
utmost
extremity
of
torture
,
rather
than
utter
a
word
that
should
reveal
it,—a
traitor
!
<EOS>
No
,
father
,
I
am
none
.
<EOS>
If
you
think
so
,
take
this
sword
and
at
once
put
an
end
to
your
doubts
.
<EOS>
"There
<EOS>
was
something
so
irresistible
in
the
manner
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
that
Garnet
remained
silent
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
with
me
what
you
please
,
"
continued
Fawkes
;
"
but
do
not
compel
Sir
William
Radcliffe
to
join
the
conspiracy
.
<EOS>
He
will
be
fatal
to
it
.
<EOS>
""No
<EOS>
one
shall
compel
me
to
join
it
,
"
replied
the
knight
.
<EOS>
"Perhaps
<EOS>
it
is
better
thus
,
"
returned
Garnet
,
after
a

,
during

he
was
buried

.
<EOS>
"
I
will
urge
you
no
further
,
my
son
.
<EOS>
But
before
you
depart
you
must
swear
not
to

what
you
have
just
learnt
.
<EOS>
""Willingly
,
"
replied
the
knight
.
<EOS>
"There
<EOS>
is
another
person
who
must
also
take
that
oath
,
"
said
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
having
accidentally
become
acquainted
with
as
much
as
yourself
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
stepping
out
of
the
chapel
,
he
immediately
afterwards
returned
with
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"You
will
now
understand
why
I
would
not
allow
Sir
William
to
join
the
conspiracy
,
"
he
observed
to
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
do
,
"
replied
the
latter
,
gloomily
.
<EOS>
The
oath
administered
,
the
knight
and
his
daughter
quitted
the
chapel
,
accompanied
by
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Viviana
was
profuse
in
her
expressions
of
gratitude
,
nor
was
her
father
less
earnest
in
his
acknowledgments
.
<EOS>
A
few
hours
after
this
,
Sir
William
Radcliffe
informed
Sir
Everard
Digby
that
it
was
his
intention
to
depart
immediately
,
and
,
though
the
latter
attempted
to
dissuade
him
by
representing
the
danger
to
which
he
would
be
exposed
,
he
continued
inflexible
.
<EOS>
The
announcement
surprised
both
Catesby
and
Garnet
,
who
were
present
when
it
was
made
,
and
added
their
entreaties
to
those
of
Digby
—
but
without
effect
.
<EOS>
Catesby
's
proposal
to
serve
as
an
escort
was
likewise
refused
by
Sir
William
,
who
said
he
had
no
fears
,
and
when
questioned
as
to
his
destination
,
he
returned
an
evasive
answer
.
<EOS>
This
sudden
resolution
of
the
knight
coupled
with
his
refusal
to
join
the
plot
,
alarmed
the
conspirators
,
and
more
than
one
expressed
fears
of
treachery
.
<EOS>
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
however
,
was
not
of
the
number
,
but
asserted
that
Radcliffe
was
a
man
of
the
highest
honour
,
and
he
would
answer
for
his
secrecy
with
his
life
.
<EOS>
"Will
<EOS>
you
answer
for
that
of
his
daughter
?
"
demanded
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
will
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"To
put
the
matter
beyond
a
doubt
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
"
I
will
set
out
shortly
after
him
,
and
follow
him
unobserved
till
he
halts
for
the
night
,
and
ascertain
whether
he
stops
at
any
suspicious
quarter
.
<EOS>
""Do
<EOS>
so
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"It
is
needless
,
"
observed
Sir
Everard
Digby
;
"
but
do
as
you
please
.
<EOS>
"By
<EOS>
this
time
,
Radcliffe
's
horses
being
brought
round
by
Heydocke
,
he
and
his
daughter
took
a
hasty
leave
of
their
friends
.
<EOS>
When
they
had
been
gone
a
few
minutes
,
Catesby
called
for
his
steed
;
and
,
after
exchanging
a
word
or
two
with
Garnet
,
rode
after
them
.
<EOS>
He
had
proceeded
about
a
couple
of
miles
along
a
cross
-
road
leading
to
Nantwich
,
which
he
learnt
from
some
cottagers
was
the
route
taken
by
the
party
before
him
,
when
he
heard
the
tramp
of
a
horse
in
the
rear
,
and
,
turning
at
the
sound
,
beheld
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Drawing
in
the
bridle
,
he
halted
till
the
latter
came
up
,
and
angrily
demanded
on
what
errand
<EOS>
he
was
bent
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
errand
is
the
same
as
your
own
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
intend
to
follow
Sir
William
Radcliffe
,
and
,
if
need
be
,
defend
him
.
<EOS>
"Whatever
<EOS>
Catesby
's
objections
might
be
to
this
companionship
,
he
did
not
think
fit
to
declare
them
,
and
,
though
evidently
much
displeased
,
suffered
Guy
Fawkes
to
ride
by
his
side
without
opposition
.
<EOS>
Having
gained
the
summit
of
the
mountainous
range
extending
from
Malpas
to
Tottenhall
,
whence
they
beheld
the
party
whose
course
they
were
tracking
enter
a
narrow
lane
at
the
foot
of
the
hill
,
Catesby
,
fearful
of
losing
sight
of
them
,
set
spurs
to
his
steed
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
kept
close
beside
him
,
and
they
did
not
slacken
their
pace
until
they
reached
the
lane
.
<EOS>
Having
proceeded
along
it
for
a
quarter
of
a
mile
,
they
were
alarmed
by
the
sudden
report
of
fire
-
arms
,
followed
by
a
loud
shriek
,
which
neither
of
them
doubted
was
uttered
by
Viviana
.
<EOS>
Again
dashing
forward
,
on
turning
a
corner
of
the
road
,
they
beheld
the
party
surrounded
by
half
-
a
-
dozen
troopers
.
<EOS>
Sir
William
Radcliffe
had
shot
one
of
his
assailants
,
and
,
assisted
by
Heydocke
,
was
defending
himself
bravely
against
the
others
.
<EOS>
With
loud
shouts
,
Catesby
and
Guy
Fawkes
galloped
towards
the
scene
of
strife
.
<EOS>
But
they
were
too
late
.
<EOS>
A
bullet
pierced
the
knight
's
brain
;
and
he
no
sooner
fell
,
than
,
regardless
of
himself
,
the
old
steward
flung
away
his
sword
,
and
threw
himself
,
with
the
most
piteous
lamentations
,
on
the
body
.
<EOS>
Viviana
,
meanwhile
,
had
been
compelled
to
dismount
,
and
was
in
the
hands
of
the
troopers
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
her
father
's
fate
,
her
shrieks
were
so
heart
-
piercing
,
that
even
her
captors
were
moved
to
compassion
.
<EOS>
Fighting
his
way
towards
her
,
Catesby
cut
down
one
of
the
troopers
,
and
snatching
her
from
the
grasp
of
the
other
,
who
was
terrified
by
the
furious
assault
,
placed
her
on
the
saddle
beside
him
,
and
striking
spurs
into
his
charger
at
the
same
moment
,
leapt
the
hedge
,
and
made
good
his
retreat
.
<EOS>
This
daring
action
,
however
,
could
not
have
been
accomplished
without
the
assistance
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
warded
off
with
his
rapier
all
the
blows
aimed
at
him
and
his
lovely
charge
.
<EOS>
While
thus
engaged
,
he
received
a
severe
cut
on
the
head
,
which
stretched
him
senseless
and
bleeding
beneath
his
horse
's
feet
.
<EOS>
XIV
.
<EOS>
—
THE
PACKETOn
recovering
from
the
effects
of
the
wound
he
had
received
from
the
trooper
,
Guy
Fawkes
found
himself
stretched
upon
a
small
bed
in
a
cottage
,
with
Viviana
and
Catesby
watching
beside
him
.
<EOS>
A
thick
fold
of
linen
was
bandaged
round
his
head
,
and
he
was
so
faint
from
the
great
effusion
of
blood
he
had
sustained
,
that
,
after
gazing
vacantly
around
him
for
a
few
minutes
,
and
but
imperfectly
comprehending
what
he
beheld
,
his
eyes
closed
,
and
he
relapsed
into
insensibility
.
<EOS>
Restoratives
being
applied
,
he
revived
in
a
short
time
,
and
,
in
answer
to
his
inquiries
how
he
came
thither
,
was
informed
by
Catesby
that
he
had
been
left
for
dead
by
his
assailants
,
who
,
contenting
themselves
with
making
the
old
steward
prisoner
,
had
ridden
off
in
the
direction
of
Chester
.
<EOS>
"What
has
become
of
Sir
William
Radcliffe
?
"
asked
the
wounded
man
in
a
feeble
voice
.
<EOS>
Catesby
raised
his
finger
to
his
lips
,
and
Fawkes
learnt
the
distressing
nature
of
the
question
he
had
asked
by
the
agonizing
cry
that
burst
from
Viviana
.
<EOS>
Unable
to
control
her
grief
,
she
withdrew
,
and
Catesby
then
told
him
that
the
body
of
Sir
William
Radcliffe
was
lying
in
an
adjoining
cottage
,
whither
it
had
been
transported
from
the
scene
of
the
conflict
;
adding
that
it
was
Viviana
's
earnest
desire
that
it
should
be
conveyed
to
Manchester
to
the
family
vault
in
the
Collegiate
Church
;
but
that
he
feared
her
wish
could
not
be
safely
complied
with
.
<EOS>
A
messenger
,
however
,
had
been
despatched
to
Holt
;
and
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
and
Fathers
Garnet
and
Oldcorne
,
were
momentarily
expected
,
when
some
course
would
be
decided
upon
for
the
disposal
of
the
unfortunate
knight
's
remains
.
<EOS>
"Poor
Viviana
!
"
groaned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
She
has
now
no
protector
.
<EOS>
""Rest
<EOS>
easy
on
that
score
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
She
shall
never
want
one
while
I
live
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
wounded
man
fixed
his
eyes
,
now
blazing
with
red
and
unnatural
light
,
inquiringly
upon
him
,
but
he
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
"I
know
what
you
mean
,
"
continued
Catesby
;
"
you
think
I
shall
we
d
her
,
and
you
are
in
the
right
.
<EOS>
I
shall
.
<EOS>
The
marriage
is
essential
to
our
enterprise
;
and
the
only
obstacle
to
it
is
removed
.
<EOS>
"Fawkes
<EOS>
attempted
to
reply
,
but
his
parched
tongue
refused
its
office
.
<EOS>
Catesby
arose
,
and
carefully
raising
his
head
,
held
a
cup
of
water
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
The
sufferer
eagerly
drained
it
,
and
would
have
asked
for
more
;
but
seeing
that
the
request
would
be
refused
,
he
left
it
unuttered
.
<EOS>
"Have
<EOS>
you
examined
my
wound
?
<EOS>
"
he
said
,
after
a
pause
.
<EOS>
Catesby
answered
in
the
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
do
you
judge
it
mortal
?
<EOS>
"
continued
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
that
I
have
any
fear
of
Death
.
<EOS>
I
have
looked
him
in
the
face
too
often
for
that
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
somewhat
on
my
mind
which
I
would
fain
discharge
before
my
earthly
pilgrimage
is
ended
.
<EOS>
""Do
not
delay
it
,
then
,
"
rejoined
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
Knowing
I
speak
to
a
soldier
,
and
a
brave
one
,
I
do
not
hesitate
to
tell
you
your
hours
are
numbered
.
<EOS>
""Heaven
's
will
be
done
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Fawkes
,
in
a
tone
of
resignation
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
myself
destined
to
be
one
of
the
chief
instruments
of
the
restoration
of
our
holy
religion
.
<EOS>
But
I
find
I
was
mistaken
.
<EOS>
When
Father
Garnet
arrives
,
I
beseech
<EOS>
you
let
me
see
him
instantly
.
<EOS>
Or
,
if
he
should
not
come
speedily
,
entreat
Miss
Radcliffe
to
grant
me
a
few
moments
in
private
.
<EOS>
""Why
<EOS>
not
unburthen
yourself
to
me
?
"
returned
Catesby
,
distrustfully
.
<EOS>
"
In
your
circumstances
I
should
desire
no
better
confessor
than
a
brother
soldier,—no
other
crucifix
than
a
sword
-
hilt
.
<EOS>
""Nor
<EOS>
I
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
But
this
is
no
confession
I
am
about
to
make
.
<EOS>
What
I
have
to
say
relates
to
others
,
not
to
myself
.
""Indeed
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Then
there
is
the
more
reason
why
it
should
not
be
deferred
.
<EOS>
I
hold
it
my
duty
to
tell
you
that
the
fever
of
your
wound
will
,
in
all
probability
,
produce
delirium
.
<EOS>
Make
your
communication
while
your
senses
remain
to
you
.
<EOS>
And
whatever
you
enjoin
shall
be
rigorously
fulfilled
.
<EOS>
""Will
<EOS>
you
swear
this
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Fawkes
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
But
before
an
answer
could
be
returned
,
he
added
,
in
an
altered
tone
,
"
No,—no,—it
can
not
be
.
<EOS>
""This
is
no
time
for
anger
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
sternly
,
"
or
I
should
ask
whether
you
doubt
the
assurance
I
have
given
you?""I
doubt
nothing
but
your
compliance
with
my
request
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
oh
!
<EOS>
if
you
hope
to
be
succoured
at
your
hour
of
need
,
tell
Miss
Radcliffe
<EOS>
I
desire
to
speak
with
her
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
message
will
not
need
to
be
conveyed
,
"
said
Viviana
,
who
had
noiselessly
entered
the
room
;
"
she
is
here
.
<EOS>
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
turned
his
gaze
in
the
direction
of
the
voice
;
and
,
notwithstanding
his
own
deplorable
condition
,
he
was
filled
with
concern
at
the
change
wrought
in
her
appearance
by
the
terrible
shock
<EOS>
she
had
undergone
.
<EOS>
Her
countenance
was
as
pale
as
death,—her
eyes
,
from
which
no
tears
would
flow
,
as
is
ever
the
case
with
the
deepest
distress
,
were
glassy
and
lustreless,—her
luxuriant
hair
hung
in
dishevelled
masses
over
her
shoulders,—and
<EOS>
her
attire
was
soiled
and
disordered
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
desire
to
speak
with
me
<EOS>
,
"
she
continued
,
advancing
towards
the
couch
of
the
wounded
man
.
<EOS>
"It
must
be
alone
,
"
he
replied
.
<EOS>
Viviana
glanced
at
Catesby
,
who
reluctantly
arose
,
and
closed
the
door
after
him
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
alone
now
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"Water
!
<EOS>
water
!
"
<EOS>
gasped
the
sufferer
,
"
or
I
perish
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
request
being
complied
with
<EOS>
,
he
continued
in
a
low
solemn
voice
,
"
Viviana
,
you
have
lost
the
dearest
friend
you
had
on
earth
,
and
you
will
soon
lose
one
who
,
if
he
had
been
spared
,
would
have
endeavoured
,
as
far
as
he
could
,
to
repair
the
loss
.
<EOS>
I
say
not
this
to
aggravate
your
distress
,
but
to
prove
the
sincerity
of
my
regard
.
<EOS>
Let
me
conjure
you
,
with
my
dying
breath
,
not
to
we
d
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
""Fear
<EOS>
it
not
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
endure
death
than
consent
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
""Be
upon
your
guard
against
him
,
then
,
"
continued
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
When
an
object
is
to
be
gained
,
he
suffers
few
scruples
to
stand
in
his
way
.
<EOS>
""I
am
well
aware
of
it
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
and
on
the
arrival
of
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
I
shall
place
myself
under
his
protection
.
<EOS>
""Should
<EOS>
you
be
driven
to
extremity
,
"
said
Fawkes
,
taking
a
small
packet
from
the
folds
of
his
doublet
,
"
break
open
this
;
it
will
inform
you
what
to
do
.
<EOS>
Only
promise
me
you
will
not
have
recourse
to
it
till
all
other
means
have
failed
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
<EOS>
took
the
packet
,
and
gave
the
required
promise
.
<EOS>
"Conceal
<EOS>
it
about
your
person
,
and
guard
it
carefully
,
"
continued
Fawkes
;
"
for
you
know
not
when
you
may
require
it
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
having
cleared
my
conscience
,
I
can
die
easily
.
<EOS>
Let
me
have
your
prayers
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
<EOS>
knelt
down
by
the
bedside
,
and
poured
forth
the
most
earnest
supplications
in
his
behalf
.
<EOS>
"Perhaps
<EOS>
,
"
she
said
,
as
she
arose
,
"
and
it
is
some
consolation
to
think
so,—you
may
be
saved
by
death
from
the
commission
of
a
great
crime
,
which
would
for
ever
have
excluded
you
from
the
joys
of
heaven
.
<EOS>
""Say
<EOS>
rather
,
"
cried
Guy
Fawkes
,
whose
brain
began
to
wander
,
"
which
would
have
secured
them
to
me
.
<EOS>
Others
will
achieve
it
;
but
I
shall
have
no
share
in
their
glory
,
or
their
reward
.
<EOS>
""Their
reward
will
be
perdition
in
this
world
and
in
the
next
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
repeat
,
that
though
I
deeply
deplore
your
condition
,
I
rejoice
in
your
delivery
from
this
sin
.
<EOS>
It
is
better
—
far
better
—
to
die
thus
,
than
by
the
hands
of
the
common
executioner
.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
do
I
see
?
"
cried
Guy
Fawkes
,
trying
to
raise
himself
,
and
sinking
back
again
instantly
upon
the
pillow
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Elizabeth
Orton
rises
before
me
.
<EOS>
She
beckons
me
after
her
—
I
come!—I
come!""Heaven
pity
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
senses
have
left
him!""She
<EOS>
leads
me
into
a
gloomy
cavern
,
"
continued
Fawkes
,
more
wildly
;
"
but
my
eyes
are
like
the
wolf
's
,
and
can
penetrate
the
darkness
.
<EOS>
It
is
filled
with
barrels
of
gunpowder
.
<EOS>
I
see
them
ranged
in
tiers
,
one
above
another
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
know
where
I
am
now
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
vault
beneath
the
Parliament
-
house
.
<EOS>
The
King
and
his
nobles
are
assembled
in
the
hall
above
.
<EOS>
Lend
me
a
torch
,
that
I
may
fire
the
train
,
and
blow
them
into
the
air
.
<EOS>
Quick
!
<EOS>
quick
!
<EOS>
I
have
sworn
their
destruction
,
and
will
keep
my
oath
.
<EOS>
What
matter
if
I
perish
with
them
?
<EOS>
Give
me
the
torch
,
I
say
,
or
it
will
be
too
late
.
<EOS>
Is
the
powder
damp
that
it
will
not
kindle
?
<EOS>
And
see
!
<EOS>
the
torch
is
expiring
—
it
is
gone
out
!
<EOS>
Distraction!—to
be
baffled
thus
!
<EOS>
Why
do
you
stand
and
glare
at
me
with
your
stony
eyes
?
<EOS>
Who
are
those
with
you
?
<EOS>
Fiends!—no
!
<EOS>
they
are
armed
men
.
<EOS>
They
seize
me
—
they
drag
me
before
a
grave
assemblage
.
<EOS>
What
is
that
hideous
engine
?
<EOS>
The
rack!—Bind
me
on
it
—
break
every
limb
—
ye
shall
not
force
me
to
confess
—
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
I
laugh
at
your
threats
—
ha
!
<EOS>
ha!""Mother
of
mercy
!
<EOS>
release
him
from
this
torture
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"So
!
<EOS>
ye
have
condemned
me
,
"
continued
Fawkes
,
"
and
will
drag
me
to
execution
.
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
I
am
prepared
.
<EOS>
But
what
a
host
is
assembled
to
see
me
!
<EOS>
Ten
thousand
faces
are
turned
towards
me
,
and
all
with
one
abhorrent
bloodthirsty
expression
.
<EOS>
And
what
a
scaffold
!
<EOS>
Get
it
done
quickly
,
thou
butcherly
villain
.
<EOS>
The
rope
is
twisted
round
my
throat
in
serpent
folds
.
<EOS>
It
strangles
me
—
ah!""Horror
!
"
exclaimed
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
listen
to
this
no
longer
.
<EOS>
Help
,
Mr.
Catesby
,
help!""The
knife
is
at
my
breast
—
it
pierces
my
flesh
—
my
heart
is
torn
forth
—
I
die
!
<EOS>
I
die
!
"
<EOS>
And
he
uttered
a
dreadful
groan
.
<EOS>
"What
has
happened
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
rushing
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
Is
he
dead?""I
fear
so
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
and
his
end
has
been
a
fearful
one
.
<EOS>
""No
—
<EOS>
no
,
"
said
Catesby
;
<EOS>
"
his
pulse
still
beats
—
but
fiercely
and
feverishly
.
<EOS>
You
had
better
not
remain
here
longer
,
Miss
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
I
will
watch
over
him
.
<EOS>
All
will
soon
be
over
.
"Aware
<EOS>
that
she
could
be
of
no
further
use
,
Viviana
cast
a
look
of
the
deepest
commiseration
at
the
sufferer
,
and
retired
.
<EOS>
The
occupant
of
the
cottage
,
an
elderly
female
,
had
surrendered
all
the
apartments
of
her
tenement
,
except
one
small
room
,
to
her
guests
,
and
she
was
therefore
undisturbed
.
<EOS>
The
terrible
event
which
had
recently
occurred
,
and
the
harrowing
scene
she
had
just
witnessed
,
were
too
much
for
Viviana
,
and
her
anguish
was
so
intense
,
that
she
began
to
fear
her
reason
was
deserting
her
.
<EOS>
She
stood
still,—gazed
fearfully
round
,
as
if
some
secret
danger
environed
her,—clasped
her
hands
to
her
temples
,
and
found
them
burning
like
hot
iron,—and
,
then
,
alarmed
at
her
own
state
,
knelt
down
,
prayed
,
and
wept
.
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
she
wept
,
for
the
first
time
,
since
her
father
's
destruction
,
and
the
relief
afforded
by
those
scalding
tears
was
inexpressible
.
<EOS>
From
this
piteous
state
she
was
aroused
by
the
tramp
of
horses
at
the
door
of
the
cottage
,
and
the
next
moment
Father
Garnet
presented
himself
.
<EOS>
"How
<EOS>
uncertain
are
human
affairs
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
after
a
sorrowful
greeting
had
passed
between
them
.
<EOS>
"
I
little
thought
,
when
we
parted
yesterday
,
we
should
meet
again
so
soon
,
and
under
such
afflicting
circumstances
.
<EOS>
""It
is
the
will
of
Heaven
,
father
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
"
and
we
must
not
murmur
at
its
decrees
,
but
bear
our
chastening
as
we
best
may
.
<EOS>
""I
am
happy
to
find
you
in
such
a
comfortable
frame
of
mind
,
dear
daughter
.
<EOS>
I
feared
the
effect
of
the
shock
upon
your
feelings
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
glad
to
find
you
bear
up
against
it
<EOS>
so
well
.
<EOS>
""I
am
surprised
at
my
own
firmness
,
father
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
been
schooled
in
affliction
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
tie
left
to
bind
me
to
the
world
,
and
shall
retire
from
it
,
not
only
without
regret
,
but
with
eagerness
.
<EOS>
""Say
<EOS>
not
so
,
dear
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
,
I
trust
,
much
happiness
in
store
for
you
;
and
when
the
sharpness
of
your
affliction
is
worn
off
,
you
will
view
your
condition
in
a
more
cheering
light
.
""Impossible
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
mournfully
.
<EOS>
"
Hope
is
wholly
extinct
in
my
breast
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
contest
the
point
.
<EOS>
Is
not
Sir
Everard
Digby
with
you?""He
is
not
,
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
"
and
I
will
explain
to
you
wherefore
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
your
departure
yesterday
,
the
mansion
we
occupied
at
Holt
was
attacked
by
a
band
of
soldiers
,
headed
by
Miles
Topcliffe
,
one
of
the
most
unrelenting
of
our
persecutors
;
and
though
they
were
driven
off
with
some
loss
,
yet
,
as
there
was
every
reason
to
apprehend
,
they
would
return
with
fresh
force
,
Sir
Everard
judged
it
prudent
to
retreat
;
and
accordingly
he
and
his
friends
,
with
all
their
attendants
,
except
those
he
has
sent
with
me
,
have
departed
for
Buckinghamshire
.
<EOS>
""Where
,
then
,
is
Father
Oldcorne
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"Alas
!
<EOS>
daughter
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
,
"
<EOS>
I
grieve
to
say
he
is
a
prisoner
.
<EOS>
Imprudently
exposing
himself
during
the
attack
,
he
was
seized
and
carried
off
by
Topcliffe
and
his
myrmidons
.
<EOS>
""How
<EOS>
true
is
the
saying
that
misfortunes
never
come
single
!
"
<EOS>
sighed
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
seem
bereft
of
all
I
hold
dear
.
<EOS>
""Sir
<EOS>
Everard
has
sent
four
of
his
trustiest
servants
with
me
,
"
remarked
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
well
armed
,
and
will
attend
you
wherever
you
choose
to
lead
them
.
<EOS>
He
has
also
furnished
me
with
a
sum
of
money
for
your
use
.
<EOS>
""He
is
most
kind
and
considerate
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
father
,
"
she
faltered
,
"
there
is
one
subject
which
it
is
necessary
to
speak
upon
;
and
,
though
I
shrink
from
it
,
it
must
not
be
postponed
.
<EOS>
""I
guess
what
you
mean
,
daughter
,
"
said
Garnet
,
sympathizingly
;
"
you
allude
to
the
interment
of
Sir
William
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
Is
the
body
here?""It
<EOS>
is
in
an
adjoining
cottage
,
"
replied
Viviana
in
a
broken
voice
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
already
expressed
my
wish
to
Mr.
Catesby
to
have
it
conveyed
to
Manchester
,
to
our
family
vault
.
<EOS>
""I
see
not
how
that
can
be
accomplished
,
dear
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
;
"
but
I
will
confer
with
Mr.
Catesby
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
Where
is
he?""In
the
next
room
,
by
the
couch
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
is
dying
,
"
said
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"Dying
!
"
echoed
Garnet
,
starting
.
<EOS>
"
I
heard
he
was
dangerously
hurt
,
but
did
not
suppose
the
wound
would
prove
fatal
.
<EOS>
Here
is
another
grievous
blow
to
the
good
cause
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
this
moment
the
door
was
opened
by
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"How
<EOS>
is
the
sufferer
?
"
asked
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"A
<EOS>
slight
change
for
the
better
appears
to
have
taken
place
,
"
answered
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
fever
has
in
some
decree
abated
,
and
he
has
sunk
into
a
gentle
slumber
.
<EOS>
""Can
<EOS>
he
be
removed
with
safety
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Garnet
<EOS>
;
"
for
,
I
fear
,
if
he
remains
here
,
he
will
fall
into
the
hands
of
Topcliffe
and
his
crew
,
who
are
scouring
the
country
in
every
direction
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
recapitulated
all
he
had
just
stated
to
Viviana
.
<EOS>
Catesby
was
for
some
time
lost
in
reflection
.
<EOS>
"I
am
fairly
perplexed
as
to
what
course
it
will
be
best
to
pursue
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Dangers
and
difficulties
beset
us
on
every
side
.
<EOS>
I
am
inclined
to
yield
to
Viviana
's
request
,
and
proceed
to
Manchester
.
<EOS>
""That
will
be
rushing
into
the
very
face
of
danger
,
"
observed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"And
,
therefore
,
may
be
the
safest
plan
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Our
adversaries
will
scarcely
suspect
us
of
so
desperate
a
step
.
<EOS>
""Perhaps
you
are
in
the
right
,
my
son
,
"
returned
Garnet
,
after
a
moment
's
reflection
.
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
I
bow
to
your
judgment
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
plan
is
too
much
in
accordance
with
my
own
wishes
to
meet
with
any
opposition
on
my
part
,
"
observed
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"Will
<EOS>
you
accompany
us
,
father
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Catesby
;
"
or
do
you
proceed
to
Gothurst?""I
will
go
with
you
,
my
son
.
<EOS>
Viviana
will
need
a
protector
.
<EOS>
And
,
till
I
have
seen
her
in
some
place
of
safety
,
I
will
not
leave
her
.
<EOS>
""Since
we
have
come
to
this
determination
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
"
as
soon
as
the
needful
preparations
can
be
made
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
has
had
some
hours
'
repose
,
we
will
set
out
.
<EOS>
Under
cover
of
night
we
can
travel
with
security
;
and
,
by
using
some
exertion
,
may
reach
Ordsall
Hall
,
whither
<EOS>
,
I
presume
,
Viviana
would
choose
to
proceed
,
in
the
first
instance
,
before
daybreak
.
<EOS>
""I
am
well
mounted
,
and
so
are
my
attendants
,
"
replied
Garnet
;
"
and
,
by
the
provident
care
of
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
each
of
them
has
a
led
horse
with
him
.
<EOS>
""That
is
well
,
"
said
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
Viviana
,
may
I
entreat
you
to
take
my
place
for
a
short
time
by
the
couch
of
the
sufferer
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
hours
everything
shall
be
in
readiness
.
"He
<EOS>
then
retired
with
Garnet
,
while
Viviana
proceeded
to
the
adjoining
chamber
,
where
she
found
Guy
Fawkes
still
slumbering
tranquilly
.
<EOS>
As
the
evening
advanced
,
he
awoke
,
and
appeared
much
refreshed
.
<EOS>
While
he
was
speaking
,
Garnet
and
Catesby
approached
his
bedside
,
and
he
seemed
overjoyed
at
the
sight
of
the
former
.
<EOS>
The
subject
of
the
journey
being
mentioned
to
him
,
he
at
once
expressed
his
ready
compliance
with
the
arrangement
,
and
only
desired
that
the
last
rites
of
his
church
might
be
performed
for
him
before
he
set
out
.
<EOS>
Garnet
informed
him
that
he
had
come
for
that
very
purpose
;
and
as
soon
as
they
were
left
alone
,
he
proceeded
to
the
discharge
of
his
priestly
duties
,
confessed
and
absolved
him
,
giving
him
the
viaticum
and
the
extreme
unction
.
<EOS>
And
,
lastly
,
he
judged
it
expedient
to
administer
a
powerful
opiate
,
to
lull
the
pain
of
his
wound
on
the
journey
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
summoned
Catesby
,
who
,
with
two
of
the
attendants
,
raised
the
couch
on
which
the
wounded
man
was
stretched
,
and
conveyed
him
to
the
litter
.
<EOS>
So
well
was
this
managed
,
that
Fawkes
sustained
no
injury
,
and
little
inconvenience
,
from
the
movement
.
<EOS>
Two
strong
country
vehicles
had
been
procured
;
the
one
containing
the
wounded
man
's
litter
,
the
other
the
shell
,
which
had
been
hastily
put
together
,
to
hold
the
remains
of
the
unfortunate
Sir
William
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
Viviana
being
placed
in
the
saddle
,
and
Catesby
having
liberally
rewarded
the
cottagers
who
had
afforded
them
shelter
,
the
little
cavalcade
was
put
in
motion
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
they
journeyed
through
the
night
;
and
shaping
their
course
through
Tarporley
,
Northwich
,
and
Altringham
,
arrived
at
daybreak
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Ordsall
Hall
.
<EOS>
XV
.
<EOS>
—
THE
ELIXIROn
beholding
the
well
-
remembered
roof
and
gables
of
the
old
mansion
peeping
from
out
the
grove
of
trees
in
which
it
was
embosomed
,
Viviana
's
heart
died
away
within
her
.
<EOS>
The
thought
that
her
father
,
who
had
so
recently
quitted
it
in
the
full
enjoyment
of
health
,
and
of
every
worldly
blessing
,
should
be
so
soon
brought
back
a
corpse
,
was
almost
too
agonizing
for
endurance
.
<EOS>
Reflecting
,
however
,
that
this
was
no
season
for
the
indulgence
of
grief
,
but
that
she
was
called
upon
to
act
with
firmness
,
she
bore
up
resolutely
against
her
emotion
.
<EOS>
Arrived
within
a
short
distance
of
the
Hall
,
Catesby
caused
the
little
train
to
halt
under
the
shelter
of
the
trees
,
while
he
rode
forward
to
ascertain
that
they
could
safely
approach
it
.
<EOS>
As
he
drew
near
,
everything
proclaimed
that
the
hand
of
the
spoiler
had
been
there
.
<EOS>
Crossing
the
drawbridge
,
he
entered
the
court
,
which
bore
abundant
marks
of
the
devastation
recently
committed
.
<EOS>
Various
articles
of
furniture
,
broken
,
burnt
,
or
otherwise
destroyed
,
were
lying
scattered
about
.
<EOS>
The
glass
in
the
windows
was
shivered
;
the
doors
forced
from
their
hinges
;
the
stone
-
copings
of
the
walls
pushed
off
;
the
flower
-
beds
trampled
upon
;
the
moat
itself
was
in
some
places
choked
up
with
rubbish
,
while
in
others
its
surface
was
covered
with
floating
pieces
of
timber
.
<EOS>
Led
by
curiosity
Catesby
proceeded
to
the
spot
where
the
stables
had
stood
.
<EOS>
Nothing
but
a
heap
of
blackened
ruins
met
his
gaze
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
one
stone
was
standing
on
another
.
<EOS>
The
appearance
of
the
place
was
so
desolate
and
disheartening
,
that
he
turned
away
instantly
.
<EOS>
Leaving
his
horse
in
a
shed
,
he
entered
the
house
.
<EOS>
Here
,
again
,
he
encountered
fresh
ravages
.
<EOS>
The
oak
-
panels
and
skirting
-
boards
were
torn
from
the
walls
;
the
ceilings
pulled
down
;
and
the
floor
lay
inch
-
deep
in
broken
plaster
and
dust
.
<EOS>
On
ascending
to
the
upper
rooms
,
he
found
the
same
disorder
.
<EOS>
The
banisters
of
the
stairs
were
broken
;
the
bedsteads
destroyed
;
the
roof
partially
untiled
.
<EOS>
Every
room
was
thickly
strewn
with
leaves
torn
from
valuable
books
,
with
fragments
of
apparel
,
and
other
articles
,
which
the
searchers
not
being
able
to
carry
off
had
wantonly
destroyed
.
<EOS>
Having
contemplated
this
scene
of
havoc
for
some
time
,
with
feelings
of
the
bitterest
indignation
,
Catesby
descended
to
the
lowest
story
;
and
,
after
searching
ineffectually
for
the
domestics
,
was
about
to
depart
,
when
,
turning
suddenly
,
he
perceived
a
man
watching
him
from
an
adjoining
room
.
<EOS>
Catesby
instantly
called
to
him
;
but
,
seeing
that
the
fellow
disregarded
his
assurances
,
and
was
about
to
take
to
his
heels
,
he
drew
his
sword
,
and
threatened
him
with
severe
punishment
if
he
attempted
to
fly
.
<EOS>
Thus
exhorted
,
the
man
—
who
was
no
other
than
the
younger
Heydocke
—
advanced
towards
him
;
and
throwing
himself
at
his
feet
,
begged
him
in
the
most
piteous
terms
to
do
him
no
injury
.
<EOS>
"I
have
already
told
you
I
am
a
friend
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
sheathing
his
sword
.
<EOS>
"Ah
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Catesby
,
is
it
you
I
behold
?
"
cried
Martin
Heydocke
,
whose
fears
had
hitherto
prevented
him
from
noticing
the
features
of
the
intruder
.
<EOS>
"
What
brings
your
worship
to
this
ill
-
fated
house?""First
let
me
know
if
there
is
any
enemy
about
?
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"None
that
I
am
aware
of
<EOS>
,
"
rejoined
Martin
.
"
<EOS>
Having
ransacked
the
premises
,
and
done
all
the
mischief
they
could
,
as
you
perceive
,
the
miscreants
departed
the
day
before
yesterday
,
and
I
have
seen
nothing
of
them
since
,
though
I
have
been
constantly
on
the
watch
.
<EOS>
The
only
alarm
I
have
had
was
that
occasioned
by
your
worship
just
now
.
<EOS>
""Are
<EOS>
you
alone
here
?
"
demanded
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"No
,
your
worship
,
"
answered
Martin
.
<EOS>
"
There
are
several
of
the
servants
concealed
in
a
secret
passage
under
the
house
.
<EOS>
But
they
are
so
terrified
by
what
has
lately
happened
,
that
they
never
dare
show
themselves
,
except
during
the
night
-
time
.
<EOS>
""I
do
not
wonder
at
it
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
now
may
I
inquire
whether
your
worship
brings
any
tidings
of
Sir
William
Radcliffe
and
Mistress
Viviana
?
"
rejoined
Martin
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
no
ill
has
befallen
them
.
<EOS>
My
father
,
old
Jerome
Heydocke
,
set
out
to
Holywell
a
few
days
ago
,
to
apprise
them
of
their
danger
,
and
I
have
not
heard
of
them
since
.
<EOS>
""Sir
<EOS>
William
Radcliffe
is
dead
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
The
villains
have
murdered
him
.
<EOS>
Your
father
is
a
prisoner
.
<EOS>
""Alas
!
<EOS>
alas
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
young
man
,
bursting
into
tears
;
"
these
are
fearful
times
to
live
in
.
<EOS>
What
will
become
of
us
all?""We
must
rise
against
the
oppressor
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
Bite
the
heel
that
tramples
upon
us
.
<EOS>
""We
must
,
"
rejoined
Martin
.
"
<EOS>
And
if
my
poor
arm
could
avail
,
it
should
not
be
slow
to
strike
.
<EOS>
""Manfully
resolved
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
who
never
lost
an
opportunity
of
gaining
a
proselyte
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
point
out
to
you
a
way
by
which
you
may
accomplish
what
you
desire
.
<EOS>
But
we
will
talk
of
this
hereafter
.
<EOS>
Hoard
up
your
vengeance
till
the
fitting
moment
for
action
arrives
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
then
proceeded
to
explain
to
the
young
man
,
who
was
greatly
surprised
by
the
intelligence
,
that
Viviana
was
at
hand
,
and
that
the
body
of
Sir
William
had
been
brought
thither
for
interment
in
the
family
vault
at
the
Collegiate
Church
.
<EOS>
Having
ascertained
that
there
was
a
chamber
,
which
,
having
suffered
less
than
the
others
,
might
serve
for
Viviana
's
accommodation
,
Catesby
returned
to
the
party
.
<EOS>
A
more
melancholy
cavalcade
has
been
seldom
seen
than
now
approached
the
gates
of
Ordsall
Hall
.
<EOS>
First
rode
Viviana
,
in
an
agony
of
tears
,
for
her
grief
had
by
this
time
become
absolutely
uncontrollable
,
with
Catesby
on
foot
,
leading
her
horse
.
<EOS>
Next
came
Garnet
,
greatly
exhausted
and
depressed
;
his
eyes
cast
dejectedly
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Then
came
the
litter
,
containing
Guy
Fawkes
;
and
,
lastly
,
the
vehicle
with
the
body
of
Sir
William
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
On
arriving
at
the
gate
,
Viviana
was
met
by
two
female
servants
,
whom
Martin
Heydocke
had
summoned
from
their
hiding
-
places
;
and
,
as
soon
as
she
had
dismounted
,
she
was
supported
,
for
she
was
scarcely
able
to
walk
unaided
,
to
the
chamber
destined
for
her
reception
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
Catesby
proceeded
,
with
some
anxiety
,
to
superintend
the
removal
of
Fawkes
,
who
was
perfectly
insensible
.
<EOS>
His
wound
had
bled
considerably
during
the
journey
;
but
the
effusion
had
stopped
when
the
faintness
supervened
.
<EOS>
He
was
placed
in
one
of
the
lower
rooms
till
a
sleeping
-
chamber
could
be
prepared
for
him
.
<EOS>
The
last
task
was
to
attend
to
the
remains
of
the
late
unfortunate
possessor
of
the
mansion
.
<EOS>
By
Catesby
's
directions
a
large
oak
table
,
once
occupying
the
great
hall
,
was
removed
to
the
Star
Chamber
,
already
described
as
the
principal
room
of
the
house
;
and
,
being
securely
propped
up,—for
,
like
the
rest
of
the
furniture
,
it
had
been
much
damaged
by
the
spoilers
,
though
,
being
of
substantial
material
,
it
offered
greater
resistance
to
their
efforts,—the
shell
containing
the
body
was
placed
upon
it
.
<EOS>
"Better
<EOS>
he
should
lie
thus
,
"
exclaimed
Catesby
,
when
the
melancholy
office
was
completed
,
"
than
live
to
witness
the
wreck
around
him
.
<EOS>
Fatal
as
are
these
occurrences
,
"
he
added
,
pursuing
the
train
of
thought
suggested
by
the
scene
,
"
they
are
yet
favourable
to
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
The
only
person
who
could
have
prevented
my
union
with
Viviana
Radcliffe
—
her
father
—
lies
there
.
<EOS>
Who
would
have
thought
when
she
rejected
my
proposal
a
few
days
ago
,
in
this
very
room
,
how
fortune
would
conspire
—
and
by
what
dark
and
inscrutable
means
—
to
bring
it
about
!
<EOS>
Fallen
as
it
is
,
this
house
is
not
yet
fallen
so
low
,
but
I
can
reinstate
it
.
<EOS>
Its
young
mistress
mine
,
her
estates
<EOS>
mine,—for
<EOS>
she
is
now
inheritress
of
all
her
father
's
possessions,—the
utmost
reach
of
my
ambition
were
gained
,
and
all
but
one
object
of
my
life
—
for
which
I
have
dared
so
much
,
and

so
long
—
<EOS>
achieved!""What
<EOS>
are
you
thinking
of
,
my
son
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Garnet
,
who
had
watched
the
changing

of
his
sombre
<EOS>
countenance,—"what
are

thinking

?
<EOS>
"
he

,

.
<EOS>
"Of
<EOS>
that
which
is
never

,

the

,
"

Catesby
;
"
and

,
which

.
<EOS>
""I
do
not
understand

,
my

,
"

.
<EOS>
"Does
<EOS>
not
Radcliffe
's

?
<EOS>
"

;
"
and

?
<EOS>
No
,
father
,
she
will
no

to
wrongs
that
would
steel

,
and

.
<EOS>
Viviana

,
"
he

,

,
"
ours
,

,

that

accrued

shall

mighty

.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
think
she
will

you

,
my
son
,
"

Garnet
.
"She
<EOS>
shall
not
refuse

,
father
,
"

Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
The
time
is
gone
by
for
idle

.
<EOS>
""I
will
be
no
party
to
forcible

,

,
"
returned
Garnet
,

.
<EOS>
"
As

,

lend

,

.
<EOS>
""Persuasion

,
I

,

,
"
answered

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
""Would
<EOS>
there

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
"
<EOS>
In

,

.
<EOS>
""We
do
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
And
yet
he
has
been
subject
to
strange

of
late
.
<EOS>
""He
has
been
appalled
,
but
never

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Of

,

.
<EOS>
When

,
you
will

alone
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
made
no
reply
,
but
led
the
way
to
the
chamber
where
the
wounded
man
lay
.
<EOS>
He
had
regained
his
consciousness
,
but
was
too
feeble
to
speak
.
<EOS>
After
such

as
were
at
hand
had

administered
,
Catesby
was
about
to
order
a
room
to

up
for
him
,
when
Viviana
,
whose
anxiety
for
the
sufferer
had
overcome
her

,
made
her
appearance
.
<EOS>
On
learning
Catesby
's
intentions
,
she
insisted
upon
Fawkes
being
removed
to
the
room
allotted
to
her
,
which
had
not
been
dismantled
like
the
rest
.
<EOS>
Seeing
it
was
in
vain
to
oppose
her
,
Catesby
assented
,
and
the
sufferer
was
accordingly
carried
thither
,
and
placed
within
the
bed
—
a
large
antique
piece
of
furniture
,
hung
with
faded
damask
curtains
.
<EOS>
The
room
was
one
of
the
oldest
in
the
house
,
and
at
the
further
end
stood
a
small
closet
,
approached
by
an
arched
doorway
,
and
fitted
up
with
a
hassock
and
crucifix
,
which
,
strange
to
say
,
had
escaped
the
ravages
of
the
searchers
.
<EOS>
Placed
within
the
couch
,
Guy
Fawkes
began
to
ramble
as
before
about
the
conspiracy
;
and
fearing
his
ravings
might
awaken
the
suspicion
of
the
servants
,
Catesby
would
not
suffer
any
of
them
to
come
near
him
,
but
arranged
with
Garnet
to
keep
watch
over
him
by
turns
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
he
became
more
composed
;
and
,
after
dozing
a
little
,
opened
his
eyes
,
and
,
looking
round
,
inquired
anxiously
for
his
sword
.
<EOS>
At
first
,
Catesby
,
who
was
alone
with
him
at
the
time
,
hesitated
in
his
answer
,
but
seeing
he
appeared
greatly
disturbed
,
he
showed
him
that
his
hat
,
gauntlets
,
and
rapier
were
lying
by
the
bedside
.
<EOS>
"I
am
content
,
"
replied
the
wounded
man
,
smiling
faintly
;
"
that
sword
has
never
left
my
side
,
waking
or
sleeping
,
for
twenty
years
.
<EOS>
Let
me
grasp
it
once
more
—
perhaps
for
the
last
time
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
handed
him
the
weapon
.
<EOS>
He
looked
at
it
for
a
few
moments
,
and
pressed
the
blade
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
"Farewell
,
old
friend
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
a
tear
gathering
in
his
eye
,
"
farewell
!
<EOS>
Catesby
,
"
he
added
,
as
he
resigned
the
weapon
to
him
,
"
I
have
one
request
to
make
.
<EOS>
Let
my
sword
be
buried
with
me
.
<EOS>
""It
<EOS>
shall
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
in
a
voice
suffocated
by
emotion
,
for
the
request
<EOS>
touched
him
where
his
stern
nature
was
most
accessible
:
"
I
will
place
it
by
you
myself
.
""Thanks
!
"
exclaimed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
And
soon
after
this
,
he
again
fell
into
a
slumber
.
<EOS>
His
sleep
endured
for
some
hours
;
but
his
breathing
grew
fainter
and
fainter
,
so
that
at
the
last
it
was
scarcely
perceptible
.
<EOS>
A
striking
change
had
likewise
taken
place
in
his
countenance
,
and
these
signs
convinced
Catesby
<EOS>
he
had
not
long
to
live
.
<EOS>
While
he
was
watching
him
with
great
anxiety
,
Viviana
appeared
at
the
door
of
the
chamber
,
and
beckoned
him
out
.
<EOS>
Noiselessly
obeying
the
summons
,
and
following
her
along
the
gallery
,
he
entered
a
room
where
he
found
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"I
have
called
you
to
say
that
a
remedy
has
been
suggested
to
me
by
Martin
Heydocke
,
"
observed
Viviana
,
"
<EOS>
by
which
I
trust
Guy
Fawkes
may
yet
be
saved
.
<EOS>
""How
?
"
asked
Catesby
,
eagerly
.
"Doctor
<EOS>
Dee
,
the
warden
of
Manchester
,
of
whom
you
must
have
heard
,
"
she
continued
,
"
is
said
to
possess
an
elixir
of
such
virtue
,
that
a
few
drops
of
it
will
snatch
him
who
drinks
them
from
the
very
jaws
of
death
.
<EOS>
""I
should
not
have
suspected
you
of
so
much
credulity
,
Viviana
,
"
<EOS>
replied
Catesby
;
"
but
grant
that
Doctor
Dee
possesses
this
marvellous
elixir
—
which
for
my
own
part
I
doubt
—
how
are
we
to
obtain
it?""If
you
will
repair
to
the
college
,
and
see
him
<EOS>
,
I
doubt
not
he
will
give
it
you
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
.
<EOS>
Catesby
smiled
incredulously
.
<EOS>
"I
have
a
claim
upon
Doctor
Dee
,
"
she
persisted
,
"
which
I
have
never
enforced
.
<EOS>
I
will
now
use
it
.
<EOS>
Show
him
this
token
,
"
she
continued
,
detaching
a
small
ornament
from
her
neck
;
"
tell
him
you
bring
it
from
me
,
and
I
am
sure
he
will
comply
with
your
request
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
commands
shall
be
obeyed
,
Viviana
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
"
but
I
frankly
confess
I
have
no
faith
in
the
remedy
.
<EOS>
""It
is
at
least
worth
the
trial
,
my
son
,
"
observed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Dee
is
a
wonderful
person
,
and
has
made
many
discoveries
in
medicine
,
as
in
other
sciences
,
and
this
marvellous
specific
may
,
for
aught
we
know
,
turn
out
no
imposture
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
such
is
your
opinion
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
"
I
will
set
out
at
once
.
<EOS>
If
it
is
to
be
tried
at
all
,
it
must
be
without
delay
.
<EOS>
The
poor
sufferer
is
sinking
fast
.
<EOS>
""Go
<EOS>
then
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
"
and
heaven
speed
your
mission
!
<EOS>
If
you
could
prevail
upon
Doctor
Dee
to
visit
the
wounded
man
in
person
,
I
should
prefer
it
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
have
another
request
to
make
of
him
—
but
that
will
do
hereafter
.
<EOS>
Lose
not
a
moment
now
.
<EOS>
""I
will
fly
on
the
wings
of
the
wind
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
Heaven
grant
that
when
I
return
the
object
of
our
solicitude
may
not
be
past
all
human
aid!"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
hurried
to
an
out
-
building
in
which
the
horses
were
placed
,
and
choosing
the
strongest
and
fleetest
from
out
their
number
,
mounted
,
and
started
at
full
gallop
in
the
direction
of
Manchester
;
nor
did
he
relax
his
speed
until
he
reached
the
gates
of
the
ancient
College
.
<EOS>
Hanging
the
bridle
of
his
smoking
steed
to
a
hook
in
the
wall
,
he
crossed
the
large
quadrangular
court
;
and
finding
the
principal
entrance
open
,
passed
the
lofty
room
now
used
as
the
refectory
,
ascended
the
flight
of
stone
stairs
that
conducts
the
modern
visitor
to
the
library
,
and
was
traversing
the
long
galleries
communicating
with
it
,
and
now
crowded
with
the
learning
of
ages
,
bequeathed
by
the
benevolence
of
his
rival
,
Humphrey
Chetham
,
when
he
encountered
a
grave
but
crafty
-
looking
personage
,
in
a
loose
brown
robe
and
Polish
cap
,
who
angrily
demanded
his
business
.
<EOS>
Apologizing
for
the
intrusion
,
Catesby
was
about
to
explain
,
when
a
small
oak
door
near
them
was
partly
opened
,
and
an
authoritative
voice
,
from
within
,
exclaimed
,
"
Do
not
hinder
him
,
Kelley
.
<EOS>
I
know
his
business
,
and
will
see
him
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
seer
made
no
further
remark
,
but
pointing
to
the
door
,
Catesby
at
once
comprehended
that
it
was
Dee
's
voice
he
had
heard
;
and
,
though
somewhat
startled
by
the
intimation
that
he
was
expected
,
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
found
the
Doctor
surrounded
by
his
magical
apparatus
,
and
slowly
returning
to
the
chair
he
had
just
quitted
.
<EOS>
Without
looking
behind
him
to
see
whom
he
addressed
,
Dee
continued
,
"
I
have
just
consulted
my
show
-
stone
,
and
know
why
you
are
come
hither
.
<EOS>
You
bring
a
token
from
Viviana
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
do
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
in
increased
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
here
.
<EOS>
""It
is
needless
to
produce
it
,
"
replied
Dee
,
still
keeping
his
back
towards
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
it
already
.
<EOS>
Kelley
,
"
he
continued
,
"
I
am
about
to
set
out
for
Ordsall
Hall
immediately
.
<EOS>
You
must
accompany
me
.
""Amazement
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Is
the
purpose
of
my
visit
then
really
known
to
your
reverence?""You
shall
hear
,
"
rejoined
Dee
,
facing
him
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
friend
who
is
at
the
point
of
death
,
and
having
heard
that
I
possess
an
elixir
of
wonderful
efficacy
,
are
come
in
quest
of
it
.
<EOS>
""True
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
utterly
confounded
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
name
of
that
friend
,
"
pursued
Dee
,
regarding
him

,
"
is
Guy
Fawkes,—your
own
,
Robert
Catesby
.
<EOS>
""I
need
no
more
to
convince
me
,
reverend

,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
trembling
,

,
"
that
all
I
have
heard
of
your
wonderful
powers
falls
far

truth
.
<EOS>
""You
are
but
just
in
time
,
"
replied
Dee
,
bowing

,
in
acknowledgment
of
the

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Another
hour
,
and
it
would
have

too
late
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
you
think
he
will
live
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"I
am
sure
of
it
,
"
replied
Dee
,
"
provided——""Provided
what
?
"
interrupted
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
Is
there
aught
I
can
do
to
ensure

,
"
replied
Dee
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
debating
within

whether
it
is
worth
while
reviving
him
for
a
more

.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
mean
you
,
reverend
sir
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Catesby
,
a
shade
passing
over
his

.
<EOS>
"You
understand
my
meaning
,
and
therefore
need
no

,
"
replied
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
Return
to
Ordsall
Hall
,
and
tell
Miss
Radcliffe
I
will
be
there
in
an
hour
.
<EOS>
Bid
her
have
no
further
fear
.
<EOS>
If
the
wounded
man
breathes
when
I
arrive
,
I
will
undertake
to

him
.
<EOS>
Add
further
,
that
I
know
the
other
request
she
desires
to
make
of
me
,
and
that
it
is
granted
before
it
is
asked
.
<EOS>
Farewell
,
sir
,
for
a
short
time
.
<EOS>
"On
reaching
the
court
,
Catesby
expanded
his
chest
,
shook
his
limbs
,
and
exclaimed
,
"
At
length
,
I
breathe
freely
.
<EOS>
The
atmosphere
of
that
infernal
chamber
smelt
so
horribly
of
sulphur
that
it
almost
stifled
me
.
<EOS>
Well
,
if
Doctor
Dee
has
not
dealings
with
the
devil
,
man
never
had
!
<EOS>
However
,
if
he
cures
Guy
Fawkes
,
I
care
not
whence
the
medicine
comes
from
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
descended
Smithy
Bank
,
and
was
about
to
cross
the
old
bridge
over
the
Irwell
,
he
perceived
a
man
riding
before
him
,
who
seemed

to
avoid
him
.
<EOS>
Struck
by
this
person
's
manner
,
he
urged
his
horse
into
a
quicker
pace
,
and
being
better
mounted
of
the
two
,
soon
overtook
him
,
when
to
his
surprise
he
found
it
was
Martin
Heydocke
.
<EOS>
"What
<EOS>
are
you
doing
here
,
sirrah
?
<EOS>
"
he
demanded
.
<EOS>
"I
have
been
sent
by
Mistress
Viviana
with
a
message
to
Mr.
Humphrey
Chetham
,
"
replied
the
young
man
,
in
great
confusion
.
"Indeed
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Catesby
,
angrily
.
"
<EOS>
And
how
dared
you
convey
a
message
to
him
,
without
consulting
me
on
the
subject?""I
<EOS>
was
not
aware
you
were
my
master
,
"
replied
Martin
,
sulkily
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
owe
obedience
to
any
one
,
it
is
to
Mr.
Chetham
,
whose
servant
I
am
.
<EOS>
But
if
Mistress
Viviana
gives
me
a
message
to
deliver
,
I
will
execute
her
commands
,
whoever
may
be
pleased
or
displeased
.
<EOS>
""I
did
but
jest
,
thou
saucy
knave
,
"
returned
Catesby
,
who
did
not
desire
to
offend
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
is
a
piece
of
money
for
thee
.
<EOS>
Now
,
if
it
be
no
secret
,
what
was
Miss
Radcliffe
's
message
to
thy
master?""I
<EOS>
know
not
what
her
letter
contained
,
"
replied
Martin
;
"
but
his
answer
was
,
that
he
would
come
to
the
hall
at
midnight
.
<EOS>
""It
is
well
<EOS>
I
ascertained
this
,
"
thought
Catesby
,
and
he
added
aloud
,
"
I
understood
your
master
had
been
arrested
and
imprisoned
.
<EOS>
""So
<EOS>
he
was
,
"
replied
Martin
;
"
but
he
had
interest
enough
with
the
Commissioners
to
procure
his
liberation
.
<EOS>
""Enough
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
and
striking
spurs
into
his
charger
,
he
dashed
off
.
<EOS>
A
quarter
of
an
hour
's
hard
riding
brought
him
to
the
hall
,
and
,
on
arriving
there
,
he
proceeded
at
once
to
the
wounded
man
's
chamber
,
where
he
found
Viviana
and
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"Have
<EOS>
you
succeeded
in
your
errand
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
former
,
eagerly
.
"
<EOS>
Will
Doctor
Dee
come
,
or
has
he
sent
the
elixir?""He
<EOS>
will
bring
it
himself
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
Viviana
uttered
an
exclamation
of
joy
,
and
the
sound
appeared
to
reach
the
ears
of
the
sufferer
,
for
he
stirred
,
and
groaned
faintly
.
<EOS>
"Doctor
<EOS>
Dee
desired
me
to
tell
you
,
"
continued
Catesby
,
drawing
Viviana
aside
,
and
speaking
in
a
low
tone
,
"
that
your
other
request
was
granted
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
looked
surprised
,
and
as
if
she
did
not
clearly
understand
him
.
<EOS>
"Might
<EOS>
he
not
refer
to
Humphrey
Chetham
?
"
remarked
Catesby
,
somewhat
maliciously
.
<EOS>
"Ah
!
<EOS>
you
have
learnt
from
Martin
Heydocke
that
I
have
written
to
him
,
"
returned
Viviana
,
blushing
deeply
.
<EOS>
"
What
I
was
about
to
ask
of
Doctor
Dee
had
no
reference
to
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
It
was
to
request
permission
to
privately
inter
my
father
's
remains
in
our
family
vault
in
the
Collegiate
Church
.
<EOS>
But
how
did
he
know
I
had
any
request
to
make?""That
passes
my
comprehension
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
"
unless
he
obtained
his
information
from
his
familiar
spirits
.
<EOS>
"Shortly
<EOS>
after
this
,
Dr.
Dee
and
Kelley
arrived
at
the
hall
.
<EOS>
Catesby
met
them
at
the
gate
,
and
conducted
them
to
the
wounded
man
's
chamber
.
<EOS>
Coldly
saluting
Garnet
,
whom
he
eyed
with
suspicion
,
and
bowing
respectfully
to
Viviana
,
the
Doctor
slowly
advanced
to
the
bedside
.
<EOS>
He
gazed
for
a
short
time
at
the
wounded
man
,
and
folded
his
arms
thoughtfully
upon
his
breast
.
<EOS>
The
eyes
of
the
sufferer
were
closed
,
and
his
lips
slightly
apart
,
but
no
breath
seemed
to
issue
from
them
.
<EOS>
His
bronzed
complexion
had
assumed
the
ghastly
hue
of
death
,
and
his
strongly
-
marked
features
had
become
fixed
and
rigid
.
<EOS>
His
black
hair
,
stiffened
and
caked
with
blood
,
escaped
from
the
bandages
around
his
head
,
and
hung
in
elf
locks
on
the
pillow
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
piteous
spectacle
;
and
Doctor
Dee
appeared
much
moved
by
it
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
worst
is
over
,
"
he
muttered
:
"
why
recall
the
spirit
to
its
wretched
tenement?""If
you
can
save
him
,
reverend
sir
,
do
not
hesitate
,
"
implored
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
am
come
hither
for
that
purpose
,
"
replied
Dee
;
"
but
I
must
have
no
other
witness
to
the
experiment
except
yourself
,
and
my
attendant
Kelley
.
<EOS>
""I
do
not
desire
to
be
present
,
reverend
sir
,
"
<EOS>
replied
Viviana
;
"
but
I
will
retire
into
that
closet
,
and
pray
that
your
remedy
may
prevail
.
<EOS>
""My
prayers
for
the
same
end
shall
be
offered
in
the
adjoining
room
,
"
observed
Garnet
;
and
taking
Catesby
's
arm
,
who
seemed
spell
-
bound
by
curiosity
,
he
dragged
him
away
.
<EOS>
The
door
closed
,
and
Viviana
withdrew
into
the
closet
,
where
she
knelt
down
before
the
crucifix
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Dee
seated
himself
on
the
bedside
;
and
taking
a
gourd
-
shaped
bottle
,
filled
with
a
clear
sparkling
liquid
,
from
beneath
his
robe
,
he
raised
it
to
his
eyes
with
his
left
hand
,
while
he
placed
his
right
on
the
wrist
of
the
wounded
man
.
<EOS>
In
this
attitude
he
continued
for
a
few
seconds
,
while
Kelley
,
with
his
arms
folded
,
likewise
kept
his
gaze
fixed
on
the
phial
.
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
that
time
,
Dee
,
who
had
apparently
counted
the
pulsations
of
the
sufferer
,
took
out
the
glass
stopper
from
the
bottle
,
the
contents
of
which
diffused
a
pungent
odour
around
;
and
wetting
a
small
piece
of
linen
with
it
,
applied
it
to
his
temples
.
<EOS>
He
then
desired
Kelley
to
raise
his
head
,
and
poured
a
few
drops
down
his
throat
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
waited
a
few
minutes
,
and
repeated
the
application
.
<EOS>
"Look
!
"
he
cried
to
Kelley
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
elixir
already
begins
to
operate
.
<EOS>
His
chest
heaves
.
<EOS>
His
limbs
shiver
.
<EOS>
That
flush
upon
the
cheek
,
and
that
dampness
upon
the
brow
,
denote
that
the
animal
heat
is
restored
.
<EOS>
A
third
draught
will
accomplish
the
cure
.
<EOS>
""I
can
already
feel
his
heart
palpitate
,
"
observed
Kelley
,
placing
his
hand
on
the
patient
's
breast
.
<EOS>
"Heaven
be
praised
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Viviana
,
who
had
suspended
her
devotions
to
listen
.
<EOS>
"Hold
<EOS>
him
tightly
,
"
cried
Dee
to
his
assistant
,
"
while
I
administer
the
last
draught
.
<EOS>
He
may
injure
himself
by
his
struggles
.
<EOS>
"Kelley
<EOS>
obeyed
,
and
twined
his
arms
tightly
round
the
wounded
man
.
<EOS>
And
fortunate
it
was
that
the
precaution
was
taken
,
for
the
elixir
was
no
sooner
poured
down
his
throat
than
his
chest
began
to
labour
violently
,
his
eyes
opened
,
and
,
raising
himself
bolt
-
upright
,
he
struggled
violently
to
break
from
the
hold
imposed
upon
him
.
<EOS>
This
he
would
have
effected
,
if
Dee
had
not
likewise
lent
his
aid
to
prevent
him
.
<EOS>
"This
is
,
indeed
,
a
wonderful
sight
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
who
had
quitted
the
closet
,
and
now
gazed
on
,
in
awe
and
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
never
be
sufficiently
thankful
to
you
,
reverend
sir
.
<EOS>
""Give
<EOS>
thanks
to
Him
to
whom
alone
they
are
due
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
Summon
your
friends
.
<EOS>
They
may
now
resume
their
posts
.
<EOS>
My
task
is
accomplished
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
<EOS>
and
Garnet
being
called
into
the
room
,
could
scarcely
credit
their
senses
when
they
beheld
Guy
Fawkes
,
who

this

ceased

,
reclining
on

's

,
and
,
except
a
certain

in
the
eye
and

of
hue
,
looking
as
he
was
wo
nt
to

.
<EOS>
IllustrationXVI
.
<EOS>
—
THE
COLLEGIATE
CHURCH
AT
MANCHESTERBidding
Kelley
remain
with
Guy
Fawkes
,
Doctor
Dee
signified
to
Viviana
that
he
had
a
few
words
to
say
to
her
in
private
before
his
departure
,
and
leading
the
way
to
an
adjoining
room
,
informed
her
that
he
was
aware
of
her
desire
to
have
her
father
's
remains
interred
in
the
Collegiate
Church
,
and
that
,
so
far
from
opposing
her
inclinations
,
he
would
willingly
accede
to
them
,
only
recommending
as
a
measure
of
prudence
that
the
ceremonial
should
be
performed
at
night
,
and
with
as
much
secrecy
as
possible
.
<EOS>
Viviana
thanked
him
in
a
voice
of
much
emotion
for
his
kindness
,
and
entirely
acquiesced
in
his
suggestion
of
caution
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
she
could
not
help
expressing
her
surprise
that
her
thoughts
should
be
known
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
Though
,
indeed
,
"
she
added
,
"
after
the
wonderful
exhibition
I
have
just
witnessed
of
your
power
,
I
can
scarcely
suppose
that
any
limits
are
to
be
placed
to
it
.
<EOS>
""Few
<EOS>
things
are
hidden
from
me
,
"
replied
Dee
,
with
a
gratified
smile
;
"
even
the
lighter
matters
of
the
heart
,
in
which
I
might
be
supposed
to
take
little
interest
,
do
not
altogether
elude
my
observation
.
<EOS>
In
reference
to
this
,
you
will
not
,
I
am
sure
be
offended
with
me
,
Viviana
,
if
I
tell
you
I
have
noticed
with
some
concern
the
attachment
that
has
arisen
between
you
and
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
uttered
an
exclamation
of
surprise
,
and
a
deep
blush
suffused
her
pallid

.
<EOS>
"I
am
assuming
the
privilege
of
an
old
man
with
you
,
Viviana
,
"
continued
Dee
,
in
a
graver

,
"
and
I
may
add
,
of
an
old
friend,—for
<EOS>
your
lamented
mother
was
one
of
my
dearest
and
best
friends
,
as
you
perchance
called
to
mind
,
when
you
sent
me
to
-
day
,
by
Mr.
Catesby
,
the
token
I
gave
her
years
ago
.
<EOS>
You
have
done
unwisely
in
inviting
Humphrey
Chetham
to
come
hither
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
""How
<EOS>
so
?
<EOS>
"
she

.
<EOS>
"Because
,
if
he
keeps
his

,
fatal
consequences
may
ensue
,
"
answered
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
message
has
reached
the
ears
of
one
from
whom,—most
of
all,—you
should
have
concealed
it
.
<EOS>
""Mr
.
<EOS>
Catesby
has
heard
of
it
,
I
know
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
do
not
apprehend
any
danger
from
him?""He
is
Chetham
's
mortal
foe
,
"
rejoined
Dee
,
"
and
will
slay
him
,
if
he
finds

.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
alarm
me
,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
will
speak
to
Mr.
Catesby
on
the
subject
,
and
entreat
him
,
as
he
values
my
regard
,
to
offer
no

to

rival
.
<EOS>
""Fancied
rival
!
"
echoed
Dee
,
raising
his
brows

.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
seek
to
persuade
me
that
you
do
not
love
Humphrey
<EOS>
Chetham?""Assuredly
not
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
freely

my
attachment
to

.
<EOS>
It
is
as
strong
as
my
aversion
to
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
But
the
latter
is
aware
that
the
suit
of
his
rival
is
as

as
his
own
.
<EOS>
""Explain
<EOS>
yourself
,
I
pray
you
?
"
said
Dee
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
destiny
is
the
cloister,—and
this
he
well
knows
,
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
As
soon
as
my
worldly

can
be
arranged
,
I
shall
retire
to
the
English
nunnery
at
Brussels
,
where
I
shall
vow
myself
to
Heaven
.
<EOS>
""Such
is
your
present
intention
,
"
replied
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
never
quit
your
own
country
.
<EOS>
""What
shall
hinder
me
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Viviana
,

.
<EOS>
"Many
things
,
"
returned
Dee
.
"
<EOS>
Amongst
others
,
this

with
your

.
<EOS>
""Call
him
not
by
that
name
<EOS>
,
I
beseech

,

,
"
she

.
"
<EOS>
Humphrey
Chetham
will
never

other

than
a

.
<EOS>
""It
may
be
,
"
answered
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
But
your

is

.
<EOS>
""For
<EOS>
what
am
I
reserved
,

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
I
dare

,
"
he

,
"
<EOS>
all
it
is
needful
for

to
know
,
is
,
that
your
future

is
mixed

with

of
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
But
do
not
concern
yourself
about
what
is
to
come
.
<EOS>
The
present
is
sufficient
to
claim

.
<EOS>
""True
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
and
my
first
object
shall
be
to
despatch
a
messenger
to
Humphrey
Chetham
to
prevent
him
from
coming
hither
.
<EOS>
""Trouble
<EOS>
yourself
no
further
on
that
score
,
"

Dee
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
convey
the
message
to
him
.
<EOS>
As
regards
the
funeral
,
it
must
take
place
without
delay
.
<EOS>
I
will
be
at
the
south

of

with
the
keys
at
midnight
,
and
Robert
Burnell
,

,

another

on

,

.
<EOS>
Though

to

Romish

to

,

Father
Garnet
.
<EOS>
I
owe
your
mother
a

,
and
will

to
her

and
her

.
<EOS>
""Thanks!—in
<EOS>
her
name
,
thanks
!
"

Viviana
,
in
a

.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
now
,
"
continued
Dee
,
"
I
would

one

.
<EOS>
My
art
has
made
me
acquainted
that
a
plot
is
hatching
against
the
King
and
his
Government
by
certain

Catholic
party
.
<EOS>
Are
you
favourable
to
the

<EOS>
am
not
,
"

Viviana
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
can
you
regard

with
more

than

.
<EOS>
""I
was
sure

,
"

Dee
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
I
am
glad
to

confirmed
from

.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
moved
towards
the
door
,
but
Viviana
arrested

.
<EOS>
"Stay
,
reverend
sir
,
"
she
cried
,
with
a
look
of
great

;
"
if
you
are
in
possession
of
this
dread
secret
,
the
lives
of
my
companions
are
in
your
power
.
<EOS>
You
will
not
betray
them
.
<EOS>
Or
,
if
you
deem
it
your
duty
to
reveal
the
plot
to
those
endangered
by
it
,
you
will
give
its
contrivers
timely
warning
.
<EOS>
""Fear
nothing
,
"
rejoined
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
,
were
I
so
disposed
,
interfere
with
the
fixed
purposes
of
fate
.
<EOS>
The
things
revealed
by
my
familiar
spirits
never
pass
my
lips
.
<EOS>
They
are
more
sacred
than
the
disclosures
made
to
a
priest
of
your
faith
at
the
confessional
.
<EOS>
The
bloody
enterprise
on
which
these
zealots
are
bent
will
fail
.
<EOS>
I
have
warned
Fawkes
;
but
my
warning
,
though
conveyed
by
the
lips
of
the
dead
,
and
by
other
means
equally
terrible
,
was
unavailing
.
<EOS>
I
would
warn
Catesby
and
Garnet
,
but
they
would
heed
me
not
.
<EOS>
Viviana
Radcliffe
,
"
he
continued
,
in
a
solemn
voice
,
"
you
questioned
me
just
now
about
the
future
.
<EOS>
Have
you
courage
to
make
the
same
demand
from
your
dead
father
?
<EOS>
If
so
,
I
will
compel
his
corpse
to
answer
you
.
<EOS>
""Oh
!
<EOS>
no
—
no
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
horror
-
stricken
;
"
not
for
worlds
would
I
commit
so
impious
an
act
.
<EOS>
Gladly
as
I
would
know
what
fate
has
in
store
for
me
,
nothing
should
induce
me
to
purchase
the
knowledge
at
so
dreadful
a
price
.
<EOS>
""Farewell
,
then
,
"
rejoined
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
midnight
,
at
the
south
porch
of
the
Collegiate
Church
,
I
shall
expect
you
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
took
his

;
and
,
on
entering
the
gallery
,
he
perceived
Catesby
hastily

.
"Aha
!
"
<EOS>
he
muttered
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
had
a
listener
here
.
<EOS>
Well
,
no
matter
.
<EOS>
What
he
has
heard
may
prove
serviceable
to
him
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
then
returned
to
the
chamber
occupied
by
Guy
Fawkes
,
and
finding
he
had
dropped
into
a

,
motioned
Kelley
,
who
was

watching

with

,
to
follow
him
,
and
bowing

to
Garnet
quitted
the
hall
.
<EOS>
As
he
crossed
the
court
,
on
his
way
to
the
drawbridge
,
Catesby
suddenly
threw
himself
in
his
path
,
and
laying
his
hand
upon
his
sword
,
cried
in
a
menacing
voice,—"Doctor
Dee
,
<EOS>
neither
you
nor
your
companion
shall
quit
the
hall
till
you
have
solemnly
sworn
not
to
divulge
<EOS>
aught
pertaining
to
the
plot
,
of
which
you
have
so

.
<EOS>
""Is
<EOS>
this
<EOS>
my
recompence
for
rescuing
your
comrade
from
the
jaws
of
death
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
replied
Dee
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
necessity
of
the
case
must
plead
its
excuse
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
own
safety
,
and
the
safety
of
those
leagued
with
me
,
require
that
I
should
be
peremptory
in
my
demand
.
<EOS>
Did
I
not
owe
you
a
large
debt
of
gratitude
for
your
resuscitation
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
I
would
have
insured
your
secrecy
with
your
life
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
I
will
be
content
with
your
oath
.
<EOS>
""Fool
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Dee
,
"
stand
aside
,
or
I
will
compel
you
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
""Think
not
to
terrify
me
by
idle
threats
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
willingly
acknowledge
your
superior
skill,—as
,
indeed
,
I
have
good
reason
to
do,—in
the
science
of
medicine
;
but
I
have
no
faith
in
your
magical
tricks
.
<EOS>
A
little
reflection
has
shown
me
how
the
knowledge
I
at
first
thought
so
wonderful
was
acquired
.
<EOS>
You
obtained
it
by
means
of
Martin
Heydocke
,
who
,
mounted
on
a
swift
steed
,
reached
the
College
before
me
.
<EOS>
He
told
you
of
the
object
of
my
visit,—of
Viviana
's
wish
to
have
her
father
interred
in
the
Collegiate
Church,—of
her
message
to
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
You
were
,
therefore
,
fully
prepared
for
my
arrival
,
and
at
first
,
I
must
confess
,
completely
imposed
upon
me
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
had
I
not
overheard
your
conversation
just
now
with
Viviana
,
I
might
have
remained
your
dupe
still
.
<EOS>
But
your
allusion
to
Chetham
's
visit
awakened
my
suspicions
,
and
,
on
re
-
considering
the
matter
,
the
whole
trick
flashed
upon
me
.
<EOS>
""What
more
?
"
demanded
Dee
,
his
brow
lowering
,
and
his
eyes
sparkling
with
rage
.
<EOS>
"Thus
much
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
your
secret
,
and
you
have
mine
.
<EOS>
And
though
the
latter
is
the
more
important
,
inasmuch
as
several
lives
hang
upon
it
,
whereas
a
conjuror
's
worthless

is
alone

on

other
,
yet
both
must
be

.
<EOS>
Swear
,
then
,
not
to
reveal
the
plot
,
and
in
my
turn
I
will
take
any
oath
you
choose
to
dictate
not
to
disclose
the
jugglery
I
have
detected
.
<EOS>
""I
will
make
no
terms
with
you
,
"
returned
Dee
;
"
and
if
I
do
not
reveal
your
damnable
plot
,
it
is
not
from
consideration
of
you
or
your
associates
,
but
because
the
hour
for

disclosure
is
not

.
<EOS>
When
full
proof
of
your
guilt
can
be
obtained
,
then
rest
assured
it
will
be
made
known,—though
not
by
me
.
<EOS>
Not
one
of
your
number
shall
escape
—
not
one
.
"Catesby
<EOS>
again
laid
his
hand
upon
his
sword
,
and
seemed

Doctor

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"What
<EOS>
you
have
said

Martin
Heydocke
is

—

foul

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
neither

,

.
<EOS>
""But
<EOS>
your

,
Edward

,
has

"
retorted

,
"

.
<EOS>
""For
<EOS>
the

,
"

,
in

.
<EOS>
Catesby

.
<EOS>
"What
<EOS>
if
I

?
<EOS>
"
he

,
in

.
<EOS>
Doctor

;
but

,

in

's

.
<EOS>
Blinded

,

raised
his
hand
to

,
and
while
in
this

a

and

,
he
was
borne

,
and
bound

.
<EOS>
Half

hour
elapsed
,
during
which
he

his

in

,
and

Dee
and

.
<EOS>
At

,

he

,

Martin

.
<EOS>
"What
!
<EOS>
is

I

?
"
<EOS>
cried

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mercy

!
<EOS>
what

?
<EOS>
Have

rascally
searchers
been

your

,

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
shrewdly
suspect
,
"

,

and

,
and

shrewdly
suspect
,
"

,

,
which

from

demure

,
"
that
you
have

.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
I
,

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not

<EOS>
,
I

.
<EOS>
It
was
by

chance
<EOS>
I
came

,

,

,

,

I

's

,

.
<EOS>
""You

's

,
rascal
,

"

.
"
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
Ah

horse

.
<EOS>
Peradventure

.
<EOS>
""That

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
But

Dee
is

,
"

,
"
neither

serve

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Humphrey
Chetham
,
as
I

,

.
<EOS>
As

Doctor
,
he
left
the
hall
some
time
since
.
<EOS>
Father
Garnet
thought
you
had
accompanied
him
on

road
.
<EOS>
I

nothing
of

.
<EOS>
Of
a
truth
I
have
not
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
reflected

,

,
while
Martin
,
with
a
secret

,
picked

,

withdrew
to
the
stable
.
<EOS>
Repairing
to
the
chamber
of
the
wounded
man
,
Catesby
found
Garnet
seated
by
his

,
and
related
what
had
occurred
.
<EOS>
The
Jesuit
listened
with
profound
attention
to
the
recital
,
and
on
its

observed,—"I
am
sorry
you
have
offended
Doctor
Dee
,
my
son
.
<EOS>
He
might
have
proved
a
good
friend
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
you
have
made
him
a
dangerous
enemy
.
<EOS>
""He
was
not
to
be
trusted
,
father
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
But
if
you
have
any
fears
of
him
,
or
Kelley
,
I
will
speedily
set
them
at
rest
.
<EOS>
""No
violence
,
my
son
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
only
increase
the
mischief
you
have
already
occasioned
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
Dee
will
betray
us
.
<EOS>
But
additional
circumspection
will
be
requisite
.
<EOS>
Tarry
here
while
I
confer
with
Viviana
on
this
subject
.
<EOS>
She
has
apparently
some
secret
influence
with
the
Doctor
,
and
may
be
prevailed
upon
to
exert
it
in
our
behalf
.
<EOS>
"It
was
long
before
Garnet
returned
.
<EOS>
When
he
reappeared
,
his
looks
convinced
Catesby
that
the
interview
had
not
proved
satisfactory
.
<EOS>
"Your
<EOS>
imprudence
has
placed
us
in
a
perilous
position
,
my
son
,
"
he
observed
.
<EOS>
"
Viviana
refuses
to
speak
to
Doctor
Dee
on
the
subject
,
and
strongly

your
conduct
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
's
<EOS>
brow
lowered
.
<EOS>
"There
<EOS>
is
but
one
course
to
pursue
,
"
he
muttered
,
rising
;
"
our
lives
or
his
must
be
sacrificed
.
<EOS>
I
will
act
at
once
.
<EOS>
""Hold
!
"
exclaimed
Garnet
authoritatively
.
"
<EOS>
Wait
till
to
-
morrow
and
,
if
aught
occurs
in
the
interim
to
confirm
your
suspicions
,
do
as
you
think
proper
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
oppose
you
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
I
forbear
so
long
,
"
returned
Catesby
,
"
it
will
not
be
safe
to
remain

.
<EOS>
""I
will
risk
it
,
"
said
Garnet
,
"
and
I
counsel
you
to
do
the
same
.
<EOS>
You
will
not
leave
Viviana
at
this

.
<EOS>
""I
have
no
such

,
"

Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
go
,
she

.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
it
will
be
in

,
I

,
to

to
induce
her
to

till

is

,
"
observed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"True
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
"
I

forgotten

.
<EOS>
We
shall
meet
the
hoary

at
the
church
,
and
an

for

my

.
<EOS>
Unless
he
will
swear

the
altar
not

,
he

die

.
<EOS>
""An
oath
in
such
a
case
would
be
no
security
,
my
son
,
"
returned
Garnet
;
"
and
his
slaughter
and
that
of
his
companion
would
be
equally
inefficacious
,
and
greatly
prejudicial
to
our
cause
.
<EOS>
If
he
means
to
betray
us
,
he
has
done
so
already
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
little
apprehension
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
him
well
affected
towards
the
government
,
and
I
can
not
but
think
,
if
you
had
not
thus

him
,
he
would
have
favoured
rather

.
<EOS>
If
he
was
aware
of
the
plot
,
and

,
what
need
was

to
exert

in
behalf

,
<EOS>
who
,
but

,

have

,
ere
this
,

?
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
my
son
.
<EOS>
You
are
far
too

in
your
judgment
.
<EOS>
Nor
am
I
less
surprised
at
your

.
<EOS>
Overlooking
the
great
benefit
conferred
upon
us
,
because
some
trifling
scheme
has
been
thwarted
,
you
would
requite
our
benefactor
by
cutting
his

.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
rebuke
is
just
,

,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
acted
heedlessly
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
endeavour
to
repair
my
error
.
<EOS>
""Enough
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
advisable
to
go
well

to

to
-

,
for
fear

.
<EOS>
But
I
shall
not

on

.
<EOS>
""Nor
<EOS>
I
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
The
conversation
was
then
carried
on
,
on
other

,
when
they
were
interrupted
by
the
entrance
of
Viviana
,
who
came
to

about
the

.
<EOS>
It
was
arranged
—
since
better
could
not
