found
—
that
the
vehicle
used
to
bring
thither
the
body
of
the
unfortunate
knight
should
transport
it
to
its
last
home
.
<EOS>
No
persuasions
of
Garnet
could
induce
Viviana
to
relinquish
the
idea
of
attending
the
ceremony
;
and
Catesby
,
though
he
affected
the
contrary
,
secretly
rejoiced
at
her
determination
.
<EOS>
Night
came
,
and
all
was
in
readiness
.
<EOS>
Viviana
to
the
last
indulged
a
hope
that
Humphrey
Chetham
would
arrive
in
time
to
attend
the
funeral
with
her
;
but
,
as
he
did
not
appear
,
she
concluded
he
had
received
Doctor
Dee
's
warning
.
<EOS>
Martin
Heydocke
was
left
in
charge
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
still
continued
to
slumber
deeply
,
and
,
when
within
half
an
hour
of
the
appointed
time
,
the
train
set
out
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
well
mounted
,
and
proceeded
at
a
slow
pace
along
the
lane
skirting
the
west
bank
of
the
Irwell
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
profoundly
dark
;
and
,
as
it
was
not
deemed
prudent
to
carry
torches
,
some
care
was
requisite
to
keep
in
the
right
road
.
<EOS>
Catesby
rode
first
,
and
was
followed
by
Garnet
and
Viviana
,
after
whom
came
the
little
vehicle
containing
the
body
.
<EOS>
The
rear
was
brought
up
by
three
of
the
servants
sent
by
Sir
Everard
Digby
;
a
fourth
acting
as
driver
of
the
sorry
substitute
for
a
hearse
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
was
uttered
by
any
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
In
this
stealthy
manner
was
the
once
-
powerful
and
wealthy
Sir
William
Radcliffe
,
the
owner
of
the
whole
district
through
which
they
were
passing
,
conveyed
to
the
burial
-
place
of
his
ancestors!In
shorter
time
than
they
had
allowed
themselves
for
the
journey
,
the
melancholy
cavalcade
reached
Salford
Bridge
,
and
crossing
it
at
a
quick
pace
,
as
had
been
previously
arranged
by
Catesby
,
arrived
without
molestation
or
notice
(
for
no
one
<EOS>
was
abroad
in
the
town
at
that
hour
)
at
the
southern
gate
of
the
Collegiate
Church
<EOS>
,
where
,
it
may
be
remembered
,
Guy
Fawkes
had
witnessed
the
execution
of
the
two
seminary
priests
,
and
on
the
spikes
of
which
their
heads
and
dismembered
bodies
were
now
fixed
.
<EOS>
An
old
man
here
presented
himself
,
and
,
unlocking
the
gate
,
informed
them
<EOS>
he
was
Robert
Burnell
,
the
sexton
.
<EOS>
The
shell
was
then
taken
out
,
and
borne
on
the
shoulders
of
the
servants
towards
the
church
,
Burnell
leading
the
way
.
<EOS>
Garnet
followed
;
and
as
soon
as
Catesby
had
committed
the
horses
to
the
care
of
the
driver
of
the
carriage
,
he
tendered
his
arm
to
Viviana
,
who
could
scarcely
have
reached
the
sacred
structure
unsupported
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Dee
met
them
at
the
church
porch
,
as
he
had
appointed
,
and
,
as
soon
as
they
had
passed
through
it
,
the
door
was
locked
.
<EOS>
Addressing
a
few
words
in
an
under
tone
to
Viviana
,
but
not
deigning
to
notice
either
of
her
companions
,
Dee
directed
the
bearers
of
the
body
to
follow
him
,
and
proceeded
towards
the
choir
.
<EOS>
The
interior
of
the
reverend
and
beautiful
fane
was
buried
in
profound
gloom
,
and
the
feeble
light
diffused
by
the
sexton
's
lantern
only
made
the
darkness
more
palpable
.
<EOS>
On
entering
the
broad
and
noble
nave
nothing
could
be
seen
of
its
clustered
pillars
,
or
of
the
exquisite
pointed
arches
,
enriched
with
cinquefoil
and
quatrefoil
,
inclosing
blank
shields
,
which
they
supported
.
<EOS>
Neither
could
its
sculptured
cornice
;
its
clerestory
windows
;
its
upper
range
of
columns
,
supporting
demi
-
angels
playing
on
musical
instruments
;
its
moulded
roof
crossed
by
transverse
beams
,
enriched
in
the
interstices
with
sculptured
ornaments
,
be
distinguished
.
<EOS>
Most
of
these
architectural
glories
were
invisible
;
but
the
very
gloom
in
which
they
were
shrouded
was
imposing
.
<EOS>
As
the
dim
light
fell
upon
pillar
after
pillar
as
they
passed
,
revealing
their
mouldings
,
piercing
a
few
feet
into
the
side
aisles
,
and
falling
upon
the
grotesque
heads
,
the
embattled
ornaments
and
grotesque
tracery
of
the
arches
,
the
effect
was
inexpressibly
striking
.
<EOS>
Nor
were
the
personages
inappropriate
to
the
sombre
scene
.
<EOS>
The
reverend
figure
of
Dee
,
with
his
loose
flowing
robe
and
long
white
beard
;
the
priestly
garb
and
grave
aspect
of
Garnet
;
the
soldier
-
like
bearing
of
Catesby
,
his
armed
heel
and
rapier
-
point
clanking
upon
the
pavement
;
the
drooping
figure
of
Viviana
,
whose
features
were
buried
in
her
kerchief
,
and
whose
sobs
were
distinctly
audible
;
the
strangely
-
fashioned
coffin
,
and
the
attendants
by
whom
it
was
borne;—all
constituted
a
singular
,
and
,
at
the
same
time
,
deeply
-
interesting
picture
.
<EOS>
Approaching
the
magnificent
screen
terminating
the
nave
,
they
passed
through
an
arched
gateway
within
it
,
and
entered
the
choir
.
<EOS>
The
west
-
end
of
this
part
of
the
church
was
assigned
as
the
burial
-
place
of
the
ancient
and
honourable
family
,
the
head
of
which
was
about
to
be
deposited
within
it
,
and
was
designated
from
the
circumstance
,
the
"
Radcliffe
chancel
.
<EOS>
"
A
long
slab
of
grey
marble
,
in
which
a
brass
plate
,
displaying
the
armorial
bearings
of
the
Radcliffes
,
was
inserted
,
had
been
removed
,
and
the
earth
thrown
out
of
the
cavity
beneath
it
.
<EOS>
Kelley
,
who
had
assisted
in
making
the
excavation
,
was
standing
beside
it
,
leaning
on
a
spade
,
with
a
lantern
at
his
feet
.
<EOS>
He
drew
aside
as
the
funeral
train
approached
,
and
the
shell
was
deposited
at
the
edge
of
the
grave
.
<EOS>
Picturesque
and
striking
as
was
the
scene
in
the
nave
,
it
fell
far
short
of
that
now
exhibited
.
<EOS>
The
choir
of
the
Collegiate
Church
at
Manchester
may
challenge
comparison
with
any
similar
structure
.
<EOS>
Its
thirty
elaborately
-
carved
stalls
,
covered
with
canopies
of
the
richest
tabernacle
work
,
surmounted
by
niches
,
mouldings
,
pinnacles
,
and
perforated
tracery
,
and
crowned
with
a
richly
-
sculptured
cornice
;
its
side
aisles
,
with
their
pillars
and
arches
;
its
moulded
ceiling
rich
in
the
most
delicate
and
fairy
tracery
;
its
gorgeous
altar
-
screen
of
carved
oak
;
and
its
magnificent
eastern
window
,
then
filled
with
stained
glass
,
form
a
coup
-
d'oeil
of
almost
unequalled
splendour
and
beauty
.
<EOS>
Few
of
these
marvels
could
now
be
seen
.
<EOS>
But
such
points
of
the
pinnacles
and
hanging
canopies
of
the
stalls
,
of
the
façades
of
the
side
-
aisles
,
and
of
the
fretted
roof
,
as
received
any
portion
of
the
light
,
came
in
with
admirable
effect
.
<EOS>
"All
is
prepared
,
you
perceive
,
"
observed
Dee
to
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
retire
while
the
ceremony
is
performed
.
"
<EOS>
And
gravely
inclining
his
head
,
he
passed
through
an
arched
door
in
the
south
aisle
,
and
entered
the
chapter
-
house
.
<EOS>
Garnet
was
about
to
proceed
with
the
service
appointed
by
the
Romish
Church
for
the
burial
of
the
dead
,
when
Viviana
,
uttering
a
loud
cry
,
would
have
fallen
,
if
Catesby
had
not
flown
to
her
assistance
,
and
borne
her
to
one
of
the
stalls
.
<EOS>
Recovering
her
self
-
possession
the
next
moment
,
she
entreated
him
to
leave
her
;
and
while
the
service
proceeded
,
she
knelt
down
and
prayed
fervently
for
the
soul
of
the
departed
.
<EOS>
Placing
himself
at
the
foot
of
the
body
,
Garnet
sprinkled
it
with
holy
water
,
which
he
had
brought
with
him
in
a
small
silver
consecrated
vessel
.
<EOS>
He
then
recited
the
De
Profundis
,
the
Miserere
,
and
other
antiphons
and
prayers
;
placed
incense
in
a
burner
,
which
he
had
likewise
brought
with
him
,
and
having
lighted
it
,
bowed
reverently
towards
the
altar
,
sprinkled
the
body
thrice
with
holy
water
,
at
the
sides
,
at
the
head
,
and
the
feet
;
and
then
walking
round
it
with
the
incense
-
burner
,
dispersed
its
fragrant
odour
over
it
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
recited
another
prayer
,
pronounced
a
solemn
benediction
over
the
place
of
sepulture
,
and
the
body
was
lowered
into
it
.
<EOS>
The
noise
of
the
earth
falling
upon
the
shell
aroused
Viviana
from
her
devotions
.
<EOS>
She
looked
towards
the
grave
,
but
could
see
nothing
but
the
gloomy
group
around
it
,
<EOS>
prominent
among
which
appeared
the
tall
figure
of
Catesby
.
<EOS>
The
sight
was
too
much
for
her
,
and
,
unable
to
control
her
grief
,
she
fainted
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
grave
was
rapidly
filled
,
all
lending
their
aid
to
the
task
;
and
nothing
was
wanting
but
to
restore
the
slab
to
its
original
position
.
<EOS>
By
the
united
efforts
of
Catesby
,
Kelley
,
and
the
sexton
,
this
was
soon
accomplished
,
and
the
former
,
unaware
of
what
had
happened
,
was
about
to
proceed
to
Viviana
,
to
tell
her
all
was
over
,
when
he
was
arrested
by
a
loud
knocking
at
the
church
door
,
accompanied
by
a
clamorous
demand
for
admittance
.
<EOS>
"We
are
betrayed
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
as
I
suspected
.
<EOS>
Take
care
of
Viviana
,
father
.
<EOS>
I
will
after
the
hoary
impostor
,
and
cleave
his
skull
!
<EOS>
Extinguish
the
lights
—
quick
!
<EOS>
quick!"Garnet
hastily
complied
with
these
injunctions
,
and
the
choir
was
plunged
in
total
darkness
.
<EOS>
He
then
rushed
to
the
stalls
,
but
could
nowhere
find
Viviana
.
<EOS>
He
called
her
by
name
,
but
received
no
answer
,
and
was
continuing
his
fruitless
search
,
when
he
heard
footsteps
approaching
,
and
the
voice
of
Catesby
exclaimed,"Follow
me
with
your
charge
,
father
.
<EOS>
""Alas
!
<EOS>
my
son
,
she
is
not
here
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
searched
each
stall
as
carefully
as
I
could
in
the
dark
.
<EOS>
I
fear
she
has
been
spirited
away
.
""Impossible
!
"
cried
Catesby
.
<EOS>
And
he
ran
his
hand
along
the
row
of
sculptured
seats
,
but
without
success
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
indeed
gone
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
distractedly
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
here
I
left
her
—
<EOS>
nay
,
here
I
beheld
her
at
the
very
moment
the
lights
were
extinguished
.
<EOS>
Viviana!—Viviana!"But
all
was
silent
.
<EOS>
"It
<EOS>
is
that
cursed
magician
's
handiwork
!
"
<EOS>
he
continued
,
striking
his
forehead
in
despair
.
<EOS>
"Did
<EOS>
you
find
him
?
"
demanded
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"No
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
The
door
of
the
chapter
-
house
was
locked
inside
.
<EOS>
The
treacherous
villain
did
well
to
guard
against
my
fury
.
<EOS>
""You
provoked
his
resentment
,
my
son
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
.
"
<EOS>
But
this
is
not
a
season
for
reproaches
.
<EOS>
Something
must
be
done
.
<EOS>
Where
is
Kelley?"At
<EOS>
the
suggestion
,
Catesby
instantly
darted
to
the
spot
where
the
seer
had
stood
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
there
.
<EOS>
He
then
questioned
the
servants
,
whose
teeth
were
chattering
with
fright
,
but
they
had
neither
heard
him
depart
,
nor
could
tell
anything
about
him
;
and
perceiving
plainly
from
their

that
these
men
would

,
even
if
they
did
not
join
the
assailants
,
he
returned
to
communicate
his
apprehensions
to
Garnet
.
<EOS>
During
all
this
time
the
knocking
and
vociferations
at
the
door
had
continued
with
increased
violence
,
and
reverberated
in
hollow
peals
along
the
roof
and
aisles
of
the
church
.
<EOS>
The
emergency
was
a
fearful
one
.
<EOS>
Catesby
,
however
,
had
been
too
often
placed
in
situations
of
peril
,
and
was
too
constitutionally
brave
,
to
experience
much
uneasiness
for
himself
;
but
his
apprehensions
lest
Garnet
should
be
captured
,
and
the
sudden
and
mysterious
disappearance
of
Viviana
almost
distracted
him
.
<EOS>
Persuading
himself
she
might
have
fallen
to
the
ground
,
or
that
he
had
overlooked
the
precise
spot
where
he
had
left
her
,
he
renewed
his
search
,
but
with
no
better
success
than
before
;
and
he
was
almost
beginning
to
believe
that
some
magic
might
have
been
practised
to
cause
her
disappearance
,
when
it
occurred
to
him
that
she
had
been
carried
off
by
Kelley
.
<EOS>
"Fool
<EOS>
that
I
was
,
not
to
think
of
that
before
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
unintentionally
aided
their
project
by
extinguishing
the
lights
.
<EOS>
But
now
that
I
am
satisfied
she
is
gone
,
I
can
devote
my
whole
energies
to
the
preservation
of
Garnet
.
<EOS>
They
shall
not
capture
us
so
easily
as
they
anticipate
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
approached
the
priest
,
and
grasping
his
hand
drew
him
noislessly
along
.
<EOS>
They
had
scarcely
passed
through
the
arched
doorway
in
the
screen
,
and
set
foot
within
the
nave
,
when
the
clamour
without
ceased
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
a
thundering
crash
was
heard
;
the
door
burst
open
,
and
a
number
of
armed
figures
bearing
torches
,
with
drawn
swords
in
their
hands
,
rushed
with
loud
vociferations
into
the
church
.
<EOS>
"We
must
surrender
,
my
son
,
"
cried
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
useless
to
contend
against
that
force
.
<EOS>
""But
<EOS>
we
may
yet
escape
them
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
And
glancing
hastily
round
he
perceived
a
small
open
door
in
the
wall
at
the
right
,
and
pointing
it
out
to
the
priest
,
hurried
towards
it
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
it
,
they
found
it
communicated
with
a
flight
of
stone
steps
,
evidently
leading
to
the
roof
.
"Saved
!
<EOS>
saved
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
triumphantly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mount
first
,
father
.
<EOS>
I
will
defend
the
passage
.
<EOS>
"The
pursuers
,
who
saw
the
course
taken
by
the
fugitives
,
set
up
a
loud
shout
,
and
ran
as
swiftly
as
they
could
in
the
same
direction
,
and
by
the
time
the
latter
had
gained
the
door
they
were
within
a
few
yards
of
it
.
<EOS>
Garnet
darted
up
the
steps
;
but
Catesby
lingered
to
make
fast
the
door
,
and
thus
oppose
some
obstacle
to
the
hostile
party
.
<EOS>
His
efforts
,
however
,
were
unexpectedly
checked
,
and
,
on
examination
,
he
found
it
was
hooked
to
the
wall
at
the
back
.
<EOS>
Undoing
the
fastening
,
the
door
swung
to
,
and
he
instantly
bolted
it
.
<EOS>
Overjoyed
at
his
success
,
and
leaving
his
pursuers
,
who
at
this
moment
arrived
,
to
vent
their
disappointment
in
loud
menaces
,
he
hastened
after
Garnet
.
<EOS>
Calling
loudly
to
him
,
he
was
answered
from
a
small
dark
chamber
on
the
right
,
into
which
the
priest
had
retreated
.
<EOS>
"We
<EOS>
have
but
prolonged
our
torture
,
"
groaned
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
find
no
outlet
.
<EOS>
Our
foes
will
speedily
force
an
entrance
,
and
we
must
then
fall
into
their
hands
.
<EOS>
""There
must
be
some
door
opening
upon
the
roof
,
father
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
Mount
as
high
as
you
can
,
and
search
carefully
.
<EOS>
I
will
defend
the
stairs
,
and
will
undertake
to
maintain
my
post
against
the
whole
rout
.
<EOS>
"Thus
urged
,
Garnet
ascended
the
steps
.
<EOS>
After
the
lapse
of
a
few
minutes
,
during
which
the
thundering
at
the
door
below
increased
,
and
the
heavy
blows
of
some
weighty
implement
directed
against
it
,
were
distinctly
heard
,
he
cried,"I
have
found
a
door
,
but
the
bolts
are
rusty
—
I
can
not
move
them
.
<EOS>
""Use
<EOS>
all
your
strength
,
father
,
"
shouted
Catesby
,
who
having
planted
himself
with
his
drawn
sword
at
an
advantageous
point
,
was
listening
with
intense
anxiety
to
the
exertions
of
the
assailing
party
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
relax
your
efforts
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
""It
is
in
vain
,
my
son
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
,
in
accents
of
despair
.
<EOS>
"
My
hands
are
bruised
and
bleeding
,
but
the
bolts
stir
not
.
<EOS>
""Distraction
!
"
cried
Catesby
,
gnashing
his
teeth
with
rage
.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
try
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
he
was
about
to
hasten
to
the
priest
's
assistance
,
when
the
door
below
was
burst
open
with
a
loud

,
and
the
assailants
rushed
up
the
steps
.
<EOS>
The
passage
was
so
narrow
that
they
were
compelled
to
mount
singly
,
and
Catesby
's
was
scarcely
a
vain

when
he
said
he
could
maintain
his
ground
against
the
whole
host
.
<EOS>
Shouting
to
Garnet
to
renew
his
efforts
,
he
prepared
for
the

.
<EOS>
Reserving
his
petronels
to

last
,
he
trusted
solely
to

,
and

against

newel
,
or

round
which

stairs

,
he
was
in
a

from
the
weapons
of
his

,
while
they
were
completely
exposed
to
his
attack
.
<EOS>
The
darkness
,
moreover
,
in
which
he
was
enveloped
offered
an
additional
protection
,
whereas
the
torches
they
carried
made
his
mark
certain
.
<EOS>
As

the
foremost
of
the
band
came
within

,
Catesby
plunged
his
sword
into
his

,
and
pushed
him
back
with
all
his
force
upon
his
comrades
.
<EOS>
The
man
fell
heavily
backwards
,
dislodging
the
next
in
advance
,
who
in
his
turn
upset
his
successor
,
and
so
on
,
till
the
whole

was

into

.
<EOS>
A
discharge
of
fire
-
arms
followed
;
but
,

by
the
newel
,
Catesby
sustained
no
injury
.
<EOS>
At
this

,
he
was
cheered
by
a
cry
from
Garnet
that
he
had
succeeded
in
forcing
back

,
terror
having
supplied

with

not
his

;
and
,
making
another

upon
his

,
amid
the
disorder
that

,
Catesby
retreated
,
and
rapidly
tracking
the
steps
,
reached
the
door
,
through
which
the
priest
had
already
passed
.
<EOS>
When
within
a
short
distance
of
the
outlet
,
Catesby
felt
,
from
the
current
of
fresh
air
that
saluted
him
,
that
it
opened
upon
the
roof
of
the
church
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
he
deceived
.
<EOS>
A
few
steps
placed
him
upon
the
leads
,
where
he
found
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"It
is
you
,
my
son
,
"
cried
the
latter
,
on
beholding

;
"
I
thought
from
the

you
had
fallen
into
the
hands
of

.
<EOS>
""No
,
Heaven
be
praised
!
<EOS>
I
am
as
yet
safe
,
and
trust
to
deliver
you
out
of
their
hands
.
<EOS>
Come
with
me
to
the

.
<EOS>
""The
battlements
!
"
exclaimed
Garnet
.
"
<EOS>
A
leap
from
such
a
height
as
that
were
certain
destruction
.
<EOS>
""It
were
so
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
dragging
him
along
.
"
<EOS>
But
trust
to
me
,
and
you
shall
yet
reach
the
ground
uninjured
.
<EOS>
"Arrived
<EOS>
at
the
battlements
,
Catesby
leaned
over
them
,
and
endeavoured
to
ascertain
what
was
beneath
.
<EOS>
It
was
still
so
dark
that
he
could
scarcely
discern
any

but
those
close
to

,
but
as

,

a

some

;
and

the
church
,
which

,
he
remembered
its
chantries
,
and
had
no
doubt
<EOS>
but
it
was
the
roof
of
one
of
them
that
he
beheld
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
reach
it
,
the
descent
from
thence
would
be
easy
,
and
he
immediately
communicated
the
idea
to
Garnet
,
who
shrank
aghast
from

.
<EOS>
Little
time
,
however
,
was
allowed
for
consideration
.
<EOS>
Their
pursuers
had
already
scaled
the
stairs
,
and
were
springing
one
after
another
upon
the
leads
,
uttering
the
most

against
the

of

.
<EOS>
Hastily
divesting
himself
of
his

,
Catesby
clambered
over
the
battlements
,
and
,
impelled
by
fear
,
Garnet
threw
off
his
robe
,
and
followed
his
example
.
<EOS>
Clinging
to
the
grotesque
stone

which
projected
below
the

,
and
placing
the
points
of

upon

of

,
and
thence
upon

and

,
Catesby
descended
in
safety
,
and
then
turned
to
assist
his
companion
,
who
was
quickly
by

side
.
<EOS>
The
most
difficult
and
dangerous
part
of
the
descent
had
yet
to
be

.
<EOS>
They
were
now
nearly
thirty
feet
from
the
ground
,
and
the
same
irregularities
in
the
walls
which
had
favoured
them
in
the
upper
structure
did
not
exist
in
the
lower
.
<EOS>
But
their
present
position
,
exposed
as
it
was
to

,
who
,
having
reached
the
point
immediately
overhead
,
were
preparing
to
fire
upon
them
,
was
too
dangerous
to
allow
of
its
occupation
for
a

,
and
Garnet
required
no
urging
to
make
him
clamber
over
the
low

.
<EOS>
Descending
a
flying
buttress
that
defended
an
angle
of
the
building
,
Catesby
,
who
was
possessed
of
great
strength
and
activity
,
was
almost
instantly
upon
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Garnet
was
not
so
fortunate
.
<EOS>
Missing
his
footing
,
he
fell
from
a
considerable
height
,
and
his
groans
proclaimed
that
he
had
received
some
serious
injury
.
<EOS>
Catesby
instantly
flew
to
him
,
and
demanded
,
in
a
tone
of
the
greatest
anxiety
,
whether
he
was
much
hurt
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
right
arm
is
broken
,
"
gasped
the
sufferer
,
raising

with
difficulty
.
<EOS>
"
What
other
injuries
I
have
sustained
I
know
not
;
but
every
joint
seems
dislocated
,
and
my
face
is
covered
with
blood
.
<EOS>
Heaven
have
pity
on
me!"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
a
shout
of
exultation
arose
from
the
hostile
party
,
who
,
having
heard
Garnet
's
fall
,
and
the
groans
that
succeeded
it
,
at
once
divined
the
cause
,
and
made
sure
of
a
capture
.
<EOS>
A
deep
silence
followed
,
proving
that
they
had
quitted
the
roof
,
and
were
hastening
to
secure
their
prey
.
<EOS>
Aware
that
it
would
take
them
some
little
time
to
descend
the
winding
staircase
,
and
traverse
the
long
aisle
of
the
church
,
Catesby
felt
certain
of
distancing
them
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
not
abandon
Garnet
,
who
had
become
insensible
from
the
agony
of
his
fractured
limb
,
and
,
lifting
him
carefully
in
his
arms
,
he
placed
him
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
started
at
a
swift
pace
towards
the
further
extremity
of
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
At
the
period
of
this
history
,
the
western
boundary
of
the
Collegiate
Church
was
formed
by
a
precipitous
sandstone
rock
of
great
height
,
the
base
of
which
was
washed
by
the
waters
of
the
Irwell
,
while
its
summit
was
guarded
by
a
low
stone
wall
.
<EOS>
In
after
years
,
a
range
of
small
habitations
was
built
upon
this
spot
,
but
they
have
been
recently
removed
,
and
the
rock
having
been
lowered
,
a
road
now
occupies
their
site
.
<EOS>
Nerved
by
desperation
,
Catesby
,
who
was
sufficiently
well
acquainted
with
the
locality
to
know
whither
he
was
shaping
his
course
,
determined
to
hazard
a
descent
,
which
,
under
calmer
circumstances
,
he
would
have
deemed
wholly
impracticable
.
<EOS>
His
pursuers
,
who
issued
from
the
church
porch
a
few
seconds
after
he
had
passed
it
,
saw
him
hurry
towards
the
low
wall
edging
the
precipice
,
and
,
encumbered
as
he
was
with
the
priest
,
vault
over
it
.
<EOS>
Not
deeming
it
possible
he
would
dare
to
spring
from
such
a
height
,
they
darted
after
him
.
<EOS>
But
they
were
deceived
,
and
could
scarcely
credit
their
senses
when
they
found
him
gone
.
<EOS>
By
the
light
of
their
torches
they
perceived
him
shooting
down
the
almost
perpendicular
side
of
the
rock
,
and
the
next
moment
a
hollow
plunge
told
that
he
had
reached
the
water
.
<EOS>
They
stared
at
each
other
in
mute
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"Will
<EOS>
you
follow
him
,
Dick
Haughton
?
<EOS>
"
observed
one
,
as
soon
as
he
had
recovered
his
speech
.
<EOS>
"Not
<EOS>
I
,
"
replied
the
fellow
addressed
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
fancy
for
a
broken
neck
.
<EOS>
Follow
him
thyself
if
thou
hast
a
mind
to
try
the
soundness
of
thy
pate
.
<EOS>
I
warrant
that
rock
will
put
it
to
the
proof
.
<EOS>
""Yet
<EOS>
the
feat
has
just
been
done
,
and
by
one
burthened
with
a
wounded
comrade
into
the
bargain
,
"
remarked

first

.
<EOS>
"He
must
be
the
devil
<EOS>
,
that
's
certain
,
"
rejoined

;
"
and
Doctor
Dee
himself
is
no
match
for

.
<EOS>
""He
has
the
Devil
's
luck
,
that
's
certain
,
"
cried

third

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
hark
!
<EOS>
he
is
swimming
across
the
river
.
<EOS>
We
may
yet
catch
him
on
the
opposite
bank
.
<EOS>
Come
along
,
comrades
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
they
rushed
out
of
the
churchyard
;
made
the
best
of
their
way
to
the
bridge
;
and
crossing

,
flew
to
the
bank
of
the
river
,
where
they
dispersed
in
every

,
in
search
for
the
fugitive
.
<EOS>
But
they
could
not
discover
a
trace
of
him
or
his
wounded

.
<EOS>
XVII
.
<EOS>
—
THE
RENCOUNTERCatesby
himself
could
scarcely
tell
how
he
accomplished
his
hair
-
breadth
escape
.
<EOS>
Reckless
almost
of
the
result
,
he
slided
down
the
rock
,
catching
at
occasional
irregularities
as
he
descended
.
<EOS>
The
river
was
of
great
depth
at
this
point
,
and
broke
the
force
of
his
fall
.
<EOS>
On
rising
,
he
struck
out
a
few
yards
,
and
suffered
himself
to
be
carried
down
the
stream
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
for
one
moment
relinquished
his
hold
of
Garnet
,
and
being
an
admirable
swimmer
,
found
little
difficulty
in
sustaining
him
with
one
arm
,
while
with
the
other
he
guided
his
course
in
the
water
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
he
reached
the
shore
in
safety
,
about
a
hundred
yards
below
the
bridge
,
by
which
means
he
avoided
his
pursuers
,
who
,
as
has
just
been
stated
,
searched
for
him
above
it
.
<EOS>
After
debating
with
himself
for
a
short
time
as
to
what
course
he
should
pursue
,
he
decided
upon
conveying
Garnet
to
the
Hall
,
where
he
could
procure
restoratives
and
assistance
;
and
though
he
was
fully
sensible
of
the
danger
of
this
plan
,
not
doubting
the
mansion
would
be
visited
and
searched
by
his
pursuers
before
morning
,
yet
the
necessity
of
warning
Guy
Fawkes
outweighed
every
other
consideration
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
again
shouldering
the
priest
,
who
,
though
he
had
regained
his
sensibility
,
was
utterly
unable
to
move
,
he
commenced
his
toilsome
march
;
and
being
frequently
obliged
to
pause
and
rest
himself
,
more
than
an
hour
elapsed
before
he
reached
his
destination
.
<EOS>
It
was
just
growing
light
as
he
crossed
the
drawbridge
,
and
seeing
a
horse
tied
to
a
tree
,
and
the
gate
open
,
he
began
to
fear
the
enemy
had
preceded
him
.
<EOS>
Full
of
misgiving
,
he
laid
Garnet
upon
a
heap
of
straw
in
an
outbuilding
,
and
entered
the
house
.
<EOS>
He
found
no
one
below
,
though
he
glanced
into
each
room
.
<EOS>
He
then
noiselessly
ascended
the
stairs
,
with
the
intention
of
proceeding
to
Guy
Fawkes
's
chamber
.
<EOS>
As
he
traversed
the
gallery
,
he
heard
voices
in
one
of
the
chambers
,
the
door
of
which
was
ajar
,
and
pausing
to
listen
,
distinguished
the
tones
of
Viviana
.
<EOS>
Filled
with
astonishment
,
he
was
about
to
enter
the
room
to
inquire
by
what
means
she
had
reached
the
Hall
,
when
he
was
arrested
by
the
voice
of
her
companion
.
<EOS>
It
was
that
of
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
Maddened
by
jealousy
,
Catesby
's
first
impulse
was
to
rush
into
the
room
,
and
stab
his
rival
in
the
presence
of
his
mistress
.
<EOS>
But
he
restrained
his
passion
by
a
powerful
effort
.
<EOS>
After
listening
for
a
few
minutes
intently
to
their
conversation
,
he
found
that
Chetham
was
taking
leave
,
and
creeping
softly
down
-
stairs
,
stationed
himself
in
the
hall
,
through
which
he
knew
his
rival
must
necessarily
pass
.
<EOS>
Chetham
presently
appeared
.
<EOS>
His
manner
was
dejected
;
his
looks
downcast
;
and
he
would
have
passed
Catesby
without
observing
him
,
if
the
latter
had
not
laid
his
hand
upon
his
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"Mr
.
<EOS>
Catesby
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
young
merchant
,
starting
as
he
beheld
the
stern
glance
fixed
upon
him
<EOS>
"
I
thought——""You
thought
I
was
a
prisoner
,
no
doubt
,
"
interrupted
Catesby
,
bitterly
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
mistaken
.
<EOS>
I
am
here
to
confound
you
and
your
juggling
and
treacherous
associate
.
<EOS>
""I
do
not
understand
you
,
"
replied
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"I
will
soon
make
myself
intelligible
,
"
retorted
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
Follow
me
to
the
garden
.
<EOS>
""I
perceive
your
purpose
,
Mr.
Catesby
,
"
replied
Chetham
,
calmly
;
"
but
it
is
no
part
of
my
principles
to
expose
my
life
to
ruffianly
violence
.
<EOS>
If
you
choose
to
lay
aside
this
insolent

,
which
is
more

an
Alsatian
bully
than
a
gentleman
,
I
will
readily
give
you
such
explanation
of
my
conduct
as
will
fully

,
and
satisfy
you
that
any

unfounded
.
<EOS>
""Coward
!
"
exclaimed
Catesby
,
striking
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
want
no
explanation
.
<EOS>
Defend
yourself
,
or
I
will
treat
you
with
still

.
<EOS>
""Lead
<EOS>
on
,
then
,
"
cried
Chetham
:
"
<EOS>
I
would
have
avoided
the
quarrel
if
I
could
.
<EOS>
But
this
outrage
shall
not
pass
unpunished
.
<EOS>
"As
they
quitted
the
hall
,
Viviana
entered
it
;
and
,
though
she
was
greatly
surprised
by
the
appearance
of
Catesby
,
his
furious
gestures
left
her
in
no
doubt
as
to
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
She
called
to
him
to
stop
.
<EOS>
But
no
attention
was
paid
by
either

to
her
cries
.
<EOS>
IllustrationOn
gaining
a
retired
spot
beneath
the
trees
,
Catesby
,
without
giving
his
antagonist
time
to
divest
himself
of
the
heavy
horseman
's
cloak
with
which
he
was
encumbered
,
and
scarcely
to
draw
his
sword
,
assaulted
him
.
<EOS>
The
combat
was
furious
on
both
sides
,
but
it
was
evident
that
the
young
merchant
was
no
match
for
his
adversary
.
<EOS>
He
maintained
his
ground
,
however
,
for
some

with
great
resolution
;
but
,
being
hotly
pressed
,
in
retreating
to
avoid
a
thrust
,
his
foot
caught
in
the
long
grass
,
and
he
fell
.
<EOS>
Catesby
would
have
passed
his
sword
through
his
body
,
if
it
had
not
been
turned
aside
by
another
weapon
.
<EOS>
It
was
that
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
,
followed
by
Martin
Heydocke
,
had
staggered
towards
the
scene
of
strife
,
reaching
it
just
in
time
to
save
the
life
of
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"Heaven
be
praised
!
<EOS>
I
am
not
too
late
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
<EOS>
"
Put
up
your
blade
,
Catesby
;
or
,
turn
it
against
me
.
"XVIII
.
<EOS>
—
THE
EXPLANATIONUttering
an
exclamation
of
rage
<EOS>
,
Catesby
turned
fiercely
upon
Fawkes
,
and
for
a
moment
appeared
disposed
to
accept
his
invitation
to
continue
the
combat
with
him
.
<EOS>
But
as
he
regarded
the
other
's
haggard
features
,
and
perceived
in
them
the
traces
of
his
recent
struggle
with
death
—
as
he
saw
he
was
scarcely
able
to
wield
the
blade
he
opposed
against
him
—
his
wrath
changed
to
compassion
,
and
he
sheathed
his
sword
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
Humphrey
Chetham
had
sprung
to
his
feet
,
and
picking
up
his
fallen
weapon
,
stood
on
his
defence
.
<EOS>
But
finding
that
Catesby
meditated
no
further
hostilities
,
he
returned
it
to
the
scabbard
.
<EOS>
"I
owe
my
life
to
you
,
"
he
said
to
Guy
Fawkes
,
in
a
tone
of
deep
gratitude
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
owe
it
to
Viviana
Radcliffe
,
not
to
me
,
"
returned
Fawkes
feebly
,
and
leaning
upon
his
sword
for
support
.
"
<EOS>
Had
it
not
been
for
her
cries
,
I
should
have
known
nothing
of
this
quarrel
.
<EOS>
And
I
would
now
gladly
learn
what
has
occasioned
it
.
<EOS>
""So
<EOS>
would
I
,
"
added
Chetham
;
"
for
I
am
as

as
yourself

how
I
have
offended
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
""I
will
tell
you
,
then
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
were
a
party
to
the
snare
set
for
us
by
Dr.
Dee
,
from
which
I
narrowly
escaped
with

,
and
Father
Garnet
at

.
<EOS>
""Is
Garnet
hurt
?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"Grievously
,
"

<EOS>
;
"

"

.
<EOS>
""I
am

,
"

,
"
having

,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
But
Humphrey

folded

,

,

.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
by
Martin
Heydocke
,
and
presently
afterwards
the

of
his
horse
's
feet
was
heard
crossing
the

.
<EOS>
XIX
.
<EOS>
—
THE
DISCOVERYTendering
his
arm
to
Fawkes
,
who
was
almost
too
feeble
to
walk
unsupported
,
Catesby
led
him
slowly
to
the
Hall
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
it
,
they
met
Viviana
,
in
a
state
bordering
upon
distraction
,
but
her
distress
was
speedily
relieved
by
their
assurances
that
the
young
merchant
had
departed
unhurt,—a
statement
immediately
afterwards
confirmed
by
the
entrance
of
Martin
Heydocke
,
charged
with
a
message
from
his
master
to
her
.
<EOS>
Without
communicating
his
design
to
the
others
,
and
,
indeed
,
almost
shunning
Viviana
,
Catesby
proceeded
to
the
outbuilding
where
he
had
deposited
Garnet
.
<EOS>
He
found
him
in
great
pain
,
and
praying
fervently
to
be
released
from
his
suffering
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
not
despair
,
father
,
"
said
Catesby
,
in
as
cheerful
a
tone
as
he
could
assume
,
"
the
worst
is
over
.
<EOS>
Viviana
is
in
safety
.
<EOS>
Father
Oldcorne
has
escaped
,
and
is
within
a
short
distance
of
us
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
is
fully
able
to
undertake
a
journey
of
any
distance
.
<EOS>
You
are
our
sole
concern
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
assured
,
if
you
will
allow
me
to
exercise
the
slight
surgical
skill
I
possess
in
your
behalf
,
that
you
will
be
able
to
accompany
us
.
<EOS>
""Do
with
me
what
you
please
,
my
son
,
"
groaned
Garnet
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
if
my
case
is
as
desperate
as
I
believe
it
,
I
entreat
you
not
to
bestow
any
further
care
upon
me
,
and
,
above
all
,
not
to
expose
yourself
to
risk
on
my
account
.
<EOS>
Our
enemies
are
sure
to
pursue
us,—and
what
matter
if
I
am
captured
?
<EOS>
They
will
wreak
their
vengeance
on
a
worthless
carcass,—for
<EOS>
such
I
shall
soon
be
.
<EOS>
But
it
would
double
the
anguish
I
now
endure
,
if
you
and
Fawkes
were
to
fall
into
their
hands
.
<EOS>
Go
,
then
,
and
leave
me
here
to
perish
.
<EOS>
My
dying
moments
will
be
cheered
by
the
conviction
that
the
great
enterprise
—
for
which
alone
I
desire
to
live
—
will
not
be
unaccomplished
.
<EOS>
""There
is
no
need
to
leave
you
,
father
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
"
nor
shall
any
consideration
induce
me
to
do
so
,
till
I
have
rendered
you
every
aid
that
circumstances
will
permit
.
<EOS>
""My
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
faintly
,
"
the
most
efficacious
balm
you
can
apply
will
be
the
certainty
that
you
are
in
safety
.
<EOS>
You
say
Viviana
is
here
.
<EOS>
Fly
with
Fawkes
,
and
leave
me
to
her
care
.
<EOS>
""She
must
go
with
us
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
uneasily
.
"Not
<EOS>
so
,
my
son
,
"
returned
Garnet
;
"
her
presence
will
only
endanger
you
.
<EOS>
She
must
not
go
.
<EOS>
And
you
must
abandon
all
hopes
of
an
union
with
her
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
would
as
soon
abandon
the
great
design
itself
,
"
returned
Catesby
,
moodily
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
you
persist
in
this
,
you
will
ruin
it
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
Think
of
her
no
more
.
<EOS>
Bend
your
thoughts
exclusively
on
the
one
grand
object
,
and
be
what
you
are
chosen
to
be
,
the
defender
and
deliverer
of
our
holy
Church
.
<EOS>
""I
would
gladly
act
as
you
advise
me
,
father
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
"
but
I
am
spell
-
bound
by
this
maiden
.
<EOS>
""This
is
idle
from
you
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
reproachfully
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Separate
yourself
from
her
,
and
you
will
soon
regain
your
former
mastery
over
yourself
.
<EOS>
""Well
,
well
,
father
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
"
the
effort
,
at
least
,
shall
be
made
.
<EOS>
But
her
large
possessions
,
which
would
be
so
useful
to
our
cause
,
and
which
,
if
I
wedded
her
,
would
be
wholly
devoted
to
it,—think
of
what
we
lose
,
father
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
have
thought
of
it
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
;
"
but
the
consideration
does
not
alter
my
opinion
:
and
if
I
possess
any
authority
over
you
,
I
strictly
enjoin
you
not
to
proceed
farther
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
Viviana
never
can
be
yours
.
<EOS>
""She
<EOS>
shall
be
,
nevertheless
,
"
muttered
Catesby
,
"
and
before
many
hours
have
elapsed,—if
not
by
her
own
free
will
,
by
force
.
<EOS>
I
have
ever
shown
myself
obedient
to
your
commands
,
father
,
"
he
added
aloud
,
"
and
I
shall
not
transgress
them
now
.
<EOS>
""Heaven
keep
you
in
this
disposition
,
my
dear
son
!
"
exclaimed
Garnet
,
with
a
look
of
distrust
:
"
and
let
me
recommend
you
to
remove
yourself
as
soon
as
possible
out
of
the
way
of
temptation
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
<EOS>
muttered
an
affirmative
,
and
taking
Garnet
in
his
arms
,
conveyed
him
carefully
to
his
own
chamber
,
and
placing
him
on
a
couch
,
examined
his
wounds
,
which
were
not
so
serious
as
either
he
or
the
sufferer
imagined
,
and
with
no
despicable
skill
—
for
the
experiences
of
a
soldier
's
life
had
given
him
some
practice
—
bandaged
his
broken
arm
,
and
fomented
his
bruises
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
Garnet
felt
so
much
easier
,
that
he
entreated
Catesby
to
send
Viviana
to
him
,
and
to
make
preparations
for
his
own
immediate
departure
.
<EOS>
Feigning
acquiescence
,
Catesby
quitted
the
room
,
but
with
no
intention
of
complying
with
the
request
.
<EOS>
Not
a
moment
he
felt
must
be
lost
if
he
would
execute
his
dark
design
,
and
,
after
revolving
many
wild
expedients
,
an
idea
occurred
to
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
to
lure
Viviana
to
the
cave
where
Father
Oldcorne
was
concealed
;
and
he
knew
enough
of
the
pliant
disposition
of
the
latter
to
be
certain
he
would
assent
to
his
scheme
.
<EOS>
No
sooner
did
this
plan
occur
to
him
than
he
hurried
to
the
cell
,
and
found
the
priest
,
as
Chetham
had
stated
.
<EOS>
As
he
had
foreseen
,
it
required
little
persuasion
to
induce
Oldcorne
to
lend
his
assistance
to
the
forced
marriage
,
and
he
only
feared
the
decided
opposition
they
should
encounter
from
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"Fear
<EOS>
nothing
,
then
,
father
,
"
said
Catesby
;
"
in
this
solitary
spot
no
one
will
hear
her
cries
.
<EOS>
Whatever
resistance
she
may
make
,
perform
the
ceremony
,
and
leave
the
consequences
to
me
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
plan
is
desperate
,
my
son
,
"
returned
Oldcorne
,
"
but
so
are
our
fortunes
.
<EOS>
And
,
as
Viviana
will
not
hear
reason
,
we
have
no
alternative
.
<EOS>
You
swear
that
if
you
are
once
wedded
to
her
,
all
her
possessions
shall
be
devoted
to
the
furtherance
of
the
great
cause
.
<EOS>
""All
<EOS>
,
father
—
I
swear
it
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
fervently
.
"Enough
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"
The
sooner
it
is
done
,
the
better
.
<EOS>
"It
was
then
agreed
between
them
that
the
plan
least
likely
to
excite
suspicion
would
be
for
Oldcorne
to
proceed
to
the
Hall
,
and
under
some
plea
prevail
upon
Viviana
to
return
with
him
to
the
cave
.
<EOS>
Acting
upon
this
arrangement
,
they
left
the
cell
together
,
shaping
their
course
under
the
trees
to
avoid
observation
;
and
while
Oldcorne
repaired
to
the
Hall
,
Catesby
proceeded
to
the
stable
,
and
saddling
the
only
steed
left
,
rode
back
to
the
cave
,
and
concealing
the
animal
behind
the
brushwood
,
entered
the
excavation
.
<EOS>
Some
time
elapsed
before
the
others
arrived
,
and
as
in
his
present
feverish
state
of
mind
moments
appeared
ages
,
the
suspense
was
almost
intolerable
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
he
heard
footsteps
approaching
,
and
,
with
a
beating
heart
,
distinguished
the
voice
of
Viviana
.
<EOS>
The
place
was
buried
in
profound
darkness
;
but
Oldcorne
struck
a
light
,
and
set
fire
to
a
candle
in
a
lantern
.
<EOS>
The
feeble
glimmer
diffused
by
it
was
not
sufficient
to
penetrate
the
recesses
of
the
cavern
;
and
Catesby
,
who
stood
at
the
farther
extremity
,
was
completely
sheltered
from
observation
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
now
,
father
,
"
observed
Viviana
,
seating
herself
with
her
back
towards
Catesby
,
upon
the
stone
bench
once
used
by
the
unfortunate
prophetess
,
"
I
would
learn
the
communication
you
desire
to
make
to
me
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
something
of
importance
since
you
would
not
disclose
it
at
the
Hall
.
<EOS>
""It
is
,
daughter
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
,
who
could
scarcely
conceal
his
embarrassment
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
brought
you
hither
,
where
I
am
sure
we
shall
be
uninterrupted
,
to
confer
with
you
on
a
subject
nearest
my
heart
.
<EOS>
Your
lamented
father
being
taken
from
us
,
I
,
as
his
spiritual
adviser
,
aware
of
his
secret
wishes
and
intentions
,
conceive
myself
entitled
to
assume
his
place
.
<EOS>
""I
consider
you
in
the
light
of
a
father
,
dear
sir
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
"
and
will
follow
your
advice
as
implicitly
as
I
would
that
of
him
I
have
lost
.
<EOS>
""Since
<EOS>
I
find
you
so
tractable
,
child
,
"
returned
Oldcorne
,
reassured
by
her
manner
,
"
I
will
no
longer
hesitate
to
declare
the
motive
I
had
in
bringing
you
hither
.
<EOS>
You
will
recollect
that
I
have
of
late
strongly
opposed
your
intention
of
retiring
to
a
convent
.
<EOS>
""I
know
it
,
father
,
"
interrupted
Viviana
;
"
but——""Hear
me
out
,
"
continued
Oldcorne
;
"
recent
events
have
strengthened
my
disapproval
of
the
step
.
<EOS>
You
are
now
called
upon
to
active
duties
,
and
must
take
your
share
in
the
business
of
life,—must
struggle
and
suffer
like
others,—and
not
shrink
from
the
burthen
imposed
upon
you
by
Heaven
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
do
not
shrink
from
it
,
father
,
"
replied
Viviana
:
"
and
if
I
were
equal
to
the
active
life
you
propose
,
I
would
not
hesitate
to
embrace
it
,
but
I
feel
I
should
sink
under
it
.
<EOS>
""Not
<EOS>
if
you
had
one
near
you
who
could
afford
you
that
support
which
feeble
woman
ever
requires
,
"
returned
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"What
<EOS>
mean
you
,
father
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Viviana
,
fixing
her
dark
eyes
full
upon
him
.
<EOS>
"That
you
must
marry
,
daughter
,
"
returned
Oldcorne
,
"
unite
yourself
to
some
worthy
man
,
who
will
be
to
you
what
I
have
described
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
was
it
to
tell
me
this
that
you
brought
me
here
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Viviana
,
in
a
slightly
offended
tone
.
<EOS>
"It
was
,
daughter
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
;
"
but
I
have
not
yet
done
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
only
needful
you
should
marry
,
but
your
choice
must
be
such
as
I
,
who
represent
your
father
,
and
have
your
welfare
thoroughly
at
heart
,
can
approve
.
<EOS>
""You
can
find
me
a
husband
,
I
doubt
not
?
"
remarked
Viviana
,
coldly
.
<EOS>
"I
have
already
found
one
,
"
returned
Oldcorne
:
"
a
gentleman
suitable
to
you
in
rank
,
religion
,
<EOS>
years,—for
<EOS>
your
husband
should
be
older
than
yourself
,
Viviana
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
affect
to
misunderstand
you
,
father
,
"
she
replied
;
"
you
mean
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
""You
have
guessed
aright
,
dear
daughter
,
"
rejoined
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"I
thought
I
had
made
myself
sufficiently
intelligible
on
this
point
before
,
father
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"True
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
;
"
but
you
are
no
longer
,
as
I
have
just
laboured
to
convince
you
,
in
the
same
position
you
were
when
the
subject
was
formerly
discussed
.
<EOS>
""To
<EOS>
prevent
further
misunderstanding
,
father
<EOS>
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
,
"
I
now
tell
you
,
that
in
whatever
position
I
may
be
placed
<EOS>
,
I
will
never
,
under
any
circumstances
,
we
d
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
""What
are
your
objections
to
him
,
daughter
?
"
asked
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"They
are
numberless
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
but
it
is
useless
to
particularize
them
.
<EOS>
I
must
pray
you
to
change
the
conversation
,
or
you
will
compel
me
to
quit
you
.
<EOS>
""Nay
<EOS>
,
daughter
,
if
you
thus
obstinately
shut
your
ears
to
reason
,
I
must
use
very
different
language
towards
you
.
<EOS>
Armed
with
parental
authority
,
I
shall
exact
obedience
to
my
commands
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
obey
you
,
father
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
bursting
into
tears,—"indeed
,
indeed
I
can
not
.
<EOS>
My
heart
,
I
have
already
told
you
,
is
another's
.
<EOS>
""He
who
has
robbed
you
of
it
is
a
heretic
,
"
rejoined
Oldcorne
,
sternly
,
"
and
therefore
your
union
with
him
is
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
you
will
we
d
Mr.
Catesby
,
or
,
in
the
name
of
your
dead
father
,
I
will
invoke
a
curse
upon
your
head
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
""Never
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"
My
father
would
never
have
enforced
my
compliance
,
and
I
dread
no
curse
thus
impiously
pronounced
.
<EOS>
You
are
overstepping
the
bounds
of
your
priestly
office
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Farewell
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
she
moved
to
depart
,
a
strong
grasp
was
laid
on
her
arm
,
and
turning
,
she
beheld
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
here
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
she
cried
,
in
great
alarm
.
<EOS>
"Ay
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
At
last
you
are
in
my
power
,
Viviana
.
<EOS>
""I
would
fain
misunderstand
you
,
sir
,
"
she
rejoined
,
trembling
;
"
but
your
looks
terrify
me
.
<EOS>
You
mean
no
<EOS>
violence?""I
mean
that
Father
Oldcorne
shall
we
d
<EOS>
us,—and
that
too
without
a
moment
's
delay
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
sternly
.
"Monster
!
<EOS>
"
shrieked
Viviana
,
"
you
will
not,—dare
not
commit
this
foul
offence
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
dare
,
Father
Oldcorne
will
not
assist
you
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
what
means
that
sign
?
<EOS>
I
can
not
be
mistaken
in
you
,
father
?
<EOS>
You
can
not
be
acting
in
concert
with
this
wicked
man
?
<EOS>
Save
me
from
him!—save
me
.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
the
priest
kept
aloof
,
and
taking
a
missal
from
his
vest
,
hastily
turned
over
the
leaves
.
<EOS>
Viviana
saw
that
her
appeal
to
him
was
vain
.
<EOS>
"Let
<EOS>
me
go
!
<EOS>
"
she
shrieked
,
struggling
with
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You

we

d
you

.
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
Help!—help
!
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"Heed
her
<EOS>
not
,

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
"Oldcorne
,

<EOS>
"This

<EOS>

<EOS>
""Mr
.
<EOS>
Catesby

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
XX
.
<EOS>
—
THE
DEPARTURE
FROM
THE
HALLGuy
Fawkes
was
as
much
surprised
to
hear
of
the
sudden
departure
of
Catesby
as
he
was
concerned
at
the
cause
;
but
he
still
thought
it
probable
he
would
return
.
<EOS>
In
this
expectation
,
however
,
he
was
disappointed
.
<EOS>
The
day
wore
on
,
and
no
one
came
.
<EOS>
The
uncertainty
in
which
Fawkes
was
kept
,
added
to
his
unwillingness
to
leave
Garnet
,
still
detained
him
,
in
spite
of
the
risk
he
ran
,
at
the
Hall
;
and
it
was
only
when
urged
by
Viviana
that
he
began
seriously
to
reflect
whither
he
should
bend
his
steps
.
<EOS>
Towards
evening
,
Garnet
was
so
much
better
,
that
he
was
able
to
sit
up
,
and
he
passed
some
hours
in
conference
with
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
I
do
not
suffer
a

,
"
he
observed
to

,
"
I
will
set
out
with
Guy
Fawkes
to
-
morrow
,
and
we
will
proceed
by
easy

to
London
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
but
approve
your
resolution
<EOS>
,
"
returned
Oldcorne
;
"
for
though
so
long

journey
may

inconvenient
,
and

recovery
,
yet
every

remain
here
is

.
<EOS>
I
will
accompany
you
.
<EOS>
We
shall
both
be
safer
in
the
capital
;
and
perhaps
Viviana
,
now
she
will
be
no
longer
exposed
to
the
persecutions
of
Catesby
,
will
form
one
of

.
<EOS>
""I
should
not
wonder
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
deeply

if
Catesby
has
really

the
enterprise
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
not
think
it
.
<EOS>
I
did

to

from

,

,

.
<EOS>
""Say

<EOS>
,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
The

failed
,

;

I

.
<EOS>
If

Guy
Fawkes
,
who
is
a
host

,
and

.
<EOS>
""We

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
With
many

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Give

,

.
<EOS>

.

"

"

.
<EOS>
Garnet
,

,

,

ajar
,

.
<EOS>
The

was

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"When
<EOS>
you
quit
this

,
"

's
ear
,
"
<EOS>
we
shall
never
meet
again
;
and
oh
!
<EOS>
let
me

the
consolation
of
thinking
that
,
in

for
the

attachment
you
have
shown

,
and
the
dangers
from

you
have

,
I

from
one

.
<EOS>
Catesby
,
from
whatever

,
has
abandoned

.
<EOS>
Do

act
likewise
,
and
the

scheme
will

.
<EOS>
""Catesby
can
not

,
"

Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
bound
by
ties
that
no

sunder
.
<EOS>
And
,
however

may

from
us
now
,

,
rest

.
<EOS>
"Illustration"It
may
be
so
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
but
I
deny
that
the
oath
either

you
have

is
binding
.
<EOS>
The
deed
you
have
sworn
to
do
is
evil
,
and
no

,
however

,
can
compel
you
to
commit
crime
.
<EOS>
Avoid
this
sin
—
avoid
further
connexion
with
those
who
would
work
your
undoing
,
and
do
not
stain
your
soul
with
guilt
from
which
it
will
never
be
cleansed
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
seek
in
vain
to
move
me
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
,
firmly
.
<EOS>
"
My
purpose
is
unalterable
.
<EOS>
The
tempest
that
clears
away
the
pestilence
destroys
many
innocent
lives
,
but
it
is
not
the
less
wholesome
on
that
account
.
<EOS>
Our
unhappy
land
is
choked
with
the
pestilence
of
heresy
,
and
must
be
freed
from
it
,
cost
what
it
will
,
and
suffer
who
may
.
<EOS>
The
wrongs
of
the
English
Catholics
imperatively
demand
redress
;
and
,
since
it
is
denied
us
,
we
must
take
it
.
<EOS>
Oppression
can
go
no
farther
;
nor
endurance
hold
out
longer
.
<EOS>
If
this
blow
be
not
struck
we
shall
have
no
longer
a
religion
.
<EOS>
And
how
comes
it
,
Viviana
,
that
you
,
a

,
whose
father
perished
by
these
very
oppressors
,

yourself

from

,
can
seek
to
turn
me
from
my
purpose?""Because
<EOS>
I
know

is
wrongful
,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no

death
of
my
slaughtered
father
,
still
less
to

by

.
<EOS>
In
his

due

,
the
Lord
will

.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
Lord
has

,
"

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,
"

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
—
do

<EOS>
Fawkes
continued

,

,

<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"Then

<EOS>

"

"

""And

,

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
""You

<EOS>

<EOS>
""In

"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
""Let
