,
daughter
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
;
"
enough
has
been
said
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
I
came
hither
to
tell
Guy
Fawkes
,
that
if
our
enemies
permit
us
to
pass
the
night
without
molestation
(
as
Heaven
grant
they
may
!
)
<EOS>
I
think
I
shall
be
strong
enough
to
set
out
with
him
to
-
morrow
,
when
I
propose
we
should
journey
together
to
London
.
<EOS>
""Agreed
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Father
<EOS>
Oldcorne
will
accompany
us
,
"
pursued
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
I
,
too
,
will
go
with
you
,
if
you
will
permit
me
,
"
said
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
remain
here
;
and
I
have
no
further
fears
of
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Dee
told
me
my
future
fate
was
strangely
mixed
up
with
that
of
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
I
know
not
how
it
may
be
,
but
I
will
not
abandon
him
while
there
is
a
hope
to
cling
to
.
<EOS>
""Viviana
Radcliffe
,
"
rejoined
Guy
Fawkes
,
coldly
,
"
deeply
as
I
feel
the
interest
you
take
in
me
<EOS>
,
I
think
it
right
to
tell
you
that
no
efforts
you
can
use
will
shake
me
from
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
If
I
live
,
I
will
execute
my
design
.
<EOS>
""While
I
live
,
I
will
urge
you
to
it
,
"
remarked
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
while
I
live
,
I
will
dissuade
you
from
it
,
"
added
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
who
will
obtain
the
victory
.
<EOS>
""We
<EOS>
shall
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
smiling
confidently
.
<EOS>
"Hear
me
further
,
"
continued
Viviana
;
"
I
do
not
doubt
that
your
zeal
is
disinterested
;
yet
still
,
your
mode
of
life
,
and
the
difficulties
in
which
you
are
placed
,
may
not
unnaturally
influence
your
conduct
.
<EOS>
That
this
may
no
longer
be
the
case
,
I
here
place
part
of
my
fortune
at
your
disposal
.
<EOS>
I
require
little
or
nothing
myself
.
<EOS>
But
I
would
,
if
possible
,
save
one
to
whom
I
owe
so
much
,
and
whom
I
value
so
much
,
from
destruction
.
<EOS>
""I
fully
appreciate
your
generosity
—
to
give
it
its
lightest
term
—
Viviana
,
"
returned
Guy
Fawkes
,
in
a
voice
of
deep
emotion
.
<EOS>
"
Under
any
circumstances
I
should
reject
it,—under
the
present
,
I
do
so
the
more
positively
,
because
the
offer
,
kind
as
it
is
,
seems
to
imply
that
my
poverty
leads
me
to
act
contrary
to
my
principles
.
<EOS>
Gold
has
no
power
over
me
:
I
regard
it
as
dross
;
and
when
I
could
easily
have
won
it
,
I
neglected
the
opportunity
.
<EOS>
As
no
reward
would
ever
induce
me
to
commit
an
action
my
conscience
disapproved
,
so
none
will
deter
me
from
a
purpose
which
I
regard
as
my
duty
.
<EOS>
""Enough
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
sadly
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
no
longer
question
your
motives
,
or
oppose
your
plan
,
but
will
pray
Heaven
to
open
your
eyes
to
the
truth
.
<EOS>
""Your
conduct
is
in
all
respects
worthy
of
you
,
daughter
,
"
observed
Garnet
,
kindly
.
<EOS>
"You
have
rejected
one
offer
,
"
continued
Viviana
,
looking
at
Fawkes
;
"
but
I
trust
you
will
not
decline
that
I
am
about
to
propose
to
you
.
<EOS>
""What
is
it
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Fawkes
,
in
some
surprise
.
<EOS>
"It
<EOS>
is
that
I
may
be
permitted
to
regard
you
as
a
father
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
with
some
hesitation
.
<EOS>
"
Having
lost
my
own
father
,
I
feel
I
need
some
protector
,
and
I
would
gladly
make
choice
of
you
,
if
you
will
accept
the
office
.
<EOS>
""I
willingly
accede
to
your
request
,
and
am
much
flattered
by
it
,
Viviana
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
homeless
man
,
and
a
friendless
,
and
the
affection
of
such
a
being
as
yourself
will
fill
up
the
only
void
in
my
heart
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
wedded
to
the
great
cause
.
<EOS>
I
can
never
be
more
to
you
than
a
father
.
<EOS>
""Nay
<EOS>
,
I
ask
nothing
more
,
"
she
replied
,
blushing
deeply
.
<EOS>
"Having
<EOS>
thus
arranged
the
terms
upon
which
we
shall
travel
,
"
observed
Garnet
,
with
a
smile
,
"
nothing
is
needed
but
to
prepare
for
our
journey
.
<EOS>
We
start
early
to
-
morrow
morning
.
<EOS>
""I
shall
be
ready
at
daybreak
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
I
am
ready
now
,
"
added
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
In
my
opinion
,
we
run
great
risk
in
remaining
here
another
night
.
<EOS>
But
be
it
as
you
will
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
this
moment
they
were
interrupted
by
the
entrance
of
Father
Oldcorne
,
who
with
a
countenance
of
great
alarm
informed
them
he
could
nowhere
find
Martin
Heydocke
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
you
suspect
any
treachery
on
his
part
?
"
asked
Garnet
of
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
have
always
found
him
trustworthy
,
"
she
answered
;
"
and
his
father
was
my
father
's
oldest
servant
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
think
he
would
betray
us
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
I
must
admit
his
disappearance
at
this
juncture
looks
suspicious
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
my
strength
were
equal
to
it
,
"
returned
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
I
would
keep
watch
throughout
the
night
;
but
that
might
prevent
me
from
accompanying
you
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
My
advice
,
I
repeat
,
is
—
to
set
out
at
once
.
<EOS>
"This
opinion
,
however
,
was
overruled
by
Garnet
and
Viviana
,
who
did
not
think
the
danger
so
urgent
,
and
attributed
the
absence
of
Martin
Heydocke
to
some
unimportant
cause
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
made
no
further
remonstrance
,
and
it
was
agreed
they
should
start
,
as
originally
proposed
,
at
daybreak
.
<EOS>
The
party
then
separated
,
and
Viviana
wandered
alone
over
the
old
house
,
taking
a
farewell
,
which
she
felt
would
be
her
last
,
of
every
familiar
object
.
<EOS>
Few
things
were
as
she
had
known
them
,
but
even
in
their
present
forlorn
state
they
were
dear
to
her
;
and
the
rooms
she
trod
,
<EOS>
though
dismantled
,
were
the
same
she
had
occupied
in
childhood
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
pang
more
acute
to
a
sensitive
nature
than
that
occasioned
by
quitting
an
abode
or
spot
endeared
by
early
recollections
and
associations
,
to
which
we
feel
a
strong
presentiment
we
shall
never
return
.
<EOS>
Viviana
experienced
this
feeling
in
its
full
force
,
and
she
lingered
in
each
room
as
if
she
had
not
the
power
to
leave
it
.
<EOS>
Her
emotions
at
length
became
so
overpowering
,
that
to
relieve
them
she
strolled
forth
into
the
garden
.
<EOS>
Here
,
new
objects
awakened
her
attention
,
and
recalled
happier
times
with
painful
distinctness
.
<EOS>
Twilight
was
fast
deepening
,
and
,
viewed
through
this
dim
and
softened
medium
,
everything
looked
as
of
old
,
and
produced
a
tightening
and
stifling
sensation
in
her
breast
,
that
nothing
but
a
flood
of
tears
could
remove
.
<EOS>
The
flowers
yielded
forth
their
richest
scents
,
and
the
whole
scene
was
such
as
she
had
often
beheld
it
in
times
long
ago
,
when
sorrow
was
wholly
unknown
to
her
.
<EOS>
Perfumes
,
it
is
well
known
,
exercise
a
singular
influence
over
the
memory
.
<EOS>
A
particular
odour
will
frequently
call
up
an
event
and
a
long
train
of
circumstances
connected
with
the
time
when
it
was
first
inhaled
.
<EOS>
Without
being
aware
whence
it
arose
,
Viviana
felt
a
tide
of
recollections
pressing
upon
her
,
which
she
would
have
willingly
repressed
,
but
which
it
was
out
of
her
power
to
control
.
<EOS>
Her
tears
flowed
abundantly
,
and
at
length
,
with
a
heart
somewhat
lightened
of
its
load
,
she
arose
from
the
bench
on
which
she
had
thrown
herself
,
and
proceeded
along
a
walk
to
gather
a
few
flowers
as
memorials
of
the
place
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
she
reached
the
further
end
of
the
garden
,
and
was
stooping
to
pluck
a
spray
of
some
fragrant
shrub
,
when
she
perceived
the
figure
of
a
man
behind
a
tree
at
a
little
distance
from
her
.
<EOS>
From
his
garb
,
which
was
that
of
a
soldier
,
she
instantly
knew
he
was
an
enemy
,
and
,
though
greatly
alarmed
,
she
had
the
courage
not
to
scream
,
but
breaking
off
the
branch
,
she
uttered
a
careless
exclamation
,
and
slowly
retraced
her
steps
.
<EOS>
She
half
expected
to
hear
that
the
soldier
was
following
her
,
and
prepared
to
start
off
at
full
speed
to
the
house
;
but
,
deceived
by
her
manner
,
he
did
not
stir
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
end
of
the
walk
,
she
could
not
resist
the
inclination
to
look
back
,
and
glancing
over
her
shoulder
,
perceived
the
man
watching
her
.
<EOS>
But
as
she
moved
,
he
instantly
withdrew
his
head
.
<EOS>
Her
first
step
on
reaching
the
house
was
to
close
and
fasten
the
door
;
her
next
to
hasten
to
Guy
Fawkes
's
chamber
,
where
she
found
him
,
together
with
Garnet
and
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
All
three
were
astounded
at
the
intelligence
,
agreeing
that
an
attack
was
intended
,
and
that
a
large
force
was
,
in
all
probability
,
concealed
in
the
garden
awaiting
only
the
arrival
of
night
to
surprise
and
seize
them
.
<EOS>
The
disappearance
of
the
younger
Heydocke
was
no
longer
a
mystery
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
secured
and
carried
off
by
the
hostile
party
,
to
prevent
him
from
giving
the
alarm
.
<EOS>
The
emergency
was
a
fearful
one
,
and
it
excited
consternation
amongst
all
except
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
preserved
his
calmness
.
<EOS>
"I
foresaw
we
should
be
attacked
to
-
night
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
I
am
therefore
not
wholly
unprepared
.
<EOS>
Our
only
chance
is
to
steal
out
unobserved
;
for
resistance
would
be
in
vain
,
as
their
force
is
probably
numerous
,
and
I
am
as
helpless
as
an
infant
,
while
Father
Garnet
's
broken
arm
precludes
any
assistance
from
him
.
<EOS>
The
subterranean
passage
leading
from
the
oratory
to
the
further
side
of
the
moat
having
been
stopped
up
by
the
pursuivant
and
his
band
,
it
will
be
necessary
to
cross
the
drawbridge
,
and
as
soon
as
it
grows
sufficiently
dark
,
we
must
make
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
We
have
no
horses
,
and
must
trust
to
our
own
exertions
for
safety
.
<EOS>
Catesby
would
now
be
invaluable
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
his
custom
to
desert
his
friends
at
the
season
of
their
greatest
need
.
<EOS>
""Great
<EOS>
as
is
my
danger
,
"
observed
Viviana
,
"
<EOS>
I
would
rather
,
so
far
as
I
am
concerned
,
that
he
were
absent
,
than
owe
my
preservation
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
fears
for
myself
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
my
only
fears
are
for
you
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
of
intense
anxiety
was
now
passed
by
the
party
.
<EOS>
Garnet
was
restless
and
uneasy
.
<EOS>
Oldcorne
betrayed
his
agitation
by
unavailing
lamentations
,
by
listening
to
every
sound
,
and
by
constantly
rushing
to
the
windows
to
reconnoitre
,
until
he
was
checked
by
Fawkes
,
who
represented
to
him
the
folly
of
his
conduct
.
<EOS>
Viviana
,
though
ill
at
ease
,
did
not
allow
her
terror
to
appear
,
but
endeavoured
to
imitate
the
immoveable
demeanour
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
always
became
more
collected
in
proportion
to
the
danger
by
which
he
was
threatened
.
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
the
time
above
mentioned
,
it
had
become
quite
dark
,
and
desiring
his
companions
to
follow
him
,
Guy
Fawkes
drew
his
sword
,
and
,
grasping
Viviana
's
hand
,
led
the
way
down
stairs
.
<EOS>
Before
opening
the
door
,
he
listened
intently
,
and
,
hearing
no
sound
,
issued
cautiously
forth
.
<EOS>
The
party
had
scarcely
gained
the
centre
of
the
court
,
when
a
caliver
was
discharged
at
them
,
which
,
though
it
did
no
damage
,
served
as
a
signal
to
the
rest
of
their
foes
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
had
never
relinquished
his
hold
of
Viviana
,
now
pressed
forward
as
rapidly
as
his
strength
would
permit
,
and
the
two
priests
followed
.
<EOS>
But
loud
shouts
were
raised
on
the
drawbridge
,
and
it
was
evident
it
was
occupied
by
the
enemy
.
<EOS>
Uncertain
what
to
do
,
Guy
Fawkes
halted
,
and
was
about
to
return
to
the
house
,
when
a
shout
from
behind
told
him
their
retreat
was
intercepted
.
<EOS>
In
this
dilemma
there
was
nothing
for
it
but
to
attempt
to
force
a
passage
across
the
drawbridge
,
or
to
surrender
at
discretion
;
and
though
Guy
Fawkes
would
not
at
other
seasons
have
hesitated
to
embrace
the
former
alternative
,
he
knew
that
his
strength
was
not
equal
to
it
now
.
<EOS>
While
he
was
internally
resolving
not
to
yield
himself
with
life
,
and
supporting
Viviana
,
who
clung
closely
to
him
,
the
clatter
of
hoofs
was
heard
rapidly
approaching
along
the
avenue
,
and
presently
afterwards
two
horsemen
galloped
at
full
speed
toward
the
drawbridge
.
<EOS>
The
noise
had
likewise
attracted
the
attention
of
the
enemy
;
who
,
apprehensive
of
a
rescue
,
prepared
to
stop
them
.
<EOS>
But
the
tremendous
pace
of
the
riders
rendered
this
impossible
.
<EOS>
A
few
blows
were
exchanged
,
a
few
shots
fired
,
and
they
had
crossed
the
drawbridge
.
<EOS>
"Who
goes
there
?
"
shouted
Guy
Fawkes
,
as
the
horsemen
approached
him
.
<EOS>
"It
is
the
voice
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
cried
the
foremost
,
whose
tones
proclaimed
it
was
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
here
,
"
he
cried
,
reining
in
his
steed
.
<EOS>
"Where
is
Viviana
?
"
<EOS>
vociferated
his
companion
,
who
was
no
other
than
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"Here
—
here
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
With
the
quickness
of
thought
,
the
young
merchant
was
by
her
side
,
and
in
another
moment
she
was
placed
on
the
saddle
before
him
,
and
borne
at
a
headlong
pace
across
the
drawbridge
.
<EOS>
"Follow
<EOS>
me
,
"
cried
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
clear
a
passage
for
you
.
<EOS>
Once
across
the
drawbridge
,
you
are
safe
.
<EOS>
A
hundred
yards
down
the
avenue
,
on
the
right
,
you
will
find
a
couple
of
horses
tied
to
a
tree
.
<EOS>
Quick
!
<EOS>
quick!"As
he
spoke
,
a
shot
whizzed
past
his
head
,
and
<EOS>
a
tumultuous
din
in
the
rear
told
that
their
pursuers
were
close
upon
them
.
<EOS>
Striking
spurs
into
his
steed
,
Catesby
dashed
forward
,
and
dealing
blows
right
and
left
,
cleared
the
drawbridge
of
its
occupants
,
many
of
whom
leaped
into
the
moat
to
escape
his
fury
.
<EOS>
His
companions
were
close
at
his
heels
,
and
got
over
the
bridge
in
safety
.
<EOS>
"Fly!—fly
!
"
cried
Catesby,—"to
the
horses
—
the
horses
!
<EOS>
I
will
check
all
pursuit
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
and
while
the
others
flew
towards
the
avenue
,
he
faced
his
opponents
,
and
making
a
desperate
charge
upon
them
,
drove
them
backwards
.
<EOS>
In
this
conflict
,
though
several
shots
were
fired
,
and
blows
aimed
at
him
on
all
sides
,
he
sustained
no
injury
,
but
succeeded
in
defending
the
bridge
sufficiently
long
to
enable
his
friends
to
mount
.
<EOS>
He
then
rode
off
at
full
speed
,
and
found
the
party
waiting
for
him
at
the
end
of
the
avenue
.
<EOS>
Father
Oldcorne
was
seated
on
the
same
steed
as
his
superior
.
<EOS>
After
riding
with
them
upwards
of
a
mile
,
Humphrey
Chetham
dismounted
,
and
resigning
his
horse
to
Viviana
,
bade
her
farewell
,
and
disappeared
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
now
to
London
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
striking
into
a
road
on
the
right
,
and
urging
his
steed
to
a
rapid
pace
.
<EOS>
"Ay
,
to
London!—to
the
Parliament
House
!
"
echoed
Fawkes
,
following
him
with
the
others
.
<EOS>
IllustrationBOOK
THE
SECOND
—
THE
DISCOVERYThe
next
point
to
be
considered
is
the
means
to
compass
and
work
these
designs
.
<EOS>
These
means
were
most
cruel
and
damnable;—by
mining
,
and
by
thirty
-
six
barrels
of
powder
,
having
crows
of
iron
,
stones
,
and
wood
,
laid
upon
the
barrels
,
to
have
made
the
breach
the
greater
.
<EOS>
Lord
!
<EOS>
what
a
wind
,
what
a
fire
,
what
a
motion
and
commotion
of
earth
and
air
<EOS>
would
there
have
been!—Sir
Edward
Coke
's
Speech
on
the
Trial
of
the
Conspirators
in
the
Gunpowder
Plot
.
<EOS>
I.
—
THE
LANDING
OF
THE
POWDERTowards
<EOS>
the
close
of
the
sixth
day
after
their
departure
from
Ordsall
Hall
,
the
party
approached
the
capital
.
<EOS>
The
sun
was
setting
as
they
descended
Highgate
Hill
,
and
the
view
of
the
ancient
,
and
then
most
picturesque
city
,
was
so
enchanting
,
that
Viviana
,
who
beheld
it
for
the
first
time
,
entreated
her
companions
to
pause
for
a
few
minutes
to
allow
her
to
contemplate
it
.
<EOS>
From
the
spot
where
they
halted
,
the
country
was
completely
open
to
Clerkenwell
,
and
only
a
few
scattered
habitations
lay
between
them
and
the
old
grey
ramparts
of
the
city
,
with
their
gates
and
fortifications
,
which
were
easily
discernible
even
at
that
distance
.
<EOS>
Above
them
rose
the
massive
body
and
central
tower
of
Saint
Paul
's
cathedral,—a
structure
far
surpassing
that
which
has
succeeded
it,—while
amid
the
innumerable
gables
,
pointed
roofs
,
and
twisted
chimneys
of
the
houses
sprang
a
multitude
of
lesser
towers
and
spires
,
lending
additional
beauty
to
the
scene
.
<EOS>
Viviana
was
enraptured
,
and
,
while
gazing
on
the
prospect
,
almost
forgot
her
sorrows
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
and
Catesby
,
who
were
a
little
in
advance
of
the
others
,
turned
their
gaze
westward
,
and
the
former
observed
to
his
companion,"The
<EOS>
sun
is
setting
over
the
Parliament
House
.
<EOS>
The
sky
seems
stained
with
blood
.
<EOS>
It
looks
portentous
of
what
is
to
follow
.
<EOS>
""I
would
gladly
behold
the
explosion
from
this
hill
,
or
from
yon
heights
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
pointing
towards
Hampstead
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
a
sight
such
as
man
has
seldom
seen
.
<EOS>
""I
shall
never
live
to
witness
it
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Guy
Fawkes
,
in
a
melancholy
tone
.
<EOS>
"What
!
<EOS>
still
desponding
?
<EOS>
"
returned
Catesby
,
reproachfully
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
,
since
you
had
fully
recovered
from
your
wound
,
you
had
shaken
off
your
fears
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
misunderstand
me
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
mean
that
I
shall
perish
with
our
foes
.
<EOS>
""Why
<EOS>
so
?
"
cried
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
There
will
be
plenty
of
time
to
escape
after
you
have
fired
the
train
.
<EOS>
""I
shall
not
attempt
it
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
in
a
sombre
voice
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
abide
the
result
in
the
vault
.
<EOS>
If
I
perish
,
it
will
be
a
glorious
death
.
<EOS>
""Better
<EOS>
live
to
see
the
regeneration
of
our
faith
,
and
our
restoration
to
our
rights
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
But
we
will
speak
of
this
hereafter
.
<EOS>
Here
comes
Garnet
.
<EOS>
""Where
<EOS>
do
you
propose
we
should
lodge
to
-
night
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
latter
,
riding
up
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
the
house
at
Lambeth
,
where
the
powder
is
deposited
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"Will
<EOS>
it
be
safe
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Garnet
,
uneasily
.
"We
<EOS>
shall
be
safer
there
than
elsewhere
,
father
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
If
it
is
dark
enough
to
-
night
,
Fawkes
and
I
will
remove
a
portion
of
the
powder
.
<EOS>
But
we
are
losing
time
.
<EOS>
We
must
pass
through
the
city
before
the
gates
are
closed
.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
this
suggestion
Garnet
acquiesced
,
and
calling
to
Viviana
to
follow
them,—for
,
since
his
late
atrocious
attempt
<EOS>
,
Catesby
had
not
exchanged
a
word
or
look
with
her
,
but
during
the
whole
of
the
journey
kept
sedulously
aloof,—the
whole
party
set
forward
,
and
proceeding
at
a
brisk
pace
,
soon
reached
the
walls
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
Passing
through
Cripplegate
,
they
shaped
their
course
towards
London
Bridge
.
<EOS>
Viviana
was
filled
with
astonishment
at
all
she
saw
:
the
multitude
and
magnificence
of
the
shops
,
compared
with
such
as
she
had
previously
seen
;
the
crowds
in
the
streets,—for
even
at
that
hour
they
were
thronged
;
the
varied
dresses
of
the
passengers
—
the
sober
garb
of
the
merchant
,
contrasting
with
the
showy
cloak
,
the
preposterous
ruff
,
swelling
hose
,
plumed
cap
,
and
swaggering
gait
of
the
gallant
or
the
ruffler
;
the
brawls
that
were
constantly
occurring
;
the
number
of
signs
projecting
from
the
dwellings
;
all
she
witnessed
or
heard
surprised
and
amused
her
,
and
she
would
willingly
have
proceeded
at
a
slower
pace
to
indulge
her
curiosity
,
had
not
her
companions
urged
her
onward
.
<EOS>
As
they
were
crossing
Eastcheap
,
in
the
direction
of
Crooked
-
lane
,
a
man
suddenly
quitted
the
footpath
,
and
,
rushing
towards
Garnet
,
seized
his
bridle
,
and
cried,"I
arrest
you
.
<EOS>
You
are
a
Romish
priest
.
<EOS>
""It
is
false
,
knave
,
"
returned
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
good
a
Protestant
as
thyself
,
and
am
just
arrived
with
my
companions
from
a
long
journey
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
companions
are
all
rank
Papists
,
"
rejoined
the
stranger
.
<EOS>
"
You
yourself
are
Father
Garnet
,
superior
of
the
Jesuits
,
and
,
if
I
am
not
deceived
,
the
person
next
you
is
Father
Oldcorne
,
also
of
that
order
.
<EOS>
If
I
am
wrong
you
can
easily
refute
the
charge
.
<EOS>
Come
with
me
to
the
council
.
<EOS>
If
you
refuse
,
I
will
call
assistance
from
the
passengers
.
<EOS>
"Garnet
<EOS>
saw
he
was
lost
if
he
did
not
make
an
immediate
effort
at
self
-
preservation
,
and
resolving
to
be
beforehand
with
his
assailant
<EOS>
,
he
shouted
at
the
top
of
his
voice,"Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
<EOS>
my
masters
.
<EOS>
This
villain
would
rob
me
of
my
purse
.
<EOS>
""He
is
a
Romish
priest
,
"
vociferated
the
stranger
.
<EOS>
"
I
call
upon
you
to
assist
me
to
arrest
him
.
"While
<EOS>
the
passengers
,
scarcely
knowing
what
to
make
of
these
contradictory
statements
,
flocked
round
them
,
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
was
a
little
in
advance
of
Catesby
,
rode
back
,
and
seeing
how
matters
stood
,
instantly
drew
a
petronel
,
and
with
the
butt
-
end
felled
the
stranger
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Thus
liberated
,
Garnet
struck
spurs
into
his
steed
,
and
the
whole
party
dashed
off
at
a
rapid
pace
.
<EOS>
Shouts
were
raised
by
the
bystanders
,
a
few
of
whom
started
in
pursuit
,
but
the
speed
at
which
the
fugitives
rode
soon
bore
them
out
of
danger
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
they
had
reached
London
Bridge
,
and
Viviana
,
in
some
degree
recovered
from
the
fright
caused
by
the
recent
occurrence
,
ventured
to
look
around
her
.
<EOS>
She
could
scarcely
believe
she
was
crossing
a
bridge
,
so
completely
did
the
tall
houses
give
it
the
appearance
of
a
street
;
and
,
if
it
had
not
been
for
occasional
glimpses
of
the
river
caught
between
the
openings
of
these
lofty
habitations
,
she
would
have
thought
her
companions
had
mistaken
the
road
.
<EOS>
As
they
approached
the
ancient
gateway
(
afterwards
denominated
Traitor
's
Tower
)
,
at
the
Southwark
side
of
the
bridge
,
she
remarked
with
a
shudder
the
dismal
array
of
heads
garnishing
its
spikes
,
and
pointing
them
out
to
Fawkes
,
cried,"Heaven
grant
yours
may
never
be
amongst
the
number!"Fawkes
<EOS>
made
no
answer
,
but
dashed
beneath
the
low
and
gloomy
arch
of
the
gate
.
<EOS>
Striking
into
a
street
on
the
right
,
the
party
skirted
the
walls
of
Saint
Saviour
's
Church
,
and
presently
drew
near
the
Globe
theatre
,
above
which
floated
its
banner
.
<EOS>
Adjoining
it
was
the
old
Bear
-
garden
—
the
savage
inmates
of
which
made
themselves
sufficiently
audible
.
<EOS>
Garnet
hastily
pointed
out
the
first
-
mentioned
place
of
amusement
to
Viviana
as
they
passed
it
,
and
her
reading
having
made
her
well
acquainted
with
the
noble
dramas
produced
at
that
unpretending
establishment
—
little
better
than
a
barn
in
comparison
with
a
modern
playhouse,—she
regarded
it
with
deep
interest
.
<EOS>
Another
theatre
—
the
Swan
—
speedily
claimed
her
attention
;
and
,
leaving
it
behind
,
they
came
upon
the
open
country
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
growing
rapidly
dark
,
and
<EOS>
Catesby
,
turning
off
into
a
narrow
lane
on
the
right
,
shouted
to
his
companions
to
keep
near
him
.
<EOS>
The
tract
of
land
they
were
traversing
was
flat
and
marshy
.
<EOS>
The
air
was
damp
and
unwholesome
—
for
the
swamp
had
not
been
drained
as
in
later
times,—and
the
misty
exhalations
arising
from
it
added
to
the
obscurity
.
<EOS>
Catesby
,
however
,
did
not
relax
his
pace
,
and
his
companions
imitated
his
example
.
<EOS>
Another
turn
on
the
right
seemed
to
bring
them
still
nearer
the
river
,
and
involved
them
in
a
thicker
fog
.
<EOS>
All
at
once
Catesby
stopped
,
and
cried,"We
should
be
near
the
house
.
<EOS>
And
yet
this
fog
perplexes
me
.
<EOS>
Stay
here
while
I
search
for
it
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
you
leave
us
<EOS>
,
we
shall
not
readily
meet
again
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
But
the
caution
was
unheeded
,
Catesby
having
already
disappeared
.
<EOS>
A
few
moments
afterwards
,
Fawkes
heard
the
sound
of
a
horse
's
hoofs
approaching
him
;
and
,
thinking
it
was
Catesby
,
he
hailed
the
rider
.
<EOS>
The
horseman
made
no
answer
,
but
continued
to
advance
towards
them
.
<EOS>
Just
then
the
voice
of
Catesby
was
heard
at
a
little
distance
,
shouting
,
"
I
was
right
.
<EOS>
It
is
here
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
party
then
hastened
in
the
direction
of
the
cry
,
and
perceived
through
the
gloom
a
low
building
,
before
the
door
of
which
Catesby
,
who
had
dismounted
,
was
standing
.
<EOS>
"A
stranger
is
amongst
us
,
"
observed
Fawkes
,
in
an
under
tone
,
as
he
rode
up
.
<EOS>
"Where
<EOS>
is
he
?
"
<EOS>
demanded
Catesby
,
hastily
.
<EOS>
"Here
,
"
replied
a
voice
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
fear
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
am
a
friend
.
<EOS>
""I
must
have
stronger
assurance
than
that
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Who
are
you?""Robert
Keyes
,
"
replied
the
other
,
"
<EOS>
Do
you
not
know
my
voice?""In
good
truth
<EOS>
I
did
not
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
;
"
and
you
have
spoken
just
in
time
.
<EOS>
Your
arrival
is
most
opportune
.
<EOS>
But
what
brings
you
here
to
-
night?""The
<EOS>
same
errand
as
yourself
<EOS>
,
I
conclude
,
Catesby
,
"
replied
Keyes
.
<EOS>
"
I
came
here
to
see
that
all
was
in
safety
.
<EOS>
But
,
who
have
you
with
you?""Let
us
<EOS>
enter
the
house
,
and
you
shall
learn
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
tapped
thrice
at
the
door
in
a
peculiar
manner
,
and
presently
a
light
was
seen
through
the
windows
,
and
a
voice
from
within
demanded
who
knocked
.
<EOS>
"Your
master
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
the
door
was
instantly
unbarred
.
<EOS>
After
a
hasty
greeting
between
Catesby
and
his
servant
,
whom
he
addressed
as
Thomas
Bates
,
the
former
inquired
whether
aught
had
occurred
during
his
absence
,
and
was
answered
that
,
except
an
occasional
visit
from
Mr.
Percy
,
one
of
the
conspirators
,
no
one
had
been
near
the
house
;
everything
being
in
precisely
the
same
state
he
had
left
it
.
<EOS>
"That
is
well
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
then
,
to
dispose
of
the
horses
.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
the
party
having
dismounted
,
their
steeds
were
led
to
a
stable
at
the
back
of
the
premises
by
Catesby
and
Bates
,
while
the
others
entered
the
house
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
small
,
mean
-
looking
habitation
,
standing
at
a
short
distance
from
the
river
-
side
,
on
the
skirts
of
Lambeth
Marsh
,
and
its
secluded
situation
and
miserable
appearance
seldom
induced
any
one
to
visit
it
.
<EOS>
On
one
side
was
a
deep
muddy
sluice
communicating
with
the
river
.
<EOS>
Within
,
it
possessed
but
slight
accommodation
,
and
only
numbered
four
apartments
.
<EOS>
One
of
the
best
of
these
was
assigned
to
Viviana
,
and
she
retired
to
it
as
soon
as
it
could
be
prepared
for
her
reception
.
<EOS>
Garnet
,
who
still
carried
his
arm
in
a
sling
,
but
who
was
in
other
respects
almost
recovered
from
his
accident
,
tendered
every
assistance
in
his
power
,
and
would
have
remained
with
her
,
but
she
entreated
to
be
left
alone
.
<EOS>
On
descending
to
the
lower
room
,
he
found
Catesby
,
who
,
having
left
Bates
in
care
of
the
horses
,
produced
such
refreshments
as
they
had
brought
with
them
.
<EOS>
These
were
scanty
enough
;
but
a
few
flasks
of
excellent
wine
which
they
found
within
the
house
made
some
amends
for
the
meagre
repast
.
<EOS>
Viviana
was
solicited
by
Guy
Fawkes
to
join
them
;
but
she
declined
,
alleging
that
she
was
greatly
fatigued
,
and
about
to
retire
to
rest
.
<EOS>
Their
meal
ended
,
Catesby
proposed
that
they
should
ascertain
the
condition
of
the
powder
,
as
he
feared
it
might
have
suffered
from
being
so
long
in
the
vault
.
<EOS>
Before
making
this
examination
,
the
door
was
carefully
barred
;
the
shutters
of
the
windows
closed
;
and
Guy
Fawkes
placed
himself
as
sentinel
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
A
flag
beneath
the
grate
,
in
which
a
fire
was
never
kindled
,
was
then
raised
,
and
disclosed
a
flight
of
steps
leading
to
a
vault
beneath
.
<EOS>
Catesby
having
placed
a
light
in
a
lantern
,
descended
with
Keyes
;
but
both
Garnet
and
Oldcorne
refused
to
accompany
them
.
<EOS>
The
vault
was
arched
and
lofty
,
and
,
strange
to
say
,
for
its
situation
,
dry
—
a
circumstance
owing
,
in
all
probability
,
to
the
great
thickness
of
the
walls
.
<EOS>
On
either
side
were
ranged
twenty
barrels
filled
with
powder
;
and
at
the
further
end
stood
a
pile
of
arms
,
consisting
of
pikes
,
rapiers
,
demi
-
lances
,
petronels
,
calivers
,
corslets
,
and
morions
.
<EOS>
Removing
one
of
the
barrels
from
its
station
,
Catesby
forced
open
the
lid
,
and
examined
its
contents
,
which
he
found
perfectly
dry
and
uninjured
.
<EOS>
"It
is
fit
for
use
,
"
he
observed
,
with
a
significant
smile
,
as
he
exhibited
a
handful
of
the
powder
to
Keyes
,
who
stood
at
a
little
distance
with
the
lantern
;
"
if
it
will
keep
as
well
in
the
cellar
beneath
the
Parliament
House
,
our
foes
will
soon
be
nearer
heaven
,
than
they
would
ever
be
if
left
to
themselves
.
<EOS>
""When
<EOS>
do
you
propose
to
transport
it
across
the
river
?
"
asked
Keyes
.
<EOS>
"To
-
night
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
dark
and
foggy
,
and
fitting
for
the
purpose
.
<EOS>
Bates
!
"
<EOS>
he
shouted
;
and
at
the
call
his
servant
instantly
descended
.
"
<EOS>
Is
the
wherry
at
her
moorings?""She
is
,
your
worship
,
"
replied
Bates
.
<EOS>
"You
must
cross
the
river
instantly
,
then
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
"
and
proceed
to
the
dwelling
adjoining
the
Parliament
House
,
which
we
hired
from
Ferris
.
<EOS>
Here
is
the
key
.
<EOS>
Examine
the
premises,—and
<EOS>
bring
word
whether
all
is
secure
.
<EOS>
"Bates
was
about
to
depart
,
when
Keyes
volunteering
to
accompany
him
,
they
left
the
house
together
.
<EOS>
Having
fastened
down
the
lid
of
the
cask
,
Catesby
summoned
Fawkes
to
his
assistance
,
and
by
his
help
as
many
barrels
as
could
be
safely
stowed
in
the
boat
were
brought
out
of
the
vault
.
<EOS>
More
than
two
hours
elapsed
before
Bates
returned
.
<EOS>
He
was
alone
,
and
informed
them
that
all
was
secure
,
but
that
Keyes
had
decided
on
remaining
where
he
was,—it
being
so
dark
and
foggy
,
that
it
was
scarcely
possible
to
cross
the
river
.
<EOS>
"I
had
some
difficulty
in
landing
,
"
he
added
,
"
and
got
considerably
out
of
my
course
.
<EOS>
I
never
was
out
on
so
dark
a
night
before
.
<EOS>
""It
is
the
better
for
us
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
be
sure
to
escape
observation
.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
this
opinion
Guy
Fawkes
concurred
,
and
they
proceeded
to
transport
the
powder
to
the
boat
,
which
was
brought
up
the
sluice
within
a
few
yards
of
the
door
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
and
the
barrels
covered
with
a
piece
of
tarpaulin
,
they
embarked
,
and
Fawkes
,
seizing
an
oar
,
propelled
the
skiff
along
the
narrow
creek
.
<EOS>
As
Bates
had
stated
,
the
fog
was
so
dense
that
it
was
wholly
impossible
to
steer
correctly
,
and
Fawkes
was
therefore
obliged
to
trust
to
chance
as
to
the
course
he
took
.
<EOS>
However
,
having
fully
regained
his
strength
,
he
rowed
with
great
swiftness
,
and
,
as
far
as
he
could
judge
,
had
gained
the
mid
-
stream
,
when
,
before
he
could
avoid
it
,
he
came
in
violent
contact
with
another
boat
,
oversetting
it
,
and
plunging
its
occupants
in
the
stream
.
<EOS>
Disregarding
the
hints
and
even
menaces
of
Catesby
,
who
urged
him
to
proceed
,
Fawkes
immediately
lay
upon
his
oars
,
and
,
as
the
water
was
perfectly
smooth
,
succeeded
,
without
much
difficulty
,
in
extricating
the
two
men
from
their
perilous
situation
.
<EOS>
Their
boat
having
drifted
down
the
stream
,
could
not
be
recovered
.
<EOS>
The
chief
of
these
personages
was
profuse
in
his
thanks
to
his
deliverers
,
whom
he
supposed
were
watermen
,
and
they
took
care
not
to
undeceive
him
.
<EOS>
"You
may
rely
upon
my
gratitude
,
"
he
said
;
"
and
when
I
tell
you
I
am
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
you
will
be
satisfied
I
have
the
means
of
evincing
it
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
Earl
of
Salisbury
!
"
exclaimed
Catesby
,
who
was
seated
by
Fawkes
,
having
taken
one
of
the
oars
.
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible?""I
have
been
on
secret
state
business
,
"
replied
the
Earl
,
"
and
did
not
choose
to
employ
my
own
barge
.
<EOS>
I
was
returning
to
Whitehall
,
when
your
boat
struck
against
mine
.
<EOS>
""It
is
our
bitterest
enemy
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
in
an
under
tone
,
to
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Fate
has
delivered
him
into
our
hands
.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
are
you
about
to
do
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Fawkes
,
observing
that
his
companion
no
longer
pulled
at
the
oar
.
<EOS>
"Shoot
<EOS>
him
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Keep
still
,
while
I
disengage
my
petronel
.
<EOS>
""It
shall
not
be
,
"
returned
Fawkes
,
laying
a
firm
grasp
upon
his
arm
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
perish
with
the
others
.
<EOS>
""If
we
suffer
him
to
escape
now
,
we
may
never
have
such
a
chance
again
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
shoot
him
.
<EOS>
""I
say
you
shall
not
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
hour
is
not
yet
come
.
<EOS>
""What
are
you
talking
about
,
my
masters
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
Earl
,
who
was
shivering
in
his
wet
garments
.
<EOS>
"Nothing
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
hastily
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
throw
him
overboard
,
"
he
whispered
to
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Again
<EOS>
I
say
,
you
shall
not
,
"
replied
the
latter
.
<EOS>
"I
see
what
you
are
afraid
of
,
"
cried
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
smugglers
.
<EOS>
You
have
got
some
casks
of
distilled
waters
on
board
,
and
are
afraid
I
may
report
you
.
<EOS>
Fear
nothing
.
<EOS>
Land
me
near
the
palace
,
and
count
upon
my
gratitude
.
<EOS>
""Our
course
lies
in
a
different
direction
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
If
your
lordship
lands
at
all
,
it
must
be
where
we
choose
.
<EOS>
""But
<EOS>
I
have
to
see
the
King
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
I
have
some
important
papers
to
deliver
to
him
respecting
the
Papists
,
"
replied
Salisbury
.
"Indeed
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
,
at
least
,
have
those
papers
,
"
he
observed
,
in
a
whisper
,
to
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"That
is
a
different
affair
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
They
may
prove
serviceable
to
us
.
<EOS>
""My
<EOS>
lord
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
"
by
a
strange
chance
you
have
fallen
into
the
hands
of
Catholics
.
<EOS>
You
will
be
pleased
to
deliver
these
papers
to
us
.
<EOS>
""Ah
!
<EOS>
villains
,
would
you
rob
me
?
"
cried
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
take
my
life
sooner
.
<EOS>
""We
will
take
both
,
if
you
resist
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
in
a
menacing
tone
.
<EOS>
"Nay
,
then
,
"
returned
Salisbury
,
attempting
to
draw
his
sword
,
"
we
will
see
who
will
obtain
the
mastery
.
<EOS>
We
are
equally
matched
.
<EOS>
Come
on
;
I
fear
you
not
.
"But
<EOS>
the
waterman
who
had
rowed
the
Earl
was
not
of
equal
courage
with
his
employer
,
and
refused
to
take
part
in
the
conflict
.
<EOS>
"It
will
be
useless
to
contend
with
us
,
"
cried
Catesby
,
relinquishing
the
oar
to
Fawkes
,
and
springing
forward
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
those
papers
,
"
he
added
,
seizing
the
Earl
by
the
throat
,
"
or
I
will
throw
you
overboard
.
<EOS>
""I
am
mistaken
in
you
,
"
returned
Salisbury
;
"
you
are
no
common
mariner
.
<EOS>
""It
matters
not
who
or
what
I
am
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
fiercely
.
"
<EOS>
Your
papers
,
or
you
die
.
<EOS>
"Finding
<EOS>
it
in
vain
to
contend
with
his
opponent
,
the
Earl
was
fain
to
yield
,
and
reluctantly
produced
a
packet
from
his
doublet
,
and
delivered
it
to
him
.
<EOS>
"You
will
repent
this
outrage
,
villain
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"Your
lordship
will
do
well
to
recollect
you
are
still
in
my
power
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
One
thrust
of
my
sword
will
wipe
off
some
of
the
injuries
you
have
inflicted
on
our
suffering
party
.
<EOS>
""I
have
heard
your
voice
before
,
"
cried
Salisbury
;
"
you
shall
not
escape
me
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
imprudence
has
destroyed
you
,
"
retorted
Catesby
,
clutching
the
Earl
's
throat
more
tightly
,
and
shortening
his
sword
,
with
the
intent
to
plunge
it
into
his
breast
.
<EOS>
"Hold
!
"
exclaimed
Fawkes
,
grasping
his
arm
,
and
preventing
the
blow
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
already
said
you
shall
not
slay
him
.
<EOS>
You
are
in
possession
of
his
papers
.
<EOS>
What
more
would
you
have?""His
life
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
struggling
to
liberate
his
arm
.
<EOS>
"Let
<EOS>
him
swear
not
to
betray
us
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
refuses
,
I
will
not
stay
your
hand
.
<EOS>
""You
hear
what
my
companion
says
,
my
lord
,
"
cried
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Will
you
swear
to
keep
silence
as
to
what
has
just
occurred?"After
a
moment
's
hesitation
,
Salisbury
assented
,
and
Catesby
relinquished
his
grasp
.
<EOS>
During
this
time
,
the
boat
had
drifted
considerably
down
the
stream
,
and
,
in
spite
of
the
darkness
,
Catesby
noticed
with
some
uneasiness
that
they
were
approaching
more
than
one
vessel
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
of
Salisbury
also
perceived
this
,
and
raised
a
cry
for
help
,
but
was
instantly
checked
by
Catesby
,
who
took
a
seat
beside
him
,
and
placing
the
point
of
his
rapier
at
his
breast
,
swore
he
would
stab
him
if
he
made
any
further
clamour
.
<EOS>
The
threat
,
and
the
dangerous
propinquity
of
his
enemy
,
effectually
silenced
the
Earl
,
and
Catesby
directed
Fawkes
to
make
for
the
shore
as
quickly
as
he
could
.
<EOS>
His
injunctions
were
obeyed
,
and
Fawkes
plied
the
oars
with
so
much
good
-
will
,
that
in
a
few
minutes
the
wherry
struck
against
the
steps
,
which
projected
far
into
the
water
,
a
little
to
the
right
of
the
Star
Chamber
,
precisely
on
the
spot
where
Westminster
Bridge
now
stands
.
<EOS>
Here
the
Earl
and
his
companion
were
allowed
to
disembark
,
and
they
had
no
sooner
set
foot
on
land
than
Guy
Fawkes
pushed
off
the
boat
,
and
rowed
as
swiftly
as
he
could
towards
the
centre
of
the
stream
.
<EOS>
He
then
demanded
of
Catesby
whether
he
should
make
for
the
Parliament
House
,
or
return
.
<EOS>
"I
scarcely
know
what
to
advise
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
the
Earl
will
attempt
pursuit
.
<EOS>
And
yet
I
know
not
.
<EOS>
The
papers
we
have
obtained
may
be
important
.
<EOS>
Cease
rowing
for
a
moment
,
and
let
us
listen
.
<EOS>
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
complied
,
and
they
listened
intently
,
but
could
only
hear
the
rippling
of
the
current
against
the
sides
of
the
skiff
.
<EOS>
"We
have
nothing
to
fear
,
"
observed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
He
will
not
pursue
us
,
or
he
can
not
find
a
boat
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
the
glimmer
of
torches
was
visible
on
the
shore
,
and
the
plunge
of
oars
into
the
water
convinced
him
his
opinion
was
erroneous
.
<EOS>
"What
course
shall
we
take
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"I
care
not
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
sullenly
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
had
my
own
way
,
this
would
not
have
happened
.
<EOS>
""Have
<EOS>
no
fears
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
rowing
swiftly
down
the
stream
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
easily
escape
.
<EOS>
""We
will
not
be
taken
alive
,
"
returned
Catesby
,
seating
himself
on
one
of
the
barrels
,
and
hammering
against
the
lid
with
the
butt
-
end
of
his
petronel
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
sooner
blow
us
all
to
perdition
than
he
shall
capture
us
.
<EOS>
""You
are
right
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
By
my
patron
,
Saint
James
,
he
is
taking
the
same
course
as
ourselves
.
<EOS>
""Well
,
let
him
board
us
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
ready
for
him
.
<EOS>
""Do
as
you
think
proper
if
the
worst
occurs
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
if
we
make
no
noise
,
I
am
assured
we
shall
not
be
perceived
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
he
ceased
rowing
,
and
suffered
the
boat
to
drop
down
the
stream
.
<EOS>
As
ill
-
luck
would
have
it
,
it
seemed
as
if
the
hostile
bark
had
struck
completely
into
their
track
,
and
,
aided
by
the
current
,
and
four
sturdy
rowers
,
was
swiftly
approaching
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
Earl
will
be
upon
us
in
a
few
minutes
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
any
prayers
to
offer
,
recite
them
quickly
,
for
I
swear
I
will
be
as
good
as
my
word
.
<EOS>
""I
am
ever
prepared
for
death
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
we
are
<EOS>
saved!"This
last
exclamation
was
occasioned
by
his
remarking
a
large
barge
,
towards
which
they
were
rapidly
drifting
.
<EOS>
"What
are
you
about
to
do
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Catesby.—"Leap
on
board
,
and
abandon
the
skiff
,
together
with
its
contents?""No
,
"
replied
Fawkes
;
"
sit
still
,
and
leave
the
rest
to
me
.
<EOS>
"By
<EOS>
this
time
,
they
had
approached
the
barge
,
which
was
lying
at
anchor
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
,
grasping
at
a
boat
-
hook
,
fixed
it
in
the
vessel
as
they
passed
,
and
drew
their
own
boat
close
to
its
side
—
so
close
,
in
fact
,
that
it
could
not
be
distinguished
from
it
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
the
chase
came
up
,
and
they
distinctly
perceived
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
seated
in
the
stern
of
the
boat
,
holding
a
torch
.
<EOS>
As
he
approached
the
barge
,
he
held
the
light
towards
it
;
but
the
skiff
being
on
the
off
-
side
,
entirely
escaped
notice
.
<EOS>
When
the
chase
had
got
to
a
sufficient
distance
to
be
out
of
hearing
,
the
fugitives
rowed
swiftly
in
the
contrary
direction
.
<EOS>
Not
judging
it
prudent
to
land
,
they
continued
to
ply
the
oars
,
until
fatigue
compelled
them
to
desist
,
and
they
had
placed
some
miles
between
them
and
their
pursuers
.
<EOS>
"Long
before
this
,
the
Earl
must
have
given
up
the
chase
,
"
observed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
return
before
daybreak
,
and
either
land
our
powder
near
the
Parliament
House
,
or
take
it
back
to
the
vault
at
Lambeth
.
<EOS>
""We
<EOS>
shall
run
equal
risk
either
way
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
"
and
,
having
ventured
thus
far
,
we
may
as
well
go
through
with
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
for
landing
at
Westminster
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
I
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
like
giving
up
a
project
when
I
have
once
undertaken
it
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
speak
my
sentiments
exactly
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Westminster
be
it
.
"After
<EOS>
remaining
stationary
for
about
an
hour
,
they
rowed
back
again
,
and
,
aided
by
the
stream
,
in
a
short
time
reached
their
destination
.
<EOS>
The
fog
had
in
a
great
degree
cleared
off
,
and
day
began
to
break
as
they
approached
the
stairs
leading
to
the
Parliament
House
.
<EOS>
Though
this
was
not
what
they
desired
,
inasmuch
as
the
light
added
to
the
risk
they
would
have
run
in
landing
the
powder
,
it
enabled
them
to
ascertain
that
no
one
was
on
the
watch
.
<EOS>
Running
swiftly
in
towards
a
sort
of
wharf
,
protected
by
a
roofed
building
,
Catesby
leapt
ashore
,
and
tied
the
skiff
to
a
ring
in
the
steps
.
<EOS>
He
then
desired
Fawkes
to
hand
out
the
powder
as
quickly
as
he
could
.
<EOS>
The
order
was
promptly
obeyed
,
and
in
a
few
minutes
several
barrels
were
on
the
strand
.
<EOS>
"Had
<EOS>
you
not
better
fetch
Keyes
to
help
us
,
while
I
get
out
the
rest
?
"
observed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Catesby
assented
,
and
hurrying
to
the
house
,
found
Keyes
,
who
was
in
great
alarm
about
them
.
<EOS>
He
instantly
accompanied
the
other
to
the
wharf
,
and
by
their
united
efforts
the
powder
was
expeditiously
and
safely
removed
.
<EOS>
II
.
<EOS>
—
<EOS>
THE
TRAITORThe
habitation
,
to
which
the
powder
was
conveyed
,
adjoined
,
as
has
already
been
stated
,
the
Parliament
House
,
and
stood
at
the
south
-
west
corner
of
that
structure
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
small
building
,
two
stories
high
,
with
a
little
garden
attached
to
it
,
surrounded
by
lofty
walls
,
and
belonged
to
Whinneard
,
the
keeper
of
the
royal
wardrobe
,
by
whom
it
was
let
to
a
person
named
Ferris
.
<EOS>
From
the
latter
it
was
hired
by
Thomas
Percy
,
one
of
the
conspirators
,
and
a
relative
of
the
Earl
of
Northumberland,—of
whom
it
will
be
necessary
to
speak
more
fully
hereafter,—for
the
purpose
to
which
it
was
now
put
.
<EOS>
Having
bestowed
the
barrels
of
powder
carefully
in
the
cellar
,
and
fastened
the
door
of
the
house
and
the
garden
-
gate
after
them
,
the
trio
returned
to
the
boat
,
and
rowed
back
to
Lambeth
,
where
they
arrived
without
being
noticed
.
<EOS>
They
then
threw
themselves
upon
the
floor
,
and
sought
some
repose
after
their
fatigue
.
<EOS>
It
was
late
in
the
day
before
they
awoke
.
<EOS>
Garnet
and
Oldcorne
had
been
long
astir
;
but
Viviana
had
not
quitted
her
chamber
.
<EOS>
Catesby
's
first
object
was
to
examine
the
packet
he
had
obtained
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
and
withdrawing
to
a
corner
,
he
read
over
the
papers
one
by
one
carefully
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
watched
his
countenance
as
he
perused
them
,
but
he
asked
no
questions
.
<EOS>
Many
of
the
documents
appeared
to
have
little
interest
,
for
Catesby
tossed
them
aside
with
an
exclamation
of
disappointment
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
however
,
a
small
note
dropped
from
the
bundle
.
<EOS>
Catesby
picked
it
up
,
opened
it
,
and
his
whole
expression
changed
.
<EOS>
His
brow
grew
contracted
;
and
,
springing
to
his
feet
,
he
uttered
an
ejaculation
of
rage
,
crying
,
"
It
is
as
I
suspected
.
<EOS>
We
have
traitors
among
us
.
<EOS>
""Whom
<EOS>
do
you
suspect
?
"
cried
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Tresham
!
"
cried
Catesby
,
in
a
voice
of
thunder,—"the
fawning
,
wily
,
lying
Tresham
.
<EOS>
Fool
that
I
was
to
league
him
with
us
.
<EOS>
""He
is
your
own
kinsman
,
"
observed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"He
is
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
"
but
were
he
my
own
brother
he
should
die
.
<EOS>
Here
is
a
letter
from
him
to
Lord
Mounteagle
,
which
has
found
its
way
to
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
hinting
that
a
plot
is
hatching
against
the
state
,
and
offering
to
give
him
full
information
of
it
.
<EOS>
""Traitor
!
<EOS>
false
,
perjured
traitor
!
"
cried
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
He
must
die
.
<EOS>
""He
shall
fall
by
my
hand
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Stay
!
<EOS>
a
plan
occurs
to
me
.
<EOS>
He
can
not
be
aware
that
this
letter
is
in
my
possession
.
<EOS>
I
will
send
Bates
to
bid
him
come
hither
.
<EOS>
We
will
then
charge
him
with
his
criminality
,
and
put
him
to
death
.
<EOS>
""He
deserves
severe
punishment
,
no
doubt
,
"
replied
Garnet
;
"
but
I
am
unwilling
you
should
proceed
to
the
last
extremities
with
him
.
<EOS>
""There
is
no
alternative
,
father
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Our
safety
demands
his
destruction
.
<EOS>
"Garnet
<EOS>
returned
no
answer
,
but
bowed
his
head
sorrowfully
upon
his
breast
.
<EOS>
Bates
was
then
despatched
to
Tresham
;
and
preparations
were
made
by
the
three
lay
conspirators
for
executing
their
fell
design
.
<EOS>
It
was
agreed
,
that
on
his
arrival
,
Tresham
should
be
seized
and
disarmed
,
and
after
being
interrogated
by
Catesby
touching
the
extent
of
his
treachery
,
should
be
stabbed
by
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
This
being
resolved
upon
,
it
became
a
question
how
they
should
act
in
the
interim
.
<EOS>
It
was
possible
that
,
after
the
loss
of
his
papers
,
some
communication
might
take
place
between
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
and
Lord
Mounteagle
,
and
through
the
latter
with
Tresham
.
<EOS>
Thus
prepared
,
on
the
arrival
of
Bates
,
Tresham
,
seeing
through
their
design
,
instead
of
accompanying
him
,
might
give
information
of
their
retreat
to
the
officers
.
<EOS>
The
contingency
was
by
no
means
improbable
;
and
it
was
urged
so
strongly
by
Garnet
,
that
Catesby
began
to
regret
his
precipitancy
in
sending
the
message
.
<EOS>
Still
,
his
choler
was
so
greatly
roused
against
Tresham
,
that
he
resolved
to
gratify
his
vengeance
at
any
risk
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
he
betrays
us
,
and
brings
the
officers
here
,
we
shall
know
how
to
act
,
"
he
remarked
to
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
that
below
which
will
avenge
us
on
them
all
.
<EOS>
""True
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
trust
we
shall
not
be
obliged
to
resort
to
it
.
<EOS>
"Soon
<EOS>
after
this
,
Bates
returned
with
a
message
from
Tresham
,
stating
that
he
would
be
at
the
rendezvous
at
nightfall
,
and
that
he
had
important
disclosures
to
make
to
them
.
<EOS>
He
desired
them
,
moreover
,
to
observe
the
utmost
caution
,
and
not
to
stir
abroad
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
may
,
perhaps
,
be
able
to
offer
an
explanation
of
his
conduct
,
"
observed
Keyes
.
"Impossible
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
But
he
shall
not
die
without
a
hearing
.
<EOS>
""That
is
all
I
desire
,
"
returned
Keyes
.
<EOS>
While
the
others
were
debating
upon
the
interrogations
they
should
put
to
Tresham
,
and
further
examining
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
's
papers
,
Garnet
repaired
to
Viviana
's
chamber
,
and
informed
her
what
was
about
to
take
place
.
<EOS>
She
was
filled
with
consternation
,
and
entreated
to
be
allowed
to
see
Guy
Fawkes
for
a
few
moments
alone
.
<EOS>
Moved
by
her
supplications
,
Garnet
complied
,
and
presently
afterwards
Fawkes
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
"You
have
sent
for
me
,
Viviana
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
What
would
you?""I
have
just
heard
you
are
about
to
put
one
of
your
companions
to
death
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
It
must
not
be
.
<EOS>
""Viviana
<EOS>
Radcliffe
,
"
returned
Fawkes
,
"
by
your
own
desire
you
have
mixed
yourself
up
with
my
fortunes
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
now
discuss
the
prudence
of
the
step
you
have
taken
.
<EOS>
But
I
deem
it
necessary
to
tell
you
,
once
for
all
,
that
any
attempts
to
turn
me
from
the
line
of
conduct
I
have
marked
out
to
myself
will
fail
.
<EOS>
Tresham
has
betrayed
us
,
and
he
must
pay
the
penalty
of
his
treason
.
<EOS>
""But
not
with
his
life
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
not
now
perceive
into
what
enormities
this
fatal
enterprise
will
lead
you
?
<EOS>
It
is
not
one
crime
alone
that
you
are
about
to
commit
,
but
many
.
<EOS>
You
constitute
yourselves
judges
of
your
companion
,
and
without
allowing
him
to
defend
himself
,
take
his
life
.
<EOS>
Disguise
it
as
you
may
,
it
is
assassination
—
cold
-
blooded
assassination
.
<EOS>
""His
<EOS>
life
is
justly
forfeited
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
When
he
took
the
oath
of
secrecy
and
fidelity
to
our
league
,
he
well
knew
what
the
consequences
would
be
if
he
violated
it
.
<EOS>
He
has
done
so
.
<EOS>
He
has
compromised
our
safety
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
he
has
sold
us
to
our
enemies
,
and
nothing
shall
save
him
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
this
is
so
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
"
how
much
better
would
it
be
to
employ
the
time
now
left
in
providing
for
your
safety
,
than
in
contriving
means
of
vengeance
upon
one
,
who
will
be
sufficiently
punished
for
his
baseness
by
his
own
conscience
.
<EOS>
Even
if
you
destroy
him
,
you
will
not
add
to
your
own
security
,
while
you
will
commit
a
foul
and
needless
crime
,
equal
,
if
not
exceeding
in
atrocity
that
you
seek
to
punish
.
<EOS>
""Viviana
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
in
an
angry
tone
,
"
in
an
evil
hour
,
I
consented
to
your
accompanying
me
.
<EOS>
I
now
repent
my
acquiescence
.
<EOS>
But
,
having
passed
my
word
,
I
can
not
retract
.
<EOS>
You
waste
time
,
and
exhaust
my
patience
and
your
own
by
these
unavailing
supplications
.
<EOS>
When
I
embarked
in
this
enterprise
,
I
embraced
all
its
dangers
,
all
its
crimes
if
you
will
,
and
I
shall
not
shrink
from
them
.
<EOS>
The
extent
of
Tresham
's
treachery
is
not
yet
known
to
us
.
<EOS>
There
may
be
—
and
God
grant
it!—extenuating
circumstances
in
his
conduct
that
may
save
his
life
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
the
case
stands
at
present
,
his
offence
appears
of
that
dye
that
nothing
can
wash
it
out
but
his
blood
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
he
turned
to
depart
.
<EOS>
"When
<EOS>
do
you
expect
this
wretched
man
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Viviana
,
arresting
him
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
nightfall
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Oh
!
<EOS>
that
there
were
any
means
of
warning
him
of
his
danger
!
<EOS>
"
she
cried
.
<EOS>
"There
<EOS>
are
none
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
fiercely,—"none
that
you
can
adopt
.
<EOS>
And
I
must
lay
my
injunctions
upon
you
not
to
quit
your
chamber
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
retired
.
<EOS>
Left
alone
,
Viviana
became
a
prey
to
the
most
agonizing
reflections
.
<EOS>
Despite
the
strong
,
and
almost
unaccountable
interest
she
felt
in
Guy
Fawkes
,
she
began
to
repent
the
step
she
had
taken
in
joining
him
,
as
calculated
to
make
her
a
party
to
his
criminal
conduct
.
<EOS>
But
this
feeling
was
transient
,
and
was
succeeded
by
a
firmer
determination
to
pursue
the
good
work
she
had
undertaken
.
"Though
<EOS>
slight
success
has
hitherto
attended
my
efforts
,
"
she
thought
,
"
that
is
no
reason
why
I
should
relax
them
.
<EOS>
The
time
is
arrived
when
I
may
exert
a
beneficial
influence
over
him
;
and
it
may
be
,
that
what
occurs
to
-
night
will
prove
the
first
step
towards
complete
triumph
.
<EOS>
In
any
case
,
nothing
shall
be
wanting
to
prevent
the
commission
of
the
meditated
atrocity
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
she
knelt
down
and
prayed
long
and
fervently
,
and
arose
confirmed
and
strengthened
in
her
resolution
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
no
alteration
had
taken
place
in
the
purposes
of
the
conspirators
.
<EOS>
Night
came
,
but
with
it
came
not
Tresham
.
<EOS>
Catesby
,
who
,
up
to
this
time
had
managed
to
restrain
his
impatience
,
now
arose
,
and
signified
his
intention
of
going
in
search
of
him
,
and
was
with
difficulty
prevented
from
carrying
his
threat
into
execution
by
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
represented
the
folly
and
risk
of
such
a
course
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
he
comes
not
before
midnight
,
we
shall
know
what
to
think
,
and
how
to
act
,
"
he
observed
;
"
but
till
then
let
us
remain
tranquil
.
<EOS>
"Keyes
<EOS>
and
the
others
adding
their
persuasions
to
those
of
Fawkes
,
Catesby
sat
sullenly
down
,
and
a
profound
silence
ensued
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
some
hours
were
passed
,
when
just
at
the
stroke
of
midnight
,
Viviana
descended
from
her
room
,
and
appeared
amongst
them
.
<EOS>
Her
countenance
was
deathly
pale
,
and
she
looked
anxiously
around
the
assemblage
.
<EOS>
All
,
however
,
with
the
exception
of
Fawkes
,
avoided
her
gaze
.
<EOS>
"Is
<EOS>
he
come
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
at
length
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
listened
intently
,
but
have
heard
nothing
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
have
murdered
him
.
<EOS>
And
yet
your
looks
alarm
me
.
<EOS>
Father
Garnet
,
answer
me,—is
the
deed
done?""No
,
my
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"Then
he
has
escaped
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
joyfully
.
<EOS>
"
You
expected
him
at
nightfall
.
<EOS>
""It
is
not
yet
too
late
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
in
a
sombre
tone
;
"
his
death
is
only
deferred
.
<EOS>
""Oh
!
<EOS>
do
not
say
so
,
"
she
cried
,
in
a
voice
of
agony
.
<EOS>
"
I
hoped
you
had
relented
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
this
moment
a
peculiar
knock
was
heard
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
It
was
thrice
repeated
,
and
the
strokes
vibrated
,
though
with
different
effect
,
through
every
bosom
.
<EOS>
"He
is
here
,
"
cried
Catesby
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
,
go
to
your
chamber
,
"
commanded
Guy
Fawkes
,
grasping
her
hand
,
and
leading
her
towards
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
But
she
resisted
his
efforts
,
and
fell
on
her
knees
.
<EOS>
"I
will
not
go
,
"
she
cried
,
in
a
supplicating
tone
,
"
unless
you
will
spare
this
man
's
life
.
<EOS>
""I
have
already
told
you
my
fixed
determination
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
not
retire
of
your
own
free
will
,
I
must
force
you
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
you
attempt
it
,
I
will
scream
,
and
alarm
your
victim
,
"
she
replied
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Catesby
,
"
she
added
,
"
have
my
prayers
,
my
entreaties
,
no
weight
with
you
?
<EOS>
Will
you
not
grant
me
his
life?""No
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Catesby
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
She
must
be
silenced
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
significant
look
at
Fawkes
.
"She
<EOS>
shall
,
"
replied
the
latter
,
drawing
his
poniard
.
<EOS>
"
Viviana
!
"
<EOS>
he
continued
,
in
a
voice
,
and
with
a
look
that
left
no
doubt
as
to
his
intentions
,
"
do
not
compel
me
to
be
your
destroyer
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
the
knocking
was
repeated
,
and
Viviana
uttered
a
prolonged
and
piercing
cry
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
raised
his
weapon
,
and
was
about
to
strike
,
but
his
resolution
failed
him
,
and
his
arm
dropped
nerveless
to
his
side
.
<EOS>
"Your
better
angel
has
conquered
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
clasping
his
knees
.
<EOS>
While
this
was
passing
,
the
door
was
thrown
open
by
Catesby
,
and
Tresham
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
"What
means
this
outcry
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
looking
round
in
alarm
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
what
do
I
see
?
<EOS>
Viviana
Radcliffe
here
!
<EOS>
Did
she
utter
the
scream?""She
did
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
rising
,
"
and
she
hoped
to
warn
you
by
it
.
<EOS>
But
you
were
led
on
by
your
fate
.
<EOS>
""Warn
me
from
what
?
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Tresham
,
starting
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
among
friends
.
<EOS>
""You
are
among
those
who
have
resolved
upon
your
death
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Tresham
,
making
an
effort
to
gain
the
door
,
and
draw
his
sword
.
<EOS>
In
both
attempts
,
however
,
he
was
foiled
,
for
Catesby
intercepted
him
,
while
Fawkes
and
Keyes
flung
themselves
upon
him
,
and
binding
his
arms
together
with
a
sword
-
belt
,
forced
him
into
a
chair
.
<EOS>
"Of
<EOS>
what
am
I
accused
?
<EOS>
"
he
demanded
,
in
a
voice
tremulous
with
rage
and
terror
.
<EOS>
"You
shall
learn
presently
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
And
he
motioned
to
Fawkes
to
remove
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"Let
<EOS>
me
remain
,
"
she
cried
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
My
nature
is
changed
,
and
is
become
as
savage
as
your
own
.
<EOS>
If
blood
must
be
spilt
,
I
will
tarry
to
look
upon
it
.
<EOS>
""This
is
no
place
for
you
,
dear
daughter
,
"
interposed
Garnet
.
"Nor
<EOS>
for
you
either
,
father
,
"
retorted
Viviana
,
bitterly
;
"
unless
you
will
act
as
a
minister
of
Christ
,
and
prevent
this
violence
.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
her
remain
,
if
she
will
,
"
observed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Her
presence
need
not
hinder
our
proceedings
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
seated
himself
opposite
Tresham
,
while
the
two
priests
placed
themselves
on
either
side
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
took
up
a
position
on
the
left
of
the
prisoner
,
with
his
drawn
dagger
in
his
hand
,
and
Keyes
stationed
himself
near
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
captive
regarded
them
with
terrified
glances
,
and
trembled
in
every
limb
.
<EOS>
"Thomas
<EOS>
Tresham
,
"
commenced
Catesby
,
in
a
stern
voice
,
"
you
are
a
sworn
brother
in
our
plot
.
<EOS>
Before
I
proceed
further
,
I
will
ask
you
what
should
be
his
punishment
who
violates
his
oath
,
and
betrays
his
confederates
?
<EOS>
We
await
your
answer?"But
Tresham
remained
obstinately
silent
.
<EOS>
"I
will
tell
you
,
since
you
refuse
to
speak
,
"
continued
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
death
—
death
by
the
hands
of
his
associates
.
<EOS>
""It
may
be
,
"
replied
Tresham
;
"
but
I
have
neither
broken
my
oath
,
nor
betrayed
you
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
letter
to
Lord
Mounteagle
is
in
my
possession
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
Behold
it!""Perdition
!
"
exclaimed
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
not
slay
me
?
<EOS>
I
have
betrayed
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
have
revealed
nothing
.
<EOS>
On
my
soul
's
salvation
,
I
have
not
!
<EOS>
Spare
me
!
<EOS>
spare
me
!
<EOS>
and
I
will
be
a
faithful
friend
in
future
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
indiscreet
—
I
own
it
—
but
nothing
more
.
<EOS>
I
have
mentioned
no
names
.
<EOS>
And
Lord
Mounteagle
,
as
you
well
know
,
is
as
zealous
a
Catholic
as
any
now
present
.
<EOS>
""Your
letter
has
been
sent
to
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
"
pursued
Catesby
,
coldly
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
from
him
I
obtained
it
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
Lord
Mounteagle
has
betrayed
me
,
"
returned
Tresham
,
becoming
pale
as
death
.
<EOS>
"Have
you
nothing
further
to
allege
?
"
demanded
Catesby
.
<EOS>
As
Tresham
made
no
answer
,
he
turned
to
the
others
,
and
said
,
"
Is
it
your
judgment
he
should
die?"All
,
except
Viviana
,
answered
in
the
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"Tresham
,
"
continued
Catesby
,
solemnly
,
"
prepare
to
meet
your
fate
like
a
man
.
<EOS>
And
do
you
,
father
,
"
he
added
to
Garnet
,
"
proceed
to
shrive
him
.
<EOS>
""Hold
!
"
cried
Viviana
,
stepping
into
the
midst
of
them,—"hold
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
in
a
voice
so
authoritative
,
and
with
a
look
so
commanding
,
that
the
whole
assemblage
were
awe
-
stricken
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
think
to
commit
this
crime
with
impunity
,
you
are
mistaken
.
<EOS>
I
swear
by
everything
sacred
,
if
you
take
this
man
's
life
,
I
will
go
forth
instantly
,
and
denounce
you
all
to
the
Council
.
<EOS>
You
may
stare
,
sirs
,
and
threaten
me
,
but
you
shall
find
I
will
keep
my
word
.
<EOS>
""We
must
put
her
to
death
too
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
in
an
under
tone
to
Fawkes
,
"
or
we
shall
have
a
worse
enemy
left
than
Tresham
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
consent
to
it
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"If
you
mistrust
this
person
,
why
not
place
him
in
restraint
?
"
pursued
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
mend
matters
by
killing
him
.
<EOS>
""She
<EOS>
says
<EOS>
well
,
"
observed
Garnet
;
"
let
us
put
him
in
some
place
of
security
.
<EOS>
""I
am
agreed
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
I
,
"
added
Keyes
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
judgment
,
then
,
is
overruled
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
will
not
oppose
you
.
<EOS>
We
will
imprison
him
in
the
vault
beneath
this
chamber
.
<EOS>
""He
must
be
without
light
,
"
said
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
without
arms
,
"
added
Keyes
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
without
food
,
"
muttered
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
only
exchanged
one
death
for
another
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
flag
was
then
raised
,
and
Tresham
thrust
into
the
vault
,
after
which
it
was
restored
to
its
former
position
.
<EOS>
"I
have
saved
you
from
the
lesser
crime
,
"
cried
Viviana
to
Guy
Fawkes
;
"
and
,
with
Heaven
's
grace
<EOS>
,
I
trust
to
preserve
you
from
the
greater!"III
.
—
<EOS>
THE
ESCAPE
PREVENTEDViviana
having
retired
to
her
chamber
,
apparently
to
rest
,
a
long
and
anxious
consultation
was
held
by
the
conspirators
as
to
the
next
steps
to
be
pursued
.
<EOS>
Garnet
was
of
opinion
that
,
as
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
was
aware
of
a
conspiracy
against
the
state
being
on
foot
among
the
Catholics
,
their
project
ought
to
be
deferred
,
if
not
altogether
abandoned
.
<EOS>
"We
are
sure
to
be
discovered
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Arrests
without
end
will
take
place
.
<EOS>
And
such
rigorous
measures
will
be
adopted
by
the
Earl
,
such
inquiries
instituted
,
that
all
will
infallibly
be
brought
to
light
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
we
know
not
what
Tresham
may
have
revealed
.
<EOS>
He
denies
having
betrayed
our
secret
,
but
no
credit
can
be
attached
to
his
assertions
.
<EOS>
""Shall
<EOS>
we
examine
him
again
,
father
,
"
cried
Catesby
,
"
and
wring
the
truth
from
him
by
threats
or
torture?""No
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
;
"
let
him
remain
where
he
is
till
morning
.
<EOS>
A
night
of
solitary
confinement
,
added
to
the
stings
of
his
own
guilty
conscience
,
is
likely
to
produce
a
stronger
effect
upon
him
than
any
torments
we
could
inflict
.
<EOS>
He
shall
be
interrogated
strictly
to
-
morrow
,
and
,
I
will
answer
for
it
,
will
make
a
full
confession
.
<EOS>
But
even
if
he
has
revealed
nothing
material
,
there
exists
another
and
equally
serious
ground
of
alarm
.
<EOS>
I
allude
to
your
meeting
with
the
Earl
on
the
river
.
<EOS>
I
should
be
the
last
to
counsel
bloodshed
.
<EOS>
But
if
ever
it
could
be
justified
,
it
might
have
been
so
in
this
case
.
<EOS>
""I
would
have
slain
him
if
I
had
had
my
own
way
,
"
returned
Catesby
,
with
a
fierce
and
reproachful
look
at
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"If
I
have
done
wrong
,
I
will
speedily
repair
my
error
,
"
observed
the
latter
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
desire
his
death
,
father
?
<EOS>
and
will
you
absolve
me
from
the
deed
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
turning
to
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"It
is
better
as
it
is
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
making
a
gesture
in
the
negative
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
have
our
high
and
holy
purpose
stained
by
common
slaughter
.
<EOS>
The
power
that
delivered
him
into
your
hands
,
and
stayed
them
,
no
doubt
preserved
him
for
the
general
sacrifice
.
<EOS>
My
first
fear
was
lest
,
having
noticed
the
barrels
of
powder
within
the
boat
,
he
might
have
suspected
your
design
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
satisfied
his
eyes
were
blinded
,
and
his
reason
benighted
,
so
that
he
could
discern
nothing
.
<EOS>
""Such
<EOS>
was
my
own
opinion
,
father
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
observe
the
utmost
caution
,
but
proceed
at
all
hazards
with
the
enterprise
.
<EOS>
If
we
delay
,
we
fail
.
<EOS>
""Right
,
"
returned
Catesby
;
"
and
for
that
counsel
I
forgive
you
for
standing
between
me
and
our
enemy
.
<EOS>
"Upon
<EOS>
this
,
it
was
agreed
that
if
nothing
occurred
in
the
interim
,
more
powder
should
be
transported
to
the
habitation
in
Westminster
on
the
following
night,—that
Fawkes
and
Catesby
,
who
might
be
recognised
by
Salisbury
's
description
,
should
keep
close
house
during
the
day,—and
that
the
rest
of
the
conspirators
should
be
summoned
to
assist
in
digging
the
mine
.
<EOS>
Prayers
were
then
offered
up
by
the
two
priests
for
their
preservation
from
peril
,
and
for
success
in
their
enterprise
;
after
which
,
they
threw
themselves
on
benches
or
seats
,
and
courted
slumber
.
<EOS>
All
slept
soundly
except
Fawkes
,
who
,
not
being
able
to
close
his
eyes
,
from
an
undefinable
apprehension
of
danger
,
arose
,
and
cautiously
opening
the
door
,
kept
watch
outside
.
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
,
Viviana
,
who
had
waited
till
all
was
quiet
,
softly
descended
the
stairs
,
and
,
shading
her
light
,
gazed
timorously
round
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
<EOS>
she
was
not
observed
,
she
glided
swiftly
and
noiselessly
to
the
fire
-
place
,
and
endeavoured
to
raise
the
flag
.
<EOS>
But
it
resisted
all
her
efforts
,
and
she
was
about
to
abandon
the
attempt
in
despair
,
when
she
perceived
a
bolt
on
one
side
,
that
had
escaped
her
notice
.
<EOS>
Hastily
withdrawing
it
,
she
experienced
no
further
difficulty
.
<EOS>
The
stone
revolved
on
hinges
like
a
trap
-
door
,
and
lifting
it
,
she
hurried
down
the
steps
.
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
her
approach
,
Tresham
had
retreated
to
the
further
end
of
the
vault
,
and
snatching
up
a
halbert
from
the
pile
of
weapons
,
cried
,
in
a
voice
of
desperation—"Stand
off
!
<EOS>
I
am
armed
,
and
have
severed
my
bonds
.
<EOS>
Off
,
I
say
!
<EOS>
You
shall
not
take
me
with
life
.
<EOS>
""Hush
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Viviana
,
putting
her
finger
to
her
lips
,
"
I
am
come
to
set
you
free
.
<EOS>
""Do
<EOS>
I
behold
an
inhabitant
of
this
world
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Tresham
,
crossing
himself
,
and
dropping
the
halbert
,
"
or
some
blessed
saint
?
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
as
she
advanced
towards
him
,
"
it
is
Viviana
Radcliffe
—
my
preserver
.
<EOS>
Pardon
,
sweet
lady
.
<EOS>
My
eyes
were
dazzled
by
the
light
,
and
your
sudden
appearance
and
speech,—and
<EOS>
I
might
almost
say
<EOS>
looks,—made
<EOS>
me
think
you
were
some
supernatural
being
come
to
deliver

from
these
bloody
-
minded

.
<EOS>
Where
are
they?""In
<EOS>
the
room
above
,
"
she
replied
,
in
a

if
you
speak
so

will

.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
us
fly
without
a
moment
's
delay
,
"
returned
Tresham
,
in
the
same
tone
,
and

up
a
rapier
and
a
dagger
.
<EOS>
"Stay
!
"
cried
Viviana
,
arresting
him
.
<EOS>
"
Before
you
go
,
you
must
tell
me
what
you
are
about
to
do
.
<EOS>
""We
will
talk
of
that
when
we
are
out
of
this
accursed
place
,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"You
shall
not
stir
a

,
"
she

,
placing
herself
resolutely
between
him
and
the
outlet
,
"
till
you
have
sworn
neither
to
betray
your
confederates
,
nor
to
do
them

.
<EOS>
""May
<EOS>
Heaven
requite
me
,
if
I
forgive
them
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tresham
between
his
ground

.
<EOS>
"Remember!—you
are
yet
in
their
power
,
"
she
rejoined
.
"
<EOS>
One
word
from
me
,
and
they
are
at
your
side
.
<EOS>
Swear!—and
swear
solemnly
,
or
you
do
not
quit
this
spot
.
<EOS>
"Tresham
<EOS>
gazed
at
her
fiercely
,
and
griped
his
dagger
,
as
if
determined
to
free
himself
at
any
cost
.
<EOS>
"Ah
!
<EOS>
"
she
ejaculated
,
noticing
the
movement
,
"
you
are
indeed
a
traitor
.
<EOS>
You
have
neither
sense
of
honour
nor
gratitude
,
and
I
leave
you
to
your
fate
.
<EOS>
Attempt
to
follow
me
,
and
I
give
the
alarm
.
<EOS>
""Forgive
<EOS>
me
,
Viviana
,
"
he
cried
,
abjectly
prostrating
himself
at
her
feet
,
and
clinging
to
the
hem
of
her
dress
.
<EOS>
"
I
meant
only
to
terrify
you
;
I
would
not
injure
you
for
worlds
.
<EOS>
Do
not
leave
me
with
these
ruthless
cut
-
throats
.
<EOS>
They
will
assuredly
murder
me
.
<EOS>
Do
not
remain
with
them
yourself
,
or
you
will
come
to
some
dreadful
end
.
<EOS>
Fly
with
me
,
and
I
will
place
you
beyond
their
reach
—
will
watch
over
your
safety
.
<EOS>
Or
,
if
you
are
resolved
to
brave
their
fury
,
let
me
go
,
and
I
will
take
any
oath
you
propose
.
<EOS>
As
I
hope
for
salvation
I
will
not
betray
them
.
<EOS>
""Peace
!
"
cried
Viviana
,
contemptuously
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
set
you
free
,
it
is
not
to
save
you
,
but
them
.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
mean
you
?
"
asked
Tresham
,
hesitating
.
"Question
<EOS>
me
not
,
but
follow
<EOS>
,
"
she
rejoined
,
"
and
tread
softly
,
as
you
value
your
life
.
<EOS>
"Tresham
needed
no
caution
on
this
head
,
and
as
they
emerged
from
the
trap
-
door
in
breathless
silence
,
and
he
beheld
the
figures
of
his
sleeping
foes
,
he
could
scarcely
muster
sufficient
courage
to
pass
through
them
.
<EOS>
Motioning
him
to
proceed
quickly
,
Viviana
moved
towards
the
door
,
and
to
her
surprise
found
it
unfastened
.
<EOS>
Without
pausing
to
consider
whence
this
neglect
could
arise
,
she
opened
it
,
and
Tresham
,
who
trembled
in
every
