,
and
walked
upon
the
points
of
his
feet
,
stepped
forth
.
<EOS>
As
he
crossed
the
threshold
,
however
,
a
powerful
grasp
was
laid
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
a
drawn
sword
presented
to
his
breast
,
while
the
voice
of
Fawkes
thundered
in
his
ear
,
"
Who
goes
there
?
<EOS>
Speak
,
or
I
strike
.
<EOS>
"While
<EOS>
the
fugitive
,
not
daring
to
answer
,
lest
his
accents
should
betray
him
,
endeavoured
vainly
to
break
away
,
Viviana
,
hearing
the
struggle
,
threw
open
the
door
,
and
exclaimed
,
"
It
is
Tresham
.
<EOS>
I
set
him
free
.
""You
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Fawkes
,
in
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wherefore?""In
the
hope
that
his
escape
would
induce
you
to
abandon
your
design
,
and
seek
safety
in
flight
,
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
thwarted
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
"Fawkes
<EOS>
made
no
reply
,
but
thrust
Tresham
forcibly
into
the
house
,
and
called
to
Catesby
,
who
by
this
time
had
been
roused
with
the
others
,
to
close
and
bar
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
command
was
instantly
obeyed
,
and
as
Catesby
turned
,
a
strange
and
fearful
group
met
his
view
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
stood
Tresham
,
his
haggard
features
and
palsied
frame
bespeaking
the
extremity
of
his
terror
.
<EOS>
His
sword
having
been
beaten
from
his
grasp
by
Fawkes
,
and
his
dagger
wrested
from
him
by
Keyes
,
he
was
utterly
defenceless
.
<EOS>
Viviana
had
placed
herself
between
him
and
his
assailants
,
and
screening
him
from
their
attack
,
cried—"Despatch
me
.
<EOS>
The
fault
is
mine
—
mine
only
—
and
I
am
ready
to
pay
the
penalty
.
<EOS>
Had
I
not
released
him
,
he
would
not
have
attempted
to
escape
.
<EOS>
I
am
the
rightful
victim
.
<EOS>
""She
speaks
the
truth
,
"
gasped
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
If
she
had
not
offered
to
liberate
me
,
I
should
never
have
thought
of
flying
.
<EOS>
Would
to
Heaven
<EOS>
I
had
never
yielded
to
her
solicitations!""Peace
,
craven
hound
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Fawkes
,
furiously
;
"
you
deserve
to
die
for
your
meanness
and
ingratitude
,
if
not
for
your
treachery
.
<EOS>
And
it
is
for
this
miserable
wretch
,
Viviana
,
"
he
added
,
turning
to
her
,
"
that
you
would
have
placed
your
friends
in
such
fearful
jeopardy,—it
<EOS>
is
for
him
,
who
would
sacrifice
you
without
scruple
to
save
himself
,
that
you
now
offer
your
own
life?""I
deserve
your
reproaches
,
"
she
rejoined
,
in
confusion
.
<EOS>
"Had
<EOS>
I
not
fortunately
intercepted
him
,
"
pursued
Fawkes
,
"
an
hour
would
not
have
elapsed
ere
<EOS>
he
would
have
returned
with
the
officers
;
and
we
should
have
changed
this
dwelling
for
a
dungeon
in
the
Tower,—these
benches
for
the
rack
.
<EOS>
""In
<EOS>
pity
stab
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
falling
at
his
feet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
oh
!
do
not
wound
me
with
your
words
.
<EOS>
I
have
committed
a
grievous
wrong
;
but
I
was
ignorant
of
the
consequences
;
and
,
as
I
hope
for
mercy
hereafter
,
my
sole
motive
,
beyond
compassion
for
this
wretched
man
,
was
to
terrify
you
into
relinquishing
your
dreadful
project
.
<EOS>
""You
have
acted
wrongfully,—very
wrongfully
,
Viviana
,
"
interposed
Garnet
:
"
but
since
you
are
fully
convinced
of
your
error
,
no
more
need
be
said
.
<EOS>
There
are
seasons
when
the
heart
must
be
closed
against
compassion
,
and
when
mercy
becomes
injustice
.
<EOS>
Go
to
your
chamber
,
and
leave
us
to
deal
with
this
unhappy
man
.
<EOS>
""To
-
morrow
you
must
quit
us
,
"
observed
Fawkes
,
as
she
passed
him
.
<EOS>
"Quit
you
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
offend
again
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
trust
you
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
"
unless
—
but
it
is
useless
to
impose
restrictions
upon
you
,
which
you
will
not
—
perhaps
,
can
not
observe
.
<EOS>
""Impose
<EOS>
any
restrictions
you
please
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
"
<EOS>
But
do
not
bid
me
leave
you
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
time
is
come
when
we
must
separate
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
See
you
not
that
the
course
we
are
taking
is
slippery
with
blood
,
and
beset
with
perils
which
the
firmest
of
your
sex
could
not
encounter?""I
will
encounter
them
nevertheless
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Be
merciful
,
"
she
added
,
pointing
to
Tresham
,
"
and
mercy
shall
be
shown
you
in
your
hour
of
need
.
"
<EOS>
And
she
slowly
withdrew
.
<EOS>
While
this
was
passing
,
Catesby
addressed
a
few
words
aside
to
Keyes
and
Oldcorne
,
and
now
stepping
forward
,
and
fixing
his
eye
steadily
upon
the
prisoner
,
to
note
the
effect
of
his
speech
upon
him
,
said—"I
have
devised
a
plan
by
which
the
full
extent
of
Tresham
's
treachery
can
be
ascertained
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
do
not
mean
to
torture
him
,
I
trust
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Garnet
,
uneasily
.
<EOS>
"No
,
father
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
If
torture
is
inflicted
at
all
,
it
will
be
upon
the
mind
,
not
the
body
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
it
will
be
no
torture
,
"
observed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
State
your
plan
,
my
son
.
<EOS>
""It
is
this
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
He
shall
write
a
letter
to
Lord
Mounteagle
,
stating
that
he
has
important
revelations
to
make
to
him
,
and
entreating
him
to
come
hither
unattended
.
""Here
!
"
exclaimed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Here
,
"
repeated
Catesby
;
"
and
alone
.
<EOS>
We
will
conceal
ourselves
in
such
manner
that
we
may
overhear
what
passes
between
them
,
and
if
any
attempt
is
made
by
the
villain
to
betray
our
presence
,
he
shall
be
immediately
shot
.
<EOS>
By
this
means
we
can
not
fail
to
elicit
the
truth
.
<EOS>
""I
approve
your
plan
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
;
"
but
who
will
convey
the
letter
to
Lord
Mounteagle?""I
will
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Let
it
be
prepared
at
once
,
and
the
case
will
be
thought
the
more
urgent
.
<EOS>
I
will
watch
him
,
and
see
that
he
comes
unattended
,
or
give
you
timely
warning
.
<EOS>
""Enough
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
.
"
<EOS>
Let
writing
materials
be
procured
,
and
I
will
dictate
the
letter
.
<EOS>
"Tresham
,
meanwhile
,
exhibited
no
misgiving
;
but
,
on
the
contrary
,
his
countenance
brightened
up
as
the
plan
was
approved
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
life
will
be
spared
<EOS>
if
you
find
I
have
not
deceived
you
,
will
it
not
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
in
a
supplicating
voice
.
"Assuredly
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"Give
<EOS>
me
pen
and
ink
<EOS>
,
then
,
"
he
cried
,
"
and
I
will
write
whatever
you
desire
.
<EOS>
""Our
<EOS>
secret
is
safe
,
"
whispered
Catesby
to
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
useless
to
test
him
further
.
<EOS>
""I
think
so
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
Would
we
had
made
this
experiment
sooner!""Do
<EOS>
not
delay
,
I
entreat
you
,
"
implored
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
eager
to
prove
my
innocence
.
<EOS>
""We
are
satisfied
with
the
proof
we
have
already
obtained
,
"
returned
Garnet
.
<EOS>
Tresham
dropped
on
his
knees
in
speechless
gratitude
.
<EOS>
"We
are
spared
the
necessity
of
being
your
executioners
,
my
son
,
"
pursued
Garnet
,
"
and
I
rejoice
at
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
not
acquit
you
of
the
design
to
betray
us
;
and
till
you
have
unburthened
your
whole
soul
to
me
,
and
proved
by
severe
and
self
-
inflicted
penance
that
you
are
really
penitent
,
you
must
remain
a
captive
within
these
walls
.
<EOS>
""I
will
disguise
nothing
from
you
,
father
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
"
and
will
strive
to
expiate
my
offence
by
the
severest
penance
you
choose
to
inflict
.
<EOS>
""Do
this
,
my
son
<EOS>
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
;
"
leave
no
doubt
of
your
sincerity
,
and
you
may
be
yet
restored
to
the
place
you
have
forfeited
,
and
become
a
sharer
in
our
great
enterprise
.
<EOS>
""I
will
never
trust
him
more
,
"
observed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Nor
<EOS>
I
,
"
added
Keyes
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
will
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
:
"
<EOS>
not
that
I
have
more
faith
in
him
than
either
of
you
;
but
I
will
so
watch
him
that
he
shall
not
dare
to
betray
us
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
more
,
"
he
added
,
in
an
under
tone
,
to
Garnet
,
"
I
will
turn
his
treachery
to
account
.
<EOS>
He
will
be
a
useful
spy
upon
our
enemies
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
he
can
be
relied
on
,
"
observed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"After
<EOS>
this
,
you
need
have
no
fears
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
with
a
significant
smile
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
first
part
of
your
penance
,
my
son
,
"
said
Garnet
,
addressing
Tresham
,
"
shall
be
to
pass
the
night
in
solitary
vigil
and
prayer
within
the
vault
.
<EOS>
Number
your
transgressions
,
and
reflect
upon
their
enormity
.
<EOS>
Consider
not
only
the
injury
your
conduct
might
have
done
us
,
but
the
holy
church
of
which
you
are
so
sinful
a
member
.
<EOS>
Weigh
over
all
this
,
and
to
-
morrow
<EOS>
I
will
hear
your
confession
;
when
,
if
I
find
you
in
a
state
of
grace
,
absolution
shall
not
be
refused
.
<EOS>
"Tresham
humbly
bowed
his
head
in
token
of
acquiescence
.
<EOS>
He
was
then
led
to
the
vault
,
and
the
flag
closed
over
him
,
as
before
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
after
a
brief
conversation
,
the
others
again
stretched
themselves
on
the
floor
,
and
sought
repose
.
<EOS>
IV
.
—
<EOS>
THE
MINESome
days
elapsed
before
the
conspirators
ventured
forth
from
their
present
abode
.
<EOS>
They
had
intended
to
remove
the
rest
of
the
powder
without
loss
of
time
,
but
were
induced
to
defer
their
purpose
on
the
representations
of
Tresham
,
who
stated
to
Garnet
,
that
in
his
opinion
they
would
run
a
great
and
needless
risk
.
<EOS>
Before
the
expiration
of
a
week
,
Tresham
's
apparent
remorse
for
his
perfidy
,
added
to
his
seeming
zeal
,
had
so
far
reinstated
him
in
the
confidence
of
his
associates
,
that
he
was
fully
absolved
of
his
offence
by
Garnet
;
and
,
after
taking
fresh
oaths
of
even
greater
solemnity
than
the
former
,
was
again
admitted
to
the
league
.
<EOS>
Catesby
,
however
,
who
placed
little
faith
in
his
protestations
,
never
lost
sight
of
him
for
an
instant
,
and
,
even
if
he
meditated
an
escape
,
he
had
no
opportunity
of
effecting
it
.
<EOS>
A
coldness
,
stronger
on
his
side
than
hers
,
seemed
to
have
arisen
between
Viviana
and
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Whenever
she
descended
to
the
lower
room
,
he
withdrew
on
some
excuse
;
and
though
he
never
urged
her
departure
by
words
,
his
looks
plainly
bespoke
that
he
desired
it
.
<EOS>
Upon
one
occasion
,
she
found
him
alone,—the
others
being
at
the
time
within
the
vault
.
<EOS>
He
was
whetting
the
point
of
his
dagger
,
and
did
not
hear
her
approach
,
until
she
stood
beside
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
slightly
confused
,
and
a
deep
ruddy
stain
flushed
his
swarthy
cheeks
and
brow
;
but
he
averted
his
gaze
,
and
continued
his
occupation
in
silence
.
<EOS>
"Why
<EOS>
do
you
shun
me
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Viviana
,
laying
her
hand
gently
upon
his
shoulder
.
<EOS>
And
,
as
he
did
not
answer
,
she
repeated
the
question
in
a
broken
voice
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
then
looked
up
,
and
perceived
that
her
eyes
were
filled
with
tears
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
shun
you
,
Viviana
,
for
two
reasons
,
"
he
replied
gravely
,
but
kindly
;
"
first
,
because
I
would
have
no
ties
of
sympathy
to
make
me
cling
to
the
world
,
or
care
for
it
;
and
I
feel
that
if
I
suffer
myself
to
be
interested
about
you
,
this
will
not
long
be
the
case
:
secondly
,
and
chiefly
,
because
you
are
constantly
striving
to
turn
me
from
my
fixed
purpose
;
and
,
though
your
efforts
have
been
,
and
will
be
unavailing
,
yet
I
would
not
be
exposed
to
them
further
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
fear
me
,
because
you
think
I
shall
shake
your
resolution
,
"
she
rejoined
,
with
a
forced
smile
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
will
trouble
you
no
more
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
if
you
wish
it
,
I
will
go
.
<EOS>
""It
were
better
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
in
accents
of
deep
emotion
,
and
taking
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Painful
as
will
be
the
parting
with
you
,
I
shall
feel
more
easy
when
it
is
over
.
<EOS>
It
grieves
me
to
the
soul
to
see
you
—
the
daughter
of
the
proud
,
the
wealthy
Sir
William
Radcliffe
—
an
inmate
of
this
wretched
abode
,
surrounded
by
desperate
men
,
whose
actions
you
disapprove
,
and
whose
danger
you
are
compelled
to
share
.
<EOS>
Think
how
it
would
add
to
my
suffering
if
our
plot
—
which
Heaven
avert
—
should
be
discovered
,
and
you
be
involved
in
it
.
<EOS>
""Do
not
think
of
it
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"I
can
not
banish
it
from
my
thoughts
,
"
continued
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
reconcile
it
to
my
feelings
that
one
so
young
,
so
beautiful
,
should
be
thus
treated
.
<EOS>
Dwelling
on
this
idea
unmans
me
—
unfits
me
for
sterner
duties
.
<EOS>
The
great
crisis
is
at
hand
,
and
I
must
live
only
for
it
.
<EOS>
""Live
<EOS>
for
it
,
then
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
;
"
but
,
<EOS>
oh
!
let
me
remain
with
you
till
the
blow
is
struck
.
<EOS>
Something
tells
me
I
may
yet
be
useful
to
you
—
may
save
you
.
<EOS>
""No
more
of
this
,
if
you
would
indeed
remain
,
"
rejoined
Guy
Fawkes
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Regard
me
as
a
sword
in
the
hand
of
fate
,
which
can
not
be
turned
aside,—as
a
bolt
launched
from
the
cloud
,
and
shattering
all
in
its
course
,
which
may
not
be
stopped,—as
something
terrible
,
exterminating
,
immovable
.
<EOS>
Regard
me
as
this
,
and
say
whether
I
am
not
to
be
shunned
.
<EOS>
""No
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
I
am
as
steadfast
as
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
will
remain
.
<EOS>
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
gazed
at
her
in
surprise
mixed
with
admiration
,
and
pressing
her
hand
affectionately
,
said,"I
applaud
your
resolution
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
a
daughter
,
I
should
wish
her
to
be
like
you
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
promised
to
be
a
father
to
me
,
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
be
so
if
I
leave
you?""How
<EOS>
can
I
be
so
if
you
stay
?
<EOS>
"
returned
Fawkes
,
mournfully
.
"
<EOS>
No
,
you
must
indulge
no
filial
tenderness
for
one
so
utterly
unable
to
requite
it
as
myself
.
<EOS>
Fix
your
thoughts
wholly
on
Heaven
.
<EOS>
Pray
for
the
restoration
of
our
holy
religion
—
for
the
success
of
the
great
enterprise
—
and
haply
your
prayers
may
prevail
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
pray
for
that
,
"
she
replied
;
"
for
I
do
not
wish
it
success
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
pray
—
and
fervently
—
that
all
danger
may
be
averted
from
your
head
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
this
moment
,
Catesby
and
Keyes
emerged
from
the
vault
,
and
Viviana
hurried
to
her
chamber
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
it
grew
dark
,
the
remaining
barrels
of
powder
were
brought
out
of
the
cellar
,
and
carefully
placed
in
the
boat
.
<EOS>
Straw
was
then
heaped
upon
them
,
and
the
whole
covered
with
a
piece
of
tarpaulin
,
as
upon
the
former
occasion
.
<EOS>
It
being
necessary
to
cross
the
river
more
than
once
,
the
conduct
of
the
first
and
most
hazardous
passage
was
intrusted
to
Fawkes
,
and
accompanied
by
Keyes
and
Bates
,
both
of
whom
were
well
armed
,
he
set
out
a
little
before
midnight
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
clear
starlight
night
;
but
as
the
moon
had
not
yet
risen
,
they
were
under
no
apprehension
of
discovery
.
<EOS>
The
few
craft
they
encountered
,
bent
probably
on
some
suspicious
errand
like
themselves
,
paid
no
attention
to
them
;
and
plying
their
oars
swiftly
<EOS>
,
they
shot
under
the
low
parapet
edging
the
gardens
of
the
Parliament
House
,
just
as
the
deep
bell
of
the
Abbey
tolled
forth
the
hour
of
twelve
.
<EOS>
Keeping
in
the
shade
,
they
silently
approached
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
No
one
was
there
,
not
even
a
waterman
to
attend
to
the
numerous
wherries
moored
to
the
steps
;
and
,
without
losing
a
moment
,
they
sprang
ashore
,
and
concealing
the
barrels
beneath
their
cloaks
,
glided
like
phantoms
summoned
by
the
witching
hour
along
the
passage
formed
by
two
high
walls
,
leading
to
Old
Palace
Yard
,
and
speedily
reached
the
gate
of
the
habitation
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
and
with
the
utmost
rapidity
,
the
whole
of
the
fearful
cargo
was
safely
deposited
in
the
garden
;
and
leaving
the
others
to
carry
it
into
the
house
,
Guy
Fawkes
returned
to
the
boat
.
<EOS>
As
he
was
about
to
push
off
,
two
persons
rushed
to
the
stair
-
head
,
and
the
foremost
,
evidently
mistaking
him
for
a
waterman
,
called
to
him
to
take
them
across
the
river
.
<EOS>
"I
am
no
waterman
,
friend
,
"
replied
Fawkes
;
"
and
am
engaged
on
business
of
my
own
.
<EOS>
Seek
a
wherry
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
""By
heaven
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
new
-
comer
,
in
accents
of
surprise
,
"
it
is
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Do
you
not
know
me?""Can
<EOS>
it
be
Humphrey
Chetham
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Fawkes
,
equally
astonished
.
<EOS>
"It
is
,
"
replied
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
This
meeting
is
most
fortunate
.
<EOS>
I
was
in
search
of
you
,
having
somewhat
of
importance
to
communicate
to
Viviana
.
<EOS>
""State
it
quickly
,
then
,
"
returned
Fawkes
;
"
I
can
not
tarry
here
much
longer
.
<EOS>
""I
will
go
with
you
,
"
rejoined
Chetham
,
springing
into
the
boat
,
and
followed
by
his
companion
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
take
me
to
her
.
<EOS>
""Impossible
<EOS>
,
"
cried
Fawkes
,
rising
angrily
;
"
neither
can
I
permit
you
to
accompany
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
busied
about
my
own
concerns
,
and
will
not
be
interrupted
.
<EOS>
""At
least
,
tell
me
where
I
can
find
Viviana
,
"

Chetham
.
"Not
<EOS>
now
—
not
now
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
Meet
me
to
-
morrow
night
,
at
this

,
in

Great

,
at
the
farther
side
of
the
Abbey
,
and
you
shall
learn
all
you
desire
to
know
.
<EOS>
""Why
not
now
?
"
rejoined
Chetham
,
earnestly
.
<EOS>
"
You
need
not
fear
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
no
spy
,
and
will
reveal
nothing
.
<EOS>
""But
<EOS>
your
companion
?
"
hesitated
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"It
is
only
Martin
Heydocke
,
"
answered
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
He
can
keep
a
close
tongue
as
well
as
his
master
.
<EOS>
""Well
,
sit
down
,
then
,
"
returned
Fawkes
,
sullenly
.
<EOS>
"
There
will
be
less
risk
in
taking
them
to
Lambeth
,
"
he
muttered
,
"
than
in
loitering
here
.
"
<EOS>
And
rowing
with
great
swiftness
,
he
soon
gained
the
centre
of
the
stream
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
so
,
"
he
observed
,
resting
for
a
moment
on
his
oars
,
"
you
still
cherish
your
attachment
to
Viviana
,
I
see
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
never
start
,
man
.
<EOS>
I
am
no
enemy
to
your
suit
,
though
others
may
be
.
<EOS>
And
if
she
would
place
herself
at
my
disposal
,
I
would
give
her
to
you,—certain
that
it
would
be
to
one
upon
whom
her
affections
are
fixed
.
<EOS>
""Do
<EOS>
you
think
any
change
likely
to
take
place
in
her
sentiments
towards
me
?
"
<EOS>
faltered
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
May
I
indulge
a
hope?""I
would
not
have
you
despair
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Because
,
as
far
as
I
have
noticed
,
women
are
not

to
adhere
to
their
resolutions
in
matters
of
the

;
and
because
,
as
I
have
just

,
she
loves
you
,
and
I
see
no
reasonable
bar
to
your
union
.
<EOS>
""You
give
me
new
life
,
"
cried
Chetham
,
transported
with
joy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
that
you
,
who
have
so
much
influence
with
her
,
would
speak
in
my
behalf
.
<EOS>
""Nay
,
you
must
plead
your
own
cause
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
hold
out
much
hope
at
present
;
for
recent
events
have
cast
a
deep
gloom
over
her
spirit
,
and
she
appears
to
be
a
prey
to
melancholy
.
<EOS>
Let
this
wear
<EOS>
off,—and
<EOS>
with
one
<EOS>
so
young
and
so
firm
-
minded
it
is
sure
to
do
so,—and
then
your
suit
may
be
renewed
.
<EOS>
Urge
it
when
you
may
,
you
have
my
best
wishes
for
success
,
and
shall
have
my
warmest
efforts
to
second
you
.
"Humphrey
<EOS>
Chetham
murmured
his
thanks
in
accents
almost
unintelligible
from
emotion
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
continued,"It
would
be
dangerous
for
you
to
disembark
with
me
;
but
when
I
put
you
ashore
,
I
will
point
out
the
dwelling
at
present
occupied
by
Viviana
.
<EOS>
You
can
visit
it
as
early
as
you
please
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
You
will
find
no
one
with
her
but
Father
Oldcorne
,
and
I
need
scarcely
add
,
it
will
gladden
me
to
the
heart
to
find
on
my
return
that
she
has
yielded
to
your
entreaties
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
thank
you
,
"
cried
Chetham
,
warmly
grasping
his
hand
;
"
but
I
hope
to
find
some
means
of
evincing
my
gratitude
.
<EOS>
""Prove
it
by
maintaining
the
strictest
secresy
as
to
all
you
may
see
or
hear,—or
even
suspect,—within
<EOS>
the
dwelling
you
are
about
to
visit
,
"
returned
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Knowing
that
I
am
dealing
with
a
man
of
honour
,
I
require
no
stronger
obligation
than
your
word
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
have
it
,
"
replied
Chetham
,
solemnly
.
<EOS>
"Your
<EOS>
worship
shall
have
my

,
if
you
desire

,
"
remarked
Martin
Heydocke
.
<EOS>
"No
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
;
"
your
master
will
answer
for
your
fidelity
.
<EOS>
"Shortly
<EOS>
after
this
,
Guy
Fawkes
pulled
ashore
,
and
his
companions
landed
.
<EOS>
After
pointing
out
the
solitary
habitation
,
which
possessed
greater
interest
in
Humphrey
Chetham
's
eyes
than
the
proud
structures
he
had
just
quitted
,
and
extracting
a
promise
that
the
young
merchant
would
not
approach
it
till
the
morrow
,
he
rowed
off
,
and
while
the
others
proceeded
to
Lambeth
in
search
of
lodging
for
the
night
,
made
the
best
of
his
way
to
the
little
creek
,
and
entered
the
house
.
<EOS>
He
found
the
other
conspirators
anxiously
awaiting
his
arrival
,
and
the
certainty
afforded
by
his
presence
that
the
powder
had
been
landed
in
safety
gave
general
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
Preparations
were
immediately
made
for
another
voyage
.
<EOS>
A
large
supply
of
provisions
,
consisting
of
baked
meat
of
various
kinds
,
hard
-
boiled
eggs
,
pasties
,
bread
,
and
other
viands
,
calculated
to
serve
for
a
week
's
consumption
,
without
the
necessity
of
having
recourse
to
any
culinary
process
,
and
which
had
been
previously
procured
with
that
view
,
together
with
a
few
flasks
of
wine
,
occupied
the
place
in
the
boat
lately
assigned
to
the
powder
.
<EOS>
At
the
risk
of
overloading
the
vessel
,
they
likewise
increased
its
burthen
by
a
quantity
of
mining
implements
—
spades
,
pickaxes
,
augers
,
and
wrenching
irons
.
<EOS>
To
these
were
added
as
many
swords
,
calivers
,
pikes
,
and
petronels
,
as
the
space
left
would
accommodate
.
<EOS>
Garnet
and
Catesby
<EOS>
then
embarked,—the
former
having
taken
an
affectionate
farewell
of
Viviana
,
whom
he
committed
,
with
the
strictest
injunction
to
watch
over
her
,
to
the
care
of
Father
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
lingered
for
a
moment
,
doubting
whether
he
should
mention
his
rencounter
with
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
more
undecided
from
the
deep
affliction
in
which
she
was
plunged
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
he
determined
upon
slightly
hinting
at
the
subject
,
and
to
be
guided
as
to
what

further
by

manner

which
the

was
received
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
you
decide
upon
remaining
here
till
we
return
,
Viviana
?
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
She
made
a
sign
in
the
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
you
will
see
no
one?""No
one
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"But
,
should
any
old
friend
find
his
way
hither
—
Humphrey
Chetham
,
for
instance
—
will
you
not
receive
him?""Why
<EOS>
do
you
single
out
him
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Viviana
,
inquiringly
.
<EOS>
"
Is
he
in
London
?
<EOS>
Have
you
seen
him?""I
have
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
;
"
I
accidentally
met
him
to
-
night
,
and
have
shown
him
this
dwelling
.
<EOS>
He
will
come
hither
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
""I
wanted
only
this
to
make
me
thoroughly
wretched
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
clasping
her

with

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
what
unhappy

threw
him
across
your
path
?
<EOS>
Why
did
you
tell
him
I
was
here
?
<EOS>
Why
give
him
a
hope
that
I
would
see
him
?
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
see
him
.
<EOS>
I
will
quit
this
house
rather
than
be
exposed
to
the
meeting
.
<EOS>
""What
means
this
sudden

,
Viviana
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Guy
Fawkes
,
greatly

by

.
<EOS>
"
Why
should
a
visit
from
Humphrey
Chetham
occasion
you

know
not
,
"
she
answered
,
blushing

;
"
but
I
will
not
hazard
it
.
<EOS>
""I
thought
you
superior
to
your
sex
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
"
and
should
never
have

you
of
waywardness
or

.
<EOS>
""You
charge
me
with
failings
that
do
not
belong
to
me
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
neither
wayward
nor
capricious
;
but
I
would
be
willingly
spared
the
pain
of
an

with
one
whom
I
thought
I
loved
.
<EOS>
""Thought
you
loved
!
"
echoed
Fawkes
,
in

.
<EOS>
"Ay
,
thought
,
"
repeated
Viviana
,
"
for
I
have
since
examined
my
heart
,
and
find
he
has
no
place
in
it
.
<EOS>
""You
might
be
happy
with
him
,
Viviana
,
"

Fawkes
,

.
<EOS>
"I
might
have
been
,
"
she

,
"
had
circumstances
favoured
our
union
.
<EOS>
But
I
should
not
be
so
now
.
<EOS>
Recent
events
have
wrought
an
entire
change
in
my
feelings
.
<EOS>
Were
I
to
abandon
my
resolution
of
retiring
to
a
cloister,—were
<EOS>
I
to
return
to
the
world,—and
<EOS>
were

as

Humphrey
Chetham
should
conform

faith

Rome,—still
,
I
would
not
—
could
not
we
d
him
.
<EOS>
""I
grieve
to

,
"

Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Would
<EOS>
you
have
me
we
d
him
?
<EOS>
"
she
cried
,
in
a

.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
good

I
,
"
replied
Fawkes
;
"
and
I

than

one
more

,
and
of
less

.
<EOS>
"Viviana
made
no

,
and
her

upon

.
<EOS>
"You
will
see
him
,
"

Fawkes
,

,
"
if

.
<EOS>
""Since
<EOS>
you
desire
it
<EOS>
,
I

,
"
she

,

;
"
but
it
will
cost
me
a

.
<EOS>
""I
would
not
tax
you
with
it
,
if
I
did
not

needful
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
farewell
.
<EOS>
""Farewell,—it
may
be
,
for
ever
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
sadly
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
boat
is
ready
,
and
the
tide
ebbing
,
"
cried
Catesby
,
impatiently
,
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
be
aground
if
you
tarry
longer
.
<EOS>
""I
come
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
And
,
waving
an
adieu
to
Viviana
,
he
departed
.
<EOS>
"Strange
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
muttered
to
himself
,
as
he
took
his
way
to
the
creek
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
have
sworn
she
was
in
love
with
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
Who
can
have
superseded
him
in
her
regard
?
<EOS>
Not
Catesby
,
of
a
surety
.
'
<EOS>
Tis
a
perplexing
sex
.
<EOS>
The
best
are
fickle
.
<EOS>
Heaven
be
praised
!
<EOS>
I
have
long
been
proof
against
their
wiles
.
<EOS>
"Thus
musing
,
he
sprang
into
the
skiff
,
and
assisting
Catesby
to
push
it
into
deep
water
,
seized
an
oar
,
and
exerted
himself
stoutly
to
make
up
for
lost
time
.
<EOS>
The
second
voyage
was
as
prosperous
as
the
first
.
<EOS>
A
thick
veil
of
cloud
had
curtained
the
stars
;
the
steps
were
deserted
as
before
;
and
the
provisions
,
arms
,
and
implements
were
securely
conveyed
to
their
destination
.
<EOS>
Thus
far
fortune
seemed
to
favour
their
undertaking
,
and
Garnet
,
falling
on
his
knees
,
offered
up
the
most
fervent
thanksgivings
.
<EOS>
Prayers
over
,
they
descended
to
the
cellar
,
and
their
first
care
was
to
seek
out
a
place
as
free
from
damp
as
possible
,
where
the
powder
could
be
deposited
till
the
excavation
,
which
it
was
foreseen
<EOS>
would
be
a
work
of
time
and
great
labour
,
was
completed
.
<EOS>
A
dry
corner
being
found
,
the
barrels
were
placed
in
it
,
and
carefully
concealed
with
billets
of
wood
and
coals
,
so
as
to
avert
suspicion
in
case
of
search
.
<EOS>
This
,
with
other
arrangements
,
occupied
the
greater
part
of
the
night
,
and
the
commencement
of
the
important
undertaking
was
deferred
till
the
morrow
,
when
an
increase
of
their
party
was
anticipated
.
<EOS>
Throughout
the
whole
of
the
day
no
one
stirred
forth
.
<EOS>
The
windows
were
kept
closed
;
the
doors
locked
;
and
,
as
no
fires
were
lighted
,
the
house
had
the
appearance
of
being
uninhabited
.
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
the
morning
they
underwent
considerable
alarm
.
<EOS>
Some
mischievous
urchins
having
scaled
the
garden
wall
,
one
of
them
fell
within
it
,
and
his
cries
so
terrified
his
playmates
that
they
dropped
on
the
other
side
,
and
left
him
.
<EOS>
The
conspirators
reconnoitred
the
unhappy
urchin
,
who
continued
his
vociferations
in
a
loud
key
,
through
the
holes
in
the
shutters
,
uncertain
what
to
do
,
and
fearing
that
this
trifling
mischance
might
lead
to
serious
consequences
,
when
the
subject
of
their
uneasiness
relieved
them
by
scrambling
up
the
wall
near
the
door
,
and
so
effecting
a
retreat
.
<EOS>
With
this
exception
,
nothing
material
occurred
till
evening
,
when
their
expected
associates
arrived
.
<EOS>
The
utmost
caution
was
observed
in
admitting
them
.
<EOS>
The
new
-
comers
were
provided
with
a
key
of
the
garden
-
gate
,
but
a
signal
was
given
and
repeated
before
the
house
-
door
was
opened
by
Bates
,
to
whom
the
office
of
porter
was
intrusted
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
latter
had
satisfied
himself
that
all
was
right
,
by
unmasking
a
dark
lantern
,
and
throwing
its
radiance
upon
the
faces
of
the
elder
Wright
,
Rookwood
,
and
Percy
,
he
stamped
his
foot
thrice
,
and
the
conspirators
emerged
from
their
hiding
-
places
.
<EOS>
A
warm
greeting
passed
between
the
confederates
,
and
they
adjourned
to
a
lower
chamber
,
adjoining
the
vault
,
where
the
sound
of
their
voices
could
not
be
overheard
,
and
where
,
while
partaking
of
a
frugal
meal
—
for
they
desired
to
eke
out
their
store
of
provisions
as
long
as
possible
—
they
discoursed
upon
their
plans
,
and
all
that
had
occurred
since
their
last
meeting
.
<EOS>
Nothing
was
said
of
the
treachery
of
Tresham
—
his
recent
conduct
,
as
already
observed
,
having
been
such
as
to
restore
him
in
a
great
degree
to
the
confidence
of
his
companions
.
<EOS>
Percy
,
whose
office
as
a
gentleman
-
pensioner
gave
him
the
best
opportunities
of
hearing
court
-
whispers
and
secrets
,
informed
them
it
was
rumoured
that
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
had
obtained
a
clue
to
some
Catholic
plot
,
whether
their
own
he
could
not
say
;
but
it
would
seem
from
all
that
could
be
gathered
,
that
his
endeavours
to
trace
it
out
had
been
frustrated
.
<EOS>
"Where
is
Lord
Mounteagle
?
"
demanded
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
his
mansion
near
Hoxton
,
"
replied
Percy
.
<EOS>
"Have
<EOS>
you
observed
him
much
about
the
court
of
late
,
or
with
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
?
<EOS>
"
pursued
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"No
,
"
replied
Percy
.
"
<EOS>
Yet
now
,
I
bethink
me
,
I
did
observe
them
together
,
and
in
earnest
conversation
about
a
week
ago
.
<EOS>
But
Lord
Mounteagle
knows
nothing
of
our
plot
.
<EOS>
""Hum
!
"
exclaimed
Catesby
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
,
while
significant
looks
were
exchanged
by
the
others
,
and
Tresham
hung
his
head
.
"
<EOS>
Lord
Mounteagle
may
not
know
that
you
or
I
,
or
Fawkes
,
or
Rookwood
,
are
conspiring
against
the
State
;
but
he
knows
that
a
plot
is
hatching
amongst
our
party
.
<EOS>
It
is
from
him
that
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
derived
his
information
.
""Amazement
!
"
exclaimed
Percy
.
<EOS>
"A
good
Catholic
,
and
betray
his
fellows
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Rookwood
;
"
this
passes
my
comprehension
.
<EOS>
Are
you
sure
of
it?""Unhappily
we
are
so
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
gravely
.
<EOS>
"We
will
speak
of
this
hereafter
,
"
interposed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
plan
to
get
his
lordship
into
our
power
,
and
make
him
serve
our
purposes
in
spite
of
himself
.
<EOS>
We
will
outwit
the
crafty
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
Can
any
one
tell
if
Tresham
's
sudden
disappearance
has
been
noticed
.
<EOS>
""His
<EOS>
household
report
that
he
is
on
a
visit
to
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
at
Gothurst
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Rookwood
.
<EOS>
"
I
called
at
his
residence
yesterday
,
and
was
informed
that
a
letter
had
just
been
received
from
him
dated
from
that
place
.
<EOS>
His
departure
,
they
said
,
was
sudden
,
but
his
letter
fully
accounted
for
it
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
messenger
who
bore
that
letter
had
only
to
travel
from
Lambeth
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
smiling
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
I
conclude
,
"
returned
Rookwood
.
<EOS>
"And
,
now
that
our
meal
is
ended
,
let
us
to
work
,
"
cried
Fawkes
,
who
had
taken
no
part
in
the
foregoing
conversation
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
strike
the
first
blow
,
"
he
added
,
rising
and
seizing
a
mattock
.
<EOS>
"Hold
,
my
son
!
"
exclaimed
Garnet
,
arresting
him
.
"
<EOS>
The
work
upon
which
the
redemption
of
our
holy
church
hangs
must
be
commenced
with
due
solemnity
.
<EOS>
""You
are
right
,
father
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
humbly
.
<EOS>
Headed
by
Garnet
,
bearing
a
crucifix
,
they
then
repaired
to
the
vault
.
<EOS>
A
silver
chalice
,
filled
with
holy
water
,
was
carried
by
Fawkes
,
and
two
lighted
tapers
by
Catesby
.
<EOS>
Kneeling
down
before
that
part
of
the
wall
against
which
operations
were
about
to
be
directed
,
and
holding
the
crucifix
towards
it
,
Garnet
commenced
praying
in
a
low
but
earnest
tone
,
gradually
raising
his
voice
,
and
increasing
in
fervour
as
he
proceeded
.
<EOS>
The
others
knelt
around
him
,
and
the
whole
formed
a
strange
and
deeply
-
interesting
group
.
<EOS>
The
vault
itself
harmonized
with
its
occupants
.
<EOS>
It
was
of
great
antiquity
;
and
its
solid
stone
masonry
had
acquired
a
time
-
worn
hoary
tint
.
<EOS>
In
width
it
was
about
nine
feet
,
and
of
corresponding
height
,
supported
by
a
semi
-
circular
arch
,
and
its
length
was
more
than
twenty
feet
.
<EOS>
The
countenances
of
the
conspirators
showed
that
they
were
powerfully
moved
by
what
was
passing
;
but
next
to
Garnet
,
Guy
Fawkes
exhibited
the
greatest
enthusiasm
.
<EOS>
His
ecstatic
looks
and
gestures
evinced
the
strong
effect
produced
upon
his
superstitious
character
by
the
scene
.
<EOS>
Garnet
concluded
his
prayer
as
follows:—"Thus
far
,
O
Lord
,
we
have
toiled
in
darkness
and
in
difficulty
;
but
we
have
now
arrived
at
a
point
where
all
thy
support
is
needed
.
<EOS>
Do
not
desert
us
,
we
beseech
thee
,
but
let
thy
light
guide
us
through
these
gloomy
paths
.
<EOS>
Nerve
our
arms,—sharpen
our
weapons,—and
crumble
these
hard
and
flinty
stones
,
so
that
they
may
yield
to
our
efforts
.
<EOS>
Aid
our
enterprise
,
if
thou
approvest
it
,
and
it
be
really
,
as
in
our
ignorance
we
believe
it
to
be
,
for
the
welfare
of
thy
holy
Church
,
and
the
confusion
of
its
enemies
.
<EOS>
Bear
witness
,
O
Lord
,
that
we
devote
ourselves
wholly
and
entirely
to
this
one
<EOS>
end,—and
<EOS>
that
we
implore
success
only
for
thy
glory
and
honour
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
he
arose
,
and
the
following
strains
were
chanted
by
the
whole
assemblage:—HYMN
OF
THE
CONSPIRATORS.The
heretic
and
heathen
,
Lord
,
Consume
with
fire
,
cut
down
with
sword
;
The
spoilers
from
thy
temples
thrust
,
Their
altars
trample
in
the
dust
.
<EOS>
False
princes
and
false
priests
lay
low
,
Their
habitations
fill
with
woe
.
<EOS>
Scatter
them
,
Lord
,
with
sword
and
flame
,
And
bring
them
utterly
to
shame
.
<EOS>
Thy
vengeful
arm
no
longer
stay
,
Arise
!
<EOS>
exterminate
,
and
slay
.
<EOS>
So
shall
thy
fallen
worship
be
Restored
to
its
prosperity
.
<EOS>
This
hymn
raised
the
enthusiasm
of
the
conspirators
to
the
highest
pitch
,
and
such
was
the
effect
produced
by
it
,
as
it
rolled
in
sullen
echoes
along
the
arched
roof
of
the
vault
,
that
several
of
them
drew
their
swords
,
and
crossed
the
blades
,
with
looks
of
the
most
determined
devotion
to
their
cause
.
<EOS>
When
it
was
ended
,
Garnet
recited
other
prayers
,
and
sprinkled
holy
water
upon
the
wall
,
and
upon
every
implement
about
to
be
used
,
bestowing
a
separate
benediction
on
each
.
<EOS>
As
he
delivered
the
pick
-
axe
to
Guy
Fawkes
,
he
cried
in
a
solemn
voice—"Strike
,
my
son
,
in
the
name
of
the
Most
High
,
and
in
behalf
of
our
holy
religion,—strike!"Guy
Fawkes
raised
the
weapon
,
and
stimulated
by
excitement
,
threw
the
whole
strength
of
his
arm
into
the
blow
.
<EOS>
A
large
piece
of
the
granite
was
chipped
off
,
but
the
mattock
snapped
in
twain
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
looked
deeply
disconcerted
,
and
Garnet
,
though
he
concealed
his
emotion
,
was
filled
with
dismay
.
<EOS>
"Let
<EOS>
me
take
your
place
,
"
cried
Keyes
,
advancing
,
as
Guy
Fawkes
retired
.
<EOS>
Keyes
was
a
powerful
man
,
and
exerting
his
energies
,
he
buried
the
point
of
the
pick
-
axe
so
deeply
in
the
mortar
,
that
he
could
not
remove
it
unassisted
.
<EOS>
These
untoward
circumstances
cast
a
slight
damp
upon
their
ardour
;
but
Catesby
,
who
perceived
it
,
went
more
cautiously
to
work
,
and
in
a
short
time
succeeded
with
great
labour
in
getting
out
the
large
stone
upon
which
the
others
had
expended
so
much
useless
exertion
.
<EOS>
The
sight
restored
their
confidence
,
and
as
many
as
could
work
in
the
narrow
space
joined
him
.
<EOS>
But
they
found
that
their
task
was
much
more
arduous
than
they
had
anticipated
.
<EOS>
More
than
an
hour
elapsed
before
they
could
loosen
another
stone
,
and
though
they
laboured
with
the
utmost
perseverance
,
relieving
each
other
by
turns
,
they
had
made
but
a
small
breach
when
morning
arrived
.
<EOS>
The
stones
were
as
hard
and
unyielding
as
iron
,
and
the
mortar
in
some
places
harder
than
the
stones
.
<EOS>
After
a
few
hours
'
rest
,
they
resumed
their
task
.
<EOS>
Still
,
they
made
but
small
progress
;
and
it
was
not
until
the
third
day
that
they
had
excavated
a
hole
sufficiently
wide
and
deep
to
admit
one
man
within
it
.
<EOS>
They
were
now
arrived
at
a
compost
of
gravel
and
flint
stones
;
and
if
they
had
found
their
previous
task
difficult
,
what
they
had
now
to
encounter
was
infinitely
more
so
.
<EOS>
Their
implements
made
little
or
no
impression
on
this
unyielding
substance
,
and
though
they
toiled
incessantly
,
the
work
proceeded
with
disheartening
slowness
.
<EOS>
The
stones
and
rubbish
were
conveyed
at
dead
of
night
in
hampers
into
the
garden
,
and
buried
.
<EOS>
One
night
,
when
they
were
labouring
as
usual
,
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
was
foremost
in
the
excavation
,
thought
he
heard
the
tolling
of
a
bell
within
the
wall
.
<EOS>
He
instantly
suspended
his
task
,
and
being
convinced
that
he
was
not
deceived
,
crept
out
of
the
hole
,
and
made
a
sign
to
the
others
to
listen
.
<EOS>
Each
had
heard
the
awful
sound
before
;
but
as
it
was
partially
drowned
by
the
noise
of
the
pick
-
axe
,
it
had
not
produced
much
impression
upon
them
,
as
they
attributed
it
to
some
vibration
in
the
wall
,
caused
by
the
echo
of
the
blows
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
now
distinctly
audible
—
deep
,
clear
,
slow,—like
<EOS>
a
passing
bell,—but
<EOS>
so
solemn
,
so
unearthly
,
that
its
tones
froze
the
blood
in
their
veins
.
<EOS>
IllustrationThey
listened
for
a
while
in
speechless
astonishment
,
scarcely
daring
to
look
at
each
other
,
and
expecting
each
moment
that
the
building
would
fall
upon
them
,
and
bury
them
alive
.
<EOS>
The
light
of
a
single
lantern
placed
upon
an
upturned
basket
fell
upon
figures
rigid
as
statues
,
and
countenances
charged
with
awe
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
arm
is
paralysed
,
"
said
Guy
Fawkes
,
breaking
silence
;
"
I
can
work
no
more
.
<EOS>
""Try
<EOS>
holy
water
,
father
,
"
cried
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
If
it
proceeds
from
aught
of
evil
,
that
will
quell
it
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
chalice
containing
the
sacred
lymph
was
brought
,
and
pronouncing
a
solemn
exorcism
,
Garnet
sprinkled
the
wall
.
<EOS>
The
sound
immediately
ceased
.
<EOS>
"It
is
as
I
thought
,
father
,
"
observed
Catesby
;
"
it
is
the
delusion
of
an
evil
spirit
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
the
tolling
of
the
mysterious
bell
was
again
heard
,
and
more
solemnly,—more
slowly
than
before
.
<EOS>
"Sprinkle
<EOS>
the
wall
again
,
in
Heaven
's
name
,
father
,
"
cried
Fawkes
,
crossing
himself
devoutly
.
"
<EOS>
Avoid
thee
,
Sathanas!"Garnet
complied
,
and
throwing
holy
water
upon
the
stones
,
the
same
result
followed
.
<EOS>
V.
—
THE
CAPTURE
OF
VIVIANAOn
<EOS>
the
morning
after
his
encounter
with
Guy
Fawkes
,
Humphrey
Chetham
,
accompanied
by
Martin
Heydocke
,
took
his
way
to
Lambeth
Marsh
.
<EOS>
With
a
throbbing
heart
he
approached
the
miserable
dwelling
he
knew
to
be
inhabited
by
Viviana
,
and
could
scarcely
summon
courage
to
knock
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
His
first
summons
not
being
answered
,
he
repeated
it
more
loudly
,
and
he
then
perceived
the
face
of
Father
Oldcorne
at
the
window
,
who
,
having
satisfied
himself
that
it
was
a
friend
,
admitted
him
and
his
attendant
.
<EOS>
"You
were
expected
,
my
son
,
"
said
the
priest
,
after
a
friendly
greeting
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
has
prepared
Viviana
for
your
coming
.
<EOS>
""Will
<EOS>
she
not
see
me
?
"
demanded
the
young
merchant
,
uneasily
.
<EOS>
"I
believe
so
,
"
replied
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
will
apprise
her
of
your
arrival
.
<EOS>
Be
seated
,
my
son
.
"He
<EOS>
then
carefully
fastened
the
door
,
and
repaired
to
Viviana
's
chamber
,
leaving
Chetham
in
that
state
of
tremor
and
anxiety
which
a
lover
,
hoping
to
behold
his
mistress
,
only
knows
.
<EOS>
It
was
some
time
before
Viviana
appeared
,
and
the
young
merchant
,
whose
heart
beat
violently
at
the
sound
of
her
footstep
,
was
startled
by
the
alteration
in
her
looks
,
and
the
extreme
coldness
of
her
manner
.
<EOS>
Oldcorne
was
with
her
,
and
motioning
Martin
Heydocke
to
follow
him
,
the
youthful
pair
were
left
alone
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
desire
to
see
me
<EOS>
,
I
am
given
to
understand
,
sir
,
"
observed
Viviana
,
in
a
freezing
tone
.
<EOS>
"I
have
journeyed
to
London
for
that
express
purpose
,
"
replied
Humphrey
Chetham
,
tremulously
.
<EOS>
"I
am
much
beholden
to
you
,
sir
,
"
returned
Viviana
,
in
the
same
repelling
tone
as
before
;
"
but
I
regret
you
should
have
taken
so
much
trouble
on
my
account
.
<EOS>
""To
<EOS>
serve
you
is
happiness
,
not
trouble
,
Viviana
,
"
replied
Humphrey
Chetham
,
ardently
;
"
and
I
am
overjoyed
at
finding
an
opportunity
of
proving
my
devotion
.
<EOS>
""I
have
yet
to
learn
what
service
I
must
thank
you
for
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"I
can
scarcely
say
that
I
am
warranted
in
thus
intruding
upon
you
,
"
replied
Chetham
,
greatly
abashed
;
"
but
,
having
learnt
from
my
servant
,
Martin
Heydocke
,
that
Doctor
Dee
had
set
out
for
London
,
with
the
view
of
seeking
you
out
,
and
withdrawing
you
from
your
present
associates
,
I
was
determined
to
be
beforehand
with
him
,
and
to
acquaint
you
,
if
possible
,
with
his
intentions
.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
you
say
surprises
me
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Dee
has
no
right
to
interfere
with
my
actions
.
<EOS>
Nor
should
I
obey
him
<EOS>
were
he
to
counsel
me
,
as
is
scarcely
probable
,
to
quit
my
companions
.
<EOS>
""I
know
not
what
connexion
there
may
be
between
you
to
justify
the
interposition
of
his
authority
,
"
replied
Chetham
;
"
neither
did
I
tarry
to
inquire
.
<EOS>
But
presuming
from
what
I
heard
,
that
he
would
attempt
to
exercise
some
control
over
you
,
I
set
out
at
once
,
and
,
without
guide
to
your
retreat
,
or
the
slightest
knowledge
of
it
,
was
fortunate
enough
,
on
the
very
night
of
my
arrival
in
London
,
to
chance
upon
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
directed
me
to
you
.
<EOS>
""I
am
aware
of
it
,
"
was
the
chilling
answer
.
<EOS>
"I
will
not
avouch
,
"
pursued
Chetham
,
passionately
,
"
that
I
have
not
been
actuated
as
much
by
an
irrepressible
desire
to
see
you
again
,
as
by
anxiety
to
apprise
you
of
Doctor
Dee
's
coming
.
<EOS>
I
wanted
only
a
slight
excuse
to
myself
to
induce
me
to
yield
to
my
inclinations
.
<EOS>
Your
departure
made
me
wretched
.
<EOS>
I
thought
I
had
more
control
over
myself
.
<EOS>
But
I
find
I
can
not
live
without
you
.
<EOS>
""Alas
!
<EOS>
alas
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
in
a
troubled
tone
,
and
losing
all
her
self
-
command
.
<EOS>
"
I
expected
this
.
<EOS>
Why
—
why
did
you
come?""I
have
told
you
my
motive
,
"
replied
Chetham
;
"
but
,
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
do
not
reproach
me!""I
do
not
desire
to
do
so
,
"
returned
Viviana
,
with
a
look
of
agony
.
<EOS>
"
I
bitterly
reproach
myself
that
I
can
not
meet
you
as
of
old
.
<EOS>
But
I
would
rather
—
far
rather
have
encountered
Doctor
Dee
,
had
he
come
hither
resolved
to
exert
all
his
magical
power
to
force
me
away
,
than
have
met
you
.
<EOS>
""Have
<EOS>
I
unwittingly
offended
you
,
Viviana
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Chetham
,
in
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"Oh
!
<EOS>
no
—
no
—
no
!
"
<EOS>
she
replied
,
"
you
have
not
offended
me
;
<EOS>
but——""But
what
?
<EOS>
"
he
cried
,
anxiously
.
<EOS>
"I
would
rather
have
died
than
see
you
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"I
will
not
inquire
wherefore
,
"
rejoined
Chetham
,
"
because
I
too
well
divine
the
cause
.
<EOS>
I
am
no
longer
what
I
was
to
you
.
<EOS>
""Press
<EOS>
this
matter
<EOS>
no
further
,
I
pray
of
you
,
"
returned
Viviana
,
in
much
confusion
,
and
blushing
deeply
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
ever
esteem
you,—ever
feel
the
warmest
gratitude
to
you
.
<EOS>
And
what
matters
it
whether
my
heart
is
estranged
from
you
or
not
,
since
I
can
never
we
d
<EOS>
you?""What
matters
it
?
<EOS>
"
repeated
the
young
merchant
,
in
accents
of
despair,—"it
matters
much
.
<EOS>
Drowning
love
will
cling
to
straws
.
<EOS>
The
thought
that
I
was
beloved
by
you
,
though
I
could
never
hope
to
possess
your
hand
,
reconciled
me
in
some
degree
to
my
fate
.
<EOS>
But
now
,
"
he
added
,
covering
his
face
with
his
hands,—"now
,
my
heart
is
crushed
.
<EOS>
""Nay
,
say
not
so
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
in
a
voice
of
the
deepest
emotion
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
love
you,—as
a
sister
.
<EOS>
""That
is
small
comfort
,
"
rejoined
Chetham
,
bitterly
.
<EOS>
"
I
echo
your
own
wish
.
<EOS>
Would
we
had
never
met
again
!
<EOS>
I
might
,
at
least
,
have
deluded
myself
into
the
belief
that
you
loved
me
.
<EOS>
""It
would
have
been
better
so
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
inflict
pain
on
no
one
—
far
less
on
you
,
whom
I
regard
so
much
,
and
to
whom
I
owe
so
much
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
owe
me
nothing
,
Viviana
,
"
rejoined
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
All
I
desired
was
to
serve
you
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
the
dangers
we
have
shared
together
,
I
felt
no
alarm
except
for
your
sake
.
<EOS>
I
have
done
nothing
—
nothing
.
<EOS>
Would
I
had
died
for
you!""Calm
yourself
,
<EOS>
sir
,
I
entreat
you
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
did
love
me
once
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Chetham
,
suddenly
.
<EOS>
"I
thought
so
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
The
young
merchant
uttered
an
exclamation
of
anguish
,
and
a
mournful
pause
ensued
,
broken
only
by
his
groans
.
<EOS>
"Answer
<EOS>
me
,
Viviana
,
"
he
said
,
turning
abruptly
upon
her,—"answer
me
,
and
,
in
mercy
,
answer
truly,—do
<EOS>
you
love
another?""It
<EOS>
is
a
question
I
can
not
answer
,
"
she
replied
,
becoming
ashy
pale
.
<EOS>
"Your
looks
speak
for
you
!
"
<EOS>
he
vociferated
,
in
a
terrible
tone,—"you
do
!
<EOS>
His
name?—his
name?—that
<EOS>
I
may
wreak
my
vengeance
upon
him
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
violence
terrifies
me
,
"
returned
Viviana
,
withdrawing
the
hand
he
had
seized
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
put
an
end
to
this
interview
.
<EOS>
""Pardon
me
,
Viviana
!
"
cried
Chetham
,
falling
on
his
knees
before
her—"in
pity
pardon
me
!
<EOS>
I
am
not
myself
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
calmer
presently
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
knew
the
anguish
of
the
wound
you
have
inflicted
,
you
would
not
add
to
it
.
<EOS>
""Heaven
<EOS>
knows
I
would
not
!
"
<EOS>
she
returned
,
motioning
him
to
rise
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
if
it
will
lighten
your
suffering
,
know
that
the
love
I
feel
for
another
—
if
love
,
indeed
,
it
be,—is
as
hopeless
as
your
own
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
not
a
love
of
which
even
you
could
be
jealous
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
higher
and
a
holier
passion
.
<EOS>
It
is
affection
mixed
with
admiration
,
and
purified
from
all
its
grossness
.
<EOS>
It
is
more
,
perhaps
,
than
the
love
of
a
daughter
for
her
father
—
but
it
is
nothing
more
.
<EOS>
I
shall
never
we
d
him
<EOS>
I
love
—
could
not
if
I
would
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
I
would
shun
him
,
if
I
did
not
feel
that
the
hour
will
soon
come
when
the
extent
of
my
affection
must
be
proved
.
<EOS>
""This
is
strange
sophistry
,
"
returned
Chetham
;
"
and
you
may
deceive
yourself
by
it
,
but
you
can
not
deceive
me
.
<EOS>
You
love
as
all
ardent
natures
do
love
.
<EOS>
But
in
what
way
do
you
mean
to
prove
your
affection?""Perhaps
,
by
the
sacrifice
of
my
life
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"I
can
tell
you
who
is
the
object
of
your
affections
!
"
said
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
deny
it
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
he
is
.
<EOS>
""Hear
<EOS>
me
,
then
,
"
exclaimed
Chetham
,
who
appeared
inexpressibly
relieved
by
the
discovery
he
had
made
;
"
in
my
passage
across
the
river
with
him
last
night
,
our
conversation
turned
on
the
one
subject
ever
nearest
<EOS>
my
heart
<EOS>
,
yourself,—and
Guy
Fawkes
not
only
bade
me
not
despair
,
but
promised
to
aid
my
suit
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
he
kept
his
word
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
"
for
,
while
announcing
your
proposed
visit
,
he
urged
me
strongly
in
your
behalf
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
he
knows
not
of
your
love
for
him
?
"
demanded
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
not
only
knows
it
not
,
but
never
shall
know
it
from
me,—nor
<EOS>
must
he
know
it
from
you
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
,
energetically
.
<EOS>
"Fear
<EOS>
it
not
,
"
said
Chetham
,
sighing
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
secret
I
shall
carefully
preserve
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
now
that
you
are
in
possession
of
it
,
"
she
answered
,
"
I
no
longer
feel
your
presence
as
a
restraint
.
<EOS>
Let
me
still
regard
you
as
a
friend
.
<EOS>
""Be
it
<EOS>
so
,
"
replied
Humphrey
Chetham
,
mournfully
;
"
and
<EOS>
as
a
friend
let
me
entreat
you
to
quit
this
place
,
and
abandon
your
present
associates
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
seek
to
turn
your
heart
from
Fawkes
—
nor
will
I
try
to
regain
the
love
I
have
lost
.
<EOS>
But
let
me
implore
you
to
pause
ere
you
irretrievably
mix
yourself
up
with
the
fortunes
of
one
so
desperate
.
<EOS>
I
am
too
well
aware
that
he
is
engaged
in
a
fearful
plot
against
the
State,—though
<EOS>
I
know
not
its
precise
nature
.
<EOS>
""You
will
not
betray
him
?
"
<EOS>
she
cried
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
will
not
,
though
he
is
my
rival
,
"
returned
Chetham
.
"
<EOS>
But
others
may
—
nay
,
perhaps
have
done
so
already
.
<EOS>
""Whom
<EOS>
do
you
suspect
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Viviana
,
in
the
greatest
alarm
.
<EOS>
"I
fear
Doctor
Dee
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
;
"
but
I
know
nothing
certainly
.
<EOS>
My
servant
,
Martin
Heydocke
,
who
is
in
the
Doctor
's
confidence
,
intimated
as
much
to
me
,
and
I
have
reason
to
think
that
his
journey
to
town
,
under
the
pretext
of
searching
for
you
,
is
undertaken
for
the
purpose
of
tracing
out
the
conspirators
,
and
delivering
them
to
the
Government
.
<EOS>
""Is
<EOS>
he
arrived
in
London
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Viviana
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"I
should
think
not
,
"
returned
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
I
passed
him
,
four
days
ago
,
on
this
side
Leicester
,
in
company
with
Kelley
and
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
""If
the
wretch
Topcliffe
was
with
him
<EOS>
,
your
conjectures
are
too
well
founded
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
warn
Guy
Fawkes
instantly
of
his
danger
.
<EOS>
""Command
my
services
in
any
way
,
"
said
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
know
not
what
to
do
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
after
a
pause
,
during
which
she
betrayed
the
greatest
agitation
.
<EOS>
"
I
dare
not
seek
him
out;—and
<EOS>
yet
,
if
I
do
not
,
he
may
fall
into
the
hands
of
the
enemy
.
<EOS>
I
must
see
him
at
all
hazards
.
<EOS>
""Suffer
<EOS>
me
to
go
with
you
,
"
implored
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
rely
upon
my
secrecy
.
<EOS>
And
now
I
have
a
double
motive
for
desiring
to
preserve
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
""You
are
,
indeed
,
truly
noble
-
hearted
and
generous
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
and
I
would
fully
confide
in
you
.
<EOS>
But
,
if
you
were
to
be
seen
by
the
others
,
you
would
be
certainly
put
to
death
.
<EOS>
Not
even
Fawkes
could
save
you
.
<EOS>
""I
will
risk
it
,
if
you
desire
it
,
and
it
will
save
him
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
,
devotedly
.
"
<EOS>
Nay
,
I
will
go
alone
.
<EOS>
""That
were
to
insure
your
destruction
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"
No
—
no
—
it
must
not
be
.
<EOS>
I
will
consult
with
Father
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
she
hurried
out
of
the
room
,
and
returned
in
a
short
time
with
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"Father
<EOS>
Oldcorne
is
of
opinion
that
our
friends
must
be
apprised
of
their
danger
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
And
he
thinks
it
needful
<EOS>
we
should
both
go
to
their
retreat
,
that
no
hindrance
may
be
offered
to
our
flight
,
in
case
such
a
measure
should
be
resolved
upon
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
can
not
accompany
us
,
my
son
,
"
added
Oldcorne
;
"
for
though
I
am
as
fully
assured
of
your
fidelity
as
Viviana
,
and
would
confide
my
life
to
you
,
there
are
those
who
will
not
so
trust
you
,
and
who
might
rejoice
in
the
opportunity
of
removing
you
.
<EOS>
""Viviana
!
"
exclaimed
Chetham
,
looking
entreatingly
at
her
.
"For
<EOS>
my
sake,—if
not
for
your
own,—do
not
urge
this
further
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"
There
are
already
dangers
and
difficulties
enow
without
adding
to
them
.
<EOS>
You
would
be
safer
amid
a
horde
of
robbers
than
amidst
these
men
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
it
is
to
such
persons
you
commit
yourself
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Chetham
,
reproachfully
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
be
warned
by
me
,
ere
it
is
too
late
!
<EOS>
Abandon
them!""It
is
too
late
,
already
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
The
die
is
cast
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
I
can
only
lament
it
,
"
returned
Chetham
,
sadly
.
"
<EOS>
Suffer
me
,
at
least
,
to
accompany
you
to
some
place
near
their
retreat
,
that
you
may
summon
me
in
case
of
need
.
<EOS>
""There
can
be
no
objection
to
that
,
Viviana
,
"
observed
Oldcorne
;
"
provided
Humphrey
Chetham
will
promise
not
to
follow
us
.
<EOS>
""Readily
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
.
<EOS>
"I
am
unwilling
to
expose
him
to
further
risk
on
my
account
,
"
said
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
But
be
it
as
you
will
.
<EOS>
"It
was
then
agreed
,
that
they
should
not
set
out
till
nightfall
,
but
proceed
,
as
soon
as
it
grew
dark
,
to
Lambeth
,
where
Humphrey
Chetham
undertook
to
procure
a
boat
for
their
conveyance
across
the
river
.
<EOS>
The
hour
of
departure
at
length
arrived
.
<EOS>
Viviana
,
who
had
withdrawn
to
her
own
room
,
appeared
in
her
travelling
habit
,
and
was
about
to
set
forth
with
her
companions
,
when
they
were
all
startled
by
a
sudden
and
loud
knocking
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
"We
are
discovered
,
"
she
cried
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Dee
has
found
out
our
retreat
.
<EOS>
""Fear
nothing
<EOS>
,
"
rejoined
Chetham
,
drawing
his
sword
,
while
his
example
was
imitated
by
Martin
Heydocke
;
"
they
shall
not
capture
you
while
I
live
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
the
knocking
was
repeated
,
and
the
door
shaken
so
violently
as
to
threaten
to
burst
its
fastenings
.
<EOS>
"Extinguish
<EOS>
the
light
,
"
whispered
Chetham
,
"
and
let
Father
Oldcorne
conceal
himself
.
<EOS>
We
have
nothing
to
fear
.
<EOS>
""Where
<EOS>
shall
I
fly
?
"
cried
Oldcorne
despairingly
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
impossible
to
raise
the
flag
,
and
seek
refuge
in
the
vault
.
<EOS>
""Fly
<EOS>
to
my
room
,
"
cried
Viviana
.
<EOS>
And
finding
he
stood
irresolute
,
as
if
paralysed
with
terror
,
she
took
his
arm
,
and
dragged
him
away
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
the
door
was
burst
open
with
a
loud
crash
,
and
several
armed
men
,
with
their
swords
drawn
,
followed
by
Topcliffe
,
and
another
middle
-
aged
man
,
of
slight
stature
,
and
rather
under
-
sized
,
but
richly
dressed
,
and
bearing
all
the
marks
of
exalted
rank
,
rushed
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
"You
are
my
prisoner
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Topcliffe
,
rushing
up
to
Chetham
,
who
had
planted
himself
,
with
Martin
Heydocke
,
at
the
foot
of
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
"
I
arrest
you
in
the
King
's
name!""You
are
mistaken
in
your
man
,
sir
,
"
cried
Chetham
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
committed
no
offence
.
<EOS>
Lay
a
hand
upon
me
,
at
your
peril!""How
is
this
?
"
cried
Topcliffe
.
"
<EOS>
Humphrey
Chetham
here!""Ay
,
"
returned
the
young
merchant
;
"
you
have
fallen
upon
the
wrong
house
.
<EOS>
""Not
<EOS>
so
,
sir
,
"
replied
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
satisfied
from
your
presence
that
I
am
right
.
<EOS>
Where
you
are
,
Viviana
Radcliffe
is
not
far
off
.
<EOS>
Throw
down
your
arms
.
<EOS>
You
can
offer
no
resistance
to
my
force
,
and
your
zeal
will
not
benefit
your
friends
,
while
it
will
place
your
own
safety
in
jeopardy
.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
Chetham
fiercely
refused
compliance
,
and
after
a
few
minutes
'
further
parley
,
the
soldiers
were
about
to
attack
him
,
when
Viviana
opened
a
door
above
,
and
slowly
descended
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
At
her
appearance
the
young
merchant
,
seeing
that
further
resistance
would
be
useless
,
sheathed
his
sword
,
and
she
passed
between
him
and
Heydocke
,
and
advanced
towards
the
leaders
of
the
band
.
<EOS>
"What
means
this
intrusion
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
.
<EOS>
"We
are
come
in
search
of
two
Jesuit
priests
,
whom
we
have
obtained
information
are
hidden
here
,
"
replied
Topcliffe;—"as
well
as
of
certain
other
Papists
,
disaffected
against
the
State
,
for
whose
apprehension
I
hold
a
warrant
.
<EOS>
""You
are
welcome
to
search
the
house
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
But
there
is
no
one
within
it
except
those
you
see
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
she
said
this
,
Chetham
,
who
gazed
earnestly
at
her
,
caught
her
eye
,
and
from
a
scarcely
-
perceptible
glance
,
felt
certain
that
the
priest
,
through
her
agency
,
had
effected
his
escape
.
<EOS>
But
the
soldiers
had
not
waited
for
her
permission
to
make
the
search
.
<EOS>
Rushing
up
-
stairs
they
examined
the
different
chambers,—there
were
two
small
rooms
besides
that
occupied
by
Viviana,—and
found
several
of
the
priests
'
habiliments
;
but
though
they
examined
every
corner
with
the
minutest
attention
,
sounded
the
walls
,
peered
up
the
chimneys
,
underneath
the
bed
,
and
into
every
place
,
likely
and
unlikely
,
they
could
find
no
other
traces
of
those
they
sought
,
and
were
compelled
to
return
to
their
leader
with
tidings
of
their
ill
success
.
<EOS>
Topcliffe
,
with
another
party
,
continued
his
scrutiny
below
,
and
discovering
the
moveable
flag
in
the
hearth
,
descended
into
the
vault
,
where
he
made
certain
of
discovering
his
prey
.
<EOS>
But
no
one
was
there
;
and
,
the
powder
and
arms
having
been
removed
,
he
gained
nothing
by
his
investigations
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
his
companion,—and
evidently
from
his
garb
,
and
the
deference
paid
him
,
though
he
was
addressed
by
no
title
which
could
lead
to
the
absolute
knowledge
of
his
rank
,
his
superior,—seated
himself
,
and
put
many
questions
in
a
courteous
but
authoritative
tone
to
Viviana
respecting
her
residence
in
this
solitary
abode,—the
names
of
her
companions,—where
<EOS>
they
were,—and
<EOS>
upon
what
scheme
they
were
engaged
.
<EOS>
To
none
of
these
questions
would
she
return
an
answer
,
and
her
interrogator
,
at
last
,
losing
patience
,
said,"I
hold
it
my
duty
,
to
inform
you
that
you
will
be
carried
before
the
Council
,
and
if
you
continue
thus
obstinate
,
means
will
be
taken
—
and
those
none
of
the
gentlest
—
to
extort
the
truth
from
you
.
<EOS>
""You
may
apply
the
torture
to
me
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
firmly
;
"
but
it
will
wrest
nothing
from
me
.
<EOS>
""That
remains
to
be
seen
,
"
replied
the
other
;
"
I
only
trust
you
will
not
compel
me
to
put
my
threat
into
execution
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
this
moment
Topcliffe
emerged
from
the
vault
,
and
the
soldiers
returned
from
their
unsuccessful
search
above
.
<EOS>
"They
have
escaped
us
now
,
"
remarked
Topcliffe
to
his
superior
.
"
<EOS>
But
I
will
conceal
a
party
of
men
on
the
premises
,
who
will
be
certain
to
capture
them
on
their
return
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
uttered
an
exclamation
of
irrepressible
uneasiness
,
which
did
not
escape
her
auditors
.
<EOS>
"I
am
right
<EOS>
,
you
see
,
"
observed
Topcliffe
,
significantly
,
to
his
companion
.
<EOS>
"You
are
so
,
"
replied
the
other
.
<EOS>
As
this
was
said
,
Viviana
hazarded
a
look
at
Humphrey
Chetham
,
the
meaning
of
which
he
was
not
slow
to
comprehend
.
<EOS>
He
saw
that
she
wished
him
to
make
an
effort
to
escape
,
that
he
might
warn
her
companions
,
and
regardless
of
the
consequence
,
be
prepared
to
obey
her
.
<EOS>
While
those
around
were
engaged
in
a
last
fruitless
search
,
he
whispered
his
intentions
to
Martin
Heydocke
,
and
only
awaited
a
favourable
opportunity
to
put
them
in
execution
.
<EOS>
It
occurred
sooner
than
he
expected
.
<EOS>
Before
quitting
the
premises
,
Topcliffe
determined
to
visit
the
upper
rooms
himself
,
and
he
took
several
of
the
men
with
him
.
<EOS>
Chetham
would
have
made
an
attempt
to
liberate
Viviana
,
but
,
feeling
certain
it
would
be
unsuccessful
,
he
preferred
obeying
her
wishes
to
his
own
inclinations
.
<EOS>
Topcliffe
gone
,
he
suddenly
drew
his
sword,—for
<EOS>
neither
he
nor
Heydocke
had
been
disarmed,—and
rushing
towards
the
door
,
struck
down
the
man
next
it
,
and
followed
by
his
servant
,
passed
through
it
before
he
could
be
intercepted
.
<EOS>
They
both
then
flew
at
a
swift
pace
towards
the
marshy
fields
,
and
,
owing
to
the
darkness
and
unstable
nature
of
the
ground
,
speedily
distanced
their
pursuers
.
<EOS>
Hearing
the
disturbance
below
,
and
guessing
its
cause
,
Topcliffe
immediately
descended
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
too
late
;
and
though
he
joined
in
the
pursuit
,
he
was
baffled
like
his
attendants
.
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
afterwards
,
he
returned
to
the
house
with
an
angry
and
disappointed
look
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
has
given
us
the
slip
,
"
he
observed
to
his
superior
,
who
appeared
exceedingly
provoked
by
the
young
merchant
's
flight
;
"
But
we
will
soon
have
him
again
.
"After
<EOS>
giving
directions
to
his
men
how
to
conceal
themselves
,
Topcliffe
informed
his
companions
that
he
was
ready
to
attend
him
.
<EOS>
Viviana
,
who
had
remained
motionless
and
silent
during
the
foregoing
scene
,
was
taken
out
of
the
house
,
and
conducted
towards
the
creek
,
in
which
lay
a
large
wherry
manned
by
four
rowers
.
<EOS>
She
was
placed
within
it
,
and
as
soon
as
his
superior
was
seated
,
Topcliffe
inquired—"Where
will
your
lordship
go
first?""To
<EOS>
the
Star
-
Chamber
,
"
was
the
answer
.
<EOS>
At
this
reply
,
in
spite
of
herself
,
Viviana
could
not
repress
a
shudder
.
<EOS>
"All
is
lost
!
"
she
mentally
ejaculated
.
<EOS>
VI
.
—
<EOS>
THE
CELLARIt
was
long
before
the
conspirators
gained
sufficient
courage
to
recommence
digging
the
mine
.
<EOS>
Whenever
holy
water
was
thrown
upon
the
stones
,
the
mysterious
bell
ceased
tolling
,
but
it
presently
began
anew
,
and
such
was
the
appalling
effect
of
the
sound
that
it
completely
paralysed
the
listeners
.
<EOS>
Prayers
were
said
by
Garnet
;
hymns
sung
by
the
others
;
but
all
was
of
no
avail
.
<EOS>
It
continued
to
toll
on
with
increased
solemnity
,
unless
checked
by
the
same
potent
application
as
before
.
<EOS>
The
effect
became
speedily
manifest
in
the
altered
looks
and
demeanour
of
the
conspirators
,
and
it
was
evident
that
if
something
was
not
done
to
arouse
them
,
the
enterprise
would
be
abandoned
.
<EOS>
Catesby
,
equally
superstitious
with
his
confederates
,
but
having
nerves
more
firmly
strung
,
was
the
first
to
conquer
his
terror
.
<EOS>
Crossing
himself
,
he
muttered
a
secret
prayer
,
and
,
snatching
up
a
pick
-
axe
,
entered
the
cavity
,
and
resumed
his
labour
.
<EOS>
The
noise
of
the
heavy
blows
dealt
by
him
against
the
wall
drowned
the
tolling
of
the
bell
.
<EOS>
The
charm
was
broken
.
<EOS>
And
stimulated
by
his
conduct
,
the
others
followed
his
example
,
and
though
the
awful
tolling
continued
at
intervals
during
the
whole
of
their
operations
,
it
offered
no
further
interruption
to
them
.
<EOS>
Another
and
more
serious
cause
of
anxiety
,
however
,
arose
.
<EOS>
As
the
work
advanced
,
without
being
aware
of
it
,
they
approached
the
bank
of
the
river
,
and
the
water
began
to
ooze
through
the
sides
of
the
excavation,—at
first
,
slightly
,
but
by
degrees
to
such
an
extent
as
to
convince
them
that
their
labour
would
be
entirely
thrown
away
.
<EOS>
Large
portions
of
the
clay
,
loosened
by
the
damp
,
fell
in
upon
them
,
nearly
burying
those
nearest
the
tumbling
mass
;
and
the
floor
was
now
in
some
places
more
than
a
foot
deep
in
water
,
clearly
proving
it
would
be
utterly
impossible
to
keep
the
powder
fit
for
use
in
such
a
spot
.
<EOS>
Catesby
bore
these
untoward
circumstances
with
ill
-
concealed
mortification
.
<EOS>
For
a
time
,
he
struggled
against
them
;
and
though
he
felt
that
it
was
hopeless
,
worked
on
like
a
desperate
military
leader
conducting
a
forlorn
hope
to
certain
destruction
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
however
,
the
water
began
to
make
such
incursions
that
he
could
no
longer
disguise
from
himself
or
his
companions
that
they
were
contending
against
insurmountable
difficulties
,
and
that
to
proceed
further
would
be
madness
.
<EOS>
He
,
therefore
,
with
a
heavy
heart
,
desisted
,
and
throwing
down
his
pick
-
axe
,
said
it
was
clear
that
Heaven
did
not
approve
their
design
,
and
that
it
must
be
relinquished
.
<EOS>
"We
ought
to
have
been
warned
by
that
doleful
bell
,
"
he
observed
in
conclusion
.
<EOS>
"
I
now
perceive
its
meaning
.
<EOS>
And
as
I
was
the
first
to
act
in
direct
opposition
to
the
declared
will
of
the
Supreme
Being
,
so
now
I
am
the
first
to
admit
my
error
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
account
for
that
dread
and
mysterious
sound
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
"
and
can
only
attribute
it
,
as
you
do
,
to
Divine
interference
.
<EOS>
But
whether
it
was
intended
as
a
warning
or
a
guidance
,
I
confess
I
am
unable
to
say
.
<EOS>
""Can
you
longer
doubt
,
father
,
"
returned
Catesby
,
bitterly
,
"
when
you
look
at
yon
excavation
?
<EOS>
It
took
us
more
than
a
week
's
incessant
labour
to
get
through
the
first
wall
;
and
our
toil
was
no
sooner
lightened
than
these
fatal
consequences
ensued
.
<EOS>
If
we
proceed
,
we
shall
drown
ourselves
,
instead
of
blowing
up
our
foes
.
<EOS>
And
even
if
we
should
escape
,
were
the
powder
stowed
for
one
day
in
that
damp
place
,
it
would
never
explode
.
<EOS>
We
have
failed
,
and
must
take
measures
accordingly
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
entirely
concur
with
you
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
;
"
we
must
abandon
our
present
plan
.
<EOS>
But
do
not
let
us
be
disheartened
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
at
this
very
moment
Heaven
is
preparing
for
us
a
victory
by
some
unlooked
-
for
means
.
<EOS>
""It
may
be
so
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
with
a
look
of
incredulity
.
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
an
extraordinary
noise
,
like
a
shower
of
falling
stones
,
was
heard
overhead
.
<EOS>
And
coupling
the
sound
with
their
fears
of
the
encroachment
of
the
damp
,
the
conspirators
glanced
at
each
other
in
dismay
,
thinking
the
building
was
falling
in
upon
them
.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
blessed
saints
protect
us
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Garnet
,
as
the
sound
ceased
.
<EOS>
"
What
was
that?"But
no
one
was
able
to
account
for
it
,
and
each
regarded
his
neighbour
with
apprehension
.
<EOS>
After
a
short
interval
of
silence
,
the
sound
was
heard
again
.
<EOS>
There
was
then
another
pause
—
and
again
the
same
rushing
and
inexplicable
noise
.
<EOS>
"What
<EOS>
can
it
be
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
enfeebled
by
this
underground
life
,
that
trifles
alarm
me
.
<EOS>
Are
our
enemies
pulling
down
the
structure
over
our
heads?—or
are
they
earthing
us
up
like
vermin
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
to
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
it?""I
will
go
and
see
,
"
replied
the
other
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
not
expose
yourself
,
my
son
,
"
cried
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
abide
the
result
here
.
<EOS>
""No
,
father
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
"
<EOS>
Having
failed
in
our
scheme
,
what
befals
me
is
of
little
consequence
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
.
<EOS>
If
I
return
not
,
you
will
understand
what
has
happened
.
<EOS>
"Pausing
for
a
moment
to
receive
Garnet
's
benediction
,
he
then
strode
away
.
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
elapsed
before
Fawkes
returned
,
and
the
interval
appeared
thrice
its
duration
in
the
eyes
of
the
conspirators
.
<EOS>
When
he
re
-
appeared
,
a
smile
sat
upon
his
countenance
,
and
his
looks
instantly
dispelled
the
alarm
that
had
been
previously
felt
.
<EOS>
"You
bring
us
good
news
,
my
son
?
"
cried
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"Excellent
,
father
,
"
replied
Fawkes
:
"
and
you
were
right
in
saying
that
at
the
very
moment
we
were
indulging
in
misgiving
,
Heaven
was
preparing
for
us
a
victory
by
unforeseen
and
mysterious
means
.
<EOS>
"Garnet
<EOS>
raised
his
hands
gratefully
and
reverentially
upwards
.
<EOS>
And
the
other
conspirators
crowded
round
Fawkes
to
listen
to
his
relation
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
noise
we
heard
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
,
"
arose
from
a
very
simple
circumstance,—and
when
you
hear
it
,
you
will
smile
at
your
fears
.
<EOS>
But
you
will
not
smile
at
the
result
to
which
it
has
led
.
<EOS>
Exactly
overhead
,
it
appears
,
a
cellar
is
situated
,
belonging
to
a
person
named
Bright
,
and
the
sound
was
occasioned
by
the
removal
of
his
coals
,
which
he
had
been
selling
off
.
<EOS>
""Is
<EOS>
that
all
?
"
cried
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
indeed
grown
childish
,
to
be
alarmed
by
such
a
cause
.
<EOS>
""It
appears
slight
now
it
is
explained
,
"
observed
Keyes
,
gravely
;
"
but
how
were
we
to
know
whence
it
arose?""True
,
"
returned
Fawkes
;
"
and
I
will
now
show
you
how
the
hand
of
Heaven
has
been
manifested
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
The
noise
which
led
me
to
this
investigation
,
and
which
I
regard
as
a
signal
from
on
high
,
brought
me
to
a
cellar
I
had
never
seen
before
,
and
knew
not
existed
.
<EOS>
That
cellar
lies
immediately
beneath
the
House
of
Lords
.
<EOS>
""Ah
!
<EOS>
I
see
!
"
exclaimed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You
think
it
would
form
a
good
depository
for
the
powder
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
it
had
been
built
for
the
express
purpose
,
it
could
not
be
better
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
commodious
and
dry
,
and
in
an
out
-
of
-
the
-
way
place
,
as
you
may
judge
,
when
we
ourselves
have
never
hitherto
noticed
it
.
<EOS>
""But
<EOS>
what
is
all
this
to
us
,
if
we
can
not
use
it
?
<EOS>
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"We
can
use
it
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
ours
.
<EOS>
"There
<EOS>
was
a
general
exclamation
of
surprise
.
<EOS>
"Finding
<EOS>
,
on
inquiry
,
that
Bright
was
about
to
quit
the
neighbourhood
,
"
continued
Fawkes
,
"
and
did
not
require
the
place
longer
,
I
instantly
proposed
to
take
it
from
him
,
and
to
create
no
suspicion
,
engaged
it
in
Percy
's
name
,
stating
that
he
wanted
it
for
his
own
fuel
.
<EOS>
""You
have
done
admirably
,
"
cried
Catesby
,
in
a
tone
of
exultation
.
<EOS>
"
The
success
of
the
enterprise
will
now
be
entirely
owing
to
you
.
""Not
<EOS>
to
me
,
but
to
the
Providence
that
directed
me
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
solemnly
.
<EOS>
"Right
,
my
son
,
"
returned
Garnet
.
"
<EOS>
And
let
this
teach
us
never
to
despair
again
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
next
day
,
Percy
having
taken
possession
of
the
cellar
,
it
was
carefully
examined
,
and
proved
,
as
Fawkes
had
stated
,
admirably
adapted
to
their
purpose
.
<EOS>
Their
fears
were
now
at
an
end
,
and
they
looked
on
the
success
of
their
project
as
certain
.
<EOS>
The
mysterious
bell
no
longer
tolled
,
and
their
sole
remaining
task
was
to
fill
up
the
excavation
so
far
as
to
prevent
any
damage
from
the
wet
.
<EOS>
This
was
soon
done
,
and
their
next
step
was
to
transport
the
powder
during
the
night
to
the
cellar
.
<EOS>
Concealing
the
barrels
as
before
with
faggots
and
coals
,
they
gave
the
place
the
appearance
of
a
mere
receptacle
for
lumber
,
by
filling
it
with
old
hampers
,
boxes
without
lids
,
broken

,
stone

,
and
other
rubbish
.
<EOS>
They
now
began
to
think
of
separating
,
and
Fawkes
expressed
his
intention
of
returning
that
night
to
the
house
at
Lambeth
.
<EOS>
No
intelligence
had
reached
them
of
Viviana
's
captivity
,
and
they
supposed
her
still
an
inmate
of
the
miserable
dwelling
with
Father
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
Fawkes
had
often
thought
of
her
,
and
with
uneasiness
,
during
his
toilsome
labours
;
but
they
had
so
much
engrossed
him
that
her
image
was
banished
almost
as
soon
as
it
arose
.
<EOS>
Now
that
grand
obstacle
was
surmounted
,
and
nothing
was
wanting
,
however
,
except
a
favourable
moment
to
strike
the
blow
,
he
began
to
feel
the
greatest
anxiety
respecting
her
.
<EOS>
Still
,
he
thought
it
prudent
to
postpone
his
return
to
a

hour
,
and
it
was
not
until
near

that
he
and
Catesby
ventured
to
their
boat
.
<EOS>
As
he
was
about
to
descend
the

,

by
some
one
at

;
and

next

,
a
man
,
whom

as
Humphrey

,

.
<EOS>
"You
here
again
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Fawkes
,
angrily
,
and
not

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
play
the

upon
me?""I
have
watched
for
you
for
the
last
ten
nights
,
"

Chetham
hastily
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
not
where
you
were
.
<EOS>
But
I
found
your
boat
here
,
and
I
hoped
you
would
not

the
water
in

.
<EOS>
""Why
<EOS>
all
this
care
?
"

.
"
<EOS>
Has
aught
<EOS>
happened?—Is
<EOS>
Viviana

,
man
!
<EOS>
do
not
keep
me
longer
in

!
"

,
"
she
is
a

.
<EOS>
"Illustration"A
prisoner
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Fawkes
,
in
a
hollow

.
"
<EOS>
Then
my
forebodings
were
not
without
cause
.
<EOS>
""How
has
this
happened
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
who
had

said

.
<EOS>
Chetham
then
hastily
related
all
that
had

.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
know
not
what
has

,
"
he

,

;
"
but
I
have

Star

<EOS>
he
,
it

,
was
the

of
Topcliffe,—and
,

of

,

to

,
and
<EOS>
,
I
fear
,
subjected

.
<EOS>
""Tortured
<EOS>
!
"
exclaimed
Fawkes
,

;
"
Viviana
tortured
!
<EOS>
And
I
have
brought
her
to
this
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
God
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
God!""It
is
indeed
an
agonizing
reflection
,
"
replied
Humphrey
Chetham
,
in
a

,
"
and
enough
to

.
<EOS>
Her
last

,

only
in

,
for
she

them
,
were

the
house
at
Lambeth
,

being

.
<EOS>
I

now

.
<EOS>
Farewell!"And
<EOS>
he

to

.
<EOS>
"Stay
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Catesby
,

.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Father
Oldcorne?""I
<EOS>
know
not
,
"
replied
Humphrey

.
<EOS>
"
As
I

told

,
Viviana
by

.
<EOS>
I
have
seen

.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
,
hurrying
away
,
he
was
lost
beneath
the
shadow
of
the
wall
.
<EOS>
"Is
<EOS>
this
a
troubled
dream
,
or
dread
reality
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Fawkes
to
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"I
fear
it
is
too
true
,
"
returned
the
other
,
in
a
voice
of
much
emotion
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Poor
Viviana!""Something
must
be
done
to
set
her
free
,
"
cried
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
purchase
her
liberty
by
delivering
up
myself
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
oath
—
remember
your
oath
!
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
destroy
yourself
,
but
not
your
associates
.
<EOS>
""True
—
true
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
distractedly,—"I
do
remember
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
sold
to
perdition
.
<EOS>
""Anger
<EOS>
not
Heaven
by
these
idle
lamentations,—and
at
a
time
,
too
,
when
all
is
so
prosperous
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"What
<EOS>
!
"
cried
Fawkes
,
fiercely
,
"
would
you
have
me
calm
,
when
she
who
called
me
father
,
and
was
dear
to
me
as
a
child
,
is
taken
from
me
by
these
remorseless
butchers,—subjected
to
their
terrible
examinations,—plunged
in
a
dismal
dungeon,—and
stretched
upon
the
rack,—and
<EOS>
all
for
me
—
for
me
!
<EOS>
I
shall
go
mad
if
I
think
upon
it!""You
must
not
think
upon
it
,
"
returned
Catesby,—"at
least
,
not
here
.
<EOS>
We
shall
be
observed
.
<EOS>
Let
us
return
to
the
house
;
and
perhaps
—
though
I
scarcely
dare
indulge
the
hope
—
some
plan
may
be
devised
for
her
liberation
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
dragged
Fawkes
,
who
was
almost
frenzied
with
anguish
,
forcibly
along
,
and
they
returned
to
the
house
.
<EOS>
Nothing
more
was
said
that
night
.
<EOS>
Catesby
judged
it
prudent
to
let
the
first
violence
of
his
friend
's
emotion
expend
itself
before
he
attempted
to
soothe
him
;
and
when
he
communicated
the
sad
event
to
Garnet
,
the
latter
strongly
approved
the
plan
.
<EOS>
Garnet
was
greatly
distressed
at
the
intelligence
,
and
his
affliction
was
shared
by
the
other
conspirators
.
<EOS>
No
fears
were
entertained
by
any
of
them
that
Viviana
would
reveal
aught
of
the
plot
,
but
this
circumstance
only
added
to
their
regrets
.
<EOS>
"I
will
stake
my
life
for
her
constancy
,
"
said
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
so
will
I
,
"
returned
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
She
will
die
a
martyr
for
us
.
"He
<EOS>
then
proposed
that
they
should
pray
for
her
deliverance
.
<EOS>
And
all
instantly
assenting
,
they
knelt
down
,
while
Garnet
poured
forth
the
most
earnest
supplications
to
the
Virgin
in
her
behalf
.
<EOS>
The
next
morning
,
Guy
Fawkes
set
forth
,
and
ascertained
that
Humphrey
Chetham
's
statement
was
correct
,
and
that
Viviana
was
indeed
a
prisoner
in
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
He
repaired
thither
,
and
tried
to
ascertain
in
what
part
of
the
fortress
she
was
confined
,
in
the
hope
of
gaining
admittance
to
her
.
<EOS>
But
as
he
could
obtain
no
information
and
his
inquiries
<EOS>
excited
suspicion
<EOS>
,
he
was
compelled
to
return
without
accomplishing
his
object
.
<EOS>
Crossing
Tower
Hill
on
his
way
back
,
he
turned
to
glance
at
the
stern
pile
he
had
just
quitted
,
and
which
was
fraught
with
the
most
fearful
interest
to
him
,
when
he
perceived
Chetham
issue
from
the
Bulwark
Gate
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
made
up
to
him
;
but
the
young
merchant
,
who
had
evidently
seen
him
,
though
he
looked
sedulously
another
way
,
set
off
in
the
direction
of
the
river
,
and
was
quickly
lost
to
view
.
<EOS>
Filled
with
the
gloomiest
thoughts
,
Guy
Fawkes
proceeded
to
Westminster
,
where
he
arrived
without
further
adventure
of
any
kind
.
<EOS>
In
the
latter
part
of
the
same
day
,
as
the
conspirators
were
conferring
together
,
they
were
alarmed
by
a
knocking
at
the
outer
gate
;
and
sending
Bates
to
reconnoitre
<EOS>
,
he
instantly
returned
with
the
intelligence
that
it
was
Lord
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
At
the
mention
of
this
name
,
Tresham
,
who
was
one
of
the
party
,
turned
pale
as
death
,
and
trembled
so
violently
that
he
could
scarcely
support
himself
.
<EOS>
Having
been
allowed
to
go
forth
on
that
day
,
the
visit
of
Lord
Mounteagle
at
this
juncture
,
coupled
with
the
agitation
it
occasioned
him
,
seemed
to
proclaim
him
guilty
of
treachery
for
the
second
time
.
<EOS>
"You
have
betrayed
us
,
villain
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
drawing
his
dagger
;
"
but
you
shall
not
escape
.
<EOS>
I
will
poniard
you
on
the
spot
.
<EOS>
""As
<EOS>
you
hope
for
mercy
,
do
not
strike
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
On
my
soul
,
I
have
not
seen
Lord
Mounteagle
,
and
know
not
,
any
more
than
yourselves
,
what
brings
him
hither
.
<EOS>
Put
it
to
the
proof
.
<EOS>
Let
him
come
in
.
<EOS>
Conceal
yourselves
,
and
you
will
hear
what
passes
between
us
.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
it
be
so
,
"
interposed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
step
within
this
closet
,
the
door
of
which
shall
remain
ajar
.
<EOS>
From
it
I
can
watch
him
without
being
observed
,
and
if
aught
occurs
to
confirm
our
suspicions
,
he
dies
.
<EOS>
""Bates
<EOS>
shall
station
himself
in
the
passage
,
and
stab
him
if
he
attempts
to
fly
,
"
added
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
sword
,
sir
.
<EOS>
""It
is
here
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
delivering
it
to
Catesby
,
who
handed
it
to
Bates
.
"
<EOS>
Are
you
satisfied?""Is
Lord
Mounteagle
alone
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Catesby
,
without
noticing
the
question
.
<EOS>
"He
appears
to
be
so
,
"
replied
Bates
.
<EOS>
"Admit
<EOS>
him
,
then
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
Entering
the
closet
with
Keyes
,
he
was
followed
by
Fawkes
,
who
drew
his
dagger
,
and
kept
the
door
slightly
ajar
,
while
Garnet
and
the
rest
retired
to
other
hiding
-
places
.
<EOS>
A
few
moments
afterwards
,
Bates
returned
with
Lord
Mounteagle
,
and
,
having
ushered
him
into
the
room
,
took
his
station
in
the
passage
,
as
directed
by
Catesby
.
<EOS>
The
room
was
very
dark
,
the
shutters
being
closed
,
and
light
only
finding
its
way
through
the
chinks
in

;
and
it
appeared

to

Mounteagle
,
who
,

,
stumbled
forward
,
and
exclaimed
in

of
some
alarm,"Where
<EOS>
am
I
?
<EOS>
Where
is
Mr.
Tresham?""I
am
here
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
advancing
towards
him
.
<EOS>
"
How
did
your
lordship
find
me
out
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
after
the
customary
salutations
were
exchanged
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
servant
saw
you
enter
this
house
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
,
"
and
,
knowing
I
was
anxious
to
see
you
,
waited
for
some
hours
without
,
in
the
expectation
of
your
coming
forth
.
<EOS>
But
as
this
did
not
occur
,
he
mentioned
the
circumstance
to
me
on
his
return
,
and
I
immediately
came
in
quest
of
you
.
<EOS>
When
I
knocked
at
the
gate
,
I
scarcely
knew
what
to
think
of
the
place
,
and
began
to
fear
you
must
have
fallen
into
the
hands
of
cut
-
throats
;
and
,
now
that
I
have
gained
admittance
,
my
wonder
—
and
I
may
add
my
uneasiness
—
is
not
diminished
.
<EOS>
Why
do
you
hide
yourself
in
this
wretched
place?""Be
seated
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
placing
a
chair
for
Lord
Mounteagle
,
with
his
back
to
the
closet
,
while
he
took
one
opposite
him
,
and
near
a
table
,
on
which
some
papers
were
laid
.
<EOS>
"
Your
lordship
may
remember
,
"
he
continued
,
scarcely
knowing
what
answer
to
make
to

,
"
that
I
wrote
to
you
some
time
ago
,
to
say
that
a
conspiracy
was
hatching
among
certain
of
our
party
against
the
State
.
<EOS>
""I
have
reason
to
remember
it
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
The
letter
was
laid
before
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
and
inquiries
instituted
in
consequence
.
<EOS>
But
,
owing
to
your
disappearance
,
nothing
could
be
elicited
.
<EOS>
What
plot
had
you
discovered?"At
this
moment
,
Tresham
,
who
kept
his
eye
fixed
on
the
closet
,
perceived
the
door
noiselessly
open
,
and
behind
it
the
figure
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
with
the
dagger
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"I
was
misinformed
as
to
the
nature
of
the
plot
,
"
he
stammered
.
<EOS>
"Was
<EOS>
it
against
the
King
's
life
?
"
demanded
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"No
,
"
rejoined
Tresham
;
"
as
far
as
I
could
learn
,
it
was
an
insurrection
.
<EOS>
""Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Mounteagle
,
sceptically
.
<EOS>
"
My
information
,
then
,
differed
from
yours
.
<EOS>
Who
were
the
parties
<EOS>
you
<EOS>
suspected?""As
<EOS>
I
wrongfully
suspected
them
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
evasively
,
"
<EOS>
your
lordship
must
excuse
my
naming
them
.
<EOS>
""Was
<EOS>
Catesby
—
or
Winter
—
or
Wright
—
or
Rookwood
—
or
Sir
Everard
Digby
concerned
in
it
?
"
demanded
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"Not
<EOS>
one
of
them
,
"
asseverated
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"They
are
the
persons
I
suspect
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
;
"
and
they
are
suspected
by
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
But
you
have
not
told
me
what
you
are
doing
in
this
