.
<EOS>
Are
you
ferreting
out
a
plot
,
or
contriving
one?""Both
,
"
replied
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"How
?
"
cried
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"I
am
plotting
for
myself
,
and
counterplotting
the
designs
of
others
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
mysteriously
.
<EOS>
"Is
<EOS>
this
place
,
then
,
the
rendezvous
of
a
band
of
conspirators
?
"
asked
Mounteagle
,
uneasily
.
<EOS>
Tresham
nodded
in
the
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"Who
<EOS>
are
they
?
"
<EOS>
continued
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
need
of
concealment
with
me
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
this
was
said
,
Tresham
raised
his
eyes
,
and
saw
that
Guy
Fawkes
had
stepped
silently
forward
,
and
placed
himself
behind
Mounteagle
's
chair
.
<EOS>
His
hand
grasped
his
dagger
,
and
his
gaze
never
moved
from
the
object
of
his
suspicion
.
<EOS>
"Who
<EOS>
are
they
?
"
<EOS>
repeated
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
Is
Guy
Fawkes
one
of
them?""Assuredly
not
,
"
replied
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
name
him
?
<EOS>
I
never
mentioned
him
to
your
lordship
.
<EOS>
""I
think
you
did
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
certain
you
spoke
of
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
Tresham
's
regards
involuntarily
wandered
to
the
closet
,
when
he
beheld
the
stern
glance
of
the
person
alluded
to
fixed
upon
him
.
<EOS>
"You
have
heard
of
Viviana
Radcliffe
's
imprisonment
,
I
suppose
?
"
pursued
Mounteagle
,
unconscious
of
what
was
passing
.
<EOS>
Illustration"I
have
,
"
replied
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
Earl
of
Salisbury
expected
he
would
be
able
to
wring
all
from
her
,
but
he
has
failed
,
"
observed
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"I
am
glad
of
it
,
"
observed
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"I
thought
you
were
disposed
to
serve
him
?
"
remarked
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
I
am
,
"
replied
Tresham
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
if
secrets
are
to
be
revealed
,
I
had
rather
be
the
bearer
of
them
than
any
one
else
.
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
for
Viviana
.
<EOS>
""I
could
procure
her
liberation
,
if
I
chose
,
"
observed
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"Say
<EOS>
you
so
?
"
cried
Fawkes
,
clapping
him
on
the
shoulder
;
<EOS>
"
then
you
stir
not
hence
till
you
have
procured
it!"VII
.
<EOS>
—
<EOS>
THE
STAR
-
CHAMBERViviana
,
as
has
already
been
intimated
,
after
her
capture
at
the
house
at
Lambeth
,
was
conveyed
to
the
Star
-
Chamber
.
<EOS>
Here
she
was
detained
until
a
late
hour
on
the
following
day
,
when
she
underwent
a
long
and
rigorous
examination
by
certain
members
of
the
Privy
Council
,
who
were
summoned
for
that
purpose
by
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
Throughout
this
arduous
trial
she
maintained
the
utmost
composure
,
and
never
for
a
single
moment
lost
her
firmness
.
<EOS>
On
all
occasions
,
her
matchless
beauty
and
dignity
produced
the
strongest
impression
on
the
beholders
;
but
on
no
occasion
had
they
ever
produced
so
strong
an
effect
as
the
present
.
<EOS>
Her
features
were
totally
destitute
of
bloom
,
but
their
very
paleness
,
contrasted
as
it
was
with
her
large
dark
eyes
,
which
blazed
with
unwonted
brilliancy
,
as
well
as
with
her
jet
-
black
hair
,
so
far
from
detracting
from
her
loveliness
,
appeared
to
add
to
it
.
<EOS>
As
she
was
brought
before
the
Council
,
who
were
seated
round
a
table
,
and
remained
standing
at
a
short
distance
from
them
,
guarded
by
Topcliffe
and
two
halberdiers
,
<EOS>
a
murmur
of
admiration
pervaded
the
group,—nor
<EOS>
was
this
feeling
lessened
as
the
examination
proceeded
.
<EOS>
Once
,
when
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
adverted
to
the
unworthy
position
in
which
she
,
the
daughter
of
the
proud
and
loyal
Sir
William
Radcliffe
,
had
placed
herself
,
a
shade
passed
over
her
brow
,
and
a
slight
convulsion
agitated
her
frame
.
<EOS>
But
the
next
moment
she
recovered
herself
,
and
said,"However
circumstances
may
appear
against
me
,
and
whatever
opinion
your
lordships
may
entertain
of
my
conduct
,
the
King
has
not
a
more
loyal
subject
than
myself
,
nor
have
any
of
you
made
greater
efforts
to
avert
the
danger
by
which
he
is
threatened
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
you
admit
that
his
Majesty
is
in
danger
?
"
cried
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"I
admit
nothing
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
affirm
that
I
am
his
true
and
loyal
subject
.
<EOS>
""You
can
not
expect
us
to
believe
your
assertion
,
"
replied
the
Earl
;
"
unless
you
approve
it
by
declaring
all
you
know
touching
this
conspiracy
.
<EOS>
""I
have
already
told
you
,
my
lord
,
"
she
returned
,
"
that
my
lips
are
sealed
on
that
subject
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
disclaim
,
then
,
all
knowledge
of
a
plot
against
the
King
's
life
,
and
against
his
government
?
"
pursued
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
Viviana
shook
her
head
.
<EOS>
"You
refuse
to
give
up
the
names
of
your
companions
,
or
to
reveal
their
intentions
?
<EOS>
"
continued
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
do
,
"
she
answered
,
firmly
.
<EOS>
"Your
obstinacy
will
not
save
them
,
"
rejoined
the
Earl
,
in
a
severe
tone
,
and
after
a
brief
pause
.
<EOS>
"
Their
names
and
their
atrocious
designs
are
known
to
us
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
such
be
the
case
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
"
why
interrogate
me
on
the
subject?""Because
—
but
it
is
needless
to
give
a
reason
for
the
course
which
justice
requires
me
to
pursue
,
"
returned
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
implicated
in
this
plot
,
and
nothing
can
save
you
from
condign
punishment
but
a
frank
and
full
confession
.
<EOS>
"Nothing
<EOS>
can
save
me
then
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
but
Heaven
knows
I
shall
perish
unjustly
.
<EOS>
"IllustrationA
consultation
was
then
held
by
the
lords
of
the
council
,
who
whispered
together
for
a
few
minutes
.
<EOS>
Viviana
regarded
them
anxiously
,
but
suffered
no
expression
of
uneasiness
to
escape
her
.
<EOS>
As
they
again
turned
towards
her
,
she
saw
from
their
looks
,
some
of
which
exhibited
great
commiseration
for
her
,
that
they
had
come
to
a
decision
<EOS>
(
she
could
not
doubt
<EOS>
what
)
<EOS>
respecting
her
fate
.
<EOS>
Her
heart
stopped
beating
,
and
she
could
scarcely
support
herself
.
<EOS>
Such
,
however
,
was
the
control
she
exercised
over
herself
that
,
though
filled
with
terror
,
her
demeanour
remained
unaltered
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
long
kept
in
suspense
.
<EOS>
Fixing
his
searching
gaze
upon
her
,
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
observed
in
a
severe
tone,"Viviana
Radcliffe
,
I
ask
you
for
the
last
time
whether
you
will
avow
the
truth?"No
answer
was
returned
.
<EOS>
"I
will
not
disguise
from
you
,
"
continued
the
Earl
,
"
that
your
youth
,
your
beauty
,
your
constancy
,
and
,
above
all
,
your
apparent
innocence
,
have
deeply
interested
me
,
as
well
as
the
other
noble
persons
here
assembled
to
interrogate
you
,
and
who
would
willingly
save
you
from
the
sufferings
you
will
necessarily
undergo
,
from
a
mistaken
fidelity
to
the
heinous
traitors
with
whom
you
are
so
unhappily
leagued
.
<EOS>
I
would
give
you
time
to
reflect
<EOS>
did
I
think
the
delay
would
answer
any
good
purpose
.
<EOS>
I
would
remind
you
that
no
oath
of
secresy
,
however
solemn
,
can
be
binding
in
an
unrighteous
cause
.
<EOS>
I
would
tell
you
that
your
first
duty
is
to
your
prince
and
governor
,
and
that
it
is
as
great
<EOS>
a
crime
,
as
unpardonable
in
the
eyes
of
God
as
of
man
,
to
withhold
the
revelation
of
a
conspiracy
against
the
State
,
should
it
come
to
your
knowledge
,
as
to
conspire
against
it
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
would
lay
all
this
before
you
.
<EOS>
I
would
show
you
the
magnitude
of
your
offence
,
the
danger
in
which
you
stand
,
and
the
utter
impossibility
of
screening
your
companions
,
who
,
ere
long
,
will
be
confronted
with
you,—did
<EOS>
I
think
it
would
avail
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
you
continue
obstinate
,
justice
must
take
its
course
.
<EOS>
""I
am
prepared
for
the
worst
,
<EOS>
my
lord
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
humbly
.
<EOS>
"
I
thank
your
lordship
for
your
consideration
:
but
I
take
you
all
to
witness
that
I
profess
the
utmost
loyalty
and
devotion
for
my
sovereign
,
and
that
,
whatever
may
be
my
fate
,
those
feelings
will
remain
unchanged
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
manner
and
your
words
are
so
sincere
,
that
,
were
not
your
conduct
at
variance
with
them
,
they
might
convince
us
,
"
returned
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
even
if
we
could
credit
your
innocence
,
we
are
bound
to
act
as
if
you
were
guilty
.
<EOS>
You
will
be
committed
to
the
Tower
till
his
Majesty
's
pleasure
is
known
.
<EOS>
And
I
grieve
to
add
,
if
you
still
continue
obstinate
,
the
severest
measures
will
be
resorted
to
,
to
extract
the
truth
from
you
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
concluded
,
he
attached
his
signature
to
a
warrant
which
was
lying
on
the
table
before
him
,
and
traced
a
few
lines
to
Sir
William
Waad
,
lieutenant
of
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
handed
the
papers
to
Topcliffe
,
and
waving
his
hand
,
Viviana
was
removed
to
the
chamber
in
which
she
had
been
previously
confined
,
and
where
she
was
detained
under
a
strict
guard
,
until
Topcliffe
,
who
had
left
her
,
returned
to
say
that
all
was
in
readiness
,
and
bidding
her
follow
him
,
led
the
way
to
the
river
-
side
,
where
a
wherry
,
manned
by
six
rowers
,
was
waiting
for
them
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
profoundly
dark
,
and
,
as
none
of
the
guard
carried
torches
,
their
course
was
steered
in
perfect
obscurity
.
<EOS>
But
the
rowers
were
too
familiar
with
the
river
to
require
the
guidance
of
light
.
<EOS>
Shooting
the
bridge
in
safety
,
and
pausing
only
for
a
moment
to
give
the
signal
of
their
approach
to
the
sentinels
on
the
ramparts
,
they
passed
swiftly
under
the
low
-
browed
arch
of
Traitor
's
Gate
.
<EOS>
VIII
.
<EOS>
—
THE
JAILER
'S
DAUGHTERAs
Viviana
set
foot
on
those
fatal
stairs
,
which
so
many
have
trod
,
and
none
without
feeling
that
they
took
their
first
step
towards
the
scaffold
,
she
involuntarily
shrank
backward
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
now
too
late
to
retreat
;
and
she
surrendered
her
hand
to
Topcliffe
,
who
assisted
her
up
the
steps
.
<EOS>
Half
-
a
-
dozen
men
-
at
-
arms
,
with
a
like
number
of
warders
bearing
torches
,
were
present
;
and
as
it
was
necessary
that
Topcliffe
should
deliver
his
warrant
into
Sir
William
Waad
's
own
hands
,
he
committed
his
prisoner
to
the
warders
,
with
instructions
to
them
to
take
her
to
the
guard
-
room
near
the
By
-
ward
Tower
,
while
he
proceeded
to
the
lieutenant
's
lodgings
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
time
Viviana
had
beheld
the
terrible
pile
in
which
she
was
immured
,
though
she
was
well
acquainted
with
its
history
,
and
with
the
persecutions
which
many
of
the
professors
of
her
faith
had
endured
within
it
during
the
recent
reign
of
Elizabeth
;
and
as
the
light
of
the
torches
flashed
upon
the
grey
walls
of
the
Bloody
Tower
,
and
upon
the
adjoining
ramparts
,
all
the
dreadful
tales
she
had
heard
rushed
to
her
recollection
.
<EOS>
But
having
recovered
the
first
shock
,
the
succeeding
impressions
were
powerless
in
comparison
,
and
she
accompanied
the
warders
to
the
guard
-
room
without
expressing
any
outward
emotion
.
<EOS>
Here
a
seat
was
offered
her
,
and
as
the
men
considerately
withdrew
,
she
was
able
to
pursue
her
reflections
unmolested
.
<EOS>
They
were
sad
enough
,
and
it
required
all
her
firmness
to
support
her
.
<EOS>
When
considering
what
was
likely
to
befal
her
in
consequence
of
her
adherence
to
the
fortunes
of
Fawkes
and
his
companions
,
she
had
often
pictured
some
dreadful
situation
like
the
present
,
but
the
reality
far
exceeded
her
worst
anticipations
.
<EOS>
She
had
deemed
herself
equal
to
any
emergency
,
but
as
she
thought
upon
the
dark
menaces
of
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
she
felt
it
would
require
greater
fortitude
than
she
had
hitherto
displayed
to
bear
her
through
her
trial
.
<EOS>
Nor
were
her
meditations
entirely
confined
to
herself
.
<EOS>
While
trembling
for
the
perilous
situation
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
she
reproached
herself
that
she
could
not
requite
even
in
thought
the
passionate
devotion
of
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"What
matters
it
now
,
"
she
thought
,
"
that
I
can
not
love
him
?
<EOS>
I
shall
soon
be
nothing
to
him
,
or
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
And
yet
I
feel
I
have
done
him
wrong
,
and
that
I
should
be
happier
if
I
could
requite
his
attachment
.
<EOS>
But
the
die
is
cast
.
<EOS>
It
is
too
late
to
repent
,
or
to
retreat
.
<EOS>
My
heart
acquits
me
of
having
been
influenced
by
any
unworthy
motive
,
and
I
will
strive
to
endure
the
keenest
pang
without
a
murmur
.
<EOS>
"Shortly
<EOS>
after
this
,
Topcliffe
returned
with
Sir
William
Waad
.
<EOS>
On
their
entrance
,
Viviana
arose
,
and
the
lieutenant
eyed
her
with
some
curiosity
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
middle
-
aged
man
,
tall
,
stoutly
-
built
,
and
having
harsh
features
,
stamped
with
an
expression
of
mingled
cunning
and
ferocity
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
had
a
fierce
and
bloodthirsty
look
,
and
were
overshadowed
by
thick
and
scowling
brows
.
<EOS>
Saluting
the
captive
with
affected
courtesy
,
he
<EOS>
observed,"So
<EOS>
you
refuse
to
answer
the
interrogations
of
the
Privy
Council
,
madam
,
I
understand
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
sorry
for
it
,
because
I
would
have
the
merit
of
wringing
the
truth
from
you
.
<EOS>
Those
who
have
been
most
stubborn
outside
these
walls
,
have
been
the
most
yielding
within
them
.
<EOS>
""That
will
not
be
my
case
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
coldly
.
<EOS>
"We
<EOS>
shall
see
,
"
returned
the
lieutenant
,
with
a
significant
glance
at
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
Ordering
her
to
follow
him
,
he
then
proceeded
along
the
ward
in
the
direction
of
the
Bloody
Tower
,
and
passing
beneath
its
arched
gateway
,
ascended
the
steps
on
the
left
,
and
led
her
to
his
lodgings
.
<EOS>
Entering
the
habitation
,
he
mounted
to
the
upper
story
,
and
tracking
a
long
gallery
,
brought
her
to
a
small
circular
chamber
in
the
Bell
Tower
.
<EOS>
Its
sole
furniture
were
a
chair
,
a
table
,
and
a
couch
.
<EOS>
"Here
<EOS>
you
will
remain
for
the
present
,
"
observed
the
lieutenant
,
smiling
grimly
,
and
placing
a
lamp
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
depend
upon
yourself
whether
your
accommodations
are
better
hereafter
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
quitted
the
cell
with
his
attendants
,
and
barred
the
door
outside
.
<EOS>
Left
alone
,
Viviana
,
who
had
hitherto
restrained
her
anguish
,
suffered
it
to
find
vent
in
tears
.
<EOS>
Never
had
she
felt
so
utterly
forlorn
and
desolate
.
<EOS>
All
before
her
was
threatening
and
terrible
,
full
of
dangers
,
real
and
imaginary
;
nor
could
she
look
back
upon
her
past
career
without
something
like
remorse
.
<EOS>
"Oh
,
that
Heaven
would
take
me
to
itself
!
"
<EOS>
she
murmured
,
clasping
her
hands
in
an
agony
of
distress
,
"
for
I
feel
unequal
to
my
trials
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
that
I
had
perished
with
my
dear
father
!
<EOS>
For
what
dreadful
fate
am
I
reserved?—Torture,—I
will
bear
it
,
if
I
can
.
<EOS>
But
death
by
the
hands
of
the
public
executioner,—it
is
too
horrible
to
think
of
!
<EOS>
Is
there
no
way
to
escape
that?"As
this
hideous
thought
occurred
to
her
,
she
uttered
a
loud
and
prolonged
scream
,
and
fell
senseless
on
the
floor
.
<EOS>
When
she
recovered
it
was
daylight
;
and
,
weak
and
exhausted
<EOS>
,
she
crept
to
the
couch
,
and
throwing
herself
upon
it
,
endeavoured
to
forget
her
misery
in
sleep
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
is
usually
the
case
with
the
afflicted
,
it
fled
her
eyelids
,
and
she
passed
several
hours
in
the
severest
mental
torture
,
unrelieved
by
a
single
cheering
thought
.
<EOS>
About
the
middle
of
the
day
,
the
door
of
the
cell
was
opened
by
an
old
woman
with
a
morose
and
forbidding
countenance
,
attended
by
a
younger
female
,
who
resembled
her
in
all
<EOS>
but
the
expression
of
her
features
(
her
look
was
gentle
and
compassionate
)
,
and
who
appeared
to
be
her
daughter
.
<EOS>
Without
paying
any
attention
to
Viviana
,
the
old
woman
took
a
small
loaf
of
bread
and
other
provisions
from
a
basket
she
had
brought
with
her
,
and
placed
them
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
she
was
about
to
depart
,
<EOS>
when
her
daughter
,
who
had
glanced
uneasily
at
the
couch
,
observed
in
a
kindly
tone,"Shall
we
not
inquire
whether
we
can
be
of
service
to
the
poor
young
lady
,
mother?""Why
should
we
concern
ourselves
about
her
,
Ruth
?
<EOS>
"
returned
the
old
woman
,
sharply
.
<EOS>
"
If
she
wants
anything
,
she
has
a
tongue
,
and
can
speak
.
<EOS>
If
she
desires
further
comforts
,
"
she
added
,
in
a
significant
tone
,
"
they
must
be
paid
for
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
desire
nothing
but
death
,
"
groaned
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
poor
soul
is
dying
,
I
believe
,
"
cried
Ruth
,
rushing
to
the
couch
.
"
<EOS>
Have
you
no
cordial
-
water
about
you
<EOS>
,
mother?""Truly
have
I
,
"
returned
the
old
woman
;
"
and
I
have
other

.
<EOS>
But
I
must
be
paid

.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>

she

small
,

.
<EOS>
"Give
<EOS>
it
me
,
"

,
snatching

her
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
the
young
lady
will
pay
for
it
.
<EOS>
""You
are
very
kind
,
"
said
Viviana
,

.
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
no

doing

.
<EOS>
""I
knew

,
"

the

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
knew

.
<EOS>
Give
me

,

<EOS>
She

not

.
<EOS>
Do

not

,
she

money
,

?
<EOS>
Give

me

,
I

.
<EOS>
""Nay

,

's

,
"

.
<EOS>
"Pity
,

!
<EOS>
"

woman
,

.
<EOS>
"
If

,

Ipgreve
,

,
it
would

high

.
<EOS>
Pity

!
<EOS>
Thou

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
""So
<EOS>
she

,
"

;
"

<EOS>
I

so

?

"

,

.

Are

truly
Sir
William

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
""No
—
<EOS>
no
,

,
"

Ipgreve
,

,

,
"
I

.

.
<EOS>
""I

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"You

,
"

Ipgreve
,

"
but

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
like

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
""Well

"

.
<EOS>
"
Do

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
""Ah

<EOS>
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

—

.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
""I

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
""You

<EOS>
thus,—indeed

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Suffer

.
<EOS>
""Willingly
,
"

Viviana
;
"
most

.
<EOS>
""Stay

,

"

Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
Take

,
"

.
<EOS>
Greatly

's

,

to

,
and
thanked

in

.
<EOS>
A

to

,
and

's
daughter
assured

,
that
so

,

to

.
<EOS>
By

the
old
woman
had
returned
with
a
mess
of
hot

,
which
she
carried
with
an
air
of
great

beneath

.
<EOS>
Viviana
was
prevailed
upon
by
the
solicitations
of
Ruth
to
taste
it
,
and
found
herself
much
revived
in
consequence
.
<EOS>
Her
slight
meal
ended
,
Dame
Ipgreve
departed
,
with
a
promise
to
return
in
the
evening
with
such
viands
as
she
could
manage
to
introduce

,
and
with
a
flask
of
wine
.
<EOS>
"You
will
need
it
,
sweet
lady
<EOS>
,
I
fear
,
"
she
said
;
"
for
my
husband
tells
me
you
are
in
peril
of
the
torture
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
it
is
a
sad

,
that
such

so

with
!
<EOS>
But
we
will
take
all

of
you
we

.
<EOS>
You
will
not
forget
to
requite

.
<EOS>
You
must
give
me
an
order
on
your
steward
,
or
on
some
rich
Catholic

.
<EOS>
I
am
<EOS>
half
a
Papist
myself,—that
is
,
I
like
one

as
well
as
the
other,—and
<EOS>
I
like
those
best
,
<EOS>
whatever
their
creed
may

,
who
pay
best
.
<EOS>
That

:
and

.
<EOS>
We
do
all
we
can
to
scrape

child
.
<EOS>
""No

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
It

!
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
she

.
<EOS>
""Right
<EOS>
,

,

,
"

Ipgreve;—"do

,
"

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Ruth

during

,

Poole
,

,
and
whose

's

.
<EOS>
As

,

made

,

,
a

in

,

.
<EOS>
Ruth
then
departed
,
promising
to
return
in
the
evening
with
her
mother
.
<EOS>
Soon

became
dark
,
Dame
Ipgreve
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
Ruth
's

was
so

,
that

was
certain

at

.
<EOS>
"What
is

?
<EOS>
"

.

"Make

,

"

Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"
Our
news
might

,

,

<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
alarm

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What

do

,
"

.

"
You

,

.
<EOS>
""Heaven

"
<EOS>

,

"

"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
""You

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
will

.
<EOS>
""You

,
"

Ipgreve

"
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
At

,
support

.
<EOS>
""No
,
"

;
"

,
I

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
""Misfortune

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
Well

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
My

Ipgreve
,

Come

""Oh

"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
But

—

—

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
<EOS>
Come

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
""Farewell
,

,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
Heaven

,
"
said

old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
Speak

,
and

.
<EOS>
"She
would

continued
in

,
but
Ruth
dragged
her
away
.
<EOS>
And
casting
a

,

.
<EOS>
The
dreadful
interval
between
their

and

was
passed
by

in

.
<EOS>
As

through
the
barred
embrasure
of
her

the

of
the
clock
toll
out
the
hour
of
twelve
,
the
door
opened
,
and
a

,
habited

suit
of

,
and
with
a
large

,
entered
the
cell
.
<EOS>
"You
are
Jasper
Ipgreve
?
"
said
Viviana
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"Right
,
"
replied
the
jailer
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
come
to
take
you
before
the
lieutenant
and
the

.
<EOS>
Are
you
ready?"Viviana
replied
in
the
affirmative
,
and
Ipgreve
quitting
the
cell
,
outside
which

in

,
led
the
way
down
a

,
which
brought
them
to
a
narrow

.
<EOS>
Pursuing
it
for
some
time
,
the
jailer
halted
before
a
strong
door
,
cased
with
iron
,
and
opening
it
,
admitted
the
captive
into
a
square
chamber
,
the
roof
of
which
was
supported
by
a
heavy

,
while
its

were

with

.
<EOS>
At
a
table
on
the
left
sat
the
lieutenant
and
three
other
grave
-
looking
personages
.
<EOS>
Across
the
lower
end
of
the
chamber
a
thick
black
curtain
was
stretched
,
hiding
a
deep
recess
;
and
behind
it
,
as
was
evident
from
the
glimmer
that
escaped
from
its
folds
,
there
was
a
light
.
<EOS>
Certain
indistinct
,
but
ominous
sounds
,
issuing
from
the
recess
,
proved
that
there
were
persons
within
it
,
and
Viviana
's
quaking
heart
told
her
what
was
the
nature
of
their
proceedings
.
<EOS>
She
had
ample
time
to
survey
this
dismal
apartment
and
its
occupants
,
for
several
minutes
elapsed
before
a
word
was
addressed
to
her
by
her
interrogators
,
who
continued
to
confer
together
in
an
under
tone
,
as
if
unconscious
of
her
presence
.
<EOS>
During
this
pause
,
broken
only
by
the
ominous
sounds
before
mentioned
,
Viviana
scanned
the
countenances
of
the
group
at
the
table
,
in
the
hope
of
discerning
in
them
some
glimpses
of
compassion
;
but
they
were
inscrutable
and
inexorable
,
and
scarcely
less
dreadful
to
look
upon
than
the
hideous
implements
on
the
walls
.
<EOS>
Viviana
wished
the
earth
would
open
and
swallow
her
,
that
she
might
escape
from
them
.
<EOS>
Anything
was
better
than
to
be
left
at
the
mercy
of
such
men
.
<EOS>
At
certain
times
,
and
not
unfrequently
at
the
most
awful
moments
,
a
double
current
of
thought
will
flow
through
the
brain
,
and
at
this
frightful
juncture
it
was
so
with
Viviana
.
<EOS>
While
shuddering
at
all
she
saw
around
her
,
nay
,
dwelling
upon
it
,
another
and
distinct
train
of
thought
<EOS>
led
her
back
to
former
scenes
of
happiness
,
when
she
was
undisturbed
by
any
but
remote
apprehensions
of
danger
.
<EOS>
She
thought
of
her
tranquil
residence
at
Ordsall,—of
the
flowers
she
had
tended
in
the
garden,—of
her
father
,
and
of
his
affection
for
her,—of
Humphrey
Chetham
,
and
of
her
early
and
scarce
-
acknowledged
attachment
to
him,—and
of
his
generosity
and
devotion
,
and
how
she
had
requited
it
.
<EOS>
And
then
,
like
a
sullen
cloud
darkening
the
fair
prospect
,
arose
the
figure
of
Guy
Fawkes
—
the
sombre
enthusiast
—
who
had
unwittingly
exercised
such
a
baneful
influence
upon
her
fortunes
.
<EOS>
"Had
<EOS>
he
not
crossed
my
path
,
"
she
mentally
ejaculated
,
"
I
might
have
been
happy
—
might
have
loved
Humphrey
Chetham
—
might
,
perhaps
,
have
wedded
him!"These
<EOS>
reflections
were
suddenly
dispersed
by
the
lieutenant
,
who
,
in
a
stern
tone
,
commenced
his
interrogations
.
<EOS>
As
upon
her
previous
examination
,
Viviana
observed
the
utmost
caution
,
and
either
refused
to
speak
,
or
answered
such
questions
only
as
affected
herself
.
<EOS>
At
first
,
in
spite
of
all
her
efforts
,
she
trembled
violently
,
and
her
tongue
clove
to
the
roof
of
her
mouth
.
<EOS>
But
after
a
while
,
she
recovered
her
courage
,
and
regarded
the
lieutenant
with
a
look
as
determined
as
his
own
.
<EOS>
"It
is
useless
to
urge
me
farther
,
"
she
concluded
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
all
I
will
say
.
<EOS>
""Is
it
<EOS>
your
pleasure
,
my
lords
<EOS>
,
"
observed
Sir
William
Waad
to
the
others
,
"
to
prolong
the
examination?"His
companions
replied
in
the
negative
,
and
the
one
nearest
him
remarked
,
"
Is
she
aware
what
will
follow?""I
am
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
resolutely
,
"
and
I
am
not
to
be
intimidated
.
<EOS>
"Sir
<EOS>
William
Waad
then
made
a
sign
to
Ipgreve
,
who
immediately
stepped
forward
and
seized
her
arm
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
taken
to
that
recess
,
"
said
the
lieutenant
,
"
where
the
question
will
be
put
to
you
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
we
shall
remain
here
,
you
have
only
to
utter
a
cry
if
you
are
willing
to
avow
the
truth
,
and
the
torture
shall
be
stayed
.
<EOS>
And
it
is
our
merciful
hope
that
this
may
be
the
case
.
<EOS>
"Summoning
<EOS>
up
all
her
resolution
,
and
walking
with
a
firm
footstep
,
Viviana
passed
with
Ipgreve
behind
the
curtain
.
<EOS>
She
there
beheld
two
men
and
a
woman
—
the
latter
was
the
jailer
's
wife
,
who
instantly
advanced
to
her
,
and
besought
her
to
confess
.
<EOS>
"There
is
no
help
for
it
,
if
you
refuse
,
"
she
urged
;
"
not
all
your
wealth
can
save
you
.
<EOS>
""Mind
<EOS>
your
own
business
,
dame
,
"
interposed
Ipgreve
,
angrily
,
"
and
assist
her
to
unrobe
.
<EOS>
"Saying
<EOS>
this
,
he
stepped
aside
with
the
two
men
,
one
of
whom
was
the
chirurgeon
,
and
the
other
the
tormentor
,
while
Dame
Ipgreve
helped
to
take
off
Viviana
's
gown
.
<EOS>
She
then
tied
a
scarf
over
her
shoulders
,
and
informed
her
husband
she
was
ready
.
<EOS>
The
recess
was
about
twelve
feet
high
,
and
ten
wide
.
<EOS>
It
was
crossed
near
the
roof
,
which
was
arched
and
vaulted
,
by
a
heavy
beam
,
with
pulleys
and
ropes
at
either
extremity
.
<EOS>
But
what
chiefly
attracted
the
unfortunate
captive
's
attention
was
a
couple
of
iron
gauntlets
attached
to
it
,
about
a
yard
apart
.
<EOS>
Upon
the
ground
under
the
beam
,
and
immediately
beneath
that
part
of
it
where
the
gauntlets
were
fixed
,
were
laid
three
pieces
of
wood
,
of
a
few
inches
in
thickness
,
and
piled
one
upon
another
.
<EOS>
"What
<EOS>
must
I
do
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Viviana
,
in
a
hollow
voice
,
but
with
unaltered
resolution
,
of
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"Step
upon
those
pieces
of
wood
,
"
replied
Dame
Ipgreve
,
leading
her
towards
them
.
<EOS>
Viviana
obeyed
,
and
as
soon
as
she
had
set
foot
upon
the
pile
,
the
tormentor
placed
a
joint
-
stool
beside
her
,
and
mounting
it
,
desired
her
to
place
her
right
hand
in
one
of
the
gauntlets
.
<EOS>
She
did
so
,
and
the
tormentor
then
turned
a
screw
,
which
compressed
the
iron
glove
so
tightly
as
to
give
her
excruciating
pain
.
<EOS>
He
then
got
down
,
and
Ipgreve
demanded
if
he
should
proceed
.
<EOS>
A
short
pause
ensued
;
but
,
notwithstanding
her
agony
,
Viviana
made
no
answer
.
<EOS>
The
tormentor
then
placed
the
stool
on
the
left
side
,
and
fastened
the
hand
which
was
still
at
liberty
within
the
other
gauntlet
.
<EOS>
The
torture
was
dreadful
—
and
the
fingers
appeared
crushed
by
the
pressure
.
<EOS>
Still
Viviana
uttered
no
cry
.
<EOS>
After
another
short
pause
,
Ipgreve
said,"You
had
better
let
us
stop
here
.
<EOS>
This
is
mere
child
's
play
compared
with
what
is
to
come
.
<EOS>
"No
<EOS>
answer
being
returned
,
the
tormentor
took
a
mallet
and
struck
one
of
the
pieces
of
wood
from
under
Viviana
's
feet
.
<EOS>
The
shock
was
dreadful
,
and
seemed
to
dislocate
her
wrists
,
while
the
pressure
on
the
hands
was
increased
in
a
tenfold
degree
.
<EOS>
The
poor
sufferer
,
who
was
resting
on
the
points
of
her
feet
,
felt
that
the
removal
of
the
next
piece
of
wood
would
occasion
almost
intolerable
torture
.
<EOS>
Her
constancy
,
however
,
did
not
desert
her
,
and
,
after
the
question
had
been
repeated
by
Ipgreve
,
the
second
block
was
struck
away
.
<EOS>
She
was
now
suspended
by
her
hands
,
and
the
pain
was
so
exquisite
,
that
nature
gave
way
,
and
uttering
a
piercing
scream
,
she
fainted
.
<EOS>
On
recovering
,
she
found
herself
stretched
upon
a
miserable
pallet
,
with
Ruth
watching
beside
her
.
<EOS>
A
glance
round
the
chamber
,
which
was
of
solid
stone
masonry
,
with
a
deep
embrasure
on
one
side
,
convinced
her
that
she
had
been
removed
to
some
other
prison
.
"Where
<EOS>
am
I
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
,
in
a
faint
voice
.
"In
<EOS>
the
Well
Tower
,
madam
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Ruth
:
"
one
of
the
fortifications
near
the
moat
,
and
now
used
as
a
prison
-
lodging
.
<EOS>
My
father
dwells
within
it
,
and
you
are
under
his
custody
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
father
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
shuddering
as
she
recalled
the
sufferings
she
had
recently
undergone
.
"
<EOS>
Will
he
torture
me
<EOS>
again?""Not
if
I
can
prevent
it
,
dear
lady
,
"
replied
Ruth
.
"
<EOS>
But
hush
!
<EOS>
here
comes
my
mother
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
before
her
.
"As
<EOS>
Ruth
spoke
,
Dame
Ipgreve
,
who
had
been
lingering
at
the
door
,
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
She
affected
the
greatest
solicitude
for
Viviana
—
felt
her
pulse
—
looked
at
the
bandages
fastened
round
her
swollen
and
crippled
fingers
,
and
concluded
by
counselling
her
not
to
persist
in
refusing
to
speak
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
dare
not
tell
you
what
tortures
are
in
store
for
you
,
"
she
said
,
"
if
you
continue
thus
obstinate
.
<EOS>
But
they
will
be
a
thousand
times
worse
than
what
you
endured
last
night
.
<EOS>
""When
<EOS>
will
my
next
interrogation
take
place
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"A
week
hence
,
it
may
be,—or
<EOS>
it
may
be
sooner
,
"
returned
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
It
depends
upon
the
state
you
are
in
—
and
somewhat
upon
the
fees
you
give
my
husband
,
for
he
has
a
voice
with
the
lieutenant
.
<EOS>
""I
would
give
him
all
I
possess
,
if
he
could
save
me
from
further
torture
,
"
cried
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"Alas
!
<EOS>
alas
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Dame
Ipgreve
,
"
you
ask
more
than
can
be
done
.
<EOS>
He
would
save
you
if
he
could
.
<EOS>
But
you
will
not
let
him
.
<EOS>
However
,
we
will
do
all
we
can
to
mitigate
your
sufferings
—
all
we
can
—
provided
you
pay
us
.
<EOS>
Stay
with
her
,
child
,
"
she
added
,
with
a
significant
gesture

her
daughter
,
as
she
quitted

room
,
"
stay
with
her
.
<EOS>
""My
<EOS>
heart
bleeds
for
you
,
madam
,
"
said
Ruth
,
in
accents
of
the
deepest
commiseration
,
as
soon
as
they
were
alone
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
depend
upon
my
fidelity
.
<EOS>
If
I
can
contrive
your
escape
,
I
will,—at
any
risk
to
myself
.
<EOS>
""On
no
account
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
concern
yourself
about
me
more
.
<EOS>
My
earthly
sufferings
,
I
feel
,
will
have
terminated
before
further
cruelty
can
be
practised
upon
me
.
<EOS>
""Oh
!
<EOS>
say
not
so
<EOS>
,
madam
,
"
returned
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
—
<EOS>
nay
,
I
am
sure
you
will
live
long
and
happily
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
shook
her
head
,
and
Ruth
,
finding
her
very
feeble
,
thought
it
better
not
to
continue
the
conversation
.
<EOS>
She
accordingly
applied
such
restoratives
as
were
at
hand
,
and
observing
that
the
eyes
of
the
sufferer
closed
as
if
in
slumber
,
glided
noiselessly
out
of
the
chamber
,
and
left
her
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
a
week
passed
.
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
that
time
,
the
chirurgeon
pronounced
her
in
so
precarious
a
state
,
that
if
the
torture
were
repeated
he
would
not
answer
for
her
life
.
<EOS>
The
interrogation
,
therefore
,
was
postponed
for
a
few
days
,
during
which
the
chirurgeon
constantly
visited
her
,
and
by
his
care
,
and
the
restoratives
she
was
compelled
to
take
,
she
rapidly
regained
her
strength
.
<EOS>
One
day
,
after
the
chirurgeon
had
departed
,
Ruth
cautiously
closed
the
door
,
and
observed
to
her,"You
are
now
so
far
recovered
,
madam
,
as
to
be
able
to
make
an
attempt
to
escape
.
<EOS>
I
have
devised
a
plan
,
which
I
will
communicate
to
you
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
It
must
not
be
delayed
,
or
you
will
have
to
encounter
a
second
and
more
dreadful
examination
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
attempt
it
if
you
are
exposed
to
risk
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"Heed
me
not
,
"
returned
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
One
of
your
friends
has
found
out
your
place
of
confinement
,
and
has
spoken
to
me
about
you
.
<EOS>
""What
friend
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Viviana
,
starting
.
"
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes?—I
mean
—
—
"
And
she
hesitated
,
while
her
pale
cheeks
were
suffused
with
blushes
.
<EOS>
"He
is
named
Humphrey
Chetham
,
"
returned
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
Like
myself
,
he
would
risk
his
life
to
preserve
you
.
<EOS>
""Tell
<EOS>
him
<EOS>
he
must
not
do
so
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
eagerly
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
done
enough
—
too
much
for
me
already
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
expose
him
to
further
hazard
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
so
,
and
entreat
him
to
abandon
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
""But
<EOS>
I
shall
not
see
him
,
dear
lady
,
"
replied
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Besides
,
if
I
read
him
rightly
,
he
is
not
likely
to
be
turned
aside
by
any
selfish
consideration
.
<EOS>
""You
are
right
,
he
is
not
,
"
groaned
Viviana
.
"
<EOS>
But
this
only
adds
to
my
affliction
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
if
you
should
see
him
,
dear
Ruth
,
try
to
dissuade
him
from
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
""I
will
obey
you
,
madam
,
"
replied
the
jailer
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
am
well
assured
it
will
be
of
no
avail
.
<EOS>
"After
<EOS>
some
further
conversation
,
Ruth
retired
,
and
Viviana
was
left
alone
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
Except
the
slumber
procured
by
soporific
potions
,
she
had
known
no
repose
since
she
had
been
confined
within
the
Tower
;
and
this
night
she
felt
more
than
usually
restless
.
<EOS>
After
ineffectually
endeavouring
to
compose
herself
,
she
arose
,
and
hastily
robing
herself
—
a
task
she
performed
with
no
little
difficulty
,
her
fingers
being
almost
useless
—
<EOS>
continued
to
pace
her
narrow
chamber
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
mentioned
that
on
one
side
of
the
cell
there
was
a
deep
embrasure
.
<EOS>
It
was
terminated
by
a
narrow
and
strongly
-
grated
loophole
,
looking
upon
the
moat
.
<EOS>
Pausing
before
it
,
Viviana
gazed
forth
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
pitchy
dark
,
and
not
even
a
solitary
star
could
be
discerned
;
but
as
she
had
no
light
in
her
chamber
,
the
gloom
outside
was
less
profound
than
that
within
.
<EOS>
While
standing
thus
,
buried
in
thought
,
and
longing
for
daybreak
,
Viviana
fancied
she
heard
a
slight
sound
as
of
some
one
swimming
across
the
moat
.
<EOS>
Thinking
she
might
be
deceived
,
she
listened
more
intently
,
and
as
the
sound
continued
,
she
felt
sure
she
was
right
in
her
conjecture
.
<EOS>
All
at
once
the
thought
of
Humphrey
Chetham
flashed
upon
her
,
and
she
had
no
doubt
it
must
be
him
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
she
wrong
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
a
noise
was
heard
as
of
some
one
clambering
up
the
wall
;
a
hand
grasped
the
bars
of
the
loophole
,
which
was
only
two
or
three
feet
above
the
level
of
the
water
;
and
a
low
voice
,
which
she
instantly
recognised
,
pronounced
her
name
.
<EOS>
"Is
<EOS>
it
Humphrey
Chetham
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
,
advancing
as
near
as
she
could
to
the
loophole
.
<EOS>
"It
is
,
"
was
the
reply
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
despair
.
<EOS>
I
will
accomplish
your
liberation
.
<EOS>
I
have
passed
three
days
within
the
Tower
,
and
only
ascertained
your
place
of
confinement
a
few
hours
ago
.
<EOS>
I
have
contrived
a
plan
for
your
escape
,
with
the
jailer
's
daughter
,
which
she
will
make
known
to
you
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
thank
you
sufficiently
for
your
devotion
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
in
accents
of
the
deepest
gratitude
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
implore
you
to
leave
me
to
my
fate
.
<EOS>
I
am
wretched
enough
now
,
Heaven
knows
,
but
if
aught
should
happen
to
you
,
I
shall
be
infinitely
more
so
.
<EOS>
If
I
possess
any
power
over
you,—and
that
I
do
so
,
I
well
<EOS>
know,—I
entreat
,
nay
<EOS>
,
I
command
,
you
to
desist
from
this
attempt
.
<EOS>
""I
have
never
yet
disobeyed
you
,
Viviana
,
"
replied
the
young
merchant
,
passionately—"nor
<EOS>
will
I
do
so
now
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
bid
me
abandon
you
,
I
will
plunge
into
this
moat
,
never
to
rise
again
.
<EOS>
"His
<EOS>
manner
,
notwithstanding
the
low
tone
in
which
he
spoke
,
was
so
determined
,
that
Viviana
felt
certain
he
would
carry
his
threat
into
execution
;
she
therefore
rejoined
in
a
mournful
tone,"Well
,
be
it
as
you
will
.
<EOS>
It
is
in
vain
to
resist
our
fate
,
I
am
destined
to
bring
misfortune
to
you
.
<EOS>
""Not
<EOS>
so
,
"
replied
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
can
save
you
,
I
would
rather
die
than
live
.
<EOS>
The
jailer
's
daughter
will
explain
her
plan
to
you
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
to
accede
to
it
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
<EOS>
reluctantly
assented
.
<EOS>
"I
shall
quit
the
Tower
at
daybreak
,
"
pursued
Chetham
;
"
and
when
you
are
once
out
of
it
,
hasten
to
the
stairs
beyond
the
wharf
at
Petty
Wales
.
<EOS>
I
will
be
there
with
a
boat
.
<EOS>
Farewell!"As
<EOS>
he
spoke
,
he
let
himself
drop
into
the
water
,
but
his
foot
slipping
,
the
plunge
was
louder
than
he
intended
,
and
attracted
the
attention
of
a
sentinel
on
the
ramparts
,
who
immediately
called
out
to
know
what
was
the
matter
,
and
not
receiving
any
answer
,
discharged
his
caliver
in
the
direction
of
the
sound
.
<EOS>
Viviana
,
who
heard
the
challenge
and
the
shot
,
uttered
a
loud
scream
,
and
the
next
moment
Ipgreve
and
his
wife
appeared
.
<EOS>
The
jailer
glanced
suspiciously
round
the
room
;
but
after
satisfying
himself
that
all
was
right
,
and
putting
some
questions
to
the
captive
,
which
she
refused
to
answer
,
he
departed
with
his
wife
,
and
carefully
barred
the
door
.
<EOS>
It
is
impossible
to
imagine
greater
misery
than
Viviana
endured
the
whole
of
the
night
.
<EOS>
The
uncertainty
in
which
she
was
kept
as
to
Chetham
's
fate
was
almost
insupportable
,
and
the
bodily
pain
she
had
recently
endured
appeared
light
when
compared
with
her
present
mental
torture
.
<EOS>
Day
at
length
dawned
;
but
it
brought
with
it
no
Ruth
.
<EOS>
Instead
of
this
faithful
friend
,
Dame
Ipgreve
entered
the
chamber
with
the
morning
meal
,
and
her
looks
were
so
morose
and
distrustful
,
that
Viviana
feared
she
must
have
discovered
her
daughter
's
design
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
,
however
,
venture
to
make
a
remark
,
but
suffered
the
old
woman
to
depart
in
silence
.
<EOS>
Giving
up
all
for
lost
,
and
concluding
that
Humphrey
Chetham
had
either
perished
,
or
was
,
like
herself
,
a
prisoner
,
Viviana
bitterly
bewailed
his
fate
,
and
reproached
herself
with
being
unintentionally
the
cause
of
it
.
<EOS>
Later
in
the
day
,
Ruth
entered
the
cell
.
<EOS>
To
Viviana
's
eager
inquiries
she
replied
,
that
Humphrey
Chetham
had
escaped
.
<EOS>
Owing
to
the
darkness
,
the
sentinel
had
missed
his
aim
,
and
although
the
most
rigorous
search
was
instituted
throughout
the
fortress
,
he
had
contrived
to
elude
observation
.
<EOS>
"Our
<EOS>
attempt
,
"
pursued
Ruth
,
"
must
be
made
this
evening
.
<EOS>
The
lieutenant
has
informed
my
father
that
you
are
to
be
interrogated
at
midnight
,
the
chirurgeon
having
declared
that
you
are
sufficiently
recovered
to
undergo
the
torture
(
if
needful
)
a
second
time
.
<EOS>
Now
listen
to
me
.
<EOS>
The
occurrence
of
last
night
has
made
my
mother
suspicious
,
and
she
watches
my
proceedings
with
a
jealous
eye
.
<EOS>
She
is
at
this
moment
with
a
female
prisoner
in
the
Beauchamp
Tower
,
or
I
should
not
be
able
to
visit
you
.
<EOS>
She
has
consented
,
however
,
to
let
me
bring
in
your
supper
.
<EOS>
You
must
then
change
dresses
with
me
.
<EOS>
Being
about
my
height
,
you
may
easily
pass
for
me
,
and
I
will
take
care
<EOS>
there
is
no
light
below
,
so
that
your
features
will
not
be
distinguished
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
would
have
checked
her
,
but
the
other
would
not
be
interrupted
.
<EOS>
"As
soon
as
you
are
ready
,
"
she
continued
,
"
you
must
lock
the
door
upon
me
.
<EOS>
You
must
then
descend
the
short
flight
of
steps
before
you
,
and
pass
as
quickly
as
you
can
through
the
room
where
you
will
see
my
father
and
mother
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
you
are
out
of
the
door
,
turn
to
the
left
,
and
go
straight
forward
to
the
By
-
ward
Tower
.
<EOS>
Show
this
pass
to
the
warders
.
<EOS>
It
is
made
out
in
my
name
,
and
they
will
suffer
you
to
go
forth
.
<EOS>
Do
the
same
with
the
warders
at
the
next
gate,—the
Middle
Tower,—and
again
at
the
Bulwark
Gate
.
<EOS>
That
passed
,
you
are
free
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
what
will
become
of
you
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Viviana
,
with
a
bewildered
look
.
<EOS>
"Never
<EOS>
mind
me
,
"
rejoined
Ruth
:
"
<EOS>
I
shall
be
sufficiently
rewarded
if
I
save
you
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
farewell
.
<EOS>
Be
ready
at
the
time
appointed
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
consent
,
"
returned
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"You
have
no
choice
,
"
replied
Ruth
,
breaking
from
her
,
and
hurrying
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
Time
,
as
it
ever
does
,
when
expectation
is
on
the
rack
,
appeared
to
pass
with
unusual
slowness
.
<EOS>
But
as
the
hour
at
length
drew
near
,
Viviana
wished
it
farther
off
.
<EOS>
It
was
with
the
utmost
trepidation
that
she
heard
the
key
turn
in
the
lock
,
and
beheld
Ruth
enter
the
cell
with
the
evening
meal
.
<EOS>
Closing
the
door
,
and
setting
down
the
provisions
,
the
jailer
's
daughter
hastily
divested
herself
of
her
dress
,
which
was
of
brown

,
as
well
as
of
her
coif
and
kerchief
,
while
Viviana
imitated
her
example
.
<EOS>
Without
pausing
to
attire
herself
in
the
other
's
garments
,
Ruth
then
assisted
Viviana
to
put
on
the
dress
she
had
just
laid
aside
,
and
arranged
her
hair
and
the
head
-
gear
<EOS>
so
skilfully
,
that
the
disguise
was
complete
.
<EOS>
Hastily

some
further
instructions
to
her
,
and
explaining
certain
peculiarities
in
her
gait
and
deportment
,
she
then
pressed
her
to
her
bosom
,
and
led
her
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
Viviana
would
have
remonstrated
,
but
Ruth
pushed
her
through
it
,
and
closed
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
now
no
help
,
so
Viviana
,
though
with
great
pain
to
herself
,
contrived
to
turn
the
key
in
the
lock
.
<EOS>
Descending
the
steps
,
she
found
herself
in
a
small
circular
chamber
,
in
which
Ipgreve
and
his
wife
were
seated
at
a
table
,
discussing
their
evening
meal
.
<EOS>
The
sole
light
was
afforded
by
a
few
dying
embers
on
the
hearth
.
<EOS>
"What
!
<EOS>
has
she
done
,
already
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
old
woman
,
as
Viviana
appeared
.
<EOS>
"
Why
hast
thou
not
brought
the
jelly
with
thee
,
if
she
has
not
eaten
it
all
,
and
those
cates
,
which
Master
Pilchard
,
the

,
ordered

?
<EOS>
Go
and
fetch
them
directly
.
<EOS>
They
will
finish
our
repast
daintily
;
and
there
are
other
matters
too
,
<EOS>
which
I
dare
say
she
has
not
touched
.
<EOS>
She
will
pay
for
them
,
and
that
will
make
them
the
sweeter
.
<EOS>
Go
back
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
What
dost
thou
stand
there
for
,
as
if
thou
wert
thunderstruck
?
<EOS>
Dost
hear
me
,
or
not?""Let
the
wench
alone
,
dame
,
"
growled
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"
You
frighten
her
.
<EOS>
""So
<EOS>
I
mean
to
do
,
"
replied
the
old
woman
;
"
she
deserves
to
be

.
<EOS>
Hark
thee
,
girl
,
we
must
get
an
order
from
her
on

without

—
for
I
do
n't

she
will
stand

to
-

.
<EOS>
""Nor
<EOS>
I
,
"
added
Ipgreve
,
"
especially

is
to

.
<EOS>
""She
has
a
chain
of
gold
round
her
throat
<EOS>
,
I
have
observed
,
"
said
the
old

;
"
we
must
get
that
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
have
it
,
"
said
Viviana
,
in

low

,
and

of
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
Here

is
.
<EOS>
""Did
<EOS>
she
give

?
<EOS>
"
cried

old
woman
,
getting

,
and

Viviana
's

with
such

,
that
she
had

in

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Did
she
give
it
thee
,
I
say?""She
gave
it
me
for
you
,
"
gasped
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
Take
it
.
"While
<EOS>
the
old
woman
held
the
chain
to
the
fire
,
and
called
to
her
husband
to
light
a
lamp
,
that
she
might
feast
her
greedy

upon

,
Viviana
flew
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
Just
as
she
reached
it
,
the
shrill

of
Dame
Ipgreve
arrested

.
<EOS>
"Come
back
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
dame
.
"
<EOS>
Whither
art
thou
going
at
this
time
of
night
?
<EOS>
I
will
not
have
thee
stir
forth
.
<EOS>
Come
back
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
""Pshaw
!
<EOS>
let
her
go
,
"
interposed
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
she
hath
an
appointment
on
the
Green
with
young
Nicholas
Hardesty
,
the
warder
.
<EOS>
Go
,
wench
.
<EOS>
Be
careful

,
and
return
within
the
hour
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
she
does
not
,
she
will

,
"
added
the
dame
.
<EOS>
"
Go
,

,
and
I
will
see

.
<EOS>
"Viviana
<EOS>
required
no
further
permission
.
<EOS>
Starting
off
as
she
had
been
directed
on
the
left
,
she
ran
as
fast
as
her
feet
could
carry
her
;
and
,
passing
between
two
arched
gateways
,
soon
reached
the
By
-
ward
Tower
.
<EOS>
Showing
the
pass
to
the
warder
,
he
chucked
her
under
the
chin
,
and
,
drawing
an
immense
bolt
,
opened
the
wicket
,
and
gallantly
helped
her
to
pass
through
it
.
<EOS>
The
like
good
success
attended
her
at
the
Middle
Tower
,
and
at
the
Bulwark
Gate
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
able
to
credit
her
senses
,
and
doubting
whether
she
was
indeed
free
,
she
hurried
on
till
she
came
to
the
opening
leading
to
the
stairs
at
Petty
Wales
.
<EOS>
As
she
hesitated
,
uncertain
what
to
do
,
a
man
advanced
towards
and
addressed
her
by
name
.
<EOS>
It
was
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
Overcome
by
emotion
,
Viviana
sank
into
his
arms
,
and
in
another
moment
she
was
placed
in
a
wherry
,
which
was
ordered
to
be
rowed
towards
Westminster
.
<EOS>
IX
.
<EOS>
—
THE
COUNTERPLOTStartled
,
but
not
dismayed
<EOS>
—
for
he
was
a
man
of
great
courage
—
by
the
sudden
address
and
appearance
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
Lord
Mounteagle
instantly
sprang
to
his
feet
,
and
drawing
his
sword
,
put
himself
into
a
posture
of
defence
.
<EOS>
"You
have
betrayed
me
,
"
he
cried
,
seizing
Tresham
with
his
left
hand
;
"
but
if
I
fall
,
you
shall
fall
with
me
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
have
betrayed
yourself
,
my
lord
,
"
rejoined
Guy
Fawkes
;
"
or
rather
,
Heaven
has
placed
you
in
our
hands
as
an
instrument
for
the
liberation
of
Viviana
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
You
must
take
an
oath
of
secrecy
—
a
binding
oath,—such
as
,
being
a
good
Catholic
,
you
can
not
break,—not
to
divulge
what
has
come
to
your
knowledge
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
you
must
join
me
and
my
confederates
,
or
you
quit
not
this
spot
with
life
.
<EOS>
""I
refuse
your
terms
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
,
resolutely
;
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
conspire
against
the
monarch
to
whom
I
have
sworn
allegiance
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
join
you
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
aid
you
in
procuring
Viviana
Radcliffe
's
release
.
<EOS>
Nor
will
I
take
the
oath
you
propose
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
I
arrest
you
as
a
traitor
,
and
I
command
you
,
Tresham
,
in
the
King
's
name
,
to
assist
me
in
his
capture
.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
suddenly
extricating
himself
from
the
grasp
imposed
upon
him
,
and
placing
Guy
Fawkes
between
him
and
the
Earl
,
Tresham
rejoined,—"It
is
time
to
throw
off
the
mask
,
my
good
lord
and
brother
.
<EOS>
I
can
render
you
no
assistance
.
<EOS>
I
am
sworn
to
this
league
,
and
must
support
it
.
<EOS>
Unless
you
assent
to
the
conditions
proposed,—and
which
for
your
own
sake
I
would
counsel
you
to
do,—I
must
,
despite
our
near
relationship
,
take
part
against
you,—even
,
"
he
added
,
significantly
,
"
if
your
destruction
should
be
resolved
upon
.
<EOS>
""I
will
sell
my
life
dearly
,
as
you
shall
find
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
but
for
the
sake
of
my
dear
lady
,
your
sister
,
I
would
stab
you
where
you
stand
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
lordship
will
find
resistance
in
vain
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
,
keeping
his
eye
steadily
fixed
upon
him
.
<EOS>
"
We
seek
not
your
life
,
but
your
co
-
operation
.
<EOS>
You
are
a
prisoner
.
<EOS>
""A
prisoner
!
"
echoed
Mounteagle
,
derisively
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
secured
me
yet
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
as
he
spoke
,
he
rushed
towards
the
door
,
but
his
departure
was
checked
by
Bates
,
who
presented
himself
at
the
entrance
of
the
passage
with
a
drawn
sword
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
,
Catesby
and
Keyes
issued
from
the
closet
,
while
Garnet
and
the
other
conspirators
likewise
emerged
from
their
hiding
-
places
.
<EOS>
Hearing
the
noise
behind
him
,
Lord
Mounteagle
turned
,
and
beholding
the
group
,
uttered
an
exclamation
of
surprise
and
rage
.
<EOS>
"I
am
fairly
entrapped
,
"
he
said
,
sheathing
his
sword
,
and
advancing
towards
them
.
"
<EOS>
Fool
that
I
was
,
to
venture
hither!""These
<EOS>
regrets
are
too
late
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You
came
hither
of
your
own
accord
.
<EOS>
But
being
here
,
nothing
,
except
compliance
with
our
demands
,
can
ensure
your
departure
.
<EOS>
""Yes
,
one
thing
else
,
"
thought
Mounteagle,—"cunning
.
<EOS>
It
shall
go
hard
if
I
can
not
outwit
you
.
<EOS>
Tresham
will
act
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
know
his
treacherous
nature
too
well
to
doubt
which
way
he
will
incline
.
<EOS>
Interest
,
as
well
as
relationship
,
binds
him
to
me
.
<EOS>
He
will
acquaint
me
with
their
plans
.
<EOS>
I
need
not
,
therefore
,
compromise
myself
by
joining
them
.
<EOS>
If
I
take
the
oath
of
secrecy
,
it
will
suffice
—
and
I
will
find
means
of
eluding
the
obligation
.
<EOS>
I
may
thus
make
my
own
bargain
with
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
proceed
cautiously
.
<EOS>
Too
sudden
a
compliance
might
awaken
their
suspicions
.
<EOS>
""My
lord
,
"
said
Catesby
,
who
had
watched
his
countenance
narrowly
,
and
distrusted
its
expression
,
"
we
must
have
no
double
-
dealing
.
<EOS>
Any
attempt
to
play
us
false
will
prove
fatal
to
you
.
<EOS>
""I
have
not
yet
consented
to
your
terms
,
Mr.
Catesby
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
,
"
and
I
demand
a
few
moments
'
reflection
before
I
do
so
.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
say
you
,
gentlemen
?
"
said
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
agree
to
his
lordship
's
request?"There
was
a
general
answer
in
the
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"I
would
also
confer
for
a
moment
alone
with
my
brother
Tresham
,
"
said
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"That
can
not
be
,
my
lord
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
,
peremptorily
.
"
<EOS>
And
take
heed
you
meditate
no
treachery
towards
us
,
or
you
will
destroy
yourself
here
and
hereafter
.
<EOS>
""I
have
no
desire
to
speak
with
him
,
father
,
"
observed
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
declare
what
he
has
to
say
before
you
all
.
<EOS>
"Mounteagle
<EOS>
looked
hard
at
him
,
but
he
made
no
remark
.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
my
opinion
,
we
ought
not
to
trust
him
,
"
observed
Keyes
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
plain
he
is
decidedly
opposed
to
us
.
<EOS>
And
if
the
oath
is
proposed
to
him
,
he
may
take
it
with
some
mental
reservation
.
<EOS>
""I
will
guard
against
that
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
I
take
the
oath
,
I
will
keep
it
,
father
,
"
rejoined
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
not
yet
decided
.
<EOS>
""You
must
do
so
,
then
,
quickly
,
my
lord
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
five
minutes
for
reflection
.
<EOS>
But
first
,
you
must
deliver
up
your
sword
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
Earl
started
.
<EOS>
"We
mean
you
no
treachery
,
my
lord
,
"
observed
Keyes
,
"
and
expect
to
be
dealt
with
with
equal
fairness
.
<EOS>
"Surrendering
<EOS>
his
sword
to
Catesby
,
Mounteagle
then
walked
to
the
farther
end
of
the
room
,
and
leaning
against
the
wall
,
with
his
back
to
the
conspirators
,
appeared
buried
in
thought
.
<EOS>
"Take
<EOS>
Tresham
aside
,
"
whispered
Catesby
to
Wright
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
wish
him
to
overhear
our
conference
.
<EOS>
Watch
him
narrowly
,
and
see
that
no
signal
passes
between
him
and
Lord
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"Wright
obeyed
;
and
the
others
gathering
closely
together
,
began
to
converse
in
a
low
tone
.
<EOS>
"It
will
not
do
to
put
him
to
death
,
"
observed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
From
what
he
stated
to
Tresham
,
it
appears
that
his
servant
was
aware
of
his
coming
hither
.
<EOS>
If
he
disappears
,
therefore
,
search
will
be
immediately
made
,
and
all
will
be
discovered
.
<EOS>
We
must
either
instantly
secure
ourselves
by
flight
,
and
give
up
the
enterprise
,
or
trust
him
.
<EOS>
""You
are
right
,
father
,
"
replied
Rookwood
.
<EOS>
"
The
danger
is
imminent
.
<EOS>
""We
are
safe
at
present
,
"
observed
Percy
,
"
and
may
escape
to
France
or
Flanders
before
information
can
be
given
against
us
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
we
may
carry
off
Mounteagle
with
us
,
for
that
matter
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
loth
to
trust
him
.
<EOS>
""So
am
I
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
like
his
looks
.
<EOS>
""There
is
no
help
,
"
said
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
trust
him
,
or
give
up
the
enterprise
.
<EOS>
He
may
materially
aid
us
,
and
has
himself
asserted
that
he
can
procure
Viviana
's
liberation
from
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
""Pshaw
!
"
exclaimed
Catesby
,
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
What
has
that
to
do
with
the
all
-
important
question
we
are
now
considering?""Much
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
And
I
will
not
move
further
in
the
matter
unless
that
point
is
insisted
on
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
have
become
strangely
interested
in
Viviana
of
late
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
sarcastically
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Could
I
suspect
you
of
so
light
a
passion
,
I
should
say
you
loved
her
.
<EOS>
"A
<EOS>
deep
flush
dyed
Fawkes
's
swarthy
cheeks
,
but
he
answered
in
a
voice
of
constrained
calmness,"I
do
love
her,—as
a
daughter
.
<EOS>
""Humph
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
other
,
drily
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
sternly
,
"
<EOS>
you
know
me
well
—
too
well
,
to
suppose
I
would
resort
to
any
paltry
subterfuge
.
<EOS>
I
am
willing
to
let
what
you
have
said
pass
.
<EOS>
But
I
counsel
you
not
to
jest
thus
in
future
.
<EOS>
""Jest
!
"
exclaimed
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
never
more
serious
in
my
life
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
you
do
me
wrong
,
"
retorted
Fawkes
,
fiercely
;
"
and
you
will
repeat
the
insinuation
at
your

.
<EOS>
""My
sons
—
my
sons
,
"
interposed
Garnet
,
"
what
means
this
sudden
—
this
needless
quarrel
,
at
a
moment
when
we
require
the
utmost
calmness
to
meet
the
danger
that
assails
us
?
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
is
right
.
<EOS>
Viviana
must
be
saved
.
<EOS>
If
we
desert
her
,
our
cause
will
never
prosper
.
<EOS>
But
let
us
proceed
step
by
step
,
and
first
decide
upon
what
is
to
be
done
with
Lord
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
""I
am
filled
with
perplexity
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"Then
I
will
decide
for
you
,
"
replied
Percy
.
<EOS>
"
Our
project
must
be
abandoned
.
<EOS>
""Never
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
energetically
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Fly
,
and
secure
your
own
safety
.
<EOS>
I
will
stay
and
accomplish
it
alone
.
<EOS>
""A
brave
resolution
!
"
exclaimed
Catesby
,
tendering
him
his
hand
,
which
the
other
cordially
grasped
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
stand
by
you
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
No
—
we
have
advanced
too
far
to
retreat
.
<EOS>
""Additional
<EOS>
caution
will
be
needful
,
"
observed
Keyes
.
<EOS>
"
Can
we
not
make
it
a
condition
with
Lord
Mounteagle
to
retire
,
till
the
blow
is
struck
,
to
his
mansion
at
Hoxton?""That
would
be
of
no
avail
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
trust
him
wholly
,
or
not
at
all
.
<EOS>
""There
<EOS>
I
agree
with
you
,
father
,
"
said
Percy
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
propose
the
oath
of
secrecy
to
him
,
and
detain
him
here
until
we
have
found
some
secure
retreat
,
utterly
unknown
to
him
,
or
to
Tresham
,
whence
we
can
correspond
with
our
friends
.
<EOS>
A
few
days
will
show
whether
he
has
betrayed
us
or
not
.
<EOS>
We
need
not
visit
this
place
again
till
the
moment
for
action
arrives
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
need
not
visit
it
again
at
all
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Everything
is
prepared
,
and
I
will
undertake
to
fire
the
train
.
<EOS>
Prepare
for
what
is
to
follow
the
explosion
,
and
leave
the
management
of
that
to
me
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
consent
to
such
a
course
,
my
son
,
"
said
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
The
whole
risk
will
thus
be
yours
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
whole
glory
will
be
mine
,
also
,
father
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
enthusiastically
.
<EOS>
"
I
pray
you
,
let
me
have
my
own
way
.
<EOS>
""Well
,
be
it
as
you
will
,
my
son
,
"
returned
Garnet
,
with
affected
reluctance
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
oppose
the
hand
of
Heaven
,
which
clearly
points
you
out
as
the
chief
agent
in
this
mighty
enterprise
.
<EOS>
In
reference
to
what
Percy
has
said
about
a
retreat
till
Lord
Mounteagle
's
trust
-
worthiness
can
be
ascertained
,
"
he
added
to
Catesby
,
"
I
have
just
bethought
me
of
a
large
retired
house
on
the
borders
of
Enfield
Chase
,
called
White
Webbs
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
recently
taken
by
Mrs.
Brooksby
,
and
her
sister
,
Anne
Vaux
,
and
will
afford
us
a
safe
asylum
.
<EOS>
""An
excellent
plan
,
father
,
"
cried
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
Since
Guy
Fawkes
is
willing
to
undertake
the
risk
,
we
will
leave
Lord
Mounteagle
in
his
charge
,
and
go
there
at
once
.
<EOS>
""What
must
be
done
with
Tresham
?
"
asked
Percy
.
<EOS>
"
We
can
not
take
him
with
us
,
nor
must
he
know
of
our
retreat
.
<EOS>
""Leave
him
with
me
,
"
said
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"You
will
be
at
a
disadvantage
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
"
should
he
take
part
,
as
there
is
reason
to
fear
he
may
do
,
with
Lord
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
""They
are
both
unarmed
,
"
returned
Fawkes
;
"
but
were
it
otherwise
,
I
would
answer
with
my
head
for
their
detention
.
<EOS>
""All
<EOS>
good
saints
guard
you
,
my
son
!
"
exclaimed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Henceforth
,
we
resign
the
custody
of
the
powder
to
you
.
<EOS>
""It
will
be
in
safe
keeping
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
The
party
then
advanced
towards
Lord
Mounteagle
,
who
,
hearing
their
approach
,
instantly
faced
them
.
<EOS>
"Your
decision
,
my
lord
?
"
demanded
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
shall
have
it
in
a
word
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
,
firmly
.
<EOS>
"I
will
not
join
you
,
but
I
will
take
the
required
oath
of
secrecy
.
<EOS>
""Is
<EOS>
this
your
final
resolve
,
my
lord
?
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"It
is
,
"
replied
the
Earl
.
"It
<EOS>
must
content
us
,
"
observed
Garnet
;
"
though
we
hoped
you
would
have
lent
your
active
services
to
further
a
cause
,
having
for
its
sole
object
the
restoration
of
the
church
to
which
you
belong
.
<EOS>
""I
know
not
the
means
whereby
you
propose
to
restore
it
,
father
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
,
"
and
I
do
not
desire
to
know
them
.
<EOS>
But
I
guess
that
they
are
dark
and
bloody
,
and
as
such
I
can
take
no
part
in
them
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
you
refuse
to
give
us
any
counsel
or
assistance
?
<EOS>
"
pursued
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"I
will
not
betray
you
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
say
nothing
further
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
would
rather
he
promised
too
little
,
than
too
much
,
"
whispered
Catesby
to
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
I
begin
to
think
him
sincere
.
<EOS>
""I
am
of
the
same
opinion
,
my
son
,
"
returned
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"One
<EOS>
thing
you
shall
do
,
before
I
consent
to
set
you
free
,
on
any
terms
,
my
lord
,
"
observed
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
engage
to
procure
the
liberation
of
Viviana
Radcliffe
from
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
You
told
Tresham
you
could
easily
accomplish
it
.
<EOS>
""I
scarcely
knew
what
I
said
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
,
with
a
look
of
embarrassment
.
<EOS>
"You
spoke
confidently
,
my
lord
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Because
<EOS>
I
had
no
idea
I
should
be
compelled
to
make
good
my
words
,
"
returned
the
Earl
.
"
<EOS>
But
as
a
Catholic
,
and
related
by
marriage
to
Tresham
,
who
is
a
suspected
person
,
any
active
exertions
in
her
behalf
on
my
part
might
place
me
in
jeopardy
.
<EOS>
""This
excuse
shall
not
avail
you
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
weigh
your
own
safety
against
hers
.
<EOS>
You
stir
not
hence
till
you
have
sworn
to
free
her
.
<EOS>
""I
must
perforce
assent
,
since
you
will
have
no
refusal
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
almost
despair
of
success
.
<EOS>
If
I
can
effect
her
deliverance
,
I
swear
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
""Enough
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
now
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Catesby
,
appealing
to
the
others
,
"
are
you
willing
to
let
Lord
Mounteagle
depart
upon
the
proposed
terms?""We
are
,
"
they
replied
.
<EOS>
"I
will
administer
the
oath
at
once
,
"
said
Garnet
;
"
and
you
will
bear
in
mind
,
my
son
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
stern
tone
to
the
Earl
,
"
that
it
will
be
one
which
can
not
be
violated
without
perdition
to
your
soul
.
<EOS>
""I
am
willing
to
take
it
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
Producing
a
primer
,
and
motioning
the
Earl
to
kneel
before
him
,
Garnet
then
proposed
an
oath
of
the
most
solemn
and
binding
description
.
<EOS>
The
other
repeated
it
after
him
,
and
at
its
conclusion
placed
the
book
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
"Are
<EOS>
you
satisfied
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"I
am
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
so
am
I
,
"
thought
Tresham
,
who
stood
in
the
rear
,
"
—
that
he
will
perjure
himself
.
<EOS>
""Am
I
now
at
liberty
to
depart
?
"
inquired
the
Earl
.
"Not
<EOS>
yet
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
remain
here
till
midnight
.
<EOS>
"Lord
<EOS>
Mounteagle
looked
uneasy
,
but
seeing
remonstrance
would
be
useless
,
he
preserved
a
sullen
silence
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
need
have
no
fear
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
But
we
must
take
such
precautions
as
will
ensure
our
safety
,
in
case
you
intend
us
any
treachery
.
<EOS>
""You
can
not
doubt
me
,
sir
,
after
the
oath
I
have
taken
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
,
haughtily
.
<EOS>
"
But
since
you
constitute
yourself
my
jailer
,
I
must
abide
your
pleasure
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
I
am
your
jailer
,
my
lord
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
"
I
will
prove
to
you
that
I
am
not
neglectful
of
my
office
.
<EOS>
Will
it
please
you
to
follow
<EOS>
me?"The
Earl
bowed
in
acquiescence
;
and
Catesby
,
marching
before
him
to
a
small
room
,
the
windows
of
which
were
carefully
barred
,
pointed
to
a
chair
,
and
instantly
retiring
,
locked
the
door
upon
him
.
<EOS>
He
then
returned
to
the
others
,
and
taking
Guy
Fawkes
aside
,
observed
in
a
low
tone,"We
shall
set
out
instantly
for
White
Webbs
.
<EOS>
You
will
remain
on
guard
with
Tresham
,
whom
you
will
,
of
course
,
keep
in
ignorance
of
our
proceedings
.
<EOS>
After
you
have
set
the
Earl
at
liberty
,
you
can
follow
us
if
you
choose
.
<EOS>
But
take
heed
you
are
not
observed
.
<EOS>
""Fear
nothing
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
,
Catesby
,
and
the
rest
of
the
conspirators
,
with
the
exception
of
Guy
Fawkes
and
Tresham
,
quitted
the
room
,
and
the
former
concluded
they
were
about
to
leave
the
house
.
<EOS>
He
made
no
remark
,
however
,
to
his
companion
;
but
getting
between
him
and
the
door
,
folded
his
arms
upon
his
breast
,
and
continued
to
pace
backwards
and
forwards
before
it
.
<EOS>
"Am
<EOS>
I
a
prisoner
,
as
well
as
Lord
Mounteagle
?
"
asked
Tresham
,
after
a
pause
.
<EOS>
"You
must
remain
with
me
here
till
midnight
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
not
be
disturbed
.
<EOS>
""What
!
<EOS>
are
the
others
gone
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"They
are
,
"
was
the
reply
.
<EOS>
Tresham
's
countenance
fell
,
and
he
appeared
to
be
meditating
some
project
,
which
he
could
not
muster
courage
to
execute
.
<EOS>
"Be
warned
by
the
past
,
Tresham
,
"
said
Fawkes
,
who
had
regarded
him
fixedly
for
some
minutes
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
find
reason
to
doubt
you
,
I
will
put
it
out
of
your
power
to
betray
us
a
second
time
.
<EOS>
""You
have
no
reason
to
doubt
me
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
with
apparent
candour
.
<EOS>
"
I
only
wondered
that
our
friends
should
leave
me
without
any
intimation
of
their
purpose
.
<EOS>
It
is
for
me
,
not
you
,
to
apprehend
some
ill
design
.
<EOS>
Am
I
not
to
act
with
you
further?""That
depends
upon
yourself
,
and
on
the
proofs
you
give
of
your
sincerity
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Answer
me
frankly
.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
Lord
Mounteagle
will
keep
his
oath?""I
will
stake
my
life
upon
it
,
"
replied
Tresham
.
<EOS>
The
conversation
then
dropped
,
and
no
attempt
was
made
on
either
side
to
renew
it
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
several
hours
passed
,
when
at
length
the
silence
was
broken
by
Tresham
,
who
requested
permission
to
go
in
search
of
some
refreshment
;
and
Guy
Fawkes
assenting
,
they
descended
to
the
lower
room
,
and
partook
of
a
slight
repast
.
<EOS>
Nothing
further
worthy
of
note
occurred
.
<EOS>
On
the
arrival
of
the
appointed
hour
,
Guy
Fawkes
signified
to
his
companion
that
he
might
liberate
Lord
Mounteagle
;
and
immediately
availing
himself
of
the
permission
,
Tresham
repaired
to
the
chamber
,
and
threw
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
immediately
came
forth
,
and
they
returned
together
to
the
room
in
which
Guy
Fawkes
remained
on
guard
.
<EOS>
"You
are
now
at
liberty
to
depart
,
my
lord
,
"
said
the
latter
;
"
and
Tresham
can
accompany
you
,
if
he
thinks
proper
.
<EOS>
Remember
that
you
have
sworn
to
procure
Viviana
's
liberation
.
<EOS>
""I
do
,
"
replied
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
And
he
then
quitted
the
house
with
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
have
had
a
narrow
escape
,
my
lord
,
"
remarked
the
latter
as
they
approached
Whitehall
,
and
paused
for
a
moment
under
the
postern
of
the
great
western
gate
.
<EOS>
"True
,
"
replied
the
Earl
;
"
but
I
do
not
regret
the
risk
I
have
run
.
<EOS>
They
are
now
wholly
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
forget
your
oath
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"If
I
do
,
"
replied
the
Earl
,
"
<EOS>
I
but
follow
your
example
.
<EOS>
You
have
broken
one
equally
solemn
,
equally
binding
,
and
would
break
a
thousand
more
were
they
imposed
upon
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
overthrow
this
conspiracy
,
and
yet
not
violate
mine
.
<EOS>
""I
see
not
how
that
can
be
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"You
shall
learn
in
due
season
,
"
replied
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
had
plenty
of
leisure
for
reflection
in
that
dark
hole
,
and
have
hit
upon
a
plan
which
,
I
think
,
can
not
fail
.
<EOS>
""I
hope
I
am
no
party
to
it
,
my
lord
,
"
rejoined
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
I
dare
not
hazard
myself
among
them
further
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
do
without
you
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
;
"
but
I
will
ensure
you
against
all
danger
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
necessary
for
you
,
however
,
to
act
with
the
utmost
discretion
,
and
keep
a
constant
guard
upon
every
look
and
movement
,
as
well
as
upon
your
words
.
<EOS>
You
must
fully
regain
the
confidence
of
these
men
,
and
lull
them
into
security
.
<EOS>
""I
see
your
lordship
's
drift
,
"
replied
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
You
wish
them
to
proceed
to
the
last
point
,
to
enhance
the
value
of
the
discovery
.
<EOS>
""Right
,
"
replied
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
The
plot
must
not
be
discovered
till
just
before
its
outbreak
,
when
its
magnitude
and
danger
will
be
the
more
apparent
.
<EOS>
The
reward
will
then
be
proportionate
.
<EOS>
Now
,
you
understand
me
,
Tresham
.
<EOS>
""Fully
,
"
replied
the
other
.
<EOS>
"Return
<EOS>
to
your
own
house
,
"
rejoined
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
We
need
hold
no
further
communication
together
till
the
time
for
action
arrives
.
<EOS>
""And
that
will
not
be
before
the
meeting
of
Parliament
,
"
replied
Tresham
;
"
for
they
intend
to
whelm
the
King
and
all
his
nobles
in
one
common
destruction
.
<EOS>
""By
Heaven
!
<EOS>
a
brave
design
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
pity
to
mar
it
.
<EOS>
I
knew
it
was
a
desperate
and
daring
project
,
but
should
never
have
conceived
aught
like
this
.
<EOS>
Its
discovery
will
indeed
occasion
universal
consternation
.
<EOS>
""It
may
benefit
you
and
me
to
divulge
it
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Tresham
;
"
but
the
disclosure
will
deeply
and
lastingly
injure
the
Church
of
Rome
.
<EOS>
""It
would
injure
it
more
deeply
if
the
plot
succeeded
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
,
"
because
all
loyal
Catholics
must
disapprove
so
horrible
and
sanguinary
a
design
.
<EOS>
But
we
will
not
discuss
the
question
further
,
though
what
you
have
said
confirms
my
purpose
,
and
removes
any
misgiving
I
might
have
felt
as
to
the
betrayal
.
<EOS>
Farewell
,
Tresham
.
<EOS>
Keep
a
watchful
eye
upon
the
conspirators
,
and
communicate
with
me
should
any
change
take
place
in
their
plans
.
<EOS>
We
may
not
meet
for
some
time
.
<EOS>
Parliament
,
though
summoned
for
the
third
of
October
,
will
,
in
all
probability
,
be
prorogued
till
November
.
<EOS>
""In
<EOS>
that
case
,
"
replied
Tresham
<EOS>
,
"
you
will
postpone
your
disclosure
likewise
till
November?""Assuredly
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
King
must
be
convinced
of
his
danger
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
found
out
now
,
he
would
think
lightly
of
it
.
<EOS>
But
if
he
has
actually
set
foot
upon
the
mine
which
a
single
spark
might
kindle
to
his
destruction
,
he
will
duly
appreciate
the
service
rendered
him
.
<EOS>
Farewell
!
<EOS>
and
do
not
neglect
my
counsel
.
<EOS>
"X.
<EOS>
—
WHITE
WEBBSTarrying
for
a
short
time
within
the
house
after
the
departure
of
the
others
,
Guy
Fawkes
lighted
a
lantern
,
and
concealing
it
beneath
his
cloak
,
proceeded
to
the
cellar
,
to
ascertain
that
the
magazine
of
powder
was
safe
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
of
this
,
he
made
all
secure
,
and
was
about
to
return
to
the
house
,
when
he
perceived
a
figure
approaching
him
.
<EOS>
Standing
aside
,
but
keeping
on
his
guard
for
fear
of
a
surprise
,
he
would
have
allowed
the
person
to
pass
,
but
the
other
halted
,
and
after
a
moment
's
scrutiny
addressed
him
by
name
in
the

of
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"You
seem
to
haunt
this
spot
,
young

,
"
said
Fawkes
,
in
answer

.
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
third

have

hereabouts
.
<EOS>
""On
the
last
occasion
<EOS>
,
"

,
"
I

Viviana
was
a

in

Tower
.
<EOS>
I
have
now
better

for

.
<EOS>
She
is
free
.
<EOS>
""Free
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Fawkes
,
joyfully
.
"
<EOS>
By
Lord
Mounteagle
's

I
forget
.
<EOS>
He
has
only
just
left

.
<EOS>
""She
<EOS>
has

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>

?
"

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"Heaven

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Your

so

,

,

.
<EOS>
""Come

,

"

.
<EOS>
And

,

,
where

.
<EOS>
Within

Viviana
,
covered
by

.
<EOS>
Assisting
her
to
land
,
and

she

too
much

,
Guy
Fawkes
took

in

and
carried

to

house

just

.
<EOS>
Humphrey
Chetham
followed
as
soon
as
he
had
dismissed
the
waterman
.
<EOS>
Placing
his
lovely
burthen
in

seat
,
Guy
Fawkes
instantly
went
in
search
of
such

as

.
<EOS>
Viviana
was
extremely

,
but
after

had
swallowed
a
glass

wine
,
she
revived
,
and
,

,
inquired

.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
not

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
And

"

"
perhaps
,

Chetham
will
inform

in
what
manner
he
contrived
your
escape
.
<EOS>
I
am
impatient
to
know
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
young
merchant
then

the

,
and
Viviana
added
such

as

.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
could

,

less

.
<EOS>
"You

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
""Thank

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

"Oh

"

"

.
<EOS>
If

<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
Have

no
,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
young

to

.
"Not
<EOS>
even

hope
!
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Viviana

.
<EOS>
Does

<EOS>
so
,
"

,
"
nay
,

<EOS>

Chetham
.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
""I

,
"

<EOS>
"It

,
"

Guy
Fawkes
;
"
and
I

that
I

Humphrey
Chetham
has
rendered
you
entitle

to

.
<EOS>
It
is
seldom
—
whatever
poets

feign,—that
love
is
so
strongly
proved
as
his
has
been
;
and

.
<EOS>
""Say

no

<EOS>
,

"

.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
I

"

Fawkes
,
"
because
I

what

.
<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
Nor

.
<EOS>
""Oh
,

!
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
This

.
<EOS>
""What

<EOS>
"

,

"She

,
"

,
"
that

—

.
<EOS>
""True

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

—
I

.
<EOS>
""You

,
"

Fawkes
.
"
<EOS>
And
I

nothing

female

,

to
youth

,

Chetham
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
do

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Women
's

.
<EOS>
""Such

,
"

Fawkes
;
"
but

,

.
<EOS>
You

I

—
<EOS>
nay
,

.
<EOS>
""No

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
""This

,
"

Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Viviana
has
given

a
father
with
her
.
<EOS>
And
where
her

is
so
much

as
in
the
present

,
I
should
imperfectly
discharge

duty
if
I

not

.
<EOS>
It

sincerely

,
and
I

sure

,

.
<EOS>
""I

—
I

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
""You

.
"

.
<EOS>
""I

""You

.
<EOS>
"Whom

?
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"I

"

"Oh

.

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who

,
"

.
<EOS>
"What

"

,

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
She

nothing

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>
A

season
may

.
<EOS>
"After
<EOS>
some

,

Viviana

White
Webbs
;
and

in

,
Guy

Enfield
.
<EOS>
Traversing
the
Strand,—every
hostel
in
which
was
closed,—he
turned
up
Wych
-
street
,
immediately
on
the
right
of
which
there
was
a
large
inn
<EOS>
(
still

existence
)
,
and

,

knot

in

.
<EOS>
To

respecting
a
conveyance
to
Enfield
,
one

answered
,
that
he
was
about

thither
with
his
waggon
at
four

was
then
two,—and
should
be

to
take

and

.
<EOS>
Overjoyed
at
the

,
and
at
once

to
the
man
's
terms
,
Guy
Fawkes
hurried
back
to
his
companions
,
and
,
with
the
assistance
of
Humphrey
Chetham
,
contrived
to
carry
Viviana
(
for
she
was
utterly
unable

)
to
the
inn
-
yard
,
where
she
was
immediately
placed
in

,
on

.
<EOS>
About
an
hour
after
this
,
but
long
before
daybreak
,
the
carrier
attached
his
horses
to
the
waggon
,
and
set

.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
and
Humphrey
Chetham
were
seated
near
Viviana
,
but
little
was
said
during
the
journey
,
which
occupied
about
three
hours
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
it
was
broad
daylight
;
and
as
the
carrier
stopped
at
the
door
of
a
small
inn
,
Guy
Fawkes
alighted
,
and
inquired
the
distance
to
White
Webbs
.
<EOS>
"It
is
about
a
mile
and
a
half
off
,
"
replied
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
pursue
that
lane
,
it
will
bring
you
to
a
small

about
half
a
mile
from
this
,
where
you
are
sure

some
one
who
will

to
the
house
,
which
is
a
little
out
of

,
on

forest
.
"He
<EOS>
then
assisted
Viviana
to

,
and
Humphrey
Chetham
descending
at
the
same

,
the
party
took
the
road
indicated
—
a
winding

lane
with
high

,
broken
by

—
and

slow

,
they
arrived
in
about

,

Guy
Fawkes
guessed
to
be
the
village

carrier
.
<EOS>
As

,

leaped
a

,
and
was
about
to
cross
to
another
field
,
when
Guy
Fawkes
calling
to
him
,
inquired
the
way
to
White
Webbs
.
<EOS>
"I
am
going
in
that
direction
,
"
replied
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
desire
it
,
I
will
show
you
the
road
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
shall
feel
much

you
,
friend
,
"
returned
Fawkes
,
"
and

.
<EOS>
""I

no

,
"
returned

countryman
,

.
<EOS>
Following

,
after

they
reached
the
borders
of
the
forest
,
and
took
their

along
a
patch

greensward
that

.
<EOS>
In
some

their

was

,
while
at
others

opened
upon
them
,
affording

peeps
into
the
heart
of
the
wood
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
beautiful
sylvan
scene
.
<EOS>
And
as
at
length
they
arrived
at
the
head
of
a
long

,

the
farther
end
of
which
a

deer
were
seen
,
with
their
branching

mingling
with

overhanging

,
Viviana
could
not
help
pausing
to
admire
it
.
<EOS>
"King
<EOS>
James
often
hunts
within
the
forest
,
"
observed
the
countryman
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
heard
one
of
the
rangers
say
it

not

might
be

.
<EOS>
He

's

.
<EOS>
""Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
proceed
.
<EOS>
We
lose
time
.
<EOS>
Are
we
far
from
the
house?""Not
above
a
quarter
of
a
mile
,
"
was
the
answer
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
see
it
at

road
.
<EOS>
"As
the
countryman
had
intimated
,
they
speedily
perceived
the
roof
and
tall
chimneys
of
an
ancient
house
above
the
trees
,
and
as
it
was
now
impossible
to
mistake
the
road
,
Guy
Fawkes
thanked
their
guide
for
his
trouble
,
and
would
have
rewarded
him
,
but
he
refused
the
gratuity
,
and
leaping
a
hedge
,
disappeared
.
<EOS>
Pursuing
the
road
,
they
shortly
afterwards
arrived
at
a
gate
leading
to
the
house
—
a
large
building
,
erected
probably
at
the
beginning
of
Elizabeth
's
reign
—
and
entering
it
,
they
passed
under
an
avenue
of
trees
.
<EOS>
On
approaching
the
mansion
,
they
observed
that
many
of
the
windows
were
closed
,
and
the
whole
appearance
of
the
place
was
melancholy
and
deserted
.
<EOS>
The
garden
was
overgrown
with
weeds
,
and
the
door
looked
as
if
it
was
rarely
opened
.
<EOS>
Not
discouraged
by
these
appearances
,
but
rather
satisfied
by
them
of
the
security
of
the
asylum
,
Guy
Fawkes
proceeded
to
the
back
of
the
house
,
and
entering
a
court
,
the
flags
and
stones
of
which
were
covered
with
moss
,
while
the
interstices
were
filled
with
long
grass
,
Guy
Fawkes
knocked
against
a
small
door
,
and
,
after
repeating
the
summons
,
it
was
answered
by
an
old
woman
-
servant
,
who
popped
her
head
out
of
an
upper
window
,
and
demanded
his
business
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
was
about
to
inquire
for
Mrs.
Brooksby
,
when
another
head
,
which
proved
to
be
that
of
Catesby
,
appeared
at
the
window
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
Fawkes
and
his
companions
,
Catesby
instantly
descended
,
and
unfastened
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
house
proved
far
more
comfortable
within
than
its
exterior
promised
;
and
the
old
female
domestic
having
taken
word
to
Anne
Vaux
that
Viviana
was
below
,
the
former
lady
,
who
had
not
yet
risen
,
sent
for
her
to
her
chamber
,
and
provided
everything
for
her
comfort
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
and
Humphrey
Chetham
,
neither
of
whom
had
rested
during
the
night
,
were
glad
to
obtain
a
few
hours
'
repose
on
the
floor
of
the
first
room
into
which
they
were
shown
,
and
they
were
not
disturbed
until
the
day
had
considerably
advanced
,
when
Catesby
thought
fit
to
rouse

from
their
slumbers
.
<EOS>
Explanations
were
then
given
on
both
sides
.
<EOS>
Chetham
detailed
the
manner
of
Viviana
's
escape
from
the
Tower
,
and
Catesby
in
his
turn
acquainted
them
that
Father
Oldcorne
was
in
the
house
,
having
found
his
way
thither
after
his
escape
from
the
dwelling
at
Lambeth
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
was
greatly
rejoiced
at
the
intelligence
,
and
shortly
afterwards
had
the
satisfaction
of
meeting
with
the
priest
.
<EOS>
At
noon
,
the
whole
party
assembled
,
with
the
exception

Viviana
,
who
,

of
Anne

,
kept

,
to
recruit

after
the

.
<EOS>
Humphrey
Chetham
,
of
whom
no

were
now

,
and
of
whom
Catesby
no
longer
felt
any

,
was
invited
to
stay
in
the
house
;
and
he
was
easily
induced
to
pass
his
time
near
Viviana
,
although
he
might
not
be
able
to
see
her
.
<EOS>
Long
and
frequent

were
held
by
the
conspirators
,
and
letters
were
despatched
by
Catesby
to
the
elder
Winter
at

seat
,
Huddington
,
in

,
entreating

to

for

,

to

,

,
at
Dunchurch
,

,

.
<EOS>
Arrangements
were
next
made
as
to
the
steps
to
be

by
the
different

after
the
explosion
.
<EOS>
Catesby
undertook
,
with
a
sufficient

,
to
seize
the
Princess
Elizabeth
,
the

of
James
the
First
,
who

then
at
the

of

of
Harrington
,

,
and
to

,
in

.
<EOS>
It
was
supposed
that
Henry
,
Prince
of

,
(
who
,

need
scarcely

,

,
)

with
the
King
,

,
in

,

;

,

Charles
,

,
(

,
)

,
it
was
resolved
that
he
should
be
seized
by
Percy
,
and
instantly

.
<EOS>
Other
resolutions
were
decided
upon
,
and
the
whole
time
of
the
conspirators
was
spent
in
maturing
their
projects
.
<EOS>
And
thus
weeks
,
and
even
months
,
stole
on
.
<EOS>
Viviana
had
completely
regained
her
strength
,
and
passed
a
life
of
perfect

,
seldom
,
if

,

with

others
.
<EOS>
She
,

,

of
Humphrey

,

(

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Meetings

,
and

had
more

Tresham
—
but

,

.
<EOS>
The

end

September
had
now

,

was

the
third

.
<EOS>
On

,

prepared

;
but

.
<EOS>
They
had

;
nor
,

of

,
(
and

,
)

.
<EOS>
As
she

room
,
in

,

agitated
his
frame
,
but
he
had
nerved
himself
for
the
interview
,
and
speedily
subdued
the
feeling
.
<EOS>
"I
am
starting
for
London
,
Viviana
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
voice
of
forced

.
<EOS>
"
You
may
guess
for
what
purpose
.
<EOS>
But
as
I
may
never
behold
you
again
,
I
would
not

you
without
a
confession

my

.
<EOS>
I
will
not

that
what
Humphrey
Chetham
stated
,
and
which
you

never

—
namely
,
that
you
loved
me
,
for
I
must

—
has
produced
a

effect
upon

.
<EOS>
I
have
endeavoured
to
conquer
it
,
but
it
will
return
.
<EOS>
Till
I
knew
you
I
never
loved
,
Viviana
.
<EOS>
""Indeed
!
<EOS>
"
she

.
<EOS>
"Never
,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
The
fairest
had
not

.
<EOS>
But
I
grieve
to
say
—
<EOS>
notwithstanding

—
I
do
not

.
<EOS>
""Ah
!
<EOS>
"
she
ejaculated
,

.
<EOS>
"Why
<EOS>
should

?
<EOS>
Why

I

that
—

—

?
<EOS>
Why

that

,

we

mean

?
<EOS>
"

,
with

.
<EOS>
"I
will
tell
you
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Till
I
saw
you
,
my
thoughts
were
removed

,
and
fixed

.
<EOS>
Till

,
I

not

,

.
""Die
<EOS>
so

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
Forget

—
<EOS>
oh
!

.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
can

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Nay
,

,

.
<EOS>
""I

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Oh
that
I

—

you!""Save
me
!
<EOS>
"

Fawkes
,

.
<EOS>
"
You
destroy
me
.
""How
?
<EOS>
"
she

.
<EOS>
"Because
<EOS>
I
am
sworn

,
"
he

;
"
and

I

,
I

perish

.
<EOS>
""Oh
!
<EOS>
say

<EOS>
,
"

,
"
but

.
<EOS>
Abandon

,

I
will

.
<EOS>
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
gazed

for

,
and
then
,

his

,

.
<EOS>
Viviana
approached

,
and
pressing

,
asked
in

,
"
Are
you
still

am
,
"

,

,
and

;
"
but
,
if
I
remain

,

.
<EOS>
""I

,

,
"
she

,
"

.
<EOS>
""No
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he

,

.
<EOS>
"
It
must

.
<EOS>
Farewell
,
for
ever!"And
breaking
from

,

rushed

.
<EOS>
As
he
gained
the
passage
,
he

Catesby
,
who

at

.
<EOS>
"I
have
overheard
what
has
passed
,
"
said
the
latter
,
"
and
applaud

.
<EOS>
Few

,

,
would

.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
would
not
,
"

,

.
"Perhaps
<EOS>
not
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But
that
does
not
lessen

.
<EOS>
""I
am
devoted
to
one

,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
"
and
nothing

.
<EOS>
""Remove
yourself
instantly
from
temptation
<EOS>
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

Parliament

to

.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
accompanied
Guy
Fawkes
to
the
door
;
and
the
latter
,
without
hazarding
a

behind
him
,
set
out
for
London
,
where
he
arrived
at

.
<EOS>
On
the
following
night
,
Fawkes
examined
the
cellar
,
and
found
it
in
all
respects
as
he
had
left
it
;
and
,
apprehensive
lest
some

might
arise
,
he
resolved
to
make
every
preparation
.
<EOS>
He
,
accordingly
,
pierced
the
sides
of
several
of
the
barrels
piled
against
the
walls
with
a
gimlet
,
and
inserted
in
the
holes
small
pieces
of
slow
-
burning
match
.
<EOS>
Not
content
with
this
,
he
staved
in
the
tops
of
the
uppermost
tier
,
and
scattered
powder
among
them
to
secure
their
instantaneous
ignition
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
took
a
powder
-
horn
,
with
which
he
was
provided
,
and
kneeling
down
,
and
holding
his
lantern
so
as
to
throw
a
light
upon
the
floor
,
laid
a
train
to
one
of
the
lower
barrels
,
and
brought
it
within
a
few
inches
of
the
door
,
intending
to
fire
it
from
that
point
.
<EOS>
His
arrangements
completed
,
he
arose
,
and
muttered,"A
vessel
is
provided
for
my
escape
in
the
river
,
and
my
companions
advise
me
to
use
a
slow
match
,
which
will
allow
me
to
get
out
of
harm
's
way
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
see
the
deed
done
,
and
if
the
train
fails
,
will
hold
a
torch
to
the
barrels
myself
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
this
juncture
,
a
slight
tap
was
heard
without
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
instantly
masked
his
lantern
,
and
cautiously
opening
the
door
,
beheld
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
am
come
to
tell
you
that
Parliament
is
prorogued
,
"
said

latter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
House
does
not
meet
till
the
fifth

.
<EOS>
We
have
another
month
to
wait
.
<EOS>
""I

,
"

Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I

just
laid
