.
<EOS>
The
lucky
moment
will
pass
.
"And
,
locking

,
he

to

.
<EOS>
They
had
scarcely

gone
more
than

,
when

.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
""That

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
""Another
month
!
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
Who

<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
""There

"

.
<EOS>
"
But

.
<EOS>
"XI
.
<EOS>
—
THE
MARRIAGE
IN
THE
FORESTTresham
,

have
been
conjectured
that
he
was
one
of
the
speakers
mentioned
in
the
preceding
chapter
,
on
separating
from
Lord
Mounteagle
,
took
the
same
direction
as
the
conspirators
.
<EOS>
He
hesitated
for
some
time
before
venturing
to
knock
at
the
garden
-
gate
;
and
when
he
had
done
so
,
felt
half
-
disposed
to
take
to
his
heels
.
<EOS>
But
shame
restrained
him
;
and
hearing
footsteps
approach
,
he
gave
the
customary
signal
,
and
was
instantly
admitted
by
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"What
brings
you
here
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
latter
,
as
they
entered
the
house
,
and
made
fast
the
door
behind
them
.
<EOS>
"I
have
just
heard
that
Parliament
is
prorogued
to
the
fifth
of
November
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
"
and
came
to
tell
you
so
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
already
know
it
,
"
returned
Fawkes
,
gloomily
;
"
and
for
the
first
time
feel
some
misgiving
as
to
the
issue
of
our
enterprise
.
<EOS>
""Why
<EOS>
so
?
"
inquired
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"November
<EOS>
is
unlucky
to
me
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
"
and
I
can
not
recollect
a
year
in
my
life
in
which
some
ill
has
not
befallen
me
during
that
month
,
especially
on
the
fifth
day
.
<EOS>
On
the
last
fifth
of
November
,
I
nearly
died
of
a
fever
at
Madrid
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
strange
and
unfortunate
coincidence
that
the
meeting
of
the
Parliament
should
be
appointed
for
that
particular
day
.
<EOS>
""Shall
<EOS>
I
tell
you
what
I
think
it
portends
?
"
hesitated
Tresham
.
"Do
<EOS>
so
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
"
and
speak
boldly
.
<EOS>
I
am
no
child
to
be
frightened
at
shadows
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
have
more
than
once
declared
your
intention
of
perishing
with
our
foes
,
"
rejoined
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
design
,
though
prosperous
in
itself
,
may
be
fatal
to
you
.
<EOS>
""You
are
right
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
little
doubt
I
shall
perish
on
that
day
.
<EOS>
You
are
both
aware
of
my
superstitious
nature
,
and
are
not
ignorant
that
many
mysterious
occurrences
have
combined
to
strengthen
the
feeling,—such
as
the
dying
words
of
the
prophetess
,
Elizabeth
Orton,—her
warning
speech
when
she
was
raised
from
the
dead
by
Doctor
Dee,—and
lastly
,
the
vision
at
<EOS>
St.
Winifred
's
Well
.
<EOS>
What
if
I
tell
you
the
saint
has
again
appeared
to
me?""In
a
dream
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Catesby
,
in
a
slightly
sceptical
tone
.
<EOS>
"Ay
,
in
a
dream
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
saw
her
as
plainly
as
if
I
had
been
awake
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
same
vapoury
figure
—
the
same
transparent

,
the
same
benign
countenance
,
only
far
more
pitying
than
before
—
that
I
beheld
at
Holywell
.
<EOS>
I
heard
no
sound
issue
from
her
lips
,
but
I
feltthat
she
warned
me
to
desist
.
<EOS>
""Do
you
accept
the
warning
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Tresham
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"It
is
needless
to
answer
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
laid
the
train
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
have
infected
me
with
your
misgivings
,
"
observed
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Would
the
enterprise
had
never
been
undertaken!""But
being
undertaken
,
it
must
be
gone
through
with
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
sternly
.
"
<EOS>
Hark'e
,
Tresham
.
<EOS>
You
promised
us
two
thousand
pounds
in
aid
of
the
project
,
but
have
constantly
deferred
payment
of
the
sum
on
some
plea
or
other
.
<EOS>
""Because
<EOS>
I
have
not
been
able
to
raise
it
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
sullenly
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
tried
in
vain
to
sell
part
of
my
estates
at
Rushton
,
in
Northamptonshire
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
effect
impossibilities
.
<EOS>
""Tush
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
You
well
know
I
ask
no
impossibility
.
<EOS>
I
will
no
longer
be
trifled
with
.
<EOS>
The
money
must
be
forthcoming
by
the
tenth
of
October
,
or
you
shall
pay
the
penalty
with
your
life
.
<EOS>
""This
is
the
language
of
a
cut
-
throat
,
Mr.
Catesby
,
"
replied
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"It
is
the
only
language
I
will
hold
towards
you
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
contemptuously
.
<EOS>
"
Look
you
disappoint
me
not
,
or
take
the
consequences
.
<EOS>
""I
must
leave
for
Northamptonshire
at
once
,
then
,
"
said
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
as
you
please
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Play
the
cut
-
throat
yourself
,
and
ease
some
rich
miser
of
his
store
,
if
you
think
fit
.
<EOS>
Bring
us
the
money
,
and
we
will
not
ask
how
you
came
by
it
.
<EOS>
""Before
<EOS>
we
separate
,
"
said
Tresham
,
disregarding
these
sneers
<EOS>
,
"
I
wish
to
be
resolved
on
one
point
.
<EOS>
Who
are
to
be
saved
from
destruction?""Why
<EOS>
do
you
ask
?
"
inquired
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Because
<EOS>
I
must
stipulate
for
the
lives
of
my
brothers
-
in
-
law
,
the
Lords
Mounteagle
and

.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
anything
detains
them
from
the

,
well

,
"
replied
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
But
no
warning
must
be
given
them
.
<EOS>
That
would
infallibly
lead
to
a
discovery
of
the
plot
.
<EOS>
""Some
means
might
surely
be
adopted
to
put
them
on
their
guard
without
danger
to
ourselves
?
"
urged
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
know
of
none
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"Nor
<EOS>
I
,
"
added
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
did
,
I
would
warn
Lord
Montague
,
and
some
others
whom
I
shall
grieve
to
destroy
.
<EOS>
""We
are
all
similarly
circumstanced
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Keyes
is
anxious
for
the
preservation
of
his
patron
and
friend
,
Lord
Mordaunt,—Percy
,
for
the
Earl
of
Northumberland
.
<EOS>
I
,
myself
,
would
gladly
save
the
young
Earl
of
Arundel
.
<EOS>
But
we
must
sacrifice
our
private
feeling
for
the
general

.
<EOS>
""We
must
,
"
acquiesced
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"We
<EOS>
shall
not
meet
again
till
the
night
of
the
tenth
of
October
,
"
said
Catesby
,
"
when
take
care
you
are
in

with

money
.
<EOS>
"Upon
this
<EOS>
,
the
conversation
dropped
,
and
soon
afterwards
Tresham
departed
.
<EOS>
When
he
found
himself
alone
,
he
suffered
his
rage
to
find
vent
in
words
.
"
<EOS>
Perdition
seize
them
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
"
I
shall
now
lose
two
thousand
pounds
,
in
addition
to
what
I
have
already
advanced
;
and
,
as
Mounteagle
will
not
have

disclosure
made
till
the
beginning
of
November
,
there
is
no
way
of
avoiding
payment
.
<EOS>
They
would
not
fall
into
the
snare
I
laid
to
throw
the
blame
of
the
discovery
,
when
it
takes
place
,
upon
their
own

.
<EOS>
But
I
must
devise
some
other

.
<EOS>
The
warning
shall
proceed
from
an
unknown
quarter
.
<EOS>
A
letter
,
written
in

,
and
giving
some

of

,
shall

.
<EOS>
This
will
serve
as

for
its
divulgement
to
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
they
shall
have
the
money
;
but
they
shall
pay
me
back
in
other
coin
.
<EOS>
"Early
<EOS>
on
the
following
day
,
Catesby
and
Fawkes
proceeded
to
White
Webbs
.
<EOS>
Garnet
was
greatly
surprised
to
see
them
,
and
could
not
conceal
his
disappointment
at
the
cause
of
their
return
.
<EOS>
"This
delay
bodes
<EOS>
no
good
,
"
he
observed
.
<EOS>
"
Parliament
has
been
so
often
prorogued
,
that
I
begin
to
think
some
suspicion
is
entertained
of
our
design
.
<EOS>
""Make
<EOS>
your
mind
easy
,
then
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
made
due
inquiries
,
and
find
the
meeting
is
postponed
to
suit
the
King
's
convenience
,
who
wishes
to
prolong

stay
at
Royston
.
<EOS>
He
may
probably
have
some
secret
motive
for
the
delay
,
but
I
am
sure
it
in
no
way
concerns
us
.
<EOS>
"Everything
<EOS>
being
now
fully
arranged
,
the
conspirators
had
only
to
wait
patiently
for
the
arrival
of
the
expected
fifth
of
November
.
<EOS>
Most
of
them
decided
upon
passing
the
interval
in
the
country
.
<EOS>
Ambrose
Rookwood
departed
for
Clopton
,
near
Stratford
-
upon
-
Avon,—a
seat
belonging
to
Lord
Carew
,
where
his
family
were
staying
.
<EOS>
Keyes
went
to
visit
Lord
Mordaunt
at
Turvey
,
in
Bedfordshire
;
and
Percy
and
the
two
Wrights
set
out
for
Gothurst
,
in
Buckinghamshire
,
to
desire
Sir
Everard
Digby
to
postpone
the
grand
hunting
-
party
which
he
was
to
hold
at
Dunsmore
Heath
,
as
an
excuse
for
mustering
a
strong
party
of
Catholics
,
to
the
beginning
of
November
.
<EOS>
The
two
Winters
repaired
to
their
family
mansion
,
Huddington
,
in
Worcestershire
;
while
Fawkes
and
Catesby
,
together
with
the
two
priests
,
remained
at
White
Webbs
.
<EOS>
The
three
latter
held
daily
conferences
together
,
but
were
seldom
joined
by
Fawkes
,
who
passed
his
time
in
the
adjoining
forest
,
selecting
its
densest
and
most
intricate
parts
for
his
rambles
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
the
beginning
of
October
,
and
,
as
is
generally
the
case
in
the
early
part
of
this
month
,
the
weather
was
fine
,
and
the
air
pure
and
bracing
.
<EOS>
The
forest
could
scarcely
have
been
seen
to
greater
advantage
.
<EOS>
The
leaves
had
assumed
their
gorgeous
autumnal
tints
,
and
the
masses
of
timber
,
variegated
in
colour
,
presented
an
inexpressibly
beautiful
appearance
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
spent
hours
in
the
depths
of
the
wood
.
<EOS>
His
sole
companions
were
the
lordly
stag
and
the
timid
hare
,
that
occasionally
started
across
his
path
.
<EOS>
Since
his
return
,
he
had
sedulously
avoided
Viviana
,
and
they
had
met
only
twice
,
and
then
no
speech
had
passed
between
them
.
<EOS>
One
day
,
when
he
had
plunged
even
deeper
than
usual
into
the
forest
,
and
had
seated
himself
on
the
stump
of
a
decayed
tree
,
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
a
small
clear
rivulet
welling
at
his
feet
,
he
saw
the
reflection
of
a
female
figure
in
the
water
;
and
,
filled
with
the
idea
of
the
vision
of
Saint
Winifred
,
at
first
imagined
he
was
about
to
receive
another
warning
.
<EOS>
But
a
voice
that
thrilled
to
his
heart
's
core
,
soon
undeceived
him
,
and
,
turning
,
he
beheld
Viviana
.
<EOS>
She
was
habited
in
a
riding
-
dress
,
and
appeared
prepared
to
set
out
upon
a
journey
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
you
have
tracked
me
to
my
solitude
,
"
he
observed
,
in
a
tone
of
forced
coldness
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
was
secure
from
interruption
here
.
<EOS>
""You
will
forgive
me
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
when
you
know
my
errand
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
to
take
an
eternal
farewell
of
you
.
""Indeed
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
about
to
quit
White
Webbs?""I
<EOS>
am
,
"
she
mournfully
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
about
to
set
out
with
Father
Oldcorne
for
Gothurst
,
where
I
shall
remain
till
all
is
over
.
<EOS>
""I
entirely
approve
your
determination
,
"
returned
Fawkes
,
after
a
short
pause
.
<EOS>
"I
knew
you
would
do
so
,
or
I
should
have
consulted
you
upon
it
,
"
she
rejoined
.
"
<EOS>
And
as
you
appear
to
avoid
me
,
I
would
fain
have
departed
without
taking
leave
of
you
,
but
found
it
impossible
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
well
know
my
motive
for
avoiding
you
,
Viviana
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
no
longer
what
we
were
to
each
other
.
<EOS>
A
fearful
struggle
has
taken
place
within
me
,
though
I
have
preserved
an
unmoved
exterior
,
between
passion
and
the
sense
of
my
high
calling
.
<EOS>
I
have
told
you
I
never
loved
before
,
and
fancied
my
heart
immoveable
as
adamant
.
<EOS>
But
I
now
find
out
my
error
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
prey
to
a
raging
and
constant
flame
.
<EOS>
I
have
shunned
you
,
"
he
continued
,
with
increased
excitement
,
"
because
the
sight
of
you
shakes
my
firmness,—because
<EOS>
I
feel
it
sinful
to
think
of
you
in
preference
to
holier
objects,—and
<EOS>
because
,
after
I
have
quitted
you
,
your
image
alone
engrosses
my
thoughts
.
<EOS>
Here
,
in
the
depths
of
this
wood
,
by
the
side
of
this
brook
,
I
can
commune
with
my
soul,—can
abstract
myself
from
the
world
and
the
thoughts
of
the
world
—
from
you
—
<EOS>
yes
,
you
,
who
are
all
the
world
to
me
now,—and
prepare
to
meet
my
end
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
you
are
resolved
to
die
?
<EOS>
"
she
cried
.
<EOS>
"I
shall
abide
the
explosion
,
and
nothing
but
a
miracle
can
save
me
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
think
not
it
will
be
exerted
in
your
behalf
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
Heaven
does
not
approve
your
design
,
and
you
will
assuredly
incur
its
vengeance
by
your
criminal
conduct
.
<EOS>
""Viviana
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Guy
Fawkes
,
rising
,
"
man
can
not
read
my
heart
,
but
Heaven
can
;
and
the
sincerity
of
my
purpose
will
be
recognised
above
.
<EOS>
What
I
am
about
to
do
is
for
the
regeneration
of
our
holy
religion
;
and
if
the
welfare
of
that
religion
is
dear
to
the
Supreme
Being
,
our
cause
must
prosper
.
<EOS>
If
the
contrary
,
it
deserves
to
fail
,
and
will
fail
.
<EOS>
I
have
ever
told
you
that
I
care
not
what
becomes
of
myself
.
<EOS>
I
am
now
more
than
ever
indifferent
to
life,—or
rather
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
sombre
tone
,
"
I
am
anxious
to
die
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
dreadful
wish
<EOS>
,
I
fear
,
will
be
accomplished
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
sadly
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
constantly
haunted
by
frightful
apprehensions
respecting
you
,
and
my
dead
father
has
appeared
to
me
in
my
dreams
.
<EOS>
His
spirit
,
if
such
it
were
,
seemed
to
gaze
upon
me
with
a
mournful
look
,
and
,
as
I
thought
,
pronounced
your
name
in
piteous
accents
.
<EOS>
""These
<EOS>
forebodings
chime
with
my
own
<EOS>
,
"
muttered
Fawkes
,
repressing
a
shudder
;
"
but
nothing
shall
shake
me
.
<EOS>
It
will
inflict
a
bitter
pang
upon
me
to
part
with
you
,
<EOS>
Viviana,—the
bitterest
<EOS>
I
can
ever
feel,—and
<EOS>
I
shall
be
glad
when
it
is
over
.
<EOS>
""I
echo
your
own
wish
,
"
she
returned
,
"
and
deeply
lament
that
we
ever
met
.
<EOS>
But
the
fate
that
brought
us
together
must
for
ever
unite
us
.
<EOS>
""What
mean
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
inquired
,
gazing
fixedly
at
her
.
<EOS>
"There
<EOS>
is
one
sad
consolation
which
you
can
afford
me
,
and
which
you
owe
me
for
the
deep
and
lasting
misery
I
shall
endure
on
your
account
,
"
replied
Viviana;—"a
consolation
that
will
enable
me
to
bear
your
loss
with
fortitude
,
and
to
devote
myself
wholly
to
Heaven
.
<EOS>
""Whatever
I
can
do
that
will
not
interfere
with
my
purpose
,
you
may
command
,
"
he
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"What
<EOS>
I
have
to
propose
will
not
interfere
with
it
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"
Now
,
hear
me
,
and
put
the
sole
construction
I
deserve
on
my
conduct
.
<EOS>
Father
Garnet
is
at
a
short
distance
from
us
,
behind
those
trees
,
waiting
my
summons
.
<EOS>
I
have
informed
him
of
my
design
,
and
he
approves
of
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
to
unite
us
in
marriage
—
solemnly
unite
us
—
that
though
I
may
never
live
with
you
as
a
wife
,
I
may
mourn
you
as
a
widow
.
<EOS>
Do
you
<EOS>
consent?"Guy
Fawkes
returned
an
affirmative
,
in
a
voice
broken
by
emotion
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
moment
the
ceremony
is
over
,
"
pursued
Viviana
,
"
I
shall
start
with
Father
Oldcorne
for
Gothurst
.
<EOS>
We
shall
never
meet
again
in
this
world
.
<EOS>
""Unless
I
succeed
,
"
said
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"You
will
not
succeed
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
thought
so
,
I
should
not
take
this
step
.
<EOS>
I
look
upon
it
as
an
espousal
with
the
dead
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
she
hurried
away
,
and
disappearing
beneath
the
covert
,
returned
in
a
few
seconds
with
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"I
have
a
strange
duty
to
perform
for
you
,
my
son
,
"
said
Garnet
to
Fawkes
,
who
remained
motionless
and
stupified
;
"
but
I
am
right
willing
to
perform
it
,
because
I
think
it
will
lead
to
your
future
happiness
with
the
fair
creature
who
has
bestowed
her
affections
on
you
.
<EOS>
""Do
not
speculate
on
the
future
,
father
,
"
cried
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
whyI
asked
you
to
perform
this
ceremony
.
<EOS>
You
know
,
also
,
that
I
have
made
preparations
for
instant
departure
;
and
that
I
indulge
no
hope
of
seeing
Guy
Fawkes
again
.
<EOS>
""All
<EOS>
this
I
know
,
dear
daughter
,
"
returned
Garnet
;
"
but
,
in
spite
of
your
anticipations
of
ill
,
I
still
hope
that
your
union
may
prove
auspicious
.
<EOS>
""I
take
you
to
witness
,
father
,
"
said
Viviana
,
"
that
in
bestowing
my
hand
upon
Guy
Fawkes
,
I
bestow
at
the
same
time
all
my
possessions
upon
him
.
<EOS>
He
is
free
to
use
them
as
he
thinks
proper,—even
in
the
furtherance
of
his
design
against
the
state
,
which
,
though
I
can
not
approve
it
,
seems
good
to
him
.
<EOS>
""This
must
not
be
,
"
cried
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"It
shall
be
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
Proceed
with
the
ceremony
,
father
.
""Let
<EOS>
her
have
her
own
way
,
my
son
,
"
observed
Garnet
,
in
a
low
tone
.
<EOS>
"
Under
any
circumstances
,
her
estates
must
now
be
necessarily
yours
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
then
took
a
breviary
from
his
vest
,
and
placing
them
near
each
other
,
began
to
read
aloud
the
marriage
-
service
appointed
by
the
Romish
Church
.
<EOS>
And
there
,
in
that
secluded
spot
,
and
under
such
extraordinary
circumstances
,
with
no
other
witnesses
than
the
ancient
trees
around
them
,
and
the
brook
rippling
at
their
feet
,
were
Guy
Fawkes
and
Viviana
united
.
<EOS>
The
ceremony
over
,
Guy
Fawkes
pressed
his
bride
to
his
breast
,
and
imprinted
a
kiss
upon
her
lips
.
<EOS>
"I
have
broken
my
faith
to
Heaven
,
to
which
I
was
first
espoused
,
"
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"No
<EOS>
,
"
she
returned
;
"
you
will
now
return
to
your
first
and
holiest
choice
.
<EOS>
Think
of
me
only
as
I
shall
think
of
you,—as
of
the
dead
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
the
party
slowly
and
silently
returned
to
the
house
,
where
they
found
a
couple
of
steeds
,
with
luggage
strapped
to
the
saddles
,
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
Father
Oldcorne
was
already
mounted
,
and
in
a
few
minutes
Viviana
was
by
his
side
.
<EOS>
Before
her
departure
,
she
bade
Guy
Fawkes
a
tender
farewell
;
and
at
this
trying
juncture
her
firmness
nearly
deserted
her
.
<EOS>
But
rousing
herself
,
she
sprang
upon
her
horse
,
and
urging
the
animal
into
a
quick
pace
,
and
followed
by
Oldcorne
,
she
speedily
disappeared
from
view
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
watched
her
out
of
sight
,
and
shunning
the
regards
of
Catesby
,
who
formed
one
of
the
group
,
struck
into
the
forest
,
and
was
not
seen
again
till
the
following
day
.
<EOS>
The
tenth
of
October
having
arrived
,
Guy
Fawkes
and
Catesby
repaired
to
the
place
of
rendezvous
.
<EOS>
But
the
night
passed
,
and
Tresham
did
not
appear
.
<EOS>
Catesby
was
angry
and
disappointed
,
and
could
not
conceal
his
apprehensions
of
treachery
.
<EOS>
Fawkes
took
a
different
view
of
the
matter
,
and
thought
it
not
improbable
that
their
confederate
's
absence
might
be
occasioned
by
the
difficulty
he
found
in
complying
with
their
demands
;
and
this
opinion
was
confirmed
the
next
morning
by
the
arrival
of
a
letter
from
Tresham
,
stating
that
he
had
been
utterly
unable
to
effect
the
sales
he
contemplated
,
and
could
not
,
therefore
,
procure
the
money
till
the
end
of
the
month
.
<EOS>
"I
will
immediately
go
down
to
Rushton
,
"
said
Catesby
,
"
and
if
I
find
him
disposed
to
palter
with
us
,
I
will
call
him
to
instant
account
.
<EOS>
But
Garnet
informs
me
that
Viviana
has
bestowed
all
her
wealth
upon
you
.
<EOS>
Are
you
willing
to
devote
it
to
the
good
cause?""No
!
<EOS>
"
replied
Fawkes
,
in
a
tone
so
decisive
that
his
companion
felt
it
would
be
useless
to
urge
the
matter
further
.
<EOS>
"
I
give
my
life
to
the
cause,—that
must
suffice
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
subject
was
never
renewed
.
<EOS>
At
night
,
Catesby
,
having
procured
a
powerful
steed
,
set
out
upon
his
journey
to
Northamptonshire
,
while
Fawkes
returned
to
White
Webbs
.
<EOS>
About
a
fortnight
passed
unmarked
by
any
event
of
importance
.
<EOS>
Despatches
were
received
from
Catesby
,
stating
that
he
had
received
the
money
from
Tresham
,
and
had
expended
it
in
procuring
horses
and
arms
.
<EOS>
He
also
added
that
he
had
raised
numerous
recruits
on
various
pretences
.
<EOS>
This
letter
was
dated
from
Ashby
St.
Leger
's
,
the
seat
of
his
mother
,
Lady
Catesby
,
but
he
expressed
his
intention
of
proceeding
to
Coughton
Hall
,
near
Alcester
,
in
Warwickshire
,
the
residence
of
Mr.
Thomas
Throckmorton
(
a
wealthy
Catholic

)
,
whither
Sir
Everard
Digby
had
removed
with
his
family
,
to
be
in
readiness
for
the
grand
hunting
-
party
to
be
held
on
the
fifth
of
November
on
Dunsmore
Heath
.
<EOS>
Here
he
expected
to
be
joined
by
the
two
Wrights
,
the
Winters
,
Rookwood
,
Keyes
,
and
the
rest
of
the
conspirators
,
and
undertook
to
bring
them
all
up
to
White
Webbs
on
Saturday
the
twenty
-
sixth
of
October
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
Guy
Fawkes
had
in
a
great
degree
recovered
his
equanimity
,
and
left
alone
with
Garnet
,
held
long
and
frequent
religious
conferences
with
him
;
it
being
evidently
his
desire
to
prepare
himself
for
his
expected
fate
.
<EOS>
He
spent
the
greater
part
of
the
nights
in
solitary
vigils
—
fasted
even
more
rigorously
than
he
was
enjoined
to
do
—
and
prayed
with
such
fervour
and
frequency
,
that
,
fearing
an
ill
effect
upon
his
health
,
and
almost
upon
his
mind
,
which
had
become
exalted
to
the
highest
pitch
of
enthusiasm
,
Garnet
thought
it
necessary
to
check
him
.
<EOS>
The
priest
did
not
fail
to
note
that
Viviana
's
name
never
passed
his
lips
,
and
that
in
all
their
walks
in
the
forest
he
carefully
shunned
the
scene
of
his
espousals
.
<EOS>
And
thus
time
flew
by
.
<EOS>
On
the
evening
of
the
twenty
-
sixth
of
October
,
in
accordance
with
Catesby
's
intimation
,
the
conspirators
arrived
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
assembled
at
supper
,
and
were
relating
the
different
arrangements
which
had
been
made
in
anticipation
of
the
important
event
,
when
Garnet
observed
with
a
look
of
sudden
uneasiness
to
Catesby
,
"
You
said
in
one
of
your
letters
that
you
would
bring
Tresham
with
you
,
my
son
.
<EOS>
Why
do
I
not
see
him?""He
sent
a
message
to
Coughton
to
state
,
that
having
been
attacked
by
a
sudden
illness
,
he
was
unable
to
join
us
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
"
but
as
soon
as
he
could
leave
his
bed
,
he
would
hasten
to
London
.
<EOS>
This
may
be
a
subterfuge
,
but
I
shall
speedily
ascertain
the
truth
,
for
I
have
sent
my
servant
Bates
to
Rushton
,
to
investigate
the
matter
.
<EOS>
I
ought
to
tell
you
,
"
he
added
,
"
that
he
has
given
substantial
proof
of
his
devotion
to
the
cause
by
sending
another
thousand
pounds
,
to
be
expended
in
the
purchase
of
arms
and
horses
.
<EOS>
""I
hope
it
is
not
dust
thrown
into
our
eyes
,
"
returned
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
always
feared
Tresham
would
deceive
us
at
the
last
.
<EOS>
""This
<EOS>
sudden
illness
looks
suspicious
,
I
must
own
,
"
said
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
Has
aught
been
heard
of
Lord
Mounteagle?""Guy
Fawkes
<EOS>
heard
that
he
was
at
his
residence
at
Southwark
yesterday
,
"
returned
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
far
,
good
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Did
you
visit
the
cellar
where
the
powder
is
deposited
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
turning
to
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
did
,
"
replied
the
other
,
"
and
found
all
secure
.
<EOS>
The
powder
is
in
excellent
preservation
.
<EOS>
Before
quitting
the
spot
,
I
placed
certain
private
marks
against
the
door
,
by
which
I
can
tell
whether
it
is
opened
during

absence
.
<EOS>
""A
<EOS>
wise
precaution
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
gentlemen
,
"
he
added
,
filling
a
goblet
with
wine
,
"
success
to
our
enterprise
!
<EOS>
Everything
is
prepared
,
"
he
continued
,
as
the
pledge
was
enthusiastically
drunk
;
"
I
have
got
together
a
company
of
above
two
hundred
men
,
all
well
armed
and
appointed
,
who
will
follow
me
wherever
I
choose
to
lead

.
<EOS>
They
will
be
stationed
near
Dunsmore
Heath
on
the
fifth
of
next
month
,
and
as
soon
as
the
event
of
the
explosion
is
known
,
I
shall
ride
thither
as
fast
as
I
can
,
and
,
hurrying
