my
troops
to
Coventry
,
seize
the
Princess
Elizabeth
.
<EOS>
Percy
and
Keyes
will
secure
the
person
of
the
Duke
of
York
,
and
proclaim
him
King
;
while
upon
the
rest
will
devolve
the
arduous
duty
of
rousing
our
Catholic
brethren
in
London
to
rise
to
arms
.
<EOS>
""Trust
<EOS>
to
us
to
rouse
them
,
"
shouted
several
voices
.
<EOS>
"Let
<EOS>
each
man
swear
not
to
swerve
from
the
fulfilment
of
his
task
,
"
cried
Catesby
;
"
swear
it
upon
this
cup
of
wine
,
in
which
we
will
all
mix
our
blood
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
as
he
spoke
,
he
pricked
his
arm
with
the
point
of
his
sword
,
and
suffered
a
few
drops
of
blood
to
fall
into
the
goblet
,
while
the
others
,
roused
to
a
state
of
frenzied
enthusiasm
,
imitated
his
example
,
and
afterwards
raised
the
horrible
mixture
to
their
lips
,
pronouncing
at
the
same
time
the
oath
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
was
the
last
to
take
the
pledge
,
and
crying
in
a
loud
voice
,
"
I
swear
not
to
quit
my
post
till
the
explosion
is
over
,
"
he
drained
the
cup
.
<EOS>
After
this
,
they
adjourned
to
a
room
in
another
wing
of
the
house
,
fitted
up
as
a
chapel
,
where
mass
was
performed
by
Garnet
,
and
the
sacrament
administered
to
the
whole
assemblage
.
<EOS>
They
were
about
to
retire
for
the
night
,
when
a
sudden
knocking
was
heard
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
Reconnoitring
the
intruder
through
an
upper
window
,
overlooking
the
court
,
Catesby
perceived
it
was
Bates
,
who
was
holding
a
smoking
and
mud
-
bespattered
steed
by
the
bridle
.
<EOS>
"Well
,
what
news
do
you
bring
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
as
he
admitted
him
.
"
<EOS>
Have
you
seen
Tresham?""No
,
"
replied
Bates
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
illness
was
a
mere
pretence
.
<EOS>
He
has
left
Rushton
secretly
for
London
.
<EOS>
""I
knew
it
,
"
cried
Garnet
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
again
betrayed
us
.
<EOS>
""He
shall
die
,
"
said
Catesby
.
<EOS>
And
the
determination
was
echoed
by
all
the
other
conspirators
.
<EOS>
Instead
of
retiring
to
rest
,
they
passed
the
night
in
anxious
deliberation
,
and
it
was
at
last
proposed
that
Guy
Fawkes
should
proceed
without
loss
of
time
to
Southwark
,
to
keep
watch
near
the
house
of
Lord
Mounteagle
,
and
if
possible
ascertain
whether
Tresham
had
visited
it
.
<EOS>
To
this
he
readily
agreed
.
<EOS>
But
before
setting
out
,
he
took
Catesby
aside
for
a
moment
,
and
asked
,
"
Did
you
see
Viviana
at
Coughton?""Only
for
a
moment
,
and
that
just
before
I
left
the
place
,
"
was
the
answer
.
"
<EOS>
She
desired
to
be
remembered
to
you
,
and
said
you
were
never
absent
from
her
thoughts
or
prayers
.
<EOS>
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
turned
away
to
hide
his
emotion
,
and
mounting
one
of
the
horses
brought
by
the
conspirators
,
rode
off
towards
London
.
<EOS>
XII
.
<EOS>
—
THE
FIFTH
OF
NOVEMBEROn
the
same
day
as
the
occurrences
last
related
,
Lord
Mounteagle
,
who
was
then
staying
at
Southwark
,
suddenly
intimated
his
intention
of
passing
the
night
at
his
country
mansion
at
Hoxton
;
a
change
of
place
which
,
trivial
as
it
seemed
at
the
moment
,
afterwards
assumed
an
importance
,
from
the
circumstances
that
arose
out
of
it
.
<EOS>
At
the
latter
part
of
the
day
,
he
accordingly
proceeded
to
Hoxton
,
accompanied
by
his
customary
attendants
,
and
all
appeared
to
pass
on
as
usual
,
until
,
just
as
supper
was
over
,
one
of
his
pages
arrived
from
town
,
and
desired
to
see
his
lordship
immediately
.
<EOS>
Affecting
to
treat
the
matter
with
indifference
,
Lord
Mounteagle
carelessly
ordered
the
youth
to
be
ushered
into
his
presence
;
and
when
he
appeared
,
he
demanded
his
business
.
<EOS>
The
page
replied
,
that
he
brought
a
letter
for
his
lordship
,
which
had
been
delivered
under
circumstances
of
great
mystery
.
<EOS>
"I
had
left
the
house
just
as
it
grew
dusk
,
"
he
said
,
"
on
an
errand
of
little
importance
,
when
a
man
,
muffled
in
a
cloak
,
suddenly
issued
from
behind
a
corner
,
and
demanded
whether
I
was
one
of
your
lordship
's
servants
?
<EOS>
On
my
replying
in
the
affirmative
,
he
produced
this
letter
,
and
enjoined
me
,
as
I
valued
my
life
and
your
lordship
's
safety
,
to
deliver
it
into
your
own
hands
without
delay
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
delivered
the
letter
to
his
lord
,
who
,
gazing
at
its
address
,
which
was
,
"
To
the
Right
Honourable
<EOS>
the
Lord
Mounteagle
,
"
observed
,
"
There
is
nothing
very
formidable
in
its
appearance
.
<EOS>
What
can
it
mean?"Without
even
breaking
the
seal
,
which
was
secured
with
a
silken
thread
,
he
gave
it
to
one
of
his
gentlemen
,
named
Ward
,
who
was
standing
near
him
.
<EOS>
"Read
it
<EOS>
aloud
,
sir
,
"
said
the
Earl
,
with
a
slight
smile
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
it
is
some
vapouring
effusion
,
which
will
afford
us
occasion
for
laughter
.
<EOS>
Before
I
hear
what
the
writer
has
to
say
,
I
can
promise
him
he
shall
not
intimidate
me
.
<EOS>
"Thus
exhorted
,
Ward
broken
open
the
letter
,
and
read
as
follows:—"My
lord
,
out
of
the
love
I
bear
to
some
of
your
friends
,
I
have
a
care
of
your
preservation
.
<EOS>
Therefore
I
would
advise
you
,
as
you
tender
your
life
,
to
devise
some
excuse
to
shift
from
your
attendance
at
this
Parliament
,
for
God
and
man
have
concurred
to
punish
the
wickedness
of
this
time
.
<EOS>
Think
not
slightingly
of
this
advice
,
but
retire
into
the
country
,
where
you
may
expect
the
event
in
safety
;
for
,
though
there
be
no
appearance
of
any
stir
,
yet
I
say
they
shall
receive
a
terrible
blow
this
Parliament
,
and
yet
they
shall
not
know
who
hurts
them
.
<EOS>
This
counsel
is
not
to
be
contemned
.
<EOS>
It
may
do
you
good
,
and
can
do
you
no
harm
,
for
the
danger
is
passed
as
soon
as
you
have
burned
the
letter
.
<EOS>
God
,
I
hope
,
will
give
you
grace
to
make
good
use
of
it
,
to
whose
holy
protection
<EOS>
I
commend
you
.
<EOS>
""A
singular
letter
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mounteagle
,
as
soon
as
Ward
had
finished
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
your
opinion
of
it?""I
think
it
hints
at
some
dangerous
plot
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Ward
,
who
had
received
his
instructions
,
"
some
treason
against
the
state
.
<EOS>
With
submission
,
I
would
advise
your
lordship
instantly
to
take
it
to
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
""I
see
nothing
in
it
,
"
replied
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
your
opinion
,
Mervyn
?
"
he
added
,
turning
to
another
of
his
gentlemen
,
to
whom
he
had
likewise
given
his
lesson
.
<EOS>
"I
am
of
the
same
mind
as
Ward
,
"
replied
the
attendant
.
<EOS>
"Your
lordship
will
hardly
hold
yourself
excused
,
if
you
neglect
to
give
due
warning
,
should
aught
occur
hereafter
.
<EOS>
""Say
<EOS>
you
so
,
sirs
?
"
cried
Lord
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
hear
it
once
more
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
letter
was
accordingly
read
again
by
Ward
,
and
the
Earl
feigned
to
weigh
over
each
passage
.
<EOS>
"I
am
advised
not
to
attend
the
Parliament
,
"
he
said
,
"
'
for
God
and
man
have
concurred
to
punish
the
wickedness
of
this
time
.
'
<EOS>
That
is
too
vague
to
be
regarded
.
<EOS>
Then
I
am
urged
to
retire
into
the
country
.
<EOS>
The
recommendation
must
proceed
from
some
discontented
Catholic
,
who
does
not
wish
me
to
be
present
at
the
opening
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
This
is
not
the
first
time
I
have
been
so
adjured
.
'
<EOS>
They
shall
receive
a
terrible
blow
this
Parliament
,
and
yet
shall
not
know
who
hurts
them
.
'
<EOS>
That
is
mysterious
enough
,
but
it
may
mean
nothing,—any
more
than
what
follows
,
namely
,
'
the
danger
is
passed
as
soon
as
you
have
burnt
the
letter
.
<EOS>
'""I
<EOS>
do
not
think
so
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Ward
;
"
and
though
I
can
not
explain
the
riddle
,
I
am
sure
it
means
mischief
.
<EOS>
""Well
,
"
said
Lord
Mounteagle
,
"
since
you
are
of
this
mind
,
I
must
lose
no
time
in
communicating
the
letter
to
the
Secretary
of
State
.
<EOS>
It
is
better
to
err
on
the
safe
side
.
<EOS>
"Accordingly
<EOS>
,
after
some
further
consultation
,
he
set
out
at
that
late
hour
for
Whitehall
,
where
he
roused
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
and
showed
him
the
letter
.
<EOS>
It
is
almost
needless
to
state
that
the
whole
was
a
preconcerted
scheme
between
these
two
crafty
statesmen
;
but
as
the
interview
took
place
in
the
presence
of
their
attendants
,
the
utmost
caution
was
observed
.
<EOS>
Salisbury
pretended
to
be
greatly
alarmed
at
the
communication
,
and
coupling
it
,
he
said
,
with
previous
intelligence
which
he
had
received
,
he
could
not
help
fearing
,
to
adopt
the
words
of
the
writer
of
the
mysterious
letter
,
that
the
Parliament
was
indeed
threatened
with
some
"
terrible
blow
.
<EOS>
"
Acting
,
apparently
,
upon
this
supposition
,
he
caused
such
of
the
lords
of
the
Privy
Council
as
lodged
at
Whitehall
to
be
summoned
,
and
submitting
the
letter
to
them
,
they
all
concurred
in
the
opinion
that
it
referred
to
some
dangerous
plot
,
though
none
could
give
a
guess
at
its
precise
nature
.
<EOS>
"It
is
clearly
some
Popish
project
,
"
said
Salisbury
,
"
or
Lord
Mounteagle
would
not
have
been
the
party
warned
.
<EOS>
We
must
keep
a
look
-
out
upon
the
disaffected
of
his
faith
.
<EOS>
""As
<EOS>
I
have
been
the
means
of
revealing
the
plot
to
your
lordship
—
if
plot
it
be
—
I
must
pray
you
to
deal
gently
with
them
,
"
rejoined
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"I
will
be
as
lenient
as
I
can
,
"
returned
Salisbury
;
"
but
in
a
matter
of
this
kind
little
favour
can
be
shown
.
<EOS>
If
your
lordship
will
enable
me
to
discover
the
principal
actors
in
this
affair
,
I
will
take
care
that
no
innocent
party
suffers
.
<EOS>
""You
ask
an
impossibility
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
nothing
beyond
what
can
be
gathered
from
that
letter
.
<EOS>
But
I
pray
your
lordship
not
to
make
it
a
means
of
exercising
unnecessary
severity
towards
the
members
of
my
religion
.
<EOS>
""On
that
you
may
rely
,
"
returned
the
Earl
.
"
<EOS>
His
Majesty
will
not
return
from
the
hunting
expedition
on
which
he
is
engaged
at
Royston
till
Thursday
next
,
the
30th
.
<EOS>
I
think
it
scarcely
worth
while
(
considering
his
naturally
timid
nature
,
with
which
your
lordships
are
well
acquainted
)
to
inform
him
of
the
threatened
danger
,
until
his
arrival
at
the
palace
.
<EOS>
It
will
then
be
time
enough
to
take
any
needful
steps
,
as
Parliament
will
not
meet
for
four
or
five
days
afterwards
.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
the
policy
of
this
course
the
Privy
Councillors
agreed
,
and
it
was
arranged
that
the
matter
should
be
kept
perfectly
secret
until
the
King
's
opinion
had
been
taken
upon
the
letter
.
<EOS>
The
assemblage
then
broke
up
,
it
being
previously
arranged
that
,
for
fear
of
some
attempt
upon
his
life
,
Lord
Mounteagle
should
remain
within
the
palace
till
full
inquiries
had
been
instituted
into
the
affair
.
<EOS>
When
the
two
confederate
nobles
were
left
alone
,
Salisbury
observed
,
with
a
slight
laugh
,
to
his
companion,"Thus
far
we
have
proceeded
well
,
and
without
suspicion
,
and
,
rely
upon
it
<EOS>
,
none
shall
fall
on
you
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
all
is
over
,
the
most
important
post
the
King
has
to
bestow
shall
be
yours
.
<EOS>
""But
<EOS>
what
of
Tresham
?
"
asked
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
was
the
deliverer
of
this
letter
,
and
I
have
little
faith
in
him
.
<EOS>
""Hum
!
"
said
Salisbury
,
after
a
moment
's
reflection
,
"
if
you
think
it
desirable
,
we
can
remove
him
to
the
Tower
,
where
he
can
be
easily
silenced
.
<EOS>
""It
will
be
better
so
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
may
else
babble
hereafter
.
<EOS>
I
gave
him
a
thousand
pounds
to
send
in
his
own
name
to
the
conspirators
the
other
day
to
lure
them
into
our
nets
.
<EOS>
""It
<EOS>
shall
be
repaid
you
a
hundred
-
fold
,
"
replied
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
"
But
we
are
observed
,
and
must
therefore
separate
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
withdrew
to
his
own
chamber
,
while
Lord
Mounteagle
was
ushered
to
the
apartments
allotted
to
him
.
<EOS>
To
return
to
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Arriving
at
Southwark
,
he
stationed
himself
near
Lord
Mounteagle
's
residence
.
<EOS>
But
he
observed
nothing
to
awaken
his
suspicions
,
until
early
in
the
morning
he
perceived
a
page
approaching
the
mansion
,
whom
,
from
his
livery
,
he
knew
to
be
one
of
Lord
Mounteagle
's
household
,
(
it
was
,
in
fact
,
the
very
youth
who
had
delivered
the
mysterious
letter
,
)
and
from
him
he
ascertained
all
that
had
occurred
.
<EOS>
Filled
with
alarm
,
and
scarcely
knowing
what
to
do
,
he
crossed
the
river
,
and
proceeding
to
the
cellar
,
examined
the
marks
at
the
door
,
and
finding
all
precisely
as
he
had
left
it
,
felt
certain
,
that
whatever
discovery
had
been
made
,
the
magazine
had
not
been
visited
.
<EOS>
He
next
repaired
to
the
house
,
of
which
he
possessed
the
key
,
and
was
satisfied
that
no
one
had
been
there
.
<EOS>
Somewhat
relieved
by
this
,
he
yet
determined
to
keep
watch
during
the
day
,
and
concealing
himself
near
the
cellar
,
remained
on
the
look
-
out
till
night
.
<EOS>
But
no
one
came
;
nor
did
anything
occur
to
excite
his
suspicions
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
,
however
,
quit
his
post
till
about
six
o'clock
on
the
following
evening
,
when
,
thinking
further
delay
might
be
attended
with
danger
,
he
set
out
to
White
Webbs
,
to
give
his
companions
intelligence
of
the
letter
.
<EOS>
His
news
was
received
by
all
with
the
greatest
alarm
,
and
not
one
,
except
Catesby
,
who
strove
to
put
a
bold
face
upon
the
matter
,
though
he
was
full
of
inward
misgiving
,
but
confessed
that
he
thought
all
chance
of
success
was
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
While
deliberating
upon
what
should
be
done
in
this
fearful
emergency
,
they
were
greatly
alarmed
by
a
sudden
knocking
without
.
<EOS>
All
the
conspirators
concealed
themselves
,
except
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
opening
the
door
,
found
,
to
his
infinite
surprise
,
that
the
summons
proceeded
from
Tresham
.
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
till
the
other
had
entered
the
house
,
and
then
suddenly
drawing
his
dagger
,
held
it
to
his
throat
.
<EOS>
"Make
<EOS>
your
shrift
quickly
,
traitor
,
"
he
cried
in
a
furious
tone
,
"
for
your
last
hour
is
arrived
.
<EOS>
What
ho
!
"
<EOS>
he
shouted
to
the
others
,
who
instantly
issued
from
their
hiding
-
places
,
"
the
fox
has
ventured
into
the
lion
's
den
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
distrust
me
wrongfully
,
"
rejoined
Tresham
,
with
more
confidence
than
he
usually
exhibited
in
time
of
danger
;
"
I
am
come
to
warn
you
,
not
betray
you
.
<EOS>
Is
this
the
return
you
make
me
for
the
service?""Villain
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
rushing
up
to
him
,
and
holding
his
drawn
sword
to
his
breast
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
conveyed
the
letter
to
Lord
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
""It
is
false
,
"
replied
Tresham
;
"
<EOS>
I
have
only
just
heard
of
it
;
and
,
in
spite
of
the
risk
I
knew
I
should
run
from
your
suspicions
,
I
came
to
tell
you
what
had
happened
.
<EOS>
""Why
<EOS>
did
you
feign
illness
,
and
depart
secretly
for
town
,
instead
of
joining
us
at
Coughton
?
"
demanded
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"I
will
instantly
explain
my
motive
,
which
,
though
it
may
not
be
satisfactory
to
you
on
one
point
,
will
be
so
on
another
,
"
replied
Tresham
unhesitatingly
,
and
with
apparent
frankness
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
fearful
you
would
make
a
further
tool
of
me
,
and
resolved
not
to
join
you
again
till
a
few
days
before
the
outbreak
of
the
plot
.
<EOS>
To
this
determination
I
should
have
adhered
,
had
I
not
learnt
to
-
night
that
a
letter
had
been
transmitted
by
some
one
to
Lord
Mounteagle
,
which
he
had
conveyed
to
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
It
may
not
convey
any
notion
of
the
plot
,
but
it
is
certain
to
occasion
alarm
,
and
I
thought
it
my
duty
,
in
spite
of
every
personal
consideration
,
to
give
you
warning
.
<EOS>
If
you
design
to
escape
,
there
is
yet
time
.
<EOS>
A
vessel
lies
in
the
river
,
in
which
we
can
all
embark
for
Flanders
.
<EOS>
""Can
<EOS>
he
be
innocent
?
"
said
Catesby
in
a
whisper
to
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"If
I
had
betrayed
you
,
"
continued
Tresham
,
"
I
should
not
have
come
hither
.
<EOS>
And
I
have
no
motive
for
such
baseness
,
for
I
am
in
equal
danger
with
yourselves
.
<EOS>
But
though
the
alarm
has
been
given
,
I
do
not
think
any
discovery
will
be
made
.
<EOS>
They
are
evidently
on
the
wrong
scent
.
<EOS>
""I
hope
so
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
"
but
I
fear
the
contrary
.
<EOS>
""Shall
<EOS>
I
put
him
to
death
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Fawkes
of
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
not
sully
your
hands
with
his
blood
,
my
son
,
"
returned
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
has
betrayed
us
,
he
will
reap
the
traitor
's
reward
here
and
hereafter
.
<EOS>
If
he
has
not
,
it
would
be
to
take
away
a
life
unjustly
.
<EOS>
Let
him
depart
.
<EOS>
We
shall
feel
more
secure
without
him
.
<EOS>
""Will
<EOS>
it
be
safe
to
set
him
free
,
father
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"I
think
so
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
We
will
not
admit
him
to
our
further
conferences
;
but
let
us
act
mercifully
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
major
part
of
the
conspirators
concurring
in
this
opinion
,
though
Fawkes
and
Catesby
were
opposed
to
it
,
Tresham
was
suffered
to
depart
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
was
gone
,
Garnet
avowed
that
the
further
prosecution
of
the
design
appeared
so
hazardous
,
that
it
ought
to
be
abandoned
,
and
that
,
in
his
opinion
,
each
of
the
conspirators
had
better
consult
his
own
safety
by
flight
.
<EOS>
He
added
,
that
at
some
future
period
the
design
might
be
resumed
,
or
another
planned
,
which
might
be
more
securely
carried
out
.
<EOS>
After
much
discussion
,
all
seemed
disposed
to
acquiesce
in
the
proposal
,
except
Fawkes
,
who
adhered
doggedly
to
his
purpose
,
and
treated
the
danger
so
slightingly
,
that
he
gradually
brought
the
others
round
to
his
views
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
it
was
resolved
that
Garnet
should
set
out
immediately
for
Coughton
Hall
,
and
place
himself
under
the
protection
of
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
and
there
await
the
result
of
the
attempt
,
while
the
other
conspirators
decided
upon
remaining
in
town
,
in
some
secure
places
of
concealment
,
until
the
event
was
known
.
<EOS>
Unmoved
as
ever
,
Guy
Fawkes
declared
his
intention
of
watching
over
the
magazine
of
powder
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
anything
happens
to
me
,
"
he
said
,
"
you
will
take
care
of
yourselves
.
<EOS>
You
well
know
nothing
will
be
wrung
from
me
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
<EOS>
and
the
others
,
aware
of
his
resolute
nature
,
affected
to
remonstrate
with
him
,
but
they
willingly
suffered
him
to
take
his
own
course
.
<EOS>
Attended
by
Bates
,
Garnet
then
set
out
for
Warwickshire
,
and
the
rest
of
the
conspirators
proceeded
to
London
,
where
they
dispersed
,
after
appointing
Lincoln
's
Inn
Walks
as
their
place
of
midnight
rendezvous
.
<EOS>
Each
then
made
preparations
for
sudden
flight
,
in
case
it
should
be
necessary
,
and
Rookwood
provided
relays
of
horses
all
the
way
to
Dunchurch
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
alone
remained
at
his
post
.
<EOS>
He
took
up
his
abode
in
the
cellar
,
resolved
to
blow
up
himself
together
with
his
foes
,
in
case
of
a
surprise
.
<EOS>
On
Thursday
,
the
31st
of
October
,
the
King
returned
to
Whitehall
,
and
the
mysterious
letter
was
laid
before
him
in
the
presence
of
the
Privy
Council
by
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
James
perused
it
carefully
,
but
could
scarcely
hide
his
perplexity
.
<EOS>
"Your
Majesty
will
not
fail
to
remark
the
expressions
,
'
a
terrible
blow
'
to
the
Parliament
,
and
'
that
the
danger
will
be
past
as
soon
as
you
have
burnt
the
letter
,
'
evidently
referring
to
combustion
,
"
observed
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"You
are
right
,
Salisbury
,
"
said
James
,
snatching
at
the
suggestion
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
wonder
if
these
mischievous
Papists
mean
to
blow
us
all
up
with
gunpowder
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
Majesty
has
received
a
divine
illumination
,
"
returned
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
Such
an
idea
never
occurred
to
me
;
but
it
must
be
as
you
intimate
.
<EOS>
""Undoubtedly
<EOS>
—
undoubtedly
,
"
replied
the
monarch
,
pleased
with
the
compliment
to
his
sagacity
,
though
alarmed
by
the
danger
;
"
but
what
desperate
traitors
they
must
be
to
imagine
such
a
deed
!
<EOS>
Blow
us
up
!
<EOS>
God
's
mercy
,
that
were
a
dreadful
death
!
<EOS>
And
yet
that
must
evidently
be
the
meaning
of
the
passage
.
<EOS>
How
else
can
it
be
construed
,
except
by
reference
to
the
suddenness
of
the
act
,
which
might
be
as
quickly
performed
as
that
paper
would
take
to
be
consumed
in
the
fire?""Your
Majesty
's
penetration
has
discovered
the
truth
,
"
replied
Salisbury
,
"
and
by
the
help
of
your
wisdom
,
I
will
fully
develop
this
dark
design
.
<EOS>
Where
,
think
you
,
the
powder
may
lie
hidden?""Are
there
any
vaults
beneath
the
Parliament
House
?
"
demanded
James
,
trembling
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Heaven
save
us
!
<EOS>
We
have
often
walked
there
—
perhaps
,
over
a
secret
mine
.
<EOS>
""There
are
,
"
replied
Salisbury
;
"
and
I
am
again
indebted
to
your
Majesty
for
a
most
important
suggestion
.
<EOS>
Not
a
corner
in
the
vaults
shall
be
left
unsearched
.
<EOS>
But
,
perhaps
you
will
think
with
me
,
that
,
in
order
to
catch
these
traitors
in
their
own
trap
,
it
will
be
well
to
defer
the
search
till
the
very
night
before
the
meeting
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
""I
was
about
to
recommend
such
a
course
myself
,
Salisbury
,
"
replied
James
.
<EOS>
"I
was
sure
you
would
think
so
,
"
returned
the
Earl
;
"
and
now
I
must
entreat
you
to
dismiss
the
subject
from
your
thoughts
,
and
to
sleep
securely
;
for
you
may
rely
upon
it
(
after
your
Majesty
's
discovery
)
that
the
plot
shall
be
fully
unravelled
.
<EOS>
"The
significant
tone
in
which
the
Earl
uttered
the
latter
part
of
this
speech
,
convinced
the
King
that
he
knew
more
of
the
matter
than
he
cared
to
confess
;
and
he
contented
himself
with
saying
,
"
Well
,
let
it
be
so
.
<EOS>
I
trust
all
to
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
at
once
divined
their
purpose,—I
at
once
divined
it
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
Council
then
broke
up
,
and
James
laughed
and
chuckled
to
himself
at
the
discernment
he
had
displayed
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
he
less
pleased
with
his
minister
for
the
credit
given
him
in
the
affair
.
<EOS>
But
he
took
care
not
to
enter
the
Parliament
House
.
<EOS>
On
the
afternoon
of
Monday
,
the
4th
of
November
,
the
Lord
Chamberlain
,
accompanied
by
the
Lords
Salisbury
and
Mounteagle
,
visited
the
cellars
and
vaults
beneath
the
Parliament
House
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
,
they
discovered
nothing
to
excite
suspicion
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
probably
at
the
suggestion
of
Lord
Mounteagle
,
who
,
as
will
be
recollected
,
was
acquainted
with
the
situation
of
the
magazine
,
they
proceeded
to
the
cellar
,
where
they
found
the
store
of
powder
;
but
not
meeting
with
any
of
the
conspirators
,
as
they
expected
,
they
disturbed
nothing
,
and
went
away
,
reporting
the
result
of
their
search
to
the
King
.
<EOS>
By
the
recommendation
of
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
James
advised
that
a
guard
should
be
placed
near
the
cellar
during
the
whole
of
the
night
,
consisting
of
Topcliffe
and
a
certain
number
of
attendants
,
and
headed
by
Sir
Thomas
Knevet
,
a
magistrate
of
Westminster
,
upon
whose
courage
and
discretion
full
reliance
could
be
placed
.
<EOS>
Lord
Mounteagle
also
requested
permission
to
keep
guard
with
them
to
witness
the
result
of
the
affair
.
<EOS>
To
this
the
King
assented
,
and
as
soon
as
it
grew
dark
,
the
party
secretly
took
up
their
position
at
a
point
commanding
the
entrance
of
the
magazine
.
<EOS>
Fawkes
,
who
chanced
to
be
absent
at
the
time
the
search
was
made
,
returned
a
few
minutes
afterwards
,
and
remained
within
the
cellar
,
seated
upon
a
barrel
of
gunpowder
,
the
head
of
which
he
had
staved
in
,
with
a
lantern
in
one
hand
,
and
petronel
in
the
other
,
till
past
midnight
.
<EOS>
The
fifth
of
November
was
now
at
hand
,
and
the
clock
of
the
adjoining
abbey
had
scarcely
ceased
tolling
the
hour
that
proclaimed
its
arrival
,
when
Fawkes
,
somewhat
wearied
with
his
solitary
watching
,
determined
to
repair
,
for
a
short
space
,
to
the
adjoining
house
.
<EOS>
He
accordingly
quitted
the
cellar
,
leaving
his
lantern
lighted
within
it
in
one
corner
.
<EOS>
Opening
the
door
,
he
gazed
cautiously
around
,
but
perceiving
nothing
,
after
waiting
a
few
seconds
,
he
proceeded
to
lock
the
door
.
<EOS>
While
thus
employed
,
he
thought
he
heard
a
noise
behind
him
,
and
turning
suddenly
,
he
beheld
through
the
gloom
several
persons
rushing
towards
him
,
evidently
with
hostile
intent
.
<EOS>
His
first
impulse
was
to
draw
a
petronel
,
and
grasp
his
sword
:
<EOS>
but
before
he
could
effect
his
purpose
,
his
arms
were
pinioned
by
a
powerful
grasp
from
behind
,
while
the
light
of
a
lantern
thrown
full
in
his
face
revealed
the
barrel
of
a
petronel
levelled
at
his
head
,
and
an
authoritative
voice
commanded
him
in
the
King
's
name
to
surrender
.
<EOS>
IllustrationXIII
.
—
<EOS>
THE
FLIGHT
OF
THE
CONSPIRATORSOn
the
same
night
,
and
at
the
same
hour
that
Guy
Fawkes
was
captured
<EOS>
,
the
other
conspirators
held
their
rendezvous
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
Walks
.
<EOS>
A
presentiment
of
the
fate
awaiting
them
filled
the
breasts
of
all
,
and
even
Catesby
shared
in
the
general
depression
.
<EOS>
Plan
after
plan
was
proposed
,
and
,
as
soon
as
proposed
,
rejected
;
and
they
seemed
influenced
only
by
alarm
and
irresolution
.
<EOS>
Feeling
at
length
that
nothing
could
be
done
,
and
that
they
were
only
increasing
their
risk
by
remaining
together
longer
,
they
agreed
to
separate
,
appointing
to
meet
at
the
same
place
on
the
following
night
,
if
their
project
should
not
,
in
the
interim
,
be
discovered
.
<EOS>
"Before
daybreak
,
"
said
Catesby
,
"
I
will
proceed
to
the
cellar
under
the
Parliament
House
,
and
ascertain
whether
anything
has
happened
to
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
My
heart
misgives
me
about
him
,
and
I
reproach
myself
that
I
have
allowed
him
to
incur
this
peril
alone
.
<EOS>
""Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
is
arrested
,
"
said
a
voice
near
them
,
"
and
is
at
this
moment
under
examination
before
the
King
.
<EOS>
""It
is
Tresham
who
speaks
,
"
cried
Catesby
;
"
secure
<EOS>
him!"The
injunction
was
instantly
obeyed
.
<EOS>
Tresham
was
seized
,
and
several
weapons
pointed
against
his
breast
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
,
however
,
appear
to
be
dismayed
,
but
,
so
far
as
could
be
discerned
in
the
obscurity
,
seemed
to
maintain
great
boldness
of
demeanour
.
<EOS>
"I
have
again
ventured
among
you
,
at
the
hazard
of
my
life
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
firm
tone
,
"
to
give
you
this
most
important
intelligence
;
and
am
requited
,
as
I
have
ever
been
of
late
,
with
menaces
and
violence
.
<EOS>
Stab
me
,
and
see
whether
my
death
will
avail
you
in
this
extremity
.
<EOS>
I
am
in
equal
danger
with
yourselves
;
and
whether
I
perish
by
your
hands
,
or
by
those
of
the
executioner
,
is
of
little
moment
.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
me
question
him
before
we
avenge
ourselves
upon
him
,
"
said
Catesby
to
Rookwood
.
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
that
Guy
Fawkes
is
a
prisoner?""I
saw
him
taken
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
"
and
esteem
myself
singularly
fortunate
that
I
escaped
the
same
fate
.
<EOS>
Though
excluded
from
further
share
in
the
project
,
I
could
not
divest
myself
of
a
strong
desire
to
know
how
matters
were
going
on
,
and
I
resolved
to
visit
the
cellar
secretly
at
midnight
.
<EOS>
As
I
stealthily
approached
it
,
I
remarked
several
armed
figures
beneath
a
gateway
,
and
conjecturing
their
purpose
,
instantly
concealed
myself
behind
a
projection
of
the
wall
.
<EOS>
I
had
not
been
in
this
situation
many
minutes
,
when
the
cellar
door
opened
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
issued
from
it
.
<EOS>
""Well
!
"
cried
Catesby
,
breathlessly
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
party
<EOS>
I
had
noticed
immediately
rushed
forward
,
and
secured
him
before
he
could
offer
any
resistance
,
"
continued
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
After
a
brief
struggle
,
certain
of
their
number
dragged
him
into
the
cellar
,
while
others
kept
watch
without
.
<EOS>
I
should
now
have
flown
,
but
my
limbs
refused
their
office
,
and
I
was
therefore
compelled
,
however
reluctantly
,
to
see
the
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
In
a
short
time
Guy
Fawkes
was
brought
forth
again
,
and
I
heard
some
one
in
authority
give
directions
that
he
should
be
instantly
taken
to
Whitehall
,
to
be
interrogated
before
the
King
and
the
Privy
Council
.
<EOS>
He
was
then
led
away
,
and
a
guard
placed
at
the
door
of
the
cellar
.
<EOS>
Feeling
certain
I
should
be
discovered
,
I
continued
for
some
time
in
an
agony
of
apprehension
,
not
daring
to
stir
.
<EOS>
But
,
at
length
,
summoning
up
sufficient
resolution
,
I
crept
cautiously
along
the
side
of
the
wall
,
and
got
off
unperceived
.
<EOS>
My
first
object
was
to
warn
you
.
<EOS>
""How
<EOS>
did
you
become
acquainted
with
our
place
of
rendezvous
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
elder
Wright
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
overheard
you
,
at
our
last
interview
at
White
Webbs
,
appoint
a
midnight
meeting
in
this
place
,
"
replied
Tresham
,
"
and
I
hurried
hither
in
the
hope
of
finding
you
,
and
have
not
been
disappointed
.
<EOS>
""When
<EOS>
I
give
the
word
,
plunge
your
swords
into
his
breast
,
"
said
Catesby
,
in
a
low
tone
.
<EOS>
"Hold
!
"
cried
Percy
,
taking
him
aside
.
<EOS>
"
If
we
put
him
to
death
in
this
spot
,
his
body
will
be
found
,
and
his
slaughter
may
awaken
suspicions
against
us
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
will
reveal
nothing
.
<EOS>
""Of
that
I
am
well
assured
,
"
said
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
we
take
the
traitor
with
us
to
some
secure
retreat
,
where
we
can
detain
him
till
we
learn
what
takes
place
at
the
palace
,
and
if
we
find
he
has
betrayed
us
,
despatch
him?""That
would
answer
no
good
purpose
,
"
returned
Percy
<EOS>
"
The
sooner
we
are
rid
of
him
the
better
.
<EOS>
We
can
then
deliberate
as
to
what
is
best
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
""You
are
right
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
has
betrayed
us
,
life
will
be
a
burthen
to
him
,
and
the
greatest
kindness
we
could
render
him
would
be
to
rid
him
of
it
.
<EOS>
Let
him
go
.
<EOS>
Tresham
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
loud
voice
,
"
you
are
free
.
<EOS>
But
we
meet
no
more
.
<EOS>
""We
have
not
parted
yet
,
"
cried
the
traitor
,
springing
backwards
,
and
uttering
a
loud
cry
.
<EOS>
"
I
arrest
you
all
in
the
King
's
name
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
signal
was
answered
by
a
band
of
soldiers
,
who
emerged
from
behind
the
trees
where
they
had
hitherto
been
concealed
,
and
instantly
surrounded
the
conspirators
.
<EOS>
"It
is
now
my
turn
to
threaten
,
"
laughed
Tresham
.
<EOS>
Catesby
replied
by
drawing
a
petronel
,
and
firing
it
in
the
supposed
direction
of
the
speaker
.
<EOS>
But
he
missed
his
mark
.
<EOS>
The
ball
lodged
in
the
brain
of
a
soldier
who
was
standing
beside
him
,
and
the
ill
-
fated
wretch
fell
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
A
desperate
conflict
now
ensued
.
<EOS>
Topcliffe
,
who
commanded
the
assailing
party
,
ordered
his
followers
to
take
the
conspirators
alive
,
and
it
was
mainly
owing
to
this
injunction
that
the
latter
were
indebted
for
their
safety
.
<EOS>
Whispering
his
directions
to
his
companions
,
Catesby
gave
the
word
,
and
making
a
simultaneous
rush
forward
,
they
broke
through
the
opposing
ranks
,
and
instantly
dispersing
,
and
favoured
by
the
gloom
,
they
baffled
pursuit
.
<EOS>
"We
<EOS>
have
failed
in
this
part
of
our
scheme
,
"
said
Tresham
to
Topcliffe
,
as
they
met
half
an
hour
afterwards
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
to
be
done?""We
must
take
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
's
advice
upon
it
,
"
returned
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
now
hasten
to
Whitehall
to
see
how
Guy
Fawkes
's
interrogation
proceeds
,
and
will
communicate
with
his
lordship
.
<EOS>
"Upon
this
,
they
separated
.
<EOS>
None
of
the
conspirators
met
again
that
night
.
<EOS>
Each
fled
in
a
different
direction
,
and
,
ignorant
of
what
had
happened
to
the
rest
,
sought
some
secure
retreat
.
<EOS>
Catesby
ran
towards
Chancery
-
lane
,
and
passing
through
a
narrow
alley
,
entered
the
large
gardens
which
then
lay
between
this
thoroughfare
and
Fetter
-
lane
.
<EOS>
Listening
to
hear
whether
he
was
pursued
,
and
finding
nothing
to
alarm
him
,
he
threw
himself
on
the
sod
beneath
a
tree
,
and
was
lost
in
painful
reflection
.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
my
fair
schemes
are
marred
by
that
traitor
,
Tresham
,
"
he
muttered
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
forgive
myself
for
being
duped
by
him
,
if
I
had
slain
him
when
he
was
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
But
that
he
should
escape
to
exult
in
our
ruin
,
and
reap
the
reward
of
his
perfidy
,
afflicts
me
even
more
than
failure
.
<EOS>
"Tortured
<EOS>
by
thoughts
like
these
,
and
in
vain
endeavouring
to
snatch
such
brief
repose
as
would
fit
him
for
the
fatigue
he
might
have
to
endure
on
the
morrow
,
he
did
not
quit
his
position
till
late
in
the
morning
of
a
dull
November
day
—
it
was
,
as
will
be
recollected
,
the
memorable
Fifth
—
had
arrived
.
<EOS>
He
then
arose
,
and
slouching
his
hat
,
and
wrapping
his
cloak
around
him
,
shaped
his
course
towards
Fleet
-
street
.
<EOS>
From
the
knots
of
persons
gathered
together
at
different
corners,—from
their
muttered
discourse
and
mysterious
looks
,
as
well
as
from
the
general
excitement
that
prevailed,—he
felt
sure
that
some
rumour
of
the
plot
had
gone
abroad
.
<EOS>
Shunning
observation
as
much
as
he
could
,
he
entered
a
small
tavern
near
Fleet
Bridge
,
and
called
for
a
flask
of
wine
and
some
food
.
<EOS>
While
discussing
these
,
he
was
attracted
by
the
discourse
of
the
landlord
,
who
was
conversing
with
his
guests
about
the
conspiracy
.
<EOS>
"I
hear
that
all
the
Papists
are
to
be
hanged
,
drawn
,
and
quartered
,
"
cried
the
host
;
"
and
if
it
be
true
,
as
I
have
heard
,
that
this
plot
is
their
contrivance
,
they
deserve
it
.
<EOS>
I
hope
I
have
no
believer
in
that
faith
—
no
recusant
in
my
house
.
<EOS>
""Don't
<EOS>
insult
us
by
any
such
suspicion
<EOS>
,
"
cried
one
of
the
guests
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
all
loyal
men
—
all
good
Protestants
.
<EOS>
""Do
<EOS>
you
know
whether
the
conspirators
have
been
discovered
,
sir
?
"
asked
the
host
of
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
do
not
even
know
of
the
plot
,
"
replied
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
What
was
its
object?""What
was
its
object
!
"
cried
the
host
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
scarcely
credit
me
when
I
tell
you
.
<EOS>
I
tremble
to
speak
of
it
.
<EOS>
Its
object
was
to
blow
up
the
Parliament
House
,
and
the
King
and
all
the
nobles
and
prelates
of
the
land
along
with
it
.
""Horrible
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
guests
.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
how
do
you
know
it
is
a
scheme
of
the
Papists
?
"
asked
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"Because
<EOS>
I
have
been
told
so
,
"
rejoined
the
host
.
"
<EOS>
But
who
else
could
devise
such
a
monstrous
plan
?
<EOS>
It
would
never
enter
into
the
head
or
heart
of
a
Protestant
to
conceive
so
detestable
an
action
.
<EOS>
We
love
our
King
too
well
for
that
,
and
would
shed
the
last
drop
of
our
blood
rather
than
a
hair
of
his
head
should
be
injured
.
<EOS>
But
these
priest
-
ridden
Papists
think
otherwise
.
<EOS>
They
regard
him
as
a
usurper
;
and
having
received
a
dispensation
from
the
Pope
to
that
effect
,
fancy
it
would
be
a
pious
act
to
remove
him
.
<EOS>
There
will
be
no
tranquillity
in
the
kingdom
while
one
of
them
is
left
alive
;
and
I
hope
his
Majesty
will
take
advantage
of
the
present
ferment
to
order
a
general
massacre
of
them
,
like
that
of
the
poor
Protestants
on
Saint
Bartholomew
's
day
in
Paris
.
<EOS>
""Ay,—massacre
them
<EOS>
,
"
cried
the
guests
;
"
that
's
the
way
.
<EOS>
Burn
their
houses
and
cut
their
throats
.
<EOS>
Will
it
be
lawful
to
do
so
without
further
authority
<EOS>
,
mine
host
?
<EOS>
If
so
,
we
will
set
about
it
immediately
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
resolve
you
on
that
point
,
"
replied
the
landlord
.
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
wait
a
short
time
.
<EOS>
I
dare
say
their
slaughter
will
be
publicly
commanded
.
<EOS>
""Heaven
<EOS>
grant
it
may
be
so
!
"
<EOS>
cried
one
of
the
guests
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
bear
my
part
in
the
business
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
<EOS>
arose
,
paid
his
reckoning
,
and
strode
out
of
the
tavern
.
<EOS>
"Do
you
know
,
mine
host
,
"
said
the
guest
who
had
last
spoken
,
"
I
half
suspect
that
tall
fellow
,
who
has
just
left
us
,
is
a
Papist
.
<EOS>
""Perhaps
<EOS>
a
conspirator
,
"
said
another
.
<EOS>
"Let
<EOS>
us
watch
him
,
"
cried
a
third
.
<EOS>
"Stay
<EOS>
,
"
cried
the
host
,
"
he
has
paid
me
double
my
reckoning
.
<EOS>
I
believe
him
to
be
an
honest
man
and
a
good
Protestant
.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
you
say
confirms
my
suspicions
,
"
rejoined
the
first
speaker
.
<EOS>
"
We
will
follow
him
.
<EOS>
"On
<EOS>
reaching
Temple
Bar
,
Catesby
found
the
gates
closed
,
and
a
guard
stationed
at
them,—no
one
being
allowed
to
pass
through
without
examination
.
<EOS>
Not
willing
to
expose
himself
to
this
scrutiny
,
Catesby
turned
away
,
and
in
doing
so
,
perceived
three
of
the
persons
he
had
just
left
in
the
tavern
.
<EOS>
The
expression
of
their
countenances
satisfied
him
they
were
dogging
him
;
but
affecting
not
to
perceive
it
,
he
retraced
his
steps
,
gradually
quickening
his
pace
until
he
reached
a
narrow
street
leading
into
Whitefriars
,
down
which
he
darted
.
<EOS>
The
moment
his
pursuers
saw
this
,
they
hurried
after
him
,
shouting
,
"
A
Papist
—
<EOS>
a
Papist!—a
conspirator!"But
Catesby
was
now
safe
.
<EOS>
Claiming
the
protection
of
certain
Alsatians
who
were
lounging
at
the
door
of
a
tavern
,
and
offering
to
reward
them
,
they
instantly
drew
their
swords
,
and
drove
the
others
away
,
while
Catesby
,
tossing
a
few
pieces
of
money
to
his
preservers
,
passed
through
a
small
doorway
into
the
Temple
,
and
making
the
best
of
his
way
to
the
stairs
,
leaped
into
a
boat
,
and
ordered
the
waterman
to
row
to
Westminster
.
<EOS>
The
man
obeyed
,
and
plying
his
oars
,
soon
gained
the
middle
of
the
stream
.
<EOS>
Little
way
,
however
,
had
been
made
,
when
Catesby
descried
a
large
wherry
,
manned
by
several
rowers
,
swiftly
approaching
them
,
and
instinctively
comprehending
whom
it
contained
,
ordered
the
man
to
rest
on
his
oars
till
it
had
passed
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
moments
the
wherry
approached
them
.
<EOS>
It
was
filled
with
serjeants
of
the
guard
and
halberdiers
,
in
the
midst
of
whom
sat
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Catesby
could
not
resist
the
impulse
that
prompted
him
to
rise
,
and
the
movement
attracted
the
attention
of
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
The
momentary
glance
they
exchanged
convinced
Catesby
that
Fawkes
perceived
him
,
though
his
motionless
features
gave
no
token
of
recognition
,
and
he
immediately
afterwards
fixed
his
eyes
towards
heaven
,
as
if
to
intimate,—at
least
Catesby
so
construed
the
gesture,—that
<EOS>
his
earthly
career
was
well
-
nigh
ended
.
<EOS>
Heaving
a
deep
sigh
,
Catesby
watched
the
wherry
sweep
on
towards
the
Tower,—its
fatal
<EOS>
destination,—until
<EOS>
it
was
lost
to
view
.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
is
over
,
I
fear
,
with
the
bravest
of
our
band
,
"
he
thought
,
as
he
tracked
its
course
;
"
but
some
effort
must
be
made
to
save
him
.
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
we
will
die
sword
in
hand
,
and
like
soldiers
,
and
not
as
common
malefactors
.
<EOS>
"Abandoning
<EOS>
his
intention
of
proceeding
to
Westminster
<EOS>
,
he
desired
the
man
to
pull
ashore
,
and
landing
at
Arundel
Stairs
,
hastened
to
the
Strand
.
<EOS>
Here
he
found
large
crowds
collected
,
the
shops
closed
,
and
business
completely
at
a
stand
.
<EOS>
Nothing
was
talked
of
but
the
conspiracy
,
and
the
most
exaggerated
and
extraordinary
accounts
of
it
were
circulated
and
believed
.
<EOS>
Some
would
have
it
that
the
Parliament
House
was
already
blown
up
,
and
that
the
city
of
London
itself
had
been
set
fire
to
in
several
places
by
the
Papists
.
<EOS>
It
was
also
stated
that
numerous
arrests
had
taken
place
,
and
it
was
certain
that
the
houses
of
several
Catholic
nobles
and
wealthy
gentlemen
had
been
searched
.
<EOS>
To
such
a
height
was
the
popular
indignation
raised
,
that
it
required
the
utmost
efforts
of
the
soldiery
to
prevent
the
mob
from
breaking
into
these
houses
,
and
using
violence
towards
their
inmates
.
<EOS>
Every
gate
and
avenue
to
the
palace
was
strictly
guarded
,
and
troops
of
horse
were
continually
scouring
the
streets
.
<EOS>
Sentinels
were
placed
before
suspected
houses
,
and
no
one
was
suffered
to
enter
them
,
or
to
go
forth
without
special
permission
.
<EOS>
Detachments
of
soldiery
were
also
stationed
at
the
end
of
all
the
main
thoroughfares
.
<EOS>
Bars
were
thrown
across
the
smaller
streets
and
outlets
,
and
proclamation
was
made
that
no
one
was
to
quit
the
city
,
however
urgent
his
business
,
for
three
days
.
<EOS>
On
hearing
this
announcement
,
Catesby
saw
at
once
that
if
he
did
not
effect
his
escape
immediately
,
it
would
be
impracticable
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
hurried
towards
Charing
-
cross
,
and
turning
up
St.
Martin's
-
lane
,
at
the
back
of
the
King
's
Mews
,
contrived
to
elude
the
vigilance
of
the
guard
,
and
speeded
along
the
lane,—for
<EOS>
it
was
then
literally
so
,
and
surrounded
on
either
side
by
<EOS>
high
hedges,—until
<EOS>
he
came
to
St.
Giles's,—at
this
time
<EOS>
nothing
more
than
a
few
scattered
houses
,
intermixed
with
trees
.
<EOS>
Here
he
encountered
a
man
mounted
on
a
powerful
steed
,
and
seeing
this
person
look
hard
at
him
,
would
have
drawn
out
of
the
way
,
if
the
other
had
not
addressed
him
by
name
.
<EOS>
He
then
regarded
the
equestrian
more
narrowly
,
and
found
it
was
Martin
Heydocke
.
<EOS>
"I
have
heard
what
has
happened
,
Mr.
Catesby
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
and
can
imagine
the
desperate
strait
in
which
you
must
be
placed
.
<EOS>
Take
my
horse,—it
may
aid
your
flight
.
<EOS>
I
was
sent
to
London
by
my
master
,
Mr.
Humphrey
Chetham
,
to
bring
him
intelligence
of
the
result
of
your
attempt
,
and
I
am
sure
I
am
acting
in
accordance
with
his
wishes
in
rendering
you
such
a
service
.
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
I
will
risk
it
.
<EOS>
Mount
,
sir,—mount
,
and
make
the
best
of
your
way
hence
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
<EOS>
needed
no
further
exhortation
,
but
,
springing
into
the
saddle
,
hastily
murmured
his
thanks
,
and
striking
into
a
lane
on
the
right
,
rode
off
at
a
swift
pace
towards
Highgate
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
brow
of
this
beautiful
hill
,
he
drew
in
the
bridle
for
a
moment
,
and
gazed
towards
the
city
he
had
just
quitted
.
<EOS>
Dark
and
bitter
were
his
thoughts
as
he
fixed
his
eye
upon
Westminster
Abbey
,
and
fancied
he
could
discern
the
neighbouring
pile
,
whose
destruction
he
had
meditated
.
<EOS>
Remembering
that
from
this
very
spot
,
when
he
had
last
approached
the
capital
,
in
company
with
Guy
Fawkes
and
Viviana
Radcliffe
,
he
had
looked
in
the
same
direction
,
he
could
not
help
contrasting
his
present
sensations
with
those
he
had
then
experienced
.
<EOS>
At
that
time
he
was
full
of
ardour
,
and
confident
of
success
.
<EOS>
Now
,
all
was
lost
to
him
,
and
he
was
anxious
for
little
more
than
self
-
preservation
.
<EOS>
Involuntarily
,
his
eye
wandered
along
the
great
city
,
until
passing
over
the
mighty
fabric
of
Saint
Paul
's
,
it
settled
upon
the
Tower,—upon
the
place
of
Guy
Fawkes
's
captivity
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
can
nothing
be
done
for
his
deliverance
?
"
<EOS>
sighed
Catesby
,
as
he
turned
away
,
his
eyes
filling
with
moisture
"
must
that
brave
soldier
die
the
death
of
a
felon
—
must
he
be
subjected
to
the
torture
—
horror
!
<EOS>
If
he
had
died
defending
himself
,
I
should
scarcely
have
pitied
him
.
<EOS>
And
if
he
had
destroyed
himself
,
together
with
his
foes
,
as
he
resolved
to
do
,
I
should
have
envied
him
.
<EOS>
But
the
idea
of
what
he
will
have
to
suffer
in
that
dreadful
place
—
nay
,
what
he
is
now
,
perhaps
,
suffering
—
makes
the
life
-
blood
curdle
in
my
veins
.
<EOS>
I
will
never
fall
alive
into
their
hands
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
resolve
,
he
struck
spurs
into
his
steed
,
and
,
urging
him
to
a
swift
pace
,
dashed
rapidly
forward
.
<EOS>
He
had
ridden
more
than
a
mile
,
when
hearing
shouts
behind
him
,
he
perceived
two
troopers
galloping
after
him
as
fast
as
their
horses
could
carry
them
.
<EOS>
They
shouted
to
him
to
stay
,
and
as
they
were
better
mounted
than
he
was
,
it
was
evident
they
would
soon
come
up
with
him
.
<EOS>
Determined
,
however
,
to
adhere
to
the
resolution
he
had
just
formed
,
and
not
to
yield
himself
with
life
,
he
prepared
for
a
conflict
,
and
suddenly
halting
,
he
concealed
a
petronel
beneath
his
cloak
,
and
waited
till
his
foes
drew
near
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
command
you
,
in
the
King
's
name
,
to
surrender
<EOS>
,
"
said
the
foremost
trooper
,
riding
up
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
rebel
and
a
traitor
.
<EOS>
""Be
this
<EOS>
my
answer
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
aiming
at
the
man
,
and
firing
with
such
certainty
,
that
he
fell
from
his
horse
mortally
wounded
.
<EOS>
Unsheathing
his
sword
,
he
then
prepared
to
attack
the
other
trooper
.
<EOS>
But
,
terrified
at
the
fate
of
his
comrade
,
the
man
turned
his
horse
's
head
,
and
rode
off
.
<EOS>
Without
bestowing
a
thought
on
the
dying
man
who
lay
groaning
in
the
mire
,
Catesby
caught
hold
of
the
bridle
of
his
horse
,
and
satisfied
that
the
animal
was
better
than
his
own
,
mounted
him
,
and
proceeded
at
the
same
headlong
pace
as
before
.
<EOS>
In
a
short
time
he
reached
Finchley
,
where
several
persons
rushed
from
their
dwellings
to
inquire
whether
he
brought
any
intelligence
of
the
plot
,
rumours
of
which
had
already
reached
them
.
<EOS>
Without
stopping
,
Catesby
replied
that
most
important
discoveries
had
been
made
,
and
that
he
was
carrying
despatches
from
the
King
to
Northampton
.
<EOS>
No
opposition
was
therefore
offered
him
,
and
he
soon
left
all
traces
of
habitation
behind
him
.
<EOS>
Urging
his
horse
to
its
utmost
,
he
arrived
,
in
less
than
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
at
Chipping
Barnet
.
<EOS>
Here
the
same
inquiries
were
made
as
at
Finchley
,
and
returning
the
same
answer
—
for
he
never
relaxed
his
speed
for
a
moment
—
he
pursued
his
course
.
<EOS>
In
less
than
three
quarters
of
an
hour
after
this
,
he
arrived
at
Saint
Albans
,
and
proceeding
direct
to
the
post
-
house
,
asked
for
a
horse
.
<EOS>
But
instead
of
complying
with
the
request
,
the
landlord
of
the
Rose
and
Crown
—
such
was
the
name
of
the
hostel
—
instantly
withdrew
,
and
returned
the
next
moment
with
an
officer
,
who
desired
to
speak
with
Catesby
before
he
proceeded
further
.
<EOS>
The
latter
,
however
,
took
no
notice
of
the
demand
,
but
rode
off
.
<EOS>
The
clatter
of
horses
'
hoofs
behind
him
soon
convinced
him
he
was
again
pursued
,
and
he
was
just
beginning
to
consider
in
what
way
he
should
make
a
second
defence
,
when
he
observed
two
horsemen
cross
a
lane
on
the
left
,
and
make
for
the
main
road
.
<EOS>
His
situation
now
appeared
highly
perilous
,
especially
as
his
pursuers
,
who
had
noticed
the
other
horsemen
at
the
same
time
as
himself
,
shouted
to
them
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
speedily
relieved
.
<EOS>
These
persons
,
instead
of
stopping
,
accelerated
their
pace
,
and
appeared
as
anxious
as
he
was
to
avoid
those
behind
him
.
<EOS>
They
were
now
within
a
short
distance
of
Dunstable
,
and
were
ascending
the
lovely
downs
which
lie
on
the
London
side
of
this
ancient
town
,
when
one
of
the
horsemen
in
front
chancing
to
turn
round
,
Catesby
perceived
it
was
Rookwood
.
<EOS>
Overjoyed
at
the
discovery
,
he
shouted
to
him
at
the
top
of
his
voice
,
and
the
other
,
who
it
presently
appeared
was
accompanied
by
Keyes
,
instantly
stopped
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
seconds
Catesby
was
by
their
side
,
and
a
rapid
explanation
taking
place
,
they
all
three
drew
up
in
order
of
battle
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
their
pursuers
had
arrived
within
a
hundred
yards
of
them
,
and
seeing
how
matters
stood
,
and
not
willing
to
hazard
an
engagement
,
after
a
brief
consultation
,
retired
.
<EOS>
The
three
friends
then
pursued
their
route
,
passed
through
Dunstable
,
and
without
pausing
a
moment
on
the
road
,
soon
neared
Fenny
Stratford
.
<EOS>
Just
before
they
arrived
at
this
place
,
Catesby
's
horse
fell
from
exhaustion
.
<EOS>
Instantly
extricating
himself
from
the
fallen
animal
,
he
ran
by
the
side
of
his
companions
till
they
got
to
the
town
,
where
Rookwood
,
who
had
placed
relays
on
the
road
,
changed
his
horse
,
and
the
others
were
fortunate
enough
to
procure
fresh
steeds
.
<EOS>
Proceeding
with
unabated
impetuosity
,
they
soon
cleared
a
few
more
miles
,
and
had
just
left
Stony
Stratford
behind
them
,
when
they
overtook
a
solitary
horseman
,
who
proved
to
be
John
Wright
,
and
a
little
further
on
they
came
up
with
Percy
,
and
Christopher
Wright
.
<EOS>
Though
their
numbers
were
thus
increased
,
they
did
not
consider
themselves
secure
,
but
flinging
their
cloaks
away
to
enable
them
to
proceed
with
greater
expedition
,
hurried
on
to
Towcester
.
<EOS>
Here
Keyes
quitted
his
companions
,
and
shaped
his
course
into
Warwickshire
,
where
he
was
afterwards
taken
,
while
the
others
,
having
procured
fresh
horses
,
made
the
best
of
their
way
to
Ashby
Saint
Leger's
.
<EOS>
About
six
o'clock
,
Catesby
and
his
companions
arrived
at
his
old
family
seat
,
which
he
had
expected
to
approach
in
triumph
,
but
which
he
now
approached
with
feelings
of
the
deepest
mortification
and
disappointment
.
<EOS>
They
found
the
house
filled
with
guests
—
among
whom
was
Robert
Winter
—
who
were
just
sitting
down
to
supper
.
<EOS>
Catesby
rushed
into
the
room
in
which
these
persons
were
assembled
,
covered
with
mud
and
dirt
,
his
haggard
looks
and
dejected
appearance
proclaiming
that
his
project
had
failed
.
<EOS>
His
friends
followed
,
and
their
appearance
confirmed
the
impression
that
he
had
produced
.
<EOS>
Lady
Catesby
hastened
to
her
son
,
and
strove
to
comfort
him
;
but
he
rudely
repulsed
her
.
<EOS>
"What
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
she
anxiously
inquired
.
<EOS>
"What
is
the
matter
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
in
a
furious
tone
,
and
stamping
his
foot
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
"
All
is
lost
!
<EOS>
our
scheme
is
discovered
;
Guy
Fawkes
is
a
prisoner
,
and
ere
long
we
shall
all
be
led
to
the
block
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
all
!
"
<EOS>
he
repeated
,
gazing
sternly
around
.
<EOS>
"I
will
never
be
led
thither
with
life
,
"
said
Robert
Winter
.
<EOS>
"Nor
<EOS>
I
,
"
added
a
young
Catholic
gentleman
,
named
Acton
of
Ribbesford
,
who
had
lately
joined
the
conspiracy
.
<EOS>
"
Though
the
great
design
has
failed
,
we
are
yet
free
,
and
have
swords
to
draw
,
and
arms
to
wield
them
.
<EOS>
""Ay
,
"
exclaimed
Robert
Winter
,
"
all
our
friends
are
assembled
at
Dunchurch
.
<EOS>
Let
us
join
them
instantly
,
and
we
may
yet
stir
up
a
rebellion
which
may
accomplish
all
we
can
desire
.
<EOS>
I
,
myself
,
accompanied
Humphrey
Littleton
to
Dunchurch
this
morning
,
and
know
we
shall
find
everything
in
readiness
.
<EOS>
""Do
not
despair
<EOS>
,
"
cried
Lady
Catesby
;
"
all
will
yet
be
well
.
<EOS>
Every
member
of
our
faith
will
join
you
,
and
you
will
soon
muster
a
formidable
army
.
<EOS>
""We
<EOS>
must
not
yield
without
a
blow
,
"
cried
Percy
,
pouring
out
a
bumper
of
wine
,
and
swallowing
it
at
a
draught
.
<EOS>
"You
are
right
,
"
said
Rookwood
,
imitating
his
example
.
<EOS>
"
We
will
sell
our
lives
dearly
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
you
will
adhere
to
this
resolution
,
gentlemen
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
"
we
may
yet
retrieve
our
loss
.
<EOS>
With
five
hundred
stanch
followers
,
who
will
stand
by
me
to
the
last
,
I
will
engage
to
raise
such
a
rebellion
in
England
as
shall
not
be
checked
,
except
by
the
acknowledgment
of
our
rights
,
or
the
dethronement
of
the
king
.
<EOS>
""We
<EOS>
will
all
stand
by
you
,
"
cried
the
others
.
<EOS>
"Swear
<EOS>
it
,
"
cried
Catesby
,
raising
the
glass
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
"We
<EOS>
do
,
"
was
the
reply
.
<EOS>
"Wearied
<EOS>
as
we
are
,
"
cried
Catesby
,
"
<EOS>
we
must
at
once
proceed
to
Dunchurch
,
and
urge
our
friends
to
rise
in
arms
with
us
.
<EOS>
""Agreed
,
"
cried
the
others
.
<EOS>
Summoning
all
his
household
,
and
arming
them
,
Catesby
then
set
out
with
the
rest
for
Dunchurch
,
which
lay
about
five
miles
from
Ashby
Saint
Leger
's
.
<EOS>
They
arrived
there
in
about
three
quarters
of
an
hour
,
and
found
the
mansion
crowded
with
Catholic
gentlemen
and
their
servants
.
<EOS>
Entering
the
banquet
hall
,
they
found
Sir
Everard
Digby
at
the
head
of
the
board
,
with
Garnet
on
his
right
hand
.
<EOS>
Upwards
of
sixty
persons
were
seated
at
the
table
.
<EOS>
Their
arrival
was
greeted
with
loud
shouts
,
and
several
of
the
guests
drew
their
swords
and
flourished
them
over
their
heads
.
<EOS>
"What
news
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Sir
Everard
Digby
.
<EOS>
"
Is
the
blow
struck?""No
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
"
we
have
been
betrayed
.
<EOS>
"A
<EOS>
deep
silence
prevailed
.
<EOS>
A
change
came
over
the
countenances
of
the
guests
.
<EOS>
Significant
glances
were
exchanged
,
and
it
was
evident
that
general
uneasiness
prevailed
.
<EOS>
"What
is
to
be
done
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
after
a
pause
.
<EOS>
"Our
<EOS>
course
is
clear
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
stand
by
each
other
.
<EOS>
In
that
case
,
we
have
nothing
to
fear
,
and
shall
accomplish
our
purpose
,
though
not
in
the
way
originally
intended
.
<EOS>
""I
will
have
nothing
further
to
do
with
the
matter
,
"
said
Sir
Robert
Digby
of
Coleshill
,
Sir
Everard
's
uncle
.
<EOS>
And
rising
,
he
quitted
the
room
with
several
of
his
followers
,
while
his
example
was
imitated
by
Humphrey
Littleton
and
others
.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
chance
for
the
restoration
of
our
faith
in
England
is
over
,
"
observed
Garnet
,
in
a
tone
of
despondency
.
"Not
<EOS>
so
,
father
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
"
if
we
are
true
to
each
other
.
<EOS>
My
friends
,
"
he
cried
,
stopping
those
who
were
about
to
depart
,
"
in
the
name
of
our
holy
religion
I
beseech
you
to
pause
.
<EOS>
Much
is
against
us
now
.
<EOS>
But
let
us
hold
together
,
and
all
will
speedily
be
righted
.
<EOS>
Every
Catholic
in
this
county
,
in
Cheshire
,
in
Lancashire
,
and
Wales
,
must
flock
to
our
standard
when
it
is
once
displayed
—
do
not
desert
us
—
do
not
desert
yourselves
—
for
our
cause
is
your
cause
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
large
force
at
my
command
;
so
has
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
and
together
we
can
muster
nearly
five
hundred
adherents
.
<EOS>
With
these
,
we
can
offer
such
a
stand
as
will
enable
as
to
make
conditions
with
our
opponents
,
or
even
to
engage
with
them
with
a
reasonable
prospect
of
success
.
<EOS>
I
am
well
assured
,
moreover
,
if
we
lose
no
time
,
but
proceed
to
the
houses
of
our
friends
,
we
shall
have
a
large
army
with
us
.
<EOS>
Do
not
fall
off
,
then
.
<EOS>
On
you
depends
our
success
.
<EOS>
"This
address
was
followed
by
loud
acclamations
;
and
all
who
heard
it
agreed
to
stand
by
the
cause
in
which
they
had
embarked
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
As
Catesby
left
the
banqueting
-
hall
with
Sir
Everard
,
to
make
preparations
for
their
departure
,
they
met
Viviana
and
a
female
attendant
.
<EOS>
"I
hear
the
enterprise
has
failed
,
"
she
cried
,
in
a
voice
suffocated
by
emotion
.
<EOS>
"
What
has
happened
to
my
husband
?
<EOS>
Is
he
safe
?
<EOS>
Is
he
with
you?""Alas
!
<EOS>
no
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
"
he
is
a
prisoner
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
uttered
a
cry
of
anguish
,
and
fell
senseless
into
the
arms
of
the
attendant
.
<EOS>
XIV
.
<EOS>
—
THE
EXAMINATIONDisarmed
by
Sir
Thomas
Knevet
and
his
followers
,
who
found
upon
his
person
a
packet
of
slow
matches
and
touchwood
,
and
bound
hand
and
foot
,
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
was
dragged
into
the
cellar
by
his
captors
,
who
instantly
commenced
their
search
.
<EOS>
In
a
corner
behind
the
door
they
discovered
a
dark
lantern
,
with
a
light
burning
within
it
;
and
moving
with
the
utmost
caution
—
for
they
were
afraid
of
bringing
sudden
destruction
upon
themselves
—
they
soon
perceived
the
barrels
of
gunpowder
ranged
against
the
wall
.
<EOS>
Carefully
removing
the
planks
,
billets
,
and
iron
bars
with
which
they
were
covered
,
they
remarked
that
two
of
the
casks
were
staved
in
,
while
the
hoops
from
a
third
were
taken
off
,
and
the
powder
scattered
around
it
.
<EOS>
They
also
noticed
that
several
trains
were
laid
along
the
floor,—everything
,
in
short
,
betokening
that
the
preparations
for
the
desperate
deed
were
fully
completed
.
<EOS>
While
they
were
making
this
investigation
,
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
,
seeing
that
further
resistance
was
useless
,
had
remained
perfectly
motionless
up
to
this
moment
,
suddenly
made
a
struggle
to
free
himself
;
and
so
desperate
was
the
effort
,
that
he
burst
the
leathern
thong
that
bound
his
hands
,
and
seizing
the
soldier
nearest
to
him
,
bore
him
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
He
then
grasped
the
lower
limbs
of
another
,
who
held
a
lantern
,
and
strove
to
overthrow
him
,
and
wrest
the
lantern
from
his
grasp
,
evidently
intending
to
apply
the
light
to
the
powder
.
<EOS>
And
he
would
unquestionably
have
executed
his
terrible
design
,
if
three
of
the
most
powerful
of
the
soldiers
had
not
thrown
themselves
upon
him
,
and
overpowered
him
.
<EOS>
All
this
was
the
work
of
a
moment
;
but
it
was
so
startling
,
that
Sir
Thomas
Knevet
and
Topcliffe
,
though
both
courageous
men
,
and
used
to
scenes
of
danger
—
especially
the
latter
—
rushed
towards
the
door
,
expecting
some
dreadful
catastrophe
would
take
place
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
him
<EOS>
no
harm
,
"
cried
Knevet
,
as
he
returned
to
the
soldiers
,
who
were
still
struggling
with
Fawkes,—"do
him
no
harm
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
here
he
must
die
.
<EOS>
""A
moment
more
,
and
I
had
blown
you
all
to
perdition
,
"
cried
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
Heaven
ordained
it
otherwise
.
<EOS>
""Heaven
will
never
assist
such
damnable
designs
as
yours
,
"
rejoined
Knevet
.
"
<EOS>
Thrust
him
into
that
corner
,
"
he
added
to
his
men
,
who
instantly
obeyed
his
injunctions
,
and
held
down
the
prisoner
so
firmly
that
he
could
not
move
a
limb
.
"
<EOS>
Keep
him
there
.
<EOS>
I
will
question
him
presently
.
<EOS>
""You
may
question
me
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
sternly
;
"
but
you
will
obtain
no
answer
.
<EOS>
""We
shall
see
,
"
returned
Knevet
.
<EOS>
Pursuing
the
search
with
Topcliffe
,
he
counted
thirty
-
six
hogsheads
and
casks
of
various
sizes
,
all
of
which
were
afterwards
found
to
be
filled
with
powder
.
<EOS>
Though
prepared
for
this
discovery
,
Knevet
could
not
repress
his
horror
at
it
,
and
gave
vent
to
execrations
against
the
prisoner
,
to
which
the
other
replied
by
a
disdainful
laugh
.
<EOS>
They
then
looked
about
,
in
the
hope
of
finding
some
document
or
fragment
of
a
letter
,
which
might
serve
as
a
clue
to
the
other
parties
connected
with
the
fell
design
,
but
without
success
.
<EOS>
Nothing
was
found
except
a
pile
of
arms
;
but
though
they
examined
them
,
no
name
or
cipher
could
be
traced
on
any
of
the
weapons
.
<EOS>
"We
<EOS>
will
now
examine
the
prisoner
more
narrowly
,
"
said
Knevet
.
<EOS>
This
was
accordingly
done
.
<EOS>
On
removing
Guy
Fawkes
's
doublet
,
a
horse
-
hair
shirt
appeared
,
and
underneath
it
,
next
his
heart
,
suspended
by
a
silken
cord
from
his
neck
,
was
a
small
silver
cross
.
<EOS>
When
this
was
taken
from
him
,
Guy
Fawkes
could
not
repress
a
deep
sigh
.
<EOS>
"There
<EOS>
is
some
secret
attached
to
that
cross
,
"
whispered
Topcliffe
,
plucking
Knevet
's
sleeve
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
the
other
held
it
to
the
light
,
while
Topcliffe
kept
his
eye
fixed
upon
the
prisoner
,
and
observed
that
,
in
spite
of
all
his
efforts
to
preserve
an
unmoved
demeanour
,
he
was
slightly
agitated
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
you
perceive
anything
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
.
<EOS>
"Yes
,
"
replied
Knevet
,
"
there
is
a
name
.
<EOS>
But
the
character
is
so
small
I
can
not
decipher
it
.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
me
look
at
it
,
"
said
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
most
important
,
"
he
added
,
after
gazing
at
it
for
a
moment
;
"
the
words
inscribed
on
it
are
,
'
Viviana
Radcliffe
,
Ordsall
Hall
'
<EOS>
You
may
remember
that
this
young
lady
was
examined
a
short
time
ago
,
on
suspicion
of
being
connected
with
some
Popish
plot
against
the
state
,
and
committed
to
the
Tower
,
whence
she
escaped
in
a
very
extraordinary
manner
.
<EOS>
This
cross
,
found
upon
the
prisoner
,
proves
her
connexion
with
the
present
plot
.
<EOS>
Every
effort
must
be
used
to
discover
her
retreat
.
<EOS>
"Another
<EOS>
deep
sigh
involuntarily
broke
from
the
breast
of
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"You
hear
how
deeply
interested
he
is
in
the
matter
,
"
observed
Topcliffe
,
in
a
low
tone
.
<EOS>
"
This
trinket
will
be
of
infinite
service
to
us
in
future
examinations
,
and
may
do
more
for
us
with
this
stubborn
subject
even
than
the
rack
itself
.
<EOS>
""You
are
right
,
"
returned
Knevet
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
now
convey
him
to
Whitehall
,
and
acquaint
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
with
his
capture
.
<EOS>
""Do
<EOS>
so
,
"
replied
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
further
duty
to
perform
.
<EOS>
Before
morning
I
hope
to
net
the
whole
of
this
wolfish
pack
.
""Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Knevet
.
"
<EOS>
Have
you
any
knowledge
of
the
others?"Topcliffe
smiled
significantly
.
<EOS>
"Time
will
show
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
But
if
you
do
not
require
me
further
,
I
will
leave
you
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
quitted
the
cellar
,
and
joined
the
Earl
of
Mounteagle
and
Tresham
,
who
were
waiting
for
him
outside
at
a
little
distance
from
the
cellar
.
<EOS>
After
a
brief
conference
,
it
was
arranged
,
in
compliance
with
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
's
wishes
,
that
if
they
failed
in
entrapping
the
conspirators
,
nothing
should
be
said
about
the
matter
.
<EOS>
He
then
departed
with
Tresham
.
<EOS>
Their
subsequent
proceedings
have
already
been
related
.
<EOS>
By
Sir
Thomas
Knevet
's
directions
,
Guy
Fawkes
was
now
raised
by
two
of
the
soldiers
,
and
led
out
of
the
cellar
.
<EOS>
As
he
passed
through
the
door
,
he
uttered
a
deep
groan
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
groan
for
what
you
have
done
,
villain
,
"
said
one
of
the
soldiers
.
<EOS>
"On
<EOS>
the
contrary
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
sternly
,
"
I
groan
for
what
I
have
not
done
.
<EOS>
"He
was
then
hurried
along
by
his
conductors
,
and
conveyed
through
the
great
western
gate
,
into
the
palace
of
Whitehall
,
where
he
was
placed
in
a
small
room
,
the
windows
of
which
were
strongly
grated
.
<EOS>
Before
quitting
him
,
Sir
Thomas
Knevet
put
several
questions
to
him
,
but
he
maintained
a
stern
and
obstinate
silence
.
<EOS>
Committing
him
to
the
custody
of
an
officer
of
the
guard
,
whom
he
enjoined
to
keep
strict
guard
over
him
,
as
he
valued
his
life
,
Knevet
then
went
in
search
of
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
The
Secretary
,
who
had
not
retired
to
rest
,
and
was
anxiously
awaiting
his
arrival
,
was
delighted
with
the
success
of
the
scheme
.
<EOS>
They
were
presently
joined
by
Lord
Mounteagle
;
and
after
a
brief
conference
it
was
resolved
to
summon
the
Privy
Council
immediately
,
to
rouse
the
King
,
and
acquaint
him
with
what
had
occurred
,
and
to
interrogate
the
prisoner
in
his
presence
.
<EOS>
"Nothing
will
be
obtained
from
him
,
I
fear
,
"
said
Knevet
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
one
of
the
most
resolute
and
determined
fellows
I
ever
encountered
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
he
then
related
the
desperate
attempt
made
by
Fawkes
in
the
vault
to
blow
them
all
up
.
<EOS>
"Whether
<EOS>
he
will
speak
or
not
,
the
King
must
see
him
,
"
said
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Knevet
was
gone
,
the
Earl
observed
to
Mounteagle
,
"
You
had
now
better
leave
the
palace
.
<EOS>
You
must
not
appear
further
in
this
matter
,
except
as
we
have
arranged
.
<EOS>
Before
morning
,
I
trust
we
shall
have
the
whole
of
the
conspirators
in
our
power
,
with
damning
proofs
of
their
guilt
.
<EOS>
""By
<EOS>
this
time
,
my
lord
,
they
are
in
Tresham
's
hands
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
he
fails
,
not
a
word
must
be
said
,
"
observed
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
"
It
must
not
be
supposed
we
have
moved
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
All
great
statesmen
have
contrived
treasons
,
that
they
might
afterwards
discover
them
;
and
though
I
have
not
contrived
this
plot
,
I
have
known
of
its
existence
from
the
first
,
and
could
at
any
time
have
crushed
it
had
<EOS>
I
been
so
minded
.
<EOS>
But
that
would
not
have
answered
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
And
I
shall
now
use
it
as
a
pretext
to
crush
the
whole
Catholic
party
,
except
those
on
whom
,
like
yourself
,
I
can
confidently
rely
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
lordship
must
admit
that
I
have
well
seconded
your
efforts
,
"
observed
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
do
so
,
"
replied
Salisbury
,
"
and
you
will
not
find
me
ungrateful
.
<EOS>
Farewell
!
<EOS>
I
hope
soon
to
hear
of
our
further
success
.
"Mounteagle
<EOS>
then
took
his
departure
,
and
Salisbury
immediately
caused
all
such
members
of
the
Privy
Council
as
lodged
in
the
palace
to
be
aroused
,
desiring
they
might
be
informed
that
a
terrible
plot
had
been
discovered
,
and
a
conspirator
arrested
.
<EOS>
In
a
short
time
,
the
Duke
of
Lennox
,
the
Earl
of
Marr
,
Lord
Hume
,
the
Earl
of
Southampton
,
Lord
Henry
Howard
,
Lord
Mountjoy
,
Sir
George
Hume
,
and
others
,
were
assembled
;
and
all
eagerly
inquired
into
the
occasion
of
the
sudden
alarm
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
had
himself
repaired
to
the
King
's
bedchamber
,
and
acquainted
him
with
what
had
happened
.
<EOS>
James
immediately
roused
himself
,
and
desired
the
chamberlain
,
who
accompanied
the
Earl
,
to
quit
the
presence
.
<EOS>
"Will
<EOS>
it
be
safe
to
interrogate
the
prisoner
here
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
<EOS>
"I
will
take
care
<EOS>
your
Majesty
shall
receive
no
injury
,
"
replied
Salisbury
;
"
and
it
is
absolutely
necessary
you
should
examine
him
before
he
is
committed
to
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
him
be
brought
before
me
,
then
,
directly
,
"
said
the
King
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
impatient
to
behold
a
wretch
who
has
conceived
so
atrocious
—
so
infernal
a
design
against
me
,
and
against
my
children
.
<EOS>
Hark
'
e
,
Salisbury
,
one
caution
I
wish
to
observe
.
<EOS>
Let
a
captain
of
the
guard
,
with
his
drawn
sword
in
hand
,
place
himself
between
me
and
the
prisoner
,
and
let
two
halberdiers
stand
beside
him
,
and
if
the
villain
moves
a
step
,
bid
them
strike
him
dead
.
<EOS>
You
understand?"Illustration"Perfectly
,
"
replied
Salisbury
,
bowing
.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
that
case
,
you
may
take
off
his
bonds
—
that
is
,
if
you
think
it
prudent
to
do
so
—
not
otherwise
,
"
continued
James
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
have
the
knave
suppose
he
can
awe
me
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
Majesty
's
commands
shall
be
fulfilled
to
the
letter
,
"
returned
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"Lose
<EOS>
no
time
,
Salisbury
,
"
cried
James
,
springing
out
of
bed
,
and
beginning
to
dress
himself
without
the
assistance
of
his
chamberlain
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
hastily
retired
,
and
ordered
the
attendants
to
repair
to
their
royal
master
.
<EOS>
He
next
proceeded
to
the
chamber
where
Guy
Fawkes
was
detained
,
and
ordered
him
to
be
unbound
,
and
brought
before
the
King
.
<EOS>
When
the
prisoner
heard
this
mandate
,
a
slight
smile
crossed
his
countenance
,
but
he
instantly
resumed
his
former
stern
composure
.
<EOS>
The
smile
,
however
,
did
not
escape
the
notice
of
Salisbury
,
and
he
commanded
the
halberdiers
to
keep
near
to
the
prisoner
,
and
if
he
made
the
slightest
movement
in
the
King
's
presence
,
instantly
to
despatch
him
.
<EOS>
Giving
some
further
directions
,
the
Earl
then
led
the
way
across
a
court
,
and
entering
another
wing
of
the
palace
,
ascended
a
flight
of
steps
,
and
traversed
a
magnificent
corridor
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
followed
,
attended
by
the
guard
.
<EOS>
They
had
now
reached
the
antechamber
leading
to
the
royal
sleeping
apartment
,
and
"
Salisbury
ascertained
from
the
officers
in
attendance
that
all
was
in
readiness
.
<EOS>
Motioning
the
guard
to
remain
where
they
were
,
he
entered
the
inner
room
alone
,
and
found
James
seated
on
a
chair
of
state
near
the
bed
,
surrounded
by
his
council;—the
Earl
of
Marr
standing
on
his
right
hand
,
and
the
Duke
of
Lennox
on
his
left
,
all
anxiously
awaiting
his
arrival
.
<EOS>
Behind
the
King
were
stationed
half
a
dozen
halberdiers
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
prisoner
is
without
,
"
said
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
"
Is
it
your
Majesty
's
pleasure
that
he
be
admitted?""Ay
,
let
him
come
in
forthwith
,
"
replied
James
.
<EOS>
"
Stand
by
me
,
my
lords
.
<EOS>
And
do
you
,
varlets
,
keep
a
wary
eye
upon
him
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
saying
what
he
may
attempt
.
<EOS>
"Salisbury
<EOS>
then
waved
his
hand
.
<EOS>
The
door
was
thrown
open
,
and
an
officer
entered
the
room
,
followed
by
Guy
Fawkes
,
who
marched
between
two
halberdiers
.
<EOS>
When
within
a
couple
of
yards
of
the
King
,
the
officer
halted
,
and
withdrew
a
little
on
the
right
,
so
as
to
allow
full
view
of
the
prisoner
,
while
he
extended
his
sword
between
him
and
the
King
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
more
undaunted
than
the
looks
and
demeanour
of
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
He
strode
firmly
into
the
room
,
and
without
making
any
reverence
,
folded
his
arms
upon
his
breast
,
and
looked
sternly
at
James
.
<EOS>
"A
bold
villain
!
"
cried
the
King
,
as
he
regarded
him
with
curiosity
not
unmixed
with
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
,
and
what
are
you
,
traitor?""A
conspirator
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"That
I
know
,
"
rejoined
James
,
sharply
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
how
are
you
called?""John
Johnson
,
"
answered
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
servant
to
Mr.
Thomas
Percy
.
<EOS>
""That
is
false
,
"
cried
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
"
Take
heed
that
you
speak
the
truth
,
traitor
,
or
the
rack
shall
force
it
from
you
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
rack
will
force
nothing
from
me
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
sternly
;
"
neither
will
I
answer
any
question
asked
by
your
lordship
.
<EOS>
""Leave
him
to
me
<EOS>
,
Salisbury,—leave
him
to
me
,
"
interposed
James
.
<EOS>
"
And
it
was
your
hellish
design
to
blow
us
all
up
with
gunpowder
?
"
<EOS>
he
demanded
.
<EOS>
"It
was
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
how
could
you
resolve
to
destroy
so
many
persons
,
none
of
whom
have
injured
you
?
"
pursued
James
.
<EOS>
"Dangerous
<EOS>
diseases
require
desperate
remedies
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Milder
means
have
been
tried
,
but
without
effect
.
<EOS>
It
was
God
's
pleasure
that
this
scheme
,
which
was
for
the
benefit
of
his
holy
religion
,
should
not
prosper
,
and
therefore
I
do
not
repine
at
the
result
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
are
you
so
blinded
as
to
suppose
that
Heaven
can
approve
the
actions
of
him
who
raises
his
hand
against
the
King
—
against
the
Lord
's
anointed
?
"
cried
James
.
<EOS>
"He
is
no
king
who
is
excommunicated
by
the
apostolic
see
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"This
to
our
face
!
<EOS>
"
cried
James
,
angrily
.
"
<EOS>
Have
you
no
remorse
—
no
compunction
for
what
you
have
done?""My
<EOS>
sole
regret
is
that
I
have
failed
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"You
will
not
speak
thus
confidently
on
the
rack
,
"
said
James
.
<EOS>
"Try
<EOS>
me
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"What
purpose
<EOS>
did
you
hope
to
accomplish
by
this
atrocious
design
?
"
<EOS>
'
demanded
the
Earl
of
Marr
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
main
purpose
was
to
blow
back
the
beggarly
Scots
to
their
native
mountains
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"This
audacity
surpasses
belief
,
"
said
James
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mutius
Scævola
,
when
in
the
presence
of
Porsenna
,
was
not
more
resolute
.
<EOS>
Hark
'
e
,
villain
<EOS>
,
if
I
give
you
your
life
,
will
you
disclose
the
names
of
your
associates?""No
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"They
shall
be
wrung
from
you
<EOS>
,
"
cried
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
Fawkes
smiled
contemptuously
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
me
not
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"It
is
idle
to
interrogate
him
further
,
"
said
James
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
be
removed
to
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
""Be
it
<EOS>
so
,
"
returned
Salisbury
;
"
and
when
next
your
Majesty
questions
him
,
I
trust
it
will
be
in
the
presence
of
his
confederates
.
<EOS>
""Despite
<EOS>
the
villain
's
horrible
intent
<EOS>
,
I
can
not
help
admiring
his
courage
,
"
observed
James
,
in
a
low
tone
;
"
and
were
he
as
loyal
as
he
is
brave
<EOS>
,
he
should
always
be
near
our
person
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
waved
his
hand
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
was
led
forth
.
<EOS>
He
was
detained
by
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
's
orders
till
the
morning,—it
being
anticipated
that
before
that
time
the
other
conspirators
would
be
arrested
.
<EOS>
But
as
this
was
not
the
case
,
he
was
placed
in
a
wherry
,
and
conveyed
,
as
before
related
,
to
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
BOOK
THE
THIRD
<EOS>
—
THE
CONSPIRATORS.The
conclusion
shall
be
from
the
admirable
clemency
and
moderation
of
the
king
;
in
that
,
howsoever
these
traitors
have
exceeded
all
others
in
mischief
,
yet
neither
will
the
king
exceed
the
usual
punishment
of
law
,
nor
invent
any
new
torture
or
torment
for
them
,
but
is
graciously
pleased
to
afford
them
as
well
an
ordinary
course
of
trial
as
an
ordinary
punishment
much
inferior
to
their
offence
.
<EOS>
And
surely
worthy
of
observation
is
the
punishment
by
law
provided
and
appointed
for
high
treason
:
<EOS>
for
,
first
,
after
a
traitor
hath
had
his
just
trial
,
and
is
convicted
and
attainted
,
he
shall
have
his
judgment
to
be
drawn
to
the
place
of
execution
from
his
prison
,
as
being
not
worthy
any
more
to
tread
upon
the
face
of
the
earth
<EOS>
whereof
he
was
made
;
also
,
for
that
he
hath
been
retrograde
to
nature
,
therefore
is
he
drawn
backward
at
a
horsetail
.
<EOS>
After
,
to
have
his
head
cut
off
which
had
imagined
the
mischief
.
<EOS>
And
,
lastly
,
his
body
to
be
quartered
,
and
<EOS>
the
quarters
set
up
in
some
high
and
eminent
place
,
to
the
view
and
detestation
of
men
,
and
to
become
a
prey
for
the
fowls
of
the
air
.
<EOS>
And
this
is
a
reward
due
to
traitors
,
whose
hearts
be
hardened
;
for
that
it
is
a
physic
of
state
and
government
to
let
out
corrupt
blood
from
the
heart.—Sir
Edward
Coke
's
Speech
on
the
Gunpowder
Treason
.
<EOS>
I.
—
<EOS>
HOW
GUY
FAWKES
WAS
PUT
TO
THE
TORTUREIntimation
of
the
arrest
of
Guy
Fawkes
having
been
sent
to
the
Tower
,
his
arrival
was
anxiously
expected
by
the
warders
and
soldiers
composing
the
garrison
,
a
crowd
of
whom
posted
themselves
at
the
entrance
of
Traitor
's
Gate
,
to
obtain
a
sight
of
him
.
<EOS>
As
the
bark
that
conveyed
the
prisoner
shot
through
London
Bridge
,
and
neared
the
fortress
,
notice
of
its
approach
was
given
to
the
lieutenant
,
who
,
scarcely
less
impatient
,
had
stationed
himself
in
a
small
circular
chamber
in
one
of
the
turrets
of
Saint
Thomas
's
or
Traitor
's
Tower
,
overlooking
the
river
.
<EOS>
He
hastily
descended
,
and
had
scarcely
reached
the
place
of
disembarkation
,
when
the
boat
passed
beneath
the
gloomy
archway
,
the
immense
wooden
wicket
closed
behind
it
;
and
the
officer
in
command
springing
ashore
,
was
followed
more
deliberately
by
Fawkes
,
who
mounted
the
slippery
stairs
with
a
firm
footstep
.
<EOS>
As
he
gained
the
summit
,
the
spectators
pressed
forward
;
but
Sir
William
Waad
,
ordering
them
in
an
authoritative
tone
to
stand
back
,
fixed
a
stern
and
scrutinizing
glance
on
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
"Many
<EOS>
vile
traitors
have
ascended
those
steps
,
"
he
said
,
"
but
none
so
false
-
hearted
,
none
so
bloodthirsty
as
you
.
<EOS>
""None
<EOS>
ever
ascended
them
with
less
misgiving
,
or
with
less
self
-
reproach
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Miserable
wretch
!
<EOS>
Do
you
glory
in
your
villany
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
lieutenant
.
<EOS>
"
If
anything
could
heighten
my
detestation
of
the
pernicious
creed
you
profess
,
it
would
be
to
witness
its
effects
on
such
minds
as
yours
.
<EOS>
What
a
religion
must
that
be
,
which
can
induce
its
followers
to
commit
such
monstrous
actions
,
and
delude
them
into
the
belief
that
they
are
pious
and
praiseworthy!""It
is
a
religion
,
<EOS>
at
least
,
that
supports
them
at
seasons
when
they
most
require
it
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Peace
!
"
cried
the
lieutenant
,
fiercely
,
"
or
I
will
have
your
viperous
tongue
torn
out
by
the
roots
.
<EOS>
"Turning
<EOS>
to
the
officer
,
he
demanded
his
warrant
,
and
glancing
at
it
,
gave
some
directions
to
one
of
the
warders
,
and
then
resumed
his
scrutiny
of
Fawkes
,
who
appeared
wholly
unmoved
,
and
steadily
returned
his
gaze
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
several
of
the
spectators
,
eager
to
prove
their
loyalty
to
the
king
,
and
abhorrence
of
the
plot
,
loaded
the
prisoner
with
execrations
,
and
finding
these
produced
no
effect
,
proceeded
to
personal
outrage
.
<EOS>
Some
spat
upon
his
face
and
garments
;
some
threw
mud
,
gathered
from
the
slimy
steps
,
upon
him
;
some
pricked
him
with
the
points
of
their
halberds
;
while
others
,
if
they
had
not
been
checked
,
would
have
resorted
to
greater
violence
.
<EOS>
Only
one
bystander
expressed
the
slightest
commiseration
for
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
Ruth
Ipgreve
,
who
,
with
her
parents
,
formed
part
of
the
assemblage
.
<EOS>
A
few
kindly
words
pronounced
by
this
girl
moved
the
prisoner
more
than
all
the
insults
he
had
just
experienced
.
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
,
but
a
slight
and
almost
imperceptible
quivering
of
the
lip
told
what
was
passing
within
.
<EOS>
The
jailer
was
extremely
indignant
at
his
daughter
's
conduct
,
fearing
it
might
prejudice
him
in
the
eyes
of
the
lieutenant
.
<EOS>
"Get
<EOS>
hence
,
girl
,
"
he
cried
,
"
and
stir
not
from
thy
room
for
the
rest
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
I
allowed
thee
to
come
forth
.
<EOS>
""You
must
look
to
her
,
Jasper
Ipgreve
,
"
said
Sir
William
Waad
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
No
man
shall
hold
an
office
in
the
Tower
who
is
a
favourer
of
papacy
.
<EOS>
If
you
were
a
good
Protestant
,
and
a
faithful
servant
of
King
James
,
your
daughter
could
never
have
acted
thus
unbecomingly
.
<EOS>
Look
to
her
,
I
say,—and
to
yourself
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
will
,
honourable
sir
,
"
replied
Jasper
,
in
great
confusion
.
<EOS>
"
Take
her
home
directly
,
"
he
added
,
in
an
under
tone
to
his
wife
.
"
<EOS>
Lock
her
up
till
I
return
,
and
scourge
her
if
thou
wilt
.
<EOS>
She
will
ruin
us
by
her
indiscretion
.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
obedience
to
this
injunction
,
Dame
Ipgreve
seized
her
daughter
's
hand
,
and
dragged
her
away
.
<EOS>
Ruth
turned
for
a
moment
to
take
a
last
look
at
the
prisoner
,
and
saw
that
his
gaze
followed
her
,
and
was
fraught
with
an
expression
of
the
deepest
gratitude
.
<EOS>
By
way
of
showing
his
disapproval
of
his
daughter
's
conduct
,
the
jailer
now
joined
the
bitterest
of
Guy
Fawkes
's
assailants
;
and
ere
long
the
assemblage
became
infuriated
to
such
an
ungovernable
pitch
,
that
the
lieutenant
,
who
had
allowed
matters
to
proceed
thus
far
in
the
hope
of
shaking
the
prisoner
's
constancy
,
finding
his
design
fruitless
,
ordered
him
to
be
taken
away
.
<EOS>
Escorted
by
a
dozen
soldiers
with
calivers
on
their
shoulders
,
Guy
Fawkes
was
led
through
the
archway
of
the
Bloody
Tower
,
and
across
the
Green
to
the
Beauchamp
Tower
.
<EOS>
He
was
placed
in
the
spacious
chamber
on
the
first
floor
of
that
fortification
,
now
used
as
a
mess
-
room
by
the
Guards
.
<EOS>
Sir
William
Waad
followed
him
,
and
seating
himself
at
a
table
,
referred
to
the
warrant
.
<EOS>
"You
are
here
called
John
Johnson
.
<EOS>
Is
that
your
name
?
"
<EOS>
he
demanded
.
<EOS>
"If
you
find
it
thus
written
,
you
need
make
no
further
inquiry
from
me
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
the
person
so
described
.
<EOS>
That
is
sufficient
for
you
.
<EOS>
""Not
<EOS>
so
,
"
replied
the
lieutenant
;
"
and
if
you
persist
in
this
stubborn
demeanour
,
the
severest
measures
will
be
adopted
towards
you
.
<EOS>
Your
sole
chance
of
avoiding
the
torture
is
in
making
a
full
confession
.
<EOS>
""I
do
not
desire
to
avoid
the
torture
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
wrest
nothing
from
me
.
<EOS>
""So
<EOS>
all
think
till
they
have
experienced
it
,
"
replied
the
lieutenant
;
"
but
greater
fortitude
than
yours
has
given
way
before
our
engines
.
<EOS>
"Fawkes
<EOS>
smiled
disdainfully
,
but
made
no
answer
.
<EOS>
The
lieutenant
then
gave
directions
that
he
should
be
placed
within
a
small
cell
adjoining
the
larger
chamber
,
and
that
two
of
the
guard
should
remain
constantly
beside
him
,
to
prevent
him
from
doing
himself
any
violence
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
need
have
no
fear
,
"
observed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
destroy
my
chance
of
martyrdom
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
this
juncture
a
messenger
arrived
,
bearing
a
despatch
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
The
lieutenant
broke
the
seal
,
and
after
hurriedly
perusing
it
,
drew
his
sword
,
and
desiring
the
guard
to
station
themselves
outside
the
door
,
approached
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Notwithstanding
<EOS>
the
enormity
of
your
offence
<EOS>
,
"
he
observed
,
"
I
find
his
Majesty
will
graciously
spare
your
life
,
provided
you
will
reveal
the
names
of
all
your
associates
,
and
disclose
every
particular
connected
with
the
plot
.
<EOS>
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
appeared
lost
in
reflection
,
and
the
lieutenant
,
conceiving
he
had
made
an
impression
upon
him
,
repeated
the
offer
.
<EOS>
"How
<EOS>
am
I
to
be
assured
of
this
?
"
asked
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
promise
must
suffice
,
"
rejoined
Waad
.
<EOS>
"It
will
not
suffice
to
me
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
a
pardon
signed
by
the
King
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
shall
have
it
on
one
condition
,
"
replied
Waad
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
evidently
troubled
with
few
scruples
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
's
conviction
that
the
heads
of
many
important
Catholic
families
are
connected
with
this
plot
.
<EOS>
If
they
should
prove
to
be
so,—or
,
to
be
plain
,
if
you
will
accuse
certain
persons
whom
I
will

,
you
shall
have
the
pardon
