.
<EOS>
How
shall
we
begin?""With
the
Scavenger
's
Daughter
and
the
Little
Ease
,
if
it
please
you
,
honourable
sir
,
"
replied
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"
If
these
fail
,
we
can
try
the
gauntlets
and
the
rack
;
and
lastly
,
the
dungeon
among
the
rats
,
and
the
hot
stone
.
<EOS>
""A
good
progression
,
"
said
the
lieutenant
,
smiling
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
now
repair
to
the
torture
-
chamber
.
<EOS>
Let
the
prisoner
be
brought
there
without
delay
.
<EOS>
He
is
in
the
Beauchamp
Tower
.
<EOS>
"Ipgreve
bowed
and
departed
,
while
the
lieutenant
,
calling
to
an
attendant
to
bring
a
torch
,
proceeded
along
a
narrow
passage
communicating
with
the
Bell
Tower
.
<EOS>
Opening
a
secret
door
within
it
,
he
descended
a
flight
of
stone
steps
,
and
traversing
a
number
of
intricate
passages
,
at
length
stopped
before
a
strong
door
,
which
he
pushed
aside
,
and
entered
the
chamber
he
had
mentioned
to
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
This
dismal
apartment
has
already
been
described
.
<EOS>
It
was
that
in
which
Viviana
's
constancy
was
so
fearfully
approved
.
<EOS>
Two
officials
in
the
peculiar
garb
of
the
place
—
a
sable
livery
—
were
occupied
in
polishing
the
various
steel
implements
.
<EOS>
Besides
these
,
there
was
the
chirurgeon
,
who
was
seated
at
a
side
table
,
reading
by
the
light
of
a
brazen
lamp
.
<EOS>
He
instantly
arose
on
seeing
the
lieutenant
,
and
began
,
with
the
other
officials
,
to
make
preparations
for
the
prisoner
's
arrival
.
<EOS>
The
two
latter
concealed
their
features
by
drawing
a
large
black
capoch
,
or
hood
,
attached
to
their
gowns
over
them
,
and
this
disguise
added
materially
to
their
lugubrious
appearance
.
<EOS>
One
of
them
then
took
down
a
broad
iron
hoop
,
opening
in
the
centre
with
a
hinge
,
and
held
it
in
readiness
.
<EOS>
Their
preparations
were
scarcely
completed
when
heavy
footsteps
announced
the
approach
of
Fawkes
and
his
attendants
.
<EOS>
Jasper
Ipgreve
ushered
them
into
the
chamber
,
and
fastened
the
door
behind
them
.
<EOS>
All
the
subsequent
proceedings
were
conducted
with
the
utmost
deliberation
,
and
were
therefore
doubly
impressive
.
<EOS>
No
undue
haste
occurred
,
and
the
officials
,
who
might
have
been
mistaken
for
phantoms
or
evil
spirits
,
spoke
only
in
whispers
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
watched
their
movements
with
unaltered
composure
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
Jasper
Ipgreve
signified
to
the
lieutenant
that
all
was
ready
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
opportunity
you
desired
of
having
your
courage
put
to
the
test
is
now
arrived
,
"
said
the
latter
to
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
"What
am
I
to
do
?
"
was
the
reply
.
<EOS>
"Remove
<EOS>
your
doublet
,
and
prostrate
yourself
,
"
subjoined
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
obeyed
,
and
when
in
this
posture
began
audibly
to
recite
a
prayer
to
the
Virgin
.
<EOS>
"Be
<EOS>
silent
,
"
cried
the
lieutenant
,
"
or
a
gag
shall
be
thrust
into
your
mouth
.
<EOS>
"Kneeling
<EOS>
upon
the
prisoner
's
shoulders
,
and
passing
the
hoop
under
his
legs
,
Ipgreve
then
succeeded
,
with
the
help
of
his
assistants
,
who
added
their
weight
to
his
own
,
in
fastening
the
hoop
with
an
iron
button
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
they
left
the
prisoner
with
his
limbs
and
body
so
tightly
compressed
together
that
he
was
scarcely
able
to
breathe
.
<EOS>
In
this
state
he
was
allowed
to
remain
for
an
hour
and
a
half
.
<EOS>
The
chirurgeon
then
found
on
examination
that
the
blood
had
burst
profusely
from
his
mouth
and
nostrils
,
and
in
a
slighter
degree
from
the
extremities
of
his
hands
and
feet
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
must
be
released
,
"
he
observed
in
an
under
tone
to
the
lieutenant
.
"
<EOS>
Further
continuance
might
be
fatal
.
<EOS>
"Accordingly
<EOS>
,
the
hoop
was
removed
,
and
it
was
at
this
moment
that
the
prisoner
underwent
the
severest
trial
.
<EOS>
Despite
his
efforts
to
control
himself
,
a
sharp
convulsion
passed
across
his
frame
,
and
the
restoration
of
impeded
circulation
and
respiration
occasioned
him
the
most
acute
agony
.
<EOS>
The
chirurgeon
bathed
his
temples
with
vinegar
,
and
his
limbs
being
chafed
by
the
officials
,
he
was
placed
on
a
bench
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
warrant
directs
me
to
begin
with
the
'
gentler
tortures
,
'
and
to
proceed
by
degrees
to
extremities
,
"
observed
the
lieutenant
,
significantly
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
now
had
a
taste
of
the
milder
sort
,
and
may
form
some
conjecture
what
the
worst
are
like
.
<EOS>
Do
you
still
continue
contumacious?""I
am
in
the
same
mind
as
before
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
in
a
hoarse
but
firm
voice
.
<EOS>
"Take
him
to
the
Little
Ease
,
and
let
him
pass
the
night
there
,
"
said
the
lieutenant
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
I
will
continue
the
investigation
.
<EOS>
"Fawkes
was
then
led
out
by
Ipgreve
and
the
officials
,
and
conveyed
along
a
narrow
passage
,
until
arriving
at
a
low
door
,
in
which
there
was
an
iron
grating
,
it
was
opened
,
and
disclosed
a
narrow
cell
about
four
feet
high
,
one
and
a
few
inches
wide
,
and
two
deep
.
<EOS>
Into
this
narrow
receptacle
,
which
seemed
wholly
inadequate
to
contain
a
tall
and
strongly
-
built
man
like
himself
,
the
prisoner
was
with
some
difficulty
thrust
,
and
the
door
locked
upon
him
.
<EOS>
In
this
miserable
plight
,
with
his
head
bent
upon
his
breast,—the
cell
being
so
contrived
that
its
wretched
inmate
could
neither
sit
,
nor
recline
at
full
length
within
it,—Guy
Fawkes
prayed
long
and
fervently
;
and
no
longer
troubled
by
the
uneasy
feelings
which
had
for
some
time
haunted
him
,
he
felt
happier
in
his
present
forlorn
condition
than
he
had
been
when
anticipating
the
full
success
of
his
project
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
least
,
"
he
thought
,
"
I
shall
now
win
myself
a
crown
of
martyrdom
,
and
whatever
my
present
sufferings
may
be
,
they
will
be
speedily
effaced
by
the
happiness
I
shall
enjoy
hereafter
.
<EOS>
"Overcome
,
at
length
,
by
weariness
and
exhaustion
,
he
fell
into
a
sort
of
doze
—
it
could
scarcely
be
called
sleep
—
and
while
in
this
state
,
fancied
he
was
visited
by
Saint
Winifred
,
who
,
approaching
the
door
of
the
cell
,
touched
it
,
and
it
instantly
opened
.
<EOS>
She
then
placed
her
hand
upon
his
limbs
,
and
the
pain
he
had
hitherto
felt
in
them
subsided
.
<EOS>
"Your
troubles
will
soon
be
over
,
"
murmured
the
saint
,
"
and
you
will
be
at
rest
.
<EOS>
Do
not
hesitate
to
confess
.
<EOS>
Your
silence
will
neither
serve
your
companions
nor
yourself
.
"
<EOS>
With
these
words
the
vision
disappeared
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
awoke
.
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
the
effect
of
imagination
,
or
that
his
robust
constitution
had
in
reality
shaken
off
the
effects
of
the
torture
,
it
is
impossible
to
say
,
but
it
is
certain
that
he
felt
his
strength
restored
to
him
,
and
attributing
his
recovery
entirely
to
the
marvellous
interposition
of
the
saint
,
he
addressed
a
prayer
of
gratitude
to
her
.
<EOS>
While
thus
occupied
,
he
heard
—
for
it
was
so
dark
he
could
distinguish
nothing
—
a
sweet
low
voice
at
the
grating
of
the
cell
,
and
imagining
it
was
the
same
benign
presence
as
before
,
paused
and
listened
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
you
hear
me
?
"
asked
the
voice
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
do
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
Is
it
the
blessed
Winifred
,
who
again
vouchsafes
to
address
me?""Alas
,
no
!
"
replied
the
voice
;
"
it
is
one
of
mortal
mould
.
<EOS>
I
am
Ruth
Ipgreve
,
the
jailer
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
You
may
remember
that
I
expressed
some
sympathy
in
your
behalf
at
your
landing
at
Traitor
's
Gate
to
-
day
,
for
which
I
incurred
my
father
's
displeasure
.
<EOS>
But
you
will
be
quite
sure
I
am
a
friend
,
when
I
tell
you
I
assisted
Viviana
Radcliffe
to
escape
.
<EOS>
""Ha
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Guy
Fawkes
,
in
a
tone
of
great
emotion
.
<EOS>
"I
was
in
some
degree
in
her
confidence
,
"
pursued
Ruth
;
"
and
,
if
I
am
not
mistaken
,
you
are
the
object
of
her
warmest
regard
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
prisoner
could
not
repress
a
groan
.
<EOS>
"You
are
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
pursued
Ruth
.
"
<EOS>
Nay
,
you
need
have
no
fear
of
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
risked
my
life
for
Viviana
,
and
would
risk
it
for
you
.
<EOS>
""I
will
disguise
nothing
from
you
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
he
you
have
named
.
<EOS>
As
the
husband
of
Viviana
—
for
such
I
am
—
I
feel
the
deepest
gratitude
to
you
for
the
service
you
rendered
her
.
<EOS>
She
bitterly
reproached
herself
with
having
placed
you
in
so
much
danger
.
<EOS>
How
did
you
escape?""I
was
screened
by
my
parents
,
"
replied
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
given
out
by
them
that
Viviana
escaped
through
the
window
of
her
prison
,
and
I
was
thus
preserved
from
punishment
.
<EOS>
Where
is
she
now?""In
safety
,
I
trust
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
I
shall
never
behold
her
again
.
<EOS>
""Do
not
despair
,
"
returned
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
try
to
effect
your
liberation
;
and
though
I
have
but
<EOS>
slender
hope
of
accomplishing
it
<EOS>
,
still
there
is
a
chance
.
<EOS>
""I
do
not
desire
it
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
content
to
perish
.
<EOS>
All
I
lived
for
is
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
""This
shall
not
deter
me
from
trying
to
save
you
,
"
replied
Ruth
;
"
and
I
still
trust
there
is
happiness
in
store
for
you
with
Viviana
.
<EOS>
Amid
all
your
sufferings
,
rest
certain
there
is
one
who
will
ever
watch
over
you
.
<EOS>
I
dare
not
remain
here
longer
,
for
fear
of
a
surprise
.
<EOS>
Farewell!"She
then
departed
,
and
it
afforded
Guy
Fawkes
some
solace
to
ponder
on
the
interview
during
the
rest
of
the
night
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
Jasper
Ipgreve
appeared
,
and
placed
before
him
a
loaf
of
the
coarsest
bread
,
and
a
jug
of
dirty
water
.
<EOS>
His
scanty
meal
ended
,
he
left
him
,
but
returned
in
two
hours
afterwards
with
a
party
of
halberdiers
,
and
desiring
him
to
follow
him
,
led
the
way
to
the
torture
-
chamber
.
<EOS>
Sir
William
Waad
was
there
when
he
arrived
,
and
demanding
in
a
stern
tone
whether
he
still
continued
obstinate
,
and
receiving
no
answer
,
ordered
him
to
be
placed
in
the
gauntlets
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
he
was
suspended
from
a
beam
by
his
hands
,
and
endured
five
hours
of
the
most
excruciating
agony
—
his
fingers
being
so
crushed
and
lacerated
that
he
could
not
move
them
.
<EOS>
He
was
then
taken
down
,
and
still
refusing
to
confess
,
was
conveyed
to
a
horrible
pit
,
adjoining
the
river
,
called
,
from
the
loathsome
animals
infesting
it
,
"
the
dungeon
among
the
rats
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
about
twenty
feet
wide
and
twelve
deep
,
and
at
high
tide
was
generally
more
than
two
feet
deep
in
water
.
<EOS>
Into
this
dreadful
chasm
was
Guy
Fawkes
lowered
by
his
attendants
,
who
,
warning
him
of
the
probable
fate
that
awaited
him
,
left
him
in
total
darkness
.
<EOS>
At
this
time
the
pit
was
free
from
water
;
but
he
had
not
been
there
more
than
an
hour
,
when
a
bubbling
and
hissing
sound
proclaimed
that
the
tide
was
rising
,
while
frequent
plashes
convinced
him
that
the
rats
were
at
hand
.
<EOS>
Stooping
down
,
he
felt
that
the
water
was
alive
with
them
—
that
they
were
all
around
him
—
and
would
not
,
probably
,
delay
their
attack
.
<EOS>
Prepared
as
he
was
for
the
worst
,
he
could
not
repress
a
shudder
at
the
prospect
of
the
horrible
death
with
which
he
was
menaced
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
he
was
surprised
by
the
appearance
of
a
light
,
and
perceived
at
the
edge
of
the
pit
a
female
figure
bearing
a
lantern
.
<EOS>
Not
doubting
it
was
his
visitant
of
the
former
night
,
he
called
out
to
her
,
and
was
answered
in
the
voice
of
Ruth
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
dare
not
remain
here
many
minutes
,
"
she
said
,
"
because
my
father
suspects
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
could
not
let
you
perish
thus
.
<EOS>
I
will
let
down
this
lantern
to
you
,
and
the
light
will
keep
away
the
rats
.
<EOS>
When
the
tide
retires
you
can
extinguish
it
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
she
tore
her
kerchief
into
shreds
,
and
tying
the
slips
together
,
lowered
the
lantern
to
the
prisoner
,
and
without
waiting
to
receive
his
thanks
,
hurried
away
.
<EOS>
Thus
aided
,
Guy
Fawkes
defended
himself
as
well
as
he
could
against
his
loathsome
assailants
.
<EOS>
The
light
showed
that
the
water
was
swarming
with
them
—
that
they
were
creeping
by
hundreds
up
the
sides
of
the
pit
,
and
preparing
to
make
a
general
attack
upon
him
.
<EOS>
At
one
time
,
Fawkes
determined
not
to
oppose
them
,
but
to
let
them
work
their
will
upon
him
;
but
the
contact
of
the
noxious
animals
made
him
change
his
resolution
,
and
he
instinctively
drove
them
off
.
<EOS>
They
were
not
,
however
,
to
be
easily
repulsed
,
and
returned
to
the
charge
with
greater
fury
than
before
.
<EOS>
The
desire
of
self
preservation
now
got
the
better
of
every
other
feeling
,
and
the
dread
of
being
devoured
alive
giving
new
vigour
to
his
crippled
limbs
,
he
rushed
to
the
other
side
of
the
pit
.
<EOS>
His
persecutors
,
however
,
followed
him
in
myriads
,
springing
upon
him
,
and
making
their
sharp
teeth
meet
in
his
flesh
in
a
thousand
places
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
the
contest
continued
for
some
time
,
Guy
Fawkes
speeding
round
the
pit
,
and
his
assailants
never
for
one
moment
relaxing
in
the
pursuit
,
until
he
fell
from
exhaustion
,
and
his
lantern
being
extinguished
,
the
whole
host
darted
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Thinking
all
over
,
he
could
not
repress
a
loud
cry
,
and
it
was
scarcely
uttered
,
when
lights
appeared
,
and
several
gloomy
figures
bearing
torches
were
seen
at
the
edge
of
the
pit
.
<EOS>
Among
these
he
distinguished
Sir
William
Waad
,
who
offered
instantly
to
release
him
if
he
would
confess
.
<EOS>
"I
will
rather
perish
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
"
and
I
will
make
no
further
effort
to
defend
myself
.
<EOS>
I
shall
soon
be
out
of
the
reach
of
your
malice
.
<EOS>
""This
must
not
be
,
"
observed
the
lieutenant
to
Jasper
Ipgreve
,
who
stood
by
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Earl
of
Salisbury
will
never
forgive
me
if
he
perishes
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
not
a
moment
must
be
lost
,
or
those
ravenous
brutes
will
assuredly
devour
him
,
"
replied
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
so
fierce
,
that
I
scarcely
like
to
venture
among
them
.
<EOS>
"A
ladder
was
then
let
down
into
the
pit
,
and
the
jailer
and
the
two
officials
descended
.
<EOS>
They
were
just
in
time
.
<EOS>
Fawkes
had
ceased
to
struggle
,
and
the
rats
were
attacking
him
with
such
fury
that
his
words
would
have
been
speedily
verified
,
but
for
Ipgreve
's
timely
interposition
.
<EOS>
On
being
taken
out
of
the
pit
,
he
fainted
from
exhaustion
and
loss
of
blood
;
and
when
he
came
to
himself
,
found
he
was
stretched
upon
a
couch
in
the
torture
-
chamber
,
with
the
chirurgeon
and
Jasper
Ipgreve
in
attendance
.
<EOS>
Strong
broths
and
other
restoratives
were
then
administered
;
and
his
strength
being
sufficiently
restored
to
enable
him
to
converse
,
the
lieutenant
again
visited
him
,
and
questioning
him
as
before
,
received
a
similar
answer
.
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
that
day
and
the
next
,
he
underwent
at
intervals
various
kinds
of
torture
,
each
more
excruciating
than
the
preceding
,
all
of
which
he
bore
with
unabated
fortitude
.
<EOS>
Among
other
applications
,
the
rack
was
employed
with
such
rigour
,
that
his
joints
started
from
their
sockets
,
and
his
frame
seemed
torn
asunder
.
<EOS>
On
the
fourth
day
he
was
removed
to
another
and
yet
gloomier
chamber
,
devoted
to
the
same
dreadful
objects
as
the
first
.
<EOS>
It
had
an
arched
stone
ceiling
,
and
at
the
further
extremity
yawned
a
deep
recess
.
<EOS>
Within
this
there
was
a
small
furnace
,
in
which
fuel
was
placed
,
ready
to
be
kindled
;
and
over
the
furnace
lay
a
large
black
flag
,
at
either
end
of
which
were
stout
leathern
straps
.
<EOS>
After
being
subjected
to
the
customary
interrogations
of
the
lieutenant
,
Fawkes
was
stripped
of
his
attire
,
and
bound
to
the
flag
.
<EOS>
The
fire
was
then
lighted
,
and
the
stone
gradually
heated
.
<EOS>
The
writhing
frame
of
the
miserable
man
ere
long
showed
the
extremity
of
his
suffering
;
but
as
he
did
not
even
utter
a
groan
,
his
tormentors
were
compelled
to
release
him
.
<EOS>
On
this
occasion
,
there
were
two
personages
present
who
had
never
attended
any
previous
interrogation
.
<EOS>
They
were
wrapped
in
large
cloaks
,
and
stood
aloof
during
the
proceedings
.
<EOS>
Both
were
treated
with
the
most
ceremonious
respect
by
Sir
William
Waad
,
who
consulted
them
as
to
the
extent
to
which
he
should
continue
the
torture
.
<EOS>
When
the
prisoner
was
taken
off
the
heated
stone
,
one
of
those
persons
advanced
towards
him
,
and
gazed
curiously
at
him
.
<EOS>
Fawkes
,
upon
whose
brow
thick
drops
were
standing
,
and
who
was
sinking
into
the
oblivion
brought
on
by
overwrought
endurance
,
exclaimed
,
"
It
is
the
King
;
"
and
fainted
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
traitor
knew
your
Majesty
,
"
said
the
lieutenant
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
see
it
is
in
vain
to
attempt
to
extort
anything
from
him
.
<EOS>
""So
<EOS>
it
seems
,
"
replied
James
;
"
and
I
am
greatly
disappointed
,
for
I
was
led
to
believe
that
I
should
hear
a
full
confession
of
the
conspiracy
from
his
own
lips
.
<EOS>
How
say
you
,
good
Master
chirurgeon
,
will
he
endure
further
torture?""Not
without
danger
of
life
,
your
Majesty
,
unless
he
has
some
days
'
repose
,
"
replied
the
chirurgeon
,
"
even
if
he
can
endure
it
then
.
<EOS>
""It
will
not
be
necessary
to
apply
it
further
,
"
replied
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
now
in
full
possession
of
the
names
of
all
the
principal
conspirators
;
and
when
the
prisoner
finds
further
concealment
useless
,
he
will
change
his
tone
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
,
the
commissioners
appointed
by
your
Majesty
for
the
examination
of
all
those
concerned
in
this
dreadful
project
,
will
interrogate
him
in
the
lieutenant
's
lodgings
,
and
I
will
answer
with
my
life
that
the
result
will
be
satisfactory
.
<EOS>
""Enough
,
"
said
James
.
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
a
painful
spectacle
which
we
have
just
witnessed
,
and
yet
we
would
not
have
missed
it
.
<EOS>
The
wretch
possesses
undaunted
resolution
,
and
we
can
never
be
sufficiently
grateful
to
the
beneficent
Providence
that
prevented
him
from
working
his
ruthless
purpose
upon
us
.
<EOS>
The
day
on
which
we
were
preserved
from
this
Gunpowder
Treason
shall
ever
hereafter
be
kept
sacred
in
our
church
,
and
thanks
shall
be
returned
to
Heaven
for
our
wonderful
deliverance
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
Majesty
will
act
wisely
,
"
replied
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
"
The
Ordinance
will
impress
the
nation
with
a
salutary
horror
of
all
Papists
and
traitors,—for
they
are
one
and
the
same
thing,—and
<EOS>
keep
alive
a
proper
feeling
of
enmity
against
them
.
<EOS>
Such
a
fearful
example
shall
be
made
of
these
miscreants
as
shall
,
it
is
to
be
hoped
,
deter
all
others
from
following
their
cause
.
<EOS>
Not
only
shall
they
perish
infamously
,
but
their
names
shall
for
ever
be
held
in
execration
.
<EOS>
""Be
it
<EOS>
so
,
"
rejoined
James
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
good
legal
maxim
—
Crescente
malitiâ
,
<EOS>
crescere
debuit
et
poena
.
<EOS>
"Upon
<EOS>
this
,
he
left
the
chamber
,
and
,
traversing
a
number
of
subterranean
passages
with
his
attendants
,
crossed
the
drawbridge
near
the
Byward
Tower
to
the
wharf
,
where
his
barge
was
waiting
for
him
,
and
returned
in
it
to
Whitehall
.
<EOS>
At
an
early
hour
on
the
following
day
,
the
commissioners
appointed
to
the
examination
of
the
prisoner
,
met
together
in
a
large
room
on
the
second
floor
of
the
lieutenant
's
lodgings
,
afterwards
denominated
,
from
its
use
on
this
occasion
,
the
Council
Chamber
.
<EOS>
Affixed
to
the
walls
of
this
room
may
be
seen
at
the
present
day
a
piece
of
marble
sculpture
,
with
an
inscription
commemorative
of
the
event
.
<EOS>
The
commissioners
were
nine
in
number
,
and
included
the
Earls
of
Salisbury
,
Northampton
,
Nottingham
,
Suffolk
,
Worcester
,
Devon
,
Marr
,
and
Dunbar
,
and
Sir
John
Popham
,
Lord
Chief
Justice
.
<EOS>
With
these
were
associated
Sir
Edward
Coke
,
attorney
-
general
,
and
Sir
William
Waad
.
<EOS>
The
apartment
in
which
the
examination
took
place
is
still
a
spacious
one
,
but
at
the
period
in
question
it
was
much
larger
and
loftier
.
<EOS>
The
walls
were
panelled
with
dark
lustrous
oak
,
covered
in
some
places
with
tapestry
,
and
adorned
in
others
with
paintings
.
<EOS>
Over
the
chimney
-
piece
hung
a
portrait
of
the
late
sovereign
,
Elizabeth
.
<EOS>
The
commissioners
were
grouped
round
a
large
heavily
carved
oak
table
,
and
,
after
some
deliberation
together
,
it
was
agreed
that
the
prisoner
should
be
introduced
.
<EOS>
Sir
William
Waad
then
motioned
to
Topcliffe
,
who
was
in
attendance
with
half
a
dozen
halberdiers
,
and
a
few
moments
afterwards
a
panel
was
pushed
aside
,
and
Guy
Fawkes
was
brought
through
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
supported
by
Topcliffe
and
Ipgreve
,
and
it
was
with
the
greatest
difficulty
he
could
drag
himself
along
.
<EOS>
So
severe
had
been
the
sufferings
to
which
he
had
been
subjected
,
that
they
had
done
the
work
of
time
,
and
placed
more
than
twenty
years
on
his
head
.
<EOS>
His
features
were
thin
and
sharp
,
and
of
a
ghastly
whiteness
,
and
his
eyes
hollow
and
bloodshot
.
<EOS>
A
large
cloak
was
thrown
over
him
,
which
partially
concealed
his
shattered
frame
and
crippled
limbs
;
but
his
bent
shoulders
,
and
the
difficulty
with
which
he
moved
,
told
how
much
he
had
undergone
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
the
presence
in
which
he
stood
,
a
flush
for
a
moment
rose
to
his
pallid
cheek
,
his
eye
glowed
with
its
wonted
fire
,
and
he
tried
to
stand
erect
—
but
his
limbs
refused
their
office
—
and
the
effort
was
so
painful
,
that
he
fell
back
into
the
arms
of
his
attendants
.
<EOS>
He
was
thus
borne
forward
by
them
,
and
supported
during
his
examination
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
of
Salisbury
then
addressed
him
,
and
enlarging
on
the
magnitude
and
horrible
nature
of
his
treason
,
concluded
by
saying
that
the
only
reparation
he
could
offer
was
to
disclose
not
only
all
his
own
criminal
intentions
,
but
the
names
of
his
associates
.
<EOS>
"I
will
hide
nothing
concerning
myself
,
"
replied
Fawkes
;
"
but
I
shall
be
for
ever
silent
respecting
others
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
Earl
then
glanced
at
Sir
Edward
Coke
,
who
proceeded
to
take
down
minutes
of
the
examination
.
<EOS>
"You
have
hitherto
falsely
represented
yourself
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
your
real
name?""Guy
Fawkes
,
"
replied
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
do
you
confess
your
guilt
?
"
pursued
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
admit
that
it
was
my
intention
to
blow
up
the
King
and
the
whole
of
the
lords
spiritual
and
temporal
assembled
in
the
Parliament
House
with
gunpowder
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
you
placed
the
combustibles
in
the
vault
where
they
were
discovered
?
"
demanded
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
The
prisoner
answered
in
the
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"You
are
a
Papist
?
"
continued
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"I
am
a
member
of
the
Church
of
Rome
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
you
regard
this
monstrous
design
as
righteous
and
laudable
—
as
consistent
with
the
religion
you
profess
,
and
as
likely
to
uphold
it
?
"
said
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
did
so
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
now
convinced
that
Heaven
did
not
approve
it
,
and
I
lament
that
it
was
ever
undertaken
.
<EOS>
""Still
,
you
refuse
to
make
the
only
reparation
in
your
power
—
you
refuse
to
disclose
your
associates
?
"
said
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
"I
can
not
betray
them
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Traitor
!
<EOS>
it
is
needless
,
"
cried
the
Earl
;
"
they
are
known
to
us
—
<EOS>
nay
,
they
have
betrayed
themselves
.
<EOS>
They
have
risen
in
open
and
armed
rebellion
against
the
King
;
but
a
sufficient
power
has
been
sent
against
them
;
and
if
they
are
not
ere
this
defeated
and
captured
,
many
days
will
not
elapse
before
they
will
be
lodged
in
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
this
is
the
case
,
you
require
no
information
from
me
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
pray
you
name
them
to
me
.
<EOS>
""I
will
do
so
,
"
replied
Salisbury
;
"
and
if
I
have
omitted
you
can
supply
the
deficiency
.
<EOS>
I
will
begin
with
Robert
Catesby
,
the
chief
contriver
of
this
hell
-
engendered
plot,—I
<EOS>
will
next
proceed
to
the
superior
of
the
Jesuits
,
Father
Garnet,—next
,
to
another
Jesuit
priest
,
Father
Oldcorne,—next
,
to
Sir
Everard
Digby,—then
,
to
Thomas
Winter
and
Robert
Winter,—then
,
to
John
Wright
and
Christopher
<EOS>
Wright,—then
,
to
Ambrose
Rookwood
,
Thomas
Percy
,
and
John
Grant
,
and
lastly
,
to
Robert
Keyes
.
<EOS>
""Are
<EOS>
these
all
?
"
demanded
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
we
are
acquainted
with
,
"
said
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
"Then
add
to
them
the
names
of
Francis
Tresham
,
and
of
his
brother
-
in
-
law
,
Lord
Mounteagle
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
charge
both
with
being
privy
to
the
plot
.
<EOS>
""I
have
forgotten
another
name
,
"
said
Salisbury
,
in
some
confusion
,
"
that
of
Viviana
Radcliffe
,
of
Ordsall
Hall
.
<EOS>
I
have
received
certain
information
that
she
was
wedded
to
you
while
you
were
resident
at
White
Webbs
,
near
Epping
Forest
,
and
was
cognisant
of
the
plot
.
<EOS>
If
captured
,
she
will
share
your
fate
.
<EOS>
"Fawkes
<EOS>
could
not
repress
a
groan
.
<EOS>
Salisbury
pursued
his
interrogations
,
but
it
was
evident
,
from
the
increasing
feebleness
of
the
prisoner
,
that
he
would
sink
under
it
if
the
examination
was
further
protracted
.
<EOS>
He
was
therefore
ordered
to
attach
his
signature
to
the
minutes
taken
by
Sir
Edward
Coke
,
and
was
placed
in
a
chair
for
that
purpose
.
<EOS>
A
pen
was
then
given
him
,
but
for
some
time
his
shattered
fingers
refused
to
grasp
it
.
<EOS>
By
a
great
effort
,
and
with
acute
pain
,
he
succeeded
in
tracing
his
Christian
name
thus:—IllustrationWhile
endeavouring
to
write
his
surname
,
the
pen
fell
from
his
hand
,
and
he
became
insensible
.
<EOS>
II
.
<EOS>
—
SHOWING
THE
TROUBLES
OF
VIVIANAOn
coming
to
herself
,
Viviana
inquired
for
Garnet
;
and
being
told
that
he
was
in
his
chamber
alone
,
she
repaired
thither
,
and
found
him
pacing
to
and
fro
in
the
greatest
perturbation
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
you
come
to
me
for
consolation
,
daughter
,
"
he
said
,
"
you
come
to
one
who
can
not
offer
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
completely
prostrated
in
spirit
by
the
disastrous
issue
of
our
enterprise
;
and
though
I
tried
to
prepare
myself
for
what
has
taken
place
,
I
now
find
myself
utterly
unable
to
cope
with
it
.
<EOS>
"Illustration"If
<EOS>
such
is
your
condition
,
father
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
"
what
must
be
that
of
my
husband
,
upon
whose
devoted
head
all
the
weight
of
this
dreadful
calamity
now
falls
?
<EOS>
You
are
still
at
liberty
—
still
able
to
save
yourself
—
still
able
,
at
least
,
to
resist
unto
the
death
,
if
you
are
so
minded
.
<EOS>
But
he
is
a
captive
in
the
Tower
,
exposed
to
every
torment
that
human
ingenuity
can
invent
,
and
with
nothing
but
the
prospect
of
a
lingering
death
before
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
What
is
your
condition
,
compared
with
his?""Happy
—
most
happy
,
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
"
and
I
have
been
selfish
and
unreasonable
.
<EOS>
I
have
,
given
way
to
the
weakness
of
humanity
,
and
I
thank
you
from
the
bottom
of
my
heart
for
enabling
me
to
shake
it
off
.
<EOS>
""You
have
indulged
false
hopes
,
father
,
"
said
Viviana
,
"
whereas
I
have
indulged
none
,
or
rather
,
all
has
come
to
pass
as
I
desired
.
<EOS>
The
dreadful
crime
with
which
I
feared
my
husband
's
soul
would
have
been
loaded
is
now
uncommitted
,
and
I
have
firm
hope
of
his
salvation
.
<EOS>
If
I
might
counsel
you
,
I
would
advise
you
to
surrender
yourself
to
justice
,
and
by
pouring
out
your
blood
on
the
scaffold
,
wash
out
your
offence
.
<EOS>
Such
will
be
my
own
course
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
involuntarily
led
into
connexion
with
this
plot
;
and
though
I
have
ever
disapproved
of
it
,
since
I
have
not
revealed
it
I
am
as
guilty
as
if
I
had
been
its
contriver
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
shun
my
punishment
.
<EOS>
Fate
has
dealt
hardly
with
me
,
and
my
path
on
earth
has
been
strewn
with
thorns
,
and
cast
in
grief
and
trouble
.
<EOS>
But
I
humbly
trust
that
my
portion
hereafter
will
be
with
the
blessed
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
doubt
it
,
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
;
"
and
though
I
do
not
view
our
design
in
the
light
that
you
do
,
but
regard
it
as
justifiable
,
if
not
necessary
,
yet
,
with
your
feelings
,
I
can
not
sufficiently
admire
your
conduct
.
<EOS>
Your
devotion
and
self
-
sacrifice
is
wholly
without
parallel
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
I
would
try
to
dissuade
you
from
surrendering
yourself
to
our
relentless
enemies
.
<EOS>
Believe
me
,
it
will
add
the
severest
pang
to
your
husband
's
torture
to
know
that
you
are
in
their
power
.
<EOS>
His
nature
is
stern
and
unyielding
,
and
,
persuaded
as
he
is
of
the
justice
of
his
cause
,
he
will
die
happy
in
that
conviction
,
certain
that
his
name
,
though
despised
by
our
heretical
persecutors
,
will
be
held
in
reverence
by
all
true
professors
of
our
faith
.
<EOS>
No
,
daughter
,
fly
and
conceal
yourself
till
pursuit
is
relinquished
,
and
pass
the
rest
of
your
life
in
prayer
for
the
repose
of
your
husband
's
soul
.
<EOS>
""I
will
pass
it
in
endeavouring
to
bring
him
to
repentance
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
sole
boon
I
shall
seek
from
my
judges
will
be
permission
to
attempt
this
.
<EOS>
""It
will
be
refused
,
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
"
and
you
will
only
destroy
yourself
,
not
aid
him
.
<EOS>
Rest
satisfied
that
the
Great
Power
who
judges
the
hearts
of
men
,
and
implants
certain
impulses
within
them
,
for
his
own
wise
but
inscrutable
purposes
,
well
knows
that
Guy
Fawkes
,
however
culpable
his
conduct
may
appear
in
your
eyes
,
<EOS>
acted
according
to
the
dictates
of
his
conscience
,
and
in
the
full
confidence
that
the
design
would
restore
the
true
worship
of
God
in
this
kingdom
.
<EOS>
The
failure
of
the
enterprise
proves
that
he
was
mistaken
—
that
we
were
all
mistaken,—and
that
Heaven
was
unfavourable
to
the
means
<EOS>
adopted,—but
<EOS>
it
does
not
prove
his
insincerity
.
<EOS>
""These
arguments
have
no
weight
with
me
,
father
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
I
will
leave
nothing
undone
to
save
his
soul
,
and
whatever
may
be
the
result
,
I
will
surrender
myself
to
justice
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
shall
not
seek
to
move
you
from
your
purpose
,
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
"
and
can
only
lament
it
.
<EOS>
Before
,
however
,
you
finally
decide
,
let
us
pray
together
for
directions
from
on
high
.
<EOS>
"Thus
<EOS>
exhorted
,
Viviana
knelt
down
with
the
priest
before
a
small
silver
image
of
the
Virgin
,
which
stood
in
a
niche
in
the
wall
,
and
they
both
prayed
long
and
earnestly
.
<EOS>
Garnet
was
the
first
to
conclude
his
devotions
;
and
as
he
gazed
at
the
upturned
countenance
and
streaming
eyes
of
his
companion
,
his
heart
was
filled
with
admiration
and
pity
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
the
door
opened
,
and
Catesby
and
Sir
Everard
Digby
entered
.
<EOS>
On
hearing
them
,
Viviana
immediately
arose
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
urgency
of
our
business
must
plead
an
excuse
for
the
interruption
,
if
any
is
needed
,
"
said
Catesby
;
"
but
do
not
retire
,
madam
.
<EOS>
We
have
no
secrets
from
you
now
.
<EOS>
Sir
Everard
and
I
have
fully
completed
our
preparations
,
"
he
added
,
to
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
Our
men
are
all
armed
and
mounted
in
the
court
,
and
are
in
high
spirits
for
the
enterprise
.
<EOS>
As
the
service
,
however
,
will
be
one
of
the
greatest
danger
and
difficulty
,
you
had
better
seek
a
safe
asylum
,
father
,
till
the
first
decisive
blow
is
struck
.
<EOS>
""I
would
go
with
you
,
my
son
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
,
"
if
I
did
not
think
my
presence
might
be
an
hinderance
.
<EOS>
I
can
only
aid
you
with
my
prayers
,
and
those
can
be
more
efficaciously
uttered
in
some
secure
retreat
,
than
during
a
rapid
march
or
dangerous
encounter
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
had
better
retire
to
Coughton
with
Lady
Digby
and
Viviana
,
"
said
Sir
Everard
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
provided
a
sufficient
escort
to
guard
you
thither,—and
,
as
you
are
aware
,
there
are
many
hiding
-
places
in
the
house
,
where
you
can
remain
undiscovered
in
case
of
search
.
<EOS>
""I
place
myself
at
your
disposal
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
"
<EOS>
But
Viviana
is
resolved
to
surrender
herself
.
<EOS>
""This
must
not
be
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
Such
an
act
at
this
juncture
would
be
madness
,
and
would
materially
injure
our
cause
.
<EOS>
Whatever
your
inclinations
may
prompt
,
you
must
consent
to
remain
in
safety
,
madam
.
<EOS>
""I
have
acquiesced
in
your
proceedings
thus
far
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
"
because
I
could
not
oppose
them
without
injury
to
those
dear
to
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
take
no
further
share
in
them
.
<EOS>
My
mind
is
made
up
as
to
the
course
I
shall
pursue
.
<EOS>
""Since
you
are
bent
upon
your
own
destruction,—for
<EOS>
it
is
nothing
less,—it
is
the
duty
of
your
friends
to
save
you
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
do
what
you
propose
,
and
when
you
are
yourself
again
,
and
have
recovered
from
the
shock
your
feelings
have
sustained
,
you
will
thank
me
for
my
interference
.
<EOS>
""You
are
right
,
Catesby
,
"
observed
Sir
Everard
;
"
it
would
be
worse
than
insanity
to
allow
her
to
destroy
herself
thus
.
<EOS>
""I
am
glad
you
are
of
this
opinion
,
"
said
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
I
tried
to
reason
her
out
of
her
design
,
but
without
avail
.
<EOS>
""Catesby
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
throwing
herself
at
his
feet
,
"
by
the
love
you
once
professed
for
me,—by
the
friendship
you
entertained
for
him
who
unhesitatingly
offered
himself
for
you
,
and
your
cause
,
I
implore
you
not
to
oppose
me
now!""I
shall
best
serve
you
,
and
most
act
in
accordance
with
the
wishes
of
my
friend
,
by
doing
so
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Therefore
,
you
plead
in
vain
.
<EOS>
""Alas
!
"
cried
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
My
purposes
are
ever
thwarted
.
<EOS>
You
will
have
to
answer
for
my
life
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
should
,
indeed
,
have
it
to
answer
for
,
if
I
permitted
you
to
act
as
you
desire
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
repeat
you
will
thank
me
ere
many
days
are
passed
.
<EOS>
""Sir
Everard
,
"
exclaimed
Viviana
,
appealing
to
the
knight
,
"
I
entreat
you
to
have
pity
upon
me
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
do
sincerely
sympathise
with
your
distress
,
"
replied
Digby
,
in
a
tone
of
the
deepest
commiseration
;
"
but
I
am
sure
what
Catesby
advises
is
for
the
best
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
reconcile
it
to
my
conscience
to
allow
you
to
sacrifice
yourself
thus
.
<EOS>
Be
governed
by
prudence
.
<EOS>
""Oh
<EOS>
no
——
no
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
distractedly
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
be
stayed
.
<EOS>
I
command
you
not
to
detain
me
.
<EOS>
""Viviana
,
"
said
Catesby
,
taking
her
arm
,
"
this
is
no
season
for
the
display
of
silly
weakness
either
on
our
part
or
yours
.
<EOS>
If
you
can
not
control
yourself
,
you
must
be
controlled
.
<EOS>
Father
Garnet
,
I
intrust
her
to
your
care
.
<EOS>
Two
of
my
troop
shall
attend
you
,
together
with
your
own
servant
,
Nicholas
Owen
.
<EOS>
You
shall
have
stout
horses
,
able
to
accomplish
the
journey
with
the
greatest
expedition
,
and
I
should
wish
you
to
convey
her
to
her
own
mansion
,
Ordsall
Hall
,
and
to
remain
there
with
her
till
you
hear
tidings
of
us
.
<EOS>
""It
shall
be
as
you
direct
,
my
son
,
"
said
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
prepared
to
set
out
at
once
.
<EOS>
""That
is
well
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"You
will
not
do
me
this
violence
,
sir
,
"
cried
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
appeal
against
it
,
to
you
,
Sir
Everard
.
<EOS>
""I
can
not
help
you
,
madam
,
"
replied
the
knight
,
"
<EOS>
indeed
,
I
cannot
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
Heaven
,
I
trust
,
will
help
me
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
"
for
I
am
wholly
abandoned
of
man
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
beseech
you
,
madam
<EOS>
,
put
some
constraint
upon
yourself
,
"
said
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
If
,
after
your
arrival
at
Ordsall
,
you
are
still
bent
upon
your
rash
and
fatal
design
,
Father
Garnet
shall
not
oppose
its
execution
.
<EOS>
But
give
yourself
time
for
reflection
.
<EOS>
""Since
it
may
not
be
otherwise
,
I
assent
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
must
go
,
I
will
start
at
once
.
<EOS>
""Wisely
<EOS>
resolved
,
"
replied
Sir
Everard
.
<EOS>
Viviana
then
retired
,
and
soon
afterwards
appeared
equipped
for
her
journey
.
<EOS>
The
two
attendants
and
Nicholas
Owen
were
in
the
court
-
yard
,
and
Catesby
assisted
her
into
the
saddle
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
not
lose
sight
of
her
,
"
he
said
to
Garnet
,
as
the
latter
mounted
.
<EOS>
"Rest
<EOS>
assured
I
will
not
,
"
replied
the
other
.
<EOS>
And
taking
the
direction
of
Coventry
,
the
party
rode
off
at
a
brisk
pace
.
<EOS>
Catesby
then
joined
the
other
conspirators
,
while
Sir
Everard
sent
off
Lady
Digby
and
his
household
,
attended
by
a
strong
escort
,
to
Coughton
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
the
whole
party
repaired
to
the
court
-
yard
,
where
they
called
over
the
muster
-
roll
of
their
men
,
to
ascertain
that
none
were
missing,—examined
their
arms
and
ammunition,—and
finding
all
in
order
,
sprang
to
their
steeds
,
and
putting
themselves
at
the
head
of
the
band
,
rode
towards
Southam
and
Warwick
.
<EOS>
III
.
—
<EOS>
HUDDINGTONAbout
six
o'clock
in
the
morning
<EOS>
the
conspirators
reached
Leamington
Priors
,
at
that
time
an
inconsiderable
village
;
and
having
ridden
nearly
twenty
miles
over
heavy
and
miry
roads,—for
a
good
deal
of
rain
had
fallen
in
the
night,—they
<EOS>
stood
in
need
of
some
refreshment
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
they
entered
the
first
farm
-
yard
they
came
to
,
and
proceeding
to
the
cow
-
houses
and
sheepfolds
,
turned
out
the
animals
within
them
,
and
fastening
up
their
own
steeds
in
their
places
,
set
before
them
whatever
provender
they
could
find
.
<EOS>
Those
,
and
they
were
by
far
the
greater
number
,
who
could
not
find
better
accommodation
,
fed
their
horses
in
the
yard
,
which
was
strewn
with
trusses
of
hay
and
great
heaps
of
corn
.
<EOS>
The
whole
scene
formed
a
curious
picture
.
<EOS>
Here
was
one
party
driving
away
the
sheep
and
cattle
,
which
were
bleating
and
<EOS>
lowing,—there
,
another
rifling
a
hen
-
roost
,
and
slaughtering
its
cackling
inmates
.
<EOS>
On
this
hand
,
by
the
direction
of
Catesby
,
two
stout
horses
were
being
harnessed
with
ropes
to
a
cart
,
which
he
intended
to
use
as
a
baggage
-
waggon
;
on
that
,
Sir
Everard
Digby
was
interposing
his
authority
to
prevent
the
destruction
of
a
fine
porker
.
<EOS>
Their
horses
fed
,
the
next
care
of
the
conspirators
was
to
obtain
something
for
themselves
:
and
ordering
the
master
of
the
house
,
who
was
terrified
almost
out
of
his
senses
,
to
open
his
doors
,
they
entered
the
dwelling
,
and
causing
a
fire
to
be
lighted
in
the
chief
room
,
began
to
boil
a
large
kettle
of
broth
upon
it
,
and
to
cook
other
provisions
.
<EOS>
Finding
a
good
store
of
eatables
in
the
larder
,
rations
were
served
out
to
the
band
.
<EOS>
Two
casks
of
strong
ale
were
likewise
broached
,
and
their
contents
distributed
;
and
a
small
keg
of
strong
waters
being
also
discovered
,
it
was
disposed
of
in
the
same
way
.
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
was
the
extent
of
the
mischief
done
.
<EOS>
All
the
conspirators
,
but
chiefly
Catesby
and
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
dispersed
themselves
amongst
the
band
,
and
checked
any
disposition
to
plunder
.
<EOS>
The
only
articles
taken
away
from
the
house
were
a
couple
of
old
rusty
swords
and
a
caliver
.
<EOS>
Catesby
proposed
to
the
farmer
to
join
their
expedition
.
<EOS>
But
having
now
regained
his
courage
,
the
sturdy
churl
obstinately
refused
to
stir
a
foot
with
them
,
and
even
ventured
to
utter
a
wish
that
the
enterprise
might
fail
.
<EOS>
"I
am
a
good
Protestant
,
and
a
faithful
subject
of
King
James
,
and
will
never
abet
Popery
and
treason
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
This
bold
sally
would
have
been
answered
by
a
bullet
from
one
of
the
troopers
,
if
Catesby
had
not
interfered
.
<EOS>
"You
shall
do
as
you
please
,
friend
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
conciliatory
tone
.
<EOS>
"
We
will
not
compel
any
man
to
act
against
his
conscience
,
and
we
claim
the
same
right
ourselves
.
<EOS>
Will
you
join
us
,
good
fellows
?
<EOS>
"
he
added
,
to
two
farming
men
,
who
were
standing
near
their
master
.
<EOS>
"Must
<EOS>
I
confess
to
a
priest
?
"
asked
one
of
them
.
<EOS>
"Certainly
<EOS>
not
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
no
constraint
whatever
put
upon
you
.
<EOS>
All
I
require
is
obedience
to
my
commands
in
the
field
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
I
am
with
you
,
"
replied
the
fellow
.
<EOS>
"Thou'rt
<EOS>
a
traitor
and
rebel
,
Sam
Morrell
,
"
cried
the
other
hind
,
"
and
wilt
come
to
a
traitor
's
end
.
<EOS>
I
will
never
fight
against
King
James
.
<EOS>
And
if
I
must
take
up
arms
,
it
shall
be
against
his
enemies
,
and
in
defence
of
our
religion
.
<EOS>
No
priests,—no
papistry
for
me
.
<EOS>
""Well
said
,
Hugh
,
"
cried
his
master
;
"
we
'll
die
in
that
cause
,
if
need
be
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
turned
angrily
away
,
and
giving
the
word
to
his
men
to
prepare
to
set
forth
,
in
a
few
minutes
all
were
in
the
saddle
;
but
on
inquiring
for
the
new
recruit
,
Sam
Morrell
,
it
was
found
he
had
disappeared
.
<EOS>
The
cart
was
laden
with
arms
,
ammunition
and
a
few
sacks
of
corn
;
and
the
line
being
formed
,
they
commenced
their
march
.
<EOS>
The
morning
was
dark
and
misty
,
and
all
looked
dull
and
dispiriting
.
<EOS>
The
conspirators
,
however
,
were
full
of
confidence
,
and
their
men
,
exhilarated
and
refreshed
by
their
meal
,
appeared
anxious
for
an
opportunity
of
distinguishing
themselves
.
<EOS>
Arrived
within
half
a
mile
of
Warwick
,
whence
the
lofty
spire
of
the
church
of
Saint
Nicholas
,
the
tower
of
Saint
Mary
's
,
and
the
ancient
gates
of
this
beautiful
old
town
could
just
be
discerned
through
the
mist
,
a
short
consultation
was
held
by
the
rebel
leaders
as
to
the
expediency
of
attacking
the
castle
,
and
carrying
off
the
horses
with
which
they
had
learnt
its
stables
were
filled
.
<EOS>
Deciding
upon
making
the
attempt
,
their
resolution
was
communicated
to
their
followers
,
and
received
with
loud
acclamations
.
<EOS>
Catesby
then
put
himself
at
the
head
of
the
band
,
and
they
all
rode
forward
at
a
brisk
pace
.
<EOS>
Crossing
the
bridge
over
the
Avon
,
whence
the
castle
burst
upon
them
in
all
its
grandeur
and
beauty
,
Catesby
dashed
forward
to
an
embattled
gate
commanding
the
approach
to
the
structure
,
and
knocking
furiously
against
it
,
a
wicket
was
opened
by
an
old
porter
,
who
started
back
on
beholding
the
intruders
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
closed
the
wicket
,
but
Catesby
was
too
quick
for
him
,
and
springing
from
his
steed
,
dashed
aside
the
feeble
opposition
of
the
old
man
,
and
unbarred
the
gate
.
<EOS>
Instantly
mounting
again
,
he
galloped
along
<EOS>
a
broad
and
winding
path
cut
so
deeply
in
the
rock
,
that
the
mighty
pile
they
were
approaching
was
completely
hidden
from
view
.
<EOS>
A
few
seconds
,
however
,
brought
them
to
a
point
,
from
which
its
three
towers
reared
themselves
full
before
them
.
<EOS>
Another
moment
brought
them
to
the
edge
of
the
moat
,
at
this
time
crossed
by
a
stone
bridge
,
but
then
filled
with
water
,
and
defended
by
a
drawbridge
.
<EOS>
As
no
attack
like
the
present
was
apprehended
,
and
as
the
owner
of
the
castle
,
the
celebrated
Fulke
Greville
,
afterwards
Lord
Brooke
,
to
whom
it
had
been
recently
granted
by
the
reigning
monarch
,
was
then
in
the
capital
,
the
drawbridge
was
down
,
and
though
several
retainers
rushed
forth
on
hearing
the
approach
of
so
many
horsemen
,
they
were
too
late
to
raise
it
.
<EOS>
Threatening
these
persons
with
destruction
if
any
resistance
was
offered
,
Catesby
passed
through
the
great
entrance
,
and
rode
into
the
court
,
where
he
drew
up
his
band
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
whole
of
the
inmates
of
the
castle
had
collected
on
the
ramparts
,
armed
with
calivers
and
partisans
,
and
whatever
weapons
they
could
find
,
and
though
their
force
was
utterly
disproportioned
to
that
of
their
opponents
,
they
seemed
disposed
to
give
them
battle
.
<EOS>
Paying
no
attention
to
them
,
Catesby
proceeded
to
the
stables
,
where
he
found
upwards
of
twenty
horses
,
which
he
exchanged
for
the
worst
and
most
jaded
of
his
own
,
and
was
about
to
enter
the
castle
in
search
of
arms
,
when
he
was
startled
by
hearing
the
alarm
-
bell
rung
.
<EOS>
This
was
succeeded
by
the
discharge
of
a
culverin
on
the
summit
of
the
tower
,
named
after
the
redoubted
Guy
,
Earl
of
Warwick
;
and
though
the
bell
was
instantly
silenced
,
Rookwood
,
who
had
dislodged
the
party
from
the
ramparts
,
brought
word
that
the
inhabitants
of
Warwick
were
assembling
,
that
drums
were
beating
at
the
gates
,
and
that
an
attack
might
be
speedily
expected
.
<EOS>
Not
desiring
to
hazard
an
engagement
at
this
juncture
,
Catesby
gave
up
the
idea
of
ransacking
the
castle
,
and
ordered
his
men
to
their
horses
.
<EOS>
Some
delay
,
however
,
occurred
before
they
could
all
be
got
together
,
and
,
meanwhile
,
the
ringing
of
bells
and
other
alarming
sounds
continued
.
<EOS>
At
one
time
,
it
occurred
to
Catesby
to
attempt
to
maintain
possession
of
the
castle
;
but
this
design
was
overruled
by
the
other
conspirators
,
who
represented
to
him
the
impracticability
of
the
design
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
the
whole
troop
being
assembled
,
they
crossed
the
drawbridge
,
and
speeded
along
the
rocky
path
.
<EOS>
Before
the
outer
gate
they
found
a
large
body
of
men
,
some
on
horseback
,
and
some
on
foot
,
drawn
up
.
<EOS>
These
persons
,
however
,
struck
with
terror
at
their
appearance
,
retreated
,
and
allowed
them
a
free
passage
.
<EOS>
On
turning
to
cross
the
bridge
,
they
found
it
occupied
by
a
strong
and
well
-
armed
body
of
men
,
headed
by
the
Sheriff
of
Warwickshire
,
who
showed
no
disposition
to
give
way
.
<EOS>
While
the
rebel
party
were
preparing
to
force
a
passage
,
a
trumpet
was
sounded
,
and
the
Sheriff
,
riding
towards
them
,
commanded
them
in
the
King
's
name
to
yield
themselves
prisoners
.
<EOS>
"We
do
not
acknowledge
the
supremacy
of
James
Stuart
,
whom
you
call
king
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
We
fight
for
our
liberties
,
and
for
the
restoration
of
the
holy
Catholic
religion
which
we
profess
.
<EOS>
Do
not
oppose
us
,
or
you
will
have
cause
to
rue
your
temerity
.
<EOS>
""Hear
me
<EOS>
,
"
cried
the
Sheriff
,
turning
from
him
to
his
men
:
"
<EOS>
I
promise
you
all
a
free
pardon
in
the
King
's
name
,
if
you
will
throw
down
your
arms
,
and
deliver
up
your
leaders
.
<EOS>
But
,
if
after
this
warning
,
you
continue
in
open
rebellion
against
your
sovereign
,
you
will
all
suffer
the
vilest
death
.
<EOS>
""Rejoin
<EOS>
your
men
,
sir
,
"
said
Catesby
,
in
a
significant
tone
,
and
drawing
a
petronel
.
<EOS>
"A
free
pardon
and
a
hundred
pounds
to
him
who
will
bring
me
the
head
of
Robert
Catesby
,
"
said
the
Sheriff
,
disregarding
the
menace
.
<EOS>
"Your
own
is
not
worth
half
the
sum
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
;
and
levelling
the
petronel
,
he
shot
him
dead
.
<EOS>
The
Sheriff
's
fall
was
the
signal
for
a
general
engagement
.
<EOS>
Exasperated
by
the
death
of
their
leader
,
the
royalist
party
assailed
the
rebels
with
the
greatest
fury
,
and
as
the
latter
were
attacked
at
the
same
time
in
the
rear
,
their
situation
began
to
appear
perilous
.
<EOS>
But
nothing
could
withstand
the
vigour
and
determination
of
Catesby
.
<EOS>
Cheering
on
his
men
,
he
soon
cut
a
way
across
the
bridge
,
and
would
have
made
good
his
retreat
,
if
he
had
not
perceived
,
to
his
infinite
dismay
,
that
Percy
and
Rookwood
had
been
captured
.
<EOS>
Regardless
of
any
risk
he
might
run
,
he
shouted
to
those
near
to
follow
him
,
and
made
such
a
desperate
charge
upon
the
royalists
that
in
a
few
minutes
he
was
by
the
side
of
his
friends
,
and
had
liberated
them
.
<EOS>
In
trying
,
however
,
to
follow
up
his
advantage
he
got
separated
from
his
companions
,
and
was
so
hotly
pressed
on
all
sides
,
that
his
destruction
seemed
inevitable
.
<EOS>
His
petronels
had
both
brought
down
their
mark
;
and
in
striking
a
blow
against
a
stalwart
trooper
his
sword
had
shivered
close
to
the
handle
.
<EOS>
In
this
defenceless
state
his
enemies
made
sure
of
him
,
but
they
miscalculated
his
resources
.
<EOS>
He
was
then
close
to
the
side
of
the
bridge
,
and
,
before
his
purpose
could
be
divined
,
struck
spurs
deeply
into
his
horse
,
and
cleared
the
parapet
with
a
single
bound
.
<EOS>
A
shout
of
astonishment
and
admiration
arose
alike
from
friend
and
foe
,
and
there
was
a
general
rush
towards
the
side
of
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
The
noble
animal
that
had
borne
him
out
of
danger
was
seen
swimming
towards
the
bank
,
and
,
though
several
shots
were
fired
at
him
,
he
reached
it
in
safety
.
<EOS>
This
gallant
action
so
raised
Catesby
in
the
estimation
of
his
followers
,
that
they
welcomed
him
with
the
utmost
enthusiasm
,
and
rallying
round
him
,
fought
with
such
vigour
,
that
they
drove
their
opponents
over
the
bridge
and
compelled
them
to
flee
towards
the
town
.
<EOS>
Catesby
now
mustered
his
men
,
and
finding
his
loss
slighter
than
he
expected
,
though
several
were
so
severely
wounded
,
that
he
was
compelled
to
leave
them
behind
,
rode
off
at
a
quick
pace
.
<EOS>
After
proceeding
for
about
four
miles
along
the
Stratford
road
,
they
turned
off
on
the
right
into
a
narrow
lane
leading
to
Snitterfield
,
with
the
intention
of
visiting
Norbrook
,
the
family
residence
of
John
Grant
.
<EOS>
On
arriving
there
,
they
put
the
house
into
a
state
of
defence
,
and
then
assembled
in
the
hall
,
while
their
followers
recruited
themselves
in
the
court
-
yard
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
far
,
well
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
flinging
himself
into
a
chair
;
"
the
first
battle
has
been
won
.
<EOS>
""True
,
"
replied
Grant
;
"
but
it
will
not
do
to
tarry
here
long
.
<EOS>
This
house
can
not
hold
out
against
a
prolonged
attack
.
<EOS>
""We
will
not
remain
here
more
than
a
couple
of
hours
,
"
replied
Catesby
:
"
but
where
shall
we
go
next
?
<EOS>
I
am
for
making
some
desperate
attempt
,
which
shall
strike
terror
into
our
foes
.
<EOS>
""Are
<EOS>
we
strong
enough
to
march
to
the
Earl
of
Harrington
's
mansion
near
Coventry
,
and
carry
off
the
Princess
Elizabeth
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Percy
.
<EOS>
"She
were
indeed
a
glorious
prize
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
"
but
I
have
no
doubt
,
on
the
first
alarm
of
our
rising
,
she
has
been
conveyed
to
a
place
of
safety
.
<EOS>
And
even
if
she
were
there
,
we
should
have
the
whole
armed
force
of
Coventry
to
contend
with
.
<EOS>
No
—
<EOS>
no
,
it
will
not
do
to
attempt
that
.
<EOS>
""Nothing
venture
,
nothing
have
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Sir
Everard
Digby
.
<EOS>
"
We
ought
,
in
my
opinion
,
to
run
any
risk
to
secure
her
.
""You
know
me
too
well
,
Digby
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
"
to
doubt
my
readiness
to
undertake
any
project
,
however
hazardous
,
which
would
offer
the
remotest
chance
of
success
.
<EOS>
But
in
this
I
see
none
,
unless
,
indeed
,
it
could
be
accomplished
by
stratagem
.
<EOS>
Let
us
first
ascertain
what
support
we
can
obtain
,
and
then
decide
upon
the
measures
to
be
adopted
.
<EOS>
""I
am
content
,
"
returned
Digby
.
<EOS>
"Old
<EOS>
Mr.
Talbot
of
Grafton
is
a
friend
of
yours
,
is
he
not
?
"
<EOS>
continued
Catesby
,
addressing
Thomas
Winter
.
<EOS>
"
Can
you
induce
him
to
join
us?""I
will
try
,
"
replied
Thomas
Winter
;
"
but
I
have
some
misgivings
.
<EOS>
""Be
not
faint
-
hearted
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You
and
Stephen
Littleton
shall
go
to
him
at
once
,
and
join
us
at
your
own
mansion
of
Huddington
,
whither
we
will
proceed
as
soon
as
our
men
are
thoroughly
recruited
.
<EOS>
Use
every
argument
you
can
devise
with
Talbot,—tell
him
that
the
welfare
of
the
Catholic
cause
depends
on
our
success,—and
that
neither
his
years
nor
infirmities
can
excuse
his
absence
at
this
juncture
.
<EOS>
If
he
will
not
,
or
can
not
come
himself
,
cause
him
to
write
letters
to
all
his
Catholic
neighbours
,
urging
them
to
join
us
,
and
bid
him
send
all
his
retainers
and
servants
to
us
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
neglect
a
single
plea
,
"
replied
Thomas
Winter
,
"
and
I
will
further
urge
compliance
by
his
long
friendship
towards
myself
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
have
just
said
,
I
despair
of
success
.
<EOS>
"Soon
<EOS>
after
this
,
he
and
Stephen
Littleton
,
with
two
of
the
troopers
well
-
mounted
and
well
-
armed
,
rode
across
the
country
through
lanes
and
by
-
roads
,
with
which
they
were
well
acquainted
,
to
Grafton
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
Catesby
repaired
to
the
court
-
yard
,
and
assembling
his
men
,
found
there
were
twenty
-
five
missing
.
<EOS>
More
than
half
of
these
it
was
known
had
been
killed
or
wounded
at
Warwick
;
but
the
rest
,
it
was
suspected
,
had
deserted
.
<EOS>
Whatever
effect
this
scrutiny
might
secretly
have
upon
Catesby
,
he
maintained
a
cheerful
and
confident
demeanour
,
and
mounting
a
flight
of
steps
,
harangued
the
band
in
energetic
and
exciting
terms
.
<EOS>
Displaying
a
small
image
of
the
virgin
to
them
,
he
assured
them
they
were
under
the
special
protection
of
heaven
,
whose
cause
they
were
fighting
—
and
concluded
by
reciting
a
prayer
,
in
which
the
whole
assemblage
heartily
joined
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
they
filled
the
baggage
-
cart
with
provisions
and
further
ammunition
,
and
forming
themselves
into
good
order
,
took
the
road
to
Alcester
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
gone
far
,
when
torrents
of
rain
fell
,
and
the
roads
being
in
a
shocking
condition
,
and
ploughed
up
with
ruts
,
they
turned
into
the
fields
wherever
it
was
practicable
,
and
continued
their
march
very
slowly
,
and
under
excessively
disheartening
circumstances
.
<EOS>
On
arriving
at
the
ford
across
the
Avon
,
near
Bishopston
,
they
found
the
stream
so
swollen
that
it
was
impossible
to
get
across
it
.
<EOS>
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
who
made
the
attempt
,
was
nearly
carried
off
by
the
current
.
<EOS>
They
were
therefore
compelled
to
proceed
to
Stratford
,
and
cross
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
"My
friends
,
"
said
Catesby
,
commanding
a
halt
at
a
short
distance
of
the
town
,
"
I
know
not
what
reception
we
may
meet
with
here
.
<EOS>
Probably
much
the
same
as
at
Warwick
.
<EOS>
But
I
command
you
not
to
strike
a
blow
,
except
in
self
-
defence
.
<EOS>
"Those
<EOS>
injunctions
given
,
attended
by
the
other
conspirators
,
except
Percy
and
Rookwood
,
who
brought
up
the
rear
,
he
rode
slowly
into
Stratford
,
and
proceeding
to
the
market
-
place
,
ordered
a
trumpet
to
be
sounded
.
<EOS>
On
the
first
appearance
of
the
troop
,
most
of
the
inhabitants
fled
to
their
houses
,
and
fastened
the
doors
,
but
some
few
courageous
persons
followed
them
at
a
wary
distance
.
<EOS>
These
were
harangued
at
some
length
by
Catesby
,
who
called
upon
them
to
join
the
expedition
,
and
held
out
promises
,
which
only
excited
the
derision
of
the
hearers
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
dejected
looks
of
most
of
the
band
,
and
the
drenched
and
muddy
state
of
their
apparel
,
made
them
objects
of
pity
and
contempt
,
rather
than
of
serious
apprehension
:
and
nothing
but
their
numbers
prevented
an
attack
being
made
upon
them
.
<EOS>
Catesby
's
address
concluded
amid
groans
of
dissatisfaction
;
and
finding
he
was
wasting
time
,
and
injuring
his
own
cause
,
he
gave
the
word
to
march
,
and
moved
slowly
through
the
main
street
,
but
not
a
single
recruit
joined
him
.
<EOS>
Another
unpropitious
circumstance
occurred
just
as
they
were
leaving
Stratford
.
<EOS>
Two
or
three
of
his
followers
tried
to
slink
away
,
when
Catesby
,
riding
after
them
,
called
to
them
to
return
,
and
no
attention
being
paid
to
his
orders
,
he
shot
the
man
nearest
him
,
and
compelled
the
others
,
by
threats
of
the
same
punishment
,
to
return
to
their
ranks
.
<EOS>
This
occurrence
,
while
it
occasioned
much
discontent
and
ill
-
will
among
the
band
,
gave
great
uneasiness
to
their
leaders
.
<EOS>
Catesby
and
Percy
now
brought
up
the
rear
,
and
kept
a
sharp
look
-
out
to
check
any
further
attempt
at
desertion
.
<EOS>
Digby
and
Winter
,
being
well
acquainted
with
all
the
Catholic
gentry
in
the
neighbourhood
<EOS>
,
they
proceeded
to
their
different
residences
,
and
were
uniformly
coldly
received
,
and
in
some
cases
dismissed
with
reproaches
and
menaces
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
all
their
efforts
,
too
,
repeated
desertions
took
place
;
and
long
before
they
reached
Alcester
,
their
force
was
diminished
by
a
dozen
men
.
<EOS>
Not
thinking
it
prudent
to
pass
through
the
town
,
they
struck
into
a
lane
on
the
right
,
and
fording
the
Arrow
near
Ragley
,
skirted
that
extensive
park
,
and
crossing
the
hills
near
Weethly
and
Stoney
Moreton
,
arrived
in
about
an
hour
and
a
half
,
in
a
very
jaded
condition
,
at
Huddington
,
the
seat
of
Robert
Winter
.
<EOS>
Affairs
seemed
to
wear
so
unpromising
an
aspect
,
that
Catesby
,
on
entering
the
house
,
immediately
called
a
council
of
his
friends
,
and
asked
them
what
they
proposed
to
do
.
"For
<EOS>
my
own
part
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
am
resolved
to
fight
it
out
.
<EOS>
I
will
continue
my
march
as
long
as
I
can
get
a
man
to
follow
me
,
and
when
they
are
all
gone
,
will
proceed
alone
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
never
yield
.
<EOS>
""We
will
all
die
together
,
if
need
be
,
"
said
Sir
Everard
Digby
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
rest
here
to
-
night
,
and
in
the
morning
proceed
to
Lord
Windsor
's
mansion
,
Hewel
Grange
,
which
I
know
to
be
well
stocked
with
arms
,
and
,
after
carrying
off
all
we
can
,
we
will
fortify
Stephen
Littleton
's
house
at
Holbeach
,
and
maintain
it
for
a
few
days
against
our
enemies
.
<EOS>
"This
proposal
agreed
to
,
they
repaired
to
the
court
-
yard
,
and
busied
themselves
in
seeing
the
wants
of
their
followers
attended
to
;
and
such
a
change
was
effected
by
good
fare
and
a
few
hours
'
repose
,
that
the
spirits
of
the
whole
party
revived
,
and
confidence
was
once
more
restored
.
<EOS>
A
slight
damp
,
however
,
was
again
thrown
upon
the
satisfaction
of
the
leaders
,
by
the
return
of
Thomas
Winter
and
Stephen
Littleton
from
Grafton
.
<EOS>
Their
mission
had
proved
wholly
unsuccessful
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Talbot
had
not
merely
refused
to
join
them
,
but
had
threatened
to
detain
them
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
says
we
deserve
the
worst
of
deaths
,
"
observed
Thomas
Winter
,
in
conclusion
,
"
and
that
we
have
irretrievably
injured
the
Catholic
cause
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
I
begin
to
fear
he
speaks
the
truth
,
"
rejoined
Christopher
Wright
.
"
<EOS>
However
,
for
us
there
is
no
retreat
.
<EOS>
""None
<EOS>
whatever
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
in
a
sombre
tone
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
choose
between
death
upon
the
battle
-
field
or
on
the
scaffold
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
former
be
my
fate
,
"
cried
Percy
.
<EOS>
"And
mine
,
"
added
Catesby
.
<EOS>
An
anxious
and
perturbed
night
was
passed
by
the
conspirators
,
and
many
a
plan
was
proposed
and
abandoned
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
arranged
among
them
that
they
should
each
in
succession
make
the
rounds
of
the
place
,
to
see
that
the
sentinels
were
at
their
posts
—
<EOS>
strict
orders
having
been
given
to
the
latter
to
fire
upon
whomsoever
might
attempt
to
fly
—
but
,
as
Catesby
,
despite
his
great
previous
fatigue
,
was
unable
to
rest
,
he
took
this
duty
chiefly
upon
himself
.
<EOS>
Returning
at
midnight
from
an
examination
of
the
court
-
yard
,
he
was
about
to
enter
the
house
,
when
he
perceived
before
him
a
tall
figure
,
with
a
cloak
muffled
about
its
face
,
standing
in
his
path
.
<EOS>
It
was
perfectly
motionless
,
and
Catesby
,
who
carried
a
lantern
in
his
hand
,
threw
the
light
upon
it
,
but
it
neither
moved
forward
,
nor
altered
its
position
.
<EOS>
Catesby
would
have
challenged
it
,
but
an
undefinable
terror
seized
him
,
and
his
tongue
clove
to
the
roof
of
his
mouth
.
<EOS>
An
idea
rose
to
his
mind
that
it
was
the
spirit
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
and
,
by
a
powerful
effort
,
he
compelled
himself
to
address
it
.
<EOS>
"Are
<EOS>
you
come
to
warn
me
?
<EOS>
"
he
demanded
.
<EOS>
The
figure
moved
in
acquiescence
,
and
withdrawing
the
cloak
,
revealed
features
of
ghastly
paleness
,
but
resembling
those
of
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Have
I
long
to
live
?
"
demanded
Catesby
.
<EOS>
The
figure
shook
its
head
.
<EOS>
"Shall
<EOS>
I
fall
to
-
morrow
?
<EOS>
"
pursued
Catesby
.
<EOS>
The
figure
again
made
a
gesture
in
the
negative
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
next
day?"Solemnly
inclining
its
head
,
the
figure
once
more
muffled
its
ghastly
visage
in
its
cloak
,
and
melted
from
his
view
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
Catesby
remained
in
a
state
almost
of
stupefaction
.
<EOS>
He
then
summoned
up
all
the
resolution
of
his
nature
,
and
instead
of
returning
to
the
house
,
continued
to
pace
to
and
fro
in
the
court
,
and
at
last
walked
forth
into
the
garden
.
<EOS>
It
was
profoundly
dark
;
and
he
had
not
advanced
many
steps
when
he
suddenly
encountered
a
man
.
<EOS>
Repressing
the
exclamation
that
rose
to
his
lips
,
he
drew
a
petronel
from
his
belt
,
and
waited
till
the
person
addressed
him
.
<EOS>
"Is
<EOS>
it
<EOS>
you
,
Sir
John
Foliot
?
"
asked
a
voice
,
which
he
instantly
recognised
as
that
of
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"Ay
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
in
a
low
tone
.
<EOS>
"Did
<EOS>
you
manage
to
get
into
the
house
?
<EOS>
"
pursued
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"I
did
,
"
returned
Catesby
;
"
but
speak
lower
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
sentinel
within
a
few
paces
of
us
.
<EOS>
Come
this
way
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
grasping
the
other
's
arm
he
drew
him
further
down
the
walk
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
you
think
we
may
venture
to
surprise
them
?
"
demanded
Topcliffe
.
"Hum
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Catesby
,
hesitating
,
in
the
hope
of
inducing
the
other
to
betray
his
design
.
<EOS>
"Or
<EOS>
shall
we
wait
the
arrival
of
Sir
Richard
Walsh
,
the
Sheriff
of
Worcestershire
,
and
the
posse
comitatûs
?
"
<EOS>
pursued
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"How
<EOS>
soon
do
you
think
the
Sheriff
will
arrive
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Catesby
,
scarcely
able
to
disguise
his
anxiety
.
<EOS>
"He
can
not
be
here
before
daybreak
—
if
so
soon
,
"
returned
Topcliffe
,
"
and
then
we
shall
have
to
besiege
the
house
;
and
though
I
have
no
fear
of
the
result
,
yet
some
of
the
conspirators
may
fall
in
the
skirmish
;
and
my
orders
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
as
I
have
already
apprised
you
,
are
,
to
take
them
alive
.
<EOS>
""True
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
would
not
,
for
twice
the
reward
I
shall
receive
for
the
capture
of
the
whole
party
,
that
that
desperate
traitor
,
Catesby
,
should
be
slain
,
"
continued
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"
The
plot
was
contrived
by
him
,
and
the
extent
of
its
ramifications
can
alone
be
ascertained
through
him
.
<EOS>
""I
think
I
can
contrive
their
capture
,
"
observed
Catesby
;
"
but
the
utmost
caution
must
be
used
.
<EOS>
I
will
return
to
the
house
,
and
find
out
where
the
chief
conspirators
are
lodged
.
<EOS>
I
will
then
throw
open
the
door
,
and
will
return
to
this
place
,
where
you
can
have
our
men
assembled
.
<EOS>
If
we
can
seize
and
secure
the
leaders
,
the
rest
will
be
easy
.
<EOS>
""You
will
run
great
risk
,
Sir
John
,
"
said
Topcliffe
,
with
affected
concern
.
<EOS>
"Heed
not
that
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
expect
me
in
a
few
minutes
.
<EOS>
Get
together
your
men
as
noiselessly
as
you
can
.
<EOS>
"With
this
<EOS>
he
hastily
withdrew
.
<EOS>
On
returning
to
the
house
,
he
instantly
roused
his
companions
,
and
acquainted
them
with
what
had
occurred
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
object
,
"
he
said
,
"
is
to
make
Topcliffe
a
prisoner
.
<EOS>
We
may
obtain
much
useful
information
from
him
.
<EOS>
As
to
the
others
,
if
they
offer
resistance
,
we
will
put
them
to
death
.
<EOS>
""What
force
have
they
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
with
some
uneasiness
.
<EOS>
"It
is
impossible
to
say
precisely
,
"
replied
Catesby
;
"
but
not
more
than
a
handful
of
men
,
I
should
imagine
,
as
they
are
waiting
for
Sir
Richard
Walsh
.
<EOS>
""I
know
not
what
may
be
the
issue
of
this
matter
,
"
observed
Robert
Winter
,
whose
looks
were
unusually
haggard
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
have
had
a
strange
and
ominous
dream
,
which
fills
me
with
apprehension
.
<EOS>
""Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Catesby
,
upon
whose
mind
the
recollection
of
the
apparition
he
had
beheld
rushed
.
<EOS>
"Catesby
,
"
pursued
Robert
Winter
,
taking
him
aside
,
"
if
you
have
any
sin
unrepented
of
,
I
counsel
you
to
make
your
peace
with
Heaven
,
for
I
fear
you
are
not
long
for
this
world
.
<EOS>
""It
may
be
so
,
"
rejoined
Catesby
,
firmly
;
"
and
I
have
many
dark
and
damning
sins
upon
my
soul
,
but
I
will
die
as
I
have
lived
,
firm
and
unshaken
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
let
us
prepare
for
our
foes
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
proceeded
to
call
up
the
trustiest
of
his
men
,
and
enjoining
profound
silence
upon
them
,
disposed
them
in
various
places
,
that
they
might
instantly
appear
at
his
signal
.
<EOS>
After
giving
them
other
directions
,
he
returned
to
the
garden
,
and
coughed
slightly
.
<EOS>
He
was
answered
by
a
quickly
-
approaching
footstep
,
and
a
voice
demanded,"Are
<EOS>
you
there
<EOS>
,
Sir
John?"Catesby
answered
in
a
low
tone
in
the
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"Come
<EOS>
forward
,
then
,
"
rejoined
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
there
was
a
rush
of
persons
towards
the
spot
,
and
seizing
Catesby
,
he
cried
,
in
a
triumphant
tone
,
while
he
unmasked
a
lantern
,
and
threw
its
light
full
upon
his
face,"You
are
caught
in
your
own
trap
,
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
You
are
my
prisoner
.
<EOS>
""Not
<EOS>
so
,
villain
,
"
cried
Catesby
,
disengaging
himself
by
a
powerful
effort
.
<EOS>
Springing
backwards
,
he
drew
his
sword
,
and
making
the
blade
describe
a
circle
round
his
body
,
effected
his
retreat
in
safety
,
though
a
dozen
shots
were
fired
at
him
.
<EOS>
Leaping
the
garden
wall
,
he
was
instantly
surrounded
by
the
other
conspirators
,
and
the
greater
part
of
the
band
,
who
,
hearing
the
reports
of
the
fire
-
arms
,
had
hurried
to
the
spot
.
<EOS>
Instantly
putting
himself
at
their
head
,
Catesby
returned
to
the
garden
;
but
Topcliffe
and
his
party
had
taken
the
alarm
and
fled
.
<EOS>
Torches
were
brought
,
and
,
by
Catesby
's
directions
,
a
large
heap
of
dry
stubble
was
set
on
fire
.
<EOS>
But
,
though
the
flames
revealed
every
object
for
a
considerable
distance
around
them
,
no
traces
of
the
hostile
party
could
be
discerned
.
<EOS>
After
continuing
their
ineffectual
search
for
some
time
,
the
conspirators
returned
to
the
house
,
and
abandoning
all
idea
of
retiring
to
rest
,
kept
strict
watch
during
the
remainder
of
the
night
.
<EOS>
Little
conversation
took
place
.
<EOS>
All
were
deeply
depressed
;
and
Catesby
paced
backwards
and
forwards
within
a
passage
leading
from
the
hall
to
the
dining
-
chamber
.
<EOS>
His
thoughts
were
gloomy
enough
,
and
he
retraced
the
whole
of
his
wild
and
turbulent
career
,
pondering
upon
its
close
,
which
he
could
not
disguise
from
himself
was
at
hand
.
<EOS>
"It
<EOS>
matters
not
,
"
he
mentally
ejaculated
;
"
I
shall
not
die
ignominiously
,
and
I
would
rather
perish
in
the
vigour
of
manhood
than
linger
out
a
miserable
old
age
.
<EOS>
I
have
striven
hard
to
achieve
a
great
enterprise
,
and
having
failed
,
have
little
else
to
live
for
.
<EOS>
This
band
can
not
hold
together
two
days
longer
.
<EOS>
Our
men
will
desert
us
,
or
turn
upon
us
to
obtain
the
price
set
upon
our
heads
.
<EOS>
And
,
were
they
true
,
I
have
little
reliance
upon
my
companions
.
<EOS>
They
have
no
longer
the
confidence
that
can
alone
insure
success
,
and
I
expect
each
moment
some
one
will
propose
a
surrender
.
<EOS>
Surrender
!
<EOS>
I
will
never
do
so
with
life
.
<EOS>
Something
must
be
done
—
something
worthy
of
me
—
and
then
let
me
perish
.
<EOS>
I
have
ever
prayed
to
die
a
soldier
's
death
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
he
uttered
these
words
unconsciously
aloud
,
he
became
aware
of
the
presence
of
Robert
Winter
,
who
stood
at
the
end
of
the
passage
,
watching
him
.
<EOS>
"Your
prayer
will
not
be
granted
,
Catesby
,
"
said
the
latter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Some
dreadful
doom
,
I
fear
,
is
reserved
for
you
and
all
of
us
.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
mean
you
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
other
,
uneasily
.
"Listen
<EOS>
to
me
,
"
replied
Robert
Winter
.
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
I
had
a
strange
and
appalling
dream
to
-
night
,
and
I
will
now
relate
it
.
<EOS>
I
thought
I
was
in
a
boat
upon
the
river
Thames
,
when
all
at
once
the
day
,
which
had
been
bright
and
smiling
,
became
dark
and
overcast,—not
dark
like
the
shades
of
night
,
but
gloomy
and
ominous
,
as
when
the
sun
is
shrouded
by
an
eclipse
.
<EOS>
I
looked
around
,
and
every
object
was
altered
.
<EOS>
The
tower
of
Saint
Paul
's
stood
awry
,
and
seemed
ready
to
topple
down,—so
did
the
spires
and
towers
of
all
the
surrounding
fanes
.
<EOS>
The
houses
on
London
Bridge
leaned
frightfully
over
the
river
,
and
the
habitations
lining
its
banks
on
either
side
,
seemed
shaken
to
their
foundations
.
<EOS>
I
fancied
some
terrible
earthquake
must
have
occurred
,
or
that
the
end
of
the
world
was
at
hand
.
<EOS>
""Go
on
,
"
said
Catesby
,
who
had
listened
with
profound
attention
to
the
relation
.
<EOS>
"The
stream
,
too
,
changed
its
colour
,
"
continued
Robert
Winter
,
"
and
became
red
as
blood
,
and
the
man
who
rowed
my
boat
was
gone
,
and
his
place
occupied
by
a
figure
masked
and
habited
like
an
executioner
.
<EOS>
I
commanded
him
to
row
me
ashore
,
and
in
an
instant
the
bark
shot
to
land
,
and
I
sprang
out
,
glad
to
be
liberated
from
my
mysterious
conductor
.
<EOS>
My
steps
involuntarily
led
me
toward
the
cathedral
,
and
on
entering
it
,
I
found
its
pillars
,
shrines
,
monuments
,
and
roof
hung
with
black
.
<EOS>
The
throng
that
ever
haunt
Paul
's
Walk
had
disappeared
,
and
a
few
dismal
figures
alone
traversed
the
aisles
.
<EOS>
On
approaching
them
,
I
recognised
in
their
swollen
,
death
-
like
,
and
blackened
lineaments
,
some
resemblance
to
you
and
our
friends
.
<EOS>
I
was
about
to
interrogate
them
,
when
I
was
awakened
by
yourself
.
<EOS>
""A
<EOS>
strange
dream
,
truly
,
"
observed
Catesby
,
musingly
,
"
and
coupled
with
what
I
myself
have
seen
to
-
night
,
would
seem
to
bode
evil
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
he
then
proceeded
to
describe
the
supernatural
appearance
he
had
beheld
to
his
companion
.
<EOS>
"All
is
over
with
us
,
"
rejoined
Robert
Winter
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
prepare
to
meet
our
fate
.
<EOS>
""We
must
meet
it
like
men,—like
brave
men
,
Robert
,
"
replied
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
not
disgrace
ourselves
and
our
cause
.
<EOS>
""You
are
right
,
"
rejoined
Robert
Winter
;
"
but
these
visions
are
more
terrible
than
the
contemplation
of
death
itself
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
you
require
further
rest
,
take
it
,
"
returned
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
In
an
hour
I
shall
call
up
our
men
,
and
march
to
Hewel
Grange
.
<EOS>
""I
am
wearied
enough
,
"
replied
Robert
Winter
,
"
but
<EOS>
I
dare
not
close
my
eyes
again
.
<EOS>
""Then
recommend
your
soul
to
Heaven
,
"
said
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
be
alone
.
<EOS>
Melancholy
thoughts
press
upon
me
,
and
I
desire
to
unburden
my
heart
to
God
.
"Robert
<EOS>
Winter
then
left
him
,
and
he
withdrew
into
a
closet
where
there
was
an
image
of
the
Virgin
,
and
kneeling
before
it
,
prayed
long
and
fervently
.
<EOS>
Arising
in
a
calmer
frame
of
mind
,
he
returned
to
the
hall
,
and
summoning
his
companions
and
followers
,
their
horses
were
brought
forth
,
and
they
commenced
their
march
.
<EOS>
It
was
about
four
o'clock
when
they
started
,
and
so
dark
,
that
they
had
some
difficulty
in
finding
the
road
.
<EOS>
They
proceeded
at
a
slow
pace
,
and
with
the
utmost
caution
;
but
notwithstanding
this
,
and
though
the
two
Winters
and
Grant
,
who
were
well
acquainted
with
the
country
,
led
the
way
,
many
trifling
delays
and
disasters
occurred
.
<EOS>
Their
baggage
-
cart
frequently
stuck
fast
in
the
deep
ruts
,
while
the
men
missing
their
way
,
got
into
the
trenches
skirting
the
lane
,
and
were
not
unfrequently
thrown
from
their
horses
.
<EOS>
More
than
once
,
too
,
the
alarm
was
given
that
they
were
pursued
,
and
a
sudden
halt
ordered
;
but
these
apprehensions
proved
groundless
,
and
,
after
a
most
fatiguing
ride
,
they
found
themselves
at
Stoke
Prior
,
and
within
two
miles
of
Hewel
Grange
.
<EOS>
Originally
built
in
the
early
part
of
the
reign
of
Henry
the
Eighth
,
and
granted
by
that
monarch
to
an
ancestor
of
its
present
possessor
,
Lord
Windsor
,
this
ancient
mansion
was
quadrangular
in
form
,
and
surrounded
by
a
broad
deep
fosse
.
<EOS>
Situated
in
the
heart
of
an
extensive
park
,
at
the
foot
of
a
gentle
hill
,
it
was
now
approached
from
the
brow
of
the
latter
beautiful
eminence
by
the
rebel
party
.
<EOS>
But
at
this
season
,
and
at
this
hour
,
both
park
and
mansion
had
a
forlorn
look
.
<EOS>
The
weather
still
continued
foggy
,
with
drizzling
showers
,
and
though
the
trees
were
not
yet
entirely
stripped
of
their
foliage
,
their
glories
had
altogether
departed
.
<EOS>
The
turf
was
damp
and
plashy
,
and
in
some
places
partook
so
much
of
the
character
of
a
swamp
,
that
the
horsemen
were
obliged
to
alter
their
course
.
<EOS>
But
all
obstacles
were
eventually
overcome
,
and
in
ten
minutes
after
their
entrance
into
the
park
,
they
were
within
gunshot
of
the
mansion
.
<EOS>
There
were
no
symptoms
of
defence
apparent
,
but
the
drawbridge
being
raised
,
it
was
Catesby
's
opinion
,
notwithstanding
appearances
,
that
their
arrival
was
expected
.
<EOS>
He
was
further
confirmed
in
this
idea
when
,
sounding
a
trumpet
,
and
calling
to
the
porter
to
let
down
the
drawbridge
,
no
answer
was
returned
.
<EOS>
The
entrance
to
the
mansion
was
through
a
lofty
and
machiolated
gateway
,
strengthened
at
each
side
by
an
embattled
turret
.
<EOS>
Perceiving
a
man
at
one
of
the
loopholes
,
Catesby
discharged
his
petronel
at
him
,
and
it
was
evident
from
the
cry
that
followed
that
the
person
was
wounded
.
<EOS>
An
instant
afterwards
calivers
were
thrust
through
the
other
loopholes
,
and
several
shots
fired
upon
the
rebels
,
while
some
dozen
armed
men
appeared
upon
the
summit
of
the
tower
,
and
likewise
commenced
firing
.
<EOS>
Perceiving
Topcliffe
among
the
latter
,
and
enraged
at
the
sight
<EOS>
,
Catesby
discharged
another
petronel
at
him
,
but
without
effect
.
<EOS>
He
then
called
to
some
of
his
men
to
break
down
the
door
of
an
adjoining
barn
,
and
to
place
it
in
the
moat
.
<EOS>
The
order
was
instantly
obeyed
,
and
the
door
afloat
in
the
fosse
,
and
springing
upon
it
,
he
impelled
himself
with
a
pike
towards
the
opposite
bank
.
<EOS>
Several
shots
were
fired
at
him
,
and
though
more
than
one
struck
the
door
,
he
crossed
the
moat
uninjured
.
<EOS>
So
suddenly
was
this
daring
passage
effected
,
that
before
any
of
the
defenders
of
the
mansion
could
prevent
him
,
Catesby
had
severed
the
links
of
the
chain
fastening
the
drawbridge
,
and
it
fell
clattering
down
.
<EOS>
With
a
loud
shout
,
his
companions
then
crossed
it
.
<EOS>
But
they
had
still
a
difficulty
to
encounter
.
<EOS>
The
gates
,
which
were
of
great
strength
,
and
covered
with
plates
of
iron
,
were
barred
.
<EOS>
But
a
ladder
having
been
found
in
the
barn
,
it
was
brought
forward
,
and
Catesby
mounting
it
sword
in
hand
,
drove
back
all
who
opposed
him
,
and
got
upon
the
wall
.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
by
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
Percy
,
and
several
others
,
and
driving
the
royalists
before
them
,
they
made
their
way
down
a
flight
of
stone
steps
,
and
proceeding
to
the
gateway
,
threw
it
open
,
and
admitted
the
others
.
<EOS>
All
this
was
the
work
of
a
few
minutes
.
<EOS>
Committing
the
ransacking
of
the
mansion
to
Digby
and
Percy
,
and
commanding
a
dozen
men
to
follow
him
,
Catesby
entered
a
small
arched
doorway
,
and
ascended
a
winding
stone
staircase
in
search
of
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
His
progress
was
opposed
by
the
soldiers
,
but
beating
aside
all
opposition
,
he
gained
the
roof
.
<EOS>
Topcliffe
,
however
,
was
gone
.
<EOS>
Anticipating
the
result
of
the
attack
,
he
had
let
himself
drop
from
the
summit
of
the
tower
to
the
walls
,
and
descending
by
the
ladder
,
had
made
good
his
retreat
.
<EOS>
Disarming
the
soldiers
,
Catesby
then
descended
to
the
court
-
yard
,
where
in
a
short
time
a
large
store
of
arms
,
consisting
of
corslets
,
demi
-
lances
,
pikes
,
calivers
,
and
two
falconets
,
were
brought
forth
.
<EOS>
These
,
together
with
a
cask
of
powder
,
were
placed
in
the
baggage
-
waggon
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
larder
and
cellar
had
been
explored
,
and
provisions
of
all
kinds
,
together
with
a
barrel
of
mead
,
and
another
of
strong
ale
,
being
found
,
they
were
distributed
among
the
men
.
<EOS>
While
this
took
place
,
Catesby
searched
the
mansion
,
and
,
partly
by
threats
,
partly
by
persuasion
,
induced
about
twenty
persons
to
join
them
.
<EOS>
This
unlooked
-
for
success
so
encouraged
the
conspirators
,
that
their
drooping
spirits
began
to
revive
.
<EOS>
Catesby
appeared
as
much
elated
as
the
others
,
but
at
heart
he
was
full
of
misgiving
.
<EOS>
Soon
afterwards
,
the
rebel
party
quitted
Hewel
Grange
,
taking
with
them
every
weapon
they
could
find
.
<EOS>
The
forced
recruits
were
placed
in
the
midst
of
the
band
,
so
that
escape
was
impracticable
.
<EOS>
IV
.
—
HOLBEACHAvoiding
the
high
road
,
and
traversing
an
unfrequented
part
of
the
country
,
the
conspirators
shaped
their
course
towards
Stourbridge
.
<EOS>
As
they
reached
Forfield
Green
,
they
perceived
a
large
party
descending
the
hilly
ground
near
Bromsgrove
,
and
evidently
in
pursuit
of
them
.
<EOS>
An
immediate
halt
was
ordered
,
and
taking
possession
of
a
farm
-
house
,
they
prepared
for
defence
.
<EOS>
Seeing
these
preparations
,
their
pursuers
,
who
proved
to
be
Sir
Richard
Walsh
the
Sheriff
of
Worcestershire
,
Sir
John
Foliot
,
three
gentlemen
named
Ketelbye
,
Salwaye
,
and
Conyers
,
attended
by
a
large
posse
of
men
,
all
tolerably
well
armed
,
drew
up
at
some
distance
from
the
farm
,
and
appeared
to
be
consulting
as
to
the
prudence
of
making
an
attack
.
<EOS>
Topcliffe
was
with
them
;
and
Catesby
,
who
reconnoitered
their
proceedings
from
a
window
of
the
dwelling
,
inferred
from
his
gestures
that
he
was
against
the
assault
.
<EOS>
And
so
it
proved
.
<EOS>
The
royalist
party
remained
where
they
were
,
and
as
one
or
two
of
their
number
occasionally
disappeared
,
Catesby
judged
,
and
correctly
,
that
they
were
despatched
for
a
reinforcement
.
<EOS>
Not
willing
to
wait
for
this
,
he
determined
to
continue
his
march
,
and
,
accordingly
,
forming
his
men
into
a
close
line
,
and
bringing
up
the
rear
himself
,
they
again
set
forward
.
<EOS>
Sir
Richard
Walsh
and
his
party
followed
them
,
and
whenever
they
were
in
a
difficult
part
of
the
road
,
harassed
them
with
a
sudden
attack
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
several
stragglers
were
cut
off
,
and
a
few
prisoners
made
.
<EOS>
So
exasperated
did
Catesby
become
by
these
annoyances
,
<EOS>
that
,
though
desirous
to
push
forward
as
fast
as
possible
,
he
halted
at
the
entrance
of
a
common
,
and
prepared
for
an
engagement
.
<EOS>
But
his
purpose
was
defeated
,
for
the
royalist
party
took
another
course
,
nor
did
he
see
anything
more
of
them
for
some
time
.
<EOS>
In
about
an
hour
the
rebels
arrived
at
the
banks
of
the
river
Stour
,
not
far
from
the
little
village
of
Churchill
,
and
here
,
just
as
they
were
preparing
to
ford
the
stream
,
the
sheriff
and
his
followers
again
made
their
appearance
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
also
,
the
forces
of
their
opponents
were
considerably
augmented
,
and
as
more
than
a
third
of
their
own
party
were
engaged
in
crossing
the
stream
,
which
was
greatly
swollen
by
the
recent
rains
,
and
extremely
dangerous
,
their
position
was
one
of
no
slight
peril
.
<EOS>
Nothing
daunted
,
Catesby
instantly
drew
up
his
men
on
the
bank
,
and
,
after
a
short
skirmish
,
drove
away
the
enemy
,
and
afterwards
contrived
to
cross
the
river
without
much
loss
.
<EOS>
He
found
,
however
,
that
the
baggage
-
cart
had
got
immersed
in
the
stream
,
and
it
was
feared
that
the
powder
would
be
damaged
.
<EOS>
They
remained
on
the
opposite
bank
for
some
time
;
but
as
their
enemies
did
not
attempt
to
follow
them
,
they
took
the
way
to
Holbeach
,
a
large
and
strongly
built
mansion
belonging
,
as
has
been
already
stated
,
to
Stephen
Littleton
.
<EOS>
Here
they
arrived
without
further
molestation
,
and
their
first
business
was
to
put
it
into
a
complete
state
of
defence
.
<EOS>
IllustrationAfter
a
long
and
anxious
consultation
,
Sir
Everard
Digby
quitted
them
,
undertaking
to
return
on
the
following
day
with
succours
.
<EOS>
Stephen
Littleton
also
disappeared
on
the
same
evening
.
<EOS>
His
flight
produced
a
strong
impression
on
Catesby
,
and
he
besought
the
others
not
to
abandon
the
good
cause
,
but
to
stand
by
it
,
as
he
himself
meant
to
do
,
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
They
all
earnestly
assured
him
that
they
would
do
so
,
except
Robert
Winter
,
who
sat
apart
,
and
took
no
share
in
their
discourse
.
<EOS>
Catesby
then
examined
the
powder
that
had
been
plunged
in
the
water
in
crossing
the
Stour
,
and
found
it
so
much
wetted
as
to
be
nearly
useless
.
<EOS>
A
sufficient
stock
of
powder
being
of
the
utmost
consequence
to
them
,
he
caused
all
the
contents
of
the
barrel
,
not
dissolved
by
the
immersion
,
to
be
poured
into
a
large
platter
,
and
proceeded
to
dry
it
before
a
fire
which
had
been
kindled
in
the
hall
.
<EOS>
A
bag
of
powder
,
which
had
likewise
been
slightly
wetted
,
was
also
placed
at
what
was
considered
a
safe
distance
from
the
fire
.
<EOS>
"Heaven
<EOS>
grant
<EOS>
this
may
prove
more

to

enemies
than
the
combustibles
we
placed
in

!
"
observed

.
<EOS>
"Heaven
<EOS>
grant

so
,

!
"

Catesby
,
with

.
<EOS>
"
They
would
call
it
retribution
,
where
we
to
perish
by

.
<EOS>
""Jest
<EOS>
not

serious

,
Catesby
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
For

,

dread
the
sight
of
powder
,
and

.
<EOS>
""You

,

Stephen
