?
"
rejoined
Catesby
,

.
<EOS>
"I

,
"
said
Christopher
Wright
;
"
so
you

.
<EOS>
"Accordingly
,

quitted
the
hall
with
Robert
Winter
,
and

the
court

of

,

.
<EOS>
The

building
seemed
rent

,
and

.
<EOS>
"Mother
of

!
"

Wright
,

up
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
is
a
providential
occurrence
.
<EOS>
Had
this
exploded
,
we
must
all
have
been
destroyed
.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
us
see
what
has

,
"

Robert
Winter
.
<EOS>
And
,

,

,
and

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Rookwood
was

,
and

that

.
<EOS>
Percy
was

the

,

dress
,
and
John
Grant
was

.
<EOS>
"Those
<EOS>
are

very
faces
I

,
"

Winter
,

.
<EOS>
"
It

true
warning
.
"Rushing

up

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
Wretch

!
<EOS>
that

"

.
<EOS>
"

—

.
<EOS>
""It

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
"And
<EOS>
he

,

.
<EOS>
Nor

.
<EOS>
"I
will

!
"
<EOS>
cried
John
Grant
,
whose

that

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

that

act

was
so

that
it
called
for
the
vengeance
of
Heaven
,
and
expressing

sincere

.
<EOS>
"No
<EOS>
more
of
this
,
"

,
staggering

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
mere
accident
,
I
tell

.
<EOS>
We
are
all

,
and

.
<EOS>
"On
<EOS>
inquiry
,

learnt

,
and
falling

containing

,

.
<EOS>
V.
—
THE
CLOSE
OF
THE
REBELLIONUnable
longer
to
endure
the
agony
occasioned
by
his
scorched
visage
,
Catesby
called
for
a
bucket
of
water
,
and
plunged
his
head
into
it
.
<EOS>
Somewhat
relieved
by
the
immersion
,
he
turned
to
inquire
after
his
fellow
-
sufferers
.
<EOS>
Rookwood
having
been
carried
into
the
open
air
,
had
by
this
time
regained
his
consciousness
;
Percy
was
shockingly
injured
,
his
hair
and
eyebrows
burnt
,
his
skin
blackened
and
swollen
with
unseemly
blisters
,
and
the
sight
of
one
eye
entirely
destroyed
;
while
John
Grant
,
though
a
degree
less
hurt
than
his
companions
,
presented
a
grim
and
ghastly
appearance
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
the
four
sufferers
looked
as
if
they
had
just
escaped
from
some
unearthly
place
of
torment
,
and
were
doomed
henceforth
to
bear
the
brand
of
Divine
wrath
on
their
countenances
.
<EOS>
Seeing
the
effect
produced
on
the
others
,
Catesby
rallied
all
his
force
,
and
treating
the
accident
as
a
matter
of
no
moment
,
and
which
ought
not
to
disturb
the
equanimity
of
brave
men
,
called
for
wine
,
and
quaffed
a
full
goblet
.
<EOS>
Injured
as
he
was
,
and
smarting
with
pain
,
Percy
followed
his
example
,
but
both
John
Grant
and
Rookwood
refused
the
cup
.
<EOS>
"Hark
'
e
,
gentlemen
,
"
cried
Catesby
,
fiercely
,
"
you
may
drink
or
not
,
as
you
see
fit
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
have
you
assume
a
deportment
calculated
to
depress
our
followers
.
<EOS>
Stephen
Littleton
and
Robert
Winter
have
basely
deserted
us
.
<EOS>
If
you
have
any
intention
of
following
them
,
go
at
once
.
<EOS>
We
are
better
without
you
than
with
you
.
<EOS>
""I
have
no
thought
of
deserting
you
,
Catesby
,
"
rejoined
Rookwood
,
mournfully
;
"
and
when

time
arrives
for
action
,
you
will
find
I
shall
not
be
idle
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
now
assured
that
we
have
sold
ourselves
to
perdition
.
<EOS>
""Pshaw
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Catesby
,
with
a
laugh
that
communicated
an
almost
fiendish

to

grim

;
"
because
a
little
powder
has
accidentally
exploded
and
blackened
our
faces
,
are
we
to
see
in
the
occurrence
the
retributive
justice
of
Heaven
?
<EOS>
Are
we
to
be
cast
down
by
such
a
trifle
?
<EOS>
Be
a
man
,
and
rouse
yourself
.
<EOS>
Recollect
that
the
eyes
of
all
England
are
upon
us
;
and
if
we
must
fall
,
let
us
perish
in
a
manner
that
becomes
us
.
<EOS>
No
real
mischief
has
been
done
.
<EOS>
My
hand
is
as
able
to
wield
a
blade
,
and
my
sight
to
direct
a
shot
,
as
heretofore
.
<EOS>
If
Heaven
had
meant
to
destroy
us
,
the
bag
of
powder
which
has
been
taken
up
in
the
yard
,
and
which
was
sufficient
not
only
to
annihilate

,

in

,
would
have

to

.
<EOS>
""Would

!
"

Wright
.
<EOS>
"
All

.
<EOS>
""Are

,

,

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
wrong

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

;

.
<EOS>
On

will
produce

.
<EOS>
We
must

to

.
<EOS>
Heaven
be

;
we
shall
not
perish

scaffold!""Be

,
"
said
Grant
,

.
<EOS>
"
It
may

.
<EOS>
""It

,
"

.
<EOS>
"Nor

mine
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
""In
<EOS>

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
""Again

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
You

anon
.
<EOS>
"John
<EOS>
Wright
shook
his
head
,
and
Catesby
,
pulling
his
hat
over
his
brows
to
hide
his
features
,
walked
forth
into
the
court
-
yard
.
<EOS>
He
found
,
as
he
expected
,
that
general
consternation
prevailed
amongst
the
band
.
<EOS>
The
men
were
gathered
together
in
little
knots
,
and
,
though
they
became
silent
as
he
approached
,
he
perceived
they
were
discussing
the
necessity
of
a
surrender
.
<EOS>
Nothing
daunted
by
these
unfavourable
,
appearances
,
Catesby
harangued
them
in
such
bold
terms
that
he
soon
inspired
them
with
some
of
his
own
confidence
,
and
completely
resteadied
their
wavering
feelings
.
<EOS>
Elated
with
his
success
,
he
caused
a
cup
of
strong
ale
to
be
given
to
each
man
,
and
proposed
as
a
pledge
,
the
restoration
of
the
Romish
Church
.
<EOS>
He
then
returned
to
the
house
;
and
summoning
the
other
conspirators
to
attend
him
in
a
chamber
on
the
ground
-
floor
,
they
all
prayed
long
and
fervently
,
and
concluded
by
administering
the
sacrament
to
each
other
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
thought
necessary
to
have
the
damage
done
by
the
explosion
repaired
,
and
a
few
hours
were
employed
in
the
operation
.
<EOS>
Evening
was
fast
approaching
,
and
Catesby
,
who
was
anxiously
expecting
the
return
of
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
stationed
himself
on
the
turreted
walls
of
the
mansion
to
look
out
for
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
came
not
;
and
,
fearing
some
mischance
must
have
befallen
him
,
Catesby
descended
.
<EOS>
Desirous
of
concealing
his
misgivings
from
his
companions
,
he
put
on
a
cheerful
manner
as
he
joined
them
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
am
surprised
ere
this
that
we
have
not
been
attacked
,
"
remarked
Percy
.
<EOS>
"
Our
enemies
may
be
waiting
for
the
darkness
,
to
take
us
by
surprise
.
<EOS>
But
they
will
be
disappointed
.
<EOS>
""I
can
only
account
for
the
delay
by
supposing
they
have
encountered
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
and
the
force
he
is
bringing
to
us
,
"
remarked
Christopher
Wright
.
<EOS>
"It
may
be
so
,
"
returned
Catesby
,
"
and
if
so
,
we
shall
soon
learn
the
result
.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
spite
of
all
Catesby
's
efforts
he
failed
to
engage
his
companions
in
conversation
,
and
feeling
it
would
best
suit
his
present
frame
of
mind
,
and
contribute
most
to
their
safety
,
to
keep
in
constant
motion
,
he
proceeded
to
the
court
-
yard
,
saw
that
all
the
defences
were
secure
,
that
the
drawbridge
was
raised
,
the
sentinels
at
their
posts
,
and
everything
prepared
for
the
anticipated
attack
.
<EOS>
Every
half
hour
he
thus
made
his
rounds
,
and
when
towards
midnight
he
was
going
forth
,
Percy
said
to
him,"Do
<EOS>
you
not
mean
to
take
any
rest
,
Catesby?""Not
till
I
am
in
my
grave
,
"
was
the
moody
reply
.
<EOS>
Catesby
's
untiring
energy
was
in
fact
a
marvel
to
all
his
followers
.
<EOS>
His
iron
frame
seemed
wholly
unsusceptible
of
fatigue
;
and
even
when
he
returned
to
the
house
,
he
continued
to
pace
to
and
fro
in
the
passage
in
preference
to
lying
down
.
<EOS>
"Rest
<EOS>
tranquilly
,
"
he
said
to
Christopher
Wright
,
who
offered
to
take
his
place
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
rouse
you
on
the
slightest
approach
of
danger
.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
though
he
preserved
this
stoical
exterior
,
Catesby
's
breast
was
torn
by
the
keenest
pangs
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
hide
from
himself
that
,
to
serve
his
own
ambitious
purposes
,
he
had
involved
many
loyal
and
worthy
(
till
he
had
deluded
them
)
persons
in
a
treasonable
project
,
which
must
now
terminate
in
their
destruction
;
and
their
blood
,
he
feared
,
would
rest
upon
his
head
.
<EOS>
But
what
weighed
heaviest
of
all
upon
his
soul
was
the
probable
fate
of
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"If
I
were
assured
she
would
escape
,
"
he
thought
,
"
I
should
care
little
for
all
the
rest
,
even
for
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
They
say
it
is
never
too
late
to
repent
.
<EOS>
But
my
repentance
shall
lie
between
my
Maker
and
myself
.
<EOS>
Man
shall
never
know
it
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
night
was
dark
,
and
the
gloom
was
rendered
more
profound
by
a
dense
fog
.
<EOS>
Fearing
an
attack
might
now
be
attempted
,
Catesby
renewed
his
vigilance
.
<EOS>
Marching
round
the
edge
of
the
moat
,
he
listened
to
every
sound
that
might
betray
the
approach
of
a
foe
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
,
nothing
occurred
to
excite
his
suspicions
,
until
about
an
hour
after
midnight
,
as
he
was
standing
at
the
back
of
the
house
,
he
fancied
he
detected
a
stealthy
tread
on
the
other
side
of
the
fosse
,
and
soon
became
convinced
that
a
party
of
men
were
there
.
<EOS>
Determined
to
ascertain
their
movements
before
giving
the
alarm
,
he
held
his
breath
,
and
drawing
a
petronel
,
remained
perfectly
motionless
.
<EOS>
Presently
,
though
he
could
discern
no
object
,
he
distinctly
heard
a
plank
pushed
across
the
moat
,
and
could
distinguish
in
the
whispered
accents
of
one
of
the
party
the
voice
of
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
A
thrill
of
savage
joy
agitated
his
bosom
,
and
he
internally
congratulated
himself
that
revenge
was
in
his
power
.
<EOS>
A
footstep
,
though
so
noiseless
as
to
be
inaudible
to
any
ear
less
acute
than
his
own
,
was
now
heard
crossing
the
plank
,
and
feeling
certain
it
was
Topcliffe
,
Catesby
allowed
him
to
land
,
and
then
suddenly
advancing
,
kicked
the
plank
,
on
which
were
two
other
persons
,
into
the
water
,
and
unmasking
a
dark
lantern
,
threw
its
light
upon
the
face
of
a
man
near
him
,
who
proved
,
as
he
suspected
,
to
be
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
Aware
of
the
advantage
of
making
a
prisoner
of
importance
,
Catesby
controlled
the
impulse
that
prompted
him
to
sacrifice
Topcliffe
to
his
vengeance
,
and
firing
his
petronel
in
the
air
as
a
signal
,
he
drew
his
sword
,
and
sprang
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Topcliffe
attempted
to
defend
himself
,
but
he
was
no
match
for
the
skill
and
impetuosity
of
Catesby
,
and
was
instantly
overpowered
and
thrown
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
Percy
and
several
of
the
band
had
come
up
,
and
delivering
Topcliffe
to
the
charge
of
two
of
the
stoutest
of
them
,
Catesby
turned
his
attention
to
the
other
assailants
.
<EOS>
One
of
them
got
across
the
moat
;
but
the
other
,
encumbered
by
his
arms
,
was
floundering
about
,
when
Catesby
pointing
a
petronel
at
his
head
,
he
was
fain
to
surrender
,
and
was
dragged
out
.
<EOS>
A
volley
of
musketry
was
now
fired
by
the
rebels
in
the
supposed
direction
of
their
opponents
,
but
it
could
not
be
ascertained
what
execution
was
done
.
<EOS>
After
waiting
for
some
time
,
in
expectation
of
a
further
attack
,
Catesby
placed
a
guard
upon
the
spot
,
and
proceeded
to
examine
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
thrown
into
a
cellar
beneath
the
kitchen
,
and
the
two
men
were
on
guard
over
him
.
<EOS>
He
refused
to
answer
any
of
Catesby
's
questions
,
though
enforced
by
threats
of
instant
death
.
<EOS>
On
searching
him
some
letters
were
found
upon
him
,
and
thrusting
them
into
his
doublet
,
Catesby
left
him
,
with
the
strictest
injunctions
to
the
men
as
to
his
safe
custody
.
<EOS>
He
then
proceeded
to
examine
the
other
captive
,
and
found
him
somewhat
more
tractable
.
<EOS>
This
man
informed
him
that
Topcliffe
had
intended
to
steal
into
the
house
with
the
design
of
capturing
the
conspirators
,
or
,
failing
in
that
,
of
setting
fire
to
the
premises
.
<EOS>
He
also
ascertained
that
Topcliffe
's
force
consisted
only
of
a
dozen
men
,
so
that
no
further
attack
need
be
apprehended
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
this
information
,
Catesby
determined
to
be
on
the
safe
side
,
and
doubling
the
sentinels
,
he
stationed
one
of
the
conspirators
,
all
of
whom
had
sprung
to
arms
at
his
signal
,
at
each
of
the
exposed
points
.
<EOS>
He
then
withdrew
to
the
mansion
,
and
examined
Topcliffe
's
papers
.
<EOS>
The
first
despatch
he
opened
was
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
bearing
date
about
the
early
part
of
Fawkes
's
confinement
in
the
Tower
,
in
which
the
Earl
expressed
his
determination
of
wringing
a
full
confession
from
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
A
bitter
smile
curled
Catesby
's
lip
as
he
read
this
,
but
his
brow
darkened
as
he
proceeded
,
and
found
that
a
magnificent
reward
was
offered
for
his
own
arrest
.
<EOS>
"I
must
have
Catesby
captured
,
"
ran
the
missive,—"so
<EOS>
see
you
spare
no
pains
to
take
him
.
<EOS>
I
would
rather
all
escaped
than
he
did
.
<EOS>
His
confession
is
of
the
last
importance
in
the
matter
,
and
I
rely
upon
your
bringing
him
to
me
alive
.
<EOS>
""I
will
at
least
balk
him
of
that
satisfaction
,
"
muttered
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
But
what
is
this
of
Viviana?"Reading
<EOS>
further
,
he
found
that
the
Earl
had
issued
the
same
orders
respecting
Viviana
,
and
that
she
would
be
rigorously
dealt
with
if
captured
.
<EOS>
"Alas
!
"
groaned
Catesby
;
"
I
hope
she
will
escape
these
inhuman
butchers
.
"The
<EOS>
next
despatch
he
opened
was
from
Tresham
,
and
with
a
savage
satisfaction
he
found
that
the
traitor
was
apprehensive
of
double
-
dealing
on
the
part
of
Salisbury
and
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
He
stated
that
he
had
been
put
under
arrest
,
and
was
detained
a
prisoner
in
his
own
house
;
and
fearing
he
should
be
sent
to
the
Tower
,
besought
Topcliffe
to
use
his
influence
with
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
not
to
deal
unfairly
with
him
.
<EOS>
"He
is
rightly
served
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Catesby
,
with
a
bitter
smile
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Heaven
grant
they
may
deal
with
him
as
he
dealt
with
us!"The
consideration
of
these
letters
furnished
Catesby
with
food
for
much
bitter
reflection
.
<EOS>
Pacing
the
room
to
and
fro
with
uncertain
footsteps
,
he
remained
more
than
an
hour
by
himself
,
and
at
last
yielding
to
the
promptings
of
vengeance
,
repaired
to
the
cellar
in
which
he
had
placed
Topcliffe
,
with
the
intention
of
putting
him
to
death
.
<EOS>
What
was
his
rage
and
mortification
to
find
both
the
guard
and
the
prisoner
gone
!
<EOS>
A
door
was
open
,
and
it
was
evident
that
the
fugitives
had
stolen
to
the
moat
,
and
,
swimming
noiselessly
across
it
in
the
darkness
,
had
securely
effected
their
retreat
.
<EOS>
Fearful
of
exciting
the
alarm
of
his
followers
,
Catesby
controlled
his
indignation
,
and
said
nothing
of
the
escape
of
the
prisoner
to
any
but
his
confederates
,
who
entirely
approved
of
the
policy
of
silence
.
<EOS>
They
continued
on
the
alert
during
the
remainder
of
the
night
,
and
no
one
thought
of
seeking
repose
till
it
was
fully
light
,
and
all
danger
of
a
surprise
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
Day
dawned
late
and
dismally
.
<EOS>
The
fog
that
had
hung
round
the
mansion
changed
just
before
daybreak
into
drizzling
rain
,
and
this
increased
ere
long
to
heavy
and
drenching
showers
.
<EOS>
Everything
looked
gloomy
and
depressing
,
and
the
conspirators
were
so
disheartened
,
that
they
avoided
each
other
's
regards
.
<EOS>
Catesby
mounted
the
walls
of
the
mansion
to
reconnoitre
.
<EOS>
The
prospect
was
forlorn
and
melancholy
to
the
last
degree
.
<EOS>
The
neighbouring
woods
were
obscured
by
mist
;
the
court
-
yard
and
garden
flooded
with
rain
;
and
the
waters
of
the
moat
spotted
by
the
heavy
shower
.
<EOS>
Not
an
object
was
in
view
,
except
a
hind
driving
cattle
to
a
neighbouring
farm
.
<EOS>
Catesby
shouted
to
him
,
and
the
fellow
with
evident
reluctance
approaching
the
brink
of
the
moat
,
was
asked
whether
he
had
seen
any
troops
in
the
neighbourhood
.
<EOS>
The
man
answered
in
the
negative
,
but
said
he
had
heard
that
an
engagement
had
taken
place
in
the
night
,
about
five
miles
from
thence
,
near
Hales
Owen
,
between
Sir
Everard
Digby
and
Sir
Richard
Walsh
,
and
that
Sir
Everard
's
party
had
been
utterly
routed
,
and
himself
taken
prisoner
.
<EOS>
This
intelligence
was
a
severe
blow
to
Catesby
,
as
it
destroyed
the
last
faint
hope
he
had
clung
to
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
he
continued
wrapt
in
thought
,
and
then
descended
to
the
lower
part
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
A
large
fire
had
been
kept
up
during
the
night
in
the
hall
,
and
the
greater
part
of
the
band
were
now
gathered
round
it
,
drying
their
wet
clothes
,
and
conversing
together
.
<EOS>
A
plentiful
breakfast
had
been
served
out
to
them
,
so
that
they
were
in
tolerably
good
spirits
,
and
many
of
them
talked
loudly
of
the
feats
they
meant
to
perform
in
case
of
an
attack
.
<EOS>
Catesby
heard
these
boasts
,
but
they
fell
upon
an
idle
ear
.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
all
was
over
;
that
his
last
chance
was
gone
;
and
that
the
struggle
could
not
be
much
longer
protracted
.
<EOS>
Entering
the
inner
room
,
he
sat
down
at
table
with
his
companions
,
but
he
ate
nothing
,
and
continued
silent
and
abstracted
.
<EOS>
"It
is
now
my
turn
to
reproach
you
,
"
observed
Grant
.
<EOS>
"
You
look
deeply
depressed
.
<EOS>
""Sir
<EOS>
Everard
Digby
is
a
prisoner
,
"
replied
Catesby
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
capture
grieves
me
sorely
.
<EOS>
He
should
have
died
with
us
.
<EOS>
"All
echoed
the
wish
.
<EOS>
Catesby
arose
and
closed
the
door
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
attack
will
not
be
many
hours
delayed
,
"
he
said
;
"
and
unless
there
should
be
some
miraculous
interposition
in
our
behalf
,
it
must
end
in
our
defeat
.
<EOS>
Do
not
let
us
survive
it
,
"
he
continued
earnestly
.
"
<EOS>
Let
us
swear
to
stand
by
each
other
as
long
as
we
can
,
and
to
die
together
.
<EOS>
""Agreed
!
"
cried
the
others
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
now
,
"
continued
Catesby
,
"
I
must
compel
myself
to
take
some
nourishment
,
for
I
have
much
to
do
.
<EOS>
"Having
<EOS>
swallowed
a
few
mouthfuls
of
bread
,
and
drained
a
goblet
of
wine
,
he
again
visited
every
part
of
the
habitation
,
<EOS>
examined
the
arms
of
the
men
,
encouraged
them
by
his
looks
and
words
,
and
became
satisfied
,
unless
some
unlooked
-
for
circumstance
occurred
to
damp
their
ardour
,
they
would
offer
a
determined
and
vigorous
resistance
.
<EOS>
"If
I
could
only
come
off
victorious
in
this
last
conflict
,
I
should
die
content
,
"
thought
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
do
not
despair
of
it
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
rain
continued
till
eleven
o'clock
,
when
it
ceased
,
and
the
mist
that
had
attended
it
partially
cleared
off
.
<EOS>
About
noon
,
Catesby
,
who
was
on
the
look
-
out
from
the
walls
of
the
mansion
,
descried
a
large
troop
of
horsemen
issuing
from
the
wood
.
<EOS>
He
immediately
gave
the
alarm
.
<EOS>
The
bell
was
rung
,
and
all
sprang
to
arms
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
troop
had
advanced
within
a
hundred
yards
of
the
house
,
and
Catesby
,
who
had
rushed
into
the
court
-
yard
,
mounted
a
turret
near
the
gate
to
watch
their
movements
,
and
issue
his
commands
.
<EOS>
The
royalists
were
headed
by
Sir
Richard
Walsh
,
who
was
attended
on
the
right
by
Sir
John
Foliot
,
and
on
the
left
by
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
Immediately
behind
them
were
Ketelbye
,
Salwaye
,
Conyers
,
and
others
who
had
accompanied
the
posse
comitatûs
the
day
before
.
<EOS>
A
trumpet
was
then
sounded
,
and
a
proclamation
made
in
a
loud
voice
by
a
trooper
,
commanding
the
rebels
in
the
King
's
name
to
surrender
,
and
to
deliver
up
their
leaders
.
<EOS>
The
man
had
scarcely
concluded
his
speech
when
he
was
for
ever
silenced
by
a
shot
from
Catesby
.
<EOS>
A
loud
and
vindictive
shout
was
raised
by
the
royalists
,
and
the
assault
instantly
commenced
.
<EOS>
Sir
Richard
Walsh
directed
the
attack
against
the
point
opposite
the
drawbridge
,
while
Sir
John
Foliot
,
Topcliffe
,
and
the
others
dispersed
themselves
,
and
completely
surrounded
the
mansion
.
<EOS>
Several
planks
were
thrust
across
the
moat
,
and
in
spite
of
the
efforts
of
the
rebels
many
of
the
assailants
effected
a
passage
.
<EOS>
Catesby
drove
back
the
party
under
Sir
Richard
Walsh
,
and
with
his
own
hand
hewed
asunder
their
plank
.
<EOS>
In
doing
this
,
he
so
much
exposed
himself
that
,
but
for
the
injunctions
of
the
Sheriff
,
who
commanded
his
followers
not
to
fire
upon
him
,
he
must
have
been
slain
.
<EOS>
The
other
rebel
-
leaders
displayed
equal
courage
,
and
equal
indifference
to
danger
,
and
though
,
as
has
just
been
stated
,
a
considerable
number
of
the
royalists
had
got
across
the
moat
,
and
entered
the
garden
,
they
had
obtained
no
material
advantage
.
<EOS>
Sir
John
Foliot
and
Topcliffe
commanded
this
party
,
and
encouraged
them
to
press
on
.
<EOS>
But
such
a
continued
and
well
-
directed
firing
was
kept
up
upon
them
from
the
walls
and
windows
of
the
mansion
,
that
they
soon
began
to
show
symptoms
of
wavering
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
and
while
Topcliffe
was
trying
to
keep
his
men
together
,
a
concealed
door
in
the
wall
was
opened
,
and
Catesby
issued
from
it
at
the
head
of
a
dozen
men
.
<EOS>
He
instantly
attacked
Topcliffe
and
his
band
,
put
several
to
the
sword
,
and
drove
those
who
resisted
into
the
moat
.
<EOS>
Foliot
and
Topcliffe
with
difficulty
escaped
across
the
plank
,
which
was
seized
and
pulled
over
to
his
own
side
by
Catesby
.
<EOS>
But
the
hope
which
this
success
inspired
was
instantly
crushed
.
<EOS>
Loud
shouts
were
raised
from
the
opposite
wing
of
the
mansion
,
and
Catesby
to
his
great
dismay
perceived
from
the
volumes
of
smoke
ascending
from
it
that
it
was
on
fire
.
<EOS>
Uttering
an
exclamation
of
rage
and
despair
,
he
commanded
those
with
him
not
to
quit
their
present
position
,
and
set
off
in
the
direction
of
the
fire
.
<EOS>
He
found
that
an
outbuilding
had
been
set
in
flames
by
a
lighted
brand
thrown
across
the
moat
by
a
trooper
.
<EOS>
The
author
of
the
action
was
named
John
Streete
,
and
was
afterwards
rendered
notorious
by
another
feat
to
be
presently
related
.
<EOS>
Efforts
were
made
to
extinguish
the
conflagration
,
but
such
was
the
confusion
prevailing
that
it
was
found
wholly
impossible
to
do
so
,
and
it
was
feared
that
the
destruction
of
the
whole
mansion
would
ensue
.
<EOS>
Disaster
after
disaster
followed
.
<EOS>
Another
party
had
crossed
the
moat
,
and
burst
into
the
court
-
yard
.
<EOS>
In
the
desperate
conflict
that
ensued
,
Rookwood
was
shot
through
the
arm
,
and
severely
wounded
by
a
pike
,
and
was
borne
into
the
house
by
one
of
his
followers
,
whom
he
entreated
to
kill
him
outright
,
but
his
request
was
refused
.
<EOS>
Meantime
,
the
drawbridge
was
lowered
,
and
with
loud
and
exulting
shouts
the
great
body
of
the
royalists
crossed
it
.
<EOS>
Catesby
now
perceived
that
the
day
was
irretrievably
lost
.
<EOS>
Calling
to
Christopher
Wright
,
who
was
standing
near
him
,
to
follow
him
,
and
rushing
towards
the
court
-
yard
,
he
reached
it
just
as
the
royalists
gained
an
entrance
.
<EOS>
In
numbers
both
parties
were
pretty
,
well
matched
,
but
the
rebels
were
now
thoroughly
disheartened
,
and
seeing
how
matters
must
end
,
many
of
them
threw
down
their
arms
,
and
begged
for
mercy
.
<EOS>
A
destructive
fire
,
however
,
was
still
kept
up
on
the
royalists
by
a
few
of
the
rebels
stationed
on
the
walls
of
the
mansion
,
under
the
command
of
John
Wright
.
<EOS>
Putting
himself
at
the
head
of
a
few
faithful
followers
,
Catesby
fought
with
all
the
fury
of
despair
.
<EOS>
Christopher
Wright
was
shot
by
his
side
.
<EOS>
Grant
instantly
sprang
forward
,
but
was
cut
down
by
a
trooper
.
<EOS>
Catesby
was
too
busily
occupied
to
attend
to
the
fate
of
his
companions
,
but
seeing
Thomas
Winter
near
him
,
called
to
him
to
come
on
.
<EOS>
"I
can
fight
no
longer
,
"
said
Thomas
Winter
.
<EOS>
"
My
right
arm
is
disabled
by
a
bolt
from
a
cross
-
bow
.
<EOS>
""Then
die
,
"
cried
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
shall
die
—
on
the
scaffold
,
"
rejoined
Topcliffe
,
who
had
heard
the
exclamation
.
<EOS>
And
rushing
up
to
Thomas
Winter
,
he
seized
him
,
and
conveyed
him
to
the
rear
of
his
party
.
<EOS>
Catesby
continued
to
fight
with
such
determined
bravery
that
Sir
Richard
Walsh
,
seeing
it
would
be
vain
to
take
him
alive
,
withdrew
his
restrictions
from
his
men
,
and
ordered
them
to
slay
him
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
most
of
the
rebels
had
thrown
down
their
arms
.
<EOS>
Those
on
the
walls
had
been
dislodged
,
and
John
Wright
,
refusing
to
yield
,
was
slaughtered
.
<EOS>
Catesby
,
however
,
having
been
joined
by
Percy
and
half
a
dozen
men
,
made
a
last
desperate
charge
upon
his
opponents
.
<EOS>
In
doing
this
,
his
sword
shivered
,
and
he
would
have
fallen
back
,
but
found
himself
surrounded
.
<EOS>
Percy
was
close
behind
him
,
and
keeping
together
,
they
fought
back
to
back
.
<EOS>
Even
in
this
disabled
state
,
they
made
a
long
and
desperate
resistance
.
<EOS>
"Remember
<EOS>
your
oath
,
Percy
,
"
cried
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
sworn
not
to
be
taken
to
the
scaffold
.
<EOS>
"Illustration"Fear
<EOS>
nothing
,
"
replied
Percy
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
quit
this
spot
alive
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
words
were
scarcely
out
of
his
mouth
when
he
fell
to
the
ground
mortally
wounded
,
and
the
same
shot
that
had
pierced
his
breast
had
likewise
stricken
Catesby
.
<EOS>
It
was
fired
by
the
trooper
,
John
Streete
,
who
has
just
been
mentioned
.
<EOS>
Collecting
all
his
force
,
Catesby
struck
a
few
terrible
blows
at
his
opponents
,
and
,
dashing
through
them
,
made
for
the
house
.
<EOS>
Just
as
he
reached
the
door
,
which
was
standing
open
,
his
strength
failed
,
and
he
fell
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
In
this
condition
,
he
dragged
himself
into
the
vestibule
,
where
there
was
a
large
wooden
statue
of
the
Virgin
,
and
clasping
his
arms
around
it
pressed
his
lips
to
the
feet
of
the
image
.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
by
Streete
,
with
his
drawn
sword
in
one
hand
and
a
petronel
in
the
other
,
prepared
to
finish
his
work
.
<EOS>
But
ere
he
could
reach
him
,
Catesby
had
expired
.
<EOS>
"So
,
"
exclaimed
Topcliffe
,
who
came
up
the
next
moment
,
with
Sir
Richard
Walsh
,
"
we
have
been
robbed
of
our
prey
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
of
Salisbury
will
never
forgive
me
for
this
disappointment
.
<EOS>
""I
am
glad
I
have
done
it
,
though
,
"
observed
Streete
.
"
<EOS>
To
kill
two
such
traitors
with
one
shot
is
something
to
talk
of
.
<EOS>
""You
will
be
well
rewarded
for
it
,
no
doubt
,
"
remarked
Topcliffe
,
sarcastically
.
<EOS>
"I
care
not
whether
I
am
or
not
,
"
rejoined
Streete
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
my
duty
,
and
besides
I
have
avenged
my
comrade
,
Richard
Trueman
,
who
was
shot
by
this
traitor
when
he
read
the
proclamation
.
<EOS>
""I
will
take
care
that
your
brave
action
is
duly
represented
to
his
Majesty
,
"
observed
Sir
Richard
Walsh
.
<EOS>
And
he
failed
not
to
keep
his
promise
.
<EOS>
Streete
received
a
pension
of
two
shillings
a
day
for
the
rest
of
his
life
—
no
inconsiderable
sum
in
those
days
.
<EOS>
The
conflict
was
now
at
an
end
,
for
though
some
few
of
the
more
desperate
of
the
rebels
continued
to
struggle
after
their
leaders
had
fallen
,
they
were
soon
disarmed
.
<EOS>
Sir
Richard
Walsh
and
Topcliffe
went
in
search
of
the
other
conspirators
,
and
finding
Rookwood
and
Grant
,
who
though
severely
wounded
were
not
dead
,
lying
in
the
hall
,
immediately
secured
them
.
<EOS>
Rookwood
on
their
approach
made
an
effort
to
plunge
his
dagger
into
his
breast
,
but
his
hand
was
stayed
by
Sir
Richard
Walsh
.
"We
<EOS>
shall
not
go
away
quite
empty
-
handed
,
"
cried
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"
But
these
are
sorry
substitutes
for
Catesby
.
<EOS>
"Has
<EOS>
Catesby
escaped
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Grant
,
faintly
.
<EOS>
"Ay
,
to
the
other
world
,
"
replied
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"He
<EOS>
has
kept
his
word
,
"
groaned
Grant
.
<EOS>
"He
may
have
escaped
some
part
of
his
punishment
,
"
said
Topcliffe
,
bitterly
;
"
but
the
worst
remains
.
<EOS>
His
quarters
will
be
exposed
on
every
gate
in
London
,
and
his
head
on
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
As
to
you
,
traitors
,
you
know
your
doom
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
are
prepared
for
it
,
"
rejoined
Grant
.
<EOS>
A
guard
being
left
over
the
prisoners
,
Sir
Richard
Walsh
and
Topcliffe
then
went
to
see
that
the
other
captives
were
properly
secured
.
<EOS>
Some
few
having
made
their
escape
into
the
adjoining
fields
,
they
were
pursued
and
recaptured
.
<EOS>
The
whole
of
the
prisoners
were
then
conveyed
to
Stourbridge
,
where
they
were
lodged
in
the
gaol
,
after
which
Sir
Richard
Walsh
despatched
a
messenger
to
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
and
the
Lords
of
the
Council
acquainting
them
with
what
he
had
done
.
<EOS>
VI
.
—
<EOS>
HAGLEYRobert
Winter
,
it
may
be
remembered
,
immediately
after
the
explosion
,
quitted
Holbeach
,
and
did
not
return
to
it
.
<EOS>
He
proceeded
to
the
neighbouring
thicket
,
and
while
wandering
about
in
a
state
bordering
on
distraction
encountered
Stephen
Littleton
,
who
had
likewise
deserted
his
companions
on
the
same
day
.
<EOS>
Acquainting
him
with
the
disastrous
occurrence
that
had
taken
place
,
and
stating
his
impression
that
both
God
and
man
were
against
them
,
and
that
it
would
be
vain
as
well
as
impious
to
struggle
longer
,
he
proposed
to
him
to
surrender
.
<EOS>
But
Stephen
Littleton
so
strongly
combated
this
opinion
,
that
he
at
last
consented
to
make
an
effort
to
escape
.
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
was
no
easy
matter
,
nor
could
they
devise
a
plan
that
appeared
feasible
.
<EOS>
Both
were
well
provided
with
money
;
but
under
present
circumstances
it
would
be
of
little
use
to
them
.
<EOS>
A
large
price
being
set
on
their
heads
,
and
the
whole
country
alarmed
,
they
scarcely
knew
where
to
seek
shelter
.
<EOS>
After
a
long
debate
,
they
quitted
the
covert
,
and
keeping
clear
of
all
habitations
,
took
the
direction
of
Stourbridge
.
<EOS>
On
approaching
the
Stour
,
at
a
point
opposite
Churchill
,
where
they
knew
the
river
was
fordable
,
they
perceived
Sir
Richard
Walsh
's
force
approaching
,
and
threw
themselves
into
a
ditch
to
avoid
observation
.
<EOS>
It
was
quite
dark
when
they
again
ventured
forth
,
and
at
the
peril
of
their
lives
they
forded
the
Stour
,
which
was
swollen
more
than
it
had
been
in
the
morning
by
the
long
-
continued
rain
.
<EOS>
Their
design
was
to
proceed
to
Hagley
,
the
residence
of
Stephen
Littleton
's
sister
,
Mrs.
Littleton
,
and
to
claim
her
protection
.
<EOS>
This
magnificent
mansion
lay
about
two
miles
on
the
other
side
of
the
river
,
in
the
heart
of
an
extensive
park
,
but
they
were
obliged
to
take
a
circuitous
route
of
nearly
double
the
distance
to
reach
it
,
and
when
at
length
they
arrived
there
,
and
were
about
to
steal
into
the
court
-
yard
;
they
found
it
occupied
by
a
portion
of
Sir
Richard
Walsh
's
troop
.
<EOS>
Overcome
by
anxiety
and
fatigue
,
and
scarcely
knowing
whither
to
proceed
,
they
recrossed
the
park
,
and
sought
out
the
cottage
of
a
poor
woman
,
whose
two
sons
had
joined
their
ill
-
fated
expedition
,
and
were
at
that
moment
under
arms
at
Holbeach
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
good
Catholic
,
and
they
thought
they
might
confide
in
her
.
<EOS>
Arriving
at
her
cottage
,
they
glanced
in
at
the
window
,
and
perceiving
her
,
as
they
concluded
,
alone
,
and
cooking
a
small
piece
of
meat
at
the
fire
,
they
raised
the
latch
,
and
entered
the
house
.
<EOS>
The
woman
turned
at
their
approach
,
and
uttering
a
cry
of
surprise
and
alarm
,
pointed
towards
a
back
room
.
<EOS>
They
then
saw
that
they
had
betrayed
themselves
;
but
the
caution
came
too
late
,
and
a
stalwart
trooper
,
alarmed
by
the
cry
,
issued
from
the
back
room
.
<EOS>
From
the
wretched
appearance
of
the
new
-
comers
,
he
at
once
guessed
that
they
were
rebels
,
and
felt
satisfied
,
from
the
richness
of
their
apparel
,
dirtied
and
stained
as
it
was
,
that
they
were
persons
of
consequence
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
drew
a
brace
of
petronels
,
and
holding
them
at
their
heads
,
commanded
them
to
surrender
.
<EOS>
They
were
too
much
taken
by
surprise
,
and
too
enfeebled
to
offer
resistance
,
and
the
trooper
calling
to
the
old
woman
to
bring
a
cord
to
bind
them
,
at
the
same
time
unloosed
his
own
girdle
,
with
which
he
fastened
Robert
Winter
's
arms
behind
his
back
.
<EOS>
In
doing
this
,
he
was
compelled
to
lay
down
his
petronels
,
and
he
had
scarcely
done
so
,
when
the
woman
snatched
them
up
,
and
gave
them
to
Stephen
Littleton
,
who
presented
them
at
his
head
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
the
turn
of
the
conspirators
to
triumph
.
<EOS>
In
another
instant
,
Robert
Winter
was
released
by
the
old
woman
,
and
the
pair
throwing
themselves
upon
the
trooper
,
forced
him
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
They
then
dragged
him
to
the
back
room
,
and
stripped
him
of
his
habiliments
,
which
Stephen
Littleton
put
on
instead
of
his
own
attire
,
and
binding
him
hand
and
foot
,
returned
to
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
At
the
request
of
Robert
Winter
,
she
furnished
him
with
a
suit
of
clothes
belonging
to
one
of
her
sons
,
and
then
set
before
them
the
best
eatables
she
possessed
.
<EOS>
They
were
ravenously
hungry
,
and
soon
disposed
of
the
viands
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
their
hostess
told
them
that
the
whole
country
was
in
arms
against
them
;
that
Mrs.
Littleton
being
suspected
,
though
she
had
always
been
adverse
to
the
design
,
her
house
had
undergone
a
rigorous
search
;
but
that
Mr.
Humphrey
Littleton
,
not
having
taken
any
part
in
the
insurrection
,
had
not
as
yet
been
arrested
,
though
it
was
feared
he
would
be
proved
to
be
connected
with
the
plot
.
<EOS>
She
concluded
by
strongly
counselling
them
to
use
the
utmost
caution
,
and
to
expose
themselves
as
little
as
possible
.
<EOS>
They
assured
her
she
need
have
no
apprehension
on
that
score
,
and
expressed
great
anxiety
as
to
what
would
befal
her
when
they
were
pone
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
do
not
desire
to
shed
blood
,
if
it
can
be
helped
,
"
said
Stephen
Littleton
;
"
but
in
a
case
of
necessity
,
like
the
present
,
where
life
must
be
weighed
against
life
,
I
hold
it
lawful
to
shed
it
.
<EOS>
Shall
we
put
the
trooper
to
death?""Not
unless
your
own
safety
requires
it
,
good
sirs
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
quit
this
cottage
soon
after
you
have
left
it
,
and
obtain
a
safe
asylum
with
one
of
my
neighbours
.
<EOS>
It
matters
not
what
becomes
of
me
.
<EOS>
Having
lost
my
two
sons,—for
I
consider
them
as
already
dead,—I
have
nothing
left
to
bind
me
to
life
.
<EOS>
"Unable
<EOS>
to
make
any
reply
,
the
conspirators
remained
for
some
time
silent
,
when
,
by
the
poor
woman
's
advice
,
they
withdrew
to
an
upper
chamber
,
and
stretching
themselves
on
a
bed
,
sought
a
few
hours
'
repose
.
<EOS>
The
old
woman
kept
watch
below
,
and
they
gave
her
one
of
the
petronels
,
with
strict
injunctions
to
blow
out
the
trooper
's
brains
if
he
attempted
to
move
.
<EOS>
Nothing
,
however
,
occurred
to
alarm
her
,
and
at
three
o'clock
she
awakened
them
.
<EOS>
Offering
the
woman
a
handsome
reward
,
which
,
however
,
she
declined
,
they
then
set
out
;
and
shortly
afterwards
their
hostess
quitted
her
habitation
,
and
withdrew
to
the
cottage
of
a
neighbour
,
where
she
remained
concealed
for
some
weeks
,
and
then
died
of
grief
on
learning
that
her
sons
had
been
slain
during
the
assault
of
Holbeach
by
the
royalists
.
<EOS>
Recruited
by
the
rest
they
had
enjoyed
,
the
conspirators
pursued
their
course
over
the
fields
.
<EOS>
The
weather
was
the
same
as
that
which
disheartened
their
confederates
at
Holbeach
,
and
the
rain
fell
so
heavily
that
they
had
soon
not
a
dry
thread
upon
them
.
<EOS>
But
being
now
disguised
,
they
were
not
under
so
much
apprehension
of
detection
.
<EOS>
Shaping
their
course
towards
Rowley
Regis
,
in
Staffordshire
,
which
lay
about
five
miles
from
Hagley
,
where
a
farmer
named
Pelborrow
,
a
tenant
of
Humphrey
Littleton
,
resided
,
and
whom
they
thought
would
befriend
them
,
they
proceeded
swiftly
on
their
way
;
but
,
though
well
acquainted
with
the
country
,
they
were
so
bewildered
and
deceived
by
the
fog
,
that
they
strayed
materially
out
of
their
course
,
and
when
it
grew
light
found
themselves
near
Weoley
Castle
,
and
about
four
miles
from
Birmingham
.
<EOS>
Confiding
in
their
disguises
,
and
in
their
power
of
sustaining
the
characters
they
assumed
,
they
got
into
the
high
road
,
and
approaching
a
farm
-
house
,
Stephen
Littleton
,
who
had
tied
his
companion
's
arms
behind
him
with
his
belt
,
represented
himself
as
a
trooper
conveying
a
prisoner
from
Stourbridge
to
Birmingham
,
and
in
consequence
of
this
obtained
a
breakfast
from
the
farmer
.
<EOS>
After
their
meal
was
over
,
the
host
,
who
had
eyed
them
suspiciously
,
observed
to
the
supposed
trooper,—"You
will
overtake
some
of
your
comrades
before
you
reach
Egbaston
,
and
had
better
lose
no
time
in
joining
them
.
<EOS>
You
are
known
to
me
,
my
masters
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
tone
that
could
not
be
heard
by
the
household
;
"
but
I
will
not
betray
you
.
<EOS>
Get
you
gone
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
conspirators
did
not
fail
to
act
upon
the
suggestion
,
and
as
soon
as
they
got
out
of
sight
,
struck
across
the
county
in
the
direction
of
Rowley
Regis
,
and
arrived
at
the
farm
-
house
which
was
their
destination
in
about
an
hour
.
<EOS>
Pelborrow
chanced
to
be
in
a
barn
adjoining
his
house
,
and
alone
,
and
on
seeing
them
readily
offered
to
hide
them
.
<EOS>
No
one
had
noticed
their
approach
,
and
carefully
concealing
them
amid
the
hay
in
the
loft
,
he
proceeded
about
his
business
as
if
nothing
had
happened
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
just
then
procure
them
provisions
without
exciting
suspicion
;
but
when
night
arrived
brought
them
a
sufficient
supply
for
the
next
day
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
they
passed
nearly
a
week
,
never
venturing
to
stir
forth
,
for
they
had
been
traced
to
the
neighbourhood
,
and
constant
search
was
going
on
after
them
.
<EOS>
Pelborrow
had
great
difficulty
in
keeping
his
men
out
of
the
barn
,
and
the
disappearance
of
the
provisions
excited
the
suspicions
of
his
female
domestics
,
who
began
to
think
all
was
not
right
.
<EOS>
He
therefore
intimated
to
the
conspirators
that
they
must
change
their
quarters
,
and
in
the
dead
of
the
night
,
they
removed
to
the
house
of
another
farmer
named
Perkes
,
residing
on
the
borders
of
Hagley
Park
,
to
whom
Pelborrow
had
confided
the
secret
of
their
being
in
the
neighbourhood
,
and
who
,
on
promise
of
a
large
reward
,
readily
undertook
to
secrete
them
.
<EOS>
Perkes
met
them
at
a
little
distance
from
his
house
,
and
conducted
them
to
a
barley
-
mow
,
where
he
had
contrived
a
hiding
-
place
amid
the
straw
for
them
.
<EOS>
A
woman
-
servant
and
a
man
were
both
let
into
the
secret
by
Perkes
,
and
a
sum
of
money
,
given
him
for
that
purpose
by
the
conspirators
,
bribed
them
to
silence
.
<EOS>
Here
they
remained
close
prisoners
,
unable
to
stir
forth
,
or
even
to
change
their
habiliments
for
nearly
six
weeks
,
during
which
time
they
received
constant
intelligence
from
their
protector
of
what
was
going
forward
,
and
learnt
that
the
search
for
them
had
not
relaxed
.
<EOS>
They
were
not
without
hope
,
however
,
that
the
worst
was
over
,
when
an
incident
occurred
that
gave
them
serious
uneasiness
.
<EOS>
One
night
,
Perkes
,
who
was
a
stout
,
hale
yeoman
,
and
had
formerly
been
warrener
to
Mrs.
Littleton
,
went
to
catch
conies
,
with
a
companion
named
Poynter
,
and
returned
laden
with
spoil
.
<EOS>
After
drinking
a
cup
or
two
of
ale
together
,
the
pair
separated
,
and
Poynter
feeling
fatigued
with
his
exertions
,
as
well
as
drowsy
with
the
liquor
he
had
swallowed
,
determined
to
pass
the
night
in
his
friend
's
barn
,
and
entering
it
,
clambered
up
to
the
loft
,
and
laid
himself
in
the
straw
.
<EOS>
In
doing
this
,
he
slipped
into
the
hole
made
for
the
conspirators
,
who
,
aroused
by
his
fall
,
instantly
seized
him
.
<EOS>
Terrified
to
death
,
and
fancying
he
had
fallen
into
the
hands
of
gipsies
or
other
plunderers
,
Poynter
roared
for
mercy
,
which
they
were
not
at
first
disposed
to
show
him
;
but
the
poor
wretch
,
finding
into
whose
hands
he
had
fallen
,
besought
them
in
such
piteous
terms
to
spare
his
life
,
affirming
with
the
strongest
oaths
that
he
would
never
betray
them
,
that
they
consented
to
spare
him
,
on
condition
of
his
remaining
with
them
as
long
as
they
should
occupy
their
place
of
concealment
.
<EOS>
When
Perkes
appeared
in
the
morning
,
he
was
not
a
little
surprised
at
finding
his
comrade
caught
in
such
a
trap
,
but
entirely
approved
of
the
course
taken
by
the
conspirators
.
<EOS>
Poynter
,
as
may
be
supposed
,
was
no
willing
captive
;
and
being
constantly
pondering
on
the
means
of
escape
,
and
of
obtaining
the
reward
for
the
apprehension
of
the
conspirators
,
at
last
hit
upon
the
following
expedient
.
<EOS>
While
engaged
in
the
poaching
expedition
with
Perkes
,
he
had
received
a
slight
wound
in
the
leg
,
and
the
close
confinement
to
which
he
was
now
subjected
inflamed
it
to
such
a
degree
as
to
render
it
highly
dangerous
.
<EOS>
This
he
represented
to
the
conspirators
,
who
,
however
,
would
not
suffer
him
to
depart
;
but
desired
Perkes
to
bring
him
some
ointment
to
dress
his
wound
.
<EOS>
The
request
was
complied
with
,
and
feigning
that
it
was
necessary
to
approach
the
light
to
apply
the
salve
,
Poynter
scrambled
up
the
straw
,
apparently
for
that
sole
purpose
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
attempt
to
fly
for
several
days
;
but
at
last
,
when
they
were
grown
less
suspicious
,
he
slided
down
the
other
side
of
the
loft
,
and
made
good
his
retreat
.
<EOS>
The
conspirators
saw
the
error
they
had
committed
when
too
late
.
<EOS>
Not
daring
to
pursue
him
,
they
remained
in
fearful
anticipation
of
an
arrest
throughout
the
day
.
<EOS>
But
they
were
not
disturbed
until
night
,
when
Perkes
made
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
They
told
him
what
had
happened
;
but
he
did
not
appear
to
be
much
alarmed
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
do
not
think
you
need
be
afraid
of
him
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
have
some
money
,
and
I
will
go
in
quest
of
him
at
once
,
and
bribe
him
to
silence
.
<EOS>
""Here
are
fifty
marks
,
"
replied
Stephen
Littleton
.
<EOS>
"
If
that
is
not
enough
,
take
more
.
<EOS>
""It
will
amply
suffice
,
"
replied
Perkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
answer
for
his
silence
.
<EOS>
"This
assurance
greatly
relieved
the
conspirators
,
and
they
were
made
completely
easy
by
the
return
of
Perkes
in
less
than
an
hour
afterwards
,
who
told
them
he
had
seen
Poynter
,
and
had
given
him
the
money
,
binding
him
by
the
most
solemn
oaths
not
to
betray
them
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
have
still
better
news
for
you
,
my
masters
,
"
he
added
.
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Littleton
has
set
out
for
London
to
-
day
;
and
I
have
received
orders
from
Mr.
Humphrey
Littleton
to
bring
you
to
the
hall
at
midnight
.
<EOS>
"This
<EOS>
last
intelligence
completed
their
satisfaction
,
and
they
awaited
Perkes
's
return
with
impatience
.
<EOS>
Shortly
before
midnight
,
he
came
to
summon
them
,
and
they
set
forth
together
.
<EOS>
Perkes
's
house
lay
about
a
mile
from
the
hall
,
and
they
soon
entered
the
park
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
clear
and
frosty,—it
was
now
the
middle
of
December,—and
as
the
conspirators
trod
the
crisp
sod
,
and
gazed
at
the
noble
but
leafless
trees
around
them
,
they
silently
returned
thanks
to
Heaven
for
their
restoration
to
freedom
.
<EOS>
Humphrey
Littleton
was
waiting
for
them
at
the
end
of
an
avenue
near
the
mansion
,
and
tenderly
embraced
them
.
<EOS>
Tears
of
joy
were
shed
on
both
sides
,
and
it
seemed
to
Humphrey
Littleton
as
if
his
brother
had
been
restored
from
the
grave
.
<EOS>
Dismissing
Perkes
with
warm
thanks
,
and
promises
of
a
further
recompence
,
they
then
entered
the
house
by
a
window
,
which
had
been
left
purposely
open
.
<EOS>
Humphrey
Littleton
conducted
them
to
his
own
chamber
,
where
fresh
apparel
was
provided
for
them
;
and
to
poor
wretches
who
had
not
been
able
to
put
off
their
attire
for
so
long
a
period
,
the
luxury
of
the
change
was
indescribably
great
.
<EOS>
The
arrival
of
the
fugitives
was
kept
secret
from
all
the
household
except
the
man
-
cook
,
John
Ocklie
,
upon
whose
fidelity
Humphrey
Littleton
thought
he
could
rely
.
<EOS>
A
good
supper
was
prepared
by
this
man
,
and
brought
up
into
his
master
's
chamber
,
where
the
conspirators
were
now
seated
before
a
hearth
heaped
with
blazing
logs
.
<EOS>
The
conspirators
needed
no
solicitation
to
fall
to
,
and
they
did
ample
justice
to
the
good
things
before
them
.
<EOS>
His
spirits
being
raised
by
the
good
cheer
,
Robert
Winter
observed
to
the
cook
,
who
was
in
attendance
upon
them,"Ah
!
<EOS>
Jack
,
thy
mistress
little
thinks
what
guests
are
now
in
her
house
,
who
have
neither
seen
fire
nor
tasted
a
hot
morsel
for
well
-
nigh
two
months
.
<EOS>
""Ay
,
it
is
a
sad
matter
,
"
returned
the
cook
,
shaking
his
head
,
"
and
I
wish
I
could
offer
your
worships
a
flask
of
wine
,
or
a
cup
of
stout
ale
at
the
least
.
<EOS>
But
the
butler
is
in
bed
,
and
if
I
were
to
rouse
him
at
this
hour
it
might
excite
his
suspicion
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
willing
,
sir
,
"
he
added
,
to
Humphrey
Littleton
,
"
I
will
hie
to
my
mother
's
cottage
in
the
park
,
and
bring
a
jug
of
ale
from
her
.
<EOS>
"This
was
agreed
to
,
and
the
cook
left
the
house
.
<EOS>
His
sole
object
,
however
,
was
to
instruct
his
mother
to
give
the
alarm
,
so
that
the
conspirators
might
be
arrested
before
morning
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
her
cottage
,
he
was
surprised
to
see
a
light
within
it
,
and
two
men
there
,
one
of
whom
was
Poynter
,
and
the
other
Mrs.
Littleton
's
steward
,
Robert
Hazlewood
.
<EOS>
Poynter
had
acquainted
Hazlewood
with
all
he
knew
respecting
the
conspirators
,
supposing
them
still
in
the
barley
-
mow
,
and
they
were
discussing
the
best
means
of
arresting
them
,
when
the
cook
entered
the
house
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
birds
are
flown
,
"
he
said
,
"
as
you
will
find
,
if
you
search
the
nest
.
<EOS>
But
come
to
the
hall
with
a
sufficient
force
betimes
to
-
morrow
morning
,
and
I
will
show
you
where
to
find
them
.
<EOS>
I
shall
claim
,
however
,
my
share
of
the
reward
,
though
I
must
not
appear
in
the
matter
.
"Having
<EOS>
fully
arranged
their
plan
,
he
procured
the
ale
from
his
mother
,
and
returned
to
the
hall
.
<EOS>
The
conspirators
soon
disposed
of
the
jug
,
threw
themselves
on
a
couch
in
the
room
,
and
instantly
dropping
asleep
,
enjoyed
such
repose
as
only
falls
to
the
lot
of
those
who
have
similarly
suffered
.
<EOS>
And
it
was
well
they
did
sleep
soundly
,
for
it
was
the
last
tranquil
night
<EOS>
they
ever
enjoyed!Humphrey
Littleton
,
who
,
as
has
been
stated
,
reposed
implicit
confidence
in
the
cook
,
had
committed
the
key
of
the
chamber
to
him
,
strictly
enjoining
him
to
call
them
in
the
morning
;
and
the
fellow
,
feeling
secure
of
his
prey
,
retired
to
rest
.
<EOS>
About
seven
o'clock
,
he
burst
suddenly
into
the
room
,
and
with
a
countenance
of
well
-
feigned
alarm
,
which
struck
tenor
into
the
breasts
of
the
conspirators
,
<EOS>
cried—"Master
Hazlewood
and
the
officers
are
below
,
and
say
they
must
search
the
house
.
<EOS>
Poynter
is
with
them
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
villain
has
betrayed
us
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Stephen
Littleton
.
<EOS>
"
Fools
that
we
were
to
spare
his
life!""There
is
no
use
in
lamenting
your
indiscretion
now
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
cook
;
"
leave
it
to
me
,
and
I
will
yet
effect
your
escape
.
<EOS>
""We
<EOS>
place
ourselves
entirely
in
your
hands
,
"
said
Stephen
Littleton
.
<EOS>
"Go
<EOS>
down
stairs
,
sir
,
"
said
the
cook
to
Humphrey
Littleton
,
"
and
hold
Master
Hazlewood
in
conversation
for
a
few
minutes
,
and
I
will
engage
to
get
the
gentlemen
safely
out
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
"Humphrey
<EOS>
Littleton
obeyed
,
and
descending
to
the
steward
,
told
him
he
was
willing
to
conduct
him
to
every
room
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
"I
am
certain
they
are
here
,
and
shall
not
quit
it
till
I
find
them
,
"
rejoined
Hazlewood
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
as
if
struck
by
a
sudden
thought
,
"
you
say
they
are
not
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
they
are
in
the
garden
—
in
the
summer
-
house
?
<EOS>
We
will
go
and
see
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
he
took
half
-
a
-
dozen
of
his
men
with
him
,
leaving
Poynter
and
the
rest
with
Humphrey
Littleton
,
who
was
perplexed
and
alarmed
at
his
conduct
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
cook
led
the
two
conspirators
along
the
gallery
,
and
from
thence
down
a
back
staircase
,
which
brought
them
to
a
small
door
communicating
with
the
garden
.
<EOS>
A
few
seconds
were
lost
in
opening
it
,
and
when
they
issued
forth
they
encountered
Hazlewood
and
his
men
,
who
instantly
arrested
them
.
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
conspirators
were
conveyed
under
a
strong
guard
to
London
,
where
they
were
committed
to
the
Tower
,
to
take
their
trial
with
their
confederates
.
<EOS>
VII
.
<EOS>
—
<EOS>
VIVIANA
'S
<EOS>
LAST
NIGHT
<EOS>
AT
ORDSALL
HALLOn
the
evening
of
the
third
day
after
quitting
Dunchurch
<EOS>
,
Viviana
Radcliffe
and
her
companions
arrived
at
Ordsall
Hall
.
<EOS>
They
had
encountered
many
dangers
and
difficulties
on
the
journey
,
and
were
well
-
nigh
overcome
with
fatigue
and
anxiety
.
<EOS>
Fearful
of
being
detained
,
Garnet
had
avoided
all
the
larger
towns
in
the
way
,
and
had
consequently
been
driven
greatly
out
of
the
direct
course
.
<EOS>
He
had
assumed
the
disguise
which
he
usually
wore
when
travelling
,
that
of
a
lawyer
,
and
as
he
possessed
great
mimetic
talent
,
he
sustained
the
character
admirably
.
<EOS>
Viviana
passed
for
his
daughter
,
and
his
servant
,
Nicholas
Owen
,
who
was
almost
as
clever
an
actor
as
his
master
,
represented
his
clerk
,
while
the
two
attendants
performed
the
parts
of
clients
.
<EOS>
At
Abbots'-Bromley
,
where
they
halted
for
refreshment
on
the
second
day
,
having
spent
the
night
at
a
small
village
near
Lichfield
,
they
were
detained
by
the
landlord
,
who
entertained
some
suspicions
of
them
;
but
Garnet
succeeded
in
frightening
the
man
into
allowing
them
to
depart
.
<EOS>
They
underwent
another
alarm
of
the
same
kind
at
Leek
,
and
were
for
two
hours
locked
up
.
<EOS>
But
on
the
arrival
of
a
magistrate
,
who
had
been
sent
for
by
the
host
,
Garnet
gave
so
plausible
an
account
of
himself
that
the
party
were
instantly
set
at
liberty
,
and
arrived
without
further
molestation
at
their
journey
's
end
.
<EOS>
Viviana
's
last
visit
to
the
hall
had
been
sad
enough
,
but
it
was
not
so
sad
as
the
present
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
dull
November
evening
,
and
the
wind
moaned
dismally
through
the
trees
,
scattering
the
yellow
leaves
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
The
house
looked
forlorn
and
desolate
.
<EOS>
No
smoke
issued
from
the
chimneys
,
nor
was
there
any
external
indication
that
it
was
inhabited
.
<EOS>
The
drawbridge
was
down
,
and
as
they
passed
over
it
,
the
hollow
trampling
of
their
steeds
upon
the
planks
vibrated
painfully
upon
Viviana
's
heart
.
<EOS>
Before
dismounting
,
she
cast
a
wistful
look
around
,
and
surveyed
the
grass
-
grown
and
neglected
court
,
where
,
in
years
gone
by
,
she
had
sported
;
the
moat
on
whose
brink
she
had
lingered
;
and
the
surrounding
woods
,
which
she
had
never
looked
upon
,
even
on
a
dreary
day
like
the
present
,
and
when
they
were
robbed
in
some
measure
of
their
beauty
,
without
delight
.
<EOS>
Scanning
the
deserted
mansion
from
roof
to
foundation
,
she
traced
all
its
gables
,
angles
,
windows
,
doors
,
and
walls
,
and
claimed
every
piece
of
carved
work
,
every
stone
as
a
familiar
object
,
and
as
associated
with
other
and
happier
hours
.
<EOS>
"It
is
but
the
wreck
of
what
it
was
,
"
she
thought
.
<EOS>
"
The
spirit
that
animated
it
is
fled
.
<EOS>
Grass
grows
in
its
courts
—
no
cheerful
voices
echo
in
its
chambers
—
no
hospitality
is
maintained
in
its
hall
—
but
neglect
,
gloom
,
and
despair
claim
it
as
their
own
.
<EOS>
The
habitation
and
its
mistress
are
well
matched
.
<EOS>
"Guessing
<EOS>
from
the
melancholy
expression
of
her
countenance
what
was
passing
within
,
and
thinking
it
advisable
to
turn
the
current
of
her
thoughts
,
Garnet
assisted
her
to
alight
,
and
committing
the
care
of
their
steeds
to
Owen
and
the
others
,
proceeded
with
her
to
the
principal
entrance
.
<EOS>
Everything
appeared
in
nearly
the
same
state
as
when
they
had
last
seen
it
,
and
the
only
change
that
had
taken
place
was
for
the
worse
.
<EOS>
The
ceilings
were
mapped
and
mildewed
with
damps
;
the
once
-
gorgeously
stained
glass
was
shivered
in
the
windows
;
the
costly
arras
hung
in
tattered
fragments
from
the
walls
;
while
the
floors
,
which
were
still
strewn
with
plaster
and
broken
furniture
,
were
flooded
with
the
moisture
that
had
found
its
way
through
the
holes
in
the
roof
.
<EOS>
"Bear
up
,
dear
daughter
,
"
said
Garnet
,
observing
that
Viviana
was
greatly
distressed
by
the
sight
,
"
and
let
the
contemplation
of
this
scene
of
havoc
,
instead
of
casting
you
down
,
inspire
you
with
just
indignation
against
enemies
from
whom
it
is
vain
to
expect
justice
or
mercy
.
<EOS>
How
many
Catholic
mansions
have
been
thus
laid
waste
!
<EOS>
How
many
high
-
born
and
honourable
men
,
whose
sole
fault
was
their
adherence
to
the
religion
of
their
fathers
,
and
their
refusal
to
subscribe
to
doctrines
against
which
their
consciences
revolted
,
have
been
put
to
death
like
your
father
;
nay
,
have
endured
a
worse
fate
,
for
they
have
languished
out
their
lives
in
prison
,
while
their
families
and
retainers
have
undergone
every
species
of
outrage
!
<EOS>
How
many
a
descendant
of
a
proud
line
,
distinguished
for
worth
,
for
loyalty
,
and
for
devotion
,
has
stood
,
as
you
now
stand
,
upon
his
desolate
hearth
—
has
seen
misery
and
ruin
usurp
the
place
of
comfort
and
happiness
—
and
has
heard
the
very
stones
beneath
his
feet
cry
out
for
vengeance
.
<EOS>
Accursed
be
our
oppressors
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
lifting
up
his
hands
,
and
elevating
his
voice
.
"
<EOS>
May
their
churches
be
thrown
down
—
their
faith
crushed
—
their
rights
invaded
—
their
children
delivered
to
bondage
—
their
hearths
laid
waste
,
as
ours
have
been
.
<EOS>
May
this
,
and
worse
come
to
pass
,
till
the
whole
stock
of
heresy
is
uprooted!""Hold
,
father
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Viviana
,
"
even
here
,
beholding
this
miserable
sight
,
and
with
feelings
keenly
excited
,
I
can
not
join
in
your
terrible
denunciation
.
<EOS>
What
I
hope
for
—
what
I
pray
for
,
is
toleration
,
not
vengeance
.
<EOS>
The
sufferings
of
our
brethren
will
not
have
been
in
vain
,
if
they
enable
our
successors
to
worship
God
in
their
own
way
,
and
according
to
the
dictates
of
their
consciences
.
<EOS>
The
ruthless
conduct
of
our
persecutors
must
be
held
in
as
much
abhorrence
by
all
good
Protestants
as
our
persecution
of
that
sect
,
when
we
were
in
the
ascendant
,
is
regarded
by
all
worthy
members
of
our
own
Church
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
believe
that
by
persecution
we
can
work
out
the
charitable
precepts
inculcated
by
our
Saviour
,
and
I
am
sure
such
a
course
is
as
adverse
to
the
spirit
of
religion
as
it
is
to
that
of
humanity
.
<EOS>
Let
us
bear
our
sorrows
with
patience,—let
us
utter
no
repinings
,
but
turn
the
other
cheek
to
the
smiter
,
and
we
shall
find
,
in
due
time
,
that
the
hearts
of
our
oppressors
will
relent
,
and
that
all
the
believers
in
the
True
God
will
be
enabled
to
worship
him
in
peace
,
though
at
different
altars
.
<EOS>
""Such
<EOS>
a
season
will
never
arrive
,
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
severely
,
"
till
heresy
is
extirpated
,
and
the
false
doctrines
now
prevailing
utterly
abolished
.
<EOS>
Then
,
indeed
,
when
the
Church
of
Rome
is
re
-
established
,
and
the
old
and
true
religion
restored
,
universal
peace
will
prevail
.
<EOS>
And
let
me
correct
the
grievous
and
sinful
error
into
which
you
have
fallen
.
<EOS>
Our
church
is
always
at
war
with
heresy
;
and
if
it
can
not
uproot
it
by
gentle
means
,
authorizes
,
nay
enjoins
<EOS>
the
employment
of
force
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
attempt
to
dispute
with
you
upon
points
of
faith
,
father
,
"
returned
Viviana
;
"
I
am
content
to
think
and
act
according
to
my
own
feelings
and
convictions
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
give
up
the
hope
that
in
some
milder
and
wiser
age
,
persecution
on
either
side
will
cease
,
and
the
sufferings
of
its
victims
be
remembered
only
to
soften
the
hearts
of
fanatics
,
of
whatever
creed
,
towards
each
other
.
<EOS>
Were
a
lesson
wanting
to
ourselves
,
surely
it
might
be
found
in
the
result
that
has
attended
your
dark
and
criminal
enterprise
,
and
in
which
the
disapproval
of
Heaven
has
been
signally
manifested
.
<EOS>
""Not
<EOS>
so
,
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
An
action
is
not
to
be
judged
or
justified
by
the
event
attending
it
,
but
by
its
own
intrinsic
merits
.
<EOS>
To
aver
the
contrary
were
to
throw
a
doubt
upon
the
Holy

themselves
,
where
we
read
in
the
Book

Judges
that
the
eleven

of
Israel
were
commanded
to
make
war
upon
the
tribe
of
Benjamin
,
and
yet
were
twice
defeated
.
<EOS>
We
have
failed
.
<EOS>
But
this
proves
nothing
against
our
project
,
which
I
maintain
to
be
righteous
and
praiseworthy
,
undertaken
to
overthrow
an
heretical
and
excommunicated
monarch
,
and
to
re
-
establish
the
true
faith
of
the
Most
High
throughout
this

.
<EOS>
""I
lament
to
find
that
you
still
persist
in
error
,
father
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Viviana
;
"
but
you
can
not
by
any

to
coincide
with
you
in
opinion
.
<EOS>
I
hold
the
attempt
an
offence
alike
against
God
and
man
,
and
while
I
rejoice
at
the
issue
that
has

,
I

the

it
will

to
the
whole

of
Catholics
,
all

connected
,
by

bigoted
and
unthinking
of

,

.
<EOS>
Not

have
you
done
our
cause
an
injury
,
but
you
have
in
a
measure
justified
our
opponents
'
severity
,
and
given
them
a
plea
for
further

.
<EOS>
""No

of
this
,
daughter
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
,

,
"
or
I
shall
deem
it
necessary
to

you
.
<EOS>
Let
us
search
the
house
,
and
try
to
find
some
habitable
chamber
in
which
you
can
pass
the
night
.
<EOS>
"After
<EOS>
a
long
search
,
they
discovered
a
room
in

,
and

within

,

Nicholas
Owen
,

.
"We
<EOS>
have

,
"

,
with

;
"
but

meal

,

,
which

.
<EOS>
""You

,

,
"
returned

.
"
<EOS>
But
take
heed

.
<EOS>
""Fear
nothing
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Owen
,
"
If
I
am
taken
,
your
reverence
will
lose
your

—
that
is
all
.
"He
<EOS>
then
set

upon

,
and

proceeded
to

,
where
,
to

,
he
found
the
hearthstone
still
warm
,
and
a

embers
upon

,
<EOS>
while

bread
,
and

,
proved
that
some

had
taken
a
meal
there
.
<EOS>
Startled

,

continued

,

as

;
and

any

to

,

was

.
<EOS>
One

attendants
had
placed
a
few

upon

ashes
,
and
on
returning
to
the
kitchen
,

that
they
had

.
<EOS>
A
fire

thus

,
some

was
used
to

,
and
by

's
commands
another
fire

speedily

in
Viviana
's

.
<EOS>
Night
had
now
come
on
,
and
Owen
not

,
Garnet
became
extremely
uneasy
,
and
had
almost
given

up
,
when
the
absentee
made

,

.
<EOS>
"I
have

some

in

,
"
he

;
"
and
fancying
I
observed
two

,
was

to

.
<EOS>
The

is
in

about

,
and
it

said
that
the
most
rigorous

are
to

.
"Sighing
<EOS>
at

,

,

.
<EOS>
She
ate
a
little

,
and

a

water
,
but

to

anything
else
,
and

in

to

,
Garnet

to

kitchen
,
where
,
being
much

,
he

with

and

.
<EOS>
Left
alone
,
Viviana
knelt
down
,
and
clasping
a
small

to
her

,
prayed
long
and
fervently
.
<EOS>
While
she
was
thus
engaged
,
she
heard
the
door
open
gently
behind
her
,
and
turning
her
head
,
beheld
an
old
man
clothed
in

,
with

hair
flowing

,
and

upon

.
<EOS>
As

advanced
slowly
towards

,
she
started
to
her

,
and
a
brighter
flame
arising
at

moment
from
the
fire
,
it
illumined
the
intruder
's
wobegone
features
.
<EOS>
"Is
it
possible
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed,—"can
it
be
my
father
's
old
steward
,
Jerome
Heydocke?""It
is
,
indeed
,
my
dear
young
mistress
,
"
replied
the
old
man
,
falling
on

before

.
"
<EOS>
Heaven
be
praised
!
"
<EOS>
he

,

,
and
bedewing

;
"
I
have
seen
you
once
again
,
and
shall
die
content
.
<EOS>
""I
never
expected
to
behold
you
more
,
good
Heydocke
,
"
returned
Viviana
,
raising

.
<EOS>
"
I
heard
you
had
died
in

.
<EOS>
""It
was
so
given
out
by
the

,
to
account

,
"

old

;
"

I

.
<EOS>
I
will
not

by

,
but
will
simply

I
was

,
<EOS>
whence
I

in

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
He

;

,

Martin

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
""Indeed
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
""As

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

ajar
,

,

.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"At

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"You
,

,

"

<EOS>
Heydocke

<EOS>

<EOS>

"Making

.
<EOS>
Viviana

<EOS>
Sleep

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"What

"

<EOS>
"You

,

,

"

<EOS>

resounded

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
"
<EOS>

,

"

.
<EOS>
Quick!—not

who

,
"

"Indeed

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
Admit

.
<EOS>
"Heydocke

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"Your
<EOS>

,
"

,

;
"

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Thus

<EOS>
""A

<EOS>
"Close

in

,

<EOS>
"My

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>

,
"

;
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
I
am
weary
of
my
life
,
and
would
gladly
resign
it
.
<EOS>
""I
would
call
to
your
recollection
,
Viviana
,
"
pursued
Dee
,
"
that
I
foretold
the
disastrous
result
of
this
plot
,
in
which
you
have
become
unhappily
involved
,
to
Guy
Fawkes
,
and
warned
him
not
to
proceed
in
it
.
<EOS>
But
he
would
not
be
advised
,
and
is
now
a
prisoner
in
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
""All
<EOS>
I
wish
is
to
go
thither
,
and
die
with
him
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
you
go
thither
,
you
will
die
before
him
,
"
said
Dee
.
<EOS>
"I
would
do
so
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
Radcliffe
,
"
returned
Dee
,
in
a
compassionate
tone
,
"
I
truly
grieve
for
you
.
<EOS>
Your
attachment
to
this
heinous
traitor
completely
blinds
you
.
<EOS>
The
friendship
I
entertained
for
your
mother
makes
me
anxious
to
serve
you
—
to
see
you
happy
.
<EOS>
It
is
now
in
your
power
to
be
so
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
take
another
false
step
,
your
fate
is
decided
,
and
you
will
die
an
early
death
.
<EOS>
I
will
answer
for
your
safety
—
nay
,
what
is
more
,
I
will
undertake
that
ere
long
you
shall
again
be
mistress
of
this
mansion
,
and
have
your
estates
restored
to
you
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
promise
fairly
,
sir
,
"
she
replied
,
with
a
mournful
smile
.
<EOS>
"I
have
not
yet
done
,
"
pursued
Dee
.
<EOS>
"
All
I
require
for
the
service
is
,
that
when
freed
by
the
death
of
Guy
Fawkes
from
the
chain
that
now
binds
you,—for
I
am
aware
of
your
ill
-
starred
union
with
him,—you
<EOS>
shall
bestow
your
hand
upon
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
""It
may
not
be
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
firmly
.
"
<EOS>
And
if
you
could
in
truth
read
the
secrets
of
the
heart
,
you
would
know
that
mine
would
instantly
reject
the
proposal
.
<EOS>
""Think
<EOS>
not
it
originates
with
me
,
Viviana
,
"
said
Humphrey
Chetham
,
who
had
approached
them
unobserved
.
<EOS>
"
My
previous
experience
of
your
character
would
alone
have
prevented
me
from
becoming
a
party
to
any
such
proposal
,
had
I
known
it
would
be
made
.
<EOS>
Do
not
,
I
beseech
you
,
sir
<EOS>
,
"
he
added
to
Dee
,
"
clog
your
offer
with
conditions
which
will
effectually
prevent
its
accomplishment
.
<EOS>
""You
are
true
to
yourself
,
Mr.
Chetham
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
,
"
and
will
not
,
therefore
,
wonder
that
I
continue
so
.
<EOS>
Were
I
to
assent
to
Doctor
Dee
's
proposal
,
I
should
be
further
from
happiness
than
I
am
now
,
even
if
he
could
make
good
his
words
,
and
restore
me
to
the
station
I
have
forfeited
.
<EOS>
I
have
received
a
shock
from
which
I
shall
never
recover
,
and
the
only
haven
of
repose
to
which
I
look
forward
is
the
grave
.
<EOS>
""Alas
!
"
exclaimed
Chetham
,
in
a
pitying
tone
.
<EOS>
"You
will
think
I
trespass
too
much
upon
your
kindness
,
"
she
pursued
;
"
but
you
can
render
me
a
great
service
,
and
it
will
be
the
last
I
shall
ever
require
from
you
.
<EOS>
""Name
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Chetham
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"I
would
beg
you
to
escort
me
to
London
,
"
she
rejoined
:
"
and
to
deliver
me
to
the
lords
of
the
council
.
<EOS>
I
would
willingly
escape
the
indignities
to
which
T
shall
be
exposed
if
I
am
conveyed
thither
as
a
prisoner
.
<EOS>
Will
you
do
this?""I
will
,
"
replied
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"Lest
<EOS>
you
should
think
I
have
offered
more
than
I
can
perform
,
Viviana
,
"
said
Dee
,
who
had
listened
attentively
to
the
foregoing
conversation
,
"
I
will
now
tell
you
on
what
grounds
<EOS>
I
build
my
expectation
of
procuring
your
pardon
.
<EOS>
The
conspiracy
was
first
revealed
by
me
to
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
though
for
his
own
purposes
he
kept
it
secret
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
He
owes
me
a
heavy
debt
,
and
shall
pay
it
in
the
way
I
propose
,
if
you
desire
it
.
<EOS>
""I
will
abide
by
what
I
have
done
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
know
,
then
,
what
fate
awaits
you
?
"
said
Dee
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
shall
not
shrink
from
it
,
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"It
is
well
,
"
he
replied
.
<EOS>
"
Before
I
leave
,
I
will
give
you
another
caution
.
<EOS>
Father
Garnet
is
here
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
attempt
not
to
deny
it
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
deceive
me
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
desire
to
serve
,
not
harm
him
.
<EOS>
If
he
remains
here
till
to
-
morrow
,
he
will
be
captured
.
<EOS>
A
proclamation
has
been
issued
for
his
arrest
,
as
well
as
for
that
of
Father
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
Deliver
him
this
warning
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
farewell!"With
this
,
he
took
up
his
lantern
,
and
followed
by
Kelley
,
quitted
the
hall
.
<EOS>
Humphrey
Chetham
only
tarried
a
few
moments
to
inform
Viviana
that
he
would
return
soon
after
daybreak
with
a
couple
of
steeds
for
the
journey
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
was
gone
,
Viviana
communicated
Dee
's
warning
to
Garnet
,
who
was
so
alarmed
by
it
,
that
he
resolved
not
to
delay
his
own
departure
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Taking
an
affectionate
leave
of
Viviana
,
and
confiding
her
to
the
care
of
the
old
steward
,
he
set
out
with
his
three
attendants
.
<EOS>
Faithful
to
his
promise
,
Humphrey
Chetham
appeared
at
the
appointed
time
.
<EOS>
Viviana
bade
an
eternal
farewell
to
the
old
steward
,
who
was
overwhelmed
with
grief
,
and
looked
as
if
his
sorrows
would
soon
be
ended
,
and
mounting
one
of
the
steeds
brought
by
the
young
merchant
,
they
took
the
direction
of
London
.
<EOS>
VIII
.
<EOS>
—
HENDLIPGarnet
proceeded
at
a
rapid
pace
for
some
miles
before
he
acquainted
his
companions
<EOS>
whither
he
was
going
.
<EOS>
He
then
informed
Nicholas
Owen
,
who
rode
by
his
side
,
that
he
should
make
the
best
of
his
way
to
Hendlip
House
,
the
seat
of
Mr.
Thomas
Abingdon
,
near
Droitwich
,
in
Worcestershire
,
where
he
knew
that
Father
Oldcorne
and
Anne
Vaux
had
retired
,
and
where
he
was
certain
to
meet
with
a
friendly
reception
and
protection
.
<EOS>
Owen
,
who
was
completely
in
his
master
's
confidence
,
agreed
that
no
safer
asylum
could
be
found
,
and
they
pursued
their
journey
with
so
much
ardour
,
that
early
on
the
following
night
they
arrived
within
a
short
distance
of
the
mansion
.
<EOS>
Owen
was
sent
forward
to
reconnoitre
,
and
returned
in
about
half
an
hour
with
Mr.
Abingdon
,
who
embraced
Garnet
,
and
told
him
he
was
truly
happy
in
being
able
to
offer
him
a
retreat
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
I
think
it
will
prove
a
secure
one
,
"
he
added
.
<EOS>
"
There
are
so
many
hiding
-
places
in
the
old
house
,
that
if
it
is
beset
for
a
year
you
will
scarcely
be
discovered
.
<EOS>
Have
you
heard
of
the
fate
of
your
confederates?""Alas
!
<EOS>
no
,
my
son
,
"
replied
Garnet
;
"
and
I
tremble
to
ask
it
.
<EOS>
""It
<EOS>
had
better
be
told
at
once
,
"
rejoined
Abingdon
.
<EOS>
"
Catesby
,
Percy
,
and
the
two
Wrights
,
have
been
slain
in
the
defence
of
Holbeach
;
while
Rookwood
,
Grant
,
and
Thomas
Winter
,
all
of
whom
were
severely
wounded
in
the
siege
,
have
been
made
prisoners
,
and
are
now
on
their
way
to
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
""A
fearful
catalogue
of
ills
!
"
exclaimed
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"It
is
not
yet
complete
,
"
pursued
Abingdon
.
"
<EOS>
Sir
Everard
Digby
has
been
defeated
,
and
made
prisoner
in
an
attempt
to
bring
additional
force
to
his
friends
,
and
Keyes
has
been
arrested
in
Warwickshire
.
<EOS>
""These
are
woful
tidings
<EOS>
truly
,
my
son
,
"
returned
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
Heaven
's
will
be
done!"He
then
dismissed
his
two
attendants
,
to
whom
he
gave
a
sum
of
money
,
together
with
the
steeds
,
and
attended
by
Nicholas
Owen
,
repaired
to
the
house
with
Mr.
Abingdon
,
who
admitted
them
through
a
secret
door
.
<EOS>
Hendlip
House
,
which
,
unfortunately
for
the
lovers
of
picturesque
and
storied
habitations
,
was
pulled
down
a
few
years
ago
,
having
been
latterly
used
as
a
ladies
'
boarding
-
school
,
was
a
large
and
irregular
structure
,
with
walls
of
immense
thickness
,
tall
stacks
of
chimneys
,
turrets
,
oriel
windows
,
and
numberless
projections
,
contrived
to
mask
the
labyrinths
and
secret
chambers
within
.
<EOS>
Erected
by
John
Abingdon
,
father
of
the
proprietor
at
the
period
of
this
history
,
and
cofferer
to
Queen
Elizabeth
in
the
early
part
of
the
reign
of
that
princess
,
it
was
filled
with
secret
staircases
,
masked
entrances
,
trap
-
doors
,
vaults
,
subterranean
passages
,
secret
recesses
,
and
every
other
description
of
hiding
-
place
.
<EOS>
An
immense
gallery
surrounded
three
sides
of
the
entrance
-
hall
,
containing
on
each
side
a
large
chimney
-
piece
,
surmounted
by
a
shield
displaying
the
arms
of
the
family
—
argent
,
a
bend
,
gules
,
three
eaglets
displayed
,
or
.
<EOS>
Behind
each
of
these
chimney
-
pieces
was
a
small
cell
,
or
"
priest's
-
hole
,
"
as
it
was
termed
,
contrived
in
the
thickness
of
the
wall
.
<EOS>
Throughout
the
mansion
,
the
chambers
were
so
sombre
,
and
the
passages
so
numerous
and
intricate
,
that
,
in
the
words
of
one
who
described
it
from
personal
observation
,
the
whole
place
presented
"
a
picture
of
gloom
,
insecurity
,
and
suspicion
.
"
<EOS>
Standing
on
an
elevated
situation
,
it
commanded
the
country
on
all
sides
,
and
could
not
be
approached
during
the
day
-
time
without
alarm
being
given
to
its
inmates
.
<EOS>
Thomas
Abingdon
,
the
owner
of
the
mansion
at
the
period
in
question
,
and
the
eldest
son
of
its
founder
,
was
born
at
Thorpe
,
near
Chertsey
,
in
Surrey
,
in
1560
.
<EOS>
He
was
educated
at
Oxford
,
and
finished
his
studies
at
the
Universities
of
Paris
and
Rheims
.
<EOS>
A
man
of
considerable
taste
and
learning
,
but
of
a
plotting
disposition
,
he
became
a
willing
tool
of
the
Jesuits
,
and
immediately
on
his
return
to
England
,
connected
himself
with
the
different
conspiracies
set
on
foot
for
the
liberation
of
the
imprisoned
Queen
of
Scots
.
<EOS>
For
these
offences
he
was
imprisoned
in
the
Tower
for
the
term
of
six
years
,
and
only
escaped
death
from
the
fact
of
his
being
the
Queen
's
godson
,
coupled
with
the
estimation
in
which
she
had
held
his
father
.
<EOS>
On
his
liberation
,
he
remained
perfectly
tranquil
till
the
accession
of
James
,
when
he
became
a
secret
plotter
against
that
monarch
.
<EOS>
His
concealment
of
the
two
priests
,
about
to
be
related
,
occasioned
his
being
again
sent
to
the
Tower
,
and
if
it
had
not
been
for
the
intercession
of
Lord
Mounteagle
,
whose
sister
he
had
espoused
,
he
would
have
been
executed
.
<EOS>
He
was
pardoned
on
condition
of
never
stirring
beyond
the
precincts
of
Worcestershire
,
and
he
employed
his
retirement
in
compiling
an
account
of
the
antiquities
of
that
county
,
which
he
left
behind
him
in
manuscript
,
and
of
which
Doctor
Nash
,
its
more
recent
historian
,
has
largely
availed
himself
.
<EOS>
With
a
habitation
so
contrived
,
Mr.
Abingdon
might
fairly
promise
his
guests
a
safe
asylum
.
<EOS>
Conducting
them
along
a
secret
passage
to
a
chamber
of
which
he
alone
possessed
the
key
,
he
left
Garnet
within
it
,
and
taking
Owen
with
him
to
another
place
of
concealment
,
returned
shortly
afterwards
with
Anne
Vaux
and
Father
Oldcorne
.
<EOS>
The
two
priests
tenderly
embraced
each
other
,
and
Oldcorne
poured
forth
his
tears
on
his
superior
's
shoulder
.
<EOS>
Garnet
next
turned
to
Anne
Vaux
,
between
whom
and
himself
,
as
has
been
before
mentioned
,
an
affectionate
intimacy
subsisted
,
and
found
her
quite
overcome
by
her
feelings
.
<EOS>
Supper
was
now
served
to
Garnet
by
a
confidential
servant
,
and
after
a
few
hours
spent
in
conversation
with
his
friends
,
during
which
they
discussed
the
disastrous
issue
of
the
affair
,
and
the
probable
fate
of
the
conspirators
,
they
quitted
him
,
and
he
retired
to
rest
—
but
not
before
he
had
returned
thanks
to
Heaven
for
enabling
him
once
more
to
lay
down
his
head
in
safety
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
,
he
was
visited
by
Mrs.
Abingdon
,
a
lady
of
considerable
personal
attractions
,
and
Anne
Vaux
;
and
when
he
had
recovered
from
the
fatigue
of
his
journey
,
and
the
anxieties
he
had
recently
undergone
,
he
experienced
great
delight
in
their
society
.
<EOS>
The
chamber
he
occupied
was
lighted
by
a
small
loop
-
hole
,
which
enabled
him
to
breathe
the
fresh
air
,
and
gaze
upon
the
surrounding
country
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
nearly
two
months
passed
on
,
during
which
,
though
rigorous
inquiries
were
made
throughout
the
country
,
no
clue
was
found
by
the
searchers
to
lead
them
to
Hendlip
;
and
the
concealed
parties
began
to
indulge
hopes
that
they
should
escape
detection
altogether
.
<EOS>
Being
in
constant
correspondence
with
her
brother
,
Lord
Mounteagle
,
though
she
did
not
trust
him
with
the
important
secret
of
the
concealment
of
the
priests
,
Mrs.
Abingdon
ascertained
all
that
was
done
in
reference
to
the
conspirators
,
whose
trials
were
now
approaching
,
and
communicated
the
intelligence
to
Garnet
.
<EOS>
On
the
morning
of
the
20th
of
January
,
and
when
long
quietude
had
bred
complete
fancied
security
in
Garnet
,
Anne
Vaux
and
Mrs.
Abingdon
suddenly
entered
his
chamber
,
and
with
countenances
of
the
utmost
alarm
,
informed
him
that
Mr.
Abingdon
's
confidential
servant
had
just
returned
from
Worcester
,
where
his
master
then
was
,
and
had
brought
word
that
Topcliffe
,
armed
with
a
search
-
warrant
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
had
just
passed
through
that
city
on
his
way
to
Holt
Castle
,
the
residence
of
Sir
Henry
Bromley
.
<EOS>
"It
appears
,
"
said
Mrs.
Abingdon
,
"
that
Humphrey
Littleton
,
who
has
been
apprehended
and
condemned
to
death
at
Worcester
for
harbouring
his
brother
and
Robert
Winter
,
has
sought
to
procure
a
remission
of
his
sentence
by
betraying
your
retreat
.
<EOS>
In
consequence
of
this
,
Topcliffe
has
been
sent
down
from
London
,
with
a
warrant
addressed
to
Sir
Henry
Bromley
,
to
aid
him
in
searching
Hendlip
.
<EOS>
My
husband
has
given
particular
orders
that
you
are
to
be
removed
to
the
most
secure
hiding
-
place
without
delay
;
and
he
deeply
regrets
that
he
himself
can
not
return
till
evening
,
for
fear
of
exciting
suspicion
.
<EOS>
""Take
me
where
you
please
,
daughter
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
who
was
thrown
into
great
perturbation
by
the
intelligence
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
myself
prepared
for
any
emergency
.
<EOS>
But
I
was
wofully
deceived
.
<EOS>
""Be
not
alarmed
,
father
,
"
said
Anne
Vaux
,
in
an
encouraging
tone
.
<EOS>
"
Let
them
search
as
long
as
they
will
,
they
will
never
discover
your
retreat
.
<EOS>
""I
have
a
strong
presentiment
to
the
contrary
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
Oldcorne
made
his
appearance
,
and
on
learning
the
alarming
news
,
was
as
much
dismayed
as
his
superior
.
<EOS>
After
a
short
consultation
,
and
while
the
priests
were
putting
aside
every
article
necessary
to
be
removed
,
Mrs.
Abingdon
proceeded
to
the
gallery
,
and
contrived
on
some
plausible
pretext
to
send
away
the
whole
of
the
domestics
from
this
part
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
she
hastily
returned
,
and
conducted
the
two
priests
to
one
of
the
large
fire
-
places
.
<EOS>
A
raised
stone
about
two
feet
high
occupied
the
inside
of
the
chimney
,
and
upon
it
stood
an
immense
pair
of
iron
dogs
.
<EOS>
Obeying
Mrs.
Abingdon
's
directions
,
Garnet
got
upon
the
stone
,
and
setting
his
foot
on
the
large
iron
knob
on
the
left
,
found
a
few
projections
in
the
masonry
on
the
side
,
up
which
he
mounted
,
and
opening
a
small
door
,
made
of
planks
of
wood
,
covered
with
bricks
,
and
coloured
black
,
so
as
not
to
be
distinguishable
from
the
walls
of
the
chimney
,
crept
into
a
recess
contrived
in
the
thickness
of
the
wall
.
<EOS>
This
cell
was
about
two
feet
wide
,
and
four
high
,
and
was
connected
with
another
chimney
at
the
back
,
by
means
of
three
or
four
small
holes
.
<EOS>
Around
its
sides
ran
a
narrow
stone
shelf
,
just
wide
enough
to
afford
an
uncomfortable
seat
.
<EOS>
Garnet
was
followed
by
Oldcorne
,
who
brought
with
him
a
quantity
of
books
,
vestments
,
and
sacred
vessels
used
in
the
performance
of
the
rites
of
the
Church
of
Rome
.
<EOS>
These
articles
,
which
afterwards
occasioned
them
much
inconvenience
,
they
did
not
dare
to
leave
behind
.
<EOS>
Having
seen
them
safely
bestowed
,
Mrs.
Abingdon
and
her
companion
went
in
search
of
provisions
,
and
brought
them
a
piece
of
cold
meat
and
a
pasty
,
together
with
some
bread
,
dried
fruit
,
conserves
,
and
a
flask
of
wine
.
<EOS>
They
did
not
dare
to
bring
more
,
for
fear
of
exciting
the
suspicion
of
the
household
.
<EOS>
Their
next
care
was
to
conduct
Owen
,
and
Oldcorne
's
servant
,
Chambers
,
to
a
similar
retreat
in
one
of
the
other
chimneys
,
and
to
provide
them
with
a
scanty
supply
of
provisions
and
a
flask
of
wine
.
<EOS>
All
this
was
accomplished
without
being
noticed
by
any
of
the
domestics
.
<EOS>
As
may
be
imagined
,
a
most
anxious
day
was
passed
by
all
parties
.
<EOS>
Towards
evening
,
Sir
Henry
Bromley
,
the
sheriff
of
the
county
,
accompanied
by
Topcliffe
,
and
attended
by
a
troop
of
soldiers
,
appeared
at
the
gates
of
the
mansion
,
and
demanded
admittance
.
<EOS>
Just
at
this
moment
,
Mr.
Abingdon
rode
up
,
and
affecting
to
know
nothing
of
the
matter
,
saluted
Sir
Henry
Bromley
,
with
whom
he
was
on
terms
of
intimacy
,
and
inquired
his
business
.
<EOS>
"You
are
charged
with
harbouring
two
Jesuit
priests
,
Fathers
Garnet
and
Oldcorne
,
supposed
to
be
connected
with
the
late
atrocious
conspiracy
against
the
King
,
Mr.
Abingdon
,
"
interposed
Topcliffe
;
"
and
I
brought
a
warrant
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
which
I
have
delivered
to
Sir
Henry
Bromley
,
commanding
him
to
search
your
house
for
them
.
<EOS>
""I
was
loth
to
accept
the
office
,
Mr.
Abingdon
,
"
said
Sir
Henry
Bromley
,
who
was
a
handsome
,
middle
-
aged
man
;
"
but
my
duty
to
my
sovereign
allows
me
no
alternative
.
<EOS>
I
trust
,
though
a
Catholic
,
that
you
share
my
own
detestation
of
this
diabolical
plot
,
and
would
not
shelter
any
of
its
contrivers
,
or
abettors
.
<EOS>
""You
judge
me
rightly
,
Sir
Henry
,
"
replied
Abingdon
,
who
,
meanwhile
,
had
received
a
private
signal
from
his
confidential
servant
that
all
was
safe
,
"
I
would
not
.
<EOS>
I
am
just
returned
from
Worcester
,
where
I
have
been
for
the
last
two
days
.
<EOS>
Enter
my
house
,
I
pray
you
,
and
search
every
corner
of
it
;
and
if
you
find
a
Jesuit
priest
concealed
within
it
,
you
shall
hang
me
at
my
own
gate
.
<EOS>
""You
must
be
misinformed
,
sir
,
"
observed
Sir
Henry
,
who
was
completely
imposed
upon
by
Abingdon
's
unconcerned
demeanour
;
"
they
can
not
be
here
.
<EOS>
""Trust
<EOS>
me
,
they
are
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
and
I
should
like
to
take
him
at
his
word
.
<EOS>
"Giving
<EOS>
directions
to
the
band
to
environ
the
house
,
and
guard
all
its
approaches
,
so
as
to
prevent
any
one
from
escaping
from
it
<EOS>
,
Topcliffe
took
half
-
a
-
dozen
men
with
him
,
and
instructed
them
how
to
act
.
<EOS>
They
first
repaired
to
the
great
dining
-
chamber
,
where
,
in
accordance
with
the
instructions
received
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
Topcliffe
proceeded
to
the
further
end
of
the
room
,
and
directed
his
men
to
break
down
the
wainscot
.
<EOS>
With
some
difficulty
,
the
order
was
obeyed
,
and
the
entrance
to
a
vault
discovered
,
into
which
Topcliffe
descended
but
he
found
nothing
to
repay
his
trouble
.
<EOS>
Returning
to
the
dining
-
chamber
,
he
questioned
Mr.
Abingdon
,
who
secretly
enjoyed
his
disappointment
,
as
to
the
use
of
the
vault
,
but
the
latter
professed
entire
ignorance
of
its
existence
.
<EOS>
The
searchers
next
proceeded
to
the
cellar
,
and
bored
the
floors
with
a
broach
to
a
considerable
depth
,
to
try
whether
there
were
any
vaults
beneath
them
,
but
they
made
no
discovery
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Topcliffe
hurried
upstairs
,
and
examined
the
size
of
the
rooms
,
to
see
whether
they
corresponded
with
those
below
;
and
wherever
any
difference
was
observable
,
he
caused
the
panels
to
be
pulled
down
,
and
holes
broken
in
the
walls
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
several
secret
passages
were
discovered
,
one
of
which
led
to
the
chamber
lately
occupied
by
Garnet
.
<EOS>
Encouraged
by
this
discovery
,
the
searchers
continued
their
operations
to
a
late
hour
,
when
they
desisted
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
they
resumed
their
task
,
and
Sir
Henry
Bromley
took
a
general
survey
of
the
house
,
both
externally
and
internally
,
noting
the
appearances
outside
,
and
seeing
that
they
corresponded
with
the
rooms
within
.
<EOS>
The
three
extraordinary
chimney
-
pieces
in
the
gallery
attracted
Topcliffe
's
attention
;
but
the
contrivances
within
were
so
well
managed
,
that
they
escaped
his
notice
.
<EOS>
He
even
got
into
the
chimneys
,
and
examined
the
walls
on
either
side
,
but
could
detect
nothing
.
<EOS>
And
,
lastly
,
he
ordered
large
fires
to
be
lighted
within
them
,
but
the
experiment
proving
fruitless
,
he
turned
his
attention
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
Mr
.
<EOS>
Abingdon
had
attended
him
during
this
part
of
the
search
,
and
,
though
he
preserved
an
unmoved
exterior
,
he
was
full
of
apprehension
,
and
was
greatly
relieved
when
it
was
abandoned
.
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
the
same
day
,
two
other
hiding
-
places
were
found
in
the
thickness
of
the
walls
,
but
nothing
was
discovered
within
them
.
<EOS>
In
order
to
prevent
any
communication
with
the
concealed
persons
,
Topcliffe
stationed
a
sentinel
at
the
door
of
Mr.
Abingdon
's
chamber
,
and
another
at
that
of
Anne
Vaux
.
<EOS>
On
the
third
day
the
search
was
continued
