more
rigorously
than
ever
.
<EOS>
Wainscots
were
taken
down
;
walls
broken
open
;
the
boards
of
the
floor
removed
;
and
other
secret
passages
,
vaults
,
and
hiding
-
places
discovered
.
<EOS>
Some
priests
'
vestments
and
articles
used
in
the
Romish
service
were
found
in
one
of
these
places
,
and
shown
to
Mr.
Abingdon
.
<EOS>
He
at
first
denied
all
knowledge
of
them
;
but
when
Topcliffe
brought
forward
the
title
-
deeds
of
his
property
,
which
had
been
found
in
the
same
place
,
he
was
obliged
to
confess
he
had
put
them
there
himself
.
<EOS>
Still
,
though
these
discoveries
had
been
made
,
the
searchers
were
as
far
from
their
aim
as
ever
;
and
Sir
Henry
Bromley
,
who
began
to
despair
of
success
,
would
have
departed
on
the
fifth
day
,
if
Topcliffe
had
not
prevented
him
.
<EOS>
"I
am
certain
they
are
here
,
"
said
the
latter
,
"
and
have
hit
upon
a
plan
which
can
not
fail
to
bring
them
forth
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
prisoners
meanwhile
suffered
grievously
from
their
confinement
,
and
hearing
the
searchers
knocking
against
the
walls
,
and
even
within
the
chimney
,
felt
certain
they
should
be
discovered
.
<EOS>
Not
being
able
to
stand
upright
,
or
to
stretch
themselves
within
the
cell
,
the
sitting
posture
they
were
compelled
to
adopt
became
,
after
a
time
,
intolerably
irksome
.
<EOS>
Broths
,
milk
,
wine
,
and
other
nutritious
fluids
,
were
conveyed
to
them
by
means
of
a
reed
from
the
adjoining
chimney
;
but
after
the
fifth
day
this
supply
was
stopped
,
as
Mrs.
Abingdon
and
Anne
Vaux
were
compelled
by
Topcliffe
to
remove
to
a
different
part
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
They
now
began
to
experience
all
the
horrors
of
starvation
,
and
debated
whether
they
should
die
where
they
were
,
or
yield
themselves
up
to
their
enemies
.
<EOS>
Wretched
as
their
condition
was
,
however
,
it
was
not
so
bad
as
that
of
their
domestics
,
Owen
and
Chambers
,
whose
wants
had
not
been
so
carefully
attended
to
,
and
who
were
now
reduced
to
the
most
deplorable
state
.
<EOS>
Nor
were
their
friends
less
uneasy
.
<EOS>
Aware
that
the
captives
,
whom
there
was
no
means
of
relieving
,
for
the
searchers
were
constantly
on
the
watch
,
could
not
hold
out
much
longer
,
Mrs.
Abingdon
consulted
with
her
husband
whether
it
would
not
be
better
to
reveal
their
hiding
-
places
;
but
this
he
would
not
permit
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
every
secret
chamber
,
vault
,
and
passage
in
the
place
,
except
the
actual
retreats
of
the
conspirators
,
had
been
discovered
by
Topcliffe
,
and
though
nothing
material
was
found
,
he
felt
assured
,
from
the
uneasiness
displayed
by
Mr.
Abingdon
and
his
wife
,
and
above
all
by
Anne
Vaux
,
that
it
could
not
be
long
before
his
perseverance
was
rewarded
.
<EOS>
Though
he
narrowly
watched
the
two
ladies
,
from
the
first
,
he
could
never
detect
them
in
the
act
of
conveying
food
to
the
captives
;
but
feeling
convinced
that
they
did
so
<EOS>
,
he
determined
to
remove
them
to
a
different
part
of
the
house
,
and
their
unwillingness
to
obey
the
order
confirmed
his
suspicions
.
<EOS>
"We
are
sure
of
our
prey
now
,
"
he
observed
to
Sir
Henry
Bromley
.
<EOS>
"
They
must
be
half
-
starved
by
this
time
,
and
will
speedily
surrender
themselves
.
<EOS>
""Pray
<EOS>
Heaven
<EOS>
they
do
so
!
"
returned
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
wearied
to
death
with
my
long
stay
here
.
<EOS>
""Have
a
few
hours
'
patience
<EOS>
,
"
rejoined
Topcliffe
,
"
and
you
will
find
that
your
time
has
not
been
thrown
away
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
he
was
right
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
midnight
,
a
trooper
,
who
was
watching
in
the
gallery
,
beheld
two
spectral
-
looking
figures
approach
him
,
and
appalled
by
their
ghastly
appearance
,
uttered
a
loud
cry
.
<EOS>
This
brought
Topcliffe
,
who
was
in
the
hall
below
,
<EOS>
to
his
aid
,
and
instantly
perceiving
what
was
the
matter
,
he
ran
towards
the
supposed
phantoms
,
and
seized
them
.
<EOS>
The
poor
wretches
,
who
were
no
other
than
Owen
and
Chambers
,
and
were
well
-
nigh
famished
,
offered
no
resistance
,
but
would
neither
confess
where
they
had
been
hidden
,
nor
who
they
were
.
<EOS>
As
the
trooper
had
not
seen
them
come
forth
,
though
he
affirmed
with
a
tremendous
oath
that
they
had
issued
from
the
floor
,
the
walls
were
again
sounded
,
but
with
no
result
.
<EOS>
Food
being
placed
before
the
captives
,
they
devoured
it
voraciously
;
but
Topcliffe
forbore
to
question
them
further
that
night
,
feeling
confident
that
he
could
extract
the
truth
from
them
on
the
morrow
,
either
by
promises
or
threats
.
<EOS>
He
was
however
,
mistaken
.
<EOS>
They
continued
as
obstinate
as
before
,
and
when
confronted
with
Mr.
Abingdon
,
denied
all
knowledge
of
him
:
neither
would
they
explain
how
they
got
into
the
house
.
<EOS>
Sir
Henry
Bromley
,
however
,
now
considered
himself
justified
in
placing
Mr.
Abingdon
and
his
lady
under
arrest
,
and
Topcliffe
redoubled
his
exertions
to
discover
the
hiding
-
place
of
the
two
priests
.
<EOS>
He
examined
every
part
of
the
gallery
most
carefully,—took
down
one
of
the
chimney
-
pieces
,
(
singularly
enough
,
it
was
the
wrong
one
,
)
but
was
still
unable
to
discover
their
retreat
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
poor
wretches
inside
found
it
impossible
to
endure
their
condition
longer
.
<EOS>
Anything
seemed
preferable
to
the
lingering
and
agonizing
death
they
were
now
enduring
,
and
they
resolved
to
delay
their
surrender
no
longer
.
<EOS>
Had
they
been
able
to
hold
out
a
few
hours
more
,
they
would
have
escaped
;
for
Sir
Henry
Bromley
was
so
fatigued
with
the
search
,
and
so
satisfied
that
nothing
further
would
come
of
it
,
that
he
resolved
,
notwithstanding
Topcliffe
's
efforts
to
dissuade
him
,
to
depart
on
the
morrow
.
<EOS>
Of
this
they
were
ignorant
,
and
having
come
to
the
determination
to
surrender
,
Garnet
opened
the
entrance
to
the
chimney
,
and
hearing
voices
below
,
and
being
too
feeble
to
get
out
unassisted
,
he
called
to
the
speakers
for
aid
.
<EOS>
His
voice
was
so
hollow
,
and
had
such
a
sepulchral
sound
,
<EOS>
that
those
who
heard
it
stared
at
each
other
in
astonishment
and
affright
.
<EOS>
"Who
calls
?
"
cried
one
of
the
troopers
,
after
a
pause
.
<EOS>
"One
of
those
you
seek
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
Come
and
help
us
forth
.
<EOS>
"Upon
<EOS>
hearing
this
,
and
ascertaining
whence
the
voice
came
from
,
one
of
the
men
ran
to
fetch
Sir
Henry
Bromley
and
Topcliffe
,
both
of
whom
joyfully
obeyed
the
summons
.
<EOS>
"Is
<EOS>
it
possible
<EOS>
they
can
be
in
the
chimney
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
myself
have
examined
it
twice
.
<EOS>
""We
are
here
,
nevertheless
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
who
heard
the
remark
;
"
and
if
you
would
take
us
alive
,
lose
no
time
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
hint
was
not
lost
upon
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
Casting
a
triumphant
look
at
Bromley
,
he
seized
a
torch
from
one
of
his
attendants
,
and
getting
into
the
chimney
,
soon
perceived
the
entrance
to
the
recess
.
<EOS>
On
beholding
his
prey
,
he
uttered
an
exclamation
of
joy
,
and
the
two
miserable
captives
,
seeing
the
savage
and
exulting
grin
that
lighted
up
his
features
,
half
repented
the
step
they
had
taken
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
,
however
,
too
late
,
and
Garnet
begged
him
to
help
them
out
.
<EOS>
"That
I
will
readily
do
,
father
,
"
replied
Topcliffe
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
given
us
a
world
of
trouble
.
<EOS>
But
you
have
made
ample
amends
for
it
now
.
<EOS>
""Had
we
been
so
minded
,
you
would
never
have
found
us
,
"
rejoined
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
cell
would
have
been
our
sepulchre
.
<EOS>
""No
<EOS>
doubt
,
"
retorted
Topcliffe
,
with
a
bitter
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
a
death
on
the
scaffold
is
preferable
to
the
horrors
of
starvation
.
<EOS>
"Finding
<EOS>
it
impossible
to
remove
Garnet
,
whose
limbs
were
so
cramped
that
they
refused
their
office
,
he
called
to
the
troopers
below
to
bring
a
ladder
,
which
was
placed
in
the
chimney
,
and
then
,
with
some
exertion
,
he
succeeded
in
getting
him
down
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
supported
him
towards
Sir
Henry
Bromley
,
who
was
standing
near
a
small
table
in
the
gallery
.
<EOS>
Illustration"I
told
you
your
time
would
not
be
thrown
away
,
Sir
Henry
,
"
he
observed
;
"
here
is
Father
Garnet
.
<EOS>
It
is
well
you
yielded
yourself
to
-
night
,
father
,
"
he
added
,
to
Garnet
,
with
his
customary
cynical
chuckle
;
"
for
Sir
Henry
had
resolved
to
depart
to
-
morrow
.
""Indeed
!
"
groaned
Garnet
.
"
<EOS>
Help
me
to
a
chair
.
<EOS>
"While
<EOS>
this
was
passing
,
Oldcorne
was
brought
down
by
two
of
the
troopers
,
and
the
unfortunate
priests
were
conveyed
to
an
adjoining
chamber
,
where
they
were
placed
in
a
bed
,
their
stiffened
limbs
chafed
,
and
cordials
administered
to
them
.
<EOS>
They
were
reduced
,
however
,
to
such
extremity
of
weakness
,
that
it
was
not
judged
prudent
to
remove
them
till
the
third
day
,
when
they
,
together
with
their
two
servants
,
Owen
and
Chambers
,
who
were
as
much
enfeebled
as
themselves
,
were
conveyed
to
Worcester
.
<EOS>
IX
.
<EOS>
—
<EOS>
WHITEHALLSuch
was
the
expedition
used
by
Humphrey
Chetham
and
Viviana
,
that
they
accomplished
the
journey
to
London
in
an
extraordinarily
short
space
of
time
.
<EOS>
Proceeding
direct
to
Whitehall
,
Viviana
placed
a
letter
in
the
hands
of
a
halberdier
,
and
desired
that
it
might
be
given
without
delay
to
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
After
some
demur
,
the
man
handed
it
to
an
usher
,
who
promised
to
lay
it
before
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
Some
time
elapsed
before
the
result
of
its
reception
was
known
,
when
an
officer
,
accompanied
by
two
sergeants
of
the
guard
,
made
his
appearance
,
and
commanded
Viviana
and
her
companion
to
follow
him
.
<EOS>
Crossing
a
wide
hall
,
which
was
filled
with
the
various
retainers
of
the
palace
,
who
regarded
them
with
a
sort
of
listless
curiosity
,
and
ascending
a
flight
of
marble
steps
,
they
traversed
a
long
corridor
,
and
were
at
length
ushered
into
the
presence
of
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
He
was
seated
at
a
table
,
covered
with
a
multitude
of
papers
,
and
was
busily
employed
in
writing
a
despatch
,
but
immediately
stopped
on
their
entrance
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
alone
.
<EOS>
His
companion
was
a
middle
-
aged
man
,
attired
in
a
suit
of
black
velvet
,
with
a
cloak
of
the
same
material
;
but
as
he
sat
with
his
back
towards
the
door
,
it
was
impossible
to
discern
his
features
.
<EOS>
"You
may
leave
us
,
"
said
Salisbury
to
the
officer
,
"
but
remain
without
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
be
ready
to
enter
at
a
moment
's
notice
,
"
added
his
companion
,
without
altering
his
position
.
<EOS>
The
officer
bowed
,
and
retired
with
his
followers
.
<EOS>
"Your
<EOS>
surrender
of
yourself
at
this
time
,
Viviana
Radcliffe
,
"
said
the
Earl
,
"
weighs
much
in
your
favour
;
and
if
you
are
disposed
freely
to
declare
all
you
know
of
the
conspiracy
,
it
is
not
impossible
that
the
King
may
extend
his
mercy
towards
you
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
do
not
desire
it
,
my
lord
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
In
surrendering
myself
,
I
have
no
other
aim
than
to
satisfy
the
laws
I
have
outraged
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
seek
to
defend
myself
,
but
I
desire
to
offer
an
explanation
to
your
lordship
.
<EOS>
Circumstances
,
which
it
is
needless
to
detail
,
drew
me
into
connexion
with
the
conspirators
,
and
I
became
unwillingly
the
depositary
of
their
dark
design
.
<EOS>
""You
were
guilty
of
misprision
of
treason
in
not
revealing
it
,
"
remarked
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"I
am
aware
of
it
,
"
she
rejoined
;
"
but
this
,
I
take
heaven
to
witness
,
is
the
extent
of
my
criminality
.
<EOS>
I
held
the
project
in
the
utmost
abhorrence
,
and
used
every
argument
I
was
mistress
of
to
induce
its
contrivers
to
abandon
it
.
<EOS>
""If
such
were
the
case
,
"
demanded
the
Earl
,
"
what
withheld
you
from
disclosing
it?""I
will
now
confess
what
torture
could
not
wring
from
me
before
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
restrained
from
the
disclosure
by
a
fatal
passion
.
<EOS>
""I
suspected
as
much
,
"
observed
the
Earl
,
with
a
sneer
.
"
<EOS>
For
whom?""For
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
returned
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"God
's
mercy
!
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
!
"
ejaculated
the
Earl
's
companion
,
starting
to
his
feet
.
<EOS>
And
turning
as
he
spoke
,
and
facing
her
,
he
disclosed
heavy
but
not
unintellectual
features
,
now
charged
with
an
expression
of
the
utmost
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"
Did
you
say
Guy
Fawkes
,
mistress?""It
is
the
King
,
"
whispered
Humphrey
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"Since
<EOS>
I
know
in
whose
presence
I
stand
,
sire
,
"
replied
Viviana
,
"
I
will
answer
the
interrogation
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
was
the
cause
of
<EOS>
my
concealing
my
acquaintance
with
the
plot
.
<EOS>
And
more
,
I
will
confess
to
your
Majesty
,
that
much
as
I
abhor
the
design
,
if
he
had
not
been
a
conspirator
,
I
should
never
have
loved
him
.
<EOS>
His
sombre
and
enthusiastic
character
first
gave
him
an
interest
in
my
eyes
,
which
,
heightened
by
several
important
services
which
he
rendered
me
,
soon
ripened
into
love
.
<EOS>
Linked
to
his
fortunes
,
shrouded
by
the
same
gloomy
cloud
that
enveloped
him
,
and
bound
by
a
chain
from
which
I
could
not
extricate
myself
,
I
gave
him
my
hand
.
<EOS>
But
the
moment
of
our
union
was
the
moment
of
our
separation
.
<EOS>
We
have
not
met
since
,
and
shall
meet
no
more
,
unless
to
part
for
ever
.
<EOS>
""A
strange
history
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
James
,
in
a
tone
that
showed
he
was
not
unmoved
by
the
relation
.
<EOS>
"I
beseech
your
Majesty
to
grant
me
one
boon
,
"
cried
Viviana
,
falling
at
his
feet
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
to
be
allowed
a
single
interview
with
my
husband
—
not
for
the
sad
gratification
of
beholding
him
again
—
not
for
the
indulgence
of
my
private
sorrows
—
but
that
I
may
endeavour
to
awaken
a
feeling
of
repentance
in
his
breast
,
and
be
the
means
of
saving
his
soul
alive
.
<EOS>
""My
<EOS>
inclinations
prompt
me
to
grant
the
request
,
Salisbury
,
"
said
the
King
,
irresolutely
.
<EOS>
"
There
can
be
no
risk
in
doing
it
—
eh?""Not
under
certain
restrictions
,
my
liege
,
"
replied
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
shall
have
your
wish
,
then
,
mistress
,
"
said
James
,
"
and
I
trust
your
efforts
may
be
crowned
with
success
.
<EOS>
Your
husband
is
a
hardy
traitor
—
a
second
Jacques
Clement
—
and
we
never
think
of
him
without
the
floor
shaking
beneath
our
feet
,
and
a
horrible
smell
of
gunpowder
assailing
our
nostrils
.
<EOS>
Blessed
be
God
for
our
preservation
!
<EOS>
But
whom
have
we
here
?
"
he
added
,
turning
to
Humphrey
Chetham
.
"
<EOS>
Another
conspirator
come
to
surrender
himself?""No
,
my
liege
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Chetham
;
"
I
am
a
loyal
subject
of
your
Majesty
,
and
a
stanch
Protestant
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
we
may
take
your
word
for
it
,
doubtless
,
"
replied
the
King
,
with
an
incredulous
look
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
how
come
you
in
this
lady
's
company?""I
will
hide
nothing
from
your
Majesty
,
"
replied
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
Long
before
Viviana
's
unhappy
acquaintance
with
Fawkes
—
for
such
<EOS>
I
must
ever
consider
it
—
my
affections
had
been
fixed
upon
her
,
and
I
fondly
trusted
she
would
not
prove
indifferent
to
my
suit
.
<EOS>
Even
now
,
sire
,
when
all
hope
is
dead
within
me
,
I
have
not
been
able
to
overcome
my
passion
,
but
love
her
as
devotedly
as
ever
.
<EOS>
When
,
therefore
,
she
desired
my
escort
to
London
to
surrender
herself
,
I
could
not
refuse
the
request
.
<EOS>
""It
is
the
truth
,
my
liege
,
"
added
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
I
owe
Humphrey
Chetham
(
for
so
this
gentleman
is
named
)
an
endless
debt
of
gratitude
;
and
not
the
least
of
my
present
distresses
is
the
thought
of
the
affliction
I
have
occasioned
him
.
<EOS>
""Dismiss
it
from
your
mind
<EOS>
,
then
,
Viviana
,
"
rejoined
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
not
mitigate
my
sorrows
to
feel
that
I
have
added
to
yours
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
manner
and
looks
seem
to
give
a
warranty
for
loyalty
,
young
sir
,
"
said
the
King
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
must
have
some
assurance
of
the
truth
of
your
statement
before
you
are
set
at
large
.
<EOS>
""I
am
your
willing
prisoner
,
my
liege
,
"
returned
Chetham
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
a
letter
for
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
which
may
vouch
perhaps
for
me
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
as
he
spoke
,
he
placed
a
letter
in
the
Earl
's
hands
,
who
broke
open
the
seal
,
and
hastily
glanced
at
its
contents
.
<EOS>
"It
is
from
Doctor
Dee
,
"
he
said
,
"
from
whom
,
as
your
Majesty
is
aware
,
we
have
received
much
important
information
relative
to
this
atrocious
design
.
<EOS>
He
answers
for
this
young
man
's
loyalty
.
<EOS>
""I
am
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
rejoined
the
King
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
have
been
mortifying
to
be
deceived
by
so
honest
a
physiognomy
.
<EOS>
""Your
<EOS>
Majesty
will
be
pleased
to
attach
your
signature
to
this
warrant
for
Viviana
Radcliffe
's
committal
to
the
Tower
,
"
said
Salisbury
,
placing
a
paper
before
him
.
<EOS>
James
complied
,
and
the
Earl
summoned
the
guard
.
<EOS>
"Have
<EOS>
I
your
Majesty
's
permission
to
attend
this
unfortunate
lady
to
the
fortress
?
"
cried
Chetham
,
prostrating
himself
before
the
King
.
<EOS>
James
hesitated
,
but
glancing
at
the
Earl
,
and
reading
no
objection
in
his
looks
,
he
assented
.
<EOS>
Whispering
some
private
instructions
to
the
officer
respecting
Chetham
,
Salisbury
delivered
the
warrant
to
him
.
<EOS>
Viviana
and
her
companion
were
then
removed
to
a
small
chamber
adjoining
the
guard
-
room
,
where
they
remained
for
nearly
an
hour
,
at
the
expiration
of
which
time
the
officer
again
appeared
,
and
conducted
them
to
the
palace
-
stairs
,
where
a
large
wherry
awaited
them
,
in
which
they
embarked
.
<EOS>
James
did
not
remain
long
with
his
councillor
,
and
as
soon
as
he
had
retired
,
Salisbury
summoned
a
confidential
attendant
,
and
told
him
to
acquaint
Lord
Mounteagle
,
who
was
in
an
adjoining
apartment
,
that
he
was
now
able
to
receive
him
.
<EOS>
The
attendant
departed
,
and
presently
returned
with
the
nobleman
in
question
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
they
were
alone
,
and
Salisbury
had
satisfied
himself
they
could
not
be
overheard
,
he
observed
to
the
other,"Since
Tresham
's
committal
to
the
Tower
yesterday
,
I
have
received
a
letter
from
the
lieutenant
,
stating
that
he
breathes
nothing
but
revenge
against
yourself
and
me
,
and
threatens
to
betray
us
,
if
he
is
not
released
.
<EOS>
It
will
not
do
to
let
him
be
examined
by
the
Council
;
for
though
we
can
throw
utter
discredit
on
his
statement
,
it
may
be
prejudicial
to
my
future
designs
.
<EOS>
""True
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
But
how
do
you
propose
to
silence
him?""By
poison
,
"
returned
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
trusty
fellow
in
the
Tower
,
a
jailer
named
Ipgreve
,
who
will
administer
it
to
him
.
<EOS>
Here
is
the
powder
,
"
he
added
,
unlocking
a
coffer
,
and
taking
out
a
small
packet
;
"
it
was
given
me
by
its
compounder
,
Doctor
Dee
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
same
,
I
am
assured
,
as
the
celebrated
Italian
poison
prepared
by
Pope
Alexander
the
Sixth
;
is
without
scent
or
taste
;
and
destroys
its
victim
without
leaving
a
trace
of
its
effects
.
<EOS>
""I
must
take
heed
how
I
offend
your
lordship
,
"
observed
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"Nay
,
"
rejoined
Salisbury
,
with
a
ghastly
smile
,
"
<EOS>
it
is
for
traitors
like
Tresham
,
not
true
men
like
you
,
to
fear
me
.
<EOS>
""I
understand
the
distinction
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
the
other
.
<EOS>
"I
must
intrust
the
entire
management
of
this
affair
to
you
,
"
pursued
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
"To
me
!
"
exclaimed
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"
Tresham
is
my
brother
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
I
can
take
no
part
in
his
murder
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
he
lives
,
you
are
ruined
,
"
rejoined
Salisbury
,
coldly
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
sacrifice
him
or
yourself
.
<EOS>
But
I
see
you
are
reasonable
.
<EOS>
Take
this
powder
,
and
proceed
to
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
See
Ipgreve
alone
,
and
instruct
him
to
drug
Tresham
's
wine
with
it
.
<EOS>
A
hundred
marks
shall
be
his
reward
when
the
deed
is
done
.
<EOS>
""My
<EOS>
soul
revolts
from
the
deed
,
"
said
Mounteagle
,
as
he
took
the
packet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
there
no
other
way
of
silencing
him?""None
<EOS>
whatever
,
"
replied
Salisbury
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
His
blood
be
upon
his
own
head
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
Mounteagle
took
his
departure
.
<EOS>
X.
—
<EOS>
THE
PARTING
OF
VIVIANA
AND
HUMPHREY
CHETHAMHumphrey
Chetham
was
so
oppressed
by
the
idea
of
parting
with
Viviana
,
that
he
did
not
utter
a
single
word
during
their
transit
to
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
Passing
beneath
the
gloomy
archway
of
Traitors
'
Gate
,
they
mounted
the
fatal
steps
,
and
were
conducted
to
the
guard
-
room
near
the
By
-
ward
Tower
.
<EOS>
The
officer
then
despatched
one
of
the
warders
to
inform
the
lieutenant
of
Viviana
's
arrival
,
and
telling
Humphrey
Chetham
he
would
allow
him
a
few
minutes
to
take
leave
of
her
,
considerately
withdrew
,
and
left
them
alone
together
.
<EOS>
"Oh
!
<EOS>
Viviana
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Chetham
,
unable
to
repress
his
grief
,
"
my
heart
bleeds
to
see
you
here
.
<EOS>
If
you
repent
the
step
you
have
taken
,
and
desire
freedom
,
say
so
,
and
I
will
use
every
effort
to
liberate
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
successful
once
,
and
may
be
so
again
.
<EOS>
""I
<EOS>
thank
you
for
your
devotion
<EOS>
,
"
she
replied
,
in
a
tone
of
profound
gratitude
;
"
but
you
have
rendered
me
the
last
service
I
shall
ever
require
of
you
.
<EOS>
I
deeply
deplore
the
misery
I
have
occasioned
you
,
and
regret
my
inability
to
requite
your
attachment
as
it
deserves
to
be
requited
.
<EOS>
My
last
prayers
shall
be
for
your
happiness
;
and
I
trust
you
will
meet
with
some
being
worthy
of
you
,
and
who
will
make
amends
for
my
insensibility
.
<EOS>
""Be
not
deceived
,
Viviana
,
"
replied
Chetham
,
in
a
broken
voice
;
"
I
shall
never
love
again
.
<EOS>
Your
image
is
too
deeply
imprinted
upon
my
heart
ever
to
be
effaced
.
<EOS>
""Time
may
work
a
change
,
"
she
rejoined
;
"
though
I
ought
not
to
say
so
,
for
I
feel
it
would
work
none
in
me
.
<EOS>
Suffer
me
to
give
you
one
piece
of
counsel
.
<EOS>
Devote
yourself
resolutely
to
the
business
of
life
,
and
you
will
speedily
regain
your
peace
of
mind
.
<EOS>
""I
will
follow
your
instructions
implicitly
,
"
replied
Chetham
;
"
but
have
little
hope
of
the
result
you
promise
me
.
<EOS>
""Let
<EOS>
the
effort
be
made
,
"
she
rejoined;—"and
now
promise
me
to
quit
London
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Return
to
your
native
town
,
employ
yourself
in
your
former
occupations
;
and
strive
not
to
think
of
the
past
,
except
as
a
troubled
dream
from
which
you
have
fortunately
awakened
.
<EOS>
Do
not
let
us
prolong
our
parting
,
or
your
resolution
may
waver
.
<EOS>
Farewell!"So
saying
,
she
extended
her
hand
towards
him
,
and
he
pressed
it
passionately
to
his
lips
.
"Farewell
,
Viviana
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
with
a
look
of
unutterable
anguish
.
"
<EOS>
May
Heaven
support
you
in
your
trials!""One
of
them
I
am
now
enduring
,
"
she
replied
,
in
a
broken
voice
.
"
<EOS>
Farewell
for
ever
,
and
may
all
good
angels
bless
you!"At
this
moment
,
the
officer
appeared
,
and
announcing
the
approach
of
the
lieutenant
,
told
Chetham
that
his
time
had
expired
.
<EOS>
Without
hazarding
another
look
at
Viviana
,
the
young
merchant
tore
himself
away
,
and
followed
the
officer
out
of
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
Obedient
to
Viviana
's
last
request
,
he
quitted
London
on
the
following
day
,
and
acting
upon
her
advice
,
devoted
himself
on
his
return
to
Manchester
sedulously
to
his
mercantile
pursuits
.
<EOS>
His
perseverance
and
integrity
were
crowned
with
entire
success
,
and
he
became
in
due
season
the
wealthiest
merchant
of
the
town
.
<EOS>
But
the
blighting
of
his
early
affections
tinged
his
whole
life
,
and
gave
a
melancholy
to
his
thoughts
and
an
austerity
to
his
manner
originally
foreign
to
them
.
<EOS>
True
to
his
promise
,
he
died
unmarried
.
<EOS>
His
long
and
worthy
career
was
marked
by
actions
of
the
greatest
benevolence
.
<EOS>
In
proportion
as
his
means
increased
,
his
charities
were
extended
,
and
he
truly
became
"
a
father
to
the
fatherless
and
the
destitute
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
him
the
town
of
Manchester
is
indebted
for
the
noble
library
and
hospital
bearing
his
name
;
and
for
these
admirable
institutions
by
which
they
so
largely
benefit
,
his
memory
must
ever
be
held
in
veneration
by
its
inhabitants
.
<EOS>
XI
.
<EOS>
—
THE
SUBTERRANEAN
DUNGEONRegarding
Viviana
with
a
smile
of
savage
satisfaction
,
Sir
William
Waad
commanded
Jasper
Ipgreve
,
who
accompanied
him
,
to
convey
her
to
one
of
the
subterranean
dungeons
below
the
Devereux
Tower
.
"She
<EOS>
can
not
escape
thence
without
your
connivance
,
"
he
said
;
"
<EOS>
and
you
shall
answer
to
me
for
her
safe
custody
with
your
life
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
she
escapes
again
,
your
worship
shall
hang
me
in
her
stead
,
"
rejoined
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
instructions
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
state
that
it
is
the
King
's
pleasure
that
she
be
allowed
a
short
interview
with
Guy
Fawkes
,
"
said
the
lieutenant
,
in
a
low
tone
.
<EOS>
"
Let
her
be
taken
to
his
cell
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
jailer
bowed
,
and
motioning
the
guard
to
follow
him
with
Viviana
,
he
led
the
way
along
the
inner
ward
till
he
arrived
at
a
small
strong
door
in
the
wall
a
little
to
the
north
of
the
Beauchamp
Tower
,
which
he
unlocked
,
and
descended
into
a
low
cavernous
-
looking
vault
.
<EOS>
Striking
a
light
,
and
setting
fire
to
a
torch
,
he
then
led
the
way
along
a
narrow
gloomy
passage
,
which
brought
them
to
a
circular
chamber
,
from
which
other
passages
diverged
,
and
selecting
one
of
them
,
threaded
it
till
he
came
to
the
door
of
a
cell
.
<EOS>
"Here
is
your
dungeon
,
"
he
said
to
Viviana
,
as
he
drew
back
the
heavy
bolts
,
and
disclosed
a
small
chamber
,
about
four
feet
wide
and
six
long
,
in
which
there
was
a
pallet
.
<EOS>
"
My
dame
will
attend
you
soon
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
lighted
a
lamp
,
and
departing
with
the
guard
,
barred
the
door
outside
.
<EOS>
Viviana
shuddered
as
she
surveyed
the
narrow
dungeon
in
which
she
was
placed
.
<EOS>
Roof
,
walls
,
and
floor
were
of
stone
;
and
the
aspect
of
the
place
was
so
dismal
and
tomb
-
like
,
that
she
felt
as
if
she
were
buried
alive
.
<EOS>
Some
hours
elapsed
before
Dame
Ipgreve
made
her
appearance
.
<EOS>
She
was
accompanied
by
Ruth
,
who
burst
into
tears
on
beholding
Viviana
.
<EOS>
The
jailer
's
wife
had
brought
a
few
blankets
and
other
necessaries
with
her
,
together
with
a
loaf
of
bread
and
a
jug
of
water
.
<EOS>
While
disposing
the
blankets
on
the
couch
,
she
never
ceased
upbraiding
Viviana
for
her
former
flight
.
<EOS>
Poor
Ruth
,
who
was
compelled
to
assist
her
mother
,
endeavoured
by
her
gestures
and
looks
to
convey
to
the
unfortunate
captive
that
she
was
as
much
devoted
to
her
as
ever
.
<EOS>
Their
task
completed
,
the
old
woman
withdrew
,
and
<EOS>
her
daughter
,
casting
a
deeply
-
commiserating
look
at
Viviana
,
followed
her
,
and
the
door
was
barred
without
.
<EOS>
Determined
not
to
yield
to
despondency
,
Viviana
knelt
down
,
and
addressed
herself
to
Heaven
;
and
,
comforted
by
her
prayers
,
threw
herself
on
the
bed
,
and
sank
into
a
peaceful
slumber
.
<EOS>
She
was
awakened
by
hearing
the
bolts
of
her
cell
withdrawn
,
and
the
next
moment
Ruth
stood
before
her
.
<EOS>
"I
<EOS>
fear
you
have
exposed
yourself
to
great
risk
in
thus
visiting
me
,
"
said
Viviana
,
tenderly
embracing
her
.
<EOS>
"I
would
expose
myself
to
any
risk
for
you
,
sweet
lady
,
"
replied
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
oh
!
<EOS>
why
do
I
see
you
here
again
?
<EOS>
The
chief
support
of
Guy
Fawkes
during
his
sufferings
has
been
the
thought
that
you
were
at
liberty
.
<EOS>
""I
surrendered
myself
in
the
hope
of
beholding
him
again
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"You
<EOS>
have
given
a
fond
,
but
fatal
proof
of
your
affection
,
"
returned
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
The
knowledge
that
you
are
a
captive
will
afflict
him
more
than
all
the
torments
he
has
endured
.
<EOS>
""What
<EOS>
torments
has
he
endured
,
Ruth
?
"
inquired
Viviana
with
a
look
of
anguish
.
<EOS>
"Do
not
ask
me
to
repeat
them
,
"
replied
the
jailer
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
too
dreadful
to
relate
.
<EOS>
When
you
behold
his
shattered
frame
and
altered
looks
,
you
will
comprehend
what
he
has
undergone
.
<EOS>
""Alas
!
"
exclaimed
Viviana
,
bursting
into
tears
,
"
I
almost
fear
to
behold
him
.
<EOS>
""You
must
prepare
for
a
fearful
shock
,
"
returned
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
madam
,
I
must
take
my
leave
.
<EOS>
I
will
endeavour
to
see
you
again
to
-
morrow
,
but
dare
not
promise
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
I
should
not
have
been
able
to
visit
you
now
,
but
that
my
father
is
engaged
with
Lord
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
""With
<EOS>
Lord
Mounteagle
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
Upon
what
business?"Upon
a
foul
business
,
"
rejoined
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
less
than
the
destruction
of
Mr.
Tresham
,
who
is
now
a
prisoner
in
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
Lord
Mounteagle
came
to
the
Well
Tower
this
evening
,
and
I
accidentally
overheard
him
propose
to
my
father
to
administer
poison
to
the
person
I
have
named
.
<EOS>
""I
do
not
pity
their
victim
,
"
returned
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
double
-
dyed
traitor
,
and
will
meet
with
the
fate
he
deserves
.
<EOS>
""Farewell
,
madam
,
"
said
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
do
not
see
you
again
,
you
will
know
that
you
have
one
friend
in
this
fortress
who
deeply
sympathizes
with
your
afflictions
.
<EOS>
"So
<EOS>
saying
,
she
withdrew
,
and
Viviana
heard
the
bolts
slipped
gently
into
their
sockets
.
<EOS>
Vainly
,
after
Ruth
's
visit
,
did
she
try
to
compose
herself
.
<EOS>
Sleep
fled
her
eyes
,
and
she
was
haunted
all
night
by
the
image
of
Fawkes
,
haggard
and
shattered
by
torture
,
as
he
had
been
described
by
the
jailer
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
Day
and
night
were
the
same
to
her
,
and
she
could
only
compute
progress
of
the
time
by
her
own
feelings
,
judging
by
which
,
she
supposed
it
to
be
late
in
the
day
when
she
was
again
visited
.
<EOS>
The
bolts
of
her
cell
being
withdrawn
,
two
men
clad
in
long
black
gowns
,
and
having
hoods
drawn
over
their
faces
,
entered
it
.
<EOS>
They
were
followed
by
Ipgreve
;
and
Viviana
,
concluding
she
was
about
to
be
led
to
the
torture
,
endeavoured
to
string
herself
to
its
endurance
.
<EOS>
Though
he
guessed
what
was
passing
in
her
breast
,
Jasper
Ipgreve
did
not
care
to
undeceive
her
,
but
motioning
the
hooded
officials
to
follow
him
with
her
,
quitted
the
cell
.
<EOS>
Seizing
each
a
hand
,
the
attendants
led
her
after
him
along
a
number
of
intricate
passages
,
until
he
stopped
before
the
door
of
a
cell
,
which
he
opened
.
<EOS>
"Be
<EOS>
brief
in
what
you
have
to
say
,
"
he
cried
,
thrusting
her
forward
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
allow
you
much
time
.
<EOS>
"Viviana
<EOS>
no
sooner
set
foot
in
the
cell
than
she
felt
in
whose
presence
she
stood
.
<EOS>
On
a
stool
at
the
further
end
of
the
narrow
chamber
,
with
his
head
upon
his
breast
,
and
a
cloak
wrapped
around
his
limbs
,
sat
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
A
small
iron
lamp
,
suspended
by
a
rusty
chain
from
the
ceiling
,
served
to
illumine
his
ghastly
features
.
<EOS>
He
lifted
his
eyes
from
the
ground
on
her
entrance
,
and
recognising
her
,
uttered
a
cry
of
anguish
.
<EOS>
Raising
himself
by
a
great
effort
,
he
opened
his
arms
,
and
she
rushed
into
them
.
<EOS>
For
some
moments
,
both
continued
silent
.
<EOS>
Grief
took
away
their
utterance
;
but
at
length
,
Guy
Fawkes
spoke
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
cup
of
bitterness
was
not
sufficiently
full
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
This
alone
was
wanting
to
make
it
overflow
.
<EOS>
""I
fear
you
will
blame
me
,
"
she
replied
,
"
when
you
learn
that
I
have
voluntarily
surrendered
myself
.
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
uttered
a
deep
groan
.
<EOS>
"I
am
the
cause
of
<EOS>
your
doing
so
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"You
are
so
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
forgive
me
when
you
know
my
motive
.
<EOS>
I
came
here
to
urge
you
to
repentance
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
if
you
hope
that
we
shall
meet
again
hereafter
—
if
you
hope
that
we
shall
inherit
joys
which
will
requite
us
for
all
our
troubles
,
you
will
employ
the
brief
time
left
you
on
earth
in
imploring
forgiveness
for
your
evil
intentions
.
<EOS>
""Having
<EOS>
had
no
evil
intentions
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
coldly
,
"
I
have
no
pardon
to
ask
.
<EOS>
""The
<EOS>
Tempter
who
led
you
into
the
commission
of
sin
under
the
semblance
of
righteousness
,
puts
these
thoughts
into
your
heart
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
escaped
the
commission
of
an
offence
which
must
have
deprived
you
of
the
joys
of
heaven
,
and
I
am
thankful
for
it
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
remain
impenitent
,
I
shall
tremble
for
your
salvation
.
<EOS>
""My
<EOS>
account
will
soon
be
settled
with
my
Maker
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
;
"
and
he
will
punish
or
reward
me
according
to
my
deserts
.
<EOS>
I
have
acted
according
to
my
conscience
,
and
can
never
repent
that
which
I
believe
to
be
a
righteous
design
.
<EOS>
""But
<EOS>
do
you
not
now
see
that
you
were
mistaken
,
"
returned
Viviana,—"do
<EOS>
you
not
perceive
that
the
sword
which
you
raised
against
others
has
been
turned
against
yourself,—and
that
the
Great
Power
whom
you
serve
and
worship
has
declared
himself
against
you?""You
seek
in
vain
to
move
me
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
insensible
to
your
arguments
as
to
the
tortures
of
my
enemies
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
Heaven
have
mercy
upon
your
soul
!
<EOS>
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"Look
at
me
,
Viviana
,
"
cried
Fawkes
,
"
and
behold
the
wreck
I
am
.
<EOS>
What
has
supported
me
amid
my
tortures
—
in
this
dungeon
—
in
the
presence
of
my
relentless
foes?—what
,
but
the
consciousness
of
having
acted
rightly
?
<EOS>
And
what
will
support
me
on
the
scaffold
except
the
same
conviction
?
<EOS>
If
you
love
me
,
do
not
seek
to
shake
my
faith
!
<EOS>
But
it
is
idle
to
talk
thus
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
do
so
.
<EOS>
Rest
satisfied
we
shall
meet
again
.
<EOS>
Everything
assures
me
of
it
.
<EOS>
Wretched
as
I
appear
in
this
solitary
cell
,
I
am
not
wholly
miserable
,
because
I
am
buoyed
up
by
the
certainty
that
my
actions
are
approved
by
Heaven
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
attempt
to
destroy
the
delusion
,
since
it
is
productive
of
happiness
to
you
,
"
replied
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
But
if
my
earnest
,
heartfelt
prayers
can
conduce
to
your
salvation
,
they
shall
not
be
wanting
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
she
spoke
,
the
door
of
the
cell
was
opened
by
Jasper
Ipgreve
,
who
stepped
towards
her
,
and
seized
her
roughly
by
the
hand
.
<EOS>
"Your
time
has
expired
,
mistress
,
"
he
said
;
"
you
must
come
with
me
.
<EOS>
""A
<EOS>
minute
longer
,
"
implored
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Not
<EOS>
a
second
,
"
replied
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"Shall
<EOS>
we
not
meet
again
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
distractedly
.
<EOS>
"Ay
,
the
day
before
your
execution
,
"
rejoined
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
good
news
for
you
,
"
he
added
,
pausing
for
a
moment
,
and
addressing
Fawkes
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Tresham
,
who
I
told
you
has
been
brought
to
the
Tower
,
has
been
taken
suddenly
and
dangerously
ill
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
the
traitor
perishes
before
me
<EOS>
,
I
shall
die
content
,
"
observed
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Then
rest
assured
of
it
,
"
said
Viviana
.
<EOS>
"
The
task
of
vengeance
is
already
fulfilled
.
<EOS>
"She
was
then
forced
away
by
Ipgreve
,
and
delivered
by
him
to
the
hooded
officials
outside
,
who
hurried
her
back
to
her
dungeon
.
<EOS>
XII
.
<EOS>
—
<EOS>
THE
TRAITOR
BETRAYEDLord
Mounteagle
arrived
at
the
Tower
shortly
after
Viviana
,
and
repairing
at
once
to
the
lieutenant
's
lodgings
,
had
a
brief
conference
with
him
,
and
informed
him
that
he
had
a
secret
order
to
deliver
to
Jasper
Ipgreve
,
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
touching
the
conspirators
.
<EOS>
Sir
William
Waad
would
have
summoned
the
jailer
;
but
Mounteagle
preferred
visiting
him
at
the
Well
Tower
,
and
accordingly
proceeded
thither
.
<EOS>
He
found
Ipgreve
with
his
wife
and
daughter
,
and
telling
him
he
desired
a
moment
's
private
speech
with
him
,
the
jailer
dismissed
them
.
<EOS>
Suspecting
that
the
new
-
comer
's
errand
related
in
some
way
to
Viviana
,
Ruth
contrived
to
place
herself
in
such
a
situation
that
she
could
overhear
what
passed
.
<EOS>
A
moment
's
scrutiny
of
Jasper
's
villanous
countenance
satisfied
Mounteagle
that
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
was
not
mistaken
in
his
man
;
and
,
as
soon
as
he
supposed
they
were
alone
<EOS>
,
he
unhesitatingly
opened
his
plan
to
him
.
<EOS>
As
he
expected
,
Jasper
exhibited
no
reluctance
to
undertake
it
;
and
,
after
some
further
discussion
,
it
was
agreed
to
put
it
in
execution
without
delay
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
sooner
Mr.
Tresham
is
silenced
the
better
,
"
said
Jasper
;
"
for
he
threatens
to
make
disclosures
to
the
Council
that
will
bring
some
noble
persons
,
"
with
a
significant
look
at
Mounteagle
,
"
into
trouble
.
<EOS>
""Where
<EOS>
is
he
confined
?
"
demanded
the
other
.
<EOS>
"In
<EOS>
the
Beauchamp
Tower
,
"
replied
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"I
will
visit
him
at
once
,
"
said
Mounteagle
;
"
and
when
I
have
conferred
with
him
,
will
call
for
wine
.
<EOS>
Bring
two
goblets
,
and
in
that
which
you
give
to
Tresham
place
this
powder
.
<EOS>
"Ipgreve
<EOS>
nodded
assent
,
and
with
a
grim
smile
took
the
packet
.
<EOS>
Shortly
after
this
,
they
quitted
the
Well
Tower
together
,
and
passing
under
the
archway
of
the
Bloody
Tower
,
crossed
the
green
,
and
entered
the
fortification
in
which
the
traitor
was
confined
.
<EOS>
Tresham
was
treated
with
far
greater
consideration
than
the
other
conspirators
,
being
allowed
the
use
of
the
large
room
on
the
upper
floor
of
the
Beauchamp
Tower
,
which
was
seldom
allotted
to
any
persons
except
those
of
the
highest
distinction
.
<EOS>
When
they
entered
,
he
was
pacing
to
and
fro
within
his
chamber
in
great
agitation
;
but
he
immediately
stopped
on
seeing
Mounteagle
,
and
rushed
towards
him
.
<EOS>
"You
bring
me
my
liberation
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
"It
is
impossible
to
effect
it
at
present
,
"
returned
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
But
make
yourself
perfectly
easy
.
<EOS>
Your
confinement
will
not
be
of
long
duration
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
be
trifled
with
,
"
cried
Tresham
,
furiously
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
am
examined
by
the
Council
,
look
to
yourselves
.
<EOS>
As
I
hope
for
salvation
,
the
truth
shall
out
.
<EOS>
""Leave
us
,
"
said
Mounteagle
,
with
a
significant
look
at
the
jailer
,
who
quitted
the
chamber
.
<EOS>
"Hark'e
,
Mounteagle
<EOS>
,
"
said
Tresham
,
as
soon
as
they
were
alone
,
"
I
have
been
your
tool
thus
far
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
propose
to
lead
me
blindfold
to
the
scaffold
,
you
are
greatly
mistaken
.
<EOS>
You
think
that
you
have
me
safe
within
these
walls
;
that
my
voice
can
not
be
heard
;
and
that
I
can
not
betray
you
.
<EOS>
But
you
are
deceived
—
fearfully
deceived
,
as
you
will
find
.
<EOS>
I
have
your
letters
—
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
's
letters
,
proving
that
you
were
both
aware
of
the
plot
—
and
that
you
employed
me
to
watch
its
progress
,
and
report
it
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
also
letters
from
Doctor
Dee
,
the
warden
of
Manchester
,
detailing
his
acquaintance
with
the
conspiracy
,
and
containing
descriptions
of
the
persons
of
Fawkes
and
Catesby
,
which
I
showed
to
the
Earl
of
Salisbury.—These
letters
are
now
in
my
possession
,
and
I
will
deliver
them
to
the
Council
,
if
I
am
not
released
.
<EOS>
""Deliver
them
to
me
,
and
I
swear
to
you
,
you
shall
be
set
free
,
"
said
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"I
will
not
trust
you
,
"
rejoined
Tresham
.
"
<EOS>
Liberate
me
,
and
they
are
yours
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
rob
myself
of
vengeance
.
<EOS>
I
will
confound
you
and
the
false
Earl
of
Salisbury
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
wrong
us
both
by
your
unjust
suspicions
,
"
said
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"Wrong
you
!
"
echoed
Tresham
,
contemptuously
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
is
my
promised
reward
?
<EOS>
Why
am
I
in
this
dungeon
?
<EOS>
Why
am
I
treated
like
a
traitor
?
<EOS>
If
you
meant
me
fairly
,
I
should
not
be
here
,
but
like
yourself
at
liberty
,
and
in
the
enjoyment
of
the
King
's
favour
.
<EOS>
But
you
have
duped
me
,
villain
,
and
shall
rue
it
.
<EOS>
If
I
am
led
to
the
scaffold
,
it
shall
be
in
your
company
.
<EOS>
""Compose
<EOS>
yourself
,
"
rejoined
Mounteagle
,
calmly
.
<EOS>
"
Appearances
,
I
own
,
are
against
us
.
<EOS>
But
circumstances
render
it
imperatively
necessary
that
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
should
appear
to
act
against
you
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
charged
by
Guy
Fawkes
,
when
under
the
torture
,
of
being
a
confederate
in
the
design
,
and
your
arrest
could
not
be
avoided
.
<EOS>
I
am
come
hither
to
give
you
a
solemn
assurance
that
no
harm
shall
befal
you
,
but
that
you
shall
be
delivered
from
your
thraldom
in
a
few
days
—
perhaps
in
a
few
hours
.
<EOS>
""You
have
no
further
design
against
me
,
"
said
Tresham
,
suspiciously
.
<EOS>
"What
motive
<EOS>
could
I
have
in
coming
hither
,
except
to
set
your
mind
at
rest
?
<EOS>
"
rejoined
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
I
shall
receive
my
reward
?
"
demanded
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"You
will
receive
your
reward
,
"
returned
Mounteagle
,
with
significant
emphasis
.
<EOS>
"
I
swear
it
.
<EOS>
So
make
yourself
easy
.
<EOS>
""If
<EOS>
I
thought
I
might
trust
you
,
<EOS>
I
should
not
heed
my
imprisonment
,
irksome
though
it
be
,
"
rejoined
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"It
can
not
be
avoided
,
for
the
reasons
I
have
just
stated
,
"
replied
Mounteagle
.
"
<EOS>
But
come
,
no
more
despondency
.
<EOS>
All
will
be
well
with
you
speedily
.
<EOS>
Let
us
drown
care
in
a
bumper
.
<EOS>
What
ho
!
<EOS>
jailer
,
"
he
added
,
opening
the
door
,
"
a
cup
of
wine!"In
a
few
minutes
,
<EOS>
Ipgreve
made
his
appearance
,
bearing
two
goblets
filled
with
wine
on
a
salver
,
one
of
which
he
presented
to
Mounteagle
,
and
the
other
to
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"Here
is
to
your
speedy
deliverance
from
captivity
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mounteagle
,
draining
the
goblet
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
refuse
that
pledge
,
Tresham?""Of
a
surety
not
,
"
replied
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
To
my
speedy
deliverance!"And
he
emptied
the
cup
,
while
Mounteagle
and
the
jailer
exchanged
significant
glances
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
now
,
having
fully
discharged
my
errand
,
I
must
bid
you
farewell
,
"
said
Mounteagle
.
<EOS>
"You
will
not
forget
your
promise
?
"
<EOS>
observed
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"Assuredly
<EOS>
not
,
"
replied
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
A
week
hence
,
and
you
will
make
no
complaint
against
me.—Are
<EOS>
you
sure
you
did
not
give
me
the
wrong
goblet
?
<EOS>
"
he
added
to
Ipgreve
,
as
they
descended
the
spiral
staircase
.
"Quite
<EOS>
sure
,
my
lord
,
"
returned
the
jailer
,
with
a
grim
smile
.
<EOS>
Mounteagle
immediately
quitted
the
Tower
,
and
hastening
to
Whitehall
,
sought
out
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
to
whom
he
related
what
he
had
done
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
complimented
him
on
his
skilful
management
of
the
matter
;
and
congratulating
each
other
upon
having
got
rid
of
a
dangerous
and
now
useless
instrument
,
they
separated
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
,
Tresham
was
seized
with
a
sudden
illness
,
and
making
known
his
symptoms
to
Ipgreve
,
the
chirurgeon
who
attended
the
prison
was
sent
for
,
and
on
seeing
him
,
pronounced
him
dangerously
ill
,
though
he
was
at
a
loss
to
explain
the
nature
of
his
disorder
.
<EOS>
Every
hour
the
sick
man
grew
worse
,
and
he
was
torn
with
racking
pains
.
<EOS>
Connecting
his
sudden
seizure
with
the
visit
of
Lord
Mounteagle
,
an
idea
of
the
truth
flashed
upon
him
,
and
he
mentioned
his
suspicions
to
the
chirurgeon
,
charging
Jasper
Ipgreve
with
being
accessory
to
the
deed
.
<EOS>
The
jailer
stoutly
denied
the
accusation
,
and
charged
the
prisoner
in
his
turn
with
making
a
malicious
statement
to
bring
him
into
discredit
.
<EOS>
"I
will
soon
test
the
truth
of
his
assertion
,
"
observed
the
chirurgeon
,
taking
a
small
flat
piece
of
the
purest
gold
from
his
doublet
.
<EOS>
"
Place
this
in
your
mouth
.
<EOS>
"Tresham
<EOS>
obeyed
,
and
Ipgreve
watched
the
experiment
with
gloomy
curiosity
.
<EOS>
"You
are
a
dead
man
,
"
said
the
chirurgeon
to
Tresham
,
as
he
drew
forth
the
piece
of
gold
,
and
perceived
that
it
was
slightly
tarnished
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Poison
has
been
administered
to
you
.
<EOS>
""Is
there
<EOS>
no
remedy
—
no
counter
-
poison
?
"
demanded
Tresham
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
The
chirurgeon
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
"Then
let
the
lieutenant
be
summoned
,
"
said
Tresham
;
<EOS>
"
I
have
an
important
confession
to
make
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
charge
this
man
,
"
pointing
to
the
jailer
,
"
with
giving
poisoned
wine
to
me
.
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
what
I
say
to
you?""I
do
,
"
replied
the
chirurgeon
.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
he
will
never
reveal
it
,
"
said
Ipgreve
,
with
great
unconcern
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
warrant
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
for
what
I
have
done
.
<EOS>
""What
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tresham
,
"
can
murder
be
committed
here
with
impunity?""You
<EOS>
have
to
thank
your
own
indiscretion
for
what
has
happened
,
"
rejoined
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Had
you
kept
a
close
tongue
in
your
head
,
you
would
have
been
safe
.
<EOS>
""Can
<EOS>
nothing
be
done
to
save
me
?
"
cried
the
miserable
man
,
with
an
imploring
look
at
the
chirurgeon
.
<EOS>
"Nothing
<EOS>
whatever
,
"
replied
the
person
appealed
to
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
advise
you
to
recommend
your
soul
to
God
.
<EOS>
""Will
<EOS>
you
not
inform
the
lieutenant
that
I
desire
to
speak
with
him
?
"
demanded
Tresham
.
<EOS>
The
chirurgeon
glanced
at
Ipgreve
,
and
receiving
a
sign
from
him
,
gave
a
promise
to
that
effect
.
<EOS>
They
then
quitted
the
cell
together
,
leaving
Tresham
in
a
state
of
indescribable
agony
both
of
mind
and
body
.
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
afterwards
,
the
chirurgeon
returned
,
and
informed
him
that
the
lieutenant
refused
to
visit
him
,
or
to
hear
his
confession
,
and
wholly
discredited
the
fact
of
his
being
poisoned
.
<EOS>
"I
will
take
charge
of
your
papers
,
if
you
choose
to
commit
them
to
me
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
will
lay
them
before
the
Council
.
<EOS>
""No
,
"
replied
Tresham
;
"
while
life
remains
to
me
I
will
never
part
with
them
.
<EOS>
""I
have
brought
you
a
mixture
which
,
though
it
can
not
heal
you
,
will
,
at
least
,
allay
your
sufferings
,
"
said
the
chirurgeon
.
<EOS>
"I
will
not
take
it
,
"
groaned
Tresham
.
<EOS>
"
I
distrust
you
as
much
as
the
others
.
<EOS>
""I
will
leave
it
with
you
,
at
all
events
,
"
rejoined
the
chirurgeon
,
setting
down
the
phial
.
<EOS>
The
noise
of
the
bolts
shot
into
their
sockets
sounded
to
Tresham
as
if
his
tomb
were
closed
upon
him
,
and
he
uttered
a
cry
of
anguish
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
laid
violent
hands
upon
himself
,
and
accelerated
his
own
end
,
but
he
wanted
courage
to
do
so
,
and
continued
to
pace
backwards
and
forwards
across
his
chamber
as
long
as
his
strength
lasted
.
<EOS>
He
was
about
to
throw
himself
on
the
couch
,
from
which
he
never
expected
to
rise
again
,
when
his
eyes
fell
upon
the
phial
.
<EOS>
"
What
if
it
should
be
poison
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
"
it
will
end
my
sufferings
the
sooner
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
placing
it
to
his
lips
,
he
swallowed
its
contents
.
<EOS>
As
the
chirurgeon
had
foretold
,
it
alleviated
his
sufferings
,
and
throwing
himself
on
the
bed
he
sank
into
a
troubled
slumber
,
during
which
he
dreamed
that
Catesby
appeared
to
him
with
a
vengeful
countenance
,
and
tried
to
drag
him
into
a
fathomless
abyss
that
yawned
beneath
their
feet
.
<EOS>
Shrieking
with
agony
,
he
awoke
,
and
found
two
persons
standing
by
his
couch
.
<EOS>
One
of
them
was
the
jailer
,
and
the
other
appeared
,
from
his
garb
,
to
be
a
priest
;
but
a
hood
was
drawn
over
his
head
so
as
to
conceal
his
features
.
<EOS>
"Are
<EOS>
you
come
to
witness
my
dying
pangs
,
or
to
finish
me
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Tresham
of
the
jailer
.
<EOS>
"I
am
come
for
neither
purpose
,
"
replied
Ipgreve
;
"
I
pity
your
condition
,
and
have
brought
you
a
priest
of
your
own
faith
,
who
,
like
yourself
,
is
a
prisoner
in
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
I
will
leave
him
with
you
,
but
he
can
not
remain
long
,
so
make
the
most
of
your
time
.
"
<EOS>
And
with
these
words
,
he
retired
.
<EOS>
When
he
was
gone
,
the
supposed
priest
,
who
spoke
in
feeble
and
faltering
accents
,
desired
to
hear
Tresham
's
confession
,
and
having
listened
to
it
,
gave
him
absolution
.
<EOS>
The
wretched
man
then
drew
from
his
bosom
a
small
packet
,
and
offered
it
to
the
confessor
,
who
eagerly
received
it
.
<EOS>
"This
contains
the
letters
of
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
and
Lord
Mounteagle
,
which
I
have
just
mentioned
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
pray
you
lay
them
before
the
Privy
Council
.
<EOS>
""I
will
not
fail
to
do
so
,
"
replied
the
confessor
.
<EOS>
And
reciting
the
prayer
for
one
in
extremis
over
the
dying
man
,
he
departed
.
<EOS>
"I
have
obtained
the
letters
from
him
,
"
said
Mounteagle
,
throwing
back
his
hood
as
he
quitted
the
chamber
,
and
addressing
the
jailer
.
<EOS>
"
And
now
you
need
give
yourself
no
further
concern
about
him
,
he
will
be
dead
before
morning
.
"Jasper
<EOS>
Ipgreve
locked
the
door
upon
the
prisoner
,
and
proceeded
to
the
Well
Tower
.
<EOS>
When
he
returned
,
he
found
Mounteagle
's
words
had
come
to
pass
.
<EOS>
Tresham
was
lying
on
the
floor
quite
dead
—
his
collapsed
frame
and
distorted
countenance
showing
the
agonies
in
which
he
must
have
expired
.
<EOS>
XIII
.
<EOS>
—
<EOS>
THE
TRIALThe
trial
of
the
conspirators
,
which
had
been
delayed
in
order
that
full
evidence
might
be
procured
against
them
,
was
,
at
length
,
appointed
to
take
place
in
Westminster
Hall
,
on
Monday
,
the
27th
of
January
,
1606
.
<EOS>
Early
on
the
morning
of
this
day
,
the
eight
surviving
confederates
(
Garnet
and
Oldcorne
being
at
this
time
secreted
at
Hendlip
)
were
conveyed
in
two
large
covered
wherries
from
the
fortress
to
the
place
of
trial
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
the
severity
of
the
weather,—it
was
snowing
heavily
,
and
the
river
was
covered
with
sheets
of
ice,—they
were
attended
by
a
vast
number
of
boats
filled
with
persons
anxious
to
obtain
a
sight
of
them
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
abhorrence
in
which
the
actors
in
the
conspiracy
were
held
by
the
populace
,
that
,
not
content
with
menaces
and
execrations
,
many
of
these
persons
hurled
missiles
against
the
wherries
,
and
would
have
proceeded
to
further
violence
if
they
had
not
been
restrained
by
the
pikemen
.
<EOS>
When
the
prisoners
landed
,
a
tremendous
and
fearful
shout
was
raised
by
the
mob
stationed
at
the
head
of
the
stairs
,
and
it
required
the
utmost
efforts
of
the
guard
to
protect
them
from
injury
.
<EOS>
Two
lines
of
soldiers
,
with
calivers
on
their
shoulders
,
were
drawn
out
from
the
banks
of
the
river
to
the
entrance
of
the
Hall
,
and
between
them
the
conspirators
marched
.
<EOS>
The
melancholy
procession
was
headed
by
Sir
William
Waad
,
who
was
followed
by
an
officer
of
the
guard
and
six
halberdiers
.
<EOS>
Then
came
the
executioner
,
carrying
the
gleaming
implement
of
death
with
its
edge
turned
from
the
prisoners
.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
by
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
whose
noble
figure
and
handsome
countenance
excited
much
sympathy
among
the
beholders
,
and
Ambrose
Rookwood
.
<EOS>
Next
came
the
two
Winters
,
both
of
whom
appeared
greatly
dejected
.
<EOS>
Next
,
John
Grant
and
Robert
Bates,—Catesby
's
servant
,
who
had
been
captured
at
Holbeach
.
<EOS>
And
lastly
,
Keyes
and
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Bitterly
and
justly
incensed
as
were
the
multitude
against
the
conspirators
,
their
feelings
underwent
some
change
as
they
beheld
the
haggard
countenance
and
shattered
frame
of
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
It
was
soon
understood
that
he
was
the
individual
who
had
been
found
in
the
vault
near
the
Parliament
House
,
with
the
touchwood
and
matches
in
his
belt
ready
to
fire
the
train
;
and
the
greatest
curiosity
was
exhibited
to
see
him
.
<EOS>
Just
as
the
foremost
of
the
conspirators
reached
the
entrance
of
the
Hall
,
a
terrific
yell
,
resembling
nothing
human
,
except
the
roar
of
a
thousand
tigers
thirsting
for
blood
,
was
uttered
by
the
mob
,
and
a
tremendous
but
ineffectual
attempt
was
made
to
break
through
the
lines
of
the
guard
.
<EOS>
Never
before
had
so
large
an
assemblage
been
collected
on
the
spot
.
<EOS>
The
whole
of
the
space
extending
on
one
hand
from
Westminster
Hall
to
the
gates
of
Whitehall
,
and
on
the
other
to
the
Abbey
,
was
filled
with
spectators
;
and
every
roof
,
window
,
and
buttress
was
occupied
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
the
interior
of
the
Hall
less
crowded
.
<EOS>
Not
an
inch
of
room
was
unoccupied
;
and
it
was
afterwards
complained
in
Parliament
,
that
the
members
of
the
house
had
been
so
pressed
and
incommoded
,
that
they
could
not
hear
what
was
said
at
the
arraignment
.
<EOS>
The
conspirators
were
first
conveyed
to
the
court
of
the
Star
-
Chamber
,
where
they
remained
till
the
Lords
Commissioners
had
arrived
,
and
taken
their
seats
.
<EOS>
The
commissioners
were
the
Earl
of
Nottingham
,
Lord
High
Admiral
of
England
;
the
Earl
of
Suffolk
,
Steward
of
the
Household
;
the
Earl
of
Worcester
,
Master
of
the
Horse
;
the
Earl
of
Devonshire
,
Master
of
the
Ordnance
;
the
Earl
of
Northampton
,
Warden
of
the
Cinque
-
Ports
;
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
Principal
Secretary
of
State
;
Sir
John
Popham
,
Lord
Chief
Justice
;
Sir
Thomas
Fleming
,
Lord
Chief
Baron
of
the
Exchequer
;
and
Sir
Thomas
Walmisley
and
Sir
Peter
Warburton
,
Knights
,
and
both
Justices
of
the
Common
Pleas
.
<EOS>
Summoned
by
an
usher
,
the
conspirators
were
conducted
to
a
platform
covered
with
black
cloth
,
which
had
been
erected
at
the
lower
end
of
the
Hall
.
<EOS>
A
murmur
of
indignation
,
vainly
sought
to
be
repressed
by
the
grave
looks
of
the
Commissioners
,
burst
from
the
immense
assemblage
,
as
they
one
by
one
ascended
the
steps
of
the
platform
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
was
the
last
to
mount
,
and
his
appearance
was
followed
by
a
deep
groan
.
<EOS>
Supporting
himself
against
the
rail
of
the
scaffold
,
he
surveyed
the
assemblage
with
a
stern
and
undaunted
look
.
<EOS>
As
he
gazed
around
,
he
could
not
help
marvelling
at
the
vast
multitude
before
him
.
<EOS>
The
whole
of
the
peers
and
all
the
members
of
the
House
of
Commons
were
present
,
while
in
a
box
on
the
left
,
though
screened
by
a
lattice
,
sat
the
Queen
and
Prince
Henry
;
and
in
another
on
the
right
,
and
protected
in
the
same
way
,
the
King
and
his
courtiers
.
<EOS>
Silence
being
peremptorily
commanded
,
the
indictment
was
read
,
wherein
the
prisoners
were
charged
with
conspiring
to
blow
up
the
King
and
the
peers
with
gunpowder
,
and
with
attempting
to
incite
the
Papists
,
and
other
persons
,
to
open
rebellion
;
to
which
all
the
conspirators
,
to
the
no
small
surprise
of
those
who
heard
them
,
and
were
aware
that
they
had
subscribed
their
confessions
,
pleaded
not
guilty
.
<EOS>
"How
,
sir
!
"
cried
the
Lord
Chief
Justice
,
in
a
stern
tone
to
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
With
what
face
can
you
pretend
to
deny
the
indictment
,
when
you
were
actually
taken
in
the
cellar
with
the
powder
,
and
have
already
confessed
your
treasonable
<EOS>
intentions?""I
do
not
mean
to
deny
what
I
have
confessed
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"
But
this
indictment
contains
many
matters
which
I
neither
can
nor
will
countenance
by
assent
or
silence
.
<EOS>
And
I
therefore
deny
it
.
<EOS>
""It
is
well
,
"
replied
the
Lord
Chief
Justice
.
<EOS>
"
Let
the
trial
proceed
.
<EOS>
"The
indictment
being
opened
by
Sir
Edward
Philips
,
sergeant
-
at
-
law
,
he
was
followed
by
Sir
Edward
Coke
,
the
attorney
-
general
,
who
in
an
eloquent
and
elaborate
speech
,
which
produced
an
extraordinary
effect
upon
the
assemblage
,
expatiated
upon
the
monstrous
nature
of
the
plot
,
which
he
characterised
as
"
the
greatest
treason
that
ever
was
plotted
in
England
,
and
against
the
greatest
king
that
ever
reigned
in
England
;
"
and
after
narrating
the
origin
and
progress
of
the
conspiracy
,
concluded
by
desiring
that
the
confessions
of
the
prisoners
should
be
openly
read
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
the
jury
were
ordered
by
the
Lord
Chief
Justice
to
retire
,
and
the
injunction
being
obeyed
,
they
almost
instantly
returned
with
a
verdict
of
guilty
.
<EOS>
A
deep
,
dread
silence
then
prevailed
throughout
the
Hall
,
and
every
eye
was
bent
upon
the
conspirators
,
all
of
whom
maintained
a
composed
demeanour
.
<EOS>
They
were
then
questioned
by
the
Lord
Chief
Justice
whether
they
had
anything
to
say
why
judgment
of
death
should
not
be
pronounced
against
them
.
<EOS>
"All
<EOS>
I
have
to
crave
of
your
lordships
,
"
said
Thomas
Winter
,
"
is
,
that
being
the
chief
offender
of
the
two
,
I
may
die
for
my
brother
and
myself
.
<EOS>
""And
<EOS>
I
ask
only
that
my
brother
's
request
may
not
be
granted
,
"
said
Robert
Winter
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
is
condemned
,
I
do
not
desire
to
live
.
<EOS>
""I
have
nothing
to
solicit
—
not
even
pardon
,
"
said
Keyes
,
carelessly
.
<EOS>
"
My
fortunes
were
always
desperate
,
and
are
better
now
than
they
have
ever
been
.
<EOS>
""I
desire
mercy
,
"
said
Rookwood
,
"
not
from
any
fear
of
death
,
but
because
so
shameful
an
ending
will
leave
a
perpetual
stain
upon
my
name
and
blood
.
<EOS>
I
humbly
submit
myself
to
the
King
,
and
pray
him
to
imitate
our
Supreme
Judge
,
who
sometimes
punishes
corporally
,
but
not
mortally
.
<EOS>
""I
have
been
guilty
of
a
conspiracy
,
intended
but
never
effected
,
"
said
John
Grant
,
"
and
solicit
forgiveness
on
that
plea
.
<EOS>
""My
<EOS>
crime
has
been
fidelity
to
my
master
,
"
said
Bates
.
<EOS>
"
If
the
King
will
let
me
live
,
I
will
serve
him
as
faithfully
as
I
did
Mr.
Catesby
.
<EOS>
""I
would
not
utter
a
word
,
"
said
Fawkes
,
looking
sternly
round
;
"
if
I
did
not
fear
my
silence
might
be
misinterpreted
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
accept
a
pardon
if
it
were
offered
me
.
<EOS>
I
regard
the
project
as
a
glorious
one
,
and
only
lament
its
failure
.
<EOS>
""Silence
<EOS>
the
vile
traitor
,
"
said
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
rising
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
spoke
two
halberdiers
sprang
up
the
steps
of
the
scaffold
,
and
placing
themselves
on
either
side
of
Fawkes
,
prepared
to
gag
him
.
<EOS>
"I
have
done
,
"
he
said
,
contemptuously
regarding
them
.
<EOS>
"I
have
nothing
to
say
save
this
,
"
said
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
bowing
to
the
judges
.
<EOS>
"
If
any
of
your
lordships
will
tell
me
you
forgive
me
,
I
shall
go
more
cheerfully
to
the
scaffold
.
<EOS>
""Heaven
forgive
you
,
Sir
Everard
,
"
said
the
Earl
of
Nottingham
,
returning
his
reverence
,
"
as
we
do
.
<EOS>
""I
humbly
thank
your
lordship
,
"
replied
Digby
.
<EOS>
Sentence
was
then
passed
upon
the
prisoners
by
Lord
Chief
Justice
Popham
,
and
they
were
removed
from
the
platform
.
<EOS>
As
they
issued
from
the
Hall
,
and
it
became
known
to
the
assemblage
without
that
they
were
condemned
,
a
shout
of
fierce
exultation
rent
the
air
,
and
they
were
so
violently
assailed
on
all
sides
,
that
they
had
great
difficulty
in
reaching
the
wherries
.
<EOS>
The
guard
,
however
,
succeeded
,
at
length
,
in
accomplishing
their
embarkation
,
and
they
were
conveyed
back
in
safety
to
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
XIV
.
<EOS>
—
THE
LAST
MEETING
OF
FAWKES
AND
VIVIANAUp
to
this
time
,
Viviana
had
not
been
allowed
another
interview
with
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
She
was
twice
interrogated
by
the
Privy
-
Council
,
but
having
confessed
all
she
knew
of
the
conspiracy
,
excepting
what
might
implicate
Garnet
and
Oldcorne
,
neither
of
whom
she
was
aware
had
been
apprehended
,
she
was
not
again
subjected
to
the
torture
.
<EOS>
Her
health
,
however
,
rapidly
sank
under
her
confinement
,
and
she
was
soon
reduced
to
such
an
extreme
state
of
debility
that
she
could
not
leave
her
bed
.
<EOS>
The
chirurgeon
having
been
called
in
by
Dame
Ipgreve
to
attend
her
,
reported
her
condition
to
Sir
William
Waad
,
who
directed
that
every
means
should
be
adopted
for
her
restoration
,
and
that
Ruth
Ipgreve
should
remain
in
constant
attendance
upon
her
.
<EOS>
Ascertaining
all
particulars
relative
to
Guy
Fawkes
from
the
jailer
's
daughter
,
it
was
a
sad
satisfaction
to
Viviana
to
learn
that
he
spent
his
whole
time
in
devotion
,
and
appeared
completely
resigned
to
his
fate
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
's
purpose
to
bring
Viviana
to
trial
at
the
same
time
as
the
rest
of
the
conspirators
,
but
the
chirurgeon
reporting
that
her
removal
at
this
juncture
would
be
attended
with
fatal
consequences
,
he
was
compelled
to
defer
it
.
<EOS>
When
the
result
of
the
trial
was
made
known
to
Viviana
by
Ruth
,
though
she
had
anticipated
the
condemnation
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
she
swooned
away
,
and
on
her
recovery
,
observed
to
Ruth
,
who
was
greatly
alarmed
at
her
looks
<EOS>
,
"
I
feel
I
am
going
fast
.
<EOS>
I
should
wish
to
see
my
husband
once
more
before
I
die
.
<EOS>
""I
fear
it
is
impossible
,
madam
,
"
replied
Ruth
;
"
but
I
will
try
to
accomplish
it
.
<EOS>
""Do
<EOS>
so
,
"
rejoined
Viviana
;
"
and
my
blessing
shall
rest
ever
on
your
head
.
<EOS>
""Have
you
any
valuable
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
My
heart
bleeds
to
make
the
demand
at
such
a
moment
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
the
only
way
to
produce
an
effect
on
the
avaricious
nature
of
my
father
.
<EOS>
""I
have
nothing
but
this
golden
crucifix
,
"
said
Viviana
;
"
and
I
meant
to
give
it
to
you
.
<EOS>
""It
will
be
better
employed
in
this
way
,
"
rejoined
Ruth
,
taking
it
from
her
.
<EOS>
Quitting
the
cell
,
she
hurried
to
the
Well
Tower
,
and
found
her
father
,
who
had
just
returned
from
locking
up
the
conspirators
in
their
different
dungeons
,
sitting
down
to
his
evening
meal
.
<EOS>
"What
is
the
matter
with
the
wench
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
staring
at
her
.
<EOS>
"
You
look
quite
distracted
.
<EOS>
Is
Viviana
Radcliffe
dead?""No
;
but
she
is
dying
,
"
replied
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"If
<EOS>
that
is
the
case
I
must
go
to
her
directly
,
"
observed
Dame
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"
She
may
have
some
valuable
about
her
which
I
must
secure
.
<EOS>
""You
will
be
disappointed
,
mother
,
"
rejoined
Ruth
,
with
a
look
of
irrepressible
disgust
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
has
nothing
valuable
left
but
this
golden
crucifix
,
which
she
has
sent
to
my
father
,
on
condition
of
his
allowing
Guy
Fawkes
to
see
her
before
she
dies
.
<EOS>
""Give
it
<EOS>
me
,
wench
<EOS>
,
"
cried
Jasper
Ipgreve
;
"
and
let
her
die
in
peace
.
<EOS>
""She
will
not
die
in
peace
unless
she
sees
him
,
"
replied
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
Nor
shall
you
have
it
,
if
you
do
not
comply
with
her
request
.
""How
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
her
father
,
"
do
you
dare——""Think
not
to
terrify
me
,
father
,
"
interrupted
Ruth
;
"
I
am
resolute
in
this
.
<EOS>
Hear
me
,
"
she
cried
,
seizing
his
arm
,
and
fixing
a
look
upon
him
that
seemed
to
pierce
his
soul,—"hear
me
,
"
she
said
,
in
a
tone
so
low
as
to
be
inaudible
to
her
mother
;
"
she
shall
see
him
,
or
I
will
denounce
you
as
the
murderer
of
Tresham
.
<EOS>
Now
will
you
comply?""Give
me
the
cross
,
"
said
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
"Not
<EOS>
till
you
have
earned
it
,
"
replied
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
"Well
,
well
,
"
he
rejoined
;
"
if
it
must
be
,
it
must
.
<EOS>
But
I
may
get
into
trouble
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
I
must
consult
Master
Forsett
,
the
gentleman
jailer
,
who
has
the
charge
of
Guy
Fawkes
,
before
I
dare
take
him
to
her
cell
.
<EOS>
""Consult
<EOS>
whom
you
please
,
"
rejoined
Ruth
,
impatiently
;
"
but
lose
no
time
,
or
you
will
be
too
late
.
<EOS>
"Muttering
<EOS>
imprecations
on
his
daughter
,
Ipgreve
left
the
Well
Tower
,
and
Ruth
hurried
back
to
Viviana
,
whom
she
found
anxiously
expecting
her
,
and
related
to
her
what
she
had
done
.
<EOS>
"Oh
<EOS>
,
that
I
may
hold
out
till
he
comes
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
;
"
but
my
strength
is
failing
fast
.
<EOS>
"Ruth
endeavoured
to
comfort
her
;
but
she
was
unequal
to
the
effort
,
and
bursting
into
tears
,
knelt
down
,
and
wept
upon
the
pillow
beside
her
.
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
had
now
elapsed
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
an
age
to
the
poor
sufferers
,
and
still
the
jailer
came
not
,
and
even
Ruth
had
given
up
all
hope
,
when
a
heavy
tread
was
heard
in
the
passage
;
the
door
was
opened
;
and
Guy
Fawkes
appeared
,
attended
by
Ipgreve
and
Forsett
.
"We
will
not
interrupt
your
parting
,
"
said
Forsett
,
who
seemed
to
have
a
touch
of
humanity
in
his
composition
.
<EOS>
And
beckoning
to
Ruth
to
follow
him
,
he
quitted
the
cell
with
Ipgreve
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
,
meanwhile
,
had
approached
the
couch
,
and
gazed
with
an
expression
of
intense
anguish
at
Viviana
.
<EOS>
She
returned
his
glance
with
a
look
of
the
utmost
affection
,
and
clasped
his
hand
between
her
thin
fingers
.
<EOS>
"I
am
now
standing
on
the
brink
of
eternity
,
"
she
said
in
a
solemn
tone
,
"
and
I
entreat
you
earnestly
,
as
you
hope
to
insure
our
meeting
hereafter
,
to
employ
the
few
days
left
you
in
sincere
and
hearty
repentance
.
<EOS>
You
have
sinned
—
sinned
deeply
,
but
not
beyond
the
power
of
redemption
.
<EOS>
Let
me
feel
that
I
have
saved
you
,
and
my
last
moments
will
be
happy
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
by
the
love
I
have
borne
you
—
by
the
pangs
I
have
endured
for
you
—
by
the
death
I
am
now
dying
for
you
—
let
me
implore
you
not
to
lose
one
moment
,
but
to
supplicate
a
merciful
Providence
to
pardon
your
offence
.
<EOS>
"Illustration"I
<EOS>
will
—
I
will
,
"
rejoined
Fawkes
,
in
broken
accents
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
opened
my
eyes
to
my
error
,
and
I
sincerely
repent
it
.
<EOS>
""Saved
!
<EOS>
saved
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Viviana
,
raising
herself
in
the
bed
.
<EOS>
Opening
her
arms
,
she
strained
him
to
her
bosom
;
and
for
a
few
moments
they
mingled
their
tears
together
.
<EOS>
"And
<EOS>
now
,
"
she
said
,
sinking
backwards
,
"
kneel
by
me
—
pray
for
forgiveness
—
pray
audibly
,
and
I
will
join
in
your
prayer
.
<EOS>
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
knelt
by
the
bedside
,
and
addressed
the
most
earnest
supplications
to
Heaven
for
forgiveness
.
<EOS>
For
a
while
he
heard
Viviana
's
gentle
accents
accompany
him
.
<EOS>
They
grew
fainter
and
fainter
,
until
at
last
they
totally
ceased
.
<EOS>
Filled
with
a
dreadful
apprehension
,
he
sprang
to
his
feet
.
<EOS>
An
angelic
smile
illumined
her
countenance
;
her
gaze
was
fixed
on
him
for
one
moment
—
it
then
grew
dim
and
dimmer
,
until
it
was
extinguished
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
uttered
a
cry
of
the
wildest
despair
,
and
fell
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
the
sound
,
Forsett
and
Ipgreve
,
who
were
standing
outside
,
rushed
into
the
cell
,
and
instantly
raised
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
now
in
a
state
of
distraction
,
and
for
the
moment
seemed
endowed
with
all
his
former
strength
.
<EOS>
Striving
to
break
from
them
,
he
cried
,
in
a
tone
of
the
most
piercing
anguish
,
"
You
shall
not
tear
me
from
her
!
<EOS>
I
will
die
with
her
!
<EOS>
Let
me
go
,
I
say
,
or
I
will
dash
out
my
brains
against
these
flinty
walls
,
and
balk
you
of
your
prey
.
<EOS>
"But
<EOS>
his
struggles
were
in
vain
.
<EOS>
They
held
him
fast
,
and
calling
for
further
assistance
,
conveyed
him
to
his
cell
,
where
,
fearing
he
might
do
some
violence
to
himself
,
they
placed
him
in
irons
.
<EOS>
Ruth
entered
the
cell
as
soon
as
Fawkes
and
the
others
had
quitted
it
,
and
performed
the
last
sad
offices
for
the
departed
.
<EOS>
Alternately
praying
and
weeping
,
she
watched
by
the
body
during
the
whole
of
the
night
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
,
the
remains
of
the
unfortunate
Viviana
were
interred
in
the
chapel
of
Saint
Peter
on
the
Green
,
and
the
sole
mourner
was
the
jailer
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
"Peace
be
with
her
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Ruth
,
as
she
turned
away
from
the
grave
.
<EOS>
"
Her
sorrows
at
last
are
over
.
<EOS>
"XV
.
<EOS>
—
<EOS>
SAINT
PAUL
'S
<EOS>
CHURCHYARDGuy
Fawkes
was
for
some
time
wholly
inconsolable
.
<EOS>
His
stoical
nature
seemed
completely
subdued
,
and
he
wept
like
an
infant
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
however
,
the
violence
of
his
grief
abated
,
and
calling
to
mind
the
last
injunctions
of
her
whose
loss
he
mourned
,
he
addressed
himself
to
prayer
,
and
acknowledging
his
guilt
,
besought
her
intercession
with
Heaven
for
his
forgiveness
.
<EOS>
It
will
not
seem
strange
,
when
his
superstitious
character
is
taken
into
consideration
,
that
he
should
fancy
he
received
an
immediate
proof
that
his
prayers
were
heard
.
<EOS>
To
his
excited
imagination
it
appeared
that
a
soft
unearthly
strain
of
music
floated
in
the
air
over
his
head
;
that
an
odour
like
that
of
Paradise
filled
his
cell
;
while
an
invisible
finger
touched
his
brow
.
<EOS>
While
in
this
entranced
state
,
he
was
utterly
insensible
to
his
present
miserable
situation
,
and
he
seemed
to
have
a
foretaste
of
celestial
happiness
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
,
however
,
desist
from
prayer
,
but
continued
his
supplications
throughout
the
day
.
<EOS>
On
that
night
,
he
was
visited
by
the
lieutenant
,
who
announced
to
him
that
the
execution
of
four
of
the
conspirators
was
fixed
for
Thursday
<EOS>
(
it
was
then
Tuesday
)
,
while
his
own
and
that
of
the
three
others
would
not
take
place
till
the
following
day
.
<EOS>
"As
<EOS>
you
are
the
greatest
traitor
of
all
,
your
execution
will
be
reserved
to
the
last
,
"
pursued
Waad
.
<EOS>
"
No
part
of
the
sentence
will
be
omitted
.
<EOS>
You
will
be
dragged
to
Old
Palace
Yard
,
over
against
the
scene
of
your
intended
bloody
and
damnable
action
,
at
a
horse
's
tail
,
and
will
be
there
turned
off
the
gallows
,
and
hanged
,
but
not
till
you
are
dead
.
<EOS>
You
will
then
be
embowelled
;
your
vile
heart
,
which
conceived
this
atrocious
design
,
will
be
torn
beating
from
your
breast
;
and
your
quarters
will
be
placed
on
the
palace
gates
as
an
abhorrent
spectacle
in
the
eyes
of
men
,
and
a
terrible
proof
of
the
King
's
just
vengeance
.
<EOS>
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
heard
the
recapitulation
of
his
dreadful
sentence
unmoved
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
sole
mercy
<EOS>
I
would
have
craved
of
his
Majesty
would
have
been
permission
to
die
first
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
But
Heaven
's
will
be
done
!
<EOS>
I
deserve
my
doom
.
<EOS>
""What
!
<EOS>
is
your
stubborn
nature
at
length
subdued
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
lieutenant
in
surprise
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
repent
of
your
offence?""Deeply
and
heartily
,
"
returned
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
"Make
<EOS>
the
sole
amends
in
your
power
for
it
,
then
,
and
disclose
the
names
of
all
who
have
been
connected
with
the
atrocious
design
,
"
rejoined
Waad
.
<EOS>
"I
confess
myself
guilty
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
humbly
.
"
<EOS>
But
I
accuse
no
others
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
you
die
impenitent
,
"
rejoined
the
lieutenant
,
"
and
can
not
hope
for
mercy
hereafter
.
<EOS>
"Guy
<EOS>
Fawkes
made
no
answer
,
but
bowed
his
head
upon
his
breast
,
and
the
lieutenant
,
darting
a
malignant
look
at
him
,
quitted
the
cell
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
,
the
whole
of
the
conspirators
were
taken
to
St.
John
's
chapel
,
in
the
White
Tower
,
where
a
discourse
was
pronounced
to
them
by
Doctor
Overall
,
Dean
of
St.
Paul
's
,
who
enlarged
upon
the
enormity
of
their
offence
,
and
exhorted
them
to
repentance
.
<EOS>
The
discourse
over
,
they
were
about
to
be
removed
,
when
two
ladies
,
clad
in
mourning
habits
,
entered
the
chapel
.
<EOS>
These
were
Lady
Digby
and
Mrs.
Rookwood
,
and
they
immediately
flew
to
their
husbands
.
<EOS>
The
rest
of
the
conspirators
walked
away
,
and
averted
their
gaze
from
the
painful
scene
.
<EOS>
After
an
ineffectual
attempt
to
speak
,
Lady
Digby
swooned
away
,
and
was
committed
by
her
husband
,
while
in
a
state
of
insensibility
,
to
the
care
of
an
attendant
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Rookwood
,
however
,
who
was
a
woman
of
high
spirit
,
and
great
personal
attractions
,
though
the
latter
were
now
wasted
by
affliction
,
maintained
her
composure
,
and
encouraging
her
husband
to
bear
up
manfully
against
his
situation
,
tenderly
embraced
him
,
and
withdrew
.
<EOS>
The
conspirators
were
then
taken
back
to
their
cells
.
<EOS>
At
an
early
hour
on
the
following
morning
the
four
miserable
persons
intended
for
death
,
namely
,
Sir
Everard
Digby
,
the
elder
Winter
,
John
Grant
,
and
Bates
,
were
conducted
to
the
Beauchamp
Tower
.
<EOS>
Bates
would
have
stood
aloof
from
his
superiors
;
but
Sir
Everard
Digby
took
him
kindly
by
the
hand
,
and
drew
him
towards
them
.
<EOS>
"No
<EOS>
distinctions
must
be
observed
now
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
We
ought
to
beg
pardon
of
thee
,
my
poor
fellow
,
for
bringing
thee
into
this
strait
.
<EOS>
""Think
not
of
me
,
worshipful
sir
,
"
replied
Bates
.
<EOS>
"
I
loved
Mr.
Catesby
so
well
,
that
I
would
have
laid
down
my
life
for
him
at
any
time
;
and
I
now
die
cheerfully
in
his
cause
.
<EOS>
""Mr
.
<EOS>
Lieutenant
,
"
said
Robert
Winter
to
Sir
William
Waad
,
who
stood
near
them
with
Forsett
and
Ipgreve
,
"
I
pray
you
commend
me
to
my
brother
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
I
die
in
entire
love
of
him
,
and
if
it
is
possible
for
the
departed
to
watch
over
the
living
,
I
will
be
with
him
at
his
last
hour
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
this
moment
,
a
trampling
of
horses
was
heard
on
the
green
,
and
the
lieutenant
proceeding
to
the
grated
window
,
saw
four
mounted
troopers
,
each
having
a
sledge
and
hurdle
attached
by
ropes
to
his
steed
,
drawn
up
before
the
door
.
<EOS>
While
he
was
gazing
at
them
,
an
officer
entered
the
room
,
and
informed
him
that
all
was
in
readiness
.
<EOS>
Sir
William
Waad
then
motioned
the
prisoners
to
follow
him
,
and
they
descended
the
spiral
staircase
.
<EOS>
The
green
was
thronged
with
horse
and
foot
soldiers
,
and
as
the
conspirators
issued
from
the
arched
door
of
the
fortification
,
the
bell
of
Saint
Peter
's
chapel
began
to
toll
.
<EOS>
Sir
Everard
Digby
was
first
bound
to
a
hurdle
,
with
his
face
towards
the
horse
,
and
the
others
were
quickly
secured
in
the
same
manner
.
<EOS>
The
melancholy
cavalcade
was
then
put
in
motion
.
<EOS>
A
troop
of
horse
-
soldiers
in
their
full
accoutrements
,
and
with
calivers
upon
their
shoulders
,
rode
first
;
then
came
a
band
of
halberdiers
on
foot
;
then
the
masked
executioner
mounted
on
a
led
horse
,
then
the
four
prisoners
on
the
hurdles
,
one
after
the
other
;
then
the
lieutenant
on
horseback
;
while
another
band
of
horse
-
soldiers
,
equipped
like
the
first
,
brought
up
the
rear
.
<EOS>
They
were
met
by
the
Recorder
of
London
,
Sir
Henry
Montague
,
and
the
sheriffs
,
at
the
gate
of
the
Middle
Tower
,
to
the
latter
of
whom
<EOS>
the
lieutenant
,
according
to
custom
,
delivered
up
the
bodies
of
the
prisoners
.
<EOS>
After
a
short
delay
,
the
train
again
set
forward
,
and
emerging
from
the
Bulwark
Gate
,
proceeded
through
an
enormous
concourse
of
spectators
towards
Tower
-
street
.
<EOS>
Aware
that
a
vast
crowd
would
be
assembled
in
the
city
,
and
apprehensive
of
some
popular
tumult
,
the
Lord
Mayor
had
issued
precepts
to
the
aldermen
of
every
ward
,
commanding
them
"
to
cause
one
able
and
sufficient
person
,
with
a
halbert
in
his
hand
,
to
stand
at
the
door
of
every
dwelling
-
house
in
the
open
street
in
the
way
that
the
traitors
were
to
be
drawn
towards
the
place
of
execution
,
there
to
remain
from
seven
in
the
morning
until
the
return
of
the
sheriffs
.
<EOS>
"
But
these
were
not
the
whole
of
the
arrangements
made
to
preserve
order
.
<EOS>
The
cavalcade
,
it
was
fixed
,
was
to
proceed
along
Tower
-
street
,
Gracechurch
street
,
Lombard
-
street
,
Cheapside
,
and
so
on
to
the
west
end
of
Saint
Paul
's
cathedral
,
where
the
scaffold
was
erected
.
<EOS>
Along
the
whole
road
,
on
either
side
,
a
line
of
halberdiers
was
drawn
up
,
while
barriers
were
erected
against
the
cross
streets
.
<EOS>
Nor
were
these
precautions
needless
.
<EOS>
Such
a
vast
concourse
was
collected
,
that
nothing
but
the
presence
of
a
strong
armed
force
could
have
prevented
confusion
and
disorder
.
<EOS>
The
roofs
of
all
the
houses
,
the
towers
of
the
churches
,
the
steps
of
the
crosses
were
covered
with
spectators
,
who
groaned
and
hooted
as
the
conspirators
passed
by
.
<EOS>
The
scaffold
,
as
has
just
been
stated
,
was
erected
in
front
of
the
great
western
entrance
of
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
The
mighty
valves
of
the
sacred
structure
were
thrown
open
,
and
disclosed
its
columned
aisles
crowded
with
spectators
,
as
was
its
roof
and
central
tower
.
<EOS>
The
great
bell
,
which
had
begun
to
toll
when
the
melancholy
procession
came
in
sight
,
continued
to
pour
forth
its
lugubrious
sounds
during
the
whole
of
the
ceremonial
.
<EOS>
The
rolling
of
muffled
drums
was
likewise
heard
above
the
tumultuous
murmurs
of
the
impatient
multitude
.
<EOS>
The
whole
area
from
the
cathedral
to
Ludgate
-
hill
was
filled
with
spectators
,
but
an
open
space
was
kept
clear
in
front
of
the
scaffold
,
in
which
the
prisoners
were
one
by
one
unbound
from
the
hurdles
.
<EOS>
During
this
awful
pause
,
they
had
sufficient
time
to
note
the
whole
of
the
dreadful
preparations
.
<EOS>
At
a
little
distance
from
them
was
a
large
fire
,
on
which
boiled
a
caldron
of
pitch
,
destined
to
receive
their
dismembered
limbs
.
<EOS>
A
tall
gallows
,
approached
by
a
double
ladder
,
sprung
from
the
scaffold
,
on
which
the
hangman
was
already
mounted
with
the
rope
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
At
the
foot
of
the
ladder
was
the
quartering
-
block
,
near
which
stood
the
masked
executioner
with
a
chopper
in
his
hand
,
and
two
large
sharp
knives
in
his
girdle
.
<EOS>
His
arms
were
bared
to
the
shoulder
;
and
a
leathern
apron
,
soiled
by
gory
stains
,
and
tied
round
his
waist
,
completed
his
butcherly
appearance
.
<EOS>
Straw
was
scattered
upon
the
scaffold
near
the
block
.
<EOS>
Sir
Everard
Digby
was
the
first
to
receive
the
fatal
summons
.
<EOS>
He
mounted
with
a
firm
footstep
,
and
his
youth
,
his
noble
aspect
,
and
undaunted
demeanour
,
awakened
,
as
before
,
the
sympathy
of
the
beholders
.
<EOS>
Looking
round
,
he
thus
addressed
the
assemblage:—"Good
people
,
I
am
here
about
to
die
,
ye
<EOS>
well
know
for
what
cause
.
<EOS>
Throughout
the
matter
,
I
have
acted
according
to
the
dictates
of
my
conscience
.
<EOS>
They
have
led
me
to
undertake
this
enterprise
,
which
,
in
respect
of
my
religion
,
I
hold
to
be
no
offence
,
but
in
respect
of
the
law
a
heinous
offence
,
and
I
therefore
ask
forgiveness
of
God
,
of
the
King
,
and
of
the
whole
realm
.
<EOS>
"Crossing
<EOS>
himself
devoutly
,
he
then
knelt
down
,
and
recited
his
prayers
in
Latin
,
after
which
he
arose
,
and
again
looking
round
,
said
in
an
earnest
voice,"I
desire
the
prayers
of
all
good
Catholics
,
and
of
none
other
.
<EOS>
""Then
<EOS>
none
will
pray
for
you
,
"
replied
several
voices
from
the
crowd
.
<EOS>
Heedless
of
the
retort
,
Sir
Everard
surrendered
himself
to
the
executioner
's
assistant
,
who
divested
him
of
his
cloak
and
doublet
,
and
unfastened
his
collar
.
<EOS>
In
this
state
,
he
mounted
the
ladder
,
and
the
hangman
fulfilled
his
office
.
<EOS>
Robert
Winter
was
next
summoned
,
and
ascended
the
scaffold
with
great
firmness
.
<EOS>
Everything
proclaimed
the
terrible
tragedy
that
had
just
been
enacted
.
<EOS>
The
straw
was
sprinkled
with
blood
,
so
was
the
block
,
so
were
the
long
knives
of
the
executioner
,
whose
hands
and
arms
were
dyed
with
the
same
crimson
stain
;
while
in
one
corner
of
the
scaffold
stood
a
basket
,
containing
the
dismembered
limbs
of
the
late
unfortunate
sufferer
.
<EOS>
But
these
dreadful
sights
produced
no
effect
on
Robert
Winter
.
<EOS>
Declining
to
address
the
assemblage
,
he
at
once
surrendered
himself
to
the
assistant
,
and
shared
the
fate
of
his
friend
.
<EOS>
Grant
was
the
next
to
follow
.
<EOS>
Undismayed
as
his
predecessor
,
he
looked
round
with
a
cheerful
countenance
,
and
said,—"I
am
about
to
suffer
the
death
of
a
traitor
,
and
am
content
to
die
so
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
satisfied
that
our
project
was
so
far
from
being
sinful
,
that
I
rely
entirely
on
my
merits
in
bearing
a
part
in
it
,
as
an
abundant
satisfaction
and
expiation
for
all
the
sins
I
have
at
other
times
of
my
life
committed
.
<EOS>
"This
<EOS>
speech
was
received
by
a
terrific
yell
from
the
multitude
.
<EOS>
Wholly
unmoved
,
however
,
Grant
uttered
a
few
prayers
,
and
then
crossing
himself
,
mounted
the
ladder
and
was
quickly
despatched
.
<EOS>
The
bloody
business
was
completed
by
the
slaughter
of
Bates
,
who
died
as
resolutely
as
the
others
.
<EOS>
These
executions
,
being
conducted
with
the
utmost
deliberation
,
occupied
nearly
an
hour
.
<EOS>
The
crowd
then
separated
to
talk
over
the
sight
they
had
witnessed
,
and
to
keep
holiday
during
the
remainder
of
the
day
;
rejoicing
that
an
equally
-
exciting
spectacle
was
in
store
for
them
on
the
morrow
.
<EOS>
XVI
.
<EOS>
—
OLD
PALACE
YARDGuy
Fawkes
's
tranquillity
of
mind
did
not
desert
him
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
as
his
term
of
life
drew
near
its
close
,
he
became
more
cheerful
and
resigned
;
his
sole
anxiety
being
that
all
should
be
speedily
terminated
.
<EOS>
When
Ipgreve
took
leave
of
him
for
the
night
,
he
threw
himself
on
his
couch
and
soon
fell
into
a
gentle
slumber
.
<EOS>
His
dreams
were
soothing
,
and
he
fancied
that
Viviana
appeared
to
him
clad
in
robes
of
snowy
whiteness
,
and
regarding
him
with
a
smiling
countenance
,
promised
that
the
gates
of
eternal
happiness
would
be
opened
to
him
on
the
morrow
.
<EOS>
Awaking
about
four
o'clock
,
he
passed
the
interval
between
that
time
and
his
summons
by
the
jailer
in
earnest
prayer
.
<EOS>
At
six
o'clock
,
Ipgreve
made
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
He
was
accompanied
by
his
daughter
,
who
had
prevailed
on
him
to
allow
her
to
take
leave
of
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
She
acquainted
Fawkes
with
all
particulars
of
the
interment
of
Viviana
,
to
which
he
listened
with
tearful
interest
.
<EOS>
"Would
<EOS>
my
remains
might
be
laid
beside
her
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
But
fate
forbids
it!""Truly
,
does
it
,
"
observed
Ipgreve
,
gruffly
;
"
unless
you
would
have
her
body
removed
to
the
