spikes
of
Whitehall
gates
.
<EOS>
"Disregarding
<EOS>
this
brutal
speech
,
which
called
a
blush
of
shame
to
the
cheeks
of
Ruth
,
Fawkes
affectionately
pressed
her
hand
,
and
said,"Do
not
forget
me
in
your
prayers
,
and
sometimes
visit
the
grave
of
Viviana
.
<EOS>
""Doubt
it
not
,
"
she
replied
,
in
accents
half
suffocated
by
grief
.
<EOS>
Fawkes
then
bade
her
farewell
,
and
followed
the
jailer
through
various
intricate
passages
,
which
brought
them
to
a
door
opening
upon
one
of
the
lower
chambers
of
the
Beauchamp
Tower
.
<EOS>
Unlocking
it
,
Ipgreve
led
the
way
up
the
circular
staircase
,
and
ushered
his
companion
into
the
large
chamber
where
Rookwood
,
Keyes
,
and
Thomas
Winter
were
already
assembled
.
<EOS>
The
morning
was
clear
,
but
frosty
,
and
bitterly
cold
;
and
when
the
lieutenant
appeared
,
Rookwood
besought
him
to
allow
them
a
fire
as
their
last
earthly
indulgence
.
<EOS>
The
request
was
peremptorily
refused
.
<EOS>
A
cup
of
hot
spiced
wine
was
,
however
,
offered
them
,
and
accepted
by
all
except
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
hour
as
on
the
previous
day
,
the
hurdles
were
brought
to
the
entrance
of
the
fortification
,
and
the
prisoners
bound
to
them
.
<EOS>
The
recorder
and
sheriffs
met
them
at
the
Middle
Tower
,
as
they
had
done
the
other
conspirators
,
and
the
cavalcade
set
forth
.
<EOS>
The
crowd
was
even
greater
than
on
the
former
occasion
;
and
it
required
the
utmost
exertion
on
the
part
of
the
guard
to
maintain
order
.
<EOS>
Some
little
delay
occurred
at
Ludgate
;
and
during
this
brief
halt
,
Rookwood
heard
a
cry
,
and
looking
up
,
perceived
his
wife
at
the
upper
window
of
one
of
the
habitations
,
waving
her
handkerchief
to
him
,
and
cheering
him
by
her
gestures
.
<EOS>
He
endeavoured
to
answer
her
by
signs
;
but
his
hands
were
fast
bound
,
and
the
next
moment
,
the
cavalcade
moved
on
.
<EOS>
At
Temple
Bar
another
halt
occurred
;
and
as
the
train
moved
slowly
forward
,
an
immense
crowd
,
like
a
swollen
stream
,
swept
after
it
.
<EOS>
The
two
gates
at
Whitehall
,
then
barring
the
road
to
Westminster
,
were
opened
as
the
train
approached
,
and
a
certain
portion
of
the
concourse
allowed
to
pass
through
.
<EOS>
The
scaffold
,
which
had
been
removed
from
Saint
Paul
's
,
was
erected
in
the
middle
of
Old
Palace
Yard
,
in
front
of
the
House
of
Lords
.
<EOS>
Around
it
were
circled
a
band
of
halberdiers
,
outside
whom
stood
a
dense
throng
.
<EOS>
The
buttresses
and
pinnacles
of
the
Abbey
were
covered
with
spectators
;
so
was
the
roof
of
the
Parliament
House
,
and
the
gallery
over
the
entrance
.
<EOS>
The
bell
of
the
Abbey
began
to
toll
as
the
train
passed
through
the
gates
of
Whitehall
,
and
its
deep
booming
filled
the
air
.
<EOS>
Just
as
the
conspirators
were
released
from
the
hurdles
,
Topcliffe
,
who
had
evidently
from
his
disordered
attire
arrived
from
a
long
journey
,
rode
up
,
and
dismounted
.
<EOS>
"I
am
just
in
time
,
"
he
cried
,
with
an
exulting
glance
at
the
conspirators
;
"
this
is
not
the
last
execution
I
shall
witness
.
<EOS>
Fathers
Garnet
and
Oldcorne
are
prisoners
,
and
on
their
way
to
London
.
<EOS>
I
was
a
long
time
in
unearthing
the
priestly
foxes
,
but
I
succeeded
at
last
.
<EOS>
"At
<EOS>
this
moment
an
officer
approached
,
and
summoned
Thomas
Winter
to
mount
the
scaffold
.
<EOS>
He
obeyed
,
and
exhibited
no
symptom
of
quailing
,
except
that
his
complexion
suddenly
turned
to
a
livid
colour
.
<EOS>
Being
told
of
this
by
the
lieutenant
,
he
tried
to
account
for
it
by
saying
that
he
thought
he
saw
his
brother
precede
him
up
the
steps
.
<EOS>
He
made
a
brief
address
,
protesting
he
died
a
true
Catholic
,
and
in
that
faith
,
notwithstanding
his
offences
,
hoped
to
be
saved
.
<EOS>
Rookwood
followed
him
,
and
indulged
in
a
somewhat
longer
oration
.
<EOS>
"
I
confess
my
offence
to
God
,
"
he
said
,
"
in
seeking
to
shed
blood
,
and
implore
his
mercy
.
<EOS>
I
likewise
confess
my
offence
to
the
King
,
of
whose
majesty
I
humbly
ask
forgiveness
;
and
I
further
confess
my
offence
to
the
whole
state
,
of
whom
in
general
I
entreat
pardon
.
<EOS>
May
the
Almighty
bless
the
King
,
the
Queen
,
and
all
their
royal
progeny
,
and
grant
them
a
long
and
happy
reign
!
<EOS>
May
He
turn
their
hearts
to
the
Catholic
faith
,
so
that
heresy
may
be
wholly
extirpated
from
the
kingdom!"The
first
part
of
this
speech
was
well
received
by
the
assemblage
,
but
the
latter
was
drowned
in
groans
and
hootings
,
amid
which
Rookwood
was
launched
into
eternity
.
<EOS>
Keyes
came
next
,
and
eyeing
the
assemblage
disdainfully
,
went
up
the
ladder
,
and
threw
himself
off
with
such
force
that
he
broke
the
rope
,
and
was
instantly
despatched
by
the
executioner
and
his
assistants
.
<EOS>
Guy
Fawkes
now
alone
remained
,
and
he
slowly
mounted
the
scaffold
.
<EOS>
His
foot
slipped
on
the
blood
-
stained
boards
,
and
he
would
have
fallen
,
if
Topcliffe
,
who
stood
near
him
,
had
not
caught
his
hand
.
<EOS>
A
deep
silence
prevailed
as
he
looked
around
,
and
uttered
the
following
words
in
a
clear
and
distinct
voice:—"I
ask
forgiveness
of
the
King
and
the
state
for
my
criminal
intention
,
and
trust
that
my
death
will
wash
out
my
offence
.
"He
<EOS>
then
crossed
himself
and
knelt
down
to
pray
,
after
which
his
cloak
and
doublet
were
removed
by
the
executioner
's
assistant
and
placed
with
those
of
the
other
conspirators
.
<EOS>
He
made
an
effort
to
mount
the
ladder
,
but
his
stiffened
limbs
refused
their
office
.
<EOS>
"Your
<EOS>
courage
fails
you
,
"
sneered
Topcliffe
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"My
<EOS>
strength
does
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
sternly
regarding
him
.
"
<EOS>
Help
me
up
the
ladder
,
and
you
shall
see
whether
I
am
afraid
to
die
.
<EOS>
"Seeing
<EOS>
how
matters
stood
,
the
executioner
who
stood
by
,
leaning
upon
his
chopper
,
tendered
him
his
blood
-
stained
hand
.
<EOS>
But
Fawkes
rejected
it
with
disgust
,
and
exerting
all
his
strength
,
forced
himself
up
the
ladder
.
<EOS>
As
the
hangman
adjusted
the
rope
,
he
observed
a
singular
smile
illumine
the
features
of
his
victim
.
<EOS>
"You
seem
happy
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"I
am
so
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Fawkes
,
earnestly,—"I
see
the
form
of
her
<EOS>
I
loved
beckoning
me
to
unfading
happiness
.
<EOS>
"With
<EOS>
this
,
he
stretched
out
his
arms
and
sprang
from
the
ladder
.
<EOS>
Before
his
frame
was
exposed
to
the
executioner
's
knife
,
life
was
totally
extinct
.
<EOS>
XVII
.
<EOS>
—
THE
LAST
EXECUTIONLittle
more
remains
to
be
told
,
and
that
little
is
of
an
equally
painful
nature
with
the
tragical
events
just
related
.
<EOS>
Fathers
Garnet
and
Oldcorne
,
together
with
Mr.
Abingdon
and
their
servants
,
arrived
in
London
on
the
12th
of
February
,
about
a
fortnight
after
the
execution
of
the
other
conspirators
.
<EOS>
They
were
first
taken
to
the
Gate
-
house
at
Westminster
,
and
were
examined
on
the
following
day
by
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
and
the
Privy
-
Council
at
the
Star
-
Chamber
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
elicited
from
them
,
and
Garnet
answered
the
Earl
's
interrogatories
with
infinite
subtlety
and
address
.
<EOS>
The
examination
over
,
they
were
ordered
to
be
removed
to
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
Topcliffe
accompanied
them
to
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
As
they
proceeded
thither
,
he
called
Garnet
's
attention
to
a
ghastly
object
stuck
on
a
spike
over
the
palace
gates
.
<EOS>
"Do
<EOS>
you
recognise
those
features
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
.
<EOS>
"No
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
shudderingly
averting
his
gaze
.
<EOS>
"I
am
surprised
to
hear
it
,
"
rejoined
Topcliffe
,
"
for
they
were
once
well
known
to
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
head
of
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
Of
all
the
conspirators
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
bitter
laugh
,
"
he
was
the
only
one
who
died
truly
penitent
.
<EOS>
It
is
reported
that
this
happy
change
was
wrought
in
him
by
Viviana
Radcliffe
.
<EOS>
""Heaven
have
mercy
upon
his
soul
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
Garnet
.
<EOS>
"I
will
tell
you
a
strange
tale
about
Catesby
,
"
pursued
Topcliffe
.
"
<EOS>
He
was
buried
in
the
garden
at
Holbeach
with
Percy
,
but
an
order
was
sent
down
by
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
to
have
their
bodies
disinterred
and
quartered
.
<EOS>
When
Catesby
's
head
was
severed
from
the
trunk
,
to
be
set
on
the
gates
of
Warwick
,
fresh
blood
spouted
forth
,
as
if
life
were
in
the
veins
.
<EOS>
""You
<EOS>
do
not
expect
me
to
believe
this
idle
story
?
"
said
Garnet
,
incredulously
.
<EOS>
"Believe
<EOS>
it
or
not
,
as
you
please
,
"
returned
Topcliffe
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
On
arriving
at
the
fortress
,
Garnet
was
lodged
in
the
large
chamber
of
the
Beauchamp
Tower
,
and
allowed
the
attendance
of
his
servant
,
Nicholas
Owen
,
while
Oldcorne
was
equally
well
accommodated
in
the
Constable
Tower
.
<EOS>
This
leniency
was
the
result
of
the
policy
of
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
who
hoped
to
obtain
disclosures
from
the
two
Jesuit
priests
which
would
enable
him
to
strike
the
decisive
blow
he
meditated
against
the
Papists
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
unsuccessful
.
<EOS>
They
refused
to
make
any
confessions
which
would
criminate
themselves
,
or
implicate
others
;
and
as
none
of
the
conspirators
,
not
even
Tresham
,
had
admitted
their
connexion
with
the
plot
,
it
was
difficult
to
find
proof
against
them
.
<EOS>
Garnet
underwent
daily
examinations
from
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
and
the
commissioners
,
but
he
baffled
all
their
inquiries
.
<EOS>
"If
we
can
not
wring
the
truth
from
you
by
fair
means
,
Mr.
Garnet
,
"
said
Salisbury
,
"
we
must
have
recourse
to
torture
.
<EOS>
""Minare
<EOS>
ista
pueris
,
"
replied
Garnet
,
contemptuously
.
<EOS>
"Leave
<EOS>
these
two
priests
to
me
,
my
lord
,
"
observed
Sir
William
Waad
,
who
was
present
at
the
examination
,
which
took
place
at
the
council
-
chamber
in
his
lodgings,—"leave
them
to
me
,
"
he
said
in
a
low
voice
to
the
Earl
,
"
and
I
will
engage
to
procure
a
full
confession
from
their
own
lips
,
without
resorting
to
torture
.
<EOS>
""You
will
render
the
state
an
important
service
by
doing
so
,
"
replied
Salisbury
,
in
the
same
tone
.
<EOS>
"
I
place
the
matter
entirely
in
your
hands
.
<EOS>
"The
<EOS>
lieutenant
set
to
work
without
loss
of
time
.
<EOS>
By
his
directions
,
Garnet
and
Oldcorne
were
removed
from
their
present
places
of
confinement
to
two
subterranean
cells
immediately
adjoining
each
other
,
but
between
which
a
secret
recess
,
contrived
in
the
thickness
of
the
wall
,
and
built
for
the
purpose
it
was
subsequently
put
to
,
existed
.
<EOS>
Two
days
after
they
had
been
so
immured
,
Ipgreve
,
who
had
received
his
instructions
,
loitered
for
a
moment
in
Oldcorne
's
cell
,
and
with
affected
hesitation
informed
him
that
for
a
trifling
reward
he
would
enable
him
to
hold
unreserved
communication
with
his
fellow
-
prisoner
.
<EOS>
Oldcorne
eagerly
caught
at
the
bait
,
but
required
to
be
satisfied
that
the
jailer
could
make
good
his
words
.
<EOS>
Ipgreve
immediately
proceeded
to
the
side
of
the
cell
,
and
holding
a
lamp
to
the
wall
,
showed
him
a
small
iron
knob
.
"Touch
<EOS>
this
spring
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
a
stone
will
fall
from
its
place
,
and
enable
you
to
converse
with
Father
Garnet
,
who
is
in
the
next
cell
.
<EOS>
But
you
must
take
care
to
replace
the
stone
when
any
one
approaches
.
<EOS>
"Promising
to
observe
the
utmost
caution
,
and
totally
unsuspicious
of
the
deceit
practised
upon
him
,
Oldcorne
gave
Ipgreve
the
reward
,
and
as
soon
as
he
was
gone
,
touched
the
spring
,
and
found
it
act
precisely
as
the
jailer
had
stated
.
<EOS>
Garnet
was
greatly
surprised
to
hear
the
other
's
voice
,
and
on
learning
how
the
communication
was
managed
was
at
first
suspicious
of
some
stratagem
,
but
by
degrees
his
fears
wore
off
,
and
he
became
unreserved
in
his
discourse
with
his
companion
,
discussing
the
fate
of
the
conspirators
,
their
own
share
in
the
plot
,
the
probability
of
their
acquittal
,
and
the
best
means
of
baffling
their
examiners
.
<EOS>
All
these
interlocutions
were
overheard
and
taken
down
by
the
lieutenant
and
two
other
witnesses
,
Forsett
and
Lockerson
,
private
secretary
to
the
Earl
of
Salisbury
,
who
were
concealed
in
the
recess
.
<EOS>
Having
obtained
all
the
information
he
desired
,
Sir
William
Waad
laid
his
notes
before
the
Council
,
and
their
own
confessions
being
read
to
the
priests
,
they
were
both
greatly
confused
,
though
neither
would
admit
their
authenticity
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
their
two
servants
,
Owen
and
Chambers
,
had
been
repeatedly
examined
,
and
refusing
to
confess
,
were
at
last
suspended
from
a
beam
by
the
thumbs
.
<EOS>
But
this
producing
no
result
,
they
were
told
that
on
the
following
day
they
would
be
placed
on
the
rack
.
<EOS>
Chambers
then
offered
to
make
a
full
confession
,
but
Owen
,
continuing
obstinate
,
was
conveyed
back
to
his
cell
.
<EOS>
Ipgreve
brought
him
his
food
as
usual
in
the
evening
,
and
on
this
occasion
,
it
consisted
of
broth
,
and
a
small
allowance
of
meat
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
custom
of
the
jailer
to
bring
with
him
a
small
blunt
-
pointed
knife
,
with
which
he
allowed
the
prisoner
to
cut
his
victuals
.
<EOS>
Having
got
possession
of
the
knife
,
Owen
tasted
the
broth
,
and
complaining
that
it
was
quite
cold
,
he
implored
the
jailer
to
get
it
warmed
for
him
,
as
he
felt
extremely
unwell
.
<EOS>
Somewhat
moved
by
his
entreaties
,
and
more
by
his
appearance
,
Ipgreve
complied
.
<EOS>
On
his
return
,
he
found
the
unfortunate
man
lying
in
one
corner
of
the
cell
,
partially
covered
by
a
heap
of
straw
which
ordinarily
formed
his
bed
.
<EOS>
"Here
is
your
broth
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Take
it
while
it
is
hot
.
<EOS>
I
shall
give
myself
no
further
trouble
about
you
.
<EOS>
""It
will
not
be
needed
,
"
gasped
Owen
.
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
the
sound
of
his
voice
,
Ipgreve
held
the
light
towards
him
,
and
perceived
that
his
face
was
pale
as
death
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
he
remarked
that
the
floor
was
covered
with
blood
.
<EOS>
Instantly
divining
the
truth
,
the
jailer
rushed
towards
the
wretched
man
,
and
dragging
away
the
blood
-
stained
straw
,
found
he
had
inflicted
a
frightful
wound
upon
himself
with
the
knife
which
he
still
held
in
his
grasp
.
<EOS>
"Fool
that
I
was
,
to
trust
you
with
the
weapon
!
"
cried
Ipgreve
.
"
<EOS>
But
who
would
have
thought
it
could
inflict
<EOS>
a
mortal
wound?""Any
weapon
will
serve
him
who
is
resolved
to
die
,
"
rejoined
Owen
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
put
me
on
the
rack
now
.
"
<EOS>
And
with
a
ghastly
expression
of
triumph
,
he
expired
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
,
Oldcorne
and
Abingdon
were
sent
down
to
Worcester
,
where
the
former
was
tried
and
executed
.
<EOS>
Stephen
Littleton
suffered
death
at
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
On
Friday
,
the
23rd
of
March
,
full
proofs
being
obtained
against
him
,
Garnet
was
arraigned
of
high
treason
at
Guildhall
.
<EOS>
The
trial
,
which
excited
extraordinary
interest
,
was
attended
by
the
King
,
by
the
most
distinguished
personages
,
male
and
female
,
of
his
court
,
and
by
all
the
foreign
ambassadors
.
<EOS>
Garnet
conducted
himself
throughout
his
arraignment
,
which
lasted
for
thirteen
hours
,
with
the
same
courage
and
address
which
he
had
displayed
on
his
examinations
before
the
commissioners
.
<EOS>
But
his
subtlety
availed
him
little
.
<EOS>
He
was
found
guilty
and
condemned
.
<EOS>
The
execution
of
the
sentence
was
for
some
time
deferred
,
it
being
hoped
that
a
complete
admission
of
his
guilt
would
be
obtained
from
him
,
together
with
disclosures
relative
to
the
designs
of
the
Jesuit
party
.
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
the
examinations
were
still
continued
,
but
the
rigour
with
which
he
had
been
latterly
treated
was
relaxed
.
<EOS>
A
few
days
before
his
execution
,
he
was
visited
by
several
eminent
Protestant
Divines,—Doctor
Montague
,
Dean
of
the
Chapel
Royal
;
Doctor
Neile
,
Dean
of
Westminster
;
and
Doctor
Overall
,
Dean
of
Saint
Paul
's
;
with
whom
he
had
a
long
disputation
on
points
of
faith
and
other
spiritual
matters
.
<EOS>
At
the
close
of
this
discussion
,
Doctor
Overall
remarked
,
"
I
suppose
you
expect
,
Mr.
Garnet
,
that
after
your
death
,
the
Church
of
Rome
will
declare
you
a
martyr?""I
a
martyr
!
"
exclaimed
Garnet
,
sorrowfully
.
"
<EOS>
O
what
a
martyr
I
should
be
!
<EOS>
If
,
indeed
,
I
were
really
about
to
suffer
death
for
the
Catholic
religion
,
and
had
never
known
of
this
project
,
except
by
means
of
sacramental
confession
,
I
might
perhaps
be
accounted
worthy
the
honour
of
martyrdom
,
and
might
deservedly
be
glorified
in
the
opinion
of
our
church
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
I
acknowledge
myself
to
have
sinned
in
this
respect
,
and
deny
not
the
justice
of
the
sentence
passed
upon
me
.
<EOS>
"Satisfied
<EOS>
,
at
length
,
that
no
further
disclosures
could
be
obtained
from
him
,
the
King
signed
the
warrant
for
his
execution
on
the
2nd
of
May
.
<EOS>
The
scaffold
was
erected
at
the
west
end
of
Saint
Paul
's
Cathedral
,
on
the
spot
where
Digby
and
the
other
conspirators
had
suffered
.
<EOS>
A
vast
assemblage
was
collected
as
on
the
former
occasion
,
and
similar
precautions
were
taken
to
prevent
tumult
and
disturbance
.
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
man
's
torture
was
cruelly
and
unnecessarily
prolonged
by
a
series
of
questions
proposed
to
him
on
the
scaffold
by
Doctor
Overall
and
the
Dean
of
Westminster
,
all
of
which
he
answered
very
collectedly
and
clearly
.
<EOS>
He
maintained
his
fortitude
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
When
fully
prepared
,
he
mounted
the
ladder
,
and
thus
addressed
the
assemblage:—"I
commend
myself
to
all
good
Catholics
.
<EOS>
I
grieve
that
I
have
offended
the
King
by
not
revealing
the
design
entertained
against
him
,
and
that
I
did
not
use
more
diligence
in
preventing
the
execution
of
the
plot
.
<EOS>
I
commend
myself
most
humbly
to
the
lords
of
his
Majesty
's
council
,
and
entreat
them
not
to
judge
too
hardly
by
me
.
<EOS>
I
beseech
all
men
that
Catholics
may
not
fare
the
worse
for
my
sake
,
and
I
exhort
all
Catholics
to
take
care
not
to
mix
themselves
with
seditious
or
traitorous
designs
against
the
King
's
Majesty
,
whom
God
preserve!"Making
the
sign
of
the
cross
upon
his
forehead
and
breast
,
he
continued:"In
nomine
Patris
,
Filii
,
et
Spiritûs
Sancti
!
<EOS>
Jesus
Maria
!
<EOS>
Maria
,
mater
gratiæ
!
<EOS>
mater
misericordiæ
!
<EOS>
Tu
me
ab
hoste
protege
,
et
horâ
mortis
suscipe
!
<EOS>
In
manus
tuas
,
Domine
,
commendo
spiritum
meum
,
quia
tu
redimisti
me
,
Domine
,
Deus
veritatis
.
"
<EOS>
Again
crossing
himself
,
he
added,—"Per
crucis
hoc
signum
fugiat
procul
omne
malignum
!
<EOS>
Infige
crucem
tuam
,
Domine
,
in
corde
meo!"And
with
this
last
pathetic
ejaculation
he
threw
himself
from
the
ladder
.
<EOS>
Garnet
obtained
,
after
death
,
the
distinction
he
had
disclaimed
while
living
.
<EOS>
He
was
enrolled
,
together
with
Oldcorne
,
among
the
list
of
Catholic
martyrs
.
<EOS>
Several
miracles
are
affirmed
by
the
Jesuits
to
have
been
performed
in
his
behalf
.
<EOS>
Father
More
relates
that
on
the
lawn
at
Hendlip
,
where
he
and
Oldcorne
last
set
foot
,
"
a
new
and
hitherto
unknown
species
of
grass
sprang
up
into
the
exact
shape
of
an
imperial
crown
,
and
remained
for
a
long
time
without
being
trodden
down
by
the
feet
of
passengers
,
or
eaten
up
by
the
cattle
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
further
asserted
that
a
spring
of
oil
burst
forth
at
the
west
end
of
Saint
Paul
's
Cathedral
on
the
precise
spot
where
he
suffered
.
<EOS>
But
the
most
singular
prodigy
is
that
recounted
by
Endæmon
Joannes
,
who
affirms
that
in
a
straw
which
had
been
sprinkled
with
Garnet
's
blood
,
a
human
countenance
,
strangely
resembling
that
of
the
martyr
,
was
discovered
.
<EOS>
This
legend
of
the
Miraculous
Straw
,
having
received
many
embellishments
and
improvements
as
it
travelled
abroad
,
obtained
universal
credence
,
and
was
conceived
to
fully
establish
Garnet
's
innocence
.
<EOS>
Anne
Vaux
,
the
Jesuit
's
devoted
friend
,
retired
with
her
sister
,
Mrs.
Brooksby
,
to
a
nunnery
in
Flanders
,
where
she
ended
her
days
.
<EOS>
So
terminated
the
memorable
and
never
-
to
-
be
-
forgotten
Gunpowder
Treason
,
for
deliverance
from
which
our
church
still
offers
thanksgivings
,
and
in
remembrance
of
which
,
on
the
anniversary
of
its
discovery
,
fagots
are
collected
and
bonfires
lighted
to
consume
the
effigy
of
the
arch
-
conspirator
,
Guy
Fawkes
.
